Title: Five Things Libertarians Should Be Nervous About in 2017

As the year 2016 comes to a close, many individuals are looking forward to the new year with a mix of hope and trepidation. For libertarians, there are several developments that may cause concern in 2017. Despite Donald Trump's comments on legalization being up to the states, his appointments to key positions in his cabinet, such as Senator Jeff Sessions, have raised concerns about the future of marijuana legalization. Sessions has been a vocal opponent of legalization and has criticized the Obama administration for not enforcing federal marijuana laws.

The national debt is also expected to continue growing under Trump's presidency, with estimates suggesting an additional $5.3 trillion in debt over the next four years. This could have significant implications for the economy and the country's financial stability.

The trend of questioning the value of free markets and globalization is also a cause for concern. The new administration's promises to inject itself into the affairs of private companies and Trump's threats of a costly trade war with China could have far-reaching consequences for the economy and international relations.

Additionally, the rise of "fake news" has led to concerns about censorship and the potential for government overreach. Facebook is testing new plugins to limit misinformation and partnering with fact-checking groups, which has raised fears of government control over online content.

Finally, the FBI, NSA, and CIA are likely to gain expanded surveillance powers under the Trump administration. A new rule approved this fall allows federal agents to hack millions of Americans' computers or smartphones with a single search warrant, and the UK has approved a bill giving its surveillance program the power to create a database storing the web history of every citizen.

These developments have the potential to significantly impact individual freedoms and the country's economic and social landscape. As the year 2017 begins, libertarians may want to keep a close eye on these trends and developments.

Title: Trump and Macron Engage in Tense Exchange Over ISIS Fighters and NATO

President Donald Trump and French President Emmanuel Macron engaged in a tense exchange on Tuesday in London, with Trump asking Macron if he would like to take back "some nice ISIS fighters" and later criticizing Macron's comments on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO). The exchange came hours after Trump criticized Macron's statement that the alliance was experiencing "brain death" due to recent US troop withdrawals in Syria.

Trump asked Macron if he would like to take back ISIS fighters from Europe captured in Syria, saying, "I can give them to you, you can take every one you want." Macron responded by urging Trump to "be serious" and calling for a broader push against ISIS overall. Trump then took a swipe at Macron's answer, saying it was one of the "greatest non-answers" he had ever heard.

The exchange was part of a broader discussion on NATO, with Trump criticizing Macron's comments on the alliance's effectiveness. Macron had told The Economist magazine that the alliance was experiencing "brain death" due to the US withdrawal of troops from northeastern Syria. Trump responded by saying that Macron's statement was "very, very nasty" and that the US was helping Europe unite against a common foe.

The two leaders also discussed defense spending, with Macron urging Trump to push for more contributions from European allies. Trump noted that the US had "overinvested" in defense and that he was working to get other countries to contribute more. Macron also called for a stronger European component in NATO and warned against putting too much emphasis on the cost, rather than the overall strategy.

Another point of contention between the two leaders was Macron's recent decision to impose a French digital services tax on American companies, including Facebook, Google, and Twitter. The White House has announced that the tax will be met with tariffs of up to 100% on $2.4 billion worth of French products. Trump expressed his disapproval of the tax, saying that he did not want France taxing American companies.

The exchange between Trump and Macron came as the two leaders met on the sidelines of a NATO summit in London. The summit is expected to focus on issues such as defense spending and terrorism.

Title: Trump's Actions Weaken Global Response to Pandemics, Leaving the US Vulnerable to Future Outbreaks

The article discusses the potential consequences of the United States' withdrawal from the World Health Organization (WHO) and its impact on the global response to pandemics. The author highlights that the move will not only harm the WHO but also further diminish the US' international standing. The article also explores the possibility of a second respiratory virus emerging and how the US' response to the current pandemic has left the country vulnerable to future outbreaks.

The article quotes experts, including Loyce Pace, the president of the Global Health Council, and Sarah Cobey, an immunologist at the University of Chicago, who emphasize the importance of international cooperation and individual vigilance in preventing the spread of diseases. The article also mentions the development of a "multiplex" test that could detect multiple respiratory viruses, including COVID-19, flu, and RSV, in a single nasal swab.

The article notes that countries like South Korea, New Zealand, and Germany have successfully controlled COVID-19, while others like the US, Brazil, Russia, and India are struggling. The author suggests that a new respiratory virus could spread undetected in these countries, as resources are already stretched and overwhelmed by the current pandemic.

Overall, the article presents a neutral and factual account of the potential consequences of the US' withdrawal from the WHO and the importance of international cooperation in responding to pandemics.

Title: The Decline of San Francisco: A City in Crisis

The once-thriving city of San Francisco, known for its breathtaking views, delectable food, and vibrant jazz scene, has undergone a significant transformation. Today, it is home to an army of homeless individuals, with some of the dirtiest slums in America. The city's streets, once bustling with activity, are now littered with human feces and needles.

The author, Lee Edwards, a Distinguished Fellow in Conservative Thought at The Heritage Foundation, reflects on his first visit to San Francisco in 1964, when he was part of Barry Goldwater's political team. At that time, the city was a hub of excitement and optimism, with delegates and guests attending the Republican presidential nomination at the Cow Palace. In contrast, today's San Francisco is a city in crisis, with homeless individuals openly urinating in public and needles scattered throughout the streets.

Edwards attributes the decline of San Francisco to the influence of liberal ideologies, particularly the philosophy of John Rawls, who argues that everything is relative and there is no absolute right or wrong. This philosophy has led to a shift away from the traditional values of the Founding Fathers, who believed in a system of checks and balances to limit the role of government.

The author notes that the rising generation prioritizes gay rights over other rights, and views Washington as responsible for their welfare, with socialism seen as the wave of the future. Edwards believes that this shift away from traditional values has contributed to the decline of San Francisco and the erosion of the common rules of a civil society.

In contrast, Dallas, Texas, is presented as a city that embodies the values of optimism, hard work, and community, with its residents excited about the future. The author concludes that Dallas, not San Francisco, is the future, unless the citizens of San Francisco take steps to reclaim their city.

Title: Research Suggests Moral Disapproval Drives Opposition to Same-Sex Marriage

The debate surrounding same-sex marriage has been a contentious issue in the United States, with proponents and opponents presenting various arguments to support their stance. A recent study by Indiana University sociologist Brian Powell suggests that moral disapproval is the primary motivator behind opposition to same-sex marriage. Powell's research, published in the journal Social Currents, surveyed hundreds of people across the nation and found that the majority of those opposed to same-sex marriage cited religious beliefs as the reason for their stance.

The study's findings have implications for the legal debate surrounding same-sex marriage. Powell argues that if public opinion drives public policy, the real motivation behind bans on same-sex marriage is moral disapproval, which could be unconstitutional. This notion is supported by legal experts, who argue that laws driven by moral disapproval can be seen as discriminatory and unconstitutional.

The concept of "animus" has become a key term in the legal debate. Animus refers to the idea that a law has no compelling public interest and is driven solely by moral disapproval, causing harm to a group viewed as inferior. Same-sex marriage proponents argue that denying them the right to marry is unconstitutional and perpetuates harm.

Indiana Family Institute's Curt Smith disagrees, stating that the notion of animus is an unfair characterization of those who support same-sex marriage bans. He believes that public policy considerations, such as the benefits of traditional marriage, are the driving force behind opposition.

The debate is set to continue as the Supreme Court prepares to hear the case, with some arguing that the public policy arguments are flimsy and others maintaining that they are valid. The 6th Circuit Court of Appeals has upheld same-sex marriage bans, while other circuits have deemed them unconstitutional.

The research by Powell and others highlights the complexities of the issue and the need for continued discussion and debate. As public opinion continues to evolve, it remains to be seen how the legal landscape will shape up in the coming years.

Title: Norway's Paternity Leave Policy May Hold Key to Reducing Gender Wage Gap

Article:

Norway's unique approach to paternity leave has led to a significant reduction in the country's gender wage gap. In the early 1990s, Norway introduced four weeks of mandatory paternity leave for its workers, which has since been increased to 10 weeks. This policy has not only changed cultural attitudes towards child-rearing, but also had an economic side effect. The country's gender wage gap has shrunk by more than half, with working women in Norway making about 8.3% less than men in 2010, compared to 20% less in 1991.

The idea of supporting women at home being linked to supporting them in the workplace is gaining traction in the US, particularly on Equal Pay Day, which is observed on April 12. Advocates for gender equality are making the case that more investment in child care could help shrink the pay gap, with the added bonus of growing the economy. According to an analysis from the Economic Policy Institute, access to affordable child care would help increase the participation of women in the labor force, thereby growing the economy by an estimated $210 billion each year.

The gender wage gap in the US is a persistent issue, with women making 79 cents for every dollar earned by white men, and worse for women of color. The National Partnership for Women & Families reports that this shortfall costs American women a combined $500 billion annually. If the gap were eliminated, a working woman in the US would have enough money for approximately 83 more weeks of food for her family, seven more months of mortgage and utilities payments, 11 more months of rent, or nine more years of birth control.

While there have been small but promising movements on family leave, there are still obstacles to overcome. Only 13% of US workers have access to any paid leave, and there is a mismatch between states with the most need and those that have taken action. However, some major tech companies have introduced competitive and inclusive paid-leave allowances for employees, and there is a growing recognition of the importance of supporting working families.

Investments in child care are also crucial, with 33 states having infant care costs more than in-state college tuition. However, there is a long-term benefit for businesses as well, as it contributes to workplace retention and helps women stay employed, reducing turnover costs.

Title: The New York Times Defends Tech Writer Sarah Jeong Amid Controversy Over Derogatory Tweets

The New York Times has come under fire for its decision to stand by tech writer Sarah Jeong, despite her past tweets containing derogatory comments about white people. Jeong's tweets, which date back to 2014, included statements such as "I get joy out of being cruel to old white men" and the use of the hashtag #CancelWhitePeople. The tweets were unearthed after the Times announced Jeong's hiring.

Conservative columnist Daniella Greenbaum has criticized the Times' decision, stating that the issue is not about whether Jeong's tweets were racist, but rather about the hypocrisy of the situation. Greenbaum, who has faced her own backlash for her conservative views, notes that if Jeong's tweets were swapped with those of a different group, such as black, Mexican, or Jewish people, the conversation would likely be very different.

Greenbaum, who resigned from her job at Business Insider after her own article defending Scarlett Johansson's decision to play a transgender man was removed, believes that the media industry has created an enormous, hypocritical double standard. She notes that many liberal media members, including HuffPost Editor-in-Chief Lydia Polgreen and leadership at The Verge, have defended Jeong's rhetoric.

Media Research Center analyst Kristine Marsh has also criticized the Times' decision, calling it "laughable" and stating that the paper justified Jeong's racist tweets. Some social media users have also blasted the paper's decision on Twitter.

The New York Times defended Jeong in a statement, saying that she was hired due to her exceptional work and that she was responding to online harassment by imitating the rhetoric of her harassers.

Title: Romney Reveals He Paid at Least 13% in Taxes Over the Past 10 Years

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, has revealed that he paid at least 13% in taxes over the past 10 years. This information was shared during an appearance in South Carolina, where Romney addressed the ongoing demands for him to release his tax returns. Romney has already released his 2010 tax returns, which showed an effective federal tax rate of 13.9%. He has promised to release his 2011 returns before the election.

Romney's statement came in response to claims made by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Democrat, that an unnamed source told him Romney paid no taxes over the past decade. Romney denied this claim, stating that he has paid taxes every year for the past 10 years, with the most recent year being 13.6%. Romney emphasized that he has fulfilled his legal obligation to pay taxes and has no intention of releasing more tax records.

The Obama campaign has called for Romney to release more tax records, citing concerns about his secrecy and the potential for him to have paid a lower rate than he claims. Romney's wife, Ann, also addressed the issue, stating that the couple has been transparent about what is legally required of them and will not be releasing any more tax information.

It is worth noting that Romney is under no legal requirement to release more tax records, and only one other presidential candidate or presumptive nominee has released fewer than six years of returns in the past 30 years, according to PolitiFact.

Title: Justice Department Faces Criticism Over IRS Targeting Scandal Investigation

The Justice Department is facing mounting criticism over its investigation into the IRS targeting scandal, with officials stating that they have found no evidence to warrant criminal charges. The news has sparked outrage among conservatives, who are calling the investigation a "sham" and questioning the motives behind the decision.

The FBI investigation into the IRS targeting of Tea Party and other groups is still ongoing, but officials have said that criminal charges are not expected at this point. The investigation was launched in response to allegations that the IRS singled out conservative groups for additional scrutiny as they sought tax-exempt status.

Jenny Beth Martin, co-founder of the Tea Party Patriots, called the news "absolutely outrageous" and questioned the motives behind the decision. "It only leads us to the point where we can make guesses about their motives," she said. "Why are they protecting the IRS? Why aren't they getting to the bottom of it?"

Martin believes that the administration is attempting to sweep the scandal under the rug and that there is a cover-up. "They wanted to silence us and they have done what they can to silence us," she said. "We're not going away, but they've done everything they can to make it difficult for us if not impossible at times to exercise our First Amendment rights."

The controversy has also raised questions about the involvement of the woman leading the FBI probe, who is a President Obama donor. Republicans have urged the Justice Department to take her off the case, but to no avail.

The investigation has been criticized for its lack of transparency and accountability. The toughest action taken by President Obama was the resignation of Acting IRS Commissioner Steven Miller last May, but a source told Fox News that Miller was set to resign the following month anyway. Other lower-level officials have faced discipline or left the administration, but the circumstances were unclear.

Jay Sekulow, chief counsel with the American Center for Law and Justice, called the investigation a "sham." "To reach a conclusion that no criminal charges will be filed against those responsible for this illegal targeting scheme without interviewing any of our clients - the real victims in this ordeal - is absolutely absurd," he said.

Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, questioned how sources could be discussing the likelihood of criminal charges when the probe is not even finished. "These are serious matters - but to make this decision before the investigation is completed seems entirely out of order and inappropriate," he said.

The Wall Street Journal first reported that criminal charges were unlikely, unless investigators discover evidence that dramatically changes their viewpoint. Sources separately told Fox News that the investigation is still ongoing, but that they have turned up no evidence yet to support criminal charges.

Title: Radio Host Sean Hannity Discusses Latest WikiLeaks Revelations and Media Bias

Radio host Sean Hannity recently discussed the latest revelations from WikiLeaks on his show, stating that the information confirms many conspiracy theories that have been circulating about Hillary Clinton's campaign. According to Hannity, the leaks reveal that Clinton knew Saudi Arabia and Qatar were funding ISIS, as well as her desire for a hemispheric common market, open trade, and open borders.

Hannity also accused the media of being biased and conspiring against Trump, citing examples of CNN, the New York Times, CNBC, and the Boston Globe releasing debate questions to Hillary Clinton ahead of time. He compared this to Communist propaganda in the Soviet Union, stating that it's "sad but true" and "the world you live in."

Hannity also touched on the idea of a "Republican establishment," "Democratic establishment," "media establishment," "globalist," "lobbyist," and "UN establishment" working together to shape public opinion and manipulate the narrative. He believes that this is a coordinated effort to undermine Trump's campaign and create a false narrative.

It's worth noting that the accuracy of the polls is also a topic of discussion, with Hannity stating that the recent polls do not reflect the latest WikiLeaks revelations and are biased against Trump.

Title: Biden Opens 9-Point Lead Over Trump in Senate Battlegrounds: Poll

Article:

A recent poll conducted by Hart Research Associates has found that former Vice President Joe Biden has opened a 9-point lead over President Trump in six states where Republican senators face difficult reelection battles this fall. The survey, conducted on behalf of the Democracy For All 2021 Action campaign, polled 805 likely voters in Arizona, Colorado, Iowa, Maine, Montana, and North Carolina.

The poll found that Biden leads Trump 50-41 among voters in these states, with Democratic challengers leading Republican incumbents by a margin of 46-41. Republicans currently hold 53 seats in the Senate, meaning Democrats need to flip four seats to win back a majority.

The survey also found broad support for voting by mail, with 85% of voters in the six battlegrounds saying there should be a mail option due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Eighty-three percent of voters said they support congressional action to expand access to mail balloting, including 67% of Trump supporters. There is near-universal support for mail balloting among Democrats.

The poll also found that 56% of voters who said they plan to support the GOP senator up for reelection said the incumbent should support a vote-by-mail option. If the GOP senator opposed legislation to expand mail-in balloting, 62% of voters said they would view the decision unfavorably, and 90% said they believe the decision would have been driven by politics.

The survey also found that 59% of voters overall said they do not believe that mail-in balloting is subject to fraud or corruption. The Hart Research survey has a 3.5 percentage point margin of error.

Title: Concerns Over Free Speech on University Campuses: A Conservative Student's Experience

Article:

A recent article highlights the concerns over free speech on university campuses, specifically at the University of California, Berkeley. The author, a conservative student, shares their personal experiences of being harassed, stalked, and intimidated by left-wing activists, known as Antifa, during their time at UC Berkeley. The author recounts a specific incident in 2017 where they were chased by a mob of masked, black-clad individuals who threw bricks at police officers, launched Molotov cocktails, and set fires.

The author notes that while there is much attention focused on violence and threats against minorities on college campuses, there is little recognition of the harassment and intimidation faced by campus conservatives. They highlight the university's inaction in addressing these incidents and the lack of consequences for the perpetrators.

The article also mentions the cancellation of several conservative speakers, including Milo Yiannopoulos, Ann Coulter, David Horowitz, and Ben Shapiro, due to safety concerns. The author notes that the university has locked arms with left-wing activists to shut down events and that the campus has become a hostile environment for conservative students.

The author encourages donors to major universities to reconsider their financial support if the institutions do not respect free expression. They also suggest that state legislatures have been quick to pass free-speech legislation, but that a solution to the problem lies with ordinary citizens like themselves.

The article concludes by warning that if these trends continue, universities will become violent echo chambers where intellectualism expires and Marxist dogma goes unchallenged.

Title: Republican Governors Explore Medicaid Changes as Alternative to Block Grants

Article:

A group of Republican governors, who have long been critical of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), are now exploring alternative ways to reform Medicaid, a key component of the healthcare law. Governors Rick Scott of Florida and John Kasich of Ohio, who had previously accepted parts of the ACA, are leading the charge. They are seeking to use Medicaid funds to buy private health insurance plans for low-income individuals, rather than expanding the program as originally intended.

The governors' efforts are seen as a response to the Obama administration's reluctance to grant block grants to states, which would give them greater control over Medicaid spending and structure. Instead, the governors are pushing for greater autonomy and flexibility in how they manage Medicaid, which could include using private insurance exchanges.

The move is seen as a significant shift in the Republican Party's stance on healthcare, as it marks a departure from the party's long-standing opposition to the ACA. The governors' willingness to explore alternative solutions is also seen as a response to the growing pressure to expand Medicaid and cover millions of uninsured Americans.

The governors' proposals are still in the negotiation stage, and it is unclear whether they will ultimately be successful. However, the fact that they are even exploring alternative solutions is a significant development, as it marks a shift away from the party's previous opposition to the ACA.

The trend is evident in Pennsylvania, where Republican Governor Tom Corbett recently met with Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius to discuss a potential deal. Other states, including Ohio, Tennessee, and Arkansas, have also shown interest in similar proposals.

The Oklahoma governor's office has also expressed interest in exploring alternative solutions, with Governor Mary Fallin's spokesman noting that the state is interested in pursuing a solution that addresses Oklahoma's healthcare needs. The state has contracted with a consulting firm to explore its options, including the possibility of using private insurance exchanges.

The development is seen as a significant shift in the healthcare landscape, as it marks a departure from the party's previous opposition to the ACA. While the outcome is still uncertain, the fact that Republican governors are exploring alternative solutions is a significant development in the ongoing debate over healthcare reform.

Title: Democratic Party Divided: Clinton and Warren Criticize Sanders' Leadership and Record

The Democratic Party is facing internal divisions as Hillary Clinton and Senator Elizabeth Warren have publicly criticized Senator Bernie Sanders' leadership and record, sparking concerns about the party's unity and ability to defeat the current Republican administration. Clinton, a former presidential candidate and Sanders' 2016 rival, described Sanders as a "nasty man" who has a "misogynistic" campaign and lacks the temperament to be president. Warren, another prominent Democratic leader, has accused Sanders of denying her the opportunity to become the first female president.

The criticism comes as Sanders is gaining momentum in the 2020 presidential race, with strong showings in Iowa, New Hampshire, and Nevada. Clinton and Warren's attacks have sparked a heated debate within the party, with some supporters of Sanders accusing them of trying to undermine his campaign. The tension has also raised questions about the party's ability to come together and present a united front against the current Republican administration.

The Democratic Party is known for its diversity and inclusivity, but the current divisions have exposed deep-seated differences within the party. The rival claims of different constituent groups, including African Americans, Hispanics, and women, are rising to the fore, and the party's focus is shifting from unity to who should replace Trump.

The debate has also highlighted the party's internal struggles, with some members questioning Sanders' leadership and record. Clinton and Warren's criticism has sparked a heated debate within the party, with some supporters of Sanders accusing them of trying to undermine his campaign. The tension has also raised questions about the party's ability to come together and present a united front against the current Republican administration.

In conclusion, the Democratic Party is facing internal divisions and deep-seated differences within the party, which could impact its ability to come together and present a united front against the current Republican administration.

Title: US Confirms $400 Million Cash Payment to Iran Used as "Leverage" for American Prisoner Release

The Obama administration has confirmed that the $400 million cash payment to Iran in January was used as "leverage" to secure the release of American prisoners, sparking criticism that the exchange amounted to the US paying a ransom. State Department spokesman John Kirby made the statement at a news briefing, saying that the US refused to allow Iran to take possession of the cash until a plane carrying the freed Americans had taken off from Tehran.

Kirby acknowledged that the cash payment was contingent on the prisoner release, stating, "If you're asking me was there a connection in that regard, at the endgame, I'm not going to deny that." He added that the US took advantage of the leverage to ensure the safe and efficient release of the Americans.

The revelation has drawn criticism from Republicans, with Senator Ben Sasse (R-Neb.) saying that the cash transfer was a ransom payment. "If it quacks like a duck, it's a duck," Sasse said. "If a cash payment is contingent on a hostage release, it's a ransom. The truth matters and the president owes the American people an explanation."

Senator Tom Cotton (R-Ark.) also expressed concerns, stating that the latest reports about the cash payment send a message to extremists that "the United States will pay cold, hard cash for hostages." Republican leaders in Congress have announced plans to hold hearings on the cash transfer in September.

The Obama administration has maintained that the payment was not a ransom, but rather a settlement of a failed arms deal from over three decades ago. Kirby emphasized that the cash was a useful tool, saying, "It would have been foolish, imprudent, irresponsible for us not to try to maintain maximum leverage." US officials have also denied that the prisoner release and the arms-deal settlement were linked.

The White House announced in January that the US would pay Iran $400 million as the first installment of a $1.7 billion settlement to resolve a legal dispute over the failed arms deal. However, administration officials did not disclose at the time that the payment had been made in cash and refused to answer questions about how and when the payment took place.

Title: Fox's Tucker Carlson Faces Backlash for Claiming White Supremacy is a "Hoax"

Article:

Fox News host Tucker Carlson has sparked widespread criticism for claiming that white supremacy is a "hoax" and a "conspiracy theory" used to divide the country and maintain power. This statement came after the El Paso shooting, which left 22 people dead and many more injured. The suspect's manifesto, which was published online before the attack, contained anti-immigrant and white nationalist rhetoric, echoing language frequently heard on far-right-wing talk shows and websites.

Carlson made his comments on his show "Tucker Carlson Tonight," stating that the whole thing is a lie and downplaying the threat by saying it's "not a real problem in America." However, many politicians and experts have warned about the growing threat of white nationalist violence. Conservative commentator Jonah Goldberg tweeted that if President Trump adopts these talking points, it will be "awful for the country and devastating for Trump's presidency."

The Anti-Defamation League (ADL) has tracked extremist activity and found that white supremacist murders in the US more than doubled in 2017, with far-right extremist groups and white supremacists responsible for 59% of all extremist-related fatalities in the US that year. The ADL also found that white supremacist groups posted more propaganda on college campuses for the third year in a row, attempting to recruit new young members.

FBI Director Christopher Wray warned in July that domestic terrorism threats are on the rise, and the FBI takes white supremacist hate crimes "extremely seriously." The Los Angeles Times published an editorial stating that white supremacy is the "poison in our well," and Washington Post reporter Wesley Lowery noted that white supremacy has killed more Americans than any other terroristic ideology in the history of America.

The article also highlights the long history of white supremacy in the US, dating back to the country's founding. Tucker Carlson's punditry on his show frequently focuses on immigration, depicting immigrants as dangerous criminals and rejecting multiculturalism as a threat to "Western civilization."

Title: House Judiciary Committee Hearing Highlights Tensions Over Russia Investigation and Hillary Clinton Email Probe

The House Judiciary Committee held a contentious hearing on Thursday, with Republican Representative Trey Gowdy criticizing Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein over the ongoing Russia investigation. Gowdy urged the Justice Department to "finish it the hell up" and accused the department of not providing evidence of wrongdoing by President Trump or his campaign.

Rosenstein testified alongside FBI Director Christopher Wray, and the hearing saw a series of tense exchanges between lawmakers and the officials. The hearing was sparked by a months-long battle between Republicans and the Justice Department over the handling of the Russia probe and the Hillary Clinton email investigation.

The House approved a resolution insisting the Justice Department comply with congressional subpoenas for documents related to the Russia case. Representative Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, cited the looming vote as he personally challenged Rosenstein over his compliance.

Gowdy expressed frustration over the protracted Russia investigation, saying that despite a host of charges against Trump-tied figures, the investigation has not found evidence of presidential wrongdoing. "We've seen the bias, we need to see the evidence," Gowdy said. "If you have evidence of wrongdoing by any member of the Trump campaign, present it to the damn grand jury. If you have evidence that this president acted inappropriately, present it to the American people."

Rosenstein assured the committee that the Justice Department is working to reach a conclusion and is not withholding any information. He denied allegations of stonewalling congressional document requests and said that the department is working to accommodate requests and produce relevant information.

The hearing also saw criticism from Republicans over the handling of the Russia investigation, with some lawmakers accusing the Justice Department of bias and stonewalling. Democrats, on the other hand, expressed concerns that the agencies are being pressured to disclose sensitive information.

The hearing highlighted the ongoing tensions between the Justice Department and Congress over the handling of the Russia investigation and the Hillary Clinton email probe. The investigation has been ongoing for months, and the hearing saw a series of contentious exchanges between lawmakers and officials.

Title: House Republicans Plan to Attach Controversial Items to Debt Ceiling Bill

Article:

House Republicans have outlined a lengthy wish list of items they plan to attach to legislation raising the nation's debt limit, including a delay of Obamacare, major tax reforms, changes to entitlement programs like Medicare and Social Security, and approval of the Keystone pipeline. The move is aimed at maintaining a united front in opposition to President Barack Obama's signature health care law and other issues.

The debt ceiling bill will include a mix of controversial items, increasing the threat of a default on U.S. debt. Senate Democrats have already indicated they will reject the bill, citing concerns over the inclusion of non-essential items. The Obama administration has also stated it will not negotiate on a measure to authorize additional borrowing authority for the Treasury Department, which is projected to run out sometime in October or early November.

House Speaker John Boehner and other top leaders outlined the GOP wish list, which will also include provisions for major tax reforms, changes to entitlement programs, and approval of the Keystone pipeline. The measure will also include instructions for the House and Senate to pass tax reform by a specific deadline.

The inclusion of these items is designed to keep the party unified, but it may also increase the threat of a default and ensure Capitol Hill will be tied up for the next several weeks, if not months, with partisan fighting that could ripple through the financial markets.

Title: Trump Trails in Michigan Poll, Frontrunners Biden and Sanders Outshine Him

A recent poll conducted by the Glengariff Group in Michigan has shown that President Donald Trump trails behind Democratic presidential primary frontrunners Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders among likely voters in the state. The poll, published by The Detroit News and WDIV-TV, surveyed 600 Michigan voters and had a margin of error of 4 percentage points.

According to the poll, only 36% of likely voters in Michigan would vote for Trump if the election were held today. In contrast, Biden and Sanders both outshine Trump by 12 percentage points, with 48% of voters supporting the former vice president and 47% supporting the senator.

Michigan is a crucial battleground state in the November 2020 election, and Trump's campaign is aware of the warning signs in the state. The state has not voted for a Republican president since 1988, and Trump's campaign is likely concerned about the potential impact of his trade wars on the state's manufacturing and agriculture sectors.

The poll also matched Trump against three other Democratic presidential hopefuls - Pete Buttigieg, Elizabeth Warren, and Kamala Harris. While Trump trailed behind these candidates as well, the margins were smaller than those against Biden and Sanders.

The Quinnipiac University poll conducted in early May found Biden leading Trump by 11 percentage points in Pennsylvania, another key battleground state. Republicans are optimistic that they have time to invest in states like Michigan and Pennsylvania and ultimately gain an advantage.

The results of this poll suggest that Trump's path to reelection may be more challenging than previously thought, and his campaign will need to work hard to win over voters in key battleground states like Michigan and Pennsylvania.

Title: Trump Visits Mississippi Civil Rights Museum, Absent Top African-American Leaders in Protest

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump visited the Mississippi Civil Rights Museum on Saturday, where he delivered brief remarks and toured the institution. The visit was marked by the absence of top African-American leaders, who declined to attend in protest of Trump's policies and record on race relations.

During his visit, Trump paid tribute to African-Americans who fought against institutionalized racism, including Medgar Evers, a civil rights activist who was murdered outside his home in Jackson in 1963. He also acknowledged Evers' wife Myrlie and brother Charles in the audience.

However, several prominent African-American leaders, including U.S. Representative John Lewis of Georgia and Mississippi Democratic Representative Bennie Thompson, declined to attend the museum opening due to Trump's presence. Lewis and Thompson cited Trump's "hurtful policies" and "disparaging comments" about various groups, including women, the disabled, immigrants, and National Football League players.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People also expressed disappointment with Trump's attendance. In contrast, U.S. Housing and Urban Development Secretary Ben Carson, who is black and ran against Trump in the 2016 Republican presidential primaries, accompanied the president on his tour of the museum.

Trump's record on race relations has been complicated, with some critics pointing to his past statements and actions. In August, he faced criticism for saying that both left- and right-wing protesters were to blame for violence at a white supremacist-led rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, where one woman died.

The White House called the decision by Lewis and Thompson not to attend the museum opening "unfortunate." Trump concluded his remarks by saying, "Today we pay solemn tribute to our heroes of the past and dedicate ourselves to building a future of freedom, equality, justice, and peace."

Title: Thousands of US Schoolchildren Participate in National School Walkout Against Gun Violence

The National School Walkout, held on the 19th anniversary of the Columbine High School massacre in Colorado, saw thousands of schoolchildren across the United States walk out of their classrooms to demonstrate against gun violence. The event was organized by Connecticut high school pupil Lane Murdock, who set up the campaign in the wake of the Parkland shooting in Florida.

The walkout, which involved over 2,000 schools, aimed to raise awareness of gun violence and combat political inaction. Participants held 13 seconds of silence in honor of the 13 victims of the Columbine shooting, and some students made calls to their Senators' offices and flooded social media with calls for reform.

In a separate incident, a student was shot in the ankle at Forest High School in Ocala, Florida, just an hour before the walkout was due to begin. The suspect, initially identified as a student, was later clarified to be a non-student. The student was taken to a nearby hospital and a suspect was taken into custody.

As a precaution, all schools in the district were placed on "Code Red" lockdown, and reports of a gunman at another school in Marion County turned out to be false. The goal of the demonstration was to bring attention to the issue of gun violence and push for legislative changes to control the sale of guns.

The National School Walkout is the second such event, following a similar protest on March 14, which was held one month after the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School shooting in Florida. The event has gained significant support, with over 250,000 people signing a petition on change.org.

Title: North Korean Leader's Uncle Executed, Accused of Corruption and Immoral Behavior

North Korean state media announced the execution of Kim Jong Un's uncle, Jang Song Thaek, on Friday, citing his alleged corruption, drug use, gambling, womanizing, and "dissolute and depraved life." Jang was considered the second most powerful official in the country and was seen as helping Kim Jong Un consolidate power after the death of his father, Kim Jong Il, two years ago.

According to the official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA), Jang was removed from all his posts and expelled from the ruling Workers' Party during a meeting of its politburo on Sunday. Kim Jong Un attended and "guided" the meeting, KCNA said.

The execution comes after South Korean media reports that one of Jang's aides had sought asylum in South Korea. The aide, who managed funds for Jang, was being protected by South Korean officials in a secret location in China, according to cable news network YTN and the Kyunghyang Shinmun newspaper.

Jang's removal is the latest in a series of personnel reshuffles conducted by Kim Jong Un to bolster his power. The decision to remove Jang was widely reported in North Korea's media, including on the front page of the official Rodong Sinmun newspaper on Monday.

The Rodong Sinmun carried a picture of what it said was the politburo meeting, showing Jang and Kim Kyong Hui, Jang's wife and aunt to the young leader, among 17 politburo members. However, neither Jang nor his wife could be seen in the photo.

The execution of Jang is a significant development in North Korea's leadership, which has been undergoing its biggest upheaval since the death of former leader Kim Jong Il in 2011. Jang had close ties to China and visited Beijing in 2012 on behalf of Kim Jong Un. He was also head of the North Korean side of a joint project managing a special economic zone with Beijing.

In a statement, KCNA said Jang "pretended to uphold the party and leader but was engrossed in such factional acts (such) as dreaming different dreams and involving himself in double-dealing behind the scene." The agency also accused Jang of being "affected by the capitalist way of living, committing irregularities and corruption, and leading a dissolute and depraved life."

Title: North Korea's Leader Kim Jong Un Emphasizes Nuclear Deterrent, Promotes Sister and Officials

SEOUL (Yonhap News Agency) - North Korean leader Kim Jong Un emphasized the importance of his country's nuclear weapons as a "powerful deterrent" to ensure its sovereignty, state media reported on Sunday. The statement comes after US President Donald Trump's comments that "only one thing will work" in dealing with the isolated country.

Kim Jong Un made the remarks during a speech to the Central Committee of the Workers' Party of Korea, where he addressed the "complicated international situation." He stated that North Korea's nuclear weapons are a "powerful deterrent firmly safeguarding the peace and security in the Korean peninsula and Northeast Asia," referring to the "protracted nuclear threats of the U.S. imperialists."

Recent weeks have seen North Korea launch two missiles over Japan and conduct its sixth nuclear test, with the country reportedly advancing towards its goal of developing a nuclear-tipped missile capable of hitting the US mainland. A Russian lawmaker who recently visited Pyongyang said that North Korea is preparing to test-launch such a missile.

The situation has led to increased tensions between North Korea and the US, with Trump previously stating that the US would "totally destroy" North Korea if necessary to protect itself and its allies. Kim Jong Un's comments suggest that his country's policy of parallel development of nuclear weapons and the economy is "absolutely right," with the national economy growing despite escalating sanctions.

The meeting also saw personnel changes within North Korea's ruling center of power, with Kim Jong Un's sister, Kim Yo Jong, being made an alternate member of the politburo, the top decision-making body. Her promotion indicates that she has become a key player in the country's leadership, alongside Kim Jong Un himself.

Other high-ranking officials, including Kim Jong Sik and Ri Pyong Chol, were also promoted, with the South Korean unification ministry suggesting that the moves may be an attempt by North Korea to navigate its increasing isolation. The ministry noted that the large-scale personnel reshuffle reflects Kim Jong Un's serious consideration of the current situation and his desire to promote a new generation of politicians.

North Korea's foreign minister, Ri Yong Ho, was also promoted to a full vote-carrying member of the politburo, allowing him to play a more significant role in policy-making.

Title: Trump Lowers Expectations Ahead of North Korea Summit

President Donald Trump is just one week away from his highly anticipated summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Vietnam. Trump's main goal remains to strike a deal to dismantle North Korea's nuclear program, but the process is proving to be more challenging than expected. The US has demanded a full, detailed list of North Korea's nuclear inventory before lifting sanctions, while North Korea insists on sanctions being lifted before providing the list and beginning to downgrade its nuclear capabilities.

In an effort to manage expectations, Trump has been using public statements to downplay the likelihood of a major breakthrough at the summit. On Tuesday, he told reporters, "We're in no rush whatsoever... As long as there's no testing, I'm in no rush." This comment is not new, but it carries more weight now that he mentioned it again before the February 27 meeting.

Trump often points to the fact that North Korea has not detonated a nuclear device since September 2017 or tested a missile since November of that year. However, this is not the full story. North Korea has conducted six nuclear tests in total, with only one taking place during the Trump administration. There have also been years-long gaps between North Korea's missile tests, which began in the 1980s.

Frank Aum, a North Korea expert at the US Institute of Peace, believes that Trump's comments are an attempt to create negotiating leverage before the summit by creating the impression that he is not desperate to achieve North Korea's denuclearization.

The summit is unlikely to be the last meeting between Trump and Kim, with Trump stating that he believes Pyongyang will eventually dismantle its nuclear arsenal. However, the process is expected to be long and arduous, with North Korea seeking a step-by-step approach to denuclearization.

In Singapore, Trump and Kim agreed to a four-part plan, which includes establishing new US-DPRK relations, building a lasting and stable peace regime on the Korean Peninsula, reaffirming the April 27, 2018 Panmunjom Declaration, and recovering POW/MIA remains. Denuclearization is not mentioned until the third step, and there is major disagreement about what it means.

Bridget Coggins, a North Korea expert at the University of California Santa Barbara, believes that quick denuclearization is impractical, as Kim believes having a credible nuclear program will help his regime survive by deterring an invasion from the United States. The way North Korea wants to proceed is via a step-by-step process, with the US and North Korea working together to build a lasting and stable peace regime on the Korean Peninsula.

The pressure for real substantive progress is still there, but the relationship-building aspect of the summit may take center stage.

**Stocks Rebound as Beijing Indicates No Immediate Response to Latest Tariffs**

The US stock market posted its strongest gains in recent days, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500 index, and Nasdaq Composite Index all rising by 1.3% or more. The rebound comes after Beijing indicated it would not immediately respond to the latest round of tariffs imposed by Washington.

The S&P 500 index rose 36.64 points to finish at 2,924.58, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced 326.15 points to close at 26,362.25. The Nasdaq Composite Index added 116.51 points to close at 7,973.39.

This week's rebound has erased some of the month-to-date losses for the major indexes, with the S&P 500 and Dow now less than 4% below their all-time closing highs set in July. The Nasdaq remains around 4.2% below its peak.

Investors also parsed a series of economic reports, including a revision of second-quarter GDP growth, which showed the US economy growing at a 2% annual rate. The revised numbers also showed the US consumer playing an even larger role in economic growth, with personal consumption accounting for 3.1 percentage points of growth.

New applications for jobless benefits rose by 4,000 to a seasonally adjusted 215,000 during the week ended August 24, slightly above economist expectations. The S&P 500 and Dow are each less than 4% below all-time closing highs set in July, while the Nasdaq remains around 4.2% below its peak.

Analysts pointed to the calendar as a reason for higher equity prices in recent days, as investors rebalance their portfolios heading into September. "There's a lot of evidence of month-end book squaring, as a lot of the worst-performing sectors month-to-date outperformed yesterday, despite the lack of a discernible positive catalyst," wrote Tom Essaye, president of the Sevens Report, in a Thursday note to clients.

In other market news, shares of Best Buy Co. Inc. tumbled 8% after the retailer reported second-quarter revenue that fell short of analyst expectations, while shares of Dollar General Corp. added 10.7% after the discount retailer handily beat analyst estimates for sales and profits in the second quarter.

Title: Senate to Vote on Government Funding Bills Amid Ongoing Shutdown

The United States Senate is set to vote on two bills to fund the government on Thursday, according to a deal reached between Senate leaders Mitch McConnell and Chuck Schumer. The first bill is the immigration proposal unveiled by President Donald Trump on Saturday, which is unlikely to gain traction among Democrats. The second bill is a clean continuing resolution (CR) that would reopen the government until February 8, which has already been passed by the House. This proposal is more likely to receive support from Democrats, ensuring that federal workers would not miss another paycheck.

The outcome of the vote is crucial, as it could either bring an end to the shutdown or prolong it. If enough Republicans join Democrats to pass the short-term bill, it would be a defeat for President Trump, as it does not include funding for his proposed border wall. On the other hand, if the president vetoes the proposal or scares off Senate Republicans from voting for it, the shutdown could continue.

The development marks a shift in the stalemate, as Senate Republican leaders had initially asked President Trump to develop "compromise" legislation to put on the floor. Centrist Democrats in the House also drafted a letter to Speaker Nancy Pelosi, urging her to promise the president a vote on his homeland security request, including border wall funding, after the government reopens.

While the Senate may not be able to end the shutdown on Thursday, the machinery that will eventually bring an end to the shutdown is starting to operate, with pressure building from anxious Senate Republicans and House Democrats.

Title: Former Trump Campaign Manager Lewandowski Accused of Uncooperative Behavior in Impeachment Hearing

Article:

Former Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski faced intense questioning from House Democrats during a five-hour hearing on Tuesday, as he refused to provide detailed information about his conversations with President Donald Trump. Lewandowski, a close ally of the president, was accused by House Judiciary Chair Jerrold Nadler of engaging in "completely unacceptable" behavior, as he followed White House orders not to discuss conversations with Trump beyond what was already publicly known.

Lewandowski's testimony was marked by a defiant tone, as he repeatedly refused to answer questions and instead demanded that Democrats provide him with a copy of the Mueller report. He also read directly from the report and asked Democrats to read passages to him. The former campaign manager also took an opportunity to tweet a link to his new Super PAC during a bathroom break.

The hearing underscored the central dilemma facing the House Judiciary Committee as it investigates and potentially tries to impeach Trump. The White House has blocked the committee's oversight requests at almost every turn, declining to provide new documents or allow aides and associates to testify. Lewandowski was a central figure in the Mueller report, which described two episodes in which Trump asked him to tell then-Attorney General Jeff Sessions to curtail the Russia investigation and fire Sessions if he refused to comply.

Lewandowski acknowledged that he might have lied in a previous cable interview when he said he didn't remember the president asking him to get involved with Sessions. He also stated that he has "no obligation to be honest with the media because they are just as dishonest as everybody else."

Two other witnesses who were subpoenaed alongside Lewandowski, Rick Dearborn and Rob Porter, did not show up, as the White House holds that former aides are "absolutely immune" from testifying. Democrats are challenging this position in court.

Title: Global Communities Adjust Easter and Passover Celebrations Amid COVID-19 Pandemic

The COVID-19 pandemic has forced families and communities worldwide to adapt their traditional religious observances of Passover and Holy Week. As a result, many are finding creative ways to celebrate these significant holidays while adhering to social distancing measures and public health guidelines.

In the United States and Europe, law enforcement agencies are taking extra measures to enforce social distancing over the Easter weekend. Officials claim that these efforts are beginning to show positive results, with the COVID-19 curve flattening in crucial areas.

Title: Federal Government's Phone Records Program "Goes Dark" as Senate Fails to Reach Consensus

The federal government's massive phone records program, which was set to expire on May 26, has indeed "gone dark" after the Senate failed to reach a consensus on a compromise bill. The program, which was part of the Patriot Act, allowed the government to collect and store phone records of American citizens without a warrant. The expiration of the program and other anti-terrorism surveillance provisions has dealt a blow to its advocates, including Senator Rand Paul, who has made ending the program his signature issue.

The program's expiration was expected, but it marks the first significant defeat for Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, who had worked hard to build opposition to the House bill, which passed overwhelmingly and has President Obama's support. The House bill requires phone companies to store the data and the government to obtain a search warrant to access it.

Senator Paul, a libertarian, has been a vocal opponent of the program and has used parliamentary rules to disrupt floor action on the issue. He has featured his fight in campaign ads and fundraising appeals. The House bill is expected to be voted on later this week.

The expiration of the program has left some lawmakers concerned about the potential security implications, with Senator John McCain stating that the nation will be "less secure" during the interim period. However, Democrats see the situation as a "manufactured crisis" created by McConnell, who waited until just before the Senate's Memorial Day recess to bring up the Patriot Act provisions.

Senator Susan Collins of Maine expressed concerns about the program going dark at a time when the terrorist threat is high, but noted that it was not anticipated that Senator Paul and some Democratic allies would object to short-term extensions. The expiration of the program has highlighted the difficulty of keeping lawmakers in line, particularly when they are running for president, as Senator Paul is.

Title: Detained Migrants in Assam Face Heightened Risk of Coronavirus Infection Amid Pandemic

In the midst of the global coronavirus pandemic, families of over 800 undocumented migrants being held in six detention centers across Assam, India, are worried about the safety of their loved ones. The migrants, declared "illegal immigrants" by the Foreigners Tribunal, face either deportation or detention in camps like the one in Tezpur, where Gul Mohammad, 69, has been held since 2017.

Gulbahar Begum, 28, travels 145km every other month to visit her father, who has various health issues, including a kidney ailment. She fears for his safety, citing the risk of contracting the virus in the overcrowded and unsanitary conditions of the detention center. "He should have been home in this public health crisis and not in a detention center," she said.

The National Register of Citizens (NRC) last year left nearly 1.9 million people, many of them Muslims, without citizenship, rendering them stateless. Rights organizations have called the NRC a tool used by India's ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) to target and disenfranchise the Muslim population, an allegation the party denies.

Families of those detained fear a potential coronavirus outbreak due to overcrowding in the detention centers, which makes physical distancing nearly impossible. Most centers lack proper hygiene and medical care for the detainees, exacerbating the chances of a viral transmission.

Dozens of people have died inside the detention centers since 2009, with the latest fatality occurring on Sunday. Officials cited cancer as the reason for 60-year-old Rabeda Begum's death, according to a report.

Botu Miya, 40, from Cachar district, is distressed as he fears his wife, Banesa Begum, being held in Silchar detention center, might contract the coronavirus. Banesa, a 45-year-old daily wage laborer, was first marked as a "doubtful voter" for not producing the requisite proof of Indian citizenship and later labelled an undocumented migrant.

Human rights organizations have demanded the release of the detainees amid the escalating coronavirus pandemic. Amnesty International India called for the immediate release of inmates declared foreigners, citing "appalling living conditions" inside the centers. The Supreme Court has issued notices to both the Assam and federal governments, with the next hearing scheduled for April 13.

For Gulbahar, imprisonment amid the pandemic is like a death sentence for her father. With each passing day, she says her hope of seeing him alive is fading. "I think I would never see him alive," she said. "And the government has to take responsibility for his death."

Title: Trump Condemns Syrian Chemical Attack, Signals Shift in Approach Toward Assad

President Donald Trump condemned the recent chemical attack in Syria, which has been blamed on President Bashar Assad, signaling a shift in his approach toward the country's controversial leader. During a Rose Garden news conference with Jordan's King Abdullah, Trump expressed his outrage over the attack, which has killed at least 72 people.

"It crossed a lot of lines for me," Trump said, emphasizing the devastating impact of the attack on innocent civilians, particularly children. He also criticized the Obama administration's approach to Syria, stating that it had not done enough to address the crisis.

Trump's comments marked a departure from his previous stance on Syria, which had emphasized the need for the U.S. to stay out of the conflict. However, he did not elaborate on how the U.S. would respond to the attack.

United Nations Ambassador Nikki Haley also condemned the attack, strongly criticizing Russia for its support of the Assad regime. "How many more children have to die before Russia cares?" she asked, holding up photos of the young victims.

Trump's comments also marked a shift in his stance toward Russian President Vladimir Putin, whom he has previously praised. In an interview with the New York Times, Trump cast blame toward Putin, stating that Russia was "aligned" with Syria and that all information pointed to them being responsible for the attack.

The president's comments come as the international community continues to grapple with the humanitarian crisis in Syria, which has been ongoing for years. The U.S. has previously been hesitant to take a strong stance on the conflict, but Trump's comments suggest a possible shift in approach.

Title: Obama Administration Focuses on Selling Obamacare to the Public Amidst Declining Support

The Obama administration is shifting its attention from implementing the Affordable Care Act (ACA) to selling the program to the American public. Without a willing and informed populace, the law's success is uncertain. The administration is prioritizing the individual insurance exchanges, with the Small Business Health Option Program (SHOP) exchanges taking a backseat. According to Politico, insurers are not signing up in droves to sell on the SHOP exchanges, with some states having only one insurer participating.

In Washington state and North Carolina, only one insurer has signed up to offer insurance through the SHOP exchanges, while in Mississippi, no insurers have signed up for the SHOP exchange. The limited tax credit for small businesses available only in the SHOP exchanges has received less interest than expected, and the delayed program providing employees with more freedom to pick their health plan is not expected to launch until after 2015 in federally-run state exchanges.

The administration is still trying to recruit insurers to states where there has been little interest in exchanges. However, some health law advocates believe the administration has prioritized the individual exchanges, where premium tax credits are expected to be a big draw for millions to sign up for coverage next year. The delayed program providing employees with more freedom to pick their health plan is not expected to help the Obama administration follow through on the key selling point that these exchanges would be helpful to small businesses in increasing competition and lowering costs.

Title: USA Freedom Act Passes House Judiciary Committee with Bipartisan Support

The USA Freedom Act, a legislation sponsored by an unusual coalition of conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats, has passed the House Judiciary Committee with overwhelming support from both parties. The bill is now likely to be approved by the full House. The legislation aims to reform the National Security Agency's (NSA) bulk data collection program, which was authorized under Section 215 of the Patriot Act.

The bill attracted Republican votes by increasing penalties for those convicted of material support for terrorism and allowing intelligence agencies to track suspected terrorists for 72 hours after they enter the country before needing a warrant. However, the measure faces a more uncertain future in the Senate, where a similar bill failed by two votes to overcome a filibuster last year.

The bulk collection program, which generated significant criticism after Edward Snowden revealed its details in 2013, allowed the NSA to cast a wide net for call data by forcing major phone companies to pour their data directly into government computers. The government received only "metadata" – phone numbers called, as well as the duration and time of calls, but not the content of the conversations.

Under the new legislation, the government would no longer be allowed to keep a database of this information and would be limited to obtaining data from telecommunications companies when there is a "reasonable, articulable suspicion" that a "specific selection term" used to request data is associated with international terrorism. The Electronic Frontier Foundation, a civil liberties advocacy group, analyzed the bill and stated that it "should end" the bulk collection of "everybody's phone records." However, the foundation noted that the NSA could still search for records beyond telephone data with fewer restrictions, and that the bill would not address warrantless collection of Americans' international calls and emails under Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act amendments of 2008.

In December 2013, a panel of experts appointed by President Obama found that the program had been of minimal intelligence value and ran considerable risks of invading privacy, which may have sealed the future of the bulk collection program.

Title: Berlin Christmas Market Attack: A Symbolic Target in a Turbulent Year

The recent attack on a Christmas market in Berlin, which killed 12 and injured 48, has sent shockwaves across the globe. The incident has struck at the heart of German tradition, with the Christmas market being a beloved and iconic part of the country's cultural heritage. The market, which dates back to 1434, is a cherished institution that brings people together to celebrate the holiday season.

The attack has also sparked concerns about the growing threat of terrorism in Europe, particularly in the wake of recent attacks in Nice, France, and other parts of the continent. The suspect, a man from Pakistan who entered Germany in 2015, has been arrested and denies any involvement in the attack.

The Christmas market is a powerful symbol of German culture and tradition, with its twinkling lights, festive music, and handmade crafts evoking a sense of nostalgia and community. For many Germans, the market is a cherished tradition that brings people together and provides a sense of comfort and familiarity.

The attack has also highlighted the growing tensions and divisions within Germany, with some politicians using the incident to criticize Chancellor Angela Merkel's decision to open the country's borders to refugees. The incident has also been seized upon by populist politicians in Germany, France, and the Netherlands, who are seeking to capitalize on the public's fears and anxieties.

Despite the challenges and uncertainties, the Christmas market is expected to reopen, albeit under increased security measures. The incident serves as a reminder of the importance of vigilance and cooperation in the face of terrorism, and the need for nations to come together to combat this global threat.

Title: Trump Puts Off Decision to Fire Attorney General Sessions Until After November Elections

President Donald Trump has decided to delay a decision on whether to fire Attorney General Jeff Sessions, a frequent target of his criticism, until at least after the November congressional elections. In an interview with Bloomberg News, Trump stated that he "just would love to have him do a great job" about Sessions, but declined to comment on whether he would keep him on the job beyond November.

Trump has publicly criticized Sessions for months, and recently told a Republican lawmaker that he wanted to fire him before the midterm elections. However, top Republican lawmakers have urged Sessions to resist pressure to quit and have pushed Trump to stand down for now.

According to sources, Trump surveyed his advisers earlier this week about the potential political blowback from firing Sessions, and was told that there would be little political fallout. White House officials and others who have spoken to Trump about firing Sessions said the president has not inquired about potential successors.

One factor contributing to Trump's decision to keep Sessions for the coming months is the lack of an obvious replacement. Fueling Trump's anger towards Sessions is his view that the attorney general erred in recusing himself from the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 elections, which is looking into possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia, as well as possible obstruction of justice. Russia has denied any involvement.

Last week, Trump issued another attack on Sessions, suggesting that the attorney general is allowing the special counsel's Russia investigation to proceed while permitting "real corruption" to go "untouched." In response, Sessions issued a rare public statement defending his leadership of the Justice Department, stating that "while I am attorney general, the actions of the Department of Justice will not be improperly influenced by political considerations."

Sessions is in a delicate position, fending off attacks from Trump while carrying out the president's tough-on-crime policies.

Title: AP Photo of Mitt Romney Sparks Debate Over Legitimacy of Political Journalism

The Associated Press (AP) recently published a photograph of Mitt Romney, a Republican presidential candidate, bending over, with a seemingly astonished schoolgirl standing behind him, mouth agape. The image has since gone viral, sparking a discussion about the legitimacy of political journalism.

The photograph, which was posted by the AP on Monday, has been met with mixed reactions. Tim Graham, media analysis director at the Media Research Center, described the image as "unbelievable" and "a little girl gaping at Romney from behind." Steve Manuel, a senior lecturer at Penn State's College of Communications and an award-winning photojournalist, criticized the AP for publishing the image, stating that it is not legitimate news and that it makes Romney appear foolish.

Stephen Ward, director of the Center for Journalism Ethics at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, noted that the photo by itself is not offensive but could be exploited. The National Press Photographers Association code of ethics provides guidance on treating subjects with respect and dignity and providing context when photographing or recording subjects.

The AP's decision to publish the image coincided with a story about Romney's decision to skip a Nickelodeon-sponsored "Kids Pick the President" special, which President Obama had agreed to participate in. The story was written from an anti-Romney tone, with the show's producer, Linda Ellerbee, criticizing Romney's decision. Romney's campaign claimed it did not have time to participate, and noted that kids do not actually vote.

The controversy surrounding the photograph highlights the importance of considering the ethical implications of publishing images in political journalism. While the AP may not have intended to make Romney appear foolish, the image has sparked a wider discussion about the role of photojournalism in political reporting.

Title: Trump Shrugs Off Republican Leaders' Refusal to Endorse, Predicts Party Unity

Article:

Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has downplayed the refusal of some Republican leaders to endorse him, stating that most of the party will back his nomination and new voters will compensate for the rest. In an interview on NBC's Meet the Press, Trump said, "I'm going to get millions and millions of votes more than the Republicans would have gotten."

Trump's comments come after House Speaker Paul Ryan announced he is not yet ready to endorse Trump, citing concerns about his conservatism. Other party members, including 2012 Republican nominee Mitt Romney, former 2016 GOP hopefuls Jeb Bush and Lindsey Graham, have flatly come out against the nominee-in-waiting. They have expressed concerns about Trump's abrasive language, comments about women and Hispanics, and his lack of respect for the Constitution.

Trump lacks the "temperament or strength of character" to be president, according to Bush, who wrote in a Facebook post that Trump has not displayed a respect for the Constitution and is not a consistent conservative. Romney has denounced Trump as a "phony" and a "fraud," while Graham said it would be difficult to find a conservative agenda with Trump.

In his interview, Trump accused Romney of being "ungrateful" for his support in 2012 and said he "choked" on his chance to beat President Obama. He also claimed that Bush and Graham are angry that he beat them during the nomination fight and noted that both once backed a pledge to support the nominee.

Trump said he was "blindsided" by Ryan's reluctance to endorse him, stating that he thought he had a good relationship with the House speaker. Ryan told CNN he wants to back the nominee but is not there yet.

Meanwhile, Democrats are enjoying the GOP infighting, particularly likely presidential nominee Hillary Clinton, who is targeting anti-Trump Republicans for the fall general election. Trump, however, predicts that most Republicans will ultimately back his candidacy and that he will easily beat "Crooked Hillary" in the fall.

Title: US Intelligence Chiefs to Brief President-elect Trump on Russian Hacking Report

The US intelligence community has prepared a report on Russian hacking activities during the presidential election, which President-elect Donald Trump is expected to receive a briefing on Friday. The report, prepared by the CIA, FBI, and NSA, was ordered by President Obama in December and will be made public in an unclassified version early next week. Director of National Intelligence James Clapper previewed some of the report's findings, stating that hacking was only part of Russia's cyber activities during the election, which also included classical propaganda, disinformation, and fake news.

The report's findings will be presented to Trump by four intelligence chiefs, including Clapper, CIA Director John Brennan, FBI Director James Comey, and National Security Agency Director Adm. Mike Rogers. Trump has been questioning the US intelligence community's integrity and assessment that Russia was responsible for hacking activities aimed at influencing the election.

Several Republicans in Congress, such as Rep. Michael McCaul and Sen. John McCain, have expressed confidence in the intelligence community's findings and emphasized the need for a strong stance against Russia's actions. Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-South Carolina, stated that the Obama administration's sanctions against Russian intelligence agents and entities were not sufficient and advised the president-elect to take a stronger stance.

The report's findings are expected to be a key topic of discussion in the coming weeks, as lawmakers and the new administration consider how to respond to Russia's actions.

Title: Trump Hosts White House Dinner to Honor Evangelical Leaders and Celebrate Faith and Freedom

The White House hosted a special dinner on Monday evening, where President Donald Trump honored evangelical leaders and celebrated the country's faith and freedom. The event brought together faith leaders from around the country, including Rev. Franklin Graham and Pastor Paula White, to recognize their contributions to American society.

During the dinner, Trump took a moment to express gratitude for the late Sen. John McCain's service to the country, stating, "Our hearts and prayers are going to the family of Sen. John McCain... and we very much appreciate everything Sen. McCain has done for our country."

The president also highlighted his administration's efforts to combat religious persecution, citing the release of American hostages from North Korea and the efforts to secure the release of Pastor Brunson from Turkey. Trump emphasized the importance of people of faith voting in the upcoming midterms to ensure the progress continues.

Pastor Robert Jeffress, a staunch supporter of the president, echoed Trump's sentiments, stating that evangelical leaders are concerned about the possibility of a Democrat-controlled Congress and the potential consequences for the president and the country.

The dinner was seen as a way for Trump to show appreciation for the role evangelical leaders played in his 2016 election and to pledge to protect their rights and freedoms. The Faith & Freedom Coalition's Ralph Reed noted that the dinner was not just a celebration of the president's supporters but also a recognition of the daily work of churches and houses of worship in providing spiritual guidance and support to Americans.

Title: White Supremacists and Their Confedates Face Consequences of Their Actions

The recent "Unite the Right" rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, has led to a wave of consequences for those who participated and supported the event. The rally, which was organized by white supremacists, has been widely condemned as a display of hate and intolerance. In the aftermath, many of those involved are facing financial and social repercussions.

The article highlights the idea that white supremacists are often motivated by a desire to belong and find purpose, rather than having a clear ideology or demands. This is supported by the author's personal experiences growing up in a town with a strong Confederate heritage and encountering individuals who identify as neo-Nazis.

The article also notes that many of those who participated in the rally may have been born into difficult circumstances, such as poverty and economic struggles, and that these issues are not unique to any one group.
