The author argues that most people who struggle to make it in life do not turn to hate and intolerance, but instead work hard to achieve their goals and respect those around them.

The article concludes that the "dapper" echelons of the alt-right have learned a valuable lesson: being awful in public will not get them where they want to be. This is a lesson that the rest of America has known for a while, and it is a reminder that hate and intolerance have no place in our society.

Title: Greece's Finance Minister Resigns as EU Leaders Meet to Discuss Next Steps

Greece and its European Union partners are facing a new reality after the country's citizens voted overwhelmingly against a German-led bailout plan, which would have given Greece more credit to pay its debt in exchange for tough austerity measures. The vote has sparked a fresh round of negotiations between Greece and its creditors, with the country seeking more favorable terms and its partners insisting on tough conditions.

Eurogroup President Jeroen Dijsselbloem called the vote "regrettable for the future of Greece," and an emergency meeting was convened on Tuesday. EU leaders expect Greece to present a new proposal soon.

The vote had its first concrete consequence on Monday when Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis resigned. In a statement, Varoufakis said he expects his resignation will help Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras negotiate better terms for his country. Varoufakis called the vote "splendid" and a "historic" moment in which Greece "rose up against debt bondage."

Greece has appointed Euclid Tsakalotos as its new finance minister. Tsakalotos, a 55-year-old economist, studied at prestigious private London school St Paul's and Oxford University, and has been a key negotiator in talks between the Greek government and creditors. While some may expect him to take a softer approach, he is likely to redouble efforts to put debt relief back on the table.

European Commission Vice President Valdis Dombrovskis said that while they respect the "democratic choice of the Greek people," the no vote "widens the gap between Greece and Eurozone countries." He emphasized that there is no easy way out of the crisis and that the European Commission cannot negotiate new terms without a mandate from eurogroup countries. Dombrovskis also stressed that the eurozone is not in danger and that all sides need to work together responsibly for the sake of the Greek people.

The situation remains uncertain, with Greece seeking a better deal and its partners insisting on tough conditions. The outcome will have significant implications for the country's future and the stability of the eurozone.

Title: Mississippi Senator Cindy Hyde-Smith's Past Attendance at Segregation Academy Raises Controversy Ahead of Election

Article:

Mississippi Senator Cindy Hyde-Smith has faced renewed scrutiny over her past attendance at a segregation academy in high school, according to reports from the Jackson Free Press and CNN. The reports have sparked controversy ahead of the state's runoff election, which pits Hyde-Smith against Democrat Mike Espy, who is vying to become the state's first African-American senator since the Reconstruction.

The reports reveal that Hyde-Smith attended Lawrence County Academy, a school founded in 1970, the year many Mississippi public high schools integrated. The school was created for parents who did not want to send their children to schools with black students. The Jackson Free Press included photos from the school's yearbook, including a group photo of the cheerleading squad, of which Hyde-Smith was a member. The photo shows the school's mascot dressed in what appears to be a Confederate uniform holding a Confederate flag.

Hyde-Smith's campaign responded to the report by saying that the media has "taken leave of their senses" and is attacking her family and trying to destroy her personally instead of focusing on the differences between her and her opponent.

Separately, CNN reported that Hyde-Smith co-sponsored a resolution in 2007 that honored Effie Lucille Nicholson Pharr, whose father was a soldier in Robert E. Lee's army. The resolution praised Pharr's father for his efforts to "defend his homeland" and contribute to the rebuilding of the country.

The controversy has garnered national attention, with President Donald Trump planning multiple rallies next week to help lock in another Republican seat in the Senate. The runoff election is expected to see a higher-than-average turnout, with Espy repeatedly pointing to Hyde-Smith's comments as a reason to vote against her.

Title: Trump Faces Hurdles in First Month as President

Washington - President Donald Trump is facing significant challenges in his first month in office, as the vast government machine proves difficult to navigate. The same Washington "buzzsaw" that frustrated his 44 predecessors is now posing hurdles for Trump, with rival power centers in the courts, bureaucracy, and Congress emerging as a threat at any point.

In his first month, Trump has faced setbacks, including the firing of his national security adviser and the withdrawal of one of his Cabinet nominees. He is also facing persistent questions about his campaign's ties to Russia, with some fellow Republicans on Capitol Hill becoming more vocal about their concerns. Legislative victories are hard to come by, as congressional Republicans struggle to unify behind policy measures and Democrats form a solid bloc of opposition.

The transition from candidate to president is tough for virtually every young administration, but Trump's first month is especially noteworthy since many of his troubles stem from self-inflicted wounds, such as the rushed rollout of his travel ban and his frequent Twitter distractions. The sense of turmoil surrounding the new administration could undermine a central tenet of Trump's pitch to voters - that he is a non-politician uniquely positioned to make a deal and get Washington working again.

Despite his early stumbles, Trump has shown some successes, including well-choreographed visits from foreign leaders and the unveiling of his Supreme Court nominee, Neil Gorsuch. However, controversy can develop in unexpected directions in Washington and exhaust a White House staff in a way that can be detrimental to a presidency. Trump is not the first president to come into power with a team that doesn't seem to quite measure up to Washington's demands.

Through trial and error, past presidents have learned to work the inside game in Washington to advance their political aims. However, Trump's attempts to fight back against the restrictions all presidents face could be complicated by his idiosyncratic character and political style, which were an undoubted asset when he reinvented the rules of the presidential campaign but have not yet proven effective in governing.

Title: House GOP Blocks Immigration Proposals from Being Considered on Defense Policy Bill

The House Republican leadership has blocked two immigration-related amendments from being included in the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA), a critical defense policy bill. The amendments, one from Representative Jeff Denham (R-Calif.) and another from Representative Joaquin Castro (D-Texas), aimed to provide a pathway to green cards for certain immigrants who serve in the military and allow young immigrants with temporary deportation relief to enroll in U.S. military academies.

Representative Denham expressed disappointment that his ENLIST Act amendment was not deemed "in order" for a vote, stating that he will continue to push for a standalone bill to allow undocumented young people who want to serve in the military to earn legal status. Representative Castro also expressed disappointment that his amendment was blocked, and plans to introduce it as a standalone bill with Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen (R-Fla.).

Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) stated that including the ENLIST Act on the NDAA was "inappropriate," although he noted that Republican leaders have supported the measure in the past. Boehner also mentioned that there are ongoing discussions about allowing the bill to receive a standalone vote on the House floor.

The NDAA is a sweeping annual measure that sets policy for the Pentagon, and over 300 amendments were filed for consideration. Of those, 162 will be considered, but the two immigration-related amendments were not among them.

Title: The Evolution of the US Mission in Syria: From Fighting ISIS to Regime Change

The United States' military presence in Syria has undergone significant changes since its initial deployment in 2012. Initially, the mission focused on defeating the Islamic State (ISIS), but it has since shifted to include regime change in Damascus and countering Iran's influence in the region. The withdrawal of US troops from Syria has sparked confusion and conflicting narratives about the purpose of the mission.

The US military presence in Syria began in 2012, with the goal of supporting moderate Syrian rebels fighting against the government. However, as ISIS emerged as a major threat, the mission shifted to focus on defeating the terrorist organization. The US provided military aid and training to Kurdish forces, with the aim of protecting them from Turkey, a NATO ally.

Despite the initial success in defeating ISIS, the US mission in Syria has been marked by "mission creep," with objectives changing over time. The US has provided military support to various groups, including the Free Syrian Army, which was touted as a moderate force fighting against the Assad regime. However, the army's rapid disintegration and the emergence of new threats have led to a re-evaluation of the mission.

The US has submitted various plans for continued involvement in Syria, each with the goal of defeating ISIS and toppling the Assad regime. However, these plans have been met with skepticism, as they often prioritize regime change over defeating the terrorist organization. The US has also struggled to define its objectives, with some arguing that the mission is necessary to protect the Kurds and others claiming that it is a retreat from the fight against ISIS.

The withdrawal of US troops from Syria has sparked debate about the effectiveness of the mission. Some argue that the US should remain in Syria to prevent ISIS from regrouping, while others see it as a necessary step towards a more focused and effective fight against terrorism. The US has been criticized for its lack of clear objectives and its failure to define a clear exit strategy.

In conclusion, the US mission in Syria has undergone significant changes since its inception, with the initial focus on defeating ISIS giving way to regime change and countering Iran's influence. The withdrawal of US troops has sparked debate and confusion, highlighting the need for a clear and defined mission.

Title: Abortion Debate: A Complex Issue with No Clear Consensus

The recent passage of abortion laws in New York and Alabama has sparked intense debate in the United States, with both sides presenting their views as extreme. However, a closer examination of the facts reveals a more nuanced picture.

The Alabama law, which bans abortion in nearly all cases, has been widely criticized as an attempt to challenge the landmark 1973 Supreme Court decision Roe v. Wade. Meanwhile, the New York law, which allows abortion up to the 40th week of pregnancy, has been defended as a necessary step to protect women's reproductive rights.

However, the reality is that both laws are extreme and do not reflect the views of most Americans. According to a Gallup poll, 60% of Americans support abortion rights in the first trimester, but only 13% do in the third trimester. The debate is complex, and wording matters, as many Americans are conflicted on the issue.

The media has also played a significant role in shaping the narrative, with some outlets focusing on the extreme aspects of both laws. However, this approach can be misleading and does not provide a balanced view of the issue.

The Supreme Court's Roe v. Wade decision has been a lightning rod for controversy, with some viewing it as a necessary protection of women's rights and others seeing it as an overreach of judicial power. The decision has also galvanized the pro-life movement, leading to a more absolutist stance on the issue.

In reality, the debate is not about extreme positions, but about finding a middle ground. Most Americans want a compromise, but the parties are more responsive to activists and donors. The debate has become polarized, with each side seeking to cast the other as extreme.

Ultimately, the debate over abortion is complex and multifaceted, and there is no clear consensus on the issue. However, by examining the facts and avoiding extreme rhetoric, it is possible to find common ground and work towards a more nuanced understanding of this contentious issue.

Title: Amidst Pandemic, a Call for National Unity and Action

As the United States commemorates Memorial Day, the country is faced with an unprecedented crisis, brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic. The virus has ravaged the nation, causing widespread economic devastation, with over 35 million people filing for unemployment benefits and hundreds of thousands of small businesses forced to close their doors. The pandemic has also claimed over 90,000 lives, with many more weakened or crippled by its effects.

The reality of the crisis is stark, with homeowners and renters struggling to pay their mortgages and rent, graduates unable to manage their student loans, and small businesses exhausting their reserves and forced to lay off workers. Front-line workers are dealing with immense stress, while at constant risk of infection. States and localities are facing plummeting revenues and rising costs, leading to layoffs and service cuts.

In this time of crisis, the government must act to organize a collective response, providing medical and protective gear, testing and tracing strategies, and health resources. It must also act to limit the damage, keeping families in their homes, small businesses in operation, and workers employed.

Recent statements from Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Senator Lindsey Graham have sparked concern, with McConnell suggesting that states could go bankrupt and Graham opposing an extension of supplemental unemployment benefits. However, the casualties of the pandemic are not partisan, affecting Republicans and Democrats, liberals and conservatives, small business owners and small farmers, and the most vulnerable populations.

The response to the crisis must be similarly non-partisan, with a focus on common sense solutions. A paycheck guarantee program, championed by some conservative Senate Republicans and progressive House Democrats, would support small business owners in paying their employees, enabling workers to keep their benefits and owners to sustain their teams.

The article concludes by emphasizing the need for leaders to emerge, move beyond their comfort zone, and offer bold responses to the crisis. This is not a moment for posturing, but a time for patriotism, solidarity, and action. As the country commemorates Memorial Day, it is hoped that leaders will remember the challenge and respond accordingly.

Title: Islamic State Militants Launch Attack on Ramadi, Challenging Iraqi Military's Gains

The Islamic State (IS) launched a fierce attack on the city of Ramadi, the capital of Anbar Province, on Wednesday, dealing a setback to the Iraqi military's newly launched offensive in the region. Sunni tribal leaders, who have been holding out in the city, 70 miles west of Baghdad, are reportedly short on weapons and ammunition and under intense pressure from the extremists.

According to Sterling Jensen, an assistant professor at the United Arab Emirates' National Defense College in Abu Dhabi, who keeps in close contact with tribal leaders, the situation is dire. An Iraqi Defense Ministry spokesman, Brig. Gen. Tahseen Ibrahim, acknowledged that the militants have gained a foothold in some areas of Anbar Province, but assured that reinforcements have been dispatched to the region and the situation is under control.

The fighting comes as Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi was visiting Washington, where he asked for additional U.S. support in his government's fight against the Islamic State. The Pentagon reported that Iraq's armed forces, backed by U.S. airstrikes, have reclaimed about 25% of the territory captured by the IS last year.

Residents of Anbar Province said that the militants have captured several villages, including Sjariyah, Albu-Ghanim, and Soufiya, giving them a foothold to launch an attack into the city. The fighting in Anbar is a key test for Iraq's military goal to push the IS out of the country.

The conflict in Anbar is also a test of the Iraqi government's ability to provide support to Sunni tribes, who have been alienated by the country's Shiite-dominated government. Some residents of Anbar have sided with the IS militants because they are fellow Sunnis, while others have fought against them, complaining that Baghdad has not provided them with enough support.

The U.S. has encouraged the Iraqi government to provide the Sunni tribes with arms and other support to carry out the fight against the IS. Meanwhile, al-Abadi expressed concerns about the conflict in Yemen, saying his government is "uneasy" about U.S. military support for Saudi Arabia, which is carrying out airstrikes against Shiite rebels there.

Title: House Speaker Pelosi Accuses Trump of Possible Collusion with Putin, Citing Roger Stone's Indictment

Article:

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) took to social media on Friday to express her concerns about the indictment and arrest of Roger Stone, a former campaign aide to President Donald Trump. Pelosi accused Trump's campaign officials of engaging in a "deliberate, coordinated effort" to subvert the will of the American people during the 2016 election, citing Stone's indictment.

Pelosi also raised questions about whether Russian President Vladimir Putin has leverage over Trump, asking rhetorically, "What does Putin have on @realDonaldTrump, politically, personally or financially?" She implied that Trump's efforts to weaken NATO, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, could be part of Putin's foreign policy schemes.

The speculation that Trump is doing Putin's bidding due to compromising information held against him has been made by some of Trump's critics. However, Trump has denied all allegations of this sort.

Pelosi emphasized the gravity of the crimes alleged against Stone, stating, "Lying to Congress and witness tampering constitute grave crimes. All who commit these illegal acts should be held accountable to the fullest extent of the law." She also emphasized the importance of protecting witnesses and preventing intimidation, saying, "We cannot allow any effort to intimidate witnesses or prevent them from appearing before Congress."

Title: Tax Attorney Gayle Trotter Argues Women Need Guns for Self-Defense, Equates Women with Moms

Article:

Gayle Trotter, a tax attorney and the only woman on a five-member panel at a Senate hearing on gun violence, argued that women need guns to physically defend themselves from larger and stronger male criminals. Trotter stated that the ability to arm oneself is more consequential for women than for men, as guns are the great equalizer in a violent confrontation. She emphasized that safeguarding Second Amendment rights is crucial for women to have a fighting chance.

Trotter's testimony was met with criticism from those seeking to preserve the ban against women in combat, who argue that women are inherently less fit than their male counterparts. Trotter echoed this sentiment, equating women with mothers and stating that banning certain assault weapons would put women at a disadvantage due to their physical limitations. She did not address the biological or emotional concerns raised by former presidential candidates Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich in their arguments against women in combat.

In a June op-ed, Trotter wrote that there are real reasons to avoid putting women in combat, citing the potential for pregnancies and the importance of women's roles as mothers. She asked rhetorically whether the principles of women's liberation embrace jailing mothers for refusing to leave their children behind with strangers, emphasizing the importance of women's roles as caregivers.

Title: Assaults on U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement Agents Reach Decade High

According to a recent report by the Homeland Security inspector general, assaults on U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents and Border Patrol agents have surged in recent years, with 2017 seeing the highest number of assaults in a decade. The report highlights the growing trend of immigrants living in the U.S. illegally resorting to violence rather than fleeing.

The audit found that the most frequent method of attack was projectiles, such as large rocks, which accounted for half of the assaults. Other methods used included bombs, clubs, knives, guns, and even laser pointers to blind agents. While most injuries were minor and did not require treatment, the report signals a renewed danger, particularly on the southwest border.

Customs and Border Protection recorded 1,089 assaults in 2010, which steadily decreased through 2014, when there were 381 assaults. However, the trend reversed, with 856 assaults reported in 2017. Last year was the most violent this decade at the border, with 28 assaults per every 10,000 apprehensions.

In the interior, ICE agents and officers saw 48 assaults in 2017, tying 2010 as the highest in records going back to the beginning of the decade. ICE officers and Border Patrol agents have reported an increasing willingness on the part of migrants to resort to violence in recent years.

The report highlights two specific incidents, one involving Lester Sadict Cruz-Garcia, an immigrant from Honduras who was arrested by police in New York on a domestic assault charge. Deportation officers had to track him down at his home, where he struggled and kicked, attempting to get away. He eventually bit an officer on the arm, requiring hospital treatment. Cruz-Garcia was sentenced to 364 days in jail.

In another incident, ICE officers in Massachusetts were trying to deport Mohammed Kenneh to Liberia. They drove him to Logan International Airport in Boston, but he knocked one officer to the ground and used handcuffs to ensnare the officer's hand, refusing to let go. The officer had to be taken to the emergency room.

The report notes that prosecutors often refuse to bring charges or win cases against the perpetrators, and that the government does not do a good job of tracking incidents, which may be underselling the problem.

Title: Apple and Google Collaborate on Contact Tracing Software to Combat COVID-19

Apple and Google have joined forces to develop software that assists in contact tracing, aiming to help contain the spread of COVID-19. The technology, which includes application programming interfaces (APIs) and operating system-level technology, will enable users to be alerted if they have come into contact with someone who has contracted the virus.

Public health officials have identified contact tracing as a valuable tool in containing the spread of COVID-19, as the virus can be transmitted through close proximity to affected individuals. A number of leading public health authorities, universities, and NGOs around the world have been working to develop opt-in contact tracing technology. Apple and Google's solution will be implemented in two stages. First, in May, the companies will release APIs that enable interoperability between Android and iOS devices using apps from public health authorities. These official apps will be available for users to download via their respective app stores. In the coming months, Apple and Google will work to enable a broader Bluetooth-based contact tracing platform by building this functionality into the underlying platforms.

The technology will allow users to opt-in to contact tracing, with privacy, transparency, and consent being of utmost importance. Apple and Google will openly publish information about their work for others to analyze.

However, some experts have raised concerns about the effectiveness of the "opt-out" feature. Allahpundit, a writer for Hot Air, questioned the ability for users to truly opt-out of data mining, citing the potential for personal information to be collected surreptitiously. The writer noted that even if users opt-out, their movements may still be tracked, and the default setting may be to turn contact tracing on and require users to turn it off.

The technology is modeled after a program used in Germany, which broadcasts different IDs every 30 minutes as someone goes about their day. If a person tests positive for COVID-19, the system would trace which IDs came into contact with the temporary IDs of the coronavirus-positive person and send them an alert that they may have interacted with someone who had COVID-19. However, widespread testing for the virus is still a major challenge, making it difficult to implement this technology effectively.

Title: Senate Passes Sweeping Tax Overhaul, Putting Trump Administration One Step Closer to Major Legislative Victory

The United States Senate voted in the early hours of Saturday morning to pass a comprehensive tax overhaul, worth approximately $1.4 trillion, bringing the Trump administration closer to its first major legislative achievement. The vote was 51-49, with Republican Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee being the only GOP member to side with Democrats in opposition.

The bill, which is not yet finalized, aims to reduce taxes for many Americans and businesses. The Senate and House have passed similar tax reform plans, but negotiators from both chambers will meet on Monday to agree on a single piece of legislation that both chambers must approve before it is sent to the president for his signature.

The Senate bill eliminates federal deductions for state and local income and sales taxes, but allows deductions of up to $10,000 in local property taxes. It also nearly doubles the standard deduction level to $12,000 for individuals and $24,000 for couples. The bill retains the current limit for the home mortgage interest deduction to interest paid on the first $1 million of the loan and preserves the deduction for medical expenses not covered by insurance.

The Senate bill repeals ObamaCare's individual mandate, while the House bill does not. This change is expected to lead to thousands of people dropping their health insurance, increasing costs for those who decide to keep it.

The bill eliminates the $4,050 personal tax exemption and reduces the number of tax brackets from seven to ten. It also allows owners of "pass-through" businesses to deduct 23 percent of their earnings and then pay at their personal income tax rate on the remainder.

The changes will not have any impact on taxes for 2017, which are due to the IRS by April 17, 2018. The differences in the bills will be hashed out in the coming days, with the House voting on a motion to go to conference on Monday evening and the Senate expected to vote on a similar measure soon after.

Title: Secretary of Health and Human Services to Testify Before Congress on ObamaCare Website Issues

The Secretary of Health and Human Services, Kathleen Sebelius, will testify before Congress regarding the problems plaguing the ObamaCare website, according to a top Democratic senator. Senator Dick Durbin, the chamber's No. 2 Democrat, stated that Sebelius will ultimately testify, despite the administration's initial refusal to do so.

The House Energy and Commerce Committee sent a letter to Sebelius last week, requesting her testimony on the matter. However, she has yet to respond publicly, sparking criticism from some lawmakers. Florida Republican Senator Marco Rubio expressed reluctance to call for her immediate dismissal but criticized her for not agreeing to testify, stating that her refusal to do so has undermined her credibility.

House investigators want to know whether officials involved in the website's development knew or disclosed problems, despite repeatedly stating that the site was "on track" to launch. The White House has reported that 476,000 people have applied online for health insurance, but officials have yet to provide information on how many people have purchased a policy.

Missouri Republican Senator Roy Blunt believes Sebelius' position is "unsustainable" and that she will eventually have to testify. Commerce Committee Chairman Fred Upton has also expressed frustration, stating that Sebelius had time to appear on "The Daily Show with Jon Stewart" but not to testify before Congress.

The controversy surrounding the ObamaCare website's issues has led to growing calls for Sebelius to resign. However, it remains to be seen whether her testimony will provide the answers lawmakers are seeking.

**Judge Criticizes Michael Flynn for Lying to FBI, Delays Sentencing**

A U.S. judge has criticized former national security adviser Michael Flynn for lying to FBI agents about his conversations with Russia's ambassador, Sergei Kislyak, in a probe into Russian interference in the 2016 election. U.S. District Judge Emmet Sullivan told Flynn that he had "arguably betrayed his country" and delayed sentencing him until Flynn has finished helping prosecutors.

Flynn pleaded guilty to lying to FBI agents about his December 2016 conversations with Kislyak, which took place between Trump's election victory and his inauguration in January 2017. The conversations were about U.S. sanctions imposed on Moscow by the administration of Trump's Democratic predecessor, Barack Obama.

Special Counsel Robert Mueller, leading the investigation into possible collusion between Trump's campaign and Russia, had asked the judge not to sentence Flynn to prison because he had already provided "substantial" cooperation over the course of many interviews. Lying to the FBI carries a statutory maximum sentence of five years in prison, but Flynn's plea agreement stated that he was eligible for a sentence of between zero and six months.

Sullivan sternly told Flynn that his actions were "abhorrent" and noted that he had also lied to senior White House officials, who in turn misled the public. The judge said he had read additional facts about Flynn's behavior that have not been made public.

Flynn, a retired U.S. Army lieutenant general and former director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, showed little emotion throughout the hearing and spoke calmly when he confirmed his guilty plea and answered questions from the judge. Sullivan appeared ready to sentence Flynn to prison but gave him the option of a delay in his sentencing so he could fully cooperate with any pending investigations and bolster his case for leniency. Flynn accepted the offer, and Sullivan did not set a new date for sentencing but asked Mueller's team and Flynn's attorney to give him a status report by March 13.

Title: California Wildfires: Death Toll Rises to 42, Thousands Flee as Fires Continue to Rage

Article:

The death toll in California's deadliest wildfire has risen to 42, with 228 people still missing, according to officials. The Camp Fire, which started in nearby forest on Thursday, has destroyed nearly 7,200 structures and put 15,500 more at risk. The fire has surpassed the 1933 Griffith Park disaster that killed 31.

The fire has had a devastating impact on the town of Paradise, with many residents forced to flee their homes. Sorrell Bobrink, a Paradise resident, described the scene as "exactly like any apocalyptic movie I have ever seen" and said she had to drive through the fire, which was "awful" and "traumatizing."

Many of the victims are believed to be elderly residents or people with mobility issues who would find evacuating more difficult. Forensic experts are stepping up their search in the ruins of Paradise, but officials warn that finding the bodies could take weeks.

The fire has burned more than 111,000 acres and is nearly 25% contained, while the Woolsey Fire, which started in Thousand Oaks, has consumed at least 85,500 acres and destroyed at least 177 buildings. The smaller Hill Fire has scorched 4,530 acres and is 75% contained.

The California Public Utilities Commission is investigating what sparked the latest blazes, with reports suggesting electrical companies may have suffered malfunctions near the sources shortly before the fires began. Low humidity, warm Santa Ana winds, and dry ground have created a prime fire-spreading environment.

The state's 40 million-strong population, which is almost double what it was in the 1970s, and people living closer to at-risk forest areas, have also contributed to the fires' deadliness. Governor Jerry Brown has declared a "major disaster" in the state, making federal aid available to affected residents.

Thousands of firefighters, some from across the US, have been brought in to help battle the blazes. The fires have also had a significant impact on the state's economy, with more than 300,000 locals forced to flee their homes.

Title: Lawmaker Calls for Impeachment Investigation, Accountability for President

A prominent figure in the government has expressed their opinion on the recent Mueller report and its implications for the current administration. The individual believes that the report contains evidence of obstruction of justice and obstruction of justice, and that Congress should take steps towards impeachment.

The speaker emphasized that if any other individual had engaged in similar actions, they would likely face consequences, including arrest and imprisonment. They believe that Congress has the power to hold the president accountable through the impeachment process and that it is reasonable for them to open up proceedings.

However, the individual also stated that they do not think impeachment proceedings should be a priority at the moment. Instead, they believe that the investigation should continue, with Mueller's testimony and the subpoenaing of individuals mentioned in the report to get to the truth. The speaker emphasized that Congress should take a hard look at the report and conduct a thorough investigation to determine whether the president actually obstructed justice.

The individual also touched on the idea that the best way to resolve outstanding questions may be to wait until the 2020 elections, when the American people can decide the outcome. They believe that a decisive victory at the ballot box could be the most effective way to address the issues and move forward.

In conclusion, the speaker emphasized that the impeachment proceedings are ultimately up to the House, but if they do bring the matter before the Senate, it will be dealt with accordingly.

Title: The Visceral Appeal of Destruction: Understanding the Root of Unruliness

The article discusses the destructive nature of riots and the importance of preventing them. The author reflects on a personal experience of smashing glass as a child, which sparked a visceral appeal to destruction. The article highlights that destruction is not limited to any particular group or class, and that riots become riots because the initial violence gives permission to indulge in the limbic urge to destroy.

The author emphasizes that the time to stop a riot is not when the damage is done, but rather before it happens. They argue that consistent, top-to-bottom police reform is necessary to prevent riots. The article cites the recent events in Minneapolis, where a police officer's actions led to the death of George Floyd, as an example of systemic cultural rot within the police department.

The author suggests that the Minneapolis police union's silence and the department's failure to discipline officers are indicative of a deeper problem. They argue that the police must take responsibility for their actions and root out bad cops within their ranks. The article concludes that genuine police reform is necessary to prevent future riots and that the public must demand it.

The article presents a neutral and factual account of the issue, avoiding personal opinions and subjective language. It provides a balanced view of the topic, highlighting the complexities and nuances of the issue. The author's personal experience and reflections add a human touch to the article, making it more relatable and engaging.

Title: Sen. Dianne Feinstein Clashes with Children Over Climate Change Policy

Sen. Dianne Feinstein, a moderate Democrat, faced off with a group of children over the Green New Deal, a 10-year plan to mitigate climate change, during a meeting on Friday. The senator criticized the children for presenting an ultimatum and emphasized her three decades of experience in office, citing her inability to support the proposal due to its lack of feasibility.

Feinstein expressed her concerns about the plan's cost and feasibility, stating that it would not pass the Senate and that she does not agree with its contents. She also highlighted the importance of tailoring legislation to ensure its passage and garner bipartisan support.

The children, who were passionate about the issue, urged Feinstein to support the deal, with one girl emphasizing that politicians should listen to the people they represent. Feinstein responded by saying that she has been elected by almost a million-vote plurality and knows what she is doing, suggesting that the children should listen to her experience.

The meeting became heated at times, with Feinstein dismissing the children's requests due to their tone and age. The senator also asked a 16-year-old girl how old she was, to which she replied that she was 16. Later, a young woman stressed the need for a climate plan with "bold, transformative action," to which Feinstein replied that she should run for the Senate herself.

After most of the children left, several women remained and had a calm conversation with Feinstein, with one urging her to support the deal despite its lack of immediate passage. The 16-year-old inquired about internship opportunities in Feinstein's office.

In a statement, Feinstein said she "always welcomes the opportunity to hear from Californians who feel passionately about this issue" and remains committed to enacting real, meaningful climate change legislation.

Title: Former President Bill Clinton Delivers Keynote Address at 2012 DNC

Article:

The 2012 Democratic National Convention concluded with a keynote address from former President Bill Clinton, who spoke for nearly 48 minutes. The evening's lineup prior to Clinton's speech was unremarkable, with speakers including Nancy Pelosi and Steny Hoyer, who both spoke for the second time this week. The convention's 10 pm hour was marked by a tedious and unremarkable series of speeches, with a focus on abortion proponents, union bosses, and unremarkable politicians.

Clinton's speech was a highlight of the evening, with the former president making the best case available to Obama backers. He argued that things were really bad when he took office, he inherited an impossible problem, and he's done as well as anyone possibly could have. He also emphasized that things are starting to get better and that Obama is a good guy who needs more time.

Clinton's speech was well-received by the partisan crowd, but some critics noted that it was too long and meandering at times. He addressed a litany of Republican arguments and policies, erecting and destroying straw men along the way. His "arithmetic" was tendentious and incomplete, and he repeated many of the claims FactCheck.org dealt with earlier in the day.

Despite some criticisms, Clinton's speech was still effective in making the case for "four more years" for Obama. The image of the night was Obama striding on stage to hug Clinton as the pair basked in the crowd's adulation, with some speculating that Obama is counting on Clinton's decade-old legacy to save him from his own.

Title: FBI Investigation into Hillary Clinton's Handling of State Secrets Intensifies

Article:

The FBI's investigation into Hillary Clinton's handling of state secrets has taken a significant turn, with new revelations suggesting that she may have received a Special Access Program (SAP) email on her non-secure server. SAP is the highest category of state secrets, and the presence of such an email on her personal server raises serious concerns about her ability to safeguard sensitive information.

According to reports, the SAP-denominated email was found on Clinton's husband's server, which she used to receive all her governmental emails. The FBI is investigating whether Clinton had access to the SAP email and whether she took the necessary precautions to protect it. The presence of the email on her husband's server, whether opened or not, shows a lack of regard for her obligation to maintain the secrecy of state secrets.

Clinton has claimed that she may not have known what she was doing with her emails, but this is not a viable defense. Failure to safeguard state secrets is a crime, and Clinton signed an oath on her first day as secretary of state acknowledging her responsibility to protect sensitive information. The FBI is investigating whether Clinton's actions were negligent or intentional, and the consequences could be severe.

The FBI is also investigating Clinton's use of her position to advance her husband's charitable foundation, which has raised concerns about her potential conflicts of interest. The investigation is ongoing, and the FBI will soon reveal its findings.

In the meantime, the public is left to wonder what type of data is typically protected by the SAP denomination. The most sensitive information, including the names of moles and their American handlers, codes needed to access state secrets, and ongoing intelligence gathering projects, are all protected by SAP. The exposure of SAPs can have serious consequences, including the potential for national security breaches.

The FBI's investigation into Clinton's handling of state secrets is a serious matter, and the consequences could be severe. The public will have to wait and see what the FBI's findings are, but one thing is clear: the rule of law in America will be put to the test.

Title: Mitt Romney Embarks on Six-State Bus Tour, Focuses on Connecting with Middle-Class Voters

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, arrived in Pennsylvania on Saturday, kicking off the second leg of his six-state bus tour. The tour aims to connect with undecided voters in battleground states, including Pennsylvania, Ohio, Wisconsin, Michigan, and Iowa. Romney's message focuses on putting America back to work and restoring the American Dream.

During his visit to the Weatherly Casting and Machine Company, Romney shared a story about a local businessman who took out a second mortgage to start a business, which now employs around 110 people. He emphasized the importance of supporting entrepreneurs and creating jobs. "Let's put America back to work again with those kinds of dreams," he said.

Romney's tour began in New Hampshire and will continue to Ohio, Wisconsin, Michigan, and Iowa. His second scheduled stop in Pennsylvania was moved to a nearby Agway convenience store due to a counter rally held by former Democratic Gov. Ed Rendell. Romney joked about the change, saying he didn't want to compete with Rendell's event.

The candidate also responded to President Obama's announcement to suspend deportation for hundreds of thousands of young, illegal immigrants. Romney stated that an executive order does not provide a long-term solution and emphasized the need for a comprehensive approach. This response was softer than his previous stance on the issue during the GOP primary campaign.

Romney's bus tour is his first traditional campaign, and he will be joined by former Minnesota Gov. Tim Pawlenty and Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, both considered potential vice presidential candidates. Pennsylvania has not been a Republican stronghold since 1988, and Romney's visit aims to connect with middle-class voters in the state.

Title: Walmart Introduces In-Store Health Clinic with Transparent Pricing

Walmart, the retail giant, has opened its first in-store clinic, Walmart Health, in Dallas, Georgia, offering primary medical, dental, vision, and mental health care services. The clinic is a pilot project aimed at providing basic health care to Americans, with a focus on transparency and affordability. The pricing list is publicly available, showing that basic check-ups will cost $30 (or $20 for children), while flu testing and routine vision exams will cost $20 and $40, respectively.

The clinic will be staffed with medical professionals capable of handling various services, including immunizations, counseling sessions, lab testing, and X-rays. This move marks a significant step forward for Walmart, which already operates smaller clinics in 19 stores offering flu shots and basic health care services. The new clinic is over 10,000 square feet, compared to the smaller clinics, which average around 1,500 square feet.

Walmart's entry into the health care market is part of a growing trend in the private sector, with CVS and Walgreens already offering small-scale clinics in some retail locations. If Walmart succeeds, it could bring more competition and convenience to the health care market.

Elise Amez-Droz, a health care policy associate at the Mercatus Center, a think tank based at George Mason University, believes that Walmart's approach demonstrates that the private sector can deliver high-quality, transparently priced health care services without government intervention. "The best way to cater to our varying needs is to let patients have the final say in their health care decisions, shopping for better value and reaping the benefits in the form of better care and savings," Amez-Droz said.

Access to health care is often overlooked in the national debate, which tends to focus on providing insurance rather than health care itself. Insurance is important, but it's useless if there are no providers nearby. Walmart's new clinics aim to address this issue, with about 90% of the U.S. population living within 10 miles of a Walmart store.

The pricing model Walmart is introducing could also disrupt the traditional health care system. While the company will accept most major insurance plans, the low, transparent prices will allow many customers to pay out-of-pocket for basic care. This could be a significant change, as the lack of transparency in health care prices often encourages the inflation of health care costs and overconsumption of health care.

Title: Sessions to Testify Before Senate Intelligence Committee Amid Controversy Over Russian Contacts

Article:

Former Republican Senator Jeff Sessions, now the Attorney General, is set to testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee on Tuesday, sparking another media frenzy on Capitol Hill. The controversy surrounding potential contacts between the Trump campaign and Moscow has intensified, with Sessions' remarks last week about a potential third meeting between Sessions and a top Russian official threatening to drag him deeper into the controversy.

The White House has sent mixed signals about how open Sessions will be with lawmakers. White House counselor Kellyanne Conway stated that Sessions is willing to cooperate and share what he knows, while Press Secretary Sean Spicer declined to rule out Sessions' invocation of executive privilege during his testimony, saying it depends on the scope of the questions.

The focus of Sessions' testimony will likely be on whether he had a third meeting with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak, which Comey claimed he may have had. The Justice Department has denied any private or side conversations between Sessions and Kislyak, stating that the then-senator did not have any such conversations at the Mayflower Hotel.

Sessions will also face questions about when he decided to recuse himself from the investigation into Russian election meddling, which includes a review of potential ties between the Trump campaign and Moscow. Comey testified that the FBI had expected Sessions to step back from the investigation even before his recusal on March 2, citing facts that would make it "problematic" for Sessions to oversee the probe.

The Justice Department has stressed that Sessions began consulting with career department officials shortly after he was confirmed about stepping back from the investigation, and his decision was based only on his status as a Trump campaign supporter. Sessions' decision to recuse himself from the probe reportedly strained his relationship with President Trump, and senators will likely ask him about reports that he offered to resign.

The controversy surrounding Sessions' meetings with Russian officials has sparked intense scrutiny, with Democrats arguing that he would have violated his pledge to recuse himself from the Russia probe if he was involved in Comey's firing. The Justice Department disputes Comey's version of their conversation, saying the then-FBI director told Sessions that the FBI wanted to make sure it was following the "proper communications protocol" and that Sessions "was not silent."

Title: President Obama Discusses Political Polarization and the 2016 Election

President Barack Obama held a joint press conference with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at the White House, where he made extended comments on the 2016 election and its unprecedented political polarization. The President emphasized that he does not take responsibility for the Republican Party's primaries and the selection of their candidates.

"I have been blamed by the Republicans for a lot of things," Obama said, "but to be blamed for their primaries and who they are selecting is... novel." He also stated that he does not think he was the one to prompt questions about his birth certificate or other personal matters.

The President acknowledged that he has expressed regret over the increasing polarization and negative tone of politics during his time in office. However, he also emphasized that the Republican Party's political elites, information outlets, social media, television stations, and talk radio have been fueling the notion that everything he does is to be opposed, and that cooperation or compromise is a betrayal.

"This is not something that I have contributed to," Obama said. "I don't think that I was the one to prompt questions about my birth certificate, for example. I don't remember saying, 'Hey, why don't you ask me about that.' Why don't you question whether I'm American or whether I'm loyal or whether I have America's best interests at heart?"

The President noted that the environment created by these efforts over time has allowed someone like Donald Trump to thrive. "He's just doing more of what has been done for the last seven and a half years," Obama said. "In fact, in terms of his positions on a whole range of issues, they're not very different from any of the other candidates."

When asked about his potential endorsement in the presidential election, Obama declined to comment, stating that he will not validate the notion that his actions have contributed to the Republican Party's polarization.

Title: Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker Testifies Before House Committee Amid Tensions

Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker faced intense questioning and criticism during a contentious House hearing on Friday, as lawmakers sought answers about his oversight of the Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia probe. The hearing was marked by a series of tense exchanges between Whitaker and Democratic lawmakers, with some Republicans criticizing the proceedings as a "dog and pony show."

Whitaker's testimony was the subject of much anticipation, as Democrats are keen to learn more about his involvement in the Mueller investigation and whether he has interfered with the probe. Whitaker repeatedly denied any interference, stating that he had not talked to President Trump or any White House officials about the investigation.

The hearing began with a dramatic exchange between Whitaker and Democratic Chairman Jerrold Nadler, who pressed Whitaker on whether he had been asked to approve any requests or actions related to the special counsel's investigation. Whitaker responded by saying he had not been asked to approve anything and that he had not interfered in any way.

The hearing continued with Whitaker refusing to answer several questions, including whether he had shared information about the investigation with Trump or any White House officials. Nadler repeatedly asked Whitaker to provide clear answers, but the acting attorney general declined, leading to a series of tense exchanges.

The hearing was also marked by a dispute over whether Whitaker had properly answered questions, with some lawmakers accusing him of not providing clear and direct answers. At one point, Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, D-Texas, pressed Whitaker on whether he had appeared before the committee for an oversight hearing, and he responded by saying he had not.

The hearing comes as the Senate is close to confirming President Trump's nominee for attorney general, William Barr, and as the Justice Department has been under scrutiny for its handling of the Mueller investigation. The hearing is the committee's first major oversight hearing looking at the Justice Department of this Congress.

In his testimony, Whitaker said that he had not interfered in any way with the special counsel's investigation and that he had not talked to the president or any White House officials about the investigation. He also stated that he had not made any promises or commitments regarding the Mueller investigation.

The hearing ended with Nadler requesting that Whitaker return to the committee at a later date to provide more answers, and the acting attorney general agreeing to do so. The hearing was a dramatic and intense display of the ongoing tensions between the Justice Department and Congress over the Mueller investigation.

Title: Supreme Court Rules Bladensburg Peace Cross Can Remain, Citing Consecration by Public Devotion

The Supreme Court has ruled that the Bladensburg Peace Cross, a 40-foot Latin cross standing on public park land in Prince George's County, Maryland, can remain, citing its consecration by nearly 100 years of public devotion. The ruling was a 7-2 decision, with Justice Samuel A. Alito writing the key opinion.

The cross, erected by the American Legion, was challenged by the American Humanist Association, which argued that it violated the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment. However, the court found that the cross has earned "special significance" over the years as a war memorial and expression of a community's grief for its lost sons.

Justice Alito stated that removing the cross would be an affront to the community and the First Amendment, and that the presence of the cross on the land where it has stood for so many years is fully consistent with the aim of the Constitution's Religion Clauses to foster a society in which people of all beliefs can live together harmoniously.

The ruling did not provide a clear framework for addressing hundreds of other religion-themed memorials across the country, leaving them to be fought over one by one. Justice Stephen G. Breyer agreed with the main ruling but noted that each memorial must be taken on its own facts and that Thursday's opinion does not guarantee they are all permissible.

The ruling was the latest blow to the "Lemon test," the Supreme Court's 1971 framework for deciding religion-state entanglements. Justice Alito suggested that there should be a "presumption of constitutionality for long-standing monuments" on public grounds, but only two other justices joined him in that part of the opinion.

The ruling has sparked debate among religious liberty advocates, with some calling it a landmark decision and others expressing concerns about the government's endorsement of religion. The American Humanist Association, which lost the case, took solace in the court's limited ruling, while Americans United for Separation of Church and State called the decision "misguided."

Title: Supreme Court's End-of-Term Crunch: A Study Examines the Pattern of Big Cases

The Supreme Court's tendency to decide significant cases towards the end of its term has long been observed, with many noting that the court's final days of the term feel like a "sweeps week" on network television. According to Geoffrey R. Stone, a law professor at the University of Chicago and former clerk to Justice William J. Brennan Jr., "it's inconceivable" that the court would delay opinions when they are ready. However, a new study published in The Duke Law Journal has attempted to quantify this phenomenon.

The study, which analyzed 7,219 cases from 1946 to 2013, found that while it is true that many cases are decided in June, with over 30% of decisions issued during the month and over half of those in the last week, the question remains whether big cases are disproportionately likely to come late. To answer this, the study used several measures of significance, including front-page coverage, the number of friend-of-the-court briefs filed, and how often the decision was cited in later Supreme Court opinions.

The study's findings confirmed that big decisions are indeed disproportionately likely to come in late June, according to these measures. The study's results provide insight into the court's decision-making process, suggesting that the court uses as much time as it has to decide the most important cases, as noted by Deanne E. Maynard, a lawyer with Morrison & Foerster and former law clerk to Justices Lewis F. Powell Jr. and Stephen G. Breyer.

Title: Trump Warns Iran Against Threats, Citing "Consequences Like Few Have Ever Suffered"

The article reports on a tweet sent by President Donald Trump to Iranian President Hassan Rouhani, warning him against threatening the United States again. The tweet, sent in all capital letters, reads: "NEVER, EVER THREATEN THE UNITED STATES AGAIN. WE ARE NO LONGER A COUNTRY THAT WILL STAND FOR YOUR DEMENTED WORDS OF VIOLENCE & DEATH. BE CAUTIOUS!"

The tweet was sent after Rouhani warned the US against pursuing a hostile policy against his government, stating that "war with Iran is the mother of all wars." Trump's tweet was supported by White House staff members, with Press Secretary Sarah Sanders stating that the president was not inciting a confrontation and that "the only person that is inciting anything is Iran."

National Security Adviser John Bolton also weighed in, saying that Trump told him that if Iran does anything negative, they will pay a price like few countries have ever paid before. In Iran, government officials avoided responding directly to Trump's tweet, with the head of the voluntary Basij paramilitary force, Gholamhossein Gharibpour, stating that Trump's words were merely psychological warfare.

The article also mentions comments made by US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who called Iran's ruling elite a "mafia" and accused them of amassing vast sums of wealth while allowing their people to suffer. Pompeo also criticized Iran's religious leaders, calling them "hypocritical holy men."

Title: Millennials' Incomes Stagnant, Reflecting Poor Timing in Job Market

The article discusses the current state of young adults' incomes in the United States, specifically those between the ages of 25 and 34. According to data from the Census Bureau and analyzed by Young Invincibles, a non-profit organization, salaries in four of the top five employment sectors have declined: retail, leisure and hospitality, manufacturing, and professional and business services. The only exception is the healthcare industry, where salaries have remained flat.

The article notes that the hiring climate has been poor in recent years, leading to stagnant incomes even in industries experiencing labor shortages. For those working in non-hiring industries, incomes have decreased. The median annual income for young adults is $30,759, the lowest in inflation-adjusted terms since 1995.

The article also highlights the impact of debt, particularly student loans, on millennials' financial situation. While millennials are not significantly worse off than previous generations in terms of pay, they are struggling to pay off a larger amount of debt.

The article provides data and statistics to support its claims, including a graph showing the median household income for households up to age 40. The article also notes that middle-aged and older workers are facing similar challenges, and that the problem is not unique to millennials.

Overall, the article presents a neutral and factual analysis of the current state of young adults' incomes in the United States, highlighting the challenges they face and the impact of debt on their financial situation.

Title: US Officials on High Alert for Possible North Korean Missile Launch

Article:

US officials are bracing for a possible missile launch from North Korea in the coming days, which has been referred to as a "Christmas gift" by Pyongyang. This potential launch would mark the end of North Korea's self-imposed moratorium on missile tests and would be a significant blow to one of President Trump's major foreign policy goals to get North Korea back to the negotiating table to eliminate its nuclear weapons.

Earlier this month, North Korea conducted an engine test, which experts believe may have involved an engine for a long-range missile. North Korea has been advancing its capabilities, building new missiles and testing new technologies, according to Anthony Wier, a former State Department official who tracks nuclear disarmament.

North Korea warned of a possible "Christmas gift" in early December, stating that the Trump administration was running out of time on nuclear negotiations and that it was up to the US to choose what "Christmas gift" it gets from Pyongyang. Victor Cha, a Korea expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, believes that a review of the possible launch sites in North Korea shows they are "basically ready to go."

Defense Secretary Mark Esper told reporters earlier this week that the US has heard all the talk of a possible upcoming test around Christmas. "I've been watching the Korean Peninsula for a quarter-century now. I'm familiar with their tactics, with their bluster," he said. "We need to get serious and sit down and have discussions about a political agreement that denuclearizes the peninsula. That is the best way forward and arguably the only way forward if we're going to do something constructive."

Army Gen. Mark Milley, the chairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff, stated that the US, Japan, and South Korea are ready to defend against any move by North Korea. "We always maintain very high levels of readiness," he said.

The US military has reported that North Korea has launched more than 20 missiles this year, including new types of missiles and a submarine-launched ballistic missile, in violation of UN Security Council resolutions. In 2017, North Korea conducted a torrent of missile tests, including flying two intermediate-range missiles over Japan and threatening to fire those weapons toward the US territory of Guam. However, those ICBM tests showed no clear sign that the North had perfected the technology needed to ensure a warhead could survive atmospheric re-entry.

The US has a team on the Korean peninsula that has asked North Korea for meetings, while the US military remains at a high level of readiness. A key discussion point has been the reduction in US military exercises with South Korea, a move by the Trump administration to appease North Korea and woo them to the negotiating table for denuclearization talks.

Title: China Imposes Tariffs on US Imports in Retaliation to US Steel and Aluminium Tariffs

China has imposed tariffs on up to $3 billion worth of US imports, including pork and wine, in response to the US decision to raise duties on steel and aluminium imports in March. The tariffs, which take effect on Monday, are a retaliatory measure aimed at safeguarding China's interests and balancing losses caused by the new US tariffs.

The US had previously announced plans to impose duties on up to $60 billion of Chinese imports and limit its investment in the US, citing unfair trading practices and intellectual property theft. China's theft of foreign intellectual property, including the theft of intellectual property from international companies, has been a long-standing issue, with the US citing the need for tougher measures to address the problem.

The tariffs imposed by China include a 25% increase on US scrap aluminium and frozen pork, as well as a 15% increase on several other American foods, including nuts, fresh and dried fruit, ginseng, and wine. Rolled steel bars will also see a 15% rise in duties.

The US has already announced plans for further targeted tariffs on tens of billions of dollars of Chinese imports, citing unfair trading practices and intellectual property theft. The move raises the possibility of yet more action being taken in what has become a tit-for-tat trade battle.

The tariffs are the latest development in a growing trade dispute between the US and China, with both sides imposing tariffs on each other's goods. The US has imposed tariffs on steel and aluminium imports from China, while China has retaliated with tariffs on US imports. The dispute has raised concerns about the potential impact on global trade and the economy.

It remains to be seen whether China will follow its opening gambit with stronger measures, such as taxing US tech companies like Apple. Such a move could force US tech giants to raise their prices to compensate.

Title: US President Calls for Calm in Ferguson, Missouri, After Shooting of Black Teenager

The shooting of a 18-year-old black teenager, Michael Brown, by police in Ferguson, Missouri, has sparked two nights of unrest and violence in the St. Louis suburb. US President Barack Obama has appealed for calm and described the death as "heartbreaking." The incident has led to widespread protests and demands for police transparency.

On Tuesday night, a community forum was held at Christ the King United Church of Christ, where Missouri Governor Jay Nixon and Ferguson's mayor and police chief attended. The governor described the shooting as "an old wound torn fresh," and the mayor and police chief were greeted with applause.

Civil rights activist Reverend Al Sharpton also appealed for peace, saying that becoming violent in Michael Brown's name would be a betrayal of the "gentle giant" he was. He also demanded that police reveal the name of the officer who shot and killed Brown. Sharpton joined others in calling for an objective investigation, as police have not named the officer due to death threats on social media.

Protests during the day on Tuesday were peaceful but tense, following a night of unrest in which police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse a large crowd. Thirty-two people were arrested on Sunday night after looting shops, vandalizing cars and stores, and setting a building on fire. The FBI is investigating the shooting, and US Attorney General Eric Holder has said the case deserves a "fulsome review." The justice department has also sent its community relations team to the area.

Title: The Unusual Origins of Labor Day: A Holiday Born from Unionization and Economic Turmoil

Article:

Labor Day, a federal holiday in the United States, is often seen as the unofficial end of summer and the beginning of fall. However, its origins are shrouded in a unique blend of labor unionization and economic turmoil. The holiday was first proposed by Peter J. McGuire, a carpenter and union leader, in the late 19th century.

McGuire's idea was to create a special day for all workers, which would not only provide a time of leisure but also permit unions to add to their numbers and image through parades and demonstrations. The first Labor Day was celebrated in New York City on September 5, 1882, and was supported by the United Brotherhood of Carpenters.

However, the holiday gained national recognition only after the Pullman Strike of 1894, which was a major railway strike that began in May 1894. The strike, led by the American Railway Union and its leader, Eugene V. Debs, was sparked by the Pullman Palace Car Company's decision to cut wages while maintaining rents. The strike spread to trains across 27 states, and the federal government ultimately dispatched troops, leading to Debs' conviction and imprisonment.

In the midst of the strike, Congress passed a bill establishing Labor Day as a national holiday, which was signed by President Grover Cleveland in 1894. The holiday was intended to provide a day off for workers, rather than a celebration of unionism specifically.

Interestingly, neither McGuire nor Debs played a significant role in subsequent Labor Day celebrations. McGuire was ousted from the United Brotherhood of Carpenters in 1901, and Debs spent time in jail for violating the Espionage Act during World War I.

Despite the efforts of union leaders, Labor Day became a celebration for all workers, not just those carrying union cards. The holiday has since become a time for Americans to enjoy the end of summer and the beginning of fall, rather than a specific celebration of labor unionization.

Title: Trump Tweets About Media Coverage of His First 100 Days

The White House is preparing for a report card from the press on President Trump's first 100 days in office, with the president himself taking to Twitter to express his dissatisfaction with the media's coverage of his accomplishments. In a tweet, Trump stated that "no matter how much I accomplish during the ridiculous standard of the first 100 days, & it has been a lot (including S.C.), media will kill!"

The first 100 days of a president's term is often seen as a benchmark for measuring success and setting a roadmap for future policy issues. This concept dates back to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, who signed 76 pieces of legislation during his first 100 days in office, including 15 major overhauls and new programs during the Great Depression.

Trump had promised significant changes during his first 100 days, including cracking down on illegal immigration, a complete tax overhaul, and the repeal and replace of ObamaCare. However, so far, the Trump administration has not been able to deliver on all of these promises, with the two branches of government not always being on the same page.

White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer defended the Trump administration's accomplishments, stating, "Look at the record that he's achieved over these first 90 days... It's very clear that he's committed to the conservative principles and agenda that he outlined in the campaign."

Title: YouTube Shooting Suspect's Father Blames Company for Daughter's Actions

The shooting that occurred at YouTube's headquarters in San Bruno, California, has left three people injured and the suspect, Nasim Aghdam, dead. According to her father, Ismail Aghdam, the 39-year-old woman was furious with the company because it had stopped paying her for videos she posted on the platform. Ismail Aghdam reported his daughter missing on Monday after she did not answer her phone for two days. He warned authorities that she might be headed to YouTube because she "hated" the company.

Police identified the shooter as Nasim Aghdam and said they had a run-in with her earlier in the day. Mountain View Police spokeswoman Katie Nelson confirmed that officers located a woman by the same name asleep in a vehicle in a Mountain View parking lot on Tuesday morning. The woman declined to answer further questions.

Aghdam reportedly maintained a personal website alleging that YouTube compensated her unfairly and censored her views. Authorities are still investigating the motive behind the shooting and have not found any indication that the victims knew the shooter.

The website, which appears to be Aghdam's personal blog, contains several screenshots purportedly showing her YouTube user account page. The screenshots suggest that at least one of her YouTube accounts had been "de-monetized," meaning she was not earning significant revenue from her uploads to the site. The company "de-monetizes" some channels for reasons including inappropriate material or having fewer than 1,000 subscribers.

The website also espouses veganism and includes videos apparently showing animals being skinned and cooked alive. Aghdam's YouTube videos had been removed from the site by Tuesday evening for violating the company's terms of service. Her personal website remained online.

The shooting spree left terrified YouTube employees huddled inside, calling 911, as officers and federal agents swarmed the company's suburban campus. YouTube employee Dianna Arnspiger said she was on the building's second floor when she heard gunshots, ran to a window, and saw the shooter on a patio outside. She described the woman as wearing glasses and a scarf and using a "big huge pistol."

Title: Trump Spokesperson Defends Candidate's Flip-Flopping on Women's Issues

Article:

Donald Trump's spokesperson, Katrina Pierson, appeared on Megyn Kelly's show, The Kelly File, to defend her candidate's recent policy and position reversals. The topic of discussion centered around Trump's inconsistent stances on issues related to women, including his views on the war in Afghanistan, Obamacare, and abortion.

Kelly highlighted several instances where Trump had changed his position on these topics, prompting Pierson to argue that Trump is a "non-scripted politician" who often speaks off the cuff. Pierson also claimed that Trump's statement on abortion indicated he did not want to punish women for having an illegal abortion.

However, Kelly pressed Pierson on the issue, asking why Trump had initially said he wanted to punish women for having an illegal abortion. Pierson did not directly address the question, instead shifting the focus to the "anti-Trump movement" and the media's alleged bias against Trump.

The conversation also touched on Trump's low approval ratings among women, with Kelly pointing out that Mitt Romney, who had a 51% disapproval rate, still managed to secure 44% of the vote in the 2012 presidential election. Kelly asked how Trump would improve his chances with women, given his 73% disapproval rate.

The exchange between Kelly and Pierson highlighted the ongoing concerns about Trump's ability to articulate consistent policy positions, particularly on issues related to women.

Title: NPR's Coverage of State Department's Investigation into Hillary Clinton's Emails Falls Short

NPR's coverage of the State Department's investigation into Hillary Clinton's emails has been criticized for being incomplete and lacking in digital presence. The investigation, which concluded in 2016, found no "persuasive evidence of systemic, deliberate mishandling of classified information." However, the report did identify 38 current or former employees who sent classified information to Clinton's personal email account, with some potentially facing discipline.

The investigation was covered by NPR in the past, particularly during the 2016 election cycle. However, the recent development was only reported in newscasts, with no digital story or news magazine report available online. This has left some listeners and readers feeling that the story has been under-covered.

NPR's newsroom leaders defended their decision to cover the story only in newscasts, citing the crush of other important news and stretched resources. However, some critics argue that the story is still relevant and important, especially given the ongoing impeachment inquiry and the fact that the State Department's investigation has finally concluded.

The investigation's findings may not be as newsworthy as some other stories, but it is still a significant development in the saga that has been ongoing since 2016. The affected parties, including the senders of the now-classified emails, may also be impacted by the conclusion of the investigation.

NPR's failure to provide a digital report on the story has left some readers feeling that the story has been under-covered. The lack of an archived transcript of the newscasts also means that many listeners may not have been aware of the development. While NPR's newsroom leaders may have made a judgment call to prioritize other stories, it is still important for the public to have access to this information.

Title: Rubio Guides Trump's Cuba Policy Unveiling, Forging Pragmatic Relationship

Article:

Florida Senator Marco Rubio has emerged as a key confidant of President Donald Trump, playing a crucial role in shaping the administration's policy towards Cuba. The senator's ascendant role was underscored when he joined Trump on Air Force One as they flew over the Everglades, a region Rubio has long advocated for preserving. The moment highlighted the senator's growing influence within the administration, as well as his ability to find common ground with the president despite their past differences.

Rubio's relationship with Trump has evolved significantly since the 2016 presidential campaign, when the two traded barbs and insults. However, they have since found common ground on issues such as Cuba, China, and Venezuela. Trump has expressed his "deep gratitude" to Rubio, calling him "a man who has really become a friend of mine."

While other Republican senators, such as John McCain, Ben Sasse, and Susan Collins, have publicly criticized the president, Rubio has kept his powder dry, focusing on finding ways to work with Trump to advance his legislative agenda. The senator has been a frequent visitor to the White House, having dined or met with Trump or Vice President Pence several times.

Rubio's decision to return to the Senate after pledging to leave politics has given him a new appreciation for the position, and he has found an ally in the Oval Office. The senator has been a key player in shaping the administration's policy towards Cuba, and his relationship with Trump has allowed him to advance his agenda on Florida issues and foreign affairs.

Despite some differences on issues such as Russia and human rights, Rubio has chosen not to publicly slam the president, recognizing that his agenda has a better chance of success with Trump in the fold. The senator's willingness to work with the administration has earned him praise from lobbyists and political analysts, who see his relationship with Trump as a pragmatic and effective partnership.

Title: U.S.-Israeli Relations Show Signs of Strain as Gaza Conflict Escalates

The relationship between the United States and Israel has been experiencing growing tensions as the Israeli military operation against Hamas in the Gaza Strip enters its third week. The latest sign of strain came in a statement from the White House, which described a call between President Barack Obama and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. The statement highlighted the U.S. concern about the rising number of Palestinian civilian deaths and the worsening humanitarian situation in Gaza, as well as the loss of Israeli lives.
