The statement also emphasized the need for an immediate and unconditional humanitarian cease-fire, which has been a point of contention between the U.S. and Israel. The U.S. has been pushing for a cease-fire, while Israel has been resistant, citing security concerns.

The tensions between the two countries have been building for months, with the breakdown of the Israeli-Palestinian peace process and the discovery of the bodies of three Israeli teenagers, which led to the current wave of fighting and rocket attacks. The U.S. has been critical of Israel's response, while Israel has felt that the U.S. has not been supportive enough.

The situation is further complicated by the ongoing negotiations between the U.S. and five international powers and Iran over the Iranian nuclear program. Israel is concerned about the potential for Iran to continue enriching uranium, while the U.S. is pushing for a deal that would limit Iran's nuclear capabilities.

The diplomatic dance between the U.S. and Israel is not occurring in a vacuum, with both sides having different priorities and concerns. The U.S. is focused on finding a long-term solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, while Israel is more concerned about the immediate security threats posed by Hamas and Iran. As the situation continues to escalate, it is unclear what the future holds for U.S.-Israeli relations.

Title: US Government Proposes Collecting Social Media Identities from Visa Applicants

The United States Department of State has proposed a new rule that would require most immigrant and non-immigrant visa applicants to provide a list of their social media identities from the past five years. The proposal, if approved by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), would affect approximately 14.7 million people annually.

According to the proposal, the collected information would be used to vet and identify applicants, with the goal of preventing terrorism. The new rule would expand on previous guidelines, which required consular officials to collect social media identifiers only when deemed necessary to confirm identity or conduct more rigorous national security vetting.

The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has expressed concerns about the proposal, citing potential chilling effects on freedom of speech and association. Hina Shamsi, director of the ACLU's National Security Project, stated, "People will now have to wonder if what they say online will be misconstrued or misunderstood by a government official." The ACLU is also concerned about the definition of "terrorist activities" and its potential to be used to discriminate against immigrants from Muslim-majority countries.

The proposal was published in the Federal Register on Friday, and the public has 60 days to comment on the revised procedures before the OMB approves or rejects them. If approved, the measures would also require applicants to submit five years of previously used telephone numbers, email addresses, and international travel history. Additionally, applicants would be asked if they have been deported or removed from any country and whether family members have been involved in terrorist activities. The Department of State intends not to routinely ask most diplomatic and official visa applicants for the additional information.

Title: US and Russia Press Ahead with Syria Peace Conference Despite Setbacks

The United States and Russia are pushing forward with plans to co-host a Syria peace conference in Geneva, despite setbacks and challenges. The conference, originally scheduled for this month, has been met with skepticism due to the Syrian government's defiance and the opposition's refusal to participate.

In a recent interview, Syrian President Bashar al-Assad expressed confidence that he would receive sophisticated Russian anti-aircraft missiles, which has raised concerns about the effectiveness of the peace talks. The main Syrian opposition group, the National Coalition, has announced that it will not participate in any negotiations as long as Hezbollah and Iran are fighting on behalf of the Assad regime.

The US State Department has reiterated its commitment to the peace conference, stating that it is a key element of the Obama administration's "two-track" policy to address the Syrian conflict. However, some experts believe that the US is simply playing into Russia's plan to forestall a more robust US intervention in Syria.

Senior US diplomats will meet with Russian and UN officials next week to continue planning for the conference, which may now be pushed back to July. The US has not specified what Russia's motivations are for delivering sophisticated weaponry to the Assad regime, but has emphasized that Russia has accepted the need for a "political transition" in Syria.

The conflict in Syria has resulted in over 100,000 deaths and is expected to continue to escalate, with the main opposition group refusing to participate in negotiations unless Assad steps down from power. The US has been criticized for not taking a more decisive role in the conflict, with some experts calling for a no-fly zone or arming the rebels.

Title: Former Obama White House Counsel Greg Craig Goes on Trial Over Ukraine Work

Former Obama White House counsel Greg Craig is set to go on trial on Monday, accused of making false statements related to his work on behalf of powerful interests in Ukraine. Craig, a top attorney in Democratic political circles who worked for two Democratic presidents, was indicted in April on one count of providing false statements to the Justice Department. The judge presiding over the case threw out one of the counts last week, but Craig will still face trial on the remaining count.

The case against Craig was born out of the Mueller investigation, which uncovered evidence of alleged wrongdoing by Craig. The investigation found that Craig had failed to register his work with the Justice Department, as required by the Foreign Agents Registration Act (FARA). The law requires individuals to disclose their work on behalf of foreign entities and to provide accurate information to the Justice Department.

Prosecutors allege that Craig withheld information he knew he should have provided to the department and provided other information that was incorrect. Craig's lawyers have denied any wrongdoing, calling the government's prosecution a "misguided abuse of prosecutorial discretion."

The case dates back to Craig's work for Ukraine's pro-Russian government in 2012, when he and his law firm, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, drew up a report on the government's prosecution of former Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko. The report was later used to shape early international coverage of the case.

Craig's trial is expected to last 2 1/2 weeks, with jury selection set to begin on Monday.

Title: Giuliani Clarifies Payment to Adult-Film Star, Trump Says He's Not Aware of Details

Article:

Former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani, who joined President Donald Trump's legal team in April, issued a statement on Friday clarifying his previous comments about a $130,000 payment made to adult-film star Stormy Daniels, whose real name is Stephanie Clifford. The payment was made by Trump's personal lawyer, Michael Cohen, in 2016 to keep Daniels quiet about an alleged 2006 sexual encounter with Trump.

Giuliani stated that the payment was not an election law violation, as it was made to resolve a "personal and false allegation" to protect the President's family. He added that the payment would have been made regardless of whether Trump was a candidate or not.

In a TV interview on Thursday, Giuliani had raised the possibility that the transaction may have violated federal election law, sparking controversy. However, Trump seemed to undercut Giuliani's comments, saying that Giuliani "just started a day ago" and is "learning the subject matter."

Trump also stated that Giuliani will "get his facts straight" but did not specify which statements he was referring to. Giuliani's statement on Friday did not provide specifics about Trump's knowledge of the payment.

The controversy surrounding the payment and Giuliani's comments has intensified the scrutiny of Trump's legal troubles, which include investigations into potential collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia and allegations of obstruction of justice.

Title: Obama and McConnell Discuss Potential Areas of Agreement, but Diverge on Key Issues

Article:

In a rare display of bipartisanship, President Barack Obama and incoming Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell have agreed to work together on certain issues, despite their differences. During a phone call and a planned lunch, they discussed potential areas of agreement, including trade and tax reform. However, their conversation was marked by diverging views on key issues, such as immigration reform and the Affordable Care Act.

Obama expressed willingness to "drink Kentucky bourbon" with McConnell and engage in other efforts to improve his relationship with congressional Republicans. However, he emphasized that the next move was up to McConnell and House Speaker John Boehner. McConnell, on the other hand, vowed to continue fighting against Obama's signature healthcare law and promised to move ahead on the Keystone pipeline.

The two leaders also disagreed on the minimum wage increase, with Obama pushing for it and McConnell opposing it. Obama also mentioned that he would not wait for Congress to pass a bill on immigration reform, as he believes it is essential to take action.

The election results, which saw the Republican Party gain control of the Senate and expand their House majority, have set up a new dynamic in Washington. Republicans are now faced with the challenge of proving to their base that they can govern effectively, while also setting up fights with Obama on key issues.

McConnell has stated that the Senate will not shut down the government or default on the national debt, but will instead pass legislation that Obama may not support. Republican leaders have called for working with Obama on certain issues, such as tax reform, while also pushing for repeal of the Affordable Care Act and other non-starters.

Conservative activists are pushing for the GOP to take a more confrontational approach, setting up big fights with Obama and giving voters a clear choice in the 2016 presidential election. However, Republican leaders must balance this approach with the need to govern effectively and pass legislation that benefits the American people.

Title: Republican Senator Jeff Flake Open to Reversing Opposition to Gun Background Checks

Article:

Republican Senator Jeff Flake of Arizona has expressed willingness to reconsider his opposition to expanding background checks for guns if the Senate bill's sponsors make changes to the provision dealing with internet sales. Flake initially voted against the measure due to concerns that the requirement for background checks on internet sales is too costly and inconvenient, particularly in his home state of Arizona and other rural areas where guns are often sold among friends.

According to Flake, the current language in the bill considers a gun owner's social media posts or text messages to friends as a commercial sale, which he believes is impractical and costly. He emphasized that this provision could lead to unnecessary complications and expenses for gun owners in rural areas.

Senator Joe Manchin, the chief sponsor of the bill, is working to revive the measure after its defeat in the Senate last month. However, Flake acknowledged that it may be challenging to find a compromise that satisfies his concerns. Despite this, he remains hopeful that a solution can be found.

The legislation aims to expand background checks on internet sales and private sales at gun shows. To overcome a GOP filibuster, five more senators need to switch their votes from "no" to "yes." A Senate Democratic leadership aide stated that they do not anticipate or expect to reach a deal on background checks in time for the bill to be reconsidered before the current work period ends.

Senator Flake, a first-term senator, has been criticized by gun control advocates, including former Congresswoman Gabby Giffords, who had been lobbying him to support expanding background checks. Some Republicans opposed the measure due to concerns that expanding background checks would lead to a national gun registry, but Flake dismissed this notion, stating that it is not the purpose of the bill.

During his congressional recess, Flake faced protests from gun control groups, including a woman who lost her son in the Aurora movie massacre. Despite being ranked as the most unpopular senator in the country by a Democratic polling firm, Flake received positive feedback from his constituents for opposing the background check measure as it was written.

Title: Washington Leaders Seek "Big Deal" on Budget Amid Sequestration Cuts

Washington, D.C. - Amid the $85 billion in sequestration cuts that took effect on Friday, top Democrats and Republicans in the US Congress are seeking a "big deal" on the federal budget. Both sides have been blaming each other for the cuts, but leaders from both parties are stressing the need to find a comprehensive solution to tackle the country's fiscal challenges.

Sen. Lindsey Graham, a South Carolina Republican, said on CBS' "Face the Nation" that the sequestration cuts are "abhorrent" and that he is willing to work towards a major agreement that would raise around $600 billion in revenue by closing tax loopholes and eliminating deductions. This revenue could then be used to reform Medicare and other entitlement programs.

Sen. Richard J. Durbin, the Illinois Democrat and his party's No. 2 man in the Senate, also appeared on "Face the Nation" and emphasized the need for compromise. He said that the two sides have until the end of March to achieve a deal and that the upcoming government funding deadline creates an opportunity for compromise.

Even Mitt Romney, the Republican Party's 2012 presidential nominee, chimed in, urging President Obama and congressional leaders to find a lasting solution. The country is bracing for additional budget battles, with Congress needing to approve another short-term spending plan by March 27 to avoid a government shutdown.

Top Republicans in the House and Senate have reiterated their opposition to further tax increases, with House Speaker John A. Boehner saying that the White House should not expect any more concessions on taxes after the New Year's deal to avoid the so-called fiscal cliff. Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell echoed those sentiments, stating that no Republican is willing to raise taxes to turn off the sequester.

The White House has indicated a willingness to go around the GOP leadership in the House and Senate, with National Economic Council Director Gene Sperling saying that the president spent part of Saturday calling lawmakers directly in an attempt to break the sequester logjam and find a deal. Sperling also blasted Republicans for what the White House says is an unwillingness to compromise on the revenue question.

The two sides have until the end of March to achieve a deal, and the stakes are high, with another showdown looming in May over the debt ceiling.

Title: Wisconsin Gubernatorial Recall Election Sees Record-Breaking Fundraising Efforts

The ongoing gubernatorial recall election in Wisconsin has shattered records, with a staggering $63 million raised so far, and the final tally expected to reach $70-80 million. This unprecedented amount is a testament to the intense political activity surrounding the election, with millions of phone calls made, thousands of yard signs posted, and television ads blanketing the airwaves.

According to Mike McCabe, who runs the Wisconsin Democracy Campaign, a nonpartisan campaign watchdog group, the money raised in the recall already surpasses Wisconsin's previous record of $37 million, set just 18 months ago when Republican Gov. Scott Walker was first elected. The record-breaking fundraising efforts have been fueled by both individual and outside group donations.

Walker has raised $30.5 million, while his Democratic challenger, Tom Barrett, has raised just under $4 million. The disparity can be attributed to a quirk in the election law, which allows public officials targeted for a recall to raise unlimited sums of money until the recall is formally set. This has led to a surge in donations from wealthy individuals and groups from outside Wisconsin.

Seventy percent of Walker's donations in the last month came from outside the state, with hundreds of thousands of contributors from all over the country, including Texan Bob Perry, who donated $500,000, and Las Vegas casino magnate Sheldon Adelson and Michigan millionaire Dick DeVos, who each donated $250,000.

Outside groups supporting both candidates have also flooded the state with some $25 million. Labor unions, which have an enormous stake in the recall since the backlash against Walker began when he all but did away with collective bargaining rights for public employees, have given $8 million in traceable donations to help Barrett. The Republican Governors Association has also contributed at least $9 million, including $1 million from GOP high roller David Koch.

The Wisconsin Democracy Campaign lists eight stealth super PACs on its website, most of which are groups on the right trying to help Walker, while one, Greater Wisconsin Committee, is trying to help push Walker out. The irony is that despite the tens of millions raised and spent on the recall election, it is an open question whether it will make a real difference, as Wisconsin's electorate is so polarized that public and party polls suggest most people's minds are already made up.

Title: Boehner Agrees to Allow Debt Ceiling Vote Without Conditions, Sperling Hopes for End to Default Threats

The White House's Director of the National Economic Council, Gene Sperling, expressed hope that the recent decision by House Speaker John Boehner to allow a vote on increasing the government's borrowing cap without conditions marks the end of the tactic of threatening default or the full faith and credit of the United States. Sperling, who will leave the White House next month, stated that this development would be a boost for confidence and long-term investment in the country.

Boehner's decision to allow the vote, which is expected to take place as early as Tuesday evening, is a reversal from his previous plan to link raising the debt ceiling to reversing a measure that cut pension benefits to younger military retirees. The speaker said that the GOP will put up a minimum number of votes to get the bill passed.

The change in plan comes after conservative House Republicans expressed disappointment with the original proposal, which would have cost $7 billion over the coming decade, according to the Congressional Budget Office. Representative Mo Brooks (R-Alabama) stated that the debt-ceiling bill increases spending, which is opposite of what was fought over just two years ago.

The Obama administration is supportive of efforts to grandfather current recipients of the pension benefits, but opposes "ransom" to pass the debt limit, Sperling said. Sperling, who has served as director of the National Economic Council under both President Clinton and President Obama, noted the differences between the Republican Party then and now. He emphasized that in the Clinton administration, the main challenge was dealing with a unified and strong opposition, whereas this time around, the challenge is dealing with a divided opposition.

Sperling's comments came during a Monitor-hosted breakfast for reporters, where he discussed the recent developments in the debt ceiling debate.

Title: North Carolina Governor Blames Congress for Lack of Clear Civil Rights Laws

Article:

North Carolina Governor Pat McCrory, a Republican, has come under fire for signing into law a bill that requires transgender residents to use bathrooms that correspond to their sex at birth. In an interview with TIME, McCrory blamed Congress for not updating the nation's civil rights laws, stating that the patchwork of non-discrimination laws at the state and local levels is inconsistent. He also expressed his opposition to President Barack Obama's orders allowing transgender students to use the bathroom of their choice, saying that Congress should clarify the Civil Rights Act.

McCrory acknowledged that Congress is considering a comprehensive non-discrimination law, known as the Equality Act, but did not endorse it. He emphasized the need for Congress to take action on the issue, stating that every city and state has its own non-discrimination ordinances that are inconsistent.

LGBT rights advocates have been critical of McCrory and the Republican-led legislature, estimating that the law has cost the state's economy $500 million. Corporate America has also lined up against the measure, with some major companies recruiting conservative attorney Ted Olsen to write a friend-of-the-court brief.

McCrory met with the president of the Human Rights Campaign (HRC), Chad Griffin, and described him as "Machiavellian" for his efforts to make North Carolina the epicenter of the transgender bathroom rights issue. Griffin has been successful in rallying corporate allies, leaving McCrory feeling isolated.

The law has led to boycotts and travel bans, with some entertainers announcing they will not perform in North Carolina until the law is changed. McCrory called this "hypocrisy," citing a transgender American Airlines employee, Candis Cox-Daniels, who is unable to change her birth certificate. However, Cox-Daniels' corporate counsel advises her not to go to work due to the law, and North Carolina's birth certificate policy is only available to those who have had reassignment surgery, which can be medically dangerous, costly, and unnecessary.

McCrory stated that the issue is now a national one, impacting every business, university, and school in the United States. He believes that the President has the power to enforce the law but not make or interpret it, and that it is now a national issue that goes beyond North Carolina.

Title: Houses of Worship Take Precautions Amidst Growing Concerns Over Coronavirus

As the spread of coronavirus continues to grow, many Christian communities are taking practical measures to limit the potential transmission of the virus. In Washington, Christ Church Georgetown has suspended services and activities after its lead preacher tested positive for COVID-19, and hundreds of parishioners are being urged to self-quarantine. The preacher, Rev. Timothy Cole, remains hospitalized in stable condition.

In an unusual move, Pope Francis delivered mass via video on Monday, showing solidarity with those affected by the virus. The Vatican also took measures to discourage large crowds from gathering in St. Peter's Square. The Pope briefly appeared at the window to wave to the sparse crowd.

In France, the government has announced a ban on gatherings exceeding 1,000 people, which could shut down Paris Christian Center. The church has decided to close its services and will instead stream them online. In Greenwood Village, Colorado, St. Peter Lutheran Church has replaced the traditional handshake with elbow and fist bumps during the Passing of the Peace.

Other churches have also taken precautions. The Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem has shut its doors as a precaution, while the Grand Mosque in Mecca, Saudi Arabia, was temporarily reopened for Muslim pilgrims.

These measures are aimed at preventing the spread of the virus and showing solidarity with those affected. As the situation continues to evolve, houses of worship are taking practical steps to ensure the health and well-being of their communities.

Title: Christian Leaders React to Supreme Court's Same-Sex Marriage Ruling

The Supreme Court's recent decision declaring same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry anywhere in the United States has sparked a range of reactions from Christian leaders. While some have expressed concern and warnings of civil disobedience, others have emphasized the importance of speaking the truth in love and respecting the rights of others.

Former governor and presidential candidate Mike Huckabee described the ruling as an "out-of-control act of unconstitutional judicial tyranny." Conservative activist Bob Vander Plaats, from Iowa, stated that the court "succumbed to demands to invent a new constitutional 'right' never imagined by our Founders."

The ruling has raised concerns about the impact on religious liberty, with many Christian leaders believing it will create a restricted role for people of faith in American society. Jim Campbell, Senior Legal Counsel at the Alliance Defending Freedom, said, "The Supreme Court has stripped all Americans of our freedom to debate and decide marriage policy through the democratic process. The freedom to democratically address the most pressing social issues of the day is the heart of liberty."

Some faith leaders believe the ruling will put religious liberty at risk, with Rev. Samuel Rodriguez stating that it "serves as a de facto and legal catalyst for the marginalization of Americans who embrace a biblical worldview." Others, like Liberty Counsel's Mat Staver, have called for civil disobedience in response to the ruling.

In the weeks leading up to the decision, the Southern Baptist Convention partnered with the Alliance Defending Freedom to provide guidance for churches and other faith-based institutions, releasing a booklet called "Protecting Your Ministry." Dr. Russell Moore discussed the booklet in an interview with *██ News earlier this month.

As Christian leaders continue to process the implications of the ruling, many are emphasizing the importance of speaking the truth in love and respecting the rights of others. Rev. Albert Mohler, president of the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, tweeted, "The challenge for Christians now is to speak the truth in love and to speak love in truth. Love of neighbor means we cannot lie about marriage."

Title: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit Deal Sparks Political Crisis

Article:

British Prime Minister Theresa May has announced the terms of the United Kingdom's departure from the European Union, which has sparked a political crisis in the country. The deal, which covers over 500 pages of legal and bureaucratic prose, has been met with criticism from both sides of the Brexit debate.

The deal confirms that the UK will continue to be subject to EU rules and regulations, albeit as a non-EU member state, and will have no say or vote in designing them. This has led to accusations that the deal does not deliver on the promises made during the Brexit referendum.

May has defended the deal, stating that it achieves the Brexit result that voters chose two years ago. However, critics argue that the deal contradicts her earlier "red lines," including leaving the single market and customs union.

The deal has also been criticized by Brexit supporters, who claim it is a betrayal of the original Brexit vision. They are calling for May to be replaced as leader, while Remainers are welcoming the deal as the best achievable Brexit.

The Northern Irish Democratic Unionists, who support the government's majority, have also opposed the deal, citing concerns about the border between the UK and Ireland. May's loyalist supporters are rallying around her, arguing that the deal is Brexit, while Remainers are saying it is not.

The crisis has led to several cabinet resignations, and at least half the required 48 letters for a vote of confidence have been submitted. May has refused to budge on the deal, stating that it cannot be changed without EU agreement.

The outcome of the crisis is uncertain, but it appears that May may lose the parliamentary vote on the deal and potentially her leadership. If she loses the leadership, she will be out of office. If she holds on as leader but loses the vote, she will likely be out as well.

The article concludes that the crisis is a result of May's failure to deliver on the Brexit promises and her leadership style, which has led to a divided party and a lack of trust among the public. The author suggests that the Conservative party should find a new leader who can forge a new policy to achieve a real Brexit.

Title: Louisiana Governor's Election Sees Democrat John Bel Edwards Defeat Republican David Vitter

In a significant shift in the political landscape of the Deep South, Democrat John Bel Edwards has defeated Republican U.S. Senator David Vitter in the Louisiana governor's election. Edwards will be the only Democratic governor in the region, where Republicans have traditionally dominated politics.

The outcome of the race was not entirely surprising, given the candidates' election night parties. Vitter was set up at a hotel near the airport, while Edwards held his celebration at the historic Monteleone Hotel in the French Quarter. The first hint of victory came when a brass band led a second line through the packed ballroom, with revelers waving yellow campaign hankies in the air.

Edwards' supporters were jubilant, celebrating a major upset in a state where Democrats have been shut out of statewide elected office. Edwards attributed his victory to his supporters, saying, "who were willing to believe that we could confound the conventional wisdom that this victory just couldn't happen."

Early on, Vitter was considered the frontrunner, but by the end of the night, he was conceding defeat and preparing to leave the U.S. Senate. Vitter had previously been dogged by controversy surrounding his ties to a Washington D.C. prostitute in 2007, which he had confessed to being a "serious sin." However, Edwards and his supporters attacked Vitter's character at every turn, calling him a liar and a stain on Louisiana.

Vitter also faced challenges due to voters' frustration with the current Republican Governor Bobby Jindal, who is term-limited. Some Republican officeholders, including Senator Bill Cassidy, supported Vitter, but others backed Edwards. Cassidy attributed Vitter's loss to the fractured Republican party and the effectiveness of a multimillion-dollar super PAC attacking Vitter.

State Representative Kenny Havard, who broke ranks to endorse Edwards, said the election is a message that voters are fed up with ultra-partisan politics. "We've got people on the fringe of each party, you know they rule the party, and probably 80 percent of us are stuck in the middle with nowhere to go," Havard said. "So I think the people of Louisiana spoke tonight and spoke with a loud voice."

Edwards, a veteran and West Point graduate, stakes out some conservative turf by being anti-abortion and pro-gun rights. However, he also plans to expand Medicaid and push for a higher minimum wage, issues popular with Louisiana Democrats. In his victory speech, Edwards promised to be a governor for "all the people" and added, "I will never embarrass you."

Title: Boston Marathon Bombing Suspect's Interrogation Halted Due to Medical Issues, New Evidence Emerges on Radicalized Older Brother

The investigation into the Boston Marathon bombing continues, with authorities still seeking answers from Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the surviving suspect. However, his ability to provide information has been hindered by medical issues, as he has been drifting in and out of consciousness since his apprehension on Friday evening.

Meanwhile, new evidence has emerged about his older brother, Tamerlan Tsarnaev, who was killed in the brothers' getaway attempt. According to reports, Tamerlan interrupted a speaker at a Cambridge mosque in January, calling him a "nonbeliever" and accusing him of contaminating people's minds. The congregation reportedly shouted him out of the mosque.

Dzhokhar Tsarnaev may be unable to verbally communicate with investigators even after recovery, as he suffered a wound to the throat area. It is unclear whether the wound was the result of police gunfire or a self-inflicted injury as part of a failed suicide attempt.

The federal High Value Detainee Interrogation team is standing by to question Tsarnaev in writing if possible. Authorities have indicated that Tsarnaev could be charged at any time, with possible crimes including state or federal charges.

Legal expert Robert Chesney notes that law enforcement faces no shortage of possible crimes to use in its indictment, with many being ordinary violent-crimes charges rather than terrorism-specific ones. The most serious charge Tsarnaev might face is federal: use of a weapon of mass destruction in killing, which can carry the death penalty. However, Chesney points out that the "Use of Weapons of Mass Destruction" statute carries four conditions, one of which must be met in order for it to apply.

Other federal terrorism laws that Tsarnaev might face charges from include a statute dealing with the bombing of public places and another prohibiting material support for terror acts. There is some question as to whether Tsarnaev's trial might be moved outside Massachusetts, on the grounds that any jury pool would be tainted against him.

State authorities are likely to file their own charges against the terror suspect, meaning that at some point he is quite likely to face a Bay State jury.

Title: Orlando Mass Killing Fits Pattern of Homegrown Terrorism

The recent mass killing in Orlando, Florida, is the latest in a string of terrorist attacks on U.S. soil carried out by American citizens or legal permanent residents. According to Peter Bergen, CNN's national security analyst, author, and professor, every lethal terrorist attack in the United States since 9/11 has been perpetrated by individuals with no formal connections or training from terrorist organizations.

The misconception that terrorist attacks are carried out by foreigners may stem from the fact that the 9/11 attacks were orchestrated by 19 Arab foreign-born terrorists. However, Omar Mateen, the perpetrator of the deadliest terrorist attack since 9/11, was an American citizen born in New York to parents who immigrated from Afghanistan.

Since 9/11, a total of 15 lethal terrorist attacks have been carried out by American citizens or legal permanent residents, including the Boston Marathon bombings and the Fort Hood shooting. Mateen's case is typical of jihadist terrorists in the United States, as he was previously investigated by the FBI as a possible militant.

In both cases, the Tsarnaev brothers, who carried out the Boston Marathon bombings, and Nidal Hasan, who killed 13 at Fort Hood, Texas, were also investigated by the FBI before their attacks. The Orlando mass killing serves as a reminder that the real terror threat in the United States is often homegrown, rather than foreign-born.

Title: Wisconsin Governor Recall Vote: A Test of Local Support for Democratic Challenger Tom Barrett

Article:

Wisconsin is set to hold a historic recall vote on Tuesday, with Governor Scott Walker facing a challenge from Democratic challenger Tom Barrett. The election has garnered significant attention beyond the state, but for now, it belongs to the 3 million-plus registered voters in Wisconsin. Most of them are expected to turn out, and those who do will be focused on the implications for Wisconsin, rather than the potential fallout elsewhere.

The recall vote is a rematch of the 2010 gubernatorial election, in which Walker won by about 125,000 votes. Barrett, the mayor of Milwaukee since 2004, needs to translate his mayoral popularity into a stronger showing in the state. In 2010, he won his own city in a landslide, but Walker countered the vote from the city and kept the countywide margin around where it was in 2006.

In 2006, Democratic Governor Jim Doyle rode the Milwaukee County vote to a narrow win for the overall Milwaukee metro area, surpassing the usual Republican blowout in the suburban-exurban counties of Waukesha, Washington, and Ozaukee. Two years later, presidential candidate Barack Obama followed that pattern and expanded on it, sweeping Milwaukee County by nearly 170,000 votes.

However, in 2010, Barrett found that the vote in surrounding counties had grown insurmountable. He carried Milwaukee County by a Doyle-like margin, but was nowhere near the Obama number. Meanwhile, the vote was going heavily against him in the rest of the metro. Waukesha County alone favored Walker by about 82,000 votes, and Ozaukee and Washington came piling on, going for Walker by a combined ratio approaching 3-to-1.

For Barrett to win this time around, he needs to get closer to Obama's numbers in the Milwaukee metro, find a way to squeeze even more votes out of Dane County, and widen his winning margin in outstate counties such as Eau Claire. It would also help if he could flip counties he lost in 2010, including southeastern Racine and Kenosha near the Illinois state line.

The task is a tall order, and it explains why even late polls showing the race getting closer are not shaking the confidence of the governor and his backers. The votes to be counted Tuesday night are likely to follow traditional partisan patterns that have been discernible in the state since the emergence of its modern Democratic Party in the years after World War II.

Title: US-Led Coalition Claims Progress Against Islamic State, But Critics Disagree

The US-led coalition fighting against the Islamic State (IS) has made significant gains, according to Secretary of State John Kerry. Speaking on NBC's "Meet the Press," Kerry stated that the coalition, working with Arab partners, has taken back wide swaths of territory and eliminated top IS commanders, leading him to believe they are winning. However, Kurdish leaders close to the conflict and Republican critics argue that the US leadership is lacking in several corners of the globe.

Kerry emphasized that the evidence supports his claim, citing the facts of what is happening on the ground. However, Kurdish leaders have expressed concerns about the lack of a clear strategy to rout the extremists, and US lawmakers from both parties have called for more action to support their allies without putting American troops on the ground.

The disconnect highlights the challenges facing the administration as it navigates real-life battles abroad and political ones at home. The recent spate of jihadist-inspired violence from Paris to Sydney, as well as the brutal immolation of a Jordanian pilot taken hostage by the IS, has fueled fears over the tangible and philosophical threats of radical Islam.

In Washington, the parties are pointing fingers at each other over funding for the Department of Homeland Security, which is set to run dry on February 27. The stalemate is over President Obama's executive amnesty for certain illegal immigrants, with members of both parties warning about the growing threat of homegrown terrorism.

Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson urged Congress to pass a fully funded budget, while Republican Representative Michael T. McCaul argued that the administration has not defined the enemy, which is radical Islamist extremism.

The article also touched on the conflict in Ukraine, where Republican senators are urging the administration to arm the Kiev government, which is battling Russian-backed separatists in the eastern part of the country. Secretary Kerry declined to specify what items would be provided to Ukrainian loyalists, stating that additional assistance will be given, but it will be focused on economic and diplomatic efforts.

The article concludes with Senator Ted Cruz, a potential 2016 presidential contender, criticizing the Obama administration's foreign policy, stating that it has been consistently wrong on the IS, Russia, and Iran.

Title: The Debate Over Same-Sex Marriage: Balancing Religious Liberty and Human Autonomy

The debate over same-sex marriage has a strong religious component, with questions surrounding the interpretation of biblical passages and the authority of ancient texts. However, the U.S. Supreme Court has not been asked to determine what God or the Bible thinks about same-sex marriage, as religious groups are divided on the issue. The court's role is to ensure that the Constitution is upheld, not to referee religious disputes.

The government should not act to further one or another religious view on contested moral issues, as religious groups are free to urge and practice their different visions of the good, of moral life, and compete for adherents in the marketplace of ideas. Citizens opposed to same-sex marriage cannot demand that the government refuse recognition to such marriages to avoid offending their religious sensibilities.

Religious liberty does not give anyone the right to demand that someone else be deprived of the right to live the most intimate portions of their lives according to their own deepest convictions. Recognizing same-sex marriage creates new problems for the liberties of religious believers, extending beyond the right of clergy or houses of worship not to perform or host same-sex ceremonies.

The debate surrounding same-sex marriage raises questions about religious colleges providing housing to same-sex couples, religious social service agencies placing children for adoption with same-sex couples, and religious institutions employing spouses who are in same-sex marriages. Resolving these conflicts will not be easy, as the rights of same-sex couples will sometimes trump religious liberty rights, and vice versa.

The Supreme Court's decision on same-sex marriage is imminent, and it is crucial that the court balances the rights of same-sex couples with the religious liberties of those who disagree. Same-sex couples should not be denied the right to civil marriage, and when that right is secured, they should not be allowed to force dissenting religious organizations to recognize or facilitate their marriages without good reason.

Title: Texas Gubernatorial Candidate Wendy Davis' Ad Sparks Controversy Over Use of Wheelchair in Attack Ad

Article:

Texas Democratic gubernatorial candidate Wendy Davis has released a 30-second ad, titled "Justice," which focuses on her opponent, Republican candidate Greg Abbott, and the accident that left him in a wheelchair. The ad accuses Abbott of not siding with victims like himself during his time in the state Supreme Court or as Texas attorney general. The ad has sparked controversy, with many criticizing Davis for using Abbott's disability as a political attack.

Morning Joe co-host Mika Brzezinski expressed her disapproval of the ad, stating that she "cringed" watching it and that it goes against Davis' "brand" of inspiring and empowering women. Brzezinski believes Davis should focus on appealing to women with a positive message instead of running an ad that targets Abbott's disability.

However, Davis and her pollster, Joel Benenson, are standing by the ad, saying it is part of a larger strategy to show Abbott's lack of support for victims. Benenson stated that the ad is "executing basically the same strategy we've had since Day 1" and will continue to be effective.

Despite the controversy, Abbott's campaign has released a video criticizing the ad, calling Davis "unfit to be governor." Republican strategists have also weighed in, saying the ad is a "huge blunder" and will depress voter turnout.

Abbott himself has called the ad "offensive" and "shows the tenor of the campaign." He believes the ad will not sell well and expects it to backfire. Other Texas Republican lawmakers, including Senators John Cornyn and Ted Cruz, have also expressed outrage over the ad, with Cornyn demanding Davis apologize and pull it down.

The ad has also received criticism from Republican media strategist Rick Wilson, who called it "makes even Todd Akin look like a political genius."

Title: US Military Deployment to Border Not a Solution to Illegal Immigration Crisis

Article:

The deployment of 800 US soldiers to the southern border to confront a caravan of Central American migrants is not a solution to the illegal immigration crisis, according to experts. The caravan, which has grown to over 10,000 people, is seeking to avoid exploitation by smugglers and coyotes and may take weeks to reach the United States. A second caravan is already forming behind the first, and it's unclear how many more will follow.

The issue of national sovereignty is at the heart of the debate, with some arguing that the unauthorized march on the border is a challenge to the country's sovereignty. However, others argue that the US government has the authority to close loopholes in the law that allow illegal immigrants to enter the country.

The 2008 Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act, the 1997 Flores settlement, and the "credible fear" standard are among the provisions that have transformed the character of illegal immigration. These provisions, combined with changing political conditions in Central America, have led to an influx of families and unaccompanied children seeking asylum.

The US public still views illegal immigrants as single males from Mexico seeking economic opportunities, but the reality is that the majority of illegal immigrants are now families fleeing gang violence and political instability in Central America. The number of illegal immigrants from Mexico has declined in recent years, while the number from Central America has increased.

The US military cannot solve the problem of illegal immigration, but Congress can. The legislative branch has the authority to close loopholes in the law and provide more resources to agencies dealing with the influx of migrants. The US public must also be prepared to have a nuanced conversation about the complexities of illegal immigration and the need for a comprehensive solution.

Title: Obama's High-Stakes Speech: Shifting the Argument Forward

President Barack Obama is set to deliver a speech tonight, focusing on shifting the argument forward and convincing voters that another four years in office will lead to greater accomplishments. With a jobs report due tomorrow expected to show a 43rd straight month of unemployment above 8%, Obama will need to balance highlighting his administration's achievements with a message of hope and progress.

According to Martin Medhurst, a professor of political science and rhetoric at Baylor University, Obama's speech will aim to paint a bright picture of the past four years, while also acknowledging the economic challenges the country still faces. "He's got to remind people that he's done a tremendous amount and the best is yet to come," said Minneapolis Mayor R.T. Rybak, a vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

Obama is likely to tout accomplishments such as bailing out the domestic auto industry, expanding health coverage for millions of Americans, reshaping the student loan business, ending the war in Iraq, and green-lighting the mission that killed Osama bin Laden. "He's delivered and is going to deliver a lot more than Mitt Romney can ever dream of doing," said Rybak.

The speech will also feature attacks on Republican challenger Mitt Romney's platform, framing the election as a choice between two different visions for the country. Obama will likely raise doubts and fears about what a Romney administration would look like, arguing that it would imperil the middle class.

According to George C. Edwards III, a presidential scholar at Texas A&M University, Obama will need to frame the election as a choice, not a referendum on his own record. "He's got to say, 'I'm better than the other guy,'" Edwards said.

The speech will also aim to raise the stakes by painting a dire picture of a Romney presidency, which may be enough to prod the Democratic base, which has been less energized about this election compared to four years ago. "I don't think he can recapture the magic of 2008 – no president can," said David Woodard, a Republican consultant who teaches at Clemson University. "But he has to make them feel he can lead them to victory."

Obama will also need to speak to potential supporters who are disillusioned but might still be won over. Romney and other Republicans have portrayed Obama as a well-intentioned man who has failed, so Obama will need to answer the question, "What does Barack Obama want to do in a second term that would have a better result?"

The theme of the Democratic National Convention has been "Forward," and Obama will need to answer the question, "Forward to what?" The challenge for Obama is to put out a strong vision for what he wants to do in a second term, not an imaginary vision of what he would do if Democrats had all the power, but what people could expect from him if elected for a second term.

Title: Unpopular Presidential Candidates: Trump and Clinton Struggle to Gain Favorability

The 2016 presidential election is shaping up to be a unique contest, with both major party candidates, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, struggling to gain favorability among voters. According to a recent poll by YouGov, Trump is viewed unfavorably across various demographic groups, including gender, age, race, and income. Similarly, Clinton's favorability ratings are low, with only blacks and Hispanics viewing her favorably.

The prolonged primary season and internal party squabbles have not helped the candidates' images. Typically, candidates tend to become more popular once they secure their party's nomination, as seen in the cases of John Kerry in 2004 and Mitt Romney in 2012. However, this trend may not apply to Trump and Clinton, who are both struggling to gain traction.

Trump's unfavorability ratings are particularly high, with only one-third of Americans viewing him favorably. Clinton fares slightly better, with 40% of Americans having a favorable view of her. However, she may take heart from her husband Bill Clinton's experience in 1992, when his favorability ratings improved significantly after the Democratic National Convention.

The upcoming Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia in July may provide an opportunity for Clinton to boost her favorability ratings, pending the outcome of the primary contest with Bernie Sanders. The 2016 election is shaping up to be a unique and unpredictable contest, with both major party candidates facing significant challenges in gaining the support of American voters.

Title: Police Officer Killed in San Antonio Ambush, Three Other Officers Injured in Separate Incidents Across the Country

A San Antonio police officer was killed and three others were injured in separate incidents across the United States on Sunday, in what authorities believe may be a coordinated attack on law enforcement. Detective Benjamin Marconi, a 20-year veteran of the force, was shot and killed while sitting in his patrol car across from police headquarters at 11:45 a.m. local time.

According to officials, the suspected gunman, who was driving a 2009-2012 black Mitsubishi Galant with black rims, had previously staked out police headquarters and gained access to a vestibule before leaving. Surveillance footage shows the man speaking to a clerk on an intercom before being let in, but he only stayed for a short time before departing.

The motive behind the attack is still unknown, and authorities are searching for the suspect. The San Antonio Police Chief, William McManus, stated that the uniform may have been the target, and the first person who happened to be in the area was the one who was targeted.

The same day, a St. Louis police sergeant was shot twice in the face and is expected to survive, while an officer in Sanibel, Florida, was shot and injured during a traffic stop. In Gladstone, Missouri, an officer sustained non-life-threatening injuries during a struggle with a suspect who had fled from a traffic stop.

These incidents come less than five months after a gunman killed five officers in Dallas, and just over a year since 56 state, county, and local officers were shot while on duty in 2016. The recent attacks have raised concerns about the safety of law enforcement officers and the motives behind these targeted attacks.

Title: Secret Service Provides Round-the-Clock Protection to Trump's Family and Aides

The United States Secret Service is providing 24/7 protective details to the spouses and children of President Donald Trump's adult children, as well as to several of his top aides, including Reince Priebus, H.R. McMaster, and Kellyanne Conway, at the president's request. This is in addition to the standard protection provided to top officials and immediate family members, as required by statute.

The agency is also providing protection to former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his wife, as well as to Mr. Obama's eldest daughter, until they are no longer receiving regular protection this summer. With many of the new protectees living in New York, former Secret Service officials suggest that the agency may eventually set up a fully staffed branch of the presidential protection division there, relocating agents from across the country.

For now, the agency is flying agents in from around the country to provide protection, similar to what is done during a campaign or for a large security event. This means the agency is paying for hotel rooms, transportation, and living expenses, including Manhattan prices. The agency is also renting space inside Trump Tower for offices and temporary sleeping quarters, although the details of the transaction have not been made public.

The New York field office appears to be particularly affected, with a third of the agents stationed there involved in protection on a given day. This has diminished the agency's ability to focus on investigative work, such as financial crime and cybercrime cases, which are crucial to building agents' skills and combating crime.

According to a former agency official, the increased protection detail has put the Secret Service in a "campaign mode" all the time, which will degrade the quality of life for most agents in the agency.

Title: Presidential Hopeful Kamala Harris's Plan to Address Pay Inequality Faces Criticism

Article: Presidential hopeful Kamala Harris has proposed a plan to address pay inequality in America, aiming to achieve "equal pay for equal work." Her report claims that women who work full-time are paid just 80 cents on average for every dollar paid to men. However, critics argue that this pay gap is not as clear-cut as it seems.

Harris's plan is based on a calculation that compares the median pay of women and men who work 35 hours or more a week for the full year. However, this approach does not account for differences in job selection, education, and work hours between men and women. According to Harvard economist Claudia Goldin, the remaining pay gap is not the result of discrimination, but rather the result of women's demand for "temporal flexibility," or the ability to balance work and family responsibilities.

Goldin's research suggests that women are more likely to prioritize job flexibility, which can lead to differences in job selection and career choices. As the workplace evolves and more telecommuting and flexible work arrangements become common, the pay gap may narrow as men and women choose jobs that better fit their individual needs.

Harris's proposal would require employers with over 100 workers to prove to the federal government that they are not paying women less than men for equal work, in exchange for an "Equal Pay Certification." If they fail to comply, they would face penalties of 1% of their profits for every 1% wage gap that persists. Critics argue that this approach would be impractical and bureaucratic, as it would require employers to prove that their employees are paid based on performance reviews and tasks, which is not always feasible.

The proposal could also lead to unintended consequences, such as employers scaling back on flexibility or employing fewer women to avoid the certification process. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission would need to add hundreds of employees to its staff to handle the certification process, and labor attorneys could benefit from the resulting litigation.

While politicians often propose flawed ideas on the campaign trail, Harris's plan to address pay inequality may be one of the most problematic.

Title: TIME Magazine Refutes Trump's Claim About Being Named "Person of the Year"

TIME Magazine has disputed President Donald Trump's claim that he was offered the title of "Person of the Year" and declined, stating that he had to satisfy certain editorial obligations. Trump made the claim in a tweet, saying that he was "probably" going to be named the magazine's "Man (Person) of the Year" like he was in 2016, but declined due to the required interview and photo shoot.

However, TIME Magazine responded on Twitter, saying that Trump's claim is "incorrect" and that the magazine does not comment on its choice until the publication date, which is December 6. Alan Murray, chief content officer of Time Inc., also dismissed Trump's claims, stating that there is "not a speck of truth" to them.

The magazine has opened an unofficial public poll for readers to vote on who should be named "Person of the Year," with Trump currently tied for third place at 5% of the vote, along with the hashtag "#MeToo" and "The Dreamers." Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia is currently leading the poll with 21% of the vote.

Title: Trump Expressed Approval of Chinese Concentration Camps for Uighur Muslims, According to Bolton's Memoir

Article:

Former national security adviser John Bolton's upcoming memoir, "The Room Where It Happened," reveals that President Donald Trump expressed approval of China's construction of concentration camps for Uighur Muslims during a private meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping in 2019. According to Bolton, Trump told Xi that he should "go ahead" with building the camps, which Trump believed was the "right thing to do."

The meeting took place during the 2019 G20 meeting in Japan, where Trump and Xi were accompanied only by their interpreters. Bolton's book, parts of which were published in The Wall Street Journal, details the conversation between the two leaders.

The Chinese Communist Party has been criticized for its construction of large concentration camps in Xinjiang, where millions of ethnic minority Uighur Muslims are believed to be detained under the guise of a counterterrorism campaign. The camps have been condemned by the White House and lawmakers from both parties, with some calling for sanctions against officials involved.

In a statement, the Chinese embassy in Washington, D.C. denied the allegations, saying that the notion of mistreatment is "blatantly smears China's counterterrorism and deradicalization measures and seriously interferes in China's internal affairs."

Bolton's book has sent shockwaves through Washington and the political sphere, with the former national security adviser accusing the House of Representatives of "impeachment malpractice" and saying Trump engaged in far more objectionable conduct than just what he was impeached for.

In another section of the book, Bolton described how Trump "pleaded" with Xi for China to purchase US agricultural products to help him win reelection in 2020. Bolton wrote that Trump stressed the importance of farmers and increased Chinese purchases of soybeans and wheat in the electoral outcome.

The revelations have sparked widespread criticism and concern, with some calling for accountability and others expressing outrage. The Uyghur Human Rights Policy Act, which was overwhelmingly approved by both chambers, calls for sanctions against officials involved with the camps.

Title: Trump Unveils National Security Strategy, Emphasizing Economic Competition and Self-Reliance

The Trump administration has released its national security strategy, which prioritizes economic issues such as trade, energy independence, and tax reform as central to U.S. foreign policy. The strategy, outlined by President Trump in a speech on Monday, defines four pillars: protecting the American people at home, promoting economic prosperity, preserving peace through a strong military, and advancing American interests abroad.

The strategy aims to balance competing objectives, emphasizing political and economic competition with countries like Russia and China while also seeking cooperation on security challenges like North Korea's nuclear program. Trump emphasized that the U.S. will "stand up for ourselves and our country like we have never stood up before."

The report, which is the first comprehensive update of U.S. foreign policy since 2015, defines Russia and China as "revisionist powers" intent on changing the global status quo by illegitimately seizing territory. However, it also notes that the U.S. should cooperate with them when their interests align.

The strategy places an emphasis on cyber-security and reducing intelligence on Russia's interference in the 2016 presidential election to just a couple of lines. It also omits any mention of climate change, a key focus of the previous administration's national security strategy.

Trump's speech highlighted the importance of national security innovation, promoting the concept of a "national security innovation base" to describe the technology and intellectual property that gives the U.S. a strategic and economic advantage in the world. The strategy also emphasizes the need for a strong military and the importance of protecting the country's borders and values.

The report is a departure from previous national security strategies, which focused more on terrorism and global stability. Trump's strategy is more focused on economic competition and self-reliance, with a emphasis on the importance of domestic policy in shaping the country's role in the world.

Title: The Power of Human Connection: Breaking Down Barriers Through Personal Experience

The article discusses the phenomenon of "othering," where people tend to treat others differently when they are face-to-face, rather than in theory. This is demonstrated through a 1934 study by sociologist Richard LaPiere, who found that a Chinese couple was denied service only once during their travels across the United States, despite racism being prevalent at the time. The study also showed that when asked if they would serve "members of the Chinese race," 92% of establishments responded negatively.

The article suggests that people are often more hostile to others in theory than in practice, and that this can be seen in phenomena such as the endorsement of gay rights when people realize they have gay relatives and colleagues. To make compassion and empathy more common, the article recommends being open-minded and inviting others onto one's stage, going where people are hostile and sharing one's heart, and supporting institutions that promote respectful competition of ideas.

The article concludes by encouraging readers to make this phenomenon into a national movement of American renewal, celebrating leaders who go where they are not welcome and supporting news outlets that combat anonymous hatred.

Title: Parents Urged to Be Proactive About School Security Plans After Georgia Elementary School Attack

A recent incident in Decatur, Georgia, where a gunman armed with an assault rifle attacked an elementary school, has raised concerns about school security and the importance of parents being proactive about their children's safety. Fortunately, the gunman was apprehended before anyone was injured or killed.

In the aftermath of this incident, parents are being urged to ask their school administrators several crucial questions to ensure their child's school has a comprehensive crisis response plan in place. These questions include:

1. Does the school have a crisis response plan customized for its campus? Many schools have generic plans, but it's essential to ensure the plan is tailored to the school's unique characteristics, demographics, and personnel.
2. Does the school regularly practice safety drills, such as lockdowns, shelter-in-place, and evacuations? Practicing these drills at least once per semester with teachers and school staff is crucial to ensure everyone knows what to do in case of an emergency.
3. What should parents do if there is an emergency at the school? Parents should know the school's policies for emergency situations, including whom to contact, where to go, and what documents to bring.
4. Have both staff and students received training on what to do during an active shooter incident? It's essential that administrators, teachers, and students know what to do during a crisis, and parents should demand to know the training provided to staff and students.
5. Has the school partnered with its local law enforcement agency to practice emergency response procedures? Real-time practice scenarios are crucial to a comprehensive school safety plan, and schools should work closely with local law enforcement to ensure their plans are in sync.

By asking these questions and ensuring their child's school has a comprehensive crisis response plan, parents can take a proactive role in ensuring their child's safety and well-being.

Title: Millennials' Job Expectations and Engagement: A Study Reveals a Shift in Work Culture

A recent study by Gallup has shed light on the job expectations and engagement of millennials, a generation often criticized for their perceived sense of entitlement. The survey found that millennials are less engaged in their jobs than previous generations, with 55% reporting they are "checked out" and lack passion and energy for their work. Only 29% of millennials reported active engagement in their jobs, the lowest figure among the four generations tracked in the survey.

The study attributes the job-hopping among millennials to their emphasis on finding fulfilling work rather than just high-paying jobs. Millennials prioritize opportunities to learn and grow, quality of management, interest in the type of work, and opportunities for advancement when looking for a new job. Eighty-seven percent of millennials said personal development is an important characteristic in a job, and fewer millennials than other generations said they would pursue a different line of work for a raise.

The survey also found that millennials thrive on constant communication and interaction. About 44% of those who said they meet with their manager on a regular basis reported being engaged in their work, compared to a 20% engagement rate for those who said they do not meet regularly with their manager.

The increased emphasis on jobs with meaning and personal development comes as the younger generation eschews conventional societal institutions, such as family and the church, which previously imparted purpose. The Gallup survey found that just 27% of millennials are married, compared to 36% of Gen Xers, 48% of baby boomers, and 65% of traditionalists who were married at that stage in their lives. Additionally, the survey notes that just 55% of millennials report having interest in religion, compared to 65% of Gen Xers, 70% of baby boomers, and 75% of traditionalists.

Greg Jao, vice president of campus engagement for InterVarsity Christian Fellowship, believes that the capricious employment habits of young people entering the workforce can be interpreted as a winding search for meaning – and the desire for bosses who double as life coaches, the search for a mentor. "I don't think, as a generation, they're apathetic or disengaged; I think they're looking for people who help provide meaning and coherence to what they're experiencing," he said. "And I think if millennials find a job where the goal is just to make a profit for your corporation or have a good paycheck, that's not satisfying to them."

Title: US Government Shutdown Ends, but Key Issues Remain Unresolved

The US government shutdown, which lasted for three days, has come to an end after Senate Democrats agreed to a short-term spending measure. The deal, which was signed into law by President Donald Trump, will keep the government funded for three weeks and allows for a vote on ensuring protection for Dreamers, young undocumented migrants who were brought to the US as children. However, key battles between Democrats and Republicans remain unresolved, with no consensus on a budget and no agreement on an immigration compromise that could pass both chambers and win support from the White House.

The compromise, which ended the shutdown and returned hundreds of thousands of federal employees to work, comes at a time of profound political polarization in Washington, where trust across the aisle is in short supply. Liberal groups and progressive lawmakers were furious after a majority of Senate Democrats voted to end the shutdown, trusting that Republican Majority Leader Mitch McConnell would indeed allow a vote on immigration next month.

McConnell reiterated that it was his intention to allow debate on immigration legislation that would protect Dreamers, but the offer was conditional on the government remaining open. The deal was enough to win support from 33 Senate Democrats, who joined 48 Republicans to reopen the government on Monday night. Sixteen progressive Democrats voted against the measure, including Senator Kamala Harris of California, who said it would be "foolhardy" to trust McConnell.

Despite the deal, there is no guarantee the House Republican leadership will follow. The path to a bipartisan immigration solution that satisfies Democrats' desire for Dreamer protections, Republicans' requirement for increased border security, and Trump's demand for a wall seemed as distant as ever on Tuesday. An inchoate effort to restart negotiations was underway in the Senate without clear direction or leadership.

Several senators said the current state of negotiations was unmoored from an earlier bipartisan effort that paired increased border security and tighter controls on immigration with a Dream Act, legislation that would offer a conditional path to citizenship for certain undocumented people. "There is not even an agreement on a starting point," said Richard Durbin, the No. 2 Senate Democrat, who has been at the center of negotiations over Dreamers. "But I will tell you, there is only one bipartisan bill that has been brought before the Senate. That should be the starting point."

The White House press secretary, Sarah Sanders, called the plan drafted by Republican senators Lindsey Graham, Jeff Flake, and Durbin "unacceptable" and said the legislation should be "declared dead on arrival" because it failed to meet the administration's demands on border security. Flake said negotiators had abandoned that legislation as talks resumed to find a compromise solution on immigration. "This is a new effort entirely," he told reporters on Tuesday.

Meanwhile, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer has rescinded his offer to allow funding for the construction of a border wall, which he had extended to Trump in a last-ditch effort to stave off a shutdown. Since the White House rejected that offer, Schumer said he had taken the wall offer "off the table."

Title: California Education Officials Prepare for Potential School Closures Amidst Growing Coronavirus Concerns

California education officials are reviewing and updating emergency plans, preparing for the possibility of school closures if the new coronavirus spreads widely in the state. The virus has already breached containment efforts and is expected to spread in the United States at some point, according to federal officials. A recent case in Solano County marks the first instance of the virus being transmitted locally, prompting the Fairfield-Suisun Unified School District to take precautions to prevent its spread.

The district has notified parents that staff will be disinfecting surfaces daily, as recommended by county and state officials. The state is also advising students and staff to frequently wash their hands, cover their nose and mouth when sneezing and coughing, and stay home if they are sick. In the event of a widespread outbreak, schools may consider canceling special events, holding classes in smaller groups, or implementing remote education via the internet.

Dr. Nancy Messonnier, director of the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases, emphasized the importance of preparing for potential disruptions to daily life. "I understand this whole situation may seem overwhelming and that disruption to everyday life may be severe, but these are things that people need to start thinking about now," she said.

Parents are advised to consider what they would do if schools are closed or classes are held remotely in their community. While many children in China are attending school remotely, most schools in the Bay Area or across the country wouldn't be able to conduct classes online due to a lack of computer or internet access for many students.

School districts in California have emergency plans in place for various scenarios, including earthquakes, fires, and pandemics. The pandemic influenza plan in Tulare County, for example, includes guidance to close a school if more than 30% of students are ill. State and county officials are providing guidance to school districts on how to deal with a potential outbreak.

While there are currently no confirmed cases in San Francisco, officials are planning for the possibility of an exposure at a school. The state Department of Education has advised schools to bar travelers from mainland China from school grounds for 14 days and is encouraging school staff to promote preventive measures, such as hand washing and cleaning frequently used surfaces.

In Contra Costa County, officials are in constant communication with county health officials and are preparing a plan to respond if any schools are at risk of becoming impacted. While there is no evidence of the virus circulating in the county, officials are taking precautions to keep students and schools safe and protected.

Title: The Gender Gap in the Upcoming Election May Be the Largest in Over 60 Years

The upcoming presidential election has the potential to make history not only in the possibility of electing the first female president but also in the potential for the largest gender voting gap in the modern era. According to recent polls, women are voting overwhelmingly Democratic, with an average of 13-point lead over men, who prefer Trump by 12 points, resulting in a 25-point gap.

This gender gap is not a new phenomenon, as women have consistently voted more heavily Democratic than men in presidential elections since 1996. The largest gap to date was in 2000, when women preferred Al Gore over George W. Bush by 10 points, while men chose Bush over Gore by 11 points, resulting in a 21-point total gap.

Recent polls suggest that this year's gender gap could be even wider, with women leaning towards Clinton and men towards Trump. However, it's not necessarily that women are flocking to Clinton, but rather that party ID has a stronger pull than demographic factors. Additionally, Trump's overt sexism and comments about assaulting women may be pushing some women away from his campaign, while his overtly masculine campaign may be holding onto some men.

While neither women nor men are a monolithic voting bloc, with various fissures within each group, one area that may be unusual in this election is among white women. Historically, white women have leaned Republican, but polls suggest they may be swinging Democratic this year. However, it's unclear whether this trend will continue, as white men remain about as Republican as they have been.

The gender gap is expected to be driven by white voters, who make up around three-quarters of the electorate. However, it's unclear whether the white gender gap will be as historic as the one seen nationwide, across all races.

Title: South Korean President Moon Jae-in Suggests President Trump Deserves Nobel Peace Prize for Role in Denuclearization Talks

Article:

South Korean President Moon Jae-in has expressed his support for President Trump's efforts in the denuclearization talks with North Korea, stating that Trump deserves to win the Nobel Peace Prize for his role in the negotiations. This comes after Lee Hee-ho, the widow of late South Korean President Kim Dae-jung, praised Moon's work with North Korea, prompting Moon to redirect the praise towards Trump.

According to a Korean official, Moon told a meeting of senior secretaries that "President Trump should win the Nobel Peace Prize" and emphasized that "what we need is only peace." This comment comes after Moon met with North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un for a summit at the Peace House in Panmunjom.

The summit between the two leaders resulted in an agreement to work towards a "nuclear-free Korean Peninsula" and officially ending the 1950-53 Korean War by the end of the year. The leaders also agreed to suspend loudspeaker propaganda broadcasts and dismantle broadcasting equipment, as well as stop flying propaganda leaflets across the border.

Trump has continued to play an active role in the negotiations, tweeting about the possibility of holding his expected summit with Kim at the Peace House. The date for the summit has not been scheduled yet, but Trump has expressed optimism about the progress made so far.

The Korean leaders' agreement to work towards a nuclear-free peninsula and officially ending the war is a significant step forward in the denuclearization process. The agreement to suspend propaganda broadcasts and dismantle broadcasting equipment is also a positive development, as it reduces tensions and promotes a more peaceful atmosphere on the peninsula.

The sanctions imposed by the Trump administration on North Korea have also been a key factor in the progress made so far. The sanctions, which include cutting off sources of revenue and fuel used to boost the country's nuclear program and military, have had a significant impact on the North Korean economy.

Overall, the developments in the denuclearization talks between the United States, South Korea, and North Korea are a positive step towards a more peaceful and stable region.

Title: Senate Democrats Request Information on Acting Attorney General's and Assistant Attorney General's Potential Conflicts of Interest

Article:

A group of Senate Democrats has sent a letter to the Justice Department, requesting information on potential conflicts of interest involving Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker and Assistant Attorney General Brian Benczkowski. The letter highlights concerns over Whitaker's compensation as executive director of an organization that has sued Democratic lawmakers multiple times in the past, as well as Benczkowski's history working on behalf of a Russian bank.

The senators, led by Sheldon Whitehouse (D-R.I.), Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.), and others, expressed concerns that these ties could create ethical issues, particularly in relation to Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election. The senators noted that previous Justice Department responses to their requests for information were heavily redacted and urged the department to provide prompt, complete, and public responses to their concerns.

Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker took over the top job at the Justice Department after President Donald Trump pushed out Attorney General Jeff Sessions in early November.
