Whitaker has not recused himself from the Mueller investigation, although he promised House Democrats that he would not tamper with its integrity. Assistant Attorney General Brian Benczkowski, who was confirmed in July, represented Alfa Bank, whose owners have been identified by the Treasury Department as having close ties to the Russian government. The senators criticized Benczkowski's nomination, citing concerns over his potential conflicts of interest.

Title: St. Louis Police Officer's Association Calls for NFL Discipline Over "Hands Up, Don't Shoot" Displays

The St. Louis Police Officer's Association (SLPOA) has expressed its discontent with the St. Louis Rams players who participated in "hands up, don't shoot" displays during a game on Sunday. The gesture, which has become a symbol of the protests against the shooting of Michael Brown by Ferguson Police Officer Darren Wilson, was made by five Rams players, including Jared Cook, Kenny Britt, Stedman Bailey, Chris Givens, and Tavon Austin, during pre-game introductions. Running back Tre Mason also made the gesture after scoring a touchdown.

The SLPOA believes the displays were "tasteless, offensive, and inflammatory" and is calling for the NFL to discipline the players involved. The association claims that the gesture has become synonymous with the assertion that Michael Brown was innocent of any wrongdoing and was attempting to surrender peacefully when Wilson, according to some now-discredited witnesses, gunned him down in cold blood.

The Rams, however, deny any knowledge of the on-field demonstrations. The team played the Oakland Raiders at the Edward Jones Dome in St. Louis on Sunday, winning 52-0.

The controversy surrounding the shooting of Michael Brown has been ongoing since last week, when a grand jury declined to indict Wilson for the killing. The decision sparked riots, looting, and violence in Ferguson, Missouri. Wilson resigned from the Ferguson police force over the weekend.

The SLPOA's Jeff Roorda stated that the officers have been working 12-hour shifts for over a week, including canceling their days off, including Thanksgiving, to defend the community from those perpetuating the myth that Michael Brown was executed by a police officer. He believes the players' actions were "way out-of-bounds" and that they are "sitting safely in their dome under the watchful protection of hundreds of St. Louis's finest" while making accusations against a now-exonerated officer.

Title: Border Residents Skeptical of Trump's Plan to Build a Wall

The proposal by Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump to build a wall along the US-Mexico border has sparked controversy and skepticism among residents of the southernmost tip of the United States. The current 18-foot-tall iron security fence, erected in 2009, has been deemed ineffective in preventing illegal immigration and drug trafficking.

Bonnie Elbert, a citrus farm owner, believes that the current fence does not work and that a new, bigger wall would not be effective either. She is not alone in her skepticism. Brownsville Mayor Tony Martinez and Border Patrol Agent Chris Cabrera have also expressed doubts about the feasibility and effectiveness of the wall.

The current fence has been plagued by costly legal fights with property owners, disrupted communities, and has not stemmed the flow of undocumented immigrants. According to Border Patrol statistics, apprehensions in the Rio Grande Valley sector have more than doubled since 2009.

The Border Patrol union has endorsed Trump's plan, but Agent Cabrera believes that a bigger wall without increased manpower and technology would not be effective. He notes that smugglers have already found ways to circumvent the current fence, using ladders and tunnels.

The security fence project has also faced environmental and private property lawsuits, leading to delays and increased costs. The University of Texas-Austin School of Law's Immigration Clinic has studied the fence's impact on the border and found that most of the land along the Texas border is privately owned, making it difficult to acquire and build on.

Residents of Brownsville and surrounding areas are frustrated with the current fence, which has broken up the continuity and goodwill between the city and its sister city across the river in Mexico. The fence has also created an eyesore and a psychological barrier, with some calling it "El Berlin," alluding to the 27-mile concrete wall that once divided East and West Berlin during the Cold War.

The controversy surrounding the wall highlights the complexities and challenges of addressing illegal immigration and drug trafficking along the US-Mexico border. While some see the wall as a necessary measure to improve security, others believe it is a waste of resources and a barrier to effective solutions.

Title: The Roots of Hostility Against Hillary Clinton Run Deeper Than Recent Events

The Democratic nominee, Hillary Clinton, has faced a sense of untrustworthiness throughout her political career, with some people harboring deep-seated hostility towards her. This sentiment is not limited to a "vast right-wing conspiracy" but has its roots in her early days as first lady and has been fueled by various factors over the years.

Clinton's unfavorability rating may not be as low as that of her opponent, Donald Trump, but she has still attracted significant invective from both the left and the right. Her links to Wall Street, missing emails, and perceived responsibility for the Benghazi attack have contributed to personal attacks in the past. However, the roots of hostility towards her go much deeper.

According to Craig Shirley, a Ronald Reagan biographer and historian, Clinton's reputation as a militant feminist and her decision to keep her maiden name during her husband's governorship in Arkansas sparked hostility. The press corps already had an idea of who she was, and she gave them plenty of material to work with, including her comments about not being a "little woman standing by her man" and her "I could have stayed home and baked cookies" remark.

The scandals surrounding Whitewater and Travelgate, although not necessarily illegal, further solidified her reputation as someone who was not friendly to the media and may not have done the right thing. This perception has been shaped by societal expectations, television, and what people think people in authority should look like.

Elaine Kamarck, a Brookings Institution fellow, believes that people's dislike of Clinton is not her own fault but rather a result of societal norms and expectations. She notes that people are more likely to dislike a woman who does not fit traditional beauty standards or conform to societal norms. Kamarck suggests that Clinton reminds people of their mothers or schoolteachers they didn't like, and that there is some misogyny involved.

In conclusion, the roots of hostility against Hillary Clinton run deeper than recent events and are shaped by societal expectations, television, and what people think people in authority should look like.

Title: Special Counsel Mueller Expands Investigation into Russia's Election Meddling

The special counsel investigation into Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 US presidential election has taken a significant turn, with Robert Mueller's team requesting a grand jury in Washington, D.C. to investigate further. This development suggests that the probe is expanding and may lead to charges being filed against individuals involved.

According to reports, the grand jury will allow prosecutors to subpoena documents, ensure witnesses testify under oath, and potentially charge individuals with crimes. This move implies that Mueller's team has found sufficient evidence to warrant a more formal investigation.

The investigation has already expanded to include financial ties between Trump associates and Russia, which CNN reports are among the most fruitful areas of investigation. Mueller's team has hired 16 lawyers with expertise in various areas, including cybercrime, white-collar crime, and financial crime, indicating a comprehensive approach to the investigation.

The involvement of a grand jury suggests that there is still much to investigate over the next few months, and some experts believe that the investigation may be larger and more extensive than initially thought. The move may also make it more difficult for President Trump to fire Mueller, as it would be seen as a reaction to the growing probe.

Republicans have warned Trump against firing Mueller, with Senator Lindsey Graham stating that any effort to do so could be the beginning of the end of his presidency. It remains to be seen how Trump will react to the expanding investigation, but it is likely that he will not be pleased with the increased scrutiny of his finances, associates, and family.

Title: Obama's Job Creation Record Under Scrutiny as Election Day Approaches

The economy's recent underperformance in job creation has put President Obama's re-election campaign under pressure, with the next four monthly jobs reports unlikely to change the current trend. The Labor Department's latest report showed a disappointing job growth rate, with Republicans seizing on the data as proof of Obama's failed economic policies. However, White House officials and Democrats emphasize the positive aspects of the report, highlighting the net job creation, albeit not enough to significantly reduce the unemployment rate.

The jobs reports have become a focal point in the political spin cycle, with Republicans like Mitt Romney criticizing the administration's economic policies and Democrats like Obama highlighting the positive aspects of the data. Despite the political posturing, the reports do not provide much new information about the economy's overall health. The data suggests the economy is stuck in a lower gear, with a deficit of 10 million jobs, according to Heidi Shierholz, an economist with the Economic Policy Institute.

The unemployment rate has been above 8% for 41 months, a severe crisis for the American workforce. Conventional wisdom suggests that this could be a crisis for Obama's re-election bid, as only one incumbent president, Ronald Reagan, won re-election with an unemployment rate above 7% in 1984. However, other factors may have played a greater role in the incumbents' losses in 1976, 1980, and 1992.

Romney has made the economy's underwhelming performance the core of his argument for why a change is needed in the White House. The lackluster economic growth and job creation are significant forces driving his candidacy. While there is no indication that Romney will shift his strategy, the slowdown of economies in Europe and China may worsen the situation before it improves.

Obama can direct voters' attention to his successes on the jobs front, as he has done during his bus tour in Ohio. He has repeatedly shown that it's a mistake to underestimate him, having humbled his doubters at nearly every turn in his political career. Whether he can once again defy political gravity remains to be seen, but Obama has proved that betting against him is no sure thing.

Title: Obamacare's Third Year of Open Enrollment Begins with Rising Prices and Fewer Choices

Obamacare's third year of open enrollment has started, and individuals hoping to sign up are met with a website featuring fresh photos and high-tech features. However, the actual insurance under the president's signature law has become even more unappealing. Prices continue to rise, and service quality continues to decline, leading to a lack of interest among many Americans.

Despite the Obama administration's efforts to overhaul the healthcare system, there are still over 30 million uninsured people in the United States. The reason they are not buying into Obamacare is not because they are unaware of it, but because it is a bad deal for them. As people log onto the government exchanges this year, they will notice the telltale signs of Obamacare's impending failure, including rising costs, mounting cancellations, and disappearing choices.

Premiums are increasing by double digits in many states, with Alaska experiencing a nearly 40% increase and Minnesota seeing rates rise by 14-49%. Many plans are also raising deductibles, co-pays, and out-of-pocket costs. The administration's mantra of "If you like your health care plan, you can keep it" has given way to "If you have an Obamacare plan, you better shop around." The only advice Washington has for those who want to avoid brutal rate increases is to switch insurance plans each year.

For some individuals, their old plan will not be available at any price, including over half a million people insured by one of the health co-ops that have shut down in 11 states over the past few months. Additionally, some insurers have decided to stop selling Obamacare coverage, such as WINHealth in Wyoming. In some states, plans are changing dramatically, with patients finding that their longtime doctor will no longer be part of their plan's network or that their hospital of choice is no longer included.

As people navigate the website, they will notice that the remaining options are slimmer than ever, with more HMOs available, which can mean narrower networks and no out-of-network coverage. In some states, the number of options is practically non-existent, with only one or two companies to choose from. Insurance through Obamacare is largely coming down to a simple choice of take it or leave it, and more and more Americans are leaving it.

The only people consistently signing up are those who receive subsidies from Washington, with 90% of those who received government insurance subsidies last year getting the wrong amount. The administration is trying to lower expectations, aiming for around 10 million people enrolled for 2016, which is half of the 21 million people the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office says should be covered next year. The administration is playing the lowered expectations game because they know how hard it is to convince more Americans to buy government-mandated insurance that costs so much. For many people, Obamacare doesn't have much to offer.

Title: Far-Left Groups' Involvement in Political Violence Raises Concerns

The recent violent clashes in Charlottesville, Virginia, have brought attention to the involvement of far-left groups in the escalating political violence in the United States. While some establishment political figures have described these groups as "anti-fascists" or "antifa," their own statements and actions suggest a more sinister agenda.

Far-left groups, such as Refuse Fascism and CrimethInc, have declared their intention to disrupt the American political process and make the country "ungovernable." Refuse Fascism, in particular, has been involved in violent protests, including the Berkeley riots, where they used fire and pepper spray to shut down a speech by Milo Yiannopoulos.

Another group, Workers World Party, has been identified as a Marxist-Leninist revolutionary group that has supported the murderous dictatorship of Kim Jong Un in North Korea and the regime in Venezuela. The group has also been involved in the toppling of a Confederate statue in Durham, North Carolina.

These groups' statements and actions suggest that they are not interested in protecting the American system of government, but rather in destroying it. They believe that anarchism is necessary to destroy white supremacy and patriarchy, and that the state and capitalism are the main obstacles to achieving their goals.

The involvement of these far-left groups in political violence raises concerns about the potential for further escalation and the erosion of social order. It is essential to understand the motivations and goals of these groups to better address the growing political polarization and violence in the United States.

Title: Clinton's Handling of Official Emails Under Scrutiny, Senator Dianne Feinstein Calls for Transparency

Article:

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has yet to publicly address the controversy surrounding her use of a personal email account for official business, a move that has raised concerns about the security of sensitive information. Senator Dianne Feinstein, a California Democrat, has called on Clinton to come forward and provide clarity on the situation. According to Feinstein, Clinton's silence on the matter may ultimately harm her political standing.

Clinton has faced criticism for using a private email server hosted in her Chappaqua, New York home for official communications, which has led to speculation that she may have controlled which emails were kept for official records. The former Secretary of State has turned over 55,000 pages of emails to the State Department for review, but has declined to comment further.

In contrast, former Secretary of State Colin Powell, who served under the George W. Bush administration, has stated that he did not retain any emails sent from his personal account during his tenure. Powell explained that most of his emails were addressed to State Department employees and were sent through the State.gov domain, but he is unsure if the State Department's servers captured those emails.

Powell's comments highlight the difference in approach between Clinton and himself, with Clinton using a personal email account and Powell relying on the State Department's official system. While Powell's emails were unclassified and mostly "pretty benign," he is not concerned if they were recovered. The controversy surrounding Clinton's email practices is likely to continue until she provides more transparency on the matter.

Title: UN Warns of Humanitarian Tragedy as Islamic State Fighters Close In on Syrian City

The United Nations has warned of a pending humanitarian tragedy as Islamic State (ISIS) fighters are on the brink of taking over the Syrian city of Kobani, near the Turkish border. The city has been under siege for three weeks, with the black-clad fighters raising their flag over neighborhoods. UN Special Envoy for Syria Staffan de Mistura urged the international community to intervene, stating, "The world has seen with its own eyes the images of what happens when a city in Syria or in Iraq is overtaken by the terrorist group called ISIS or Da'esh: massacres, humanitarian tragedies, rapes, horrific violence."

The city's defenses are being led by the Kurdish People's Protection Units (YPG), who have been fighting to protect the city from the ISIS advance. The group has been aided by international airstrikes, with warplanes believed to be part of the US-led coalition against ISIS striking militant positions on Tuesday. However, the Kurdish defenders are still outmatched by the more heavily armed militants.

The capture of Kobani would give ISIS control of a large swath of land bordering Turkey and eliminate a vital pocket of Kurdish resistance. It would also provide a link between the group's territory near the ancient Syrian city of Aleppo and its largest operations base at Raqqa in northeastern Syria.

Turkey has taken in an estimated 200,000 refugees fleeing the conflict, with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan calling for greater cooperation with the Syrian opposition to fight both ISIS and forces loyal to Syrian President Bashar Assad. Erdogan has also called for a no-fly zone to be created and for a secure zone parallel to the region to be declared.

The international community is urging Turkey to take a more active role in the fight against ISIS, with US officials set to travel to Turkey later this week to discuss the status of the international coalition. Despite US pressure, Turkey has largely stayed on the sidelines, with its military stationed near the border but not taking an offensive posture.

**Venezuela's Political Crisis Enters Stalemate as Protests Fail to Dislodge Maduro**

Caracas, Venezuela - Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaido called for the "largest march" in the country's history, urging citizens to take to the streets and force President Nicolas Maduro from power. However, by late afternoon, many protesters had dispersed, and the situation remained in a stalemate.

Guaido claimed millions of Venezuelans participated in the protests, but there was little concrete evidence to support this claim. The National Guard fired tear gas at a hard-core of demonstrators, and one injured protester was carried to a first aid truck. A young woman died in surgery after being shot in the head during a protest in Caracas, according to rights organizations.

The standoff has increased tensions between the United States and Russia, with both sides accusing each other of interference in Venezuela's affairs. Despite Guaido's calls for the military to support him, the armed forces' leadership has remained loyal to Maduro, who has been in power since his mentor, Hugo Chavez, died in 2013.

The Venezuelan opposition has staged huge street protests against Maduro before, but failed to dislodge him despite a deep economic recession and hyperinflation. Demonstrators said they are prepared for a long process to oust Maduro, with some frustrated that nothing has changed three months after Guaido invoked the constitution to assume an interim presidency.

The crisis has put Venezuela at the center of global geopolitical tensions, with the United States and Russia taking opposing sides. The US has imposed sanctions on the Maduro government and refused to rule out military intervention, while Russia has accused the US of interference and warned against any aggressive steps.

**Ebola Outbreak in West Africa: Efforts Intensify as Rainy Season Approaches**

Aid workers are rushing to Guinea to combat a surge in Ebola cases, which has seen nearly 25,000 people infected and over 10,000 deaths since the outbreak began in 2013. The World Health Organization (WHO) is concerned about the rise in new infections, particularly in remote villages, where the disease is spreading rapidly. The WHO has tripled the number of personnel in the field and is urging continued efforts to track and contain the virus.

The rainy season, which begins in June, poses a significant challenge to containment efforts, as it will make it more difficult to reach remote areas and track new infections. Jordan Tappero, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's (CDC) division of global health protection, emphasized the importance of getting as close to zero with contact tracing by then.

In Sierra Leone, where the disease has been slowing down, the government has ordered its 6 million residents to stay at home for three days, except for religious services, to combat the spread of the disease. The country has seen over 3,700 deaths and almost 12,000 infections since the outbreak began.

In Guinea, new infections are emerging in unexpected areas, with many outbreaks occurring in distant villages. The WHO is concerned about the low rate of healthcare workers being infected, with only 38% of new infections in Guinea last week being among people being tracked. Contact tracing is a crucial element in defeating the virus, and the WHO is urging continued efforts to track and contain the virus.

The article highlights the challenges faced by healthcare workers in Guinea, where many outbreaks are occurring in remote villages, and the importance of getting as close to zero with contact tracing before the rainy season begins.

Title: Congresswoman Ilhan Omar Embroiled in Allegations of Affair and Campaign Finance Violations

Article:

Congresswoman Ilhan Omar, a Somali-born US representative from Minnesota, is facing allegations of an affair with Democratic strategist Tim Mynett, according to divorce papers filed by his wife, Dr. Beth Jordan Mynett. The allegations were made public in a filing submitted to DC Superior Court on Tuesday.

According to the filing, Mynett told his wife in April that he was having an affair with Omar and made a "shocking declaration of love" for the congresswoman before leaving his wife. The filing also alleges that Mynett's firm, E Street Group, received over $200,000 in campaign funds from Omar's campaign, with at least $21,000 being reimbursed for personal travel.

An official complaint has been filed with the Federal Election Commission (FEC) alleging that Omar and her campaign violated the prohibition on the personal use of campaign funds by reimbursing Mynett for his travel in 2019. The complaint also alleges that Omar and her campaign failed to itemize the travel reimbursements, as required.

The National Legal and Policy Center released a statement on Wednesday, stating that although Mynett's formal relationship with Omar's campaign began in July 2018, the reimbursements for Mynett's travel did not commence until April 2019, the same month that Dr. Mynett alleges her husband told her of the affair and made a "shocking declaration of love" for Omar.

The complaint also notes that Mynett's "more recent travel and long work hours now appear to be more related to his affair with Rep. Omar than his actual work commitments."

The Washington Examiner reported that the majority of Omar's funds spent on the E Street Group were paid after she won the contested primary and during the non-competitive general election race in her D+26 district. Contrary to FEC rules, Omar's filings did not designate whether her E Street Group disbursements were for the primary election or the general election.

Omar has refused to comment on the allegations, stating that she has no interest in discussing her "personal life." In June, Omar was ordered to pay back thousands of dollars to her campaign after breaking campaign finance laws.

Title: Obama and Boehner Prioritize Base Loyalty Over Policy Initiatives

Article:

In a move that highlights the importance of keeping their political bases happy, both President Barack Obama and House Speaker John Boehner have dropped high-profile initiatives that were once considered crucial to their respective agendas. For Obama, it was the idea to tweak inflation adjustments for Social Security, which was seen as a critical piece of entitlement reform and deficit reduction. However, the proposal was met with opposition from liberal groups, and the President has since abandoned it.

Similarly, Boehner's decision to put aside his plan for big immigration changes, including a path to legal status for millions of undocumented workers, was seen as a move to avoid angering his conservative base. The argument from the right was that turning out conservatives is key to the GOP's success in the 2014 midterm elections.

The decision to prioritize base loyalty over policy initiatives has been met with criticism from both sides. The White House and its allies argued that Boehner's retreat on immigration was shortsighted and put politics ahead of the national interest. On the other hand, Boehner's office claimed that the President has no interest in addressing the country's looming debt crisis.

The move away from major policy compromise and toward election positioning is a trend that is expected to continue in the lead-up to the 2014 midterm elections. Obama is set to attend a 2014 Organizing for Action summit, which aims to try to defy the historical odds and protect Democratic seats.

Title: Bloomberg's Potential Presidential Bid Born of Biden's Perceived Weaknesses

Article:

Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg has been flirting with the idea of running for president for years, and recent reports suggest he is preparing to make a late entrance into the 2020 Democratic primary race. Bloomberg's potential candidacy is largely driven by the perceived struggles of current front-runner Joe Biden, who has seen his poll numbers decline in recent months.

Biden's inability to stay financially competitive with other candidates, such as Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren and Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders, has raised concerns about his ability to mount a successful campaign. With less than $9 million in the bank, Biden is at a significant disadvantage compared to his rivals, who have amassed over $20 million each.

Meanwhile, South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg has been gaining momentum, particularly in Iowa, where he has positioned himself as a pragmatic alternative to Biden. However, doubts remain about whether the establishment wing of the Democratic Party will support a 37-year-old mayor with limited national experience.

Enter Bloomberg, an establishment darling with a long record of centrist policy-making and a personal fortune many times over. His willingness to enter the race is rooted in Biden's perceived struggles, and Bloomberg believes he can capitalize on the fear of a rising Warren and the potential for a Democratic nominee who is too liberal for the general election.

While Bloomberg's candidacy is not without its challenges, he has the financial resources to mount a strong campaign. However, it remains to be seen whether he can overcome his lack of national experience and appeal to working-class and minority voters, who have been a key constituency for Biden. Ultimately, Bloomberg's success will depend on his ability to turn his perceived window of opportunity into a reality.

Title: Lawmakers on Track to Avoid Government Shutdown, But Immigration Issues Remain Uncertain

Article:

Lawmakers in the United States are working to avoid a repeat of last month's government shutdown, with a short-term spending measure passed by the House and Senate leaders closing in on a broader budget pact. The agreement would provide significant spending increases for the Pentagon and domestic federal programs, as well as approve overdue disaster relief money and potentially crucial legislation to increase the government's borrowing limit and avoid a possible default.

The House passed a six-week stopgap spending bill on Tuesday night, mostly along party lines, which contains increases for the military that have long been demanded by President Donald Trump and his Republican allies. The measure appears increasingly likely to be rewritten by the Senate to include legislation implementing the broader budget pact.

Senate leaders, including Republican Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and Chuck Schumer of New York, have intensified their budget negotiations in recent days, with the looming government shutdown at midnight Thursday adding urgency to the talks. The deal taking shape would also approve overdue disaster relief money and potentially crucial legislation to increase the government's borrowing limit and avoid possible default.

However, prospects for dealing with immigration issues remain uncertain. The Senate is slated to begin a debate next week to address the dilemma of immigrants left vulnerable by the looming expiration of former President Barack Obama's Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program. Weeks of bargaining have left the two parties divided over how to extend protections for such "Dreamer" immigrants, and a court ruling has blunted a March 5 deadline.

White House Chief of Staff John Kelly defended Trump's proposed solution, which would expand protection for 1.8 million immigrants, including those who have not signed up for the program. However, Senate Democratic Leader Dick Durbin of Illinois bristled at the comment, calling it "unfortunate" and "unfortunate."

The budget negotiations have also led to a compromise on spending priorities, with Democrats leveraging their influence to increase spending for domestic priorities such as combating opioid misuse, while Republicans have prevailed on defense spending. The result could be the return of trillion-dollar deficits for the first time since Obama's first term.

The stopgap spending bill would keep the government open through March 23 to allow time to write and pass detailed follow-up "omnibus" legislation to fund the government through the September 30 end of the fiscal year. The prospective longer-term budget agreement would give both the Pentagon and domestic agencies relief from a budget freeze that lawmakers say threatens military readiness and training as well as domestic priorities such as combating opioid abuse and repairing the government's troubled health care system for veterans.

Title: Trump's Surprise Decision to Ban Transgender Military Personnel Sparks Controversy

The sudden decision by U.S. President Donald Trump to ban transgender personnel from serving in the military has left senior military officers and rights groups reeling. Trump's declaration, made via Twitter on Wednesday, appeared to pre-empt an ongoing Pentagon review on allowing openly transgender recruits to join the military. The decision has been met with criticism from three senior officers interviewed by [news outlet], who expressed concerns about the implementation of the ban and its potential impact on transgender active-duty service members and reservists.

The United States' top military officer, Marine General Joseph Dunford, acknowledged the uncertainty surrounding the decision, stating that there had been no change to Pentagon policy on transgender personnel. Dunford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, emphasized that any changes would require direction from the President and guidance from the Secretary of Defense.

The Defense Department had been expected to begin formally allowing transgender people to enlist this year, but Trump's decision has put those plans on hold. The ban has been met with criticism from rights groups and some lawmakers from both parties, who argue that it is a form of discrimination.

The Trump administration has cited "tremendous medical costs and disruption" as justification for the ban, a point disputed by experts and advocates for allowing military service to be determined by an individual's capabilities, not gender identity or sexual preference. The Army's chief of staff, General Mark Milley, acknowledged that there have been issues with transgender individuals serving in the Army, but emphasized that it is a complex issue.

The Trump administration's decision has also sparked legal threats from advocates who are seeking plaintiffs to sue over the ban. The Pentagon is likely to face an especially contentious fight if it actively roots out transgender people and discharges them from the military.

The decision has left many questions unanswered, including when the ban will go into effect and whether it applies to serving members of the military or those wishing to join. One active-duty U.S. military officer expressed frustration and confusion over the decision, stating that senior officials were not consulted and that the military is "out of step" with today's personnel.

The controversy surrounding Trump's decision highlights the ongoing debate over the role of transgender individuals in the military. While some argue that the ban is necessary to ensure military effectiveness, others believe that it is a form of discrimination that goes against the values of equality and fairness.

Title: The Legalization of Marijuana: A Potential Game-Changer for the Media Industry

The recent editorial by The New York Times advocating for the legalization of marijuana has sparked a renewed interest in the potential economic benefits of the industry. With the potential to become as lucrative as cigarette and alcohol sales, the media industry stands to gain significantly from the legalization of marijuana. The article highlights the potential for marijuana companies to become major advertisers, similar to cigarette and alcohol companies, which could bring in significant revenue for media outlets.

The legalization of marijuana would also allow for the marketing of the product, which could lead to a new wave of advertising opportunities for the media industry. The article notes that restricting marijuana advertising to print media could be a way to protect young people and promote a more mature audience for the product.

The article also touches on the broader implications of marijuana legalization, including the potential for a resurgence in print media and the growth of a new industry around pot-related content. The author suggests that the legalization of marijuana could lead to a reconnection between mainstream media and young people, who are currently distracted by video games and social media.

The article concludes by noting that the legalization of marijuana could become a unifying cultural principle, bringing people together and creating a new common experience. This could be a game-changer for the media industry, providing a new focus and a way to connect with a wider audience.

Overall, the article presents a balanced view of the potential benefits and challenges of the legalization of marijuana, highlighting the potential for the media industry to benefit from this new market.

**Teenage Girls from the United States Attempt to Join ISIS in Syria**

Three teenage girls from the United States, aged 15, 16, and 17, were intercepted by German authorities at Frankfurt airport and returned to the US after attempting to travel to Turkey and join the Islamic State (ISIS) in Syria. The girls, who are of Sudanese and Somali descent, had planned the trip for months and researched how to get to Syria online.

According to officials, the girls' parents were unaware of their daughters' plans and thought they were simply running late for school. The FBI is investigating the incident and reviewing the girls' communications to determine if anyone was helping them.

This incident is one of several recent cases of young people from the West attempting to join ISIS. In the past week, a radical convert to Islam in Canada ran down two soldiers in his car, killing one of them, and a 17-year-old Australian boy appeared in a video standing with ISIS fighters and threatening to behead Western leaders.

According to intelligence estimates, over 100 foreign fighters have joined ISIS from the United States, and hundreds more from Europe. A former CIA officer attributes the appeal of ISIS to young people's search for identity and a sense of belonging, as well as the group's ability to provide a narrative of oppression and heroism.

Terror experts are concerned about the potential for homegrown violent extremism and lone-wolf attacks in the US, as well as the group's ability to use social media to spread its message and recruit new members. The FBI is working to track and prevent such incidents, but the use of the internet makes it more difficult to identify potential threats.

Title: Obama's Approval Rating Hits New Low, Disapproval Rate Reaches High

President Barack Obama's approval rating has reached a new low of 37 percent, according to a recent CBS News poll. This marks a 9-point drop since October and a significant decline in his overall approval rating. The disapproval rate has reached a new high of 57 percent.

The poll also shows that the approval rating for the Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare, has hit an all-time low of 31 percent, with 61 percent disapproving of the law. Forty-six percent of respondents said they "disapprove strongly" of the law.

The poll found that 88 percent of Republicans disapprove of the law, with little change from last month's 87 percent figure. However, approval among independents fell from 38 percent to 27 percent, and approval among Democrats dropped from 74 percent to 58 percent.

The poll also revealed that two-thirds of Americans believe the signup process for insurance on government health care exchanges is not going well, and nearly two-thirds are not confident that the federal HealthCare.gov website will be mostly fixed by December 1. The White House has set a goal of 80 percent enrollment among all users of the website, which some have described as a "best-case scenario."

In a statement, White House Press Secretary Jay Carney said that the 20 percent who are unable to enroll include those who are not "comfortable" signing up online or have personal circumstances that are too "complex" to use the website.

The poll also found that a majority of Americans do not favor the outright repeal of the law. Seven percent think it is working well and should be kept as is, 48 percent think some changes are needed, and 43 percent think it should be repealed.

During the presidential campaign last fall, 60 percent of voters viewed Obama as honest and trustworthy, compared to 49 percent in the current poll. Americans also hold dim views of both parties in Congress, with 26 percent approving of congressional Democrats and 21 percent approving of congressional Republicans.

Title: Bergdahl's Freedom Sparks Controversy and Political Debate

The recent news of Bowe Bergdahl's release from Taliban captivity has sparked a heated debate among politicians and the public. Republican legislators have criticized the Obama administration's decision to exchange five Taliban prisoners for Bergdahl, with some calling it a betrayal and a sign of weakness. However, this criticism is not new and has been levied against previous presidents, including George W. Bush, John McCain, and Mitt Romney, who would have made similar deals to secure the release of American prisoners.

The criticism of the Obama administration's decision is based on the notion that negotiating with terrorists is unacceptable and that the price paid for Bergdahl's freedom was too high. However, this argument is flawed, as the United States has been negotiating with the Taliban for years to end the war in Afghanistan. The five prisoners exchanged for Bergdahl are considered to be among the most dangerous and violent Taliban leaders, and their release may have been a necessary step towards achieving a peaceful resolution to the conflict.

Furthermore, the idea that the Obama administration's decision will embolden other terrorist groups to take American hostages is also unfounded. Guerrilla forces have been taking hostages since the beginning of warfare, and the United States has made prisoner exchanges in the past, including in Afghanistan.

The article also highlights the personal story of Bergdahl, who was a disillusioned soldier who wandered away from his unit and was captured by the Taliban. While some consider him a deserter, he is officially in good standing with the Army and has received promotions during his time in captivity.

The controversy surrounding Bergdahl's release is likely to continue, with some Republicans using it as a way to attack the Obama administration and others to criticize Bergdahl himself. However, the majority of Americans are likely to see the release as a feel-good story, celebrating the safe return of an American soldier.

Title: Job Market Booms as Employers Drop Degree and Experience Requirements

Article:

The job market is experiencing a surge, with more job openings than people looking for work. This trend is attributed to a significant increase in business investment, particularly in the private sector. According to data, business investment has risen by 9.4% during the first half of 2018, leading to a boost in job creation. This is largely due to the Trump administration's tax cuts, particularly the reduction in the corporate tax rate.

As a result, companies are more willing to hire, and job seekers like David Casarez, a 26-year-old software developer, are reaping the benefits. Casarez's homemade cardboard sign, which read "Homeless – Hungry 4 Success – Take a Resume," caught the attention of a passerby who posted his photo on Twitter. Within a day, he received over 200 job offers.

Despite this positive trend, Democratic presidential candidates Senators Kirsten Gillibrand, Cory Booker, and Bernie Sanders are advocating for a "guaranteed jobs" program. This proposal suggests that the federal government should provide a job and a paycheck to anyone who is not working, paid for by taxpayers. House Democrats have also introduced legislation to implement this program.

However, critics argue that this approach is misguided and would likely harm the economy. The U.S. already has 41 federal jobs programs costing $17 billion annually, with little success in getting people into lasting private sector jobs. Additionally, the National Bureau of Economic Research survey by David Card of University of California Berkeley and co-authors found that make-work programs have an abysmal record of getting people into lasting private sector jobs.

Moreover, some argue that the Democrats' job-guarantee campaign is not genuinely interested in helping people find work, but rather is a thinly disguised effort at radical income redistribution. The proposal is often linked to the idea of a universal government-guaranteed income, where everyone receives a check from the government, regardless of whether they work or not. This concept was praised by former President Barack Obama, who stated that it would help "stamp out inequality."

In Chicago, the Democratic-controlled municipal legislature is backing a plan to give 1,000 families a $500 monthly stipend, no questions asked, no work required. This raises concerns that the Democrats' proposals would make paychecks fair game for those who won't work at all.

For those like David Casarez, who are determined to earn their own living, it is essential to be aware of the potential consequences of these proposals.

Title: Washington Leaders Engage in Ongoing Negotiations to Avoid Fiscal Cliff

Washington D.C. - As the deadline for the fiscal cliff approaches, top Democrats and Republicans are engaged in intense negotiations to reach a deal. The key issue at stake is the inclusion of tax increases on the wealthy as part of a broader agreement. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi has flatly stated that she will not accept a deal that does not include such provisions.

Republicans, on the other hand, are open to modifying the tax code and eliminating some deductions, particularly those that benefit the rich. However, they are resistant to outright tax increases. President Obama has softened his rhetoric in recent days, focusing on closing loopholes and other means to generate revenue from the wealthy.

Finding a middle ground that satisfies both sides is crucial to reaching a deal. Democrats see the ongoing discussion as an opportunity to address the issue, while Republicans are pushing for deeper, more permanent changes to the federal government's financial structure.

Congressional Republicans are urging for a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution, limiting government spending growth, and capping government spending as a percentage of GDP. They argue that without these structural changes, the country will only be kicking the can down the road.

The president and congressional leaders met at the White House on Friday to discuss the issue, with Obama emphasizing the need for tough compromises and action. The president has called for tax increases on families earning more than $250,000 per year, while preserving tax cuts for those below that income level.

The negotiations come as the country faces the expiration of tax cuts and automatic spending cuts set to hit most government agencies in the new year. The public is looking for action and cooperation from Washington leaders to address the fiscal cliff.

Title: Democrats Intensify Pressure on Trump Administration Over Mueller Report

Article:

The Democratic Party has increased its pressure on the Trump administration over the handling of the Mueller report, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi accusing Attorney General William Barr of committing a crime by lying to lawmakers. The dispute centers around Barr's testimony to Congress regarding his interactions with Special Counsel Robert Mueller's team and the release of the report.

Pelosi stated that Barr's testimony was "reckless, irresponsible, and false," while Justice Department spokeswoman Kerri Kupec called Pelosi's allegation "reckless, irresponsible, and false." The dispute has escalated tensions between the White House and Democrats, who control the House of Representatives.

The House Judiciary Committee has issued a subpoena to Barr, demanding a full, unredacted copy of the Mueller report and underlying evidence. Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler threatened to hold Barr in contempt of Congress if he does not comply. Barr has refused to appear before the committee, citing the White House's stance that Trump has the right to tell his advisors not to testify.

The dispute has sparked concerns about the Trump administration's commitment to transparency and the authority of Congress. Pelosi has accused the administration of ignoring congressional subpoenas and likened the situation to the Watergate scandal, which led to President Richard Nixon's resignation.

The Trump administration has defended its actions, with White House legal counsel Emmet Flood stating that Trump has the right to tell his advisors not to testify. Flood also criticized Mueller's report, calling it "an extraordinary legal defect" and stating that it failed to determine whether Trump committed the crime of obstruction of justice.

The dispute has significant implications for the Trump administration, as Democrats consider whether to try to remove the president from office using the impeachment process. The situation remains ongoing, with the House Judiciary Committee planning to move forward with a contempt citation against Barr and the possibility of issuing a subpoena to force him to testify.

Title: House Intelligence Committee Releases Report on 2016 Presidential Election, Finds No Evidence of Trump-Russia Collusion

The House Intelligence Committee has released its final report on the 2016 presidential election, concluding that there is no evidence of ties between President Donald Trump's campaign and Russia. The report, written by Republicans on the committee, does criticize the Trump and Clinton campaigns for "poor judgment and ill-considered actions."

The report found that Russia did conduct a "multi-faceted" active measures campaign against the U.S. in an effort to "sow fear and division in American society." However, it did not find any evidence of collusion, coordination, or conspiracy between the Trump campaign and the Russian government.

The committee had previously revealed in a one-page summary of the report's findings that it had found no evidence of collusion. The report's release comes after a yearlong investigation that was marked by contentious panel infighting and a decision by the committee to end the investigation last month.

The report's release has been met with criticism from Democrats, who have called the move premature and an attempt to shield the White House from scrutiny. The report's author, Conaway, expressed disappointment with the number of redactions made by the intelligence community, stating that many of the redactions include information that is publicly available.

Conaway has vowed to challenge the redactions and hopes to release more information in the coming months. The report's release is seen as a significant development in the ongoing investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.

Title: Republicans Propose Permanent Tax Cuts, Democrats Oppose, Ahead of Congressional Elections

Article:

The Republican-controlled House of Representatives has proposed making permanent the individual income tax cuts approved in December, which are seen by some tax experts as unlikely to become law. The move is aimed at winning votes ahead of the November 6 elections, where control of Congress will be at stake.

The proposed "Tax Reform 2.0" package would eliminate the maximum age for some retirement account contributions and allow new businesses to write off more start-up costs. House Tax Committee Chairman Kevin Brady plans to put the measure to a committee-level vote on Thursday, with a full House vote expected by October 1.

President Donald Trump and his Republicans tout the December tax cuts as a boost to the economy, an important feature of their campaign push to defend their majorities in the House and Senate against a challenge from Democrats. However, Democrats say the cuts mainly helped the wealthy and corporations.

The cuts passed in December are projected to add an estimated $1.5 trillion over a decade to the federal deficit, the difference between Washington's spending and the taxes it collects. The new round being proposed by Republicans would add a further $576 billion to the deficit, even taking possibly higher economic growth into account, said the Tax Foundation, a pro-business think tank in Washington.

Some Republicans from Democratic-leaning states worry that constituents already dislike the cap on the federal deduction for state and local tax payments, known as SALT, which was part of the December tax cuts. A dozen House Republicans opposed the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act last December, all but one from high-tax Democratic states such as New York, New Jersey, and California. The new package would make the capped SALT deduction permanent.

Under Trump and the Republican-controlled Congress, the federal deficit has begun growing rapidly again and is expected to blow through $1 trillion in 2019. If that happens, it would be the first time since 2012 the U.S. economy would have to support such a large deficit, highlighting a basic shift for the Republican Party, which once prided itself on fiscal conservatism.

Title: Iran Threatens to Abandon Nuclear Deal, Citing Unmet "National Interests"

Iran has threatened to abandon its nuclear agreement with global powers, citing unmet "national interests," just over a year after the deal was reached. The warning comes after Iran breached international agreements by test-firing ballistic missiles, which violate current U.N. Security Council resolutions.

According to Iranian Deputy Foreign Minister Abbas Araqchi, the country will reconsider its participation in the deal if its "national interests" are not met. "If our interests are not met under the nuclear deal, there will be no reason for us to continue," Araqchi said in remarks delivered to Iranian officials in Tehran.

The threat comes as the international community is still assessing the implications of Iran's recent ballistic missile test, which is the third since the deal was announced. The White House has stated that the test does not violate the nuclear agreement, but the U.N. is investigating whether Iran can be punished for violating other sanctions or agreements.

Iranian President Hassan Rouhani was in Europe in January, securing billions of dollars in new business deals after sanctions were lifted as a result of the nuclear deal. However, if Iran were to abandon the deal, it would be challenging for Europe to cut ties entirely, as new sanctions would likely be imposed.

The development highlights the ongoing tensions surrounding the nuclear agreement and the challenges in maintaining international cooperation on the issue.

Title: Jeb Bush's Presidential Bid Faces Challenges as He Struggles to Distance Himself from Brother's Legacy

Jeb Bush, the former Florida governor and likely presidential candidate, faced a major test this week as he struggled to distance himself from his brother's legacy, particularly the Iraq War. Bush's reluctance to criticize his brother's decision to invade Iraq, despite knowing what he knows now, has raised questions about his willingness to distance himself from his brother's presidency.

In an interview with Megyn Kelly on Fox News, Bush initially said he would have authorized the 2003 invasion, even given what is now known about the faulty intelligence. He later walked back his comment, saying he had interpreted the question incorrectly. However, his hesitation to provide a clear answer has left many Republicans baffled.

Bush's struggles to distance himself from his brother's legacy are a major challenge for his presidential bid. The Iraq War remains deeply unpopular with the American public, and Bush's inability to clearly articulate his stance on the issue has raised concerns about his ability to lead.

Despite his struggles, Bush still has a strong political network and a team of experienced advisers. He also has the potential to raise a significant amount of money, thanks to his family's political connections. However, he will need to find a way to present himself as a Republican of the future, rather than a man burdened by his family's past.

Bush's campaign is still in its early stages, and he has not yet officially announced his candidacy. However, his struggles to distance himself from his brother's legacy are already raising questions about his ability to lead and his willingness to take a stand on important issues.

Title: Trump's Unconventional Rise: A New Era in American Politics?

Article:

The Republican presidential primary has reached a turning point, as Ted Cruz suspended his campaign after Donald Trump's decisive win in Indiana. This development marks a significant shift in American politics, with Trump becoming the first businessman with no prior political experience to virtually secure a major party's nomination in 75 years. The last instance of this was Wendell Willkie's surprise victory in 1940.

Trump's unconventional rise to power is more than just his business background. He is the most unconventional figure either party has put forward in modern times. While he will enter the general election as an underdog, his chances of winning the White House are not insignificant. In the coming months, American voters and the media will need to carefully examine both his strengths and weaknesses.

What is clear so far is that millions of voters see Trump as a strong leader who can reverse the national direction. Often, voters turn to candidates whose strengths compensate for the weaknesses of the sitting president. This is evident in the election of Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan, and Barack Obama, who were seen as a departure from their predecessors.

Trump's supporters believe he will act decisively to address their frustrations, and his unconventional and outrageous nature is seen as a sign of authenticity. As the general election approaches, it is crucial for voters to continue examining Trump's strengths and weaknesses to better understand his candidacy.

Title: Arizona Confirms Two More Measles Cases, Warns of Potential Exposure to Hundreds

Arizona public health officials have confirmed two new cases of measles, both linked to a family of four who had traveled to Disneyland in California. The cases, a man in Pinal County and a woman in Phoenix, bring the total number of confirmed measles cases in the state to at least four.

According to Will Humble, director of the Arizona Department of Health Services, the outbreak has reached a "critical point" and is expected to continue growing. The number of cases may exceed the state's last measles outbreak in 2008, Humble warned.

Health officials believe the Phoenix-area woman may have exposed as many as 195 children to the disease at the Phoenix Children's East Valley Center on January 20 and 21. Maricopa County officials are in the process of contacting the affected children's families.

The confirmed cases have prompted health officials to recommend that exposed children who have not had at least one dose of the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine stay home from school or day care for the 21-day incubation period. Exposed adults who were born after 1957, have not had measles, or have had only one MMR vaccine dose should also avoid work or public places for the same 21-day period.

The Pinal County case has raised concerns about potential exposure for other residents or visitors in the area, as the infected man visited various public locations while still infectious. Officials have compiled a list of businesses where he visited, including a Kearny, Ariz. gas station and post office.

Symptoms of measles typically appear seven to 12 days after exposure, but may take up to 21 days. According to Pinal County health officials, measles begins with a fever, red and watery eyes, a cough, and a runny nose, followed by a red, raised, and blotchy rash that begins on the head at the hairline and moves to the lower extremities.

The recent outbreak is thought to have originated at Disneyland before Christmas, with 59 confirmed cases reported in California and cases also reported in Washington, Utah, Colorado, and Oregon.

Title: Parkland Shooting Victim's Father Blames Democratic Policies for Daughter's Murder, Calls for Parents to Take Action

Article:

Andrew Pollack, the father of Parkland shooting victim Meadow Pollack, has written a new book detailing his investigation into the events leading up to the massacre. In the book, "Why Meadow Died: The People and Policies That Created the Parkland Shooter and Endanger America's Students," Pollack argues that Democratic policies are responsible for his daughter's murder. He claims that the current gun control laws are ineffective and that the Parkland shooter was able to obtain a weapon legally despite having a violent record.

Pollack believes that new gun control laws are not the solution to the school shooting epidemic. Instead, he argues that addressing mental health issues and arresting individuals who make threats are the real issues. He also criticizes the Democratic Party for not taking action to address these problems.

In an interview with Fox & Friends, Pollack stated that banning guns is not the answer and encouraged people to look at the underlying causes of these shootings. He also expressed his frustration with the Democratic Party, saying that his daughter's death was a result of their policies and that he holds them responsible.

Pollack has met with President Trump five times and has applauded his initiative to establish a federal school safety commission to investigate what steps need to be taken to ensure safety in schools across the country. He has also written a guide for parents to spot warning signs of potential shooters and to explain that Meadow's death was avoidable.

The book has been described as "stunning and raw" by Neil Cavuto, who has called it a "manual or guide for parents and grandparents to read it and actually look at what happened in Parkland." Pollack is committed to educating parents across the country on being alert and responsive to potential dangers surrounding their children, so no parent has to experience the pain and grief that continues to haunt him more than a year later.

Title: Trump Faces Over 50 Lawsuits in First Two Weeks in Office

The Trump administration has faced more than 50 lawsuits in its first two weeks in office, a significantly higher number than his predecessors faced during their initial days on the job. The lawsuits are primarily related to the travel ban on refugees and nationals from seven mostly-Muslim countries, which was issued on January 27. The ban has sparked widespread criticism and legal challenges, with many arguing that it violates the First, Fifth, and 14th Amendments, which guarantee religious equality, due process, and equal protection under the law.

The lawsuits have been filed in 17 different states by a diverse group of individuals, including doctors, professors, students, people fleeing violence, and Iraqis who have worked for the U.S. military. Some individuals were detained in American airports for hours over the weekend, while others were barred from boarding planes bound for the U.S. Two Syrian brothers with visas to enter the country say they were turned around at Philadelphia International Airport and sent back to Damascus.

Human rights organizations and attorneys general in five states have joined some of the suits, alleging violations of the aforementioned amendments, as well as denials of asylum and discriminatory visa processing. The city of San Francisco sued over Trump's directive to withhold federal funds from sanctuary cities, while lawyers representing the group Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington sued over Trump's alleged conflicts of interest.

The White House is fighting all the lawsuits, with Trump calling the ethics suit "without merit" and arguing that the immigration orders are necessary to keep the country safe. The Trump administration's legal strategy is to fight back against the lawsuits, with Trump stating during the campaign that he would "take it all the way" when sued.

The lawsuits over Trump's executive orders could be huge obstacles to his agenda for years to come, with court hearings on the challenges over his travel ban already underway across the country.

**Trump Blames Protesters for Canceled Rally, Claims Supporters of Rivals Caused Disruptions**

A rally by Republican presidential front-runner Donald Trump was canceled on Friday night in Chicago, with the event's organizers citing security concerns. The decision was met with protests and scuffles outside the University of Illinois at Chicago Pavilion, where the rally was held. Four men and a woman were arrested, with four still in police custody and one given an ordinance citation and released.

Trump took to Twitter to blame the protesters for the cancellation, claiming that supporters of his Democratic rivals, Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders, were responsible for the disruptions. "It is (Hillary) Clinton and (Bernie) Sanders people who disrupted my rally in Chicago - and then they say I must talk to my people," Trump tweeted.

However, the Vermont senator's campaign denied any involvement in the protests, stating that while they appreciate that some of their supporters were present at the rally, they did not organize the protests. "What caused the violence at Trump's rally is a campaign whose words and actions have encouraged it on the part of his supporters," the campaign said.

The Chicago Police Department reported that four individuals were arrested, with one given an ordinance citation and released. Another individual, activist William Calloway, was arrested and charged with misdemeanor criminal trespassing. Calloway, who was involved in the court-ordered release of a police video of a white officer fatally shooting a black teenager, believes that his role in the McDonald case may have factored into his arrest.

Trump held a rally in the Dayton suburb of Vandalia on Saturday afternoon and planned an event in Cleveland ahead of primary voting in Ohio on Tuesday. He denied some media reports that a rally in Cincinnati on Sunday had been canceled.

The incident has sparked a heated debate about the tone and rhetoric of the Trump campaign, with some critics accusing him of inciting violence and others defending his supporters' actions. Trump's rivals for the GOP nomination, including Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz, and John Kasich, have also weighed in on the issue, blaming the front-runner's rhetoric for the violence and calling for a more civil campaign.

Title: Eric Holder's Political Legacy: A Reflection of the Democratic Party's Shift

Article:

Eric Holder, the former Attorney General of the United States, has been a prominent figure in Democratic politics for decades. However, his recent actions and statements have sparked controversy and raised questions about the direction of the Democratic Party. Holder has been accused of excusing and supporting radical and anti-American groups, including the FALN separatists and al-Qaeda sympathizers. He has also been criticized for his involvement in the Fast and Furious scandal, which armed Mexican drug cartels and resulted in the death of a border patrol agent.

Holder's political views and actions have been shaped by his association with radical figures such as Saul Alinsky and his involvement in the 1960s radical movement. He has also been influenced by his friend and fellow Democrat, Al Sharpton, who has a history of inciting racial tensions and violence.

The article argues that Holder's actions and statements reflect the Democratic Party's shift towards a more radical and divisive politics. The author suggests that Holder's views on "going low" and "going high" are a facade, and that the Democratic Party's true intentions are to use any means necessary to achieve their goals, including intimidation and violence.

The article also highlights the contrast between Holder's views and those of conservative politicians, such as Steve Scalise and Rand Paul, who have been targeted by the Democratic Party's "any means necessary" politics. The author argues that the Democratic Party's obsession with power and their willingness to use any means necessary to achieve it is a threat to the country's democratic institutions and values.

Overall, the article presents a critical view of Eric Holder's political legacy and the Democratic Party's shift towards radical and divisive politics.

Title: US and China Reach Deal to Return Stolen Drone, Tensions Remain High

The United States and China have reached an agreement for the return of a US Navy research drone seized by Chinese naval forces from international waters in the South China Sea. The Pentagon confirmed the deal, stating that Chinese authorities will return the underwater unmanned vehicle (UUV) to the US.

The incident occurred on Thursday when a Chinese crew removed the drone from the water, prompting US military officials to object to the "unlawful seizure" of their equipment. The US Navy had deployed the drone about 100 miles from the US Navy base at Subic Bay in the Philippines, where it was conducting oceanographic research.

Chinese military leaders expressed regret over the incident but criticized American leaders for overreacting. The Chinese Defense Ministry spokesman, Sr. Col. Yang Yujun, stated that the US had "unilaterally hyped up the issue" and that it was "inappropriate and unhelpful" for a resolution.

The US military officials did not disclose when or how the drone would be returned, but they emphasized their objection to China's actions. The incident has sparked tensions between the two nations, with some experts speculating that China targeted the drone in response to President-elect Donald Trump's increasingly confrontational rhetoric.

The incident has also sparked debate among US politicians, with some, like Connecticut Democratic Sen. Chris Murphy, calling the escalation of the diplomatic crisis with China "madness," while others, like Republican Arizona Sen. John McCain, have called it a "flagrant violation of the freedom of the seas" and urged the country not to stand for such outrageous conduct.

Title: Supreme Court Rules Political Gerrymandering Cases Outside Federal Courts' Jurisdiction

The Supreme Court has ruled 5-4 that political partisan gerrymandering cases are outside the purview of federal courts, a decision that highlights the ideological divide among the nine justices and is likely to have lasting implications. The ruling was met with immediate outcry from Democrats and anti-gerrymandering activists, who had sought to challenge in court political district maps they believed were unconstitutional.

In the majority opinion, Chief Justice John Roberts wrote that federal courts cannot consider partisan gerrymandering cases, stating that excessive partisanship in districting leads to results that seem unjust, but the solution does not lie with the federal judiciary. The conservative justices, including Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito, Neil Gorsuch, and Brett Kavanaugh, joined Roberts in the majority opinion.

The dissenting justices, Elena Kagan, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Stephen Breyer, and Sonia Sotomayor, argued that the court's decision was a failure to remedy a constitutional violation. Kagan read part of her dissent from the bench, underscoring her opposition to the ruling.

The ruling was made in two cases involving district maps in Maryland and North Carolina, which were alleged to be instances of unconstitutional partisan gerrymandering. The decision means that pending litigation challenging other states' congressional districts as partisan gerrymanders are likely to fail.

Title: US Imposes New Sanctions on Iranian Individuals and Companies

The Trump administration has announced new economic sanctions on 13 Iranian individuals and 12 companies, citing Iran's recent missile tests and support for rebels in Yemen. The sanctions aim to target Iran's ballistic missile program and alleged support for terrorist groups, according to the Treasury Department.

The sanctions freeze any property or funds these individuals and companies may have under US jurisdiction, and US persons are prohibited from engaging in transactions with them. The Treasury Department stated that this action reflects the US commitment to enforcing sanctions on Iran with respect to its ballistic missile program and destabilizing activities in the region.

The sanctions are not related to the Iranian nuclear deal, which the Trump administration has shown no signs of voiding. The Treasury Department emphasized that the sanctions are aimed at addressing Iran's ballistic missile program and alleged support for terrorist groups, rather than the nuclear deal.

Iran has denied that its missile tests violate UN regulations and has mocked the president's criticism. The country's senior adviser, Ali Akbar Velayati, called the US sanctions "empty and baseless ranting" and warned that the new administration will realize that threatening Iran will not work.

The sanctions are the result of an ongoing review of Iranian activity that began during the Obama administration. The Treasury Department is being led by Acting Secretary Adam J. Szubin, a holdover from the Obama administration, while Trump's nominee, Steve Mnuchin, awaits Senate confirmation.

Lawmakers generally applauded the sanctions but questioned some of the administration's saber-rattling towards Iran. Senator Mark Warner, D-Va., urged the administration to bring clarity to its overall strategy towards Iran and to refrain from ambiguous rhetoric or provocative tweets that may exacerbate efforts to confront challenges.

Title: Trump Signs Bill Establishing Space Force, First New Military Service in Over 70 Years

The United States has established its first new military service in over 70 years, with President Donald Trump signing the 2020 National Defense Authorization Act, which includes the creation of the Space Force. The new service will be responsible for organizing and training military personnel to defend U.S. interests in space.

The Space Force will be administered by the Secretary of the Air Force and will have a first-year budget of $40 million and about 200 personnel. The military's largest service, the Army, has about 480,000 active-duty soldiers and a budget of about $181 billion.

The creation of the Space Force is seen as an affirmation of the need to more effectively organize for the defense of U.S. interests in space, particularly satellites used for navigation and communication. The military's reliance on space-based capabilities has grown dramatically, and outer space has evolved into a warfighting domain of its own.

Defense Secretary Mark Esper stated that maintaining dominance in space will be the mission of the Space Force. The Pentagon has asserted that China and Russia have embarked on major efforts to develop technologies that could allow them to disrupt or destroy American and allied satellites in a crisis or conflict.

The creation of the Space Force has been a topic of debate, with some Democrats opposing the idea of making it a separate branch of the military. However, the legislation has been passed, and the Space Force will be established as a provider of forces to U.S. Space Command, a separate organization established earlier this year as the overseer of the military's space operations.

The division of responsibilities and assets between Space Force and Space Command has not been fully worked out, and some experts believe that the creation of the Space Force could be curtailed or even dissolved if a Democrat wins the White House next November.

Title: Mitt Romney to Launch Five-Day Bus Tour in Six Swing States

Mitt Romney is set to embark on a five-day bus tour, dubbed the "Every Town Counts" tour, which will take him to six battleground states. The tour will kick off on Friday in New Hampshire and will cover Michigan, Iowa, Pennsylvania, Ohio, and Wisconsin.

During the tour, Romney will focus on small towns and campaign in all six states, which are crucial to the November election. The Republican presidential candidate has criticized President Obama's policies, stating that the president has "left American families to bear the burden of his failed policies."

While the campaign has not released specific city stops, local media outlets have reported some of the tour's itinerary. Romney will start the tour in Stratham, New Hampshire, where he announced his presidential bid one year ago. He will also visit Davenport, Iowa, on the following Monday, marking his third visit to the state since the caucuses.

The tour coincides with polls setting the stage for a competitive fight in swing states, with both campaigns investing heavily in advertising and voter outreach. According to a poll by Purple Strategies, Romney and Obama are neck and neck in four key swing states, with Romney leading in Ohio and Florida, and Obama ahead in Virginia and Colorado. In Michigan, Romney is currently leading Obama by one point, according to an EPIC-MRA poll.

The "Every Town Counts" tour aims to put Romney on the ground in key states, where he will connect with voters and discuss his campaign's message. The tour will conclude with a night in Michigan, followed by fundraisers in Grand Rapids and Troy on June 20.

Title: Celebrities Urge Fans to Register to Vote Ahead of November Mid-Terms

Celebrities are taking to social media to encourage their fans to register to vote ahead of the November mid-term elections. Rihanna, Taylor Swift, Chance the Rapper, John Legend, and other stars are using their platforms to remind their followers of the importance of exercising their right to vote.

Rihanna, with her 65 million followers, posted a message urging her fans to register to vote, stating that it is a "greater responsibility" than any other task. She shared a graphic highlighting the registration deadlines in various states, emphasizing the need for immediate action.

Taylor Swift, who broke her political silence, endorsed Democratic candidates Phil Breseden for Senate and Jim Cooper for the House of Representatives in her home state of Tennessee. She encouraged her 112 million followers to register to vote, stating that it is a "quick and easy" process.

The singer's post had a significant impact, with over 166,000 people registering to vote within 24 hours, with 42% of those registrants aged between 18-24. Swift also used her acceptance speech at the American Music Awards to urge her fans to vote, stating that the midterm elections are just around the corner.

Other celebrities, including Kim Kardashian-West, Chance the Rapper, John Legend, Eva Longoria, Tom Hanks, Janelle Monae, and Brendan Urie, are also using their platforms to promote voter registration. Chance the Rapper has been actively retweeting activists from his native Chicago, while John Legend has been sharing voter registration graphics and endorsing Democratic candidate Stacey Abrams for Governor of Georgia.

The celebrities' efforts are aimed at encouraging their fans to take advantage of the remaining time to register to vote before the deadlines in various states. With the midterm elections just around the corner, it is crucial for citizens to exercise their right to vote and have their voices heard.
