Title: Global Job Losses Reach Depression-Era Levels, Highlighting Need for International Cooperation

The International Labor Organization (ILO) has warned that the COVID-19 pandemic has left 1.6 billion workers, or half the world's workforce, in immediate danger of losing their livelihoods. This number is significantly higher than the 50 million people who lost their jobs during the 2008 global financial crisis. The ILO emphasizes that the employment crisis caused by COVID-19 is not limited to one country or region, and that governments must take shared, international action to address the needs of the "1.6 billion" in a post-pandemic world.

The pandemic has already caused hundreds of millions of jobs to be put on hold, with many industries, such as tourism and hospitality, being severely impacted. In the United States, over 30 million people have applied for unemployment benefits in recent weeks, while in Western Europe, joblessness is also increasing. The ILO report highlights the critical and truly global challenge posed by the pandemic, which is likely to outlast the crisis itself.

The report emphasizes that the best-case scenario involves a fairly early exit from COVID-19, through a combination of treatment or inoculation advances and a staged reboot of the world economy. However, even in a best-case scenario, there is a key question: How many of the jobs lost to COVID-19 will be lost for good, or at least for a long time after the economic reopenings?

The ILO's 1.6 billion figure covers the so-called informal economy, including migrant workers, agricultural workers, and gig workers in the developing world, as well as service-industry staff in wealthier economies. The report found that COVID-19 had left almost all 2 billion of them finding it precariously hard to make ends meet.

The immediate challenge for governments is to budget or print more money for multitrillion-dollar stimulus programs like those in the US or salary-support schemes favored in Europe and elsewhere. However, the longer-term challenge lies ahead, as the world grapples with the human cost of mass joblessness, which could pose major social and political challenges.

The ILO's warning highlights the need for governments to recognize that the employment crisis caused by COVID-19 is a global problem, requiring a global response. The organization emphasizes that the employment crisis is not limited to one country or region, and that governments must take shared, international action to address the needs of the "1.6 billion" in a post-pandemic world.

Title: Senate Intelligence Committee Leaders Emphasize Bipartisanship in Russia Investigation

The leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee, Republican Senator Richard Burr and Democratic Senator Mark Warner, held a press conference on Wednesday to discuss their investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. The duo emphasized the bipartisan nature of their inquiry, which stands in contrast to the controversy surrounding the House Intelligence Committee's investigation.

Burr, the committee's chair, acknowledged his past support for President Trump, including his role as an adviser to the campaign. However, he stressed that his duties as a senator take precedence over any personal beliefs or loyalties. Warner, the ranking member, expressed confidence that the committee will "get to the bottom of this" and urged the public to take his statement to the bank.

The Senate Intelligence Committee's approach differs significantly from the House Intelligence Committee's investigation, which has been marred by controversy and partisanship. House Intelligence Committee Chair Devin Nunes has faced criticism for meeting with a source on the White House grounds to gather information on potential surveillance of President Trump and his team. This move has been seen as an attempt to undermine the integrity of the investigation.

Burr and Warner emphasized that their committee's mission is to investigate Russian interference in the 2016 election and any contacts between the Trump campaign and Russian government officials. Burr stated that the committee will look "anywhere intelligence suggests there might have been any type of relationship or effort to influence US elections." He also cautioned against drawing conclusions about collusion between the Trump team and Russian officials, saying it is "crazy to try to draw conclusions" at this stage of the investigation.

The Senate Intelligence Committee leaders have no plans to involve the House in their investigation and will not be influenced by the partisan divisions that have plagued the House investigation. Warner emphasized the importance of a bipartisan approach, stating that if the committee does not come to a joint conclusion, they will not have fulfilled their duty.

Title: Trump's Blame-Shifting and Obfuscation on Russia's Election Meddling

Article:

During a recent news conference following his summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin, President Donald Trump sparked controversy by blaming both the United States and Russia for poor relations. Trump's statement, "I hold both countries responsible," was met with widespread criticism and dismay. The statement was seen as a departure from the usual diplomatic norms and a failure to hold Russia accountable for its actions.

The article argues that Trump's statement is a result of his defensive nature, stemming from his belief that Russia's meddling in the 2016 election is being used to undermine the legitimacy of his victory. This has led him to resort to blame-shifting and obfuscation, avoiding a direct confrontation with the fact.

The article also criticizes the notion that the West has provoked Russia by pushing NATO up to its borders, citing James Kirchick of the Brookings Institution, who has rebutted this case. The article notes that there was no formal agreement that NATO wouldn't expand, and that the alliance did expand after the Soviet Union collapsed, but only at the behest of new entrants who had experience with Russian expansionism.

The article concludes that Trump's statement was dismaying and stood in stark contrast to Putin's actions, who knew exactly what he was doing and never undercut his own country. The article suggests that Trump should take notes from Putin, who was always in control and never wavered in his stance.

Title: US Job Market Rebounds in March, But Signs of Gradual Economic Slowdown Persist

The US economy added 196,000 jobs in March, a slight improvement from the previous month's weak job market. However, the unemployment rate remained steady at 3.8%, near historic lows. The first-quarter average job growth was 180,000, down from 223,000 in 2018, indicating a gradual slowdown in the economy.

Economists had expected a slowdown, and the latest numbers support this idea. The Federal Reserve may consider an interest rate cut later this year, but this report is unlikely to prompt such a move. The unemployment rate for African Americans dropped back to 6.7%, after rising to 7% in May 2018.

One concerning sign was the slower wage growth, with average hourly earnings increasing by 3.2% over the past year, below the expected 3.4%. This suggests that the tight labor market is not accelerating wage growth as expected.

Manufacturing hiring slowed again, with a loss of 6,000 jobs in March, primarily in the auto and auto parts sector. Global manufacturing weakness and tariffs have taken a toll on the industry, and the closure of a General Motors plant in Ohio contributed to the decline.

Retail jobs also dropped by 12,000 in March, following a flat trend since January 2017. The household survey showed that the unemployment rate remained steady due to a slight decrease in the labor force, which may indicate structural barriers preventing some individuals from entering the labor market.

The median number of weeks unemployed has been increasing, suggesting that people are not finding jobs as quickly as they used to after a layoff. Overall, the job market report provides no major surprises, but reinforces the idea that the economy is gradually slowing down.

Title: Vice President Pence's Stay at Trump's Irish Property Raises Questions on Cost and Conflict of Interest

Vice President Mike Pence's decision to stay at a property owned by President Donald Trump during an official trip to Ireland has sparked concerns about the cost and potential conflict of interest. Senator Gary Peters, the ranking member of the Senate's Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee, has sent a letter to the vice president requesting information on the costs of the trip, including comparable rates for hotels nearby and across the country in Dublin.

Pence's stay at Trump International Golf Club in Doonbeg, Ireland, was defended by the vice president's office as a "logical" choice that allowed him to highlight Irish-American ties. However, Senator Peters expressed concerns that the decision may have created a conflict of interest, as it benefited the president's business interests.

The trip was also criticized by Senator Elizabeth Warren, who called it "another example of what appears to be open corruption" in the Trump administration. Warren requested more information about the trip from Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who is responsible for approving official travel.

The House Judiciary Committee has also announced plans to investigate the matter as part of their probe into violations of the Emoluments Clause, which prohibits American office-holders from personally profiting from foreign governments.

Pence's chief of staff, Marc Short, said that the vice president was "personally paying" for his sister and mother's expenses, but did not provide information on the costs of the trip or the vice president's own expenses. The vice president's office also stated that the decision to stay at the Trump property was made solely by the Office of the Vice President and was based on the requirement to find accommodations near the vice president's ancestral hometown.

The controversy has raised questions about the potential for conflicts of interest and the use of taxpayer funds to benefit the president's business interests.

Title: Senate Republicans Face Uphill Battle in Bipartisan Budget Deal

Article:

Senate Republicans, who have been vocal in their opposition to a recent rules change that makes it easier for Democrats to confirm Obama administration appointees, will now have to focus on a two-year budget deal crafted by the heads of the House and Senate Budget Committees, Rep. Paul Ryan, R-Wis., and Sen. Patty Murray, D-Wash. The bipartisan agreement, which passed the House with a solid bipartisan majority, may face a harder path in the Senate, where lawmakers are typically less inclined to compromise.

Sen. Dick Durbin, D-Ill., the number two Democrat in the Senate, predicted that Democrats will need "about eight" Republicans to vote with them in favor of the deal. With Democrats controlling 55 votes in the Senate, Durbin is likely counting on a few Democratic senators voting "no" on the deal. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, D-Nev., has scheduled a procedural vote on the measure for Tuesday, which will require 60 yes votes to overcome.

Many Republicans have come out against the deal, including Sen. Jeff Sessions, R-Ala., the top Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, and lawmakers like Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., who are up for re-election in 2014. Some Republicans eyeing the White House in 2016, such as Sens. Ted Cruz of Texas, Rand Paul of Kentucky, and Marco Rubio of Florida, have also expressed opposition.

However, Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., is one of the only Republican senators who has said he will vote for the deal, citing its undoing of some budget cuts for defense spending mandated by the sequester. A handful of other Republicans have said they will vote to end debate on the bill but are unsure whether they will ultimately support it.

Outside conservative groups have come out against the deal, but the House passed it with a solid bipartisan majority that included more than half of the Republican conference. House Speaker John Boehner, R-Ohio, publicly lashed out at the groups, saying they had "lost all credibility" and were just using Republican lawmakers and the American people.

If the deal passes both chambers, it will be significant for Congress, which has spent years budgeting by emergency legislation rather than normal order. However, even Ryan, one of the deal's authors, admitted it's mostly a "symbolically large agreement."

Title: FDA's Handling of BMPEA in Dietary Supplements Raises Concerns

The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has faced criticism for its slow response to reports of a dangerous stimulant, BMPEA, in dietary supplements. BMPEA, a chemical nearly identical to amphetamine, is added to weight-loss and workout products to enhance their effects. However, there have been no tests of its effectiveness and safety in humans.

The FDA was alerted to the issue after discovering that 21 popular supplements listed acacia rigidula as an ingredient, a common tactic used to disguise chemical additives as natural botanical extracts. The agency found that nine of these supplements contained BMPEA. Despite this, the FDA did not issue a health alert, recall the products, or name them.

In contrast, Canadian health authorities deemed BMPEA a "serious health risk" and issued a public health alert, forcing a recall of JetFuel Superburn, which contained BMPEA and another amphetamine-like stimulant.

The FDA's sluggish response has been attributed to the agency's leadership, particularly Dr. Daniel Fabricant, who previously worked for the Natural Products Association, a trade group for supplement makers and sellers. Fabricant left the FDA in 2014 to become the association's chief executive, and his successor, Cara Welch, has also been criticized for her handling of the issue.

Title: Obama Administration Signals Exemption for Those Who Lost Health Plans Due to Obamacare Requirements

The Obama administration has responded to concerns from a group of Democratic senators, stating that individuals who lost their existing health plans due to Obamacare's requirements will be eligible for a hardship exemption, allowing them to purchase a catastrophic plan. Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius assured the senators that the exemption will be available to those affected.

The exemption addresses concerns that individuals who lost coverage due to Obamacare's requirements would be left without coverage if they did not find an alternative on state-based markets by the January 1 deadline. The administration's response alleviates fears that these individuals would be left without coverage.

The exemption is a result of Obamacare's requirements that all health plans provide a range of services, which led to many policy cancellations. The administration and outside defenders of the law had previously characterized these plans as sub-par and inferior to Obamacare-compliant policies.

The concerns were initially raised by Senators Jeanne Shaheen, Angus King, Mary Landrieu, Heidi Heitkamp, Mark Warner, and Tim Kaine, who represent states served by the HealthCare.gov federal exchange system. The senators had expressed concerns about the potential impact on consumers who had lost their plans.

The Obama administration has stated that the HealthCare.gov website is functioning better as of the start of this month. The senators have welcomed the administration's response, stating that it clarifies an option that will help consumers transition more smoothly into the marketplace. They will continue to monitor the administration's implementation of the exemption and remain committed to proposing responsible solutions.

Title: The Perversion of Language: How the Campaign to Silence Dissenters Undermines Free Speech

The campaign to silence those who question progressive ideas about race and privilege has led to the rebranding of terms such as "far-right" and "alt-right," which have become meaningless due to their frequent misuse. The words "white nationalist" once described someone who supported the creation of a white ethnostate, but now activists claim that making an "okay" hand gesture can mark someone as a "white power" extremist or someone who is "alt-right-adjacent." This perversion of language aims to drive up the number of people classified as extremists, disqualifying even mild forms of dissent as de facto hate speech.

As a visible minority, the author has experienced prejudice and ignorance. While racism exists and is repugnant, the solution is not to divide society into ideological factions, with one side being publicly shamed and banished, while the other is given carte blanche to promote its own, increasingly fanatical, intersectional doctrines.

The theory of intersectionality, widely embraced by self-described feminist activists, maintains that non-whites, women, and LGBT individuals face systemic oppression whose scope increases according to the number of minority statuses a person holds. However, this belief system has a price: retaliation from those who understandably don't appreciate being the subject of discrimination.

A recent study in Political Psychology discussed the growing "whitelash" (or white backlash) and the underlying psychological reasons why individuals hold white nationalistic views. The study found that perceptions of group-based deprivation were associated with increased feelings of nationalism, and that nationalistic beliefs increased the psychological well-being of those who felt they were being deprived.

The term "intersectionality" doesn't appear in the paper, but among elites, intersectionality and similar doctrines, which openly devalue white people by presenting their accomplishments as the product of bigotry instead of hard work or talent, have been primary drivers of the "perceived loss of ingroup status" described in the paper.

The study's results seem intuitive: if a particular group (of any skin color) is constantly being lectured that they are less worthy than others—and also that complaining about such lectures is itself a symptom of privilege and racism—what other outcome might we realistically expect? Ending discrimination against minorities shouldn't require promoting intolerance against the majority. Similarly, defending individuals of the majority group from unequal treatment isn't tantamount to "complicity" in the oppression of others.

The author concludes that everyone who is categorized under the labels of white nationalist and white supremacist does not belong to a single homogeneous group. Some don't think less of minorities or believe that white people are superior. Their political activism is motivated by a desire to support a group (their own) that they believe has been demoted to the bottom of society's status totem pole. To the extent that these nationalistic activists argue there should be no totem pole whatsoever, they are at least nominally basing their appeal in the liberal notion of individual equality.

The author argues that understanding how these nationalistic activists come to their views is a more effective response than simply denouncing them as Nazis, an approach that has made it impossible to have any sort of logical or constructive dialogue.

Title: Obama and Romney Offer Different Approaches to Disaster Relief

Article:

In the wake of Hurricane Sandy, President Barack Obama and Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney have offered their thoughts and prayers to those affected by the storm. While both leaders have expressed their support for those in need, they have differing views on the role of the federal government in disaster relief.

President Obama has pledged the full resources of the federal government to aid in the recovery efforts, emphasizing that "America is with you" and will do everything possible to help those affected get back on their feet. In contrast, Romney has emphasized the importance of individual action and voluntary efforts, citing a personal anecdote about a high school project where students worked together to clean up a trash-strewn football field.

During a Republican primary debate last year, Romney argued that disaster relief should be decentralized and sent back to the states or even the private sector whenever possible. He stated that "every time you have an occasion to take something from the federal government and send it back to the states, that's the right direction. And if you can go even further and send it back to the private sector, that's even better."

However, Romney did not suggest that voluntary efforts alone are a substitute for government action. In fact, he participated in a canned food drive for storm victims in Ohio, emphasizing the importance of individual responsibility and community involvement.

State disaster officials have sometimes clashed with the federal government in the past, but President Obama has taken steps to improve coordination and communication. FEMA Director Craig Fugate, a former emergency management official in Florida, has been praised for his efforts to streamline the recovery process and eliminate bureaucratic hurdles.

Governor Chris Christie of New Jersey, a Republican, has expressed his gratitude for the federal response to the storm, praising President Obama and FEMA Administrator Fugate for their personal attention and support.

While the federal government's role in disaster relief is often a topic of debate, the importance of both individual and government action is clear. As the nation continues to recover from Hurricane Sandy, it is crucial that both leaders and citizens work together to support those affected and rebuild affected communities.

Title: Rubio Pledges to Defund ACA in Spending Bill, Citing Concerns Over Implementation

Article:

Senator Marco Rubio has stated that he will not vote for a short-term spending bill to keep the government open unless it defunds the Affordable Care Act (ACA). The Florida Republican made this pledge during a breakfast event hosted by The Weekly Standard and Concerned Veterans for America. Rubio emphasized that he believes the ACA is "un-implementable" and predicted a range of disastrous consequences as it is rolled out this fall.

According to Rubio, the insurance exchanges will not be ready on time, and the government will not verify people's income to ensure they are not collecting too much in insurance subsidies. He also predicted that many members of Congress will be forced to drop their federal insurance plans and enter the exchanges in January, a requirement included in the law that many did not intend to be included in the final legislation.

Rubio's comments come as enrollment in the insurance exchanges is set to begin in October. The senator believes that the debate over the ACA will coincide with the "implosion" of the healthcare law, which he claims will become apparent as its implementation unfolds.

Rubio's stance on the ACA is just one example of the significant philosophical differences between the two parties, which also extend to issues such as the budget, the environment, and gun control. The senator did not mention immigration, which is currently being debated in the House, during his 20-minute speech.

Title: Administration Fears Flawed System Could Bankrupt Insurance Companies and Jeopardize ObamaCare

The Obama administration has expressed confidence in its healthcare law, but privately, officials are concerned that a critical part of the system is flawed and could lead to financial harm to the government and potentially disrupt services and coverage to consumers. According to documents from the Department of Health and Human Services and the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services, the problems with the website could put the entire health insurance industry at risk, potentially leading to default and disrupting continued services and coverage to consumers.

The administration has acknowledged that the "back end" of the system, which is responsible for transmitting information to insurance companies, has not been built yet. This has led to massive confusion and missing information on who has signed up and what subsidies they are eligible for. Insurers are relying on estimates from the administration, which has raised concerns about the effectiveness of the system.

Experts, such as Doug Holtz-Eakin, former head of the Congressional Budget Office, have emphasized that the lack of a functioning "back end" is a major problem, making it difficult to match policies and people, and creating issues with federal subsidies and payments. The administration has emphasized the urgency of fixing the site by mid-March, warning that failure to do so could lead to chaos and threaten the future of ObamaCare.

A recent Quinnipiac poll has given the president poor grades for his management of healthcare, with 59% disapproving and 36% approving.

Title: CMS Proposes New Rules to Bolster Obamacare's Exchanges, Addressing Insurer Concerns

The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) has released its latest proposed rules for the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), aimed at bolstering the law's health insurance exchanges. The 294-page rule, titled the Notice of Benefit and Payment Parameters for 2018, includes changes to the risk adjustment system, which is designed to distribute risk among participating insurers and ensure that no insurer fails due to an unusually sick and expensive customer base.

The proposed changes would factor in data about prescription drug usage and account for beneficiaries who only enroll for part of the year. The goal is to mitigate the high cost of very sick individuals who rely on expensive drugs and those who game the system by paying for insurance only when they need it.

Some experts have expressed concerns about the prescription drug changes, which may lead to doctors writing additional unnecessary prescriptions to get the coding right, potentially increasing overall healthcare spending.

The new rules acknowledge the problems with the exchanges, where insurers have been dropping out and raising premiums due to sicker-than-expected beneficiaries and those gaming the system. The proposed changes are seen as a response to insurer complaints and an attempt to calm concerns.

However, the risk adjustment program is required to maintain budget neutrality, meaning it cannot fix the fundamental problem of insufficient revenue from premiums to pay for claims. The issue lies with the health mix and number of customers within the exchanges, not the rules themselves.

The new rules are best viewed as small tweaks designed to show the federal government's commitment to insurers' business. However, Obamacare's problems are too big to be solved by tweaks alone.

Title: President Obama Discusses Terrorism, NSA, and More on 'The Tonight Show'

President Barack Obama made his sixth appearance on "The Tonight Show" with Jay Leno, discussing a range of topics, including terrorism, the National Security Agency (NSA), and the George Zimmerman trial. During the interview, Obama emphasized the importance of staying vigilant against radical extremism and the need for common sense and caution when traveling.

Regarding the temporary closure of U.S. embassies in the Middle East and Africa, Obama stated that it is a reminder that terrorism is still a threat, despite progress made in combating it. He encouraged people to take precautions when traveling and to check with the State Department or embassy for information on potential dangers.

On the topic of the NSA, Obama clarified that the agency does not have a domestic spying program, but rather mechanisms to track phone numbers or email addresses connected to terrorist threats. He emphasized the importance of using this information to stay ahead of potential threats.

Regarding the George Zimmerman trial, Obama expressed his desire to wait for the trial to unfold before making any judgments, stating that he does not want to prejudge the situation.

In a separate topic, Obama discussed his interactions with Russian President Vladimir Putin, stating that he believes Russia has a stake in making the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi a success and that he hopes they will cooperate more effectively in the future.

The President also touched on his personal relationships, mentioning his friendly interactions with Senator John McCain and his admiration for the "post-administration glow" that some former officials experience.

Finally, Obama discussed the importance of understanding the sensitivity of the Trayvon Martin case, particularly for African American families who have experienced racial profiling and discrimination.

Title: Trump's Bizarre Rally Speech Highlights Media's Challenge in Covering the President

The recent rally speech delivered by President Donald Trump in Milwaukee was a peculiar event, with the president discussing topics such as lightbulbs, toilets, and showers, as well as touting war crimes and joking about a former president being in hell. The speech was a typical example of Trump's unorthodox style, which presents a challenge for media outlets seeking to provide a balanced and accurate account of the event.

Some media outlets, like NPR, have been criticized for normalizing Trump's behavior by framing his speech as a typical political speech that "ranged widely" and characterized his delivery as a response to Democratic attacks. However, this approach can downplay the unusual nature of Trump's remarks and the potential harm caused by his words.

Other media outlets have struggled to cover Trump's speeches, often omitting or downplaying the most egregious statements. For example, a previous rally in Wisconsin was reported on without mentioning the numerous lies and incendiary smears made by the president.

The media's challenge in covering Trump is to strike a balance between providing a fair and accurate account of his words and actions, while also acknowledging the potential harm caused by his rhetoric. It is a difficult task, but one that is essential to maintaining the public's trust in the press.

In conclusion, Trump's bizarre rally speech highlights the challenges faced by the media in covering the president. It is crucial for journalists to remain vigilant and provide accurate and balanced reporting, while also acknowledging the potential harm caused by Trump's words and actions.

Title: California Orders Residents to Stay at Home to Slow Spread of Coronavirus

California Governor Gavin Newsom announced on Thursday that all residents, nearly 40 million people, are required to stay at home except for essential activities until further notice. This measure aims to help slow the spread of the novel coronavirus, also known as COVID-19. The order takes effect immediately and will remain in place indefinitely, with no specific deadline given.

The decision comes as the state has confirmed 675 cases of COVID-19 and 16 deaths as of Wednesday evening. This is behind Washington state and New York, where over 5,000 cases have been confirmed.

The Los Angeles County order, which will remain in effect until at least April 19, requires all businesses, including museums, malls, retail stores, and workplaces, to stop operations and only allow people to leave their homes for essential activities, such as picking up food, visiting the doctor, or taking a walk in the neighborhood. Businesses will have an additional day to prepare to close.

Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti emphasized the need for drastic changes in daily life, stating, "We've already radically changed how we live in Los Angeles. We need to be painfully honest tonight that we're about to enter into a new way of living here."

The California order is the strictest measure taken in the country so far, following similar "shelter-in-place" orders issued by the Bay Area and Los Angeles County earlier this week.

Title: Former Senior US National Security Officials Reject Trump's National Emergency Declaration

A group of nearly 60 former senior US national security officials has rejected President Donald Trump's national emergency declaration, stating that there is "no factual basis" to circumvent Congress and build his long-promised border wall. The 11-page letter, signed by former Secretaries of State Madeleine Albright and John Kerry, along with former Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel and others, argues that there is no documented emergency at the US-Mexico border.

The former officials, including both Democrats and Republicans, as well as career civil servants who served under presidents of both parties, claim that diverting funds to the project would "undermine US national security and foreign policy interests." They point to US government statistics showing illegal border crossings at nearly 40-year lows and data on drug trafficking that shows most opioids enter the country via legal entry points, which they argue a border wall would not stop.

The letter was first reported by the Washington Post and comes as Trump moved to redirect federal funds intended for other purposes to build the border wall after Congress rejected his demand for $5.7 billion in construction money. The effort already faces numerous challenges, including multiple lawsuits.

The resolution to stop Trump's border emergency is scheduled to be voted on in the Democratically controlled House of Representatives on Tuesday, but its fate is less clear in the US Senate, which is controlled by Trump's fellow Republicans. Some Republicans have expressed concern about the declaration, and 23 former Republican lawmakers also urged current members of Congress to pass the resolution in a separate letter.

Trump has continued to defend the declaration on Twitter, calling on Republican senators to stand by him. However, even if the resolution passes, Trump has said he would veto it, and Congress would need to muster two-thirds of lawmakers to override a veto.

Title: US Senators Request Investigation into Ex-MI6 Officer Over Dossier on Trump's Alleged Russian Links

Article:

Two senior US senators, Chuck Grassley and Lindsey Graham, have requested an investigation into Christopher Steele, a former MI6 officer, over a dossier he wrote about President Trump's alleged Russian links. The dossier, which became public in January 2017, claimed that Trump had colluded with Russian officials during his election campaign and that Kremlin spies had filmed him with prostitutes at Moscow's Ritz-Carlton hotel in 2013. Both Moscow and Trump have denied the allegations.

The senators, who chair the Senate Judiciary Committee and several subcommittees, have referred the case to the US Department of Justice for review. They have passed on communications between Steele and multiple US news outlets, which could potentially indicate that Steele made false statements during his FBI interview. The senators are not alleging that Steele committed any crime, but rather are seeking further investigation into the matter.

The dossier was drawn together after an investigation funded by Republicans trying to block Trump from becoming the party's presidential candidate. Democrats then took over funding the investigation after Trump was nominated. Steele, who founded and runs Orbis Business Intelligence in London, is said to have passed on his findings to both US and UK intelligence in the run-up to the 2016 presidential election. He briefly went into hiding after being revealed as the dossier's author, but subsequently returned to work.

The UK law firm representing Steele declined to comment on the matter. The senators' decision to refer the case to the Department of Justice was not taken lightly, with Grassley stating that the rule of law depends on the government and those who work on its behalf playing by the rules themselves.

Title: Senate Bill Aims to Reform Mandatory Minimum Sentencing for Nonviolent Drug Offenders

Article:

Attorney General Eric H. Holder's recent announcement to change federal drug-sentencing policy has sparked a long-overdue conversation about the need to reform mandatory minimum sentencing laws for nonviolent drug offenders. Senator Rand Paul, a Kentucky Republican, has introduced a bipartisan bill to provide flexibility for federal judges in sentencing nonviolent offenders.

The United States has the highest incarceration rate in the world, with many individuals serving lengthy sentences for nonviolent crimes. According to the Attorney General, incarceration rates have grown by almost 800% since 1980. Almost half of those inmates are serving time for drug-related crimes, with many being sentenced to decades in prison for a single nonviolent mistake.

The mandatory minimum sentencing laws, implemented in the 1970s, 1980s, and 1990s, have resulted in decades of damage, particularly to young people. These laws have disproportionately affected African Americans, Hispanics, and others who often lack the financial means to fight back.

Judge Timothy Lewis, a former federal appeals court judge, recalled sentencing a 19-year-old to 10 years in prison for being in a car where drugs were found. The young man was on track to be the first in his family to attend college, but instead, he was sent to prison, leaving him to scream for his mother.

The mandatory minimum sentencing laws have also had a devastating impact on families and society. Drug abuse is a serious issue, but these laws often do more harm than good. Timothy Tyler, who was sentenced to life in prison for selling LSD to a police informant, is another example of the devastating consequences of these laws.

The Justice Safety Valve Act (S. 619), introduced by Senator Paul and Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Patrick J. Leahy, aims to restore judicial discretion in federal cases and provide a more balanced approach to sentencing. The bill would allow judges to consider individual circumstances and make fairer decisions.

It is essential to work together to reform these laws and ensure that our criminal justice system prioritizes rehabilitation and second chances. The time has come to end the madness and provide a more compassionate and effective approach to addressing drug-related crimes.

Title: Migrant Caravan and Political Controversies May Not Have the Desired Effect on Midterm Elections

The recent migrant caravan and various political controversies may not have the intended impact on the upcoming midterm elections, according to some analysts. The caravan, comprising over 5,000 mostly Honduran migrants, is expected to cross the US-Mexico border and claim refugee status, potentially swaying voters towards progressive candidates supporting a more relaxed immigration policy. However, many Americans may view the caravan as presumptuous, assuming they have the right to enter the country illegally.

The timing of the caravan's arrival, coinciding with the midterm elections, may also be seen as a deliberate attempt to create empathy and influence voters. However, the optics may be different this time around, as the caravan appears well-organized and does not fit the profile of desperate refugees.

Additionally, other events on the eve of the midterm elections may have the opposite effect on voters. The Supreme Court nomination hearings for Brett Kavanaugh, which ended in a scripted melodrama, may have backfired, with many Americans concluding that the protests and disruptions were incivil and ineffective. The confirmation of Kavanaugh, despite the controversy, may have further solidified his position.

Senator Elizabeth Warren's recent DNA test, intended to prove her Native American heritage, may have also had the opposite effect, confirming her claims as a farce. The test revealed that Warren might be 1% Native American, which may not be enough to justify her claims of minority status.

These events may remind voters of the importance of a border, the rule of law, and due process, rather than the intended galvanizing effect on independents and fence-sitters. The controversies may have the opposite effect, turning off voters who value civility, respect for the law, and fairness.

Title: Trump's Campaign Faces Challenges as He Blames Media for His Struggles

Article: Donald Trump's presidential campaign is facing significant challenges, with many experts predicting that he will lose the 2016 election. Trump's critics on the right have been explaining for over a year that his unconventional style and behavior may not resonate with the broader American public. According to recent polls, Trump is trailing behind Hillary Rodham Clinton in key states, including Ohio, Florida, Virginia, North Carolina, and Colorado.

Trump's campaign has been criticized for its lack of organization and preparation, with some states having only one field office or no staff at all. In contrast, the Clinton campaign has a well-established operation on the ground. Trump's inability to explain his statements and actions has also been a major issue, with his claim that President Obama is the founder of the Islamic State being a notable example.

Trump has blamed the media for making him look bad by reporting on his statements, which he claims are often taken out of context. However, experts argue that Trump's words and actions speak for themselves, and that he is not well-prepared to run a presidential campaign.

It is too early to begin recriminations, but those who enabled Trump and fueled the establishment-vs.-the-base narrative for their own personal gain will likely face scrutiny come November.

Title: US Denies Involvement in Arms Shipments to Syrian Rebels, Amid Escalating Violence

The United States has denied any involvement in arms shipments to Syrian rebels, despite claims by Secretary of State Hillary Clinton that the country's neighbors are providing weapons to the opposition. The increased ferocity of attacks and the use of more lethal weapons on both sides threaten to overwhelm diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis.

The United Nations and Arab League special envoy, Kofi Annan, continues to pressure Damascus to halt the violence and respect a cease-fire. However, Clinton has stated that if the Syrian government does not stop the violence by mid-July, the UN may have to end its observer mission in the country.

The US is pushing for a "managed transition," where Syrian President Bashar al-Assad would step aside, but Russia's role is seen as critical. Clinton's claims about helicopter shipments are likely to increase tensions with Moscow ahead of a summit meeting between President Barack Obama and Russian President Vladimir Putin.

Administration officials declined to provide details about the helicopters, citing classification, but Pentagon sources suggested that Clinton was referring to a Russian-made attack helicopter that Syria already owns but has not yet deployed. The helicopters, known as Mi-24s, are flown by Syrian pilots, with Russia providing spare parts and maintenance.

The use of helicopters is contributing to a growing sense that the fighting could be characterized as a civil war. The government of Syria has lost control of large areas and cities to the opposition and is seeking to retake control. The use of tanks, artillery, and attack helicopters has been confirmed, with opposition leaders warning that the conflict is not an even match.

Council members are wary of the term "civil war" as it suggests the conflict is an even match, but they acknowledge that the situation is gradually changing on the ground. The opposition has received antitank weaponry delivered by Turkish Army vehicles to the Syrian border, which was then transferred to smugglers who took it into Syria. Turkey has denied providing arms to the opposition, but has made refugee camps harder to visit.

The more powerful weapons have been delivered as far south as the suburbs of Damascus, but not into Damascus itself. The presence of antitank missiles has made government forces hesitant to move their tanks around urban centers, according to sources in the Syrian National Council. However, the violence has not been stemmed, with a team of UN cease-fire monitors retreating before reaching Al Heffa in the northwest due to hostile crowds.

The Pentagon has defended the purchase of attack helicopters for Afghan security forces from the same Russian company supplying the Assad government, citing the importance of helping Afghanistan create a credible self-defense force. The issue is separate from the concern over arms shipments to Syria used by the government to kill civilians.

Title: Professor's Election Prediction Model Suggests President Trump Has High Chance of Re-Election

A political science professor from Stony Brook University, Helmut Norpoth, has developed a presidential election prediction model that suggests President Trump has a high chance of being re-elected. According to Norpoth's model, which has accurately predicted 25 of the last 27 elections, Trump has a 91% chance of winning the upcoming election. The model also predicts that Trump could win a bigger majority in the Electoral College than he did in 2016.

Norpoth's model emphasizes the importance of enthusiasm generated by candidates early in the nominating process, discounting opinion polls. While current polls show Biden leading Trump, Norpoth points out that many candidates have led in the polls in the spring but lost in the fall. The professor notes that the terrain of presidential contests is littered with nominees who saw a poll lead in the spring turn to dust in the fall.

There is still a long way to go before Election Day, and polls can change significantly after the candidates hold their nominating conventions and presidential debates. The Biden campaign has announced plans for three debates with Trump, but critics have raised questions about Trump's mental abilities, citing recent gaffes.

**Iranian Oil Tanker Sabiti Hit by Explosions Off Saudi Arabia's Coast**

An Iranian oil tanker, the Sabiti, was struck by two explosions off the coast of Saudi Arabia on Friday, according to reports. The National Iran Oil Company, which owns the vessel, said the explosions damaged two main storage tanks on board, causing them to leak into the Red Sea.

The incident occurred around 5am and 5:20am local time, with the ship's crew reportedly safe and the leak under control. The National Iranian Tanker Company stated that there is no fire aboard the ship and it is completely stable.

The Sabiti was carrying 1 million barrels of oil and had not transmitted its location for 57 days, a common practice for Iranian tankers to avoid US sanctions on oil exports. The ship is now heading back to the Persian Gulf with a destination of Larak, an island in the Strait of Hormuz.

The incident comes amid ongoing tensions in the region, with a series of attacks on tankers and oil facilities blamed on Iran. The US has accused Iran of being behind the attacks, while Iran has denied any involvement.

Oil prices surged more than 2% after the attack, with Brent crude rising 2.3% to $60.46 and West Texas Intermediate jumping 2.1% to $54.69. The incident is the latest in a series of attacks on tankers and oil facilities in the region, which has led to increased tensions between Iran and the US.

The Sabiti's attack follows a series of incidents in May and June, in which four tankers were struck by explosions near the UAE, and two more in June, which the US blamed on Iran. The US has accused Iran of being behind the attacks, while Iran has denied any involvement.

The incident has sparked concerns about the stability of the global oil market and the potential for further escalation in the region.

Title: Trump Blames China for Handling of Coronavirus Pandemic, Claims Beijing Wants Him to Lose Election

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has accused China of mishandling the coronavirus pandemic, stating that Beijing "will do anything they can" to make him lose his re-election bid in November. In an interview with a news agency, Trump expressed frustration with China's response to the virus, saying it should have been more proactive in alerting the world to the outbreak.

Trump has been critical of China's role in the global pandemic, which has killed at least 60,000 people in the United States and thrown the economy into a deep recession. He believes China should have taken more decisive action to contain the virus, rather than downplaying its severity.

The President also hinted at potential consequences for China, stating that he has "many options" available to him. However, he did not specify what these options might be. China's foreign ministry has denied any involvement in interfering in the U.S. presidential election.

Trump's comments come as the U.S. and China have been trading barbs over the origin of the virus and the response to it. The President has previously praised Chinese President Xi Jinping and his government for their initial response to the virus, but has since become more critical.

In other news, Trump announced that South Korea has agreed to pay the United States more money for a defense cooperation agreement. He also expressed optimism about the development of a vaccine, stating that "things are moving along very nicely."

Title: Russian Agent Maria Butina Sentenced to 18 Months in Prison for Infiltrating US Political Groups

Maria Butina, a 30-year-old Russian agent, has been sentenced to 18 months in prison for attempting to infiltrate US political groups, specifically the National Rifle Association (NRA), to sway American policies in favor of Moscow. Butina pleaded not guilty initially but later admitted to a single count of conspiracy in December. She has been in custody since her arrest in July and will be credited with the nine months she has already served.

Butina expressed remorse in court, stating, "I destroyed my own life. I came to the United States not under any orders, but with hope, and now nothing remains but penitence." She acknowledged that her actions had harmed her parents and caused them financial and emotional distress.

Despite Butina's apology, US District Judge Tanya Chutkan was unmoved, stating that her actions "jeopardized" the country's national security. The judge fully complied with the government's sentencing recommendation, citing the severity of Butina's actions.

Federal prosecutor Erik Kenserson described Butina as an agent of a foreign government with "undoubtedly serious" intentions, although he stopped short of calling her activities espionage. As part of a plea deal, Butina agreed to cooperate with investigators and provided "substantial assistance" to law enforcement. Authorities believe the deal will provide information about Russia's efforts to interfere in US politics.

Butina's case has no connection to the Mueller inquiry into alleged Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election. The Russian Embassy in Washington described her as a "political prisoner" and demanded her immediate release, calling her detention "fabricated."

Title: Senior Republicans Break Ranks on Tax Pledge, Consider Raising Revenue

A growing number of senior Republicans are breaking their vow to oppose tax increases, signaling a shift in the party's stance on taxation. The move comes as lawmakers and the White House negotiate a deal to avoid a budget meltdown and address the nation's debt crisis.

Several senior Republicans, including Senators Bob Corker, Saxby Chambliss, and Lindsey Graham, have expressed willingness to consider raising revenue as part of a broader deal. This marks a significant departure from the party's long-standing opposition to any notion of tax increases.

Grover Norquist, the conservative lobbyist behind the "Taxpayer Protection Pledge," has long been a vocal opponent of any tax increases. He has maintained that the pledge is a commitment to voters and that lawmakers who break it will face consequences. However, some Republicans are now questioning the pledge's relevance in today's economic climate.

The shift in stance is not without controversy. Norquist has threatened to turn on lawmakers who defy him, starting with Senator Corker, who published an opinion piece outlining an alternative to the budget breakdown that includes more revenue. However, others, such as Senator John McCain, believe the pledge is losing its clout and that the economic situation has changed.

The debate highlights the ongoing struggle within the Republican Party over how to address the nation's debt crisis. While some Republicans remain committed to the pledge, others are willing to consider alternative approaches to address the country's fiscal challenges. The shift in stance may signal a more pragmatic approach to governance, but it also raises questions about the role of Grover Norquist and the future of the "Taxpayer Protection Pledge."

Title: HHS Pushes Out Cash Ahead of Supreme Court Ruling on Healthcare Law

The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has released at least $2.7 billion in funding for healthcare programs since oral arguments in the Supreme Court case challenging the Affordable Care Act (ACA) ended on March 28. This amount is more than double the $1 billion handed out in the three months leading up to the arguments, according to a review of funding announcements from HHS.

While some of this funding was in the pipeline before March, the timeline for handing out specific funds is not set in stone, giving the agency flexibility over the types of dollars being distributed. The stakes have increased as the Supreme Court approaches its decision, as money spent is unlikely to be repaid if the court strikes down the law. Remaining funds will dry up if the court rules against the ACA.

The $2.7 billion includes grants and awards handed out since the Supreme Court arguments, including over $90 million in funds for health insurance cooperatives announced on Friday. In contrast, the administration gave out about $1 billion in grants, loans, and other awards during the three months before the Supreme Court arguments.

An HHS spokesperson disputed the idea that the timeline for funding has changed due to the court case, stating that the agency has worked continuously to implement the ACA and educate the public about its benefits since its passage over two years ago. Some Republicans, however, have pushed to halt all implementation of the law until the Supreme Court ruling, with Rep. Denny Rehberg (R-Mont.) calling the latest HHS spending "irresponsible" and stating that he fought hard to prevent it. The Supreme Court is expected to announce its decision this week.

Title: Biden's Comments Reflect Common Misunderstanding about Black Support for the Democratic Party

Article:

A recent comment by President Biden has sparked controversy, highlighting a common misunderstanding within both political parties about the role of white Americans in maintaining black support for the Democratic Party. According to a book titled "Steadfast Democrats," co-authored by Ismail White and Chryl Laird, Biden's comment may have struck a chord with black Americans who prioritize group solidarity and party loyalty.

The researchers found that black social connections are key in maintaining black commitment to the Democratic Party. They discovered that black Americans enforce party loyalty through a process called "racialized social constraint," where support for the Democratic Party is seen as an expectation of political behavior meant to empower the racial group. When someone deviates from this norm, other black Americans may sanction them, denigrating their commitment to the racial group or questioning their standing within it.

To test this idea, the researchers conducted an experiment during the 2012 presidential election. They recruited 106 black students from a predominantly white university in the Midwest and randomly assigned them to one of three groups. Participants were asked to donate money to either President Barack Obama or his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney. The results showed that when black participants were accompanied by a black norm enforcer, they donated significantly more money to Obama than when they were alone or with a white norm enforcer.

The study found that norm enforcement is most effective when the enforcer is black. However, Biden's comment may have struck a wrong note with black Americans because he is not black himself. The researchers suggest that Biden's comment may have been perceived as an attempt to dictate what it means to be black, rather than acknowledging the importance of black empowerment.

To overcome this gaffe, Biden could signal his commitment to black Americans by showcasing his social connections to prominent black individuals and organizations. He has already highlighted his relationship with former President Obama and regularly points to his record by saying, "The NAACP has endorsed me every time I have run." Political scientist Andrea Benjamin's research suggests that such endorsements can influence black voters' decisions, particularly where race is concerned.

Other experts argue that selecting a black woman as his vice presidential nominee would be an effective way to show his commitment to the black community. Having knowledge of a group's norms does not mean that an outsider can enforce them; instead, a candidate should elevate people who can enforce these norms into positions of power. A black woman vice presidential nominee would be an effective signal only if black people themselves perceived her to be committed to the black community's interests.

Title: Senate Judiciary Committee and White House React to FBI's Supplemental Investigation of Brett Kavanaugh

The Senate Judiciary Committee and the White House have released statements regarding the FBI's supplementary background investigation of Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh. According to Senator Chuck Grassley, the committee has received a briefing on the investigation, which found no new information that was not already known. Grassley stated that the uncorroborated accusations against Kavanaugh have been repeatedly rejected by the nominee and that the FBI could not locate any third-party witnesses to support the allegations.

The White House also reviewed the report and expressed confidence in Kavanaugh's confirmation. In a statement, Principal Deputy Press Secretary Raj Shah said that the additional investigation is the last piece of information in the most comprehensive review of a Supreme Court nominee in history. The review includes extensive hearings, multiple committee interviews, over 1,200 questions for the record, and over half a million pages of documents.

President Trump also weighed in on the confirmation battle, tweeting that it is a "very important time in our country" and that "Due Process, Fairness and Common Sense are now on trial."

Title: Women's Rights in the Balance: A Divided Response to the Kavanaugh Hearings

The nomination of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court has sparked a heated debate about women's rights and the Me Too movement. The allegations of sexual assault against the judge have brought the issue to the forefront, with many women expressing concerns about the potential impact on reproductive rights and the court's balance. The hearings have also highlighted the deep divisions among women, with some supporting Kavanaugh and others believing the allegations.

Progressive women, such as Julia Peters and Grace Perret, are concerned about the potential consequences of Kavanaugh's appointment, citing the possibility of Roe v. Wade being overturned and the devastating impact on poor women who may not be able to afford to travel to other states for abortions. They believe that the allegations against Kavanaugh are credible and that his denial of the claims is not enough to prove his innocence.

On the other hand, conservative women, such as Rachel Gill and Nancy Wilson, are concerned about the abuse of the confirmation process and the potential for false accusations. They believe that Kavanaugh is innocent until proven guilty and that the allegations against him are being used as a political tool to block his confirmation.

The hearings have also brought attention to the Me Too movement and its impact on women's rights. Democrat Lucy Melchor, who watched the hearings, believes that the allegations against Kavanaugh are believable and that the movement is crucial for women who have been assaulted and will be assaulted in the future. She fears that if the allegations are not believed, it will create fear among women that they will not be believed in the future.

The hearings have also highlighted the importance of believing survivors of sexual violence and the need for a fair and thorough investigation. The testimonies of Dr. Christine Blasey Ford and Judge Kavanaugh have sparked a national conversation about the importance of believing survivors and the need for a fair and thorough investigation.

In conclusion, the nomination of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court has sparked a heated debate about women's rights and the Me Too movement. The hearings have highlighted the deep divisions among women, with some supporting Kavanaugh and others believing the allegations. The Me Too movement is crucial for women who have been assaulted and will be assaulted in the future, and the hearings have brought attention to the importance of believing survivors and the need for a fair and thorough investigation.

Title: Supreme Court Weighs Fate of Healthcare Law

The Supreme Court is currently deliberating on the fate of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, with a decision expected soon. The court is considering the constitutionality of the individual mandate, which requires Americans to purchase health insurance or face a penalty. The justices are also examining the expansion of Medicaid, which covers millions of additional low-income individuals.

The court's deliberations are complex, with various possible outcomes. A majority of justices could reject the individual mandate, finding it unconstitutional, and potentially dismissing related requirements for insurers to cover all applicants and not charge sick individuals more. Alternatively, the court might declare that the entire law should be rejected, citing the lack of a clear constitutional basis for the mandate. Another possibility is that the court might punt, deciding it's too early to decide the case, which would keep the debate going until the next election.

The court's decision will have significant implications for the healthcare industry and the millions of Americans affected by the law. The justices' opinions will be released in the coming days, and experts will analyze the reasoning and implications of their decisions. The court's ruling will likely have a lasting impact on the healthcare landscape and the ongoing debate over the ACA.

Title: Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich Weighs in on Trump's Candidacy and Refugee Vetting

Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich has expressed his thoughts on Donald Trump's presidential candidacy and the vetting process for Syrian refugees, stating that Trump is a "necessary candidate" who reflects a global anti-establishment sentiment. In an interview with The Associated Press, Gingrich said that Trump's candidacy is not happenstance, but rather part of a worldwide movement towards being angry at the establishment and feeling cheated by it.

Gingrich also emphasized the importance of vetting Syrian refugees based on Sharia law, stating that it is a "very important way to vet Muslims if you believe in Western civilization." He suggested that a test on whether or not a person believes in Sharia law would be revelatory, as belief in Islamic law is incompatible with secular law. However, he did not elaborate on how such a test would be administered.

Regarding Trump's potential running mate, Gingrich said that he has been vetted for the job but has yet to decide whether to partner with Trump. He stated that Trump will likely make his choice late next week, with Indiana Gov. Mike Pence and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie being other possible options.

Gingrich also weighed in on the issue of racism in the United States, saying that white parents cannot know the fears of black parents and that an open conversation is needed to address the issue. He emphasized the importance of protecting both the police and the innocent.

Overall, Gingrich's comments provide insight into his views on Trump's candidacy and the importance of vetting Syrian refugees, as well as his thoughts on racism in the United States.

Title: Rubio's Debate Performance Sparks Concerns Among Republican Rivals Ahead of New Hampshire Primary

The recent debate performance of Senator Marco Rubio has emboldened a trio of governors seeking to stem his rise in the Republican race for president. Chris Christie, John Kasich, and Jeb Bush are questioning Rubio's experience and policy depth, with Christie unleashing withering attacks against him in Saturday's debate. Rubio's rivals are seeking to capitalize on his perceived weaknesses, but a strong showing in New Hampshire could leave the GOP with a muddled mix of establishment contenders and no clear favorite to challenge Donald Trump and Ted Cruz.

According to a Monmouth University survey, Trump holds a commanding lead in New Hampshire preference polls, with 30% of likely Republican primary voters supporting him. Rubio, Kasich, Bush, and Cruz are statistically tied for second place, with each receiving around 12-14% support. The survey also indicates that 9% of New Hampshire Republican voters are undecided.

Rubio's performance in the debate has raised concerns among some voters, with some saying he relied too heavily on rehearsed talking points and failed to demonstrate the experience and policy depth required to be a viable presidential candidate. However, his campaign has raised $600,000 during the debate, three times more than it has brought in during previous debates.

The outcome of the New Hampshire primary will be crucial for Rubio and his rivals, as it will help determine the direction of the Republican Party's nomination process. If Rubio's rivals can slow him down, they may be able to create a clear favorite to challenge Trump and Cruz. However, if Rubio can bounce back from his debate performance, he may remain a strong contender in the race.

Title: Trump Administration Continues to Restrict Immigrant Entry Amidst Pandemic

The Trump Administration has continued to implement restrictions on immigrant entry into the United States, using the COVID-19 pandemic as a justification. The latest example is an amendment and extension to a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) order, which suspends the introduction of certain "covered aliens" into the country for 30 days.

According to the CDC, the extension is based on the increasing numbers of COVID-19 infections in Canada, Mexico, and the United States. However, critics argue that this move is an attempt to deny entry to those seeking refuge from violence and civil war.

In 2018, the Trump Administration implemented a "zero tolerance" policy, which led to the separation of families and detention of children. The policy was later ended, but the administration substituted it with a policy of family detention. The Flores Settlement, which protects immigrant children from being detained for more than 20 days, was also altered, allowing for longer detentions.

The CDC Amendment and Extension has allowed the administration to rapidly deport children under the guise of public health, despite the ongoing pandemic. Human Rights Watch has called for a moratorium on deportations during the pandemic to avoid contributing to the global spread of the virus. However, the U.S. has ignored this advice and continued to deport people, including those who have tested positive for COVID-19.

According to Human Rights Watch, ICE carried out 232 deportation flights to Latin America and Caribbean countries between February 3 and April 24, 2020. Some of those deported were sent back to countries where they may face harm or persecution. The organization has also reported that nearly 21,000 removals were carried out in March and April alone, including 899 expulsions of unaccompanied children as young as 10.

The CDC Amendment has also denied children the opportunity to apply for humanitarian protections they had before, instead being deported to their home countries without due process. The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has called this move "the most extreme of the Trump administration's anti-children anti-asylum policies."

**Job Openings Reach Series High in July, According to Bureau of Labor Statistics**

The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) reported that the number of job openings in the United States reached a series high of 5.8 million in July, surpassing the previous high of 5.4 million in May. The job openings rate rose to 3.9%, up from 3.6% in the previous three months.

The number of job openings increased in several industries, including professional and business services, accommodation and food services, retail trade, and nondurable goods manufacturing. The Northeast and South regions also saw an increase in job openings.

Over the 12 months ending in July, the number of job openings increased for total nonfarm and total private, while the number of job openings for government remained little changed. The largest increases in job openings over the year occurred in professional and business services, health care and social assistance, accommodation and food services, and retail trade.

The number of hires edged down to 5.0 million in July, with the hires rate at 3.5%. The number of hires was little changed for total private and government. The number of quits, which includes voluntary separations initiated by employees, remained at 1.9% for the fourth consecutive month. The quits rate was little changed for total private and government.

The number of layoffs and discharges edged down to 1.6 million in July, with the layoffs and discharges rate falling to 1.1%. The number of layoffs and discharges was little changed for total private and government. Other separations, which include separations due to retirement, death, and disability, as well as transfers to other locations of the same firm, increased to 413,000 in July.

Overall, the data suggests a strong labor market, with job openings reaching a series high and the quits rate remaining steady. However, the number of hires and layoffs and discharges edged down slightly in July.

Title: White House Requests $14 Billion in Emergency Relief Funding for Hurricane Harvey Recovery Efforts

The White House has requested an initial $7.85 billion in emergency relief funding from Congress, followed by an additional $6.7 billion, to support recovery efforts in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey. The request exceeds earlier estimates, with the administration seeking $7.4 billion for the Federal Emergency Management Agency's (FEMA) Disaster Relief Fund and $450 billion for a Small Business Administration (SBA) program.

In a letter to Speaker Paul Ryan, White House budget chief Mick Mulvaney requested the additional $6.7 billion in a stopgap spending measure that Congress must pass by the end of September to keep the government running. The total request amounts to more than $14 billion as a down payment for recovery efforts in the Gulf.

The requested funds will be used to support relief efforts in Texas and Louisiana, which were severely affected by the storm. The disaster left at least 46 people dead and caused billions of dollars in damage. President Trump is set to visit Texas for the second time in less than a week on Saturday to survey the damage and meet with local and state officials.

Congress is facing a busy legislative agenda this month, with lawmakers needing to raise the debt ceiling by September 29 and strike a spending deal to fund the government past the end of the month. The requested funds are a significant portion of what relief efforts in Texas and Louisiana are expected to cost in the long run.

Title: Justice Department Moves to Ban Bump Stock Devices, Clarify Definition of "Machinegun"

The United States Department of Justice (DOJ) has taken the first step towards banning bump stock devices, which are attachments that allow semi-automatic firearms to fire at a rate similar to fully automatic weapons. The move comes after President Trump signed an executive order instructing Attorney General Jeff Sessions to regulate the devices.

The DOJ submitted a notice to the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to clarify the definition of "machinegun" and add bump stocks to the list of devices banned under federal law. The notice is the first step in the process of banning the devices, and the DOJ plans to publish it as soon as possible.

Bump stocks were found among the weapons used in the Las Vegas shooting that killed 58 people on October 1. The devices use the recoil of a semi-automatic firearm to rapidly pull the trigger, mimicking fully automatic firing. The shooting reignited the conversation on whether the devices are legal.

The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) has debated the devices for years and has issued a series of opinions, determining that they are lawful. However, the DOJ's move to ban bump stocks is a response to growing concerns about the devices and their potential to increase the rate of fire in semi-automatic weapons.

The ban would prohibit individuals from owning, selling, or manufacturing bump stocks, and would bring the devices in line with existing federal laws regulating machine guns. The ban would also apply to devices already in circulation, although it is unclear how the government would enforce the ban on existing devices.

The move is part of a broader effort by the Trump administration to address concerns about gun violence and school safety. The President has promised to prioritize school safety and has taken several executive actions aimed at improving school security and mental health resources.

Title: Obama's Second Inaugural Address Reaffirms Conservative Suspicions of Liberal Agenda

The second inaugural address delivered by President Obama has left many conservatives feeling that their suspicions about the president's liberal leanings have been confirmed. The speech did not attempt to reach out to political adversaries, according to Rep. Paul Ryan, the 2012 Republican vice presidential nominee. Ryan stated that the president's speech was not an attempt to unify the country, but rather a reaffirmation of his liberal agenda.

Ryan, chairman of the House Budget Committee, accused the president of misstating the Republican position on entitlement beneficiaries, saying that GOP policymakers do not label those who receive "earned entitlements" like Social Security and Medicare as "takers." Instead, Ryan said that conservatives are concerned about beneficiaries who receive entitlements like Medicaid, which they did not pay for through payroll taxes.

Senate Republicans also expressed their disappointment with the president's speech, with Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell stating that the era of liberalism is back and that the president's agenda is not designed to bring the country together. Sen. John Thune of South Dakota suggested that the president's speech was evidence of his liberal bent by what he left out of the speech, specifically the words "spending" and "debt."

Conservative scholars and pundits also weighed in on the speech, with Nicholas Eberstadt, an American Enterprise Institute scholar, detecting a take-it-or-leave-it defiance on the president's part. Eberstadt stated that the president's argument is that the welfare state is not up for discussion and that there is no need to fix it.

The reaction to the speech from conservatives was swift and negative, with many expressing disappointment and frustration that the president did not attempt to reach out to his political opponents. The speech was seen as a reaffirmation of the president's liberal agenda and a sign that he is not interested in working across the aisle.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Make Final Push in Iowa Ahead of Caucuses

As the Iowa caucuses approach, Democratic presidential candidates are making their final pitches to voters, each highlighting their unique strengths and policies. In a recent town hall, Pete Buttigieg criticized his opponents for recycling the same arguments and not offering a new approach to take on President Trump.

Elizabeth Warren, meanwhile, emphasized the importance of women in politics, citing data that shows they have been outperforming men in competitive races since Trump's presidency. She argued that 2020 is not 2016 and that women are better positioned to win.

Amy Klobuchar, who has been participating in the impeachment trial, made a last-minute trip to a bar in Council Bluffs, where she met with supporters and did over 20 TV and newspaper interviews to reach voters.

Bernie Sanders, who is calling for a more progressive approach, emphasized his consistency and grassroots movement. He outlined his plans as president, including raising the minimum wage, legalizing marijuana, and protecting women's reproductive rights.

Joe Biden, on the other hand, is focusing on his experience and stability, saying he will build on the Obama years. He is also looking forward to a fight with Trump over issues like guns, health care, foreign policy, national security, morality, and personality.

Christie Vilsack, the wife of former Governor Tom Vilsack, endorsed Biden, calling him the "rock solid" choice for Iowans in 2020. Neither Biden nor Sanders mentioned their opponents in their recent events.

Some voters are looking for a more aggressive approach to take on Trump, with one undecided voter saying they want to hear candidates "hammer on Trump because I think they've taken it too easy."

Title: Holder's Threat to Dismantle Ferguson Police Department: A Complex and Unlikely Scenario

The Attorney General Eric Holder's statement that he is "prepared to use all the powers" the federal government has to get the city of Ferguson, Missouri, in line with the Constitution has sparked concerns about the potential dismantling of the Ferguson police department. However, it is essential to understand the limitations and complexities involved in such a scenario.

The Department of Justice does not have the authority to dismantle local police departments without the city's consent. Instead, the DOJ would likely work with the city to draw up an agreement where the Ferguson police department would remain independent but be monitored by the DOJ. The agreement would be enforced in federal court, and the city would only be taken over if it failed to make the necessary changes.

If Holder truly wants to dismantle the Ferguson Police Department, the best approach would be to make dissolution part of the original court-enforced agreement. However, it is more likely that the city would agree to dissolve the department or suggest it themselves, making it a city-led initiative.

Dismantling the police department would not address the broader issues identified by the Department of Justice, including discrimination and Constitutional violations in the municipal court system.
