While this is concerning, it highlights the importance of understanding the complexities of the situation and not overhyping the threat posed by ISIS to the United States.

The case of Somalia serves as a reminder that the CIA and FBI need to pay attention to the potential threat posed by American foreign fighters in Syria. However, this does not justify U.S. officials overestimating the threat posed by ISIS to the United States. Americans should remain vigilant and aware of the threats posed by extremists, but it is crucial to approach the issue with a clear understanding of the facts and avoid exaggeration.

Title: The "Glass Ceiling" Myth: A Misguided Explanation for Hillary Clinton's Loss

The 2016 presidential election was marked by many surprises, but one narrative that emerged in its aftermath was the notion that sexism played a significant role in Hillary Clinton's loss. The idea was that Trump's victory was a result of deep-seated misogyny and a reluctance among American voters to elect a woman as president. However, a closer examination of the election reveals that this narrative is flawed and oversimplifies the complex factors that contributed to Clinton's defeat.

Clinton's campaign was plagued by numerous issues, including her email scandal, her association with the Democratic Party's liberal agenda, and her own personal flaws. Her loss was not solely the result of sexism, but rather a culmination of these and other factors.

The article highlights the Clinton campaign's own efforts to emphasize the "glass ceiling" as a barrier to her election, with Clinton herself using the term to describe the challenges she faced as a woman in politics. However, this narrative has been criticized for being overly simplistic and failing to account for the many other factors that contributed to her loss.

The article also notes that Clinton's campaign was marked by a tendency to play the "woman card," with Clinton herself using the term to describe her candidacy. This strategy may have backfired, as it may have come across as overly self-congratulatory and divisive.

Ultimately, the article concludes that while sexism certainly exists, attributing Clinton's loss solely to it is absurd. The election was a complex and multifaceted event, and to reduce it to a single factor is to oversimplify the many challenges and complexities that candidates face in modern politics.

Title: Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price Discusses Obamacare Replacement Plan

Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price recently discussed the Republican plan to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) on NBC's "Meet the Press." In the interview, Price emphasized that the new plan aims to provide more choices and affordability for individuals and families, stating that "nobody will be worse off financially" in the process.

According to Price, the current system "works for government or insurance" but not for the American people. He believes that the new plan will increase coverage and provide financial feasibility for everyone to get coverage. The plan, formally known as the American Health Care Act, has been marked up and advanced through key committees, with Congressional Republicans and the White House hoping to have it signed into law before the Easter recess.

In the interview, Price highlighted the need for a system that works for people, rather than just government or insurance. He emphasized that the president and he believe that creating a system accessible to everyone and providing financial feasibility for everyone to get coverage will increase coverage and provide a better outcome than the current situation, where people are losing coverage and the number of individuals covered is decreasing.

**Colin Powell Criticizes Trump and Clinton in Leaked Emails**

Former Secretary of State Colin Powell, a retired 4-star general and a Republican, has blasted Donald Trump as a "national disgrace" and criticized repeated investigations into the 2012 Benghazi attack as a "witch hunt" in personal emails leaked online by hackers.

The contents of the emails were first reported by Buzzfeed News, which said the messages had been obtained by the website DCLeaks.com, believed to have ties to Russian intelligence services. Powell confirmed the authenticity of the emails to NBC News.

In the emails, Powell called Trump a "national disgrace" and "international pariah" in a June 17 email to a former aide, stating that the Republican presidential contender was "in the process of destroying himself, no need for Dems to attack him." He also slammed Trump for spurring the "racist" so-called "birther" movement, which questioned President Barack Obama's birthplace.

Powell also expressed frustration about his name being linked to Hillary Clinton's email issues, writing in a leaked email: "I have told Hilleary's minions repeatedly that they are making a mistake trying to drag me in, yet they still try."

In another email, Powell dismissed Trump's overtures to African-American voters, saying, "There is nothing he can say that will sway black voters so he might as well say it to white folks." He also criticized Trump's attempts to discredit President Obama, stating, "He can never overcome what he tried to do to Obama with his search for the birth certificate hoping to force Obama out of the Presidency."

Powell also criticized the Benghazi investigations, calling them a "stupid witch hunt" in a December 17 email to former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice. He stated that the basic fault falls on a courageous ambassador who thought Libyans now love him and he is okay in a very vulnerable place, but blame also rests on his leaders and supporters back here, including Pat Kennedy, Intel community, DS, and yes, HRC.

The revelations mark the latest in a string of headlines around Powell's email correspondence, which has figured heavily into the controversy around Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server.

Title: Bipartisan Concerns Over ObamaCare-Tied Tax on Medical Devices

The Affordable Care Act's 2.3% tax on medical devices has emerged as a contentious issue, with both Democratic and Republican lawmakers expressing concerns about its impact on the industry. The tax, aimed at raising nearly $30 billion over the next decade, has been criticized for causing "uncertainty and confusion" for businesses and potentially hurting the medical technology industry.

A group of 17 senators, including Democrats Amy Klobuchar and Kay Hagan, wrote a letter to Senate Democratic Leader Harry Reid urging a delay in the implementation of the tax. They argued that the medical technology industry is a significant employer, directly employing over 400,000 people in the United States and responsible for 2 million high-skilled manufacturing jobs. The lawmakers warned that the tax could hurt the industry's ability to maintain its global leadership position and keep good jobs at home.

The medical device industry has received little guidance on how to comply with the tax, causing significant uncertainty and confusion for businesses. Industry leaders have expressed concerns that the tax could cost thousands of jobs and hurt the ability of medical technology companies to find tomorrow's treatments and cures. The Advanced Medical Technology Association's president, Stephen J. Ubl, stated that the tax could push the industry off an "innovation cliff," costing as many as 43,000 jobs.

The tax would target a broad range of devices, from X-ray machines to ultrasound equipment to pacemakers. Industry representatives argue that the tax ends up being much higher than 2.3% since it's on gross sales, with one industry spokesman estimating the impact on actual earnings is more like 15%. The administration has defended the provision, stating that medical device companies will benefit from the law due to increased demand from millions of new health care customers insured as a result of the law.

The debate over the tax has sparked bipartisan opposition, with Republican Georgia Rep. Tom Price reiterating his call for the tax to be repealed, saying it's an area where Republicans and Democrats can find common ground. The fate of the tax remains uncertain, with the Republican-controlled House having voted to repeal it, but the Senate never taking it up.

Title: Trump's "Fake News" Rant: A Call for Balance and Accountability in Journalism

The recent rally in Phoenix, where President Donald Trump went off-script and launched a 30-minute tirade against journalists, has sparked a renewed debate about the role of the press in American politics. Trump's criticism of the media as "fake news" has become a staple of his rhetoric, but some argue that his words are not only unfair but also self-serving. As a former journalist with 28 years of experience at CBS News, the author of this article has witnessed both liberal bias and elitism in the media, but never saw any deliberate fabrication of news.

The article highlights a few instances where mistakes have been made, such as CNN's retraction of a story about James Comey's testimony and Anthony Scaramucci's ties to a Russian investment fund. However, these errors are attributed to flimsy reporting rather than a conspiracy to create fake news.

The author argues that Trump's criticism of the media is often self-serving, as he uses the term "fake news" to describe any news that he doesn't like. The article also notes that while there have been some bad apples in the media, the vast majority of journalists strive to be objective and accurate.

The author concludes that both Trump and the press have an obligation to be fair and accountable. Trump should stop delegitimizing the mainstream media and stop channeling his inner Joe Pesci when ranting about "fake news." Meanwhile, journalists should acknowledge that many have abandoned their role as objective observers and taken on the role of anti-Trump activists.

Title: U.S. Military Leaders Pledge Reforms to Combat Racism in the Ranks

The U.S. military has taken significant steps to address the legacy and reality of racism within its ranks. U.S. Forces Korea, led by Army Gen. Robert B. Abrams, has taken bold action over the past month to combat racial injustice and discrimination. The command has allowed at least two major demonstrations on military bases, banned Confederate flags and regalia on military grounds, and launched listening sessions, social media events, and question-and-answer forums to hear from service members, their families, and other stakeholders about their experiences with discrimination.

The U.S. Embassy in Seoul raised a "Black Lives Matter" banner this month, sparking a wave of criticism and ultimately reversing the decision. However, this move demonstrated the military's willingness to engage with the issue. The Pentagon has acknowledged criticism from private groups and Capitol Hill about racial disparities in the military justice system.

Analysts and military insiders attribute the swift action to Gen. Abrams' understanding of institutional racism and his decision to take a proactive approach. The military's willingness to allow demonstrations and engage with service members' concerns has been praised by specialists and retired military officials.

The steps taken by U.S. Forces Korea began shortly after George Floyd's death, sparking widespread protests and prompting President Trump to consider deploying active-duty troops to quell riots. Gen. Abrams issued guidance banning the Confederate flag, citing its potential to inflame racial division. The Navy and Marine Corps had already taken similar steps, but Gen. Abrams' move drew attention due to the Army's historical ties to the Confederacy.

The Army has expressed willingness to consider changing the names of 10 bases named after Confederate generals and officials, but it remains unclear where this effort will go in the face of strong public opposition from President Trump. Gen. Abrams has also allowed demonstrations on military bases, with protesters singing "God Bless America" during a gathering at Osan Air Base and holding an event celebrating Juneteenth at Camp Humphreys.

The military's top leaders have also spoken out on the issue, with Defense Secretary Mark Esper launching a review panel to examine systemic racism and discrimination in the military and recommend concrete changes within six months. Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Gen. Mark A. Milley apologized for appearing with President Trump at a photo opportunity during heated protests and directed all service chiefs to stamp out racism.

While each of these steps is important, specialists emphasize that lasting change must take root at lower levels of the military. Leadership from officials like Gen. Abrams is crucial in setting a standard that all are equal and promoting a culture of inclusivity and respect.

Title: Republicans Weigh Pros and Cons of Supreme Court Ruling on Obamacare

The Supreme Court's upcoming decision on the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, has sparked debate among Republicans about its potential impact on the November election. While some Republicans are eager for the court to strike down the law, others are concerned that doing so might not be beneficial for their party's political prospects.

One Republican who might be particularly affected by the outcome is Mitt Romney, the author of a state-level health care law similar to the federal one. If the court were to strike down the ACA, Romney's campaign to repeal the law would gain a clearer contrast with President Barack Obama, who wrote the Affordable Care Act. However, some Republicans worry that this could also lead to a decrease in enthusiasm among conservative activists, who might feel less motivated to vote if the law is overturned.

According to a CBS/New York Times poll, more than two-thirds of respondents believe the ACA should be struck down in whole or in part. This could benefit Republicans, who have been seeking a way to differentiate themselves from Obama on health care. However, others argue that the law's survival could galvanize Obama's base and increase the urgency of the election.

House Republican leaders are already preparing for the aftermath of the decision, discussing potential unified responses to the outcome. The White House, meanwhile, is rooting for the court to uphold the law in its entirety, which would put Obama's political standing and his signature achievement at risk.

Ultimately, the decision will have significant implications for both parties, and Republicans are weighing the pros and cons of the outcome.

Title: TV Personalities and Guests Practice Social Distancing Amid Coronavirus Outbreak

In response to the growing concerns about the novel coronavirus, television personalities and guests are taking measures to practice social distancing. Fox & Friends co-hosts Steve Doocy, Ainsley Earhardt, and Brian Kilmeade have started sitting in different parts of the same studio, with Doocy sitting on the "curvy couch" while his co-hosts are one level down. This move is aimed at reducing the risk of transmission and spreading the virus.

Other TV shows, including Outnumbered Overtime and The Five, have also taken similar measures. MSNBC's Morning Joe personalities Joe Scarborough, Mika Brzezinski, and Willie Geist have been beaming in from different locations, while CNN's New Day co-hosts Alisyn Camerota and John Berman have been sitting at the same desk but several feet apart, adhering to the recommended six feet of separation guideline.

Representatives from Fox News, MSNBC, and CNN have confirmed that their on-air staffers are practicing social distancing. MSNBC has also implemented measures for guests who appear on-air, requiring them to do so from a separate location. On-air staffers who sit at the same desk will always be at least six feet apart.

The television industry has also seen a shift away from live audiences, with some shows opting for pre-recorded segments or virtual appearances. The View co-host Joy Behar has taken a temporary leave from her show due to concerns about contracting the virus. Today show host Al Roker has also gone into self-quarantine after a staffer on the show tested positive for the virus.

Title: Speaker Paul Ryan Announces Retirement from House, Ending Two-Decade Career

Article:

Speaker Paul D. Ryan announced his retirement from the House of Representatives, effective at the end of this year, bringing an end to his two-decade-long congressional career. Ryan made the announcement at a press conference, stating that he wants to prioritize his family and spend more time with his children. He will remain an active lame-duck speaker until the end of his term.

Ryan's decision comes as the Republican Party prepares for the midterm elections in November, with some speculating that his retirement could impact the party's chances of retaining control of the House. However, Ryan himself believes that the GOP will hold the House regardless of his departure.

Several lawmakers are likely to compete to succeed Ryan as speaker, including Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy and Whip Steve Scalise. Ryan has been speaker for over two years, overseeing a tumultuous period marked by conservative rebellions and the passage of a large tax cut, but failing to repeal the Affordable Care Act.

Ryan's legacy includes his efforts to rewrite the federal budget to increase accountability in social spending programs, which has faced opposition from within his own party. Despite being a prominent critic of President Trump during the 2016 campaign, Ryan has since become a key ally on Capitol Hill, helping to push the White House agenda.

Democrats have expressed hope that Ryan's retirement will allow him to distance himself from President Trump and his colleagues, while Republicans do not expect his departure to significantly impact their efforts. Ryan's decision has sparked speculation about the potential impact on the midterm elections, with some analysts predicting that his retirement could give Democrats a better chance of picking up his seat.

Ryan's announcement comes after rumors of his departure had been circulating for months, which he and his aides had repeatedly denied. His decision to retire has been met with mixed reactions, with some praising his commitment to his family and others expressing disappointment at his departure.

Title: Trump Meets with Evangelical Leaders, Seeks to Win Crucial Voting Bloc

Article: Donald Trump met with hundreds of evangelical leaders in Times Square on Tuesday, a move aimed at winning over a crucial voting bloc in the upcoming presidential election. The meeting was seen as a crucial step for Trump, who needs the support of evangelicals to have a real shot at winning the presidency.

During the meeting, Trump spoke about defending religious liberty, including his desire to repeal IRS restrictions that prohibit political talk from the pulpit. He stated that a repeal could be "my biggest contribution to Christianity." The meeting was attended by around 900 evangelical leaders, including mega-church pastors and longtime stalwarts.

Some attendees, such as Matt Barber, founder and editor-in-chief of BarbWire.com, were not initially supportive of Trump but were swayed by his willingness to reach out to the evangelical community. Barber said that the meeting "moved the ball forward a little bit" and that he would "prayerfully consider" Trump as a possibility.

Trump also emphasized the importance of evangelicals banding together to protect their rights and values, which he believes are under attack. He made clear that his Supreme Court picks would make evangelicals proud, unlike Hillary Clinton's potential picks.

The meeting was seen as a success for Trump, with no major mistakes or reasons for pause. Gary Bauer, president of American Values, recalled that Trump's answers did not disappoint or cause any chagrin. Huckabee told a news outlet that Trump's willingness to engage with evangelicals was a departure from past Republican nominees.

While some evangelicals remain wary, the meeting appears to have been a turning point for Trump. Rev. Samuel Rodriguez, president of the National Hispanic Christian Leadership Conference, predicted that the meeting could be a "tipping point" for the evangelical vote. Rodriguez noted that many pastors who were skeptical before the meeting left with a newfound commitment to Trump's candidacy.

The Trump campaign will need to build on this momentum by getting evangelicals to actively work for him among their flocks. Trump also announced the formation of an Evangelical Executive Advisory Board.

Title: Ann Romney Delivers: Humanizing Her Husband and Herself

Ann Romney, the wife of Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney, delivered a prime-time speech at the GOP convention, focusing on her personal struggles and her husband's character. The speech aimed to humanize Mitt Romney and connect with women, particularly mothers, who have been skeptical of the Republican Party's stance on reproductive and workplace rights.

Ann Romney spoke candidly about her experiences with breast cancer and multiple sclerosis, as well as the challenges of raising five children. She emphasized the importance of her marriage, saying, "What Mitt Romney and I have is a real marriage. A storybook marriage? Not at all." Her speech aimed to show that she and her husband are relatable and understanding, despite their privileged background.

The speech received praise from delegates and experts, who noted that it humanized both Ann Romney and her husband. Barbara Bair, a convention delegate from Pennsylvania, said, "I was so glad she had this opportunity to talk to the women of America... And to hear that her husband is a man that stands behind her, supporting her through breast cancer. There is nothing scarier for families than cancer."

Ann Romney's speech also touched on her husband's business success and defended his work at Bain Capital, saying it has helped many people achieve their goals. However, she also acknowledged the struggles of being a mother and wife, saying, "Do we want to raise our children to be afraid of success?" Her speech was well-received, with delegate Greg Treat from Oklahoma stating, "She gave an energetic explanation of marriage... I think Ann Romney will make a difference."

Overall, Ann Romney's speech aimed to connect with women and show that she and her husband are relatable and understanding, despite their privileged background.

Title: Google Bans ZeroHedge and Issues Warning to The Federalist Over Policy Violations

Google has taken action against two far-right websites, ZeroHedge and The Federalist, for violating its policies on content related to race. According to a Google spokesperson, the company demonetized both websites after determining they had violated its policies on content that promotes hatred, intolerance, violence, or discrimination based on race.

The ban comes after the Center for Countering Digital Hate, a British nonprofit that combats online hate and misinformation, found that 10 U.S.-based websites, including ZeroHedge and The Federalist, had published racist articles about the recent Black Lives Matter protests. The center projected that these websites would make millions of dollars through Google Ads.

Google notified ZeroHedge of the policy violations last week and banned the website from its ad platform. The Federalist was given a warning and has three days to remove the violating content before a ban goes into effect. The website has since removed the offending comments.

The ban is the latest in a series of actions taken by Google against websites that violate its policies. The company has also banned various fake news operations from its advertising platform in recent years.

The Center for Countering Digital Hate found that many companies that had publicly supported the Black Lives Matter movement and recent protests were inadvertently funding content that was racist and contained conspiracy theories about George Floyd and the movement. The center's CEO, Imran Ahmed, stated that the research found advertisements for many companies running on websites that published racist articles.

The ban has sparked concerns among civil rights advocates and digital advertising companies. Caroline McCarthy, vice president of communications and content at TrueX, a digital advertising company, emphasized the need for companies to be more responsible in where their ads run. "The reality is that they [brands] have to start by asking questions," McCarthy said. "They have to say, what is my brand content going to be running against? And if the other person on the other side of the conversation can't give them a straight answer, then that's a problem."

Title: Jeb Bush's Use of "Anchor Babies" Term Sparks Controversy Among Latinos

Article:

Jeb Bush, a former governor of Florida and potential presidential candidate, has sparked controversy by using the term "anchor babies" to refer to the U.S.-born children of undocumented immigrants. In a recent exchange with reporters, Bush stated that he does not believe the term is offensive and challenged others to come up with a better alternative. However, many in the Latino community disagree, considering the term to be a slur and inaccurate.

The term "anchor baby" is often associated with the idea that having a U.S.-born child can protect undocumented immigrants from deportation. However, this notion is false. According to data from the United States, having a citizen child does not provide a guarantee against deportation. In fact, in the first six months of 2011, parents with U.S.-citizen children accounted for 22% of deportees, and between 2010 and 2012, nearly 205,000 parents of citizen kids were deported.

Another misconception surrounding "anchor babies" is that people from foreign countries are flocking to the United States to have children. While there is a phenomenon known as "birth tourism" among Asian mothers who temporarily relocate to the United States to have a child, the numbers are statistically small. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that 7,955 children were born to foreign residents in 2012. Research has shown that the overwhelming majority of undocumented immigrants come to the United States to work.

Raul A. Reyes, an attorney and member of the USA Today board of contributors, argues that the term "anchor baby" is not only offensive but also inaccurate. He emphasizes that having a U.S.-born child does not provide a guarantee against deportation and that the overwhelming majority of undocumented immigrants come to the United States to work, not to have children.

Title: Google Fires Engineer Over Memo Criticizing Company's Commitment to Hiring Women

Article:

Google has fired a software engineer, James Damore, after he wrote a 10-page memo criticizing the company's commitment to hiring women. The memo, which argued that men are biologically more suited to coding jobs than women, sparked intense debate in Silicon Valley, with many finding his views offensive and destructive. While some on the political right praised Damore as a brave truth-teller, others in the tech industry condemned his views as harmful and discriminatory.

The controversy has highlighted the ongoing debate about gender and diversity in the tech industry, with some companies facing criticism for not doing enough to promote gender equality and stamp out sexual harassment. The U.S. Labor Department is investigating Google to see whether the company has unlawfully paid women less than men, and Google denies any wrongdoing.

The episode has also raised questions about the role of free speech in the workplace, with some arguing that companies have a right to restrict employee speech in private workplaces. However, others believe that Google's decision to fire Damore was extreme and that he should have been given training instead.

The controversy has also led to some high-profile job offers for Damore, with WikiLeaks publisher Julian Assange and the CEO of the social network Gab offering him a job. However, many in the tech industry have spoken out against his views, with some calling for greater diversity and inclusion in the industry.

The debate is ongoing, with some companies taking steps to prevent similar episodes from embroiling their companies. As one executive at a major Silicon Valley firm noted, "Every large organization has a James Damore, but at tech companies, they're more liberated to share their personal views."

Title: North Carolina's 9th District Election: A Shift in Voter Patterns Raises Concerns for Democrats

The recent special election in North Carolina's 9th District has sparked concerns for the Democratic Party, as Republican Dan Bishop won the contest with a thin margin of victory. While the focus has been on Bishop's narrow win, a closer examination of the voting patterns reveals a significant shift in voter behavior, particularly among minority groups. In Robeson County, which has a diverse population, Democrat Dan McCready received a significantly lower number of votes compared to the 2018 election, with a 15.31-point margin decreasing to just 1.11 points.

Similarly, Cumberland County, which has a majority of Black, Hispanic, and minority residents, saw McCready's margin of victory dwindle, with Bishop winning the county this time around. This trend was also observed in other ethnically diverse rural counties, where voters shifted away from McCready.

The shift in voting patterns is attributed to disenchantment among minority voters with the Democratic Party, rather than any racist or discriminatory sentiment. A Harvard-Harris poll found that a majority of Blacks and Hispanics believe the economy is strong, with Black unemployment rates reaching a record low of 5.5% in August. This is a significant departure from the narrative that the economy is faltering, which the Democrats have been trying to spread.

President Trump's rally in North Carolina highlighted the importance of the economy and job creation, with over 230,000 more people employed and small business formation increasing by over 25%. Bishop's victory is seen as a testament to the president's efforts to create jobs and improve the economy for all Americans.

The election results suggest that voters in the 9th District are more concerned with economic issues and job creation than with partisan politics. The shift in voting patterns is a wake-up call for the Democratic Party, as it highlights the need to re-evaluate its messaging and policies to better resonate with minority voters.

Title: Special Counsel Mueller Adds New Charges Against Paul Manafort and Top Aide Konstantin Kilimnik

Special Counsel Robert Mueller has filed a superseding indictment against Paul Manafort, the former chairman of the Trump 2016 campaign, and his top aide, Konstantin Kilimnik. The new charges accuse the duo of conspiring to obstruct justice and tampering with witnesses ahead of Manafort's trial next month. The charges were filed in Washington D.C. on Friday.

Manafort is already facing charges of money laundering, illegal foreign lobbying, and lying to federal officials. The new charges add to the legal pressure on Manafort, who is currently under house arrest at his Virginia home. Mueller's team had previously accused Manafort of witness tampering, and he is now facing the possibility of pre-trial incarceration.

Kilimnik, a Russian citizen and Manafort's right-hand man in Ukraine, is accused of conspiring with Manafort to obstruct justice. He has denied allegations of ties to Russian intelligence. Kilimnik was a longtime employee of Manafort's political-consulting firm and had done extensive lobbying work for him in Ukraine on behalf of the country's then-pro-Russian president, Viktor Yanukovych.

The legal developments come as Mueller's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election and potential collusion with the Trump campaign continues. Mueller's team is investigating whether there was any collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia during the election, and whether the president unlawfully tried to obstruct the inquiry after the election.

Kilimnik's whereabouts are currently unknown, although Mueller's team has said he is likely based in Russia. The special counsel's investigation has been ongoing since May, when Mueller was appointed after President Donald Trump fired FBI Director James Comey.

Title: Democratic Presidential Hopefuls Reluctant to Attack Biden's Obama Legacy

Article:

Democratic presidential hopefuls have been hesitant to criticize Joe Biden's eight years as Vice President under Barack Obama, but voters in early primary states say it's an opportunity for anyone brave enough to challenge the Obama orthodoxy. While the Democratic base still holds Barack Obama in high esteem, some early state voters say he failed to deliver on many of his promises, leaving the political landscape largely unchanged a decade after his historic election.

Biden, who is running on a promise of restoring Obama-era values and stability to the country, holds a commanding lead in the crowded primary race. He has kept his political attacks focused on President Trump, with his nearly two dozen rivals mostly holding their fire on the former Vice President. However, this is expected to change at the first Democratic presidential primary debate next week in Miami, where Biden will be a prime target.

The challenge will be to hit the Obama administration's record without criticizing Obama himself. "I actually think there is probably a good bit of room to go after Obama policies without mentioning Obama by name," said Brent Nelsen, a political science professor at Furman University in Greenville, South Carolina. "There is still an afterglow from the Obama presidency, and I would say most candidates aren't going to go out and criticize Barack Obama personally or the administration directly, but you already hear them taking on things like healthcare."

Indeed, liberal activists have argued that Obama's signature achievement, the Affordable Care Act, didn't go far enough, and his administration's record on the deportation of immigrants was abysmal. Biden is also vulnerable to criticism for suddenly championing policies that didn't get a big push by the Obama White House, such as a $15 minimum wage or free tuition at community colleges.

Republican strategist and pollster John Couvillon said Biden is vulnerable on the Obama front and will get hit there sooner or later. "With President Obama fading further and further into the rearview mirror, those aspects of President Obama's record could be challenged by competitors," he said.

Some White House wannabes have tiptoed around criticism of the Obama legacy. Former Rep. Beto O'Rourke told MSNBC last week that Biden represents a return to the past. "You can't go back to the end of the Obama administration and think that that's good enough," he said. "We can't return to the past." However, when pressed to explain the comment, O'Rourke tried to thread the needle, praising Obama as the "greatest president of my lifetime" while reiterating his argument that it's time for a new generation of leadership.

The Democratic hopefuls are understandably skittish about criticizing Obama. Just look at what happened to Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, whose far-left campaign has made him a top 2020 Democratic contender. Last year, on the 50th anniversary of the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr., Sanders dared to question the accomplishments of Obama. "The business model, if you like, of the Democratic Party for the last 15 years or so has been a failure," he said at an event in Jackson, Mississippi. "People sometimes don't see that because there was a charismatic individual named Barack Obama. He was obviously an extraordinary candidate, brilliant guy. But beyond that reality, over the last 10 years, Democrats have lost about 1,000 seats in state legislatures all across this country."

The retribution by Democratic Party faithful was fast and furious. Sanders was even called "deplorable." Steffen Schmidt, a political science professor at Iowa State University, said going after the Obama years was too risky. He suggested Biden's rivals focus on what they consider blemishes from his three-plus decades in the Senate.

On the campaign trail, Biden gets lots of mileage out of his Obama ties. During a campaign swing through Iowa last week, Biden said he was proud to have served as Obama's right-hand man. He touted the role the administration played in passing the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act in response to the 2008 recession, which he credited with stopping the country from slipping into an economic depression. "As a point of personal privilege, I want to say something we don't say often enough to our party and to our nation: Barack Obama was a president of extraordinary character and decency," he said in Davenport, eliciting his biggest applause of the evening.

Title: Obama Administration Signals Close to Iran Deal, but Senate Scrutiny Looms

The Obama administration is reportedly close to finalizing a deal with Iran, but the negotiating team is working to avoid congressional scrutiny. The deal, which has been in the works for over five years, is expected to be met with skepticism by some lawmakers and the American public. The administration is seeking to avoid a lengthy review process, which could lead to changes or even a rejection of the deal.

The deal, which has been negotiated by Undersecretary of State Wendy Sherman and Secretary of State John Kerry, has been criticized for its lack of transparency and the exclusion of State Department career foreign service officials from the negotiation process. Sherman, who was previously the Executive Director of the pro-choice political group Emily's List, has been accused of being too soft on Iran and ignoring signs that the country is not serious about making concessions.

The proposed deal is weaker than the UN's previous five resolutions demanding that Iran stop enriching uranium. The deal would allow Iran to continue its nuclear program, albeit with some restrictions, and would not require Iran to dismantle its nuclear infrastructure.

The midterm elections may be the last chance to stop this deal, as a Republican-controlled Senate could potentially block its implementation. Pro-Israel voters, including evangelical Christians and Jewish voters in key states, are being urged to vote to elect a Republican-controlled Senate. Eastern European Americans concerned about the rise of Russia and the weak American response in Ukraine should also consider voting to elect the president's opposition to the Senate.

The deal is expected to be finalized in the coming weeks, and its implications will be far-reaching. The Obama administration is working to avoid congressional scrutiny, but the deal's fate ultimately rests in the hands of the American people.

Title: Republicans Unveil Final Tax Bill, Eyeing Passage and Signing by Year's End

The Republican-led Congress has unveiled its final tax bill, which is expected to be voted on next week and potentially signed into law by President Donald Trump by the end of the year. The bill aims to deliver on a campaign promise to reduce corporate and individual taxes, with key senators signaling their support for the plan.

The bill reduces the corporate tax rate from 35% to 21%, repeals the corporate alternative minimum tax, and nearly doubles the standard deduction for individuals. It also lowers individual tax rates for most brackets, including the top rate, which drops from 39.6% to 37%. The child tax credit is increased to $2,000, with a refundability of up to $1,400.

The bill keeps seven personal income tax brackets and allows individuals to deduct up to $10,000 in state and local taxes. It also repeals the corporate alternative minimum tax, which had been left in the Senate bill, but had led to outcry from business groups.

The bill sunsets individual tax breaks at the end of 2025 and repeals the individual mandate, a key part of the Affordable Care Act, to help finance the bill. The bill is expected to cost around $1.5 trillion over 10 years, with some provisions, such as expanding the child tax credit, being expensive.

The bill's passage is seen as a key test for Republicans, who have been working to deliver on their campaign promise to reduce taxes. Key senators, including Sen. Rob Portman and Sen. Marco Rubio, have signaled their support for the bill, while others, such as Sen. Susan Collins, have released positive statements without explicitly committing to vote for the bill.

The bill's release comes after months of negotiations in both chambers, with the final agreement reached after a last-minute tweak to the child tax credit aimed at winning over Rubio's support. The bill's passage is expected to be a close vote, with Republicans holding a slim two-vote majority in the Senate.

Title: Republicans Work Toward Unifying Tax Reform Bill, but Key Differences Remain

The Trump administration and congressional Republicans are working towards unifying a single tax-reform bill, aiming to pass the legislation this year. However, there are still some key differences between the priorities of the White House, the House, and the Senate that need to be ironed out. According to Speaker Paul Ryan and House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady, Republicans agree on about 80 percent of a tax reform package, but working through the final 20 percent could take some time.

Five tax reform issues that Republicans need to resolve include:

1. Permanent vs. Temporary Tax Changes: House GOP leaders are pushing for permanent tax changes, while some senators and administration officials have expressed openness to temporary tax changes. Procedural rules play into this debate, as Republicans want to pass a tax-reform bill under "reconciliation" to bypass a Democratic filibuster in the Senate. This means the legislation cannot increase the deficit outside of the budget window, and the tax bill either needs to be revenue-neutral or make tax cuts temporary.

2. Tax Rates: Republicans agree that they want to lower tax rates, but tax plans put forward by House Republicans and the White House diverge on how low to set tax rates for both individuals and businesses. The Trump administration's plan proposes individual tax brackets of 35 percent, 25 percent, and 10 percent, while the House Republicans' plan would establish individual tax rates of 33 percent, 25 percent, and 12 percent.

3. Border-Adjustment Tax (BAT): The House GOP's border-adjustment tax proposal has been a point of contention. Under the proposal, imports would be subject to a 20 percent tax that wouldn't apply to exports. However, the proposal's fate doesn't look good, as GOP senators, administration officials, and even some House Republicans have expressed concerns about its impact on consumers.

4. Business Investment: The GOP tax plan's language about business investment may be its next most hotly debated provision. The plan would eliminate the deduction for businesses' net interest expenses, instead allowing companies to immediately write off the full costs of their investments. However, the interest deduction has its defenders, who say that debt financing is important to industries such as real estate, private equity, telecommunications, and agriculture.

5. Infrastructure: The tax plans from House Republicans and the White House do not include infrastructure. However, linking taxes and transportation may not be off the table, as Trump and some lawmakers have floated the idea. A bipartisan group of House members in the Problem Solvers Caucus recently expressed support for pairing tax reform with infrastructure.

Despite these differences, Republicans are working towards unifying a single tax-reform bill. The outcome will depend on how they resolve these key issues and find common ground.

Title: Sanders Sues DNC Over Access to Voter Files After Suspension

The Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders has filed a lawsuit against the Democratic National Committee (DNC) to demand access to the party's voter files, which were suspended after Sanders' campaign was accused of accessing the campaign files of his competitor, Hillary Clinton. The DNC suspended Sanders' access to the files after detecting two dozen breaches where Sanders' employees accessed Clinton's data and attempted to download it.

The Sanders campaign claims that the DNC has no legal right to suspend their access to the files and that the party is trying to aid Clinton's campaign. The campaign has fired one staffer and is questioning others for their actions. The DNC, on the other hand, says that Sanders' actions were a violation of the terms of the access agreement and that suspending his access was the only fair move.

Clinton's campaign manager, Robby Mook, has stated that Sanders' staff "stole data from our campaign" and is calling for an independent monitor to ensure that all data has been expunged. Sanders' campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, has denied the allegations, saying that the DNC is trying to undermine their campaign.

The dispute comes ahead of the third Democratic presidential debate, which is scheduled to take place a day after the lawsuit was filed. The debate will feature Sanders, Clinton, and former Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley.

Title: White House Signs TRACED Act to Combat Robocalls

The White House announced on Monday that President Trump has signed the Pallone-Thune TRACED Act, a legislation aimed at preventing criminal robocalls. This new law provides American consumers with greater protection against unwanted and illegal robocalls. The legislation updates laws and regulations to stiffen penalties, increase transparency, and enhance government collaboration to stop unsolicited calls.

The Federal Trade Commission explains that a robocall trying to sell a product or service is illegal unless the company has written permission from the consumer. The company must be clear about its intention to call the consumer and cannot make them agree to receive calls to get a product or service. If permission is given, the consumer has the right to change their mind later.

The TRACED Act takes several important steps to curb the problem of robocalls. The bill requires phone carriers to authenticate whether calls are legitimate and block unverified robocalls at no charge to consumers. The legislation is a significant win for consumers across the country and officially puts illegal robocallers on notice.

The U.S. Senate passed the TRACED Act, which is a bipartisan effort supported by both Republicans and Democrats. The bill aims to make it easier for consumers to avoid unwanted calls and for phone carriers to block them. The legislation is a step towards making it more difficult for scammers to operate and for consumers to be harassed by robocalls.

Title: Biden Warns Democratic Voters: Nominating a Democratic Socialist Could Jeopardize Down-Ballot Elections

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden expressed concerns about the potential consequences of nominating a democratic socialist as the Democratic presidential nominee. In an interview on ABC News' "This Week," Biden stated that such a nomination could make it harder for Democrats to win elections across the board, not just the presidency. He specifically mentioned Senator Bernie Sanders, who identifies as a democratic socialist, and questioned whether voters in Mid-Western and Southern states would be willing to support Democratic candidates with such a label.

Biden emphasized that the democratic socialist label could have a ripple effect, making it more challenging for Democratic candidates to win down-ballot elections. He vowed to work to help Sanders win the election if he were to secure the nomination, but acknowledged that it would be a more difficult task.

Pete Buttigieg, another presidential contender, also expressed concerns about the potential impact of a democratic socialist nominee. He stated that it would not only make it harder for Democrats to win the election but also further divide the country. Buttigieg noted that the campaign's rhetoric often presents voters with a false dichotomy, forcing them to choose between revolution or the status quo.

Biden previously criticized Sanders last week, warning that President Donald Trump would be eager to pin the democratic socialist label on all Democratic candidates to use as a foil.

Title: US Director of National Intelligence Dan Coats Steps Down, John Ratcliffe to Replace Him

Article:

Dan Coats, the Director of National Intelligence, has announced his resignation, effective mid-August. President Donald Trump tweeted that he would nominate Congressman John Ratcliffe to replace Coats, stating that Ratcliffe would "lead and inspire greatness for the country he loves."

Coats' departure marks the latest in a string of high-profile departures from the Trump administration. As Director of National Intelligence, Coats oversaw the 17 US intelligence agencies, including the CIA and NSA. However, his assessments were often contradicted by the President, who has been critical of intelligence agencies.

Coats' tenure was marked by disagreements with Trump on key issues, including Russian interference in US elections, the Iran nuclear deal, and Trump's attempts at rapprochement with North Korea. In January, Coats told Congress that North Korea was unlikely to give up its nuclear weapons, contradicting Trump's statement that Pyongyang no longer posed a threat.

Coats' resignation letter to the President stated that the US intelligence community had become "stronger than ever" during his two-and-a-half-year tenure. He expressed his gratitude for the opportunity to serve and stated that he believes it is time for him to move on to the next chapter of his life.

Ratcliffe, a Republican congressman from Texas, has been a vocal supporter of Trump and his policies. He has served as the congressman for Texas' 4th District since 2015. Trump praised Ratcliffe, stating that he is a "highly respected congressman" who will "lead and inspire greatness for the country he loves."

Ratcliffe's views are expected to align more closely with Trump's in his new role. He has defended the President during the testimony of former special counsel Robert Mueller, stating that Mueller did not have the authority to determine Trump's innocence or exonerate him.

Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer criticized Ratcliffe's appointment, stating that it is clear that he was selected because he exhibited blind loyalty to President Trump with his demagogic questioning of Mueller.

Title: Trump Campaign Officials Indicted, Investigation Continues to Unfold

The recent guilty plea of Rick Gates, a former Trump campaign official, has sparked speculation about what information he may have provided to investigators. Legal experts believe that Gates' plea to two relatively minor charges suggests he may have something valuable to offer, possibly damaging to Trump's former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort. This has led to concerns that Manafort could potentially implicate Trump in the ongoing investigation.

Manafort was involved in a meeting in June 2016 with Donald Trump Jr. and Jared Kushner, where they met with a Russian lawyer who promised to provide information about Hillary Clinton on behalf of the Russian government. Additionally, Manafort reportedly offered to provide "private briefings" to Oleg V. Deripaska, a Russian oligarch with ties to President Vladimir Putin, who claimed Manafort owed him $19 million. Prosecutors are interested in learning more about how a Republican convention platform plank on Russia's intervention in Ukraine was watered down.

Trump's defenders argue that Gates' credibility as a witness is tainted by his guilty plea to lying to the FBI, even as he was negotiating his plea deal. Ty Cobb, the White House special counsel, has stated that Manafort has no damaging information against Trump. Manafort has maintained his innocence and plans to fight the charges.

The investigation has already ensnared several Trump associates, including Michael Flynn and Michael Cohen. While Trump has repeatedly denied any collusion with Russia, the ongoing investigation has raised concerns about the potential for political damage to his presidency. Previous presidents have faced similar scrutiny, with Jimmy Carter's confidant Bert Lance being accused of banking irregularities and Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton facing investigations into their aides' actions.

Title: FBI's James Comey Refuses to Discuss Unverified Trump Dossier in Public Testimony

Article:

Fired FBI Director James Comey declined to discuss the unverified anti-Trump dossier prepared by former British spy Christopher Steele during his testimony on Thursday, citing concerns about the sensitivity of the material. The dossier, which was part of the evidence used to obtain a FISA warrant for Carter Page, a peripheral adviser in the Trump campaign, has been a subject of controversy and scrutiny.

Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, has been critical of the FBI's failure to provide documents and answer questions about Steele and his company, Orbis Business Intelligence Ltd. Grassley has sent letters to Comey and Fusion GPS, the Washington, D.C. firm that hired Steele, seeking information and documents related to the dossier.

The dossier, which was prepared by Steele and his company, was part of the evidence used to obtain a FISA warrant for Carter Page, a peripheral adviser in the Trump campaign. The FBI offered Steele $50,000 to corroborate the dossier, according to published reports, although the bureau has denied making any payments.

Questions remain over how the unverified dossier was passed around on both sides of the Atlantic, particularly between June and December 2016, as it was shown in parts to a variety of politicians, journalists, and intelligence agencies before being brought officially to the FBI by Sen. John McCain on December 9.

Former British Ambassador Sir Andrew Wood, who brought the dossier to the attention of McCain, emphasized that intelligence always needs evaluating and that it is foolish to pretend to knowledge that you do not have. Wood stated that he had not read and could not vouch for the material, but it was produced by responsible persons.

The article also mentions that Wood's name and his relationship with Steele emerged in British court documents obtained and reviewed by Fox News as part of Steele's defense in a lawsuit brought against him by Russian technology guru Aleksej Gubarev. Gubarev has also filed a lawsuit in Fort Lauderdale, Florida against Buzzfeed for publishing the unverified 35-page dossier in full.

McCain's office has not responded to Fox News' latest request for comment on the dossier.

Title: Clinton's Campaign Faces Tight Race Against Trump Despite Advantages

Article:

Hillary Clinton, the Democratic presidential nominee, is facing a tight race against her Republican opponent, Donald Trump, despite having several advantages going into the election. Clinton has a large staff advantage over Trump, and the Electoral College is tilted in her favor. Additionally, demographics are shifting in the Democratic Party's direction, and she is running to succeed a popular president who is firmly on her side. The economy is also strengthening, which could benefit her campaign.

However, despite these advantages, Clinton's lead over Trump has narrowed in recent weeks. As of Tuesday, her lead was just 2.4 percentage points in the RealClearPolitics national average of polls. Trump has been shown to be ahead in the swing states of Florida and Ohio, and he has at least a fighting chance in all of the other battleground states.

Clinton's team believes that her strong performance in the first presidential debate will translate into a wider lead going into the second and third debates. However, Trump's campaign is also feeling the pressure, and the next presidential debate on October 9 in St. Louis could be a must-win situation for the Republican.

Clinton's supporters acknowledge that the race is still anyone's game and that there are many twists and turns to go before Election Day. They also recognize that Trump's campaign has been able to capitalize on controversy and division, which has given him a chance to stay competitive.

Clinton herself has expressed frustration with her campaign's progress, saying "Why aren't I 50 points ahead?" during a videoconference with the Laborers International Union of North America. Her supporters have also expressed frustration with the lack of a bigger lead, but they remain confident that her strong performance in the debate will translate into a wider lead.

The Trump campaign has criticized Clinton for her comment, accusing her of becoming "more and more frustrated with how out of touch she is" with voters. They also claim that her message is not resonating with everyday Americans and that she has underestimated the influence of Trump's movement.

Overall, the race between Clinton and Trump remains tight, with both candidates facing challenges and opportunities in the coming weeks.

Title: Facebook's Dominance in the Social Media Market Raises Questions About Competition

Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg testified before Congress this week, claiming that the company faces fierce competition in the marketplace from at least eight major apps. However, a closer look at the data reveals that Facebook owns or has a version of each of these apps, raising questions about the true nature of the competition.

According to mobile app insight service App Annie, Facebook's own products dominate the top 10 apps in the United States. Instagram, owned by Facebook, ranks fourth, Facebook Messenger ranks sixth, and the Facebook app itself ranks eighth. The top three apps are games, but for all other apps, Facebook has or is working on a cloned version.

Facebook has adopted features and ideas from other popular apps, such as Snapchat's "Stories" feature and YouTube's video-sharing concept. The company is also working on its "Watch Video" section to compete directly with YouTube. Additionally, Facebook owns WhatsApp, the 19th most popular app.

When questioned by the Senate, Zuckerberg stated that the average American uses eight different communication and social apps, implying that there are many choices available. However, the data suggests that Facebook owns the top three apps in the "Social Media" category, according to App Annie. This raises questions about the true extent of competition in the social media market.

In conclusion, while Facebook may claim to face competition from multiple apps, the data suggests that the company has a significant presence in the market, with many of its own products and features dominating the top apps. This raises concerns about the lack of choice for users outside of Facebook's ecosystem.

**Trump's Staff Faces Uncertainty Amidst Comey Firing Fallout**

The White House is facing a period of uncertainty and tension following the firing of FBI Director James Comey, with many aides expressing concerns about the president's handling of the situation. According to sources close to the White House, Trump's decision to keep his communications team in the dark ahead of the firing led to a chaotic rollout, producing conflicting stories about the reasoning behind the decision.

The rumors of a potential shakeup have damaged morale among White House staff, with many viewing the situation as the worst to hit the administration yet. Allies close to the administration are urging Trump to act decisively or move on, rather than keep his staff in limbo under threat of change.

The rumors have touched nearly every corner of the West Wing, including senior advisers such as Chief of Staff Reince Priebus and strategist Stephen Bannon. The most intense speculation in recent days has centered on the press operation and embattled Press Secretary Sean Spicer.

Trump publicly questioned the performance of his media relations staff, stating that he doesn't see a need for the daily White House press briefings and that his press shop isn't able to keep up with his fast-paced approach. While Trump praised Spicer as a "nice man," he declined to definitively say if he would keep his current post.

A subdued Spicer returned to the James S. Brady Press Briefing Room on Monday, where he faced another barrage of questions over Trump's decision to fire Comey. White House spokespeople did not respond to requests for comment for this story.

Those who have worked for Trump say it is common knowledge that, with the exception of family, staff members live on thin ice. However, confusion over the division of responsibilities on the team of rivals Trump has assembled has created a White House where leaks have become the norm.

Trump's allies say he is frustrated by the leaks, which they say are coming from advisers who either don't believe in Trump's message, refuse to buy into the way he does business, or are so obsessed by the Washington power game that they'd risk harming the administration to boost their own image.

The president has grown so distrustful of his staff that he chose to keep many of them out of the loop until the last minute on his decision to fire Comey, according to The Associated Press. "You almost have to clean house and bring in true believers that are better capable of governing," said one former campaign adviser.

A sweeping reshuffle would bring its own set of difficulties, including Trump's thirst for personal loyalty, which could narrow the universe of Republicans he might consider hiring. It's a problem the White House has encountered as it struggles to fill posts across the federal government.

The uncertainty surrounding Trump's staff has also raised concerns about his credibility on the global stage as he prepares to make his first overseas trip, which includes stops in Saudi Arabia and Israel as well as summit meetings with major U.S. allies.

Title: Not Voting: A Legitimate and Moral Choice

Article:

The notion that not voting is a morally reprehensible act has been perpetuated by various groups, including celebrities and politicians. However, this stance is not only misguided but also ignores the reality of the democratic process. The idea that one's vote can single-handedly sway an election is a myth. In fact, a comprehensive review of federal elections since 1898 found that a single vote has never decided a federal election. Even if one were to live in a swing state or in a state with a close election, the chances of one's vote making a difference are extremely low.

Moreover, voting is often compared to playing the Powerball lottery, where the outcome is largely determined by external factors. In reality, the outcome of an election is influenced by a multitude of factors, including campaign funding, voter turnout, and political party affiliations. One's individual vote is just a small part of the overall equation.

The notion that not voting means one has no right to complain is also a myth. Only about half of the voting-age population participates in elections, and certain groups, such as young people, the poor, and the disabled, are underrepresented in voter rolls. This lack of representation is a legitimate concern and should be addressed through alternative means, such as advocacy and activism.

Furthermore, the act of voting does not necessarily make one a good citizen. In fact, most social and cultural change occurs outside the political sphere, and this is a positive development. Rather than focusing on voting, individuals can engage in other activities that have a more tangible impact on the world, such as volunteering, donating to charity, or advocating for social change.

Ultimately, the decision to vote or not vote is a personal choice that should not be judged or shamed. Generations of brave Americans have fought for the right to vote and the right not to vote. It is a fundamental aspect of democracy, and individuals should be free to exercise this right as they see fit.

Title: Obama Apologizes to Americans Losing Health Insurance Plans, Senators Introduce Bill to Delay Individual Mandate

President Barack Obama expressed regret to Americans who are losing their health insurance plans, stating that he is "sorry" they are finding themselves in this situation. The apology came as a bipartisan bill was introduced in the Senate to delay the implementation of the individual mandate of ObamaCare by one year. This would mean Americans would avoid a $95 penalty for not having health insurance that is scheduled to kick in next year.

The bill, introduced by Senators Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) and Mark Kirk (R-Ill.), aims to address the problems with the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and make health care more affordable for all Americans. The legislation acknowledges the positive components of the ACA, but recognizes that the federal healthcare exchanges have failed to meet expectations.

Senator Manchin stated that the proposal is a "common sense" solution that would allow Americans to take more time to explore their options and make 2014 a "true transition year." Senator Kirk emphasized that delaying the entire implementation of ObamaCare would not be responsible, but Congress should take action to make "commonsense reforms" to the law.

House Speaker John Boehner responded to Obama's apology, saying that an apology is necessary, but Americans want to see the president keep his promise. The White House has not explicitly ruled out the possibility of delaying the individual mandate, but has vowed to work with those who are finding themselves in a "tough situation" as a result of the health care law.

The bill's introduction comes as the Obama administration faces criticism over the rollout of the healthcare law and the loss of health insurance plans for some Americans. The legislation aims to address the issues and provide a more affordable and reliable health care system for all Americans.

**India Imposes Nationwide Lockdown to Contain COVID-19 Outbreak**

India has become the latest country to impose a nationwide lockdown to contain the spread of the novel coronavirus, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi announcing the move in a televised address on Tuesday. The 21-day lockdown, which begins on Wednesday, aims to prevent the further spread of the virus and protect the country's population of over 1.3 billion people.

The decision comes as India has reported 469 active cases of COVID-19 and 10 deaths, with health officials warning that the virus has the potential to spread rapidly. The country's health system is under strain, with limited testing and a lack of resources to combat the outbreak.

The lockdown will affect nearly one-fifth of the world's population, with essential services such as hospitals, police, and media exempt from the stay-at-home orders. Grocery stores and pharmacies will remain open to ensure the supply of essential items.

The Indian government has pledged $2 billion to bolster the country's beleaguered healthcare system and has taken measures to restrict travel, including banning international and domestic flights and suspending passenger services on its extensive rail network.

The lockdown has raised concerns about the impact on India's economy, with experts warning that the country could be set back 21 years. However, Prime Minister Modi emphasized the need for drastic measures to contain the virus, saying that the alternative could be catastrophic.

The Indian government has not yet provided details on how the lockdown will affect the country's poorest citizens, with around 300 million people living below the poverty line. A comprehensive relief package is expected to be announced soon.

The move is seen as a major step to contain the spread of the virus, with experts warning that communal spread is inevitable in a country where tens of millions live in dense urban areas with irregular access to clean water.

Title: Pompeo's Secret Meeting with Kim Jong Un: A Rare Instance of Unconventional Diplomacy

The recent revelation of a secret meeting between US Secretary of State-designate Mike Pompeo and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has raised eyebrows in Washington. What's more surprising is that the meeting was led by the CIA director, rather than the Secretary of State. This unusual arrangement is a reflection of the Trump administration's current state, with no permanent Secretary of State and a lack of diplomatic experience among its top officials.

The meeting was a result of timing, as former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson was fired just days after the US agreed to meet with North Korea. Pompeo, nominated to replace Tillerson, took the lead on the administration's negotiations with Pyongyang. The CIA director made contact through a back channel between the agency and North Korea's Reconnaissance General Bureau, accompanied by a small group of CIA officials, but no one from the White House or State Department.

The decision to tap Pompeo for the meeting was reportedly driven by his close personal relationship with the former Tea Party lawmaker, rather than his role as CIA director. The administration official stated that the president trusts Pompeo and has a close tie with him, which led to the decision.

The meeting has sparked concerns among veteran foreign-policy hands, who see it as a sign of the administration's lack of expertise and experience in diplomacy. A senior administration official familiar with the situation noted that the State Department has been "completely sidelined" from foreign policy decisions in the past year.

The upcoming North Korea summit, tentatively planned for late May or early June, raises questions about Pompeo's continued involvement and his potential conflicts with National Security Adviser John Bolton, a notorious war hawk who has advocated for a pre-emptive military strike. Some experts worry that Bolton's skepticism about a diplomatic solution to the North Korea problem could hinder the process.

The episode highlights the unconventional nature of the Trump administration's approach to diplomacy, which has been marked by a lack of expertise and experience among its top officials. As the administration continues to navigate the complex issues surrounding North Korea, it remains to be seen whether Pompeo will be able to successfully lead the negotiations and achieve a lasting agreement.

Title: Twitter Censors Trump's Tweet on Minneapolis Riots, Citing Glorification of Violence

Article:

Twitter has censored a tweet from President Donald Trump, stating that it "glorifies violence." The tweet in question was posted on May 29, 2020, and expressed Trump's anger towards rioters in Minneapolis who were "dishonoring the memory of George Floyd." The tweet also warned that "when the looting starts, the shooting starts."

The tweet was flagged by Twitter, which stated that it violates their policies regarding the glorification of violence. The social media platform added that the tweet will remain on Twitter, but engagements with it will be limited, allowing users to Retweet with Comment but not Like, Reply, or Retweet.

The move comes after Trump signed an executive order aimed at social media companies for allegedly discriminating against and censoring conservatives. Twitter has been criticized for applying labels to Trump's tweets while ignoring false statements from Democrats and the Chinese Communist Party.

The article also highlights several tweets from public figures and viral tweets that encouraged rioting, destruction of property, or fighting against law enforcement, which Twitter did not take action against. It also mentions Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey's ties to Black Lives Matter and his company's support for the movement.

It is worth noting that the article does not provide a clear stance on the issue, instead focusing on presenting the facts and quotes from the involved parties.

Title: North Korea to Dismantle Nuclear Testing Site Ahead of Trump-Kim Summit

North Korea has announced plans to dismantle its nuclear testing site in the northeastern part of the country, a move seen as a symbolic step towards denuclearization. The ceremony, scheduled to take place on May 23-25, will involve the destruction of all tunnels at the testing ground and the removal of observation and research facilities and ground-based testing units.

According to North Korea's Foreign Ministry, the move is part of the country's pledge to discontinue nuclear tests. The announcement comes ahead of a highly anticipated summit between North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and US President Donald Trump, set to take place on June 12 in Singapore.

The closure of the site is seen as a symbolic gesture, rather than a significant step towards denuclearization. Analysts note that the move does not necessarily mean North Korea is willing to give up its nuclear weapons, but rather a willingness to demonstrate transparency and cooperation.

The event will be open to journalists from the US, South Korea, China, Russia, and Britain, who will be allowed to inspect the dismantling process. However, it remains unclear whether international experts will be granted access to the site.

The announcement comes after Kim Jong Un revealed plans to shut down the nuclear test site during his summit with South Korean President Moon Jae-in last month. The move is seen as a positive development in the ongoing nuclear negotiations between North Korea and the international community.

In a statement, US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo welcomed the news, saying North Korea can look forward to "a future brimming with peace and prosperity" if it agrees to quickly give up its nuclear weapons.

The closure of the site could be a useful precedent for Washington and Seoul as they proceed with nuclear negotiations with Pyongyang, analysts say. "Now that North Korea has accepted in principle that agreements should be verified, US negotiators should hold them to this standard for any subsequent agreement," said Adam Mount, a senior defense analyst at the Federation of American Scientists. "It will make it more difficult for Kim Jong Un to deny inspections now that he has placed them on the table."

Title: US and Russia Reach Agreement on Securing Syria's Chemical Weapons Stockpile

The United States and Russia have reached an agreement on securing Syria's chemical weapons stockpile, effectively removing the threat of US military action from the table. The deal was announced on Saturday and comes after over two weeks of diplomatic efforts led by Russia. The agreement requires Syria to remove or destroy its chemical weapons stockpile by 2014, with international inspections to begin by November and full disclosure of its arsenal within a week. Any potential violations by Syria would be taken to the United Nations Security Council, where Russia has veto power.

The agreement was reached after a last-minute diplomatic push led by Russia, which saved the deal from being scuttled. The Obama administration is cautiously optimistic about the agreement, with President Obama stating that the international community expects the Assad regime to live up to its public commitments. Secretary of State John Kerry emphasized the importance of verification, stating that the US has committed to a standard of "verify and verify."

The agreement is not without its challenges, as it requires the US to take a leap of faith in trusting the Syrians and Russians to keep their part of the deal. The deal also allows both sides to claim that they stood their ground on potential use of force for further violations by the Assad regime. However, the agreement meets Obama's goal of taking away the Assad regime's ability to conduct another chemical attack.

The deal has been met with skepticism by some, with Senator Bob Corker stating that Syria's willingness to follow through is an open question. However, experts like Jim Walsh, an expert on international security, believe that the deal is a win for Obama, despite the poor optics. The deal avoids another war in the Middle East and allows the US to claim a diplomatic victory.

Title: Chelsea Manning Released from Prison, Refuses to Testify in Wikileaks Investigation

Chelsea Manning, a former US intelligence analyst, was released from prison on Thursday after spending 62 days in custody for refusing to testify before an investigation into Wikileaks. Manning was arrested in 2010 for leaking over 700,000 confidential documents, videos, and diplomatic cables to the anti-secrecy website. She was found guilty of 20 charges related to the leak and was sentenced to 35 years in prison, the longest sentence given for a leak in US history. However, her sentence was commuted by President Barack Obama in 2017.

Manning has refused to answer further questions about Wikileaks from investigators, citing that she has already presented her testimony during her 2013 trial. Her lawyers have stated that she will continue to refuse to answer questions and will use every available legal defense to prove that she has just cause for her refusal to give testimony.

Manning was held in confinement for 62 days after a Virginia judge ordered her taken into custody in March. However, she will have to appear again before a grand jury on May 16. Her release comes after the period during which she could be held for failing to give evidence expired.

Title: Obama to Focus on Reassurance in NSA Reform Speech, Says Former Director Hayden

Article:

Former NSA Director Michael Hayden believes that President Barack Obama's upcoming speech on National Security Agency reforms will focus on reassuring the public rather than making significant changes to the way the government collects intelligence. According to news reports, Obama will propose relinquishing control over phone data collected by the NSA, but will not suggest who should collect the data instead.

Hayden, who appeared on MSNBC's "Morning Joe," stated that the biggest task for Obama in his speech is to be reassuring. He does not think that the proposed reforms will change the way intelligence agencies collect data. "I don't know that American intelligence agencies are going to be doing a whole lot of things different in a week, a month, or a year than what they are doing right now," Hayden said.

The retired general and former CIA director emphasized that the big questions Obama will need to address regarding the NSA's phone data collection are where the data is held and how it can be queried. He believes that Obama will punt the first question to Congress and that the NSA will continue to hold the data, with Congress not coming up with an acceptable change.

On the second question, Hayden expressed concern about requiring intelligence agencies to go to a judge every time they want to query data. "I was the director of NSA prior to 9/11, and if you direct the agency that they've got to go to a judge before they query data that is already there and already lawfully collected, that really feels like Sept. 10 to me," Hayden said. "It's a pre-9/11 mindset, and that would make me feel uncomfortable."

The president's 11 a.m. speech is the culmination of a months-long review of the surveillance programs made public last summer by leaker Edward Snowden. Prior to Hayden's interview, the White House had not confirmed what changes to the program Obama would suggest making.
