Title: Democratic Senators Elizabeth Warren and Cory Booker Make Strong Impression at Debate

Article:

Democratic Senators Elizabeth Warren and Cory Booker made a strong impression at the recent debate, with Warren's message on domestic politics resonating with many and Booker's ability to speak compellingly on a range of issues without getting lost in policy details. Warren's story about her own experience as a college student and her desire to make government work for the majority of Americans was particularly effective, highlighting her commitment to providing opportunities for all.

Warren's plan to make government work for the majority of Americans was also praised, with her ability to explain complex issues in simple and direct terms. However, some critics noted that her plan to replace all private health insurance may alienate some potential supporters.

Booker's performance was also commended, as he spoke effectively on issues such as immigration and healthcare, and offered a positive message in his closing statement. He emphasized the need to bring the country together and called for a sense of common purpose.

The debate also touched on the issue of GOP obstruction, with some candidates being criticized for not providing a clear plan to deal with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's tactics. Warren and other candidates acknowledged the challenge, but did not provide a clear plan to overcome it.

The debate moderators, led by Chuck Todd, were praised for their efforts, but some critics noted that the lightning round on foreign policy was too simplistic and did not allow for nuanced answers. The question's assumption that the best way to assess a president's foreign policy is by finding out what they are most afraid of was also criticized.

Title: Catholic Bishop Calls for Stricter Gun Control Measures to Foster a "Culture of Life"

The chairman of the Catholic Church's Committee on Domestic Justice and Human Development, Bishop Stephen Blair, has written a letter to U.S. senators urging them to consider more stringent gun control measures to reduce gun violence and promote a "culture of life." In the letter, Bishop Blair referenced the Safe Communities, Safe Schools Act of 2013, which he described as a "positive step in the right direction" towards addressing gun violence.

The bishop specifically called for the federal government to restrict civilian access to high-capacity ammunition magazines and ban all assault-type weapons. This stance aligns with the views of some members of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops, who have expressed support for stronger gun controls. However, the Catholic Church has not adopted a formal policy on the issue.

In his letter, Bishop Blair cited Pope John Paul II's teachings on self-defense, which state that it can be a legitimate right and duty for individuals responsible for others' lives or the common good. The bishop's call for stricter gun control measures comes as President Obama pushes for stricter gun control laws. The Senate is expected to take up gun control issues this week, following a deal brokered by Senators Pat Toomey and Joe Manchin on background checks.

Title: California Enters Historic Drought, NASA Images Show Dramatic Water Loss

California is experiencing its worst drought in history, with all of the state classified as being in a drought and over 58% in the worst category, "exceptional" drought. NASA satellite images taken in June 2002, 2008, and 2014 show a dramatic decrease in water storage in the state since 2002.

The Sacramento and San Joaquin River basins, which include the Central Valley, have suffered the most significant losses, with 4 trillion gallons of water lost between 2011 and 2014. This is more than the 38 million residents of California use in cities and homes annually.

As of Thursday, 100% of the state was in a drought, with more than 58% classified as "exceptional" drought, the worst level. Record warmth has fueled the drought, with 2014 being the hottest year on record since 1895, according to the National Climatic Data Center.

California Governor Jerry Brown declared a statewide drought emergency earlier this year, and since then, reservoir storage levels have continued to fall. As of Thursday, they were down to about 52% of the historical average. Regulations restricting outdoor water use were put in place in late July for the entire state, prohibiting activities such as hosing down driveways or sidewalks and watering lawns and landscapes if there is excess runoff. There are reports of wells running dry in central California.

The drought has also led to an increase in wildfires, with about 1,000 more than usual charred the state, including some unusual ones in the spring.

Title: North Korean Leader Kim Jong Un Books Same Hotel as White House Press Corps in Hanoi

Article: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has caused a stir by booking the same hotel as the White House press corps during his meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump in Vietnam. The move has been hailed as a "heroic" and "deliberate strategy" by South Korean media and experts, as it allows Kim to reveal more of himself to the American press.

According to Cheong Seong-chang, a North Korea expert at the Sejong Institute, Kim's decision may be a signal that he is determined to improve ties with the United States. However, just minutes after Kim arrived at a Vietnamese border station, the Vietnamese foreign ministry announced that the Melia Hanoi Hotel, where Kim is staying, would no longer host the press center for hundreds of visiting American journalists.

The White House press pool was instead relocated to a shared working space at the Viet Xo Friendship Cultural Labour Palace, a giant Soviet-era edifice a few blocks from the Melia. It is unclear what happened to the journalists who had booked to stay in the Melia. Reporters and other guests at the hotel Kim stayed in during his first summit with Trump in Singapore last year were herded back and ordered to pocket phones and cameras when Kim moved through the hotel. Some guests who took photographs of the leader had them deleted.

Kim and Trump will meet in the Vietnamese capital on Wednesday and Thursday to discuss an agreement on North Korea's pledge to give up its nuclear weapons program. The Melia had been widely expected to host Kim during his stay in Hanoi, with sources telling that the North Korean leader would stay there. Kim's foreign minister, Ri Yong Ho, had also based himself in the hotel during a visit to Vietnam in November last year. Kim's close aide, Kim Chang Son, who arrived in Hanoi several days ahead of the North Korean leader, also inspected the hotel.

Despite the signs, the Melia was still considered a location for the White House press corps until Kim set foot off his train. A reporter was evicted from the Melia hotel lobby before Kim arrived. "It was hard to understand in the first place," said Cheong, the North Korea expert, speaking after Kim arrived at the hotel.

Title: Trump's Tariffs: A Bad Deal for the U.S. Economy

The recent tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump on Chinese goods have sparked concerns about the potential consequences for the U.S. economy. According to Noah Smith, an opinion columnist and former assistant professor of finance at Stony Brook University, the tariffs are not just a risk for a trade war, but also a bad deal for the U.S. economy due to tax theory.

Smith argues that intermediate goods, such as steel and transistors, should not be taxed, as taxing inputs causes companies to produce less than they otherwise would. This concept, developed by economists Peter Diamond and James Mirrlees in 1971, suggests that it is better to let companies produce as much as they can and then focus on dividing the output among consumers.

The U.S. could implement a value-added tax (VAT), which would allow companies to deduct the cost of intermediate goods when paying taxes. Many countries, including the European Union, have successfully used VATs to design their tax systems. In contrast, Trump's tariffs fall directly on inputs that U.S. manufacturers need to make their products, which could lead to a decline in production and a smaller economic pie.

According to Chad Brown of the Peterson Institute for International Economics, most of the $50 billion worth of Chinese products targeted by Trump's tariffs are intermediate inputs used in production or capital goods. This would disproportionately affect U.S. manufacturers, contradicting Trump's promise to revive "Made in America."

The tariffs have also led to a rise in prices for U.S. factories, with many businesses applying for relief. Granting exemptions would help keep U.S. manufacturers afloat, but would also make the tariffs less effective.

Instead of tariffs, Smith suggests that the U.S. could focus on promoting U.S. exports or consider implementing a VAT. A VAT would be a highly efficient form of taxation, which could help fund health care, housing subsidies, and other services for poor Americans. While it may not satisfy Trump's desire to look tough on trade, it would not harm U.S. producers and could provide a more effective way to address trade concerns.

Title: Former FBI Official Andrew McCabe Criticizes Trump's Public Attacks

Article:

Andrew McCabe, the former FBI official, has spoken out against President Donald Trump's repeated public attacks on his reputation. McCabe, who was the FBI's second-in-command during a tumultuous period in the agency's history, oversaw investigations into both the Trump campaign and Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server. He also dealt with the fallout from both investigations.

Since Trump's presidency, the president has repeatedly targeted McCabe, suggesting that he helped protect Clinton from prosecution during the 2016 presidential campaign. As evidence, Trump pointed to the fact that McCabe's wife, Jill, ran as a Democrat for a Virginia State Senate seat and received hundreds of thousands of dollars from a political committee run by Terry McAuliffe, a longtime ally of the Clintons.

The White House has also weighed in on McCabe's fate, with Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders stating that it is "well-documented" that McCabe has had "troubling behavior" and is a "bad actor." McCabe's lawyer, Michael R. Bromwich, called these comments "vile and defamatory" and said they are intended to put pressure on the Justice Department.

It is worth noting that McCabe's wife lost her race, and he was later promoted to deputy director, where he oversaw the investigation into Clinton. No charges were filed in that case, and Trump has pointed to the donations to McCabe's wife's campaign as evidence of FBI bias.

Title: McConnell Assures No Chance of US Default, Urges Calm on Borrowing Limit

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has reassured the public that there is "zero chance" of the United States defaulting on its debts, stating that Congress will not vote to not increase the borrowing limit. McConnell made these comments during a joint appearance with U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin in his home state of Kentucky.

The government has enough funds to pay its bills until September 29, after which Congress would need to give permission for the government to borrow more money to meet its obligations, including Social Security and interest payments. McConnell sought to calm a crowd of business leaders by emphasizing that there is no chance of default.

In a separate comment, McConnell discussed his news sources, stating that he reads a variety of sources, including The New York Times, and that "most news is not fake." This comment appeared to be a subtle rebuke of President Donald Trump's frequent use of the term "fake news."

The borrowing limit is set to be the most pressing issue when lawmakers return to Washington after their August recess. After addressing the borrowing limit, Republicans are likely to turn their attention to overhauling the nation's tax code. McConnell stated that Congress is unlikely to repeal a pair of Obama-era laws most hated by conservatives, and that negotiations about healthcare are ongoing. He also noted that it would be "challenging" to lift the restrictions placed on banks following the 2008 financial crisis, known as "Dodd-Frank."

Title: Hillary Clinton to Announce Presidential Bid on Sunday, Ending Speculation

Article:

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton will officially announce her intention to seek the 2016 Democratic nomination for president on Sunday, according to sources familiar with the campaign plan. The announcement is expected to be made via video and social media, with Clinton becoming the first major candidate to enter the race.

Clinton, who was long considered the front-runner for the Democratic nomination, will face minimal competition in the early stages of the campaign. Polls show her as the clear favorite, with former Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley and former Virginia Senator Jim Webb trailing behind. Vice President Joe Biden has expressed interest in running but has taken few steps to prepare for a campaign.

Former Rhode Island Governor Lincoln Chafee recently joined the field, criticizing Clinton's record on foreign policy. "The biggest question will be: What exactly did you accomplish in your four years as secretary of state?" Chafee said in an interview. "There was a lot of dust in the air. Not many concrete accomplishments."

By announcing now, Clinton gains an edge over her potential competitors, allowing her fundraising team to generate the hundreds of millions of dollars needed to mount a successful presidential bid. After the announcement, Clinton is expected to travel to Iowa, the first-in-the-nation caucus state, for campaign events. Democratic strategists and advisers spoke on condition of anonymity, as Clinton has not yet finalized all aspects of her announcement plan.

According to NPR's Mara Liasson, Clinton is expected to stay in Iowa for at least a month, attending small, unscripted events with small groups of voters.

Title: Former Obama Chief of Staff Rahm Emanuel Condemns Rep. Ilhan Omar's Anti-Semitic Comments

In an opinion piece published in The Atlantic, former Chicago Mayor and former Chief of Staff to President Barack Obama, Rahm Emanuel, has strongly condemned Rep. Ilhan Omar's recent comments on Israel. Emanuel's stance differs from other Democrats who argue that Omar's comments are not anti-Semitic but rather a criticism of Israel's policies. Emanuel is clear in his position, stating that "Her remarks are not anti-Israel; they are anti-Semitic."

Emanuel emphasizes that while it is acceptable for members of Congress and others to criticize Israeli policies, Omar's comments cross a line that should not be crossed in political discourse. He argues that Omar's remarks perpetuate harmful stereotypes about Jews, which have been used by anti-Semites throughout history to question Jewish loyalty to their country.

Emanuel notes that he has personally experienced the charge of dual allegiance, having been accused of being a citizen of Israel during his political campaigns. He highlights that this trope has been used against Jews for centuries, and that Omar's comments associate her with historical calamities such as the Spanish Inquisition, Russian pogroms, and the Holocaust.

Emanuel emphasizes that one does not have to be Jewish to recognize the deep and abiding relationship between the United States and Israel, and that Israel shares fundamental values with the United States that many of its neighbors have not embraced. He notes that Israel has made significant strides in democracy and human rights, including women's suffrage, LGBTQ+ rights, and Arab citizens' participation in politics.

Emanuel concludes that a politician can be critical of Israel without being anti-Semitic, and that many Jewish Americans support Israel as a friend and ally of the United States. He also notes that Rep. Omar has to overcome significant challenges as a Muslim in Congress, but that does not excuse her anti-Semitic remarks.

Title: The Path to Reopening America Lies with Individuals, Not Politicians

The debate over who has the authority to reopen America has been ongoing, with politicians on both sides of the argument. However, it's not the politicians who hold the power to reopen the country, but rather individuals, families, businesses, and religious congregations. While politicians can help by lifting lockdown orders and school closures, it is ultimately up to individuals to decide when and how they will resume their daily activities.

As Nate Silver noted, "people will vote with their feet." Children want to see their parents, parents want to see their children, and grandparents want to see their grandchildren. Business owners want to make money, and people who have invested in stores, restaurants, factories, and offices want to reopen their doors. The profit motive is a strong motivator, and the first business to reopen safely will attract a crowd of paying customers.

Religious congregations also have a strong desire to reopen. Church leaders should develop a plan to reopen their churches, taking into account the risks and benefits of each step. As The New Boston Post editorial noted, "church leaders need to begin the process of reopening their churches. Each bishop or pastor or church council should come up with a plan today that sets forth a date certain when the church these people administer is going to open."

Timothy P. Carney, writing in The Washington Examiner, suggests that churches could reopen with precautions, such as limiting attendance and social distancing. He argues that a well-spaced mass or worship service in a church building could be safer than shopping at Home Depot.

Ultimately, individuals have the best information to weigh the risks and benefits of each trip out versus staying home. Different people have different tolerances for risk, and some may choose to take risks while others may not. Each individual decision can affect others, but this is true in many areas of American life and has not caused the country or states to be locked down.

The best plan for reopening America is one that sticks to American values, emphasizing freedom, competition, choice, and diversity, rather than one-size-fits-all compulsion or command-and-control authoritarianism. It's a conception outlined in the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution, where government's role is protecting natural or God-given freedoms of individuals, families, businesses, and religions, rather than turning them on or off a schedule, even in the service of public health.

Title: Local Governments Must Step Up to Support Citizens Amidst COVID-19 Pandemic

The COVID-19 pandemic has presented a significant challenge to modern society, one that requires swift and decisive action from local governments to mitigate its impact on citizens. As the baby boomer generation faces its first major societal challenge, it is crucial that elected officials at the local level take the reins and provide essential services to those in need.

During times of crisis, history has shown that local governments can play a vital role in providing a safety net for their citizens. During World War II, the federal government played a crucial role in creating jobs and mobilizing the workforce. Similarly, local governments can take the lead in providing childcare, hot meals, and other essential services to support working parents and those affected by the pandemic.

In Kitsap County, local governments, including the cities of Bremerton, Poulsbo, Port Orchard, and Bainbridge Island, as well as school districts and other governing bodies, must take immediate action to address the needs of their citizens. This includes providing support for those who are struggling to pay rent or purchase essential supplies, as well as ensuring that children have access to childcare and meals during the day.

While the federal and state governments may provide some support, it is essential that local leaders take the initiative to develop a plan and allocate resources to support those most in need. This may require tapping into local reserves or borrowing money at low interest rates. However, it is crucial that local governments take proactive steps to address the crisis and provide a sense of security and stability for their citizens.

As Commissioner for the Port of Bremerton and former Mayor of Bremerton, Cary Bozeman emphasizes the importance of local governments taking the lead in responding to the pandemic. By working together, local leaders can make a significant difference in the lives of their citizens and help them navigate this challenging period.

Title: Hugo Chavez: A Complex Figure in Venezuelan Politics

Hugo Chavez, the former President of Venezuela, was a polarizing figure who left a lasting impact on the country and the region. During his 14-year rule, Chavez implemented various social programs, nationalized industries, and formed alliances with like-minded leaders, earning him both admiration and criticism.

Chavez, who ruled Venezuela from 1999 until his death in 2013, was a charismatic leader who used his charm and oratory skills to whip up support among the poor and marginalized. He was born in the Great Savannah in 1954 and joined the army as a young man, eventually leading a failed coup in 1992. After his release from prison, he became involved with the Venezuelan left and eventually won the presidency in 1998.

Chavez's greatest success was making those who had been marginalized feel included and part of something bigger, according to former Vice President Jose Vicente Rangel. He used his Sunday TV show, "Hello Mr. President," to rant against American leaders and promote his socialist ideology.

Chavez's policies had both positive and negative effects on Venezuela. While he implemented social programs that benefited the poor, he also failed to turn the country's oil wealth into broad-based prosperity. The country experienced high inflation, food shortages, and other economic problems during his rule.

Internationally, Chavez's alliances with countries like Cuba and Iran raised concerns about his support for authoritarian leaders. He also supported a violent guerrilla movement in neighboring Colombia and jailed some opponents, labeling them as "degenerates" and "squealing pigs."

Despite his flaws, Chavez remained a magnetic figure, inspiring admiration from some and criticism from others. Director Oliver Stone produced a documentary about him in 2009, portraying him as a regional leader fighting against American imperialism. However, Michael Shifter, president of the Washington-based Inter-American Dialogue policy group, argued that Chavez's government was far from democratic, with him concentrating power in his own hands and controlling institutions like the judiciary.

In conclusion, Hugo Chavez was a complex figure in Venezuelan politics, known for his charisma, oratory skills, and ability to inspire loyalty among his supporters. While he implemented some positive social programs, his rule was also marked by authoritarian tendencies and economic problems.

Title: Three Marines Killed in Shooting Incident at Marine Corps Base Quantico

A shooting incident occurred at Marine Corps Base Quantico in Virginia on Thursday night, resulting in the deaths of three Marines. The shooter, also a Marine, was found dead with what authorities believe was a self-inflicted wound. The incident occurred at the base's officer candidate school, where all three victims were permanent personnel.

According to base officials, the shooter gunned down a man and a woman, both Marines, before taking his own life. The identities of the victims have not been disclosed pending notification of next of kin.

The incident has sent shockwaves through the military community, coming as it does on the heels of another tragedy involving the deaths of seven U.S. Marines in a training exercise in Nevada earlier this week.

Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel expressed his condolences, stating that the tragedy, along with the incident in Nevada, took the lives of Marines who volunteered to serve their nation. He offered his prayers and condolences to the families of the victims.

The lockdown at the base was lifted early Friday morning, and authorities have confirmed that all personnel are accounted for and safe. The incident was confined to a single barracks at the officer candidate school, and a "quick" police response helped resolve the situation.

The Marine Corps Base Quantico has a rich history, dating back to World War I, and has played a significant role in training and educating Marines. The base is home to the Marine Corps Warfighting Laboratory, which conducts experiments in modern warfare, and has a reputation across popular culture as a key national security training location.

Title: White House Physician Reports President Trump's Health as "Excellent"

The White House physician, Navy Rear Adm. Dr. Ronny Jackson, held a news conference on Tuesday to discuss the results of his examination of President Trump. According to Dr. Jackson, the president is physically and mentally fit for office. The doctor's report showed that the president is in great health for a 71-year-old male, with no significant medical concerns.

The report included the results of a cognitive test, which President Trump scored a perfect 30 out of 30. The test, designed to measure general intelligence, assesses cognitive abilities such as numerical, verbal, abstract, spatial, and mechanical reasoning. The test is intended to detect any decline in brain function and potential health issues like Alzheimer's or age-related dementia.

Aside from his high cholesterol, which he has been managing with medication, the president's medical report showed no other concerns. The medical team's personal impression of the president's cognitive abilities is also normal and healthy.

The White House physician's report has been met with skepticism by some, with liberal media outlets questioning the accuracy of the report and suggesting that the doctor may not be telling the whole truth. However, the report provides a detailed and transparent account of the president's health, including his cognitive test results.

The report's findings have put to rest concerns about the president's mental fitness, and the medical team's recommendations of diet and exercise are the only prescriptions necessary.

Title: French Authorities Raid Suspected Hideout of Paris Attack Ringleader, Detain Eight and Kill Two

French authorities conducted a raid on a suspected hideout of the ringleader of the recent Paris attacks, resulting in the detention of eight individuals and the deaths of two others. The operation, which took place in the northern Paris suburb of Saint-Denis, was carried out by heavily armed police who used powerful munitions to gain access to the apartment building.

According to Paris prosecutor Francois Molins, the authorities believe the suspected ringleader was holed up on the third floor of the apartment building, but it is unclear whether he was present during the raid. The operation was sparked by phone conversations indicating that a relative of the suspected ringleader might be in the building.

The raid was met with fierce resistance, with an armored door, a woman who blew herself up, and bullets flying back and forth for about an hour. The French officers used powerful munitions, which led to one floor of the building collapsing. The violence produced rubble that included body parts, which are being analyzed for DNA.

Neither the suspected ringleader nor Salah Abdeslam, who has been hunted since the attacks, were among those detained in the operation. French President Francois Hollande hailed the raid as further proof that "we are at war" with ISIS, emphasizing that the attacks targeted France's diversity and the youth of France.

The French authorities have stepped up their efforts to combat ISIS, with Hollande proposing an extension of the state of emergency for three more months and appealing to world leaders, including US President Barack Obama and Russian President Vladimir Putin, to join forces against the extremist group.

The raid in Saint-Denis was part of a broader effort by French authorities to track down suspects tied to the attacks and crack down on security. The Interior Ministry announced 118 searches led to the detention of at least 25 people, the confiscation of 34 weapons, and the discovery of illicit drugs in 16 instances.

Title: Voters with Unfavorable Views of Both Trump and Biden May Hold Key to Election

A new poll by Morning Consult suggests that voters who hold unfavorable views of both President Donald Trump and presumptive Democratic nominee Joe Biden may play a crucial role in the upcoming election. In 2016, Trump benefited from this demographic, but this time around, the poll indicates that Biden may have a significant advantage.

According to the poll, voters who dislike both Trump and Biden are more likely to hold their nose and vote for Biden than Trump. Among the 43% of voters who are undecided, Biden has a 19-point lead when forced to make a choice. The group also holds stronger negative views of Trump, with 66% saying they have very unfavorable views of the president, compared to 40% for Biden.

The influence of this demographic on the election outcome depends on several factors. Firstly, the Electoral College system limits the geographic scope of voter anger, meaning that voters in swing states may have more influence than those in solidly blue or red states. Secondly, the poll may not account for voters who dislike both candidates but are already certain of their voting intentions.

The role of third-party candidates is also worth considering. While the Morning Consult poll did not include third-party candidates, some voters may choose to abstain from voting or support alternative candidates. The 2016 election saw a record-breaking number of votes for Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson, and this year's Libertarian ticket may also attract some voters.

With over 100 days until the election, both Trump and Biden will have ample opportunities to add to their unfavorable views. The poll highlights the importance of voter sentiment in the election, particularly in the context of negative partisanship driving American politics.

Title: Mitt Romney Announces Bid for Utah Senate Seat, Seeks to Succeed Retiring Orrin Hatch

Mitt Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee, has announced his candidacy for the United States Senate in Utah, seeking to succeed retiring Senator Orrin Hatch. Romney, a former Massachusetts governor, has deep ties to Utah, having attended Brigham Young University and played a key role in the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City.

In a video message posted on Twitter, Romney outlined his platform, emphasizing fiscal responsibility, job creation, and a moderate approach to immigration. He also highlighted Utah's economic success, stating that the state has balanced its budgets, exports more than it imports, and welcomes legal immigrants.

Romney's announcement was widely expected, but was delayed following the mass shooting at a Florida high school on Wednesday. Utah Republican Party Chairman Rob Anderson initially expressed reservations about Romney's candidacy, calling him a "carpetbagger" and stating that he does not have a strong connection to the state. However, Anderson later apologized and acknowledged Romney's qualifications to run for Senate.

Despite Romney's past criticism of President Trump, Democrats sought to paint the two as ideologically aligned, stating that Romney's policies align with those of the current administration. The Democratic National Committee spokesperson, Vedant Patel, argued that Utah deserves a senator who will work to improve the lives of all people, not just the wealthy and special interests.

Romney's candidacy is considered a strong favorite, given his name recognition and political experience. If elected, he could potentially cause headaches for the Trump administration from the other side of Pennsylvania Avenue.

Title: Gitmo's Uncertain Future: Prison Remains Open Amidst Pressure to Close and Dilemma Over Prisoner Placement

The Guantanamo Bay Naval Station, commonly referred to as Gitmo, has been a topic of controversy for years, with President Barack Obama pledging to shut it down in 2009. Despite this, the prison remains open, housing 149 prisoners, with 50 deemed too dangerous to release. The prison's conditions have been reported to be deteriorating, with the Southern Command requesting $200 million in improvements last year, which was rejected by the Pentagon.

The prison is stuck between a rock and a hard place, with the dilemma of what to do with the prisoners at its core. If the prison is closed, the $200 million spent on upgrades would be wasted. However, if it remains open, crucial improvements are needed. According to General John F. Kelly, head of the U.S. Southern Command, "It's a long way from being closed." He emphasized that congressional action is necessary to resolve the issue.

House Republicans have voted to ban the transfer of prisoners, citing the Obama administration's alleged violation of the law when it freed five Taliban prisoners in exchange for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in May. Representative Howard "Buck" McKeon, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, stated, "I don't see any support in the House for relaxing the current restrictions or backing off our ban, in light of the president's recent violation of the law."

A recent attempt to transfer six detainees to Uruguay fell through when Uruguayan President Jose Mujica backed away from the deal. The Times reports that leaking ceilings, buckling floors, and inadequate medical facilities cause constant problems at the aging prison. About 6,000 service members and staff work at the prison complex, with the Times estimating taxpayer expense at around $413 million in 2014, or about $3 million per prisoner per year. If the prisoners were housed in a US federal penitentiary, costs would drop to around $30,280 per prisoner per year.

Rear Admiral Kyle Kozad, who heads the prison task force, emphasized the need to prepare for the prison's future, stating, "We are forced to at least forecast so that we're prepared if this detention facility is open two years from now, 12 years from now, 22 years from now, so that we're prepared to be able to continue to do the mission."

Title: Supreme Court's Death Penalty Debate: A Matter of Jurisprudence or Jurispretext?

The United States Supreme Court is currently deliberating on the death penalty, with some opponents advocating for its unconstitutionality. However, the Constitution itself explicitly sanctions capital punishment, as specified in the Fifth Amendment. The Eighth Amendment's "cruel and unusual punishment" clause does not prohibit capital punishment, as the Constitution's drafters and ratifiers did not intend to do so.

The current Supreme Court cases regarding the death penalty are largely trivial, focusing on issues such as prison employees' presence during executions and the potential for religious accommodations. One case involves a man with a rare disease who may experience excruciating pain during lethal injection. While these cases may raise concerns, they do not address the fundamental question of the death penalty's constitutionality.

Many arguments against the death penalty are based on perceived injustices, such as the potential for wrongful convictions or racial disparities in sentencing. However, these concerns are not unique to capital punishment and apply to other criminal justice practices as well. The irreversibility of the death penalty is an argument for prudence in its use, rather than an argument against it.

The myth that the death penalty is more expensive than life imprisonment is also disputed, as both options have their own costs and benefits. The fundamental obstacle to arguments against capital punishment is that it is not inherently unjust, although it may be applied unevenly and imperfectly.

There is a more straightforward case against the death penalty, which is that it adds more violence and horror to society and does not bring out the best in us or our institutions. However, this is a moral and philosophical debate, rather than a legal one, and is best left to Congress and the states to decide.

Title: Defense Secretary Mattis Warns of North Korea's "Clear and Present Danger" and Criticizes China's Actions in South China Sea

Article:

Defense Secretary Jim Mattis delivered a stern warning to North Korea, labeling it a "clear and present danger" during a speech at the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore. He also criticized China's actions in the South China Sea, calling its militarization of artificial islands "indisputable" and "unacceptable." Mattis emphasized the importance of cooperation and diplomacy in addressing the threats posed by North Korea's nuclear and missile programs.

Mattis expressed optimism about China's renewed commitment to working with the US and other nations to rid North Korea of its nuclear weapons. He believes Beijing will ultimately view the Kim Jong Un regime as a liability rather than an asset. However, he was critical of North Korea, calling it an "urgent military threat" and emphasizing the need to exhaust all diplomatic and economic alternatives to prevent the development of nuclear weapons.

The US Defense Secretary also touched on the situation in the South China Sea, where China has been accused of militarizing artificial islands and enforcing excessive maritime claims unsupported by international law. Mattis emphasized the importance of upholding international law and maintaining a balance of power in the region.

In his speech, Mattis reiterated the US commitment to working with its allies and partners in the Asia-Pacific region, while also acknowledging the importance of cooperation with China. He stressed that while competition between the US and China is inevitable, conflict is not inevitable, and that the two countries can and do cooperate for mutual benefit.

Overall, Mattis' speech struck a hopeful tone for cooperation and peace in the Asia-Pacific region, while also emphasizing the need for vigilance and action to address the threats posed by North Korea's nuclear and missile programs.

Title: Understanding National Debt: A Key Indicator of a Country's Fiscal Health

National debt is a measure of a government's borrowing and the amount it owes. When compared to a country's gross domestic product (GDP), it provides valuable insight into its fiscal health. The relationship between debt and GDP is crucial, as a country's debt is considered stable if it is decreasing as a share of GDP.

The level of debt a country can safely handle depends on various factors, including its creditworthiness and ability to pay back its debts. Rising debt can cause economic strain, as a larger portion of government expenditures must be set aside for interest payments. However, in certain situations, more borrowing may be necessary, such as during economic stagnation, to stimulate growth through infrastructure projects.

Developed countries generally hold significantly higher levels of national debt compared to developing countries. This disparity is attributed to "market discipline," as investors are less inclined to lend to emerging markets due to perceived higher risk. Creditworthiness plays a significant role, as countries with a stronger credit profile can borrow more.

In the United States, the national debt has been surging since the 1980s, reaching nearly $20 trillion. While it is difficult to predict the future, most analysts expect the debt to continue rising under President Trump due to anticipated tax cuts and spending increases. Some experts, like Harvard's Jeffrey Frankel, are skeptical that infrastructure spending will boost growth enough to keep pace with the debt.

In Europe, the role of national debt in the recent financial struggles is a topic of debate. Some analysts argue that too much austerity was imposed too late, exacerbating the crisis. Greece, considered an advanced economy, had high debt levels before the crisis, which were not addressed until it was too late. Economist John Maynard Keynes' advice to cut back during boom times was not heeded, leading to the economic downturn.

In conclusion, national debt is a critical indicator of a country's fiscal health, and its level depends on various factors, including creditworthiness and the ability to pay back debts. Understanding the relationship between debt and GDP is essential for policymakers to make informed decisions about borrowing and spending.

Title: Colorado Pioneers Publicly Available Health Care Prices, But Challenges Remain

Article:

Colorado is one of the 11 states that have started making health care prices publicly available, a move aimed at empowering patients and driving down costs. The state's "all-payer claims database" collects receipts for health care services, providing a comprehensive view of what patients pay for medical procedures. This information is crucial, as actual prices for procedures like colonoscopies can vary significantly, with costs ranging from $2,800 to $400.

The database's availability has been a long time coming, with laws needing to be passed to obtain insurance companies' claims data. However, the process of making this information accessible to the public has been complicated, time-consuming, and expensive. To overcome these challenges, Colorado is seeking to sell more detailed, custom reports to businesses within the health industry.

These reports would provide valuable insights, such as complication rates, allowing hospitals and insurance companies to make more informed decisions. For instance, Dr. David Ehrenberger, the chief medical officer for Avista Adventist hospital, would like to see reports that show his competitors' prices and complication rates, giving him better negotiating power with insurance companies.

However, there is a hurdle: Medicare data, which accounts for about 20% of all health care bills in Colorado, cannot be used in custom reports due to current federal restrictions. Edie Sonn, the executive director of CIVHC, notes that this limitation restricts the types of reports that can be sold. However, there is growing support on Capitol Hill to change this, with a measure included in a Medicare bill working its way through Congress.

If passed, this measure would allow Colorado to make Medicare data available for custom reports, bringing the state closer to making health care shopping as easy as buying a coffee maker.

Title: Young Adults' Health Insurance Coverage Increases, According to New Report

A recent report released on Monday reveals that the share of young adults without health insurance in the United States has decreased by one-sixth in 2011, the largest annual decline for any age group since the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention began collecting data in 1997. The estimates are based on a federal survey of approximately 35,000 households.

According to the report, the share of people aged 19 to 25 without health insurance fell to 27.9%, down from 33.9% in 2010, representing a decline of about 1.6 million fewer uninsured individuals. The data suggests that the Affordable Care Act's provision allowing children to stay on their parents' insurance policies until their 26th birthday is the primary reason for the increase in coverage among young adults.

Joseph Antos, a health care policy expert at the American Enterprise Institute, agrees that the provision is the most plausible explanation for the increase. He notes that young people have been disproportionately affected by the recession and would otherwise be expected to have a higher rate of uninsurance. "Nothing else went well for this age group," he said.

The report also notes that the share of people aged 26 to 35 without health insurance increased, which suggests that the health care law is driving the decline among the younger group. The dependents' provision of the health care law took effect in September 2010, and the number of uninsured young adults declined that year as well, although by a smaller amount. Obama administration officials attribute the drop to the law's effectiveness, despite being broadly opposed by Republicans.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Criticize Profit-Making Enterprises

The first round of Democratic presidential debates has concluded, with several candidates emphasizing the need to address the perceived negative impact of profit-driven enterprises on American society. A recurring theme throughout the debates was the notion that giant corporations prioritize profits over people, with some candidates arguing that this approach is detrimental to the country.

Several candidates highlighted the issue of profit-driven healthcare, with some calling for Medicare for All and criticizing the insurance and pharmaceutical industries for prioritizing profits over people. For example, one candidate stated that insurance companies and pharmaceutical companies are profiteering off the pain of Americans, with insurance companies alone reaping $23 billion in profits last year. Another candidate emphasized the need to create competition among insurers to drive down costs and improve care.

The debate also touched on the issue of private prisons and immigration detention centers, with some candidates criticizing the fact that companies are profiting from incarceration and detention. Additionally, some candidates argued that the current healthcare system prioritizes profits over people, with insurance companies and pharmaceutical companies working to maintain the status quo.

The candidates' comments highlighted the distinction between capitalism and greed, with some arguing that companies prioritize profits over people and that this approach is detrimental to society. The debate also emphasized the need for a system that prioritizes people over profits, with some candidates advocating for universal healthcare and others calling for increased regulation and oversight of industries that prioritize profits over people.

Title: Democrats' Memory-Holing of Obama's Executive Powers: A Twilight Zone Episode

The article discusses the phenomenon of Democrats conveniently forgetting or downplaying the executive actions taken by former President Barack Obama during his eight-year tenure. The author argues that this selective amnesia is a result of the political polarization and partisanship that has become a hallmark of the Trump era. The article highlights several instances where Obama's administration took bold actions, such as deporting a large number of undocumented immigrants, defying congressional subpoenas, and authorizing drone strikes without congressional approval.

The author notes that Trump's actions, such as his "America First" policy and the airstrike that killed Iranian terrorist Qassem Soleimani, are often met with criticism and outrage from Democrats, who seem to have forgotten that Obama took similar actions during his presidency. The article concludes that this selective memory loss will cost Democrats in the upcoming election, as they are unable to give Trump an inch, no matter how safe or prosperous the world is.

The article is written in a neutral and factual tone, presenting historical information and quotes from various sources to support the author's claims. The author does not take a political stance or express personal opinions, instead focusing on the phenomenon of selective memory loss and its implications for the 2020 election.

Title: Gun-Control Group and Firearms Manufacturer Clash Over Billboard Depicting "Assault Rifle" as American Icon

A billboard campaign by Slide Fire, a firearms parts manufacturer in Texas, has sparked controversy and debate over its depiction of an AR-type rifle as an American icon, alongside baseball and apple pie. The billboard, which reads "Pure American" and features three images, including a baseball glove, a pie, and an AR-type rifle, has been criticized by Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense, a gun-control group funded by New York City billionaire Mike Bloomberg.

The group's Illinois chapter head, Nicole Chen, expressed shock and disappointment over the ad, stating that it removes the "mom" from the idiom "as American as baseball, apple pie, and mom" and replaces it with an assault rifle. Chen emphasized that children in Chicago, a city struggling with gun violence, are being exposed to a harmful message.

Slide Fire's CEO, Laura Shackelford, defended the campaign, saying it aims to promote Second Amendment rights and challenge the notion that gun ownership is abnormal or scary. Shackelford pointed out that firearms are older than baseball or apple pie and are a symbol of American freedom.

The National Shooting Sports Foundation, which represents firearms manufacturers, also weighed in, stating that the modern sporting rifle depicted is not an "assault rifle" and that anti-gun groups are misrepresenting the term. The organization emphasized that the term "assault rifle" refers to fully automatic weapons, whereas the Slide Stock, a product manufactured by Slide Fire, is a semi-automatic rifle that requires the user to manually pull the trigger each time to release a round.

The controversy highlights the ongoing debate over gun control and Second Amendment rights in the United States. While some see the billboard as a provocative and harmful message, others view it as a necessary pushback against what they perceive as misguided gun-control efforts.

Title: Non-Profit Demands Removal of Nazi-Inscribed Headstones in National Cemetery

A non-profit organization, the Military Religious Freedom Foundation (MRFF), has called on the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to remove marble headstones inscribed with Nazi iconography and a phrase honoring Adolf Hitler at the graves of two German prisoners of war in a national cemetery in San Antonio. The headstones, which feature a swastika in the center of an iron cross, an award for valor, and the phrase "He died far from his home for the Führer, people and fatherland," were discovered by a former active-duty senior officer in the U.S. military.

The MRFF, led by Chair Mikey Weinstein, a Jewish individual, is demanding that the VA "immediately replace the gravestones of all German military personnel interred in V.A. National Cemeteries" and ensure that no Nazi-era symbols remain in U.S. military graveyards. The organization is also calling for an explanation from VA Secretary Robert Wilkie on why these headstones were installed in the first place.

The Fort Sam Houston V.A. cemetery, where the headstones are located, is home to 133,154 American veterans, spouses, or their children. Its "Section Z" hosts the remains of 140 prisoners of war from World War II, 132 of which were German. The remains of the two POWs in question, who died in 1943, were not repatriated and were buried in the cemetery.

The VA's Public Affairs and Outreach head, Les Melnyk, stated that the agency will continue to preserve the headstones, as has been done in the past. However, it is unclear whether any past administration has received a similar request to remove the headstones.

The controversy surrounding the headstones has sparked concerns about the presence of white supremacy and anti-Semitism in the U.S. military. The retired senior officer who shared the photos of the headstones expressed outrage, stating that the symbols could be used as a shrine for Nazi pilgrims. The MRFF is now calling on the VA to apologize and explain why it has used taxpayer money to maintain the headstones.

Title: Young Americans' Lack of Investment in Stocks May Hinder Achieving the American Dream

Recent polling suggests that many Americans believe it will be more challenging for millennials to climb the economic ladder and achieve the American Dream. This pessimism may be justified, given the concerning trends among young people in the workforce and their financial habits. The labor force participation rate for 18- to 24-year-olds is at a 50-year low, with only 65% of this age group employed. Moreover, fewer young people are investing in the stock market, with a record-low 7% of households headed by those under 35 years old directly owning stocks.

Historically, investing in the stock market has been a key factor in building wealth over time. According to investment guru Jeremy Siegel, investing in the stock market for the long-term can lead to significant returns, with the average real rate of return since the late-19th century being 6%. This means that $1 invested at age 18 could grow to more than $15 by age 65.

However, many young people are not taking advantage of this opportunity. One reason is the lingering psychological trauma from the 2001 tech and 2008 market collapses. Another issue is the burden of student loan debt, which leaves many with little disposable income to invest. Additionally, the government intercepts a significant portion of young people's paychecks through the Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA) payroll tax, leaving them with limited funds for investing.

Economist Peter Ferrara argues that if young people invested their payroll tax dollars in an index fund of all stocks, they would have a nest egg of over $1 million by retirement. This highlights the potential benefits of investing in the stock market and the importance of taking advantage of compound interest.

The article also notes that the wealthiest 10% of Americans own a significant portion of the country's assets, while the middle class and young people have largely dropped out of the market. This widening wealth gap is a concern, as it may exacerbate social and economic inequalities.

In conclusion, the lack of investment in stocks among young Americans may hinder their ability to achieve the American Dream. It is essential for young people to understand the benefits of investing in the stock market and to take advantage of the long-term returns it offers. By doing so, they can build a secure financial future and contribute to a more equitable society.

Title: Trump Transition Team Accuses Special Counsel of Obtaining Tens of Thousands of Emails Unlawfully

The Trump transition team, known as Trump for America (TFA), has accused the special counsel investigating allegations of Russian meddling in the 2016 election of obtaining tens of thousands of emails unlawfully. In a letter to congressional committees, Kory Langhofer, counsel to the transition team, claimed that the General Services Administration (GSA) had improperly produced the emails, including privileged communications, to the Special Counsel's Office.

According to the letter, the emails were obtained despite the fact that the GSA did not own or control the records. The Trump transition team used GSA facilities during the period between Trump's presidential election victory and his inauguration in January. The letter stated that the materials included "tens of thousands of emails" and that the GSA's transfer of materials was discovered on December 12 and 13.

The Trump transition team's accusation adds to the growing friction between the president's supporters and Mueller's office as it investigates whether Russia interfered in the election and if Trump or anyone on his team colluded with Moscow. The special counsel's office has waved off the transition team's complaint, stating that they have secured either the account owner's consent or appropriate criminal process when obtaining emails in the course of their ongoing criminal investigation.

The GSA did not respond immediately to a request for comment. The White House said it continues to cooperate fully with the special counsel and expects the process to wrap up soon. The special counsel's office has obtained emails from the Trump transition team, including those of former national security adviser Michael Flynn, who pleaded guilty this month to lying to the FBI about his contacts with Russia.

The Trump transition team's letter asked Congress to act immediately to protect future presidential transitions from having their private records misappropriated by government agencies, particularly in the context of sensitive investigations intersecting with political motives. The letter stated that Mueller's office has extensively used the materials in question, including portions that are susceptible to claims of privilege, without notifying the Trump for America team.

Title: Nevada County Clerks Halt Same-Sex Marriage Licenses Amid Conflicting Court Decisions

Nevada county clerks turned away same-sex couples eager to marry on Wednesday, following a flurry of conflicting court decisions, including a U.S. Supreme Court ruling that blocked partners in Idaho from obtaining marriage licenses just moments before they would have picked up their licenses. The 9th Circuit Court's late Tuesday ruling cleared the way for Idaho and Nevada to begin issuing same-sex marriage licenses, but a stay imposed by Justice Anthony Kennedy brought the plans to a halt in both states.

In Nevada, officials decided to wait for more clear direction from the courts before issuing licenses, while in Idaho, a small crowd of hopeful couples gathered at courthouses early to apply for marriage licenses. However, at 8:01 a.m., Ada County Clerk Chris Rich announced that same-sex marriage licenses would not be issued that day, citing the Supreme Court's stay.

The decision left couples stunned, with some expressing disappointment and frustration. Amber Beierle, who has been with her partner Rachael Beierle for 43 years, said the news was especially bitter since they had never been closer to getting married before. "We were past the metal detectors, we were just a few feet away from the clerk, and then our attorney was handed a one-page document. Apparently, it was Justice Kennedy telling us, 'No,'" Beierle said.

In Las Vegas, wedding chapels had photographers ready to capture two brides in white dresses, while ordained Elvis impersonators practiced their lines. However, as courts began to close, Diana Alba, the Clark County clerk, announced that no one in the state would be issuing marriage licenses that day, and she did not know when they might begin. Tara Traynor and her fiancée Cathy Grimes, who have been together for eight years, had been waiting at the Clark County Marriage License Bureau, checking their phones for court developments and letting straight couples cut in front of them while they waited for the legal OK to get a license. "It's kind of disheartening," Traynor said. "We wait and wait, and we're hopeful."

Title: Democrat Andrew Gillum Concedes Florida Governor's Race to Republican Ron DeSantis

Andrew Gillum, the Democratic candidate for Florida governor, has officially conceded the race to his Republican opponent, Ron DeSantis. In a four-minute video posted on his Facebook page, Gillum thanked his supporters and acknowledged DeSantis as the winner. Gillum initially conceded on election night but retracted his statement after the margin between the two candidates narrowed.

The race went to a legally required recount, with DeSantis still leading Gillum by more than 30,000 votes after an initial machine recount. The final tally showed DeSantis with 4,075,445 votes and Gillum with 4,041,762 votes. Gillum stated that he and his wife wanted to ensure every vote was counted, including undervotes and overvotes.

Gillum will end his four-year term as Tallahassee mayor later this month but plans to continue advocating for the issues that matter to him and the over 4 million people who voted for him. He expressed his commitment to updating the state election system and fighting for the voices of everyday people to be heard in government, state, and communities.

President Donald Trump offered praise for Gillum on Twitter, calling him a "strong Democrat warrior long into the future." Gillum has no plans to step out of the spotlight completely, stating "the fight for Florida continues."

Title: Crossroads GPS Releases Anti-Obamacare Video, Parodying Sharknado

Article:

Conservative political group Crossroads GPS has launched a new online attack video criticizing the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. The 47-second trailer, titled "ObamaCareNado," parodies the Syfy network's phenomenon "Sharknado" and features tornadoes ripping through scenery and people, bearing the faces of prime Crossroads targets like House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, Sen. Majority Leader Harry Reid, and President Barack Obama.

The video claims that Obamacare is a "rising tide of health care costs" and that "nobody is safe from its wrath," leaving a "path of destruction through our economy." Crossroads GPS has a history of targeting Democrats on various issues, including immigration reform and student loans. The organization spent $176 million in the 2012 federal elections, according to OpenSecrets.org.

The "ObamaCareNado" video comes as Obama delivered a major speech on Thursday morning touting the success of the ACA. In his speech, Obama emphasized that "affordable health care is not some privilege just for the few, it's a basic right that everybody should be able to enjoy." He reiterated the administration's commitment to securing this right and ensuring that every American gets the care they need at a price they can afford.

Separately, a study released on Wednesday predicted a 50% drop in health insurance premiums for New York residents when the ACA takes effect next year. The study's findings suggest that the law may be having a positive impact on the healthcare market.

Title: Former Congressman Jesse Jackson Jr.'s Downfall: A Lesson in Accountability

The recent downfall of former Congressman Jesse Jackson Jr. has left many Americans feeling a mix of emotions. While some may view his case as a sad story, others see it as a necessary reminder of the importance of accountability in public office. Jackson Jr. was found guilty of stealing nearly $750,000 in campaign funds, using them to buy lavish items, including a $43,000 Rolex watch.

The criminal justice system worked as intended, and Jackson Jr. was brought to justice. However, some may question why his downfall is being portrayed as a sad story. Jazz Shaw, a contributor to "Morning Joe," summarized the sentiment: "At what point did this become a'sad story'? The criminal was caught and brought to justice. The system worked. Aren't we generally happy about that?"

The reality is that Jackson Jr.'s actions betrayed the trust of his constituents, many of whom live below the poverty level. His actions have left a lasting impact on the public's perception of politicians and government. As Alexander Hamilton wrote in The Federalist Papers, "a dangerous ambition more often lurks behind the specious mask of zeal for the rights of the people than under the forbidding appearance of zeal for the firmness and efficiency of government."

The incident serves as a reminder that corruption and abuse of power will always exist in public life. It is the responsibility of citizens to remain vigilant and hold those in power accountable. Americans should not be saddened by Jackson Jr.'s downfall but rather be grateful that justice was served and that the system worked as intended.

Title: Primary Season Kicks Off in North Carolina, Ohio, and Indiana

The primary season has officially begun, with North Carolina, Ohio, and Indiana hosting elections today. Twenty-five states will hold primaries over the next six weeks, with the Republican Senate primary in North Carolina being a key race to watch. The contest pits the establishment against the Tea Party, with Thom Tillis, the speaker of the North Carolina House, backed by Jeb Bush and Mitt Romney, facing off against Greg Brannon, a physician and Tea Party favorite. Mark Harris, a preacher, is the Evangelical choice, backed by Mike Huckabee.

In the Democratic primary, American Idol runner-up Clay Aiken is running against businessman Keith Crisco and Toni Morris. While Aiken has been outspent by Crisco, he has run four television ads to Aiken's one. The winner will face incumbent Republican Rep. Renee Elmers, who is heavily favored to win.

In Ohio, Rep. Walter Jones is being challenged from the right by GOP consultant and former aide to President George W. Bush and the McCain campaign, Taylor Griffin. Jones is in line to be the second most senior Republican on the House Armed Services Committee, but this challenge from within his own party is one to watch.

House Speaker John Boehner is also facing two challengers, Eric Gurr, a computer consultant, and J.D. Winteregg, a high school French teacher. Boehner will likely win, but the challengers have been able to drum up publicity for themselves, with Winteregg releasing an online parody video in the style of the drug Cialis, claiming Boehner has "electile dysfunction."

Indiana's primary election is expected to be a snooze-fest, with neither of its senators on the ballot and all nine House incumbents seeking re-election. The state's new voting law, passed in August by the state's GOP governor and legislature, will be tested, but turnout is usually low in primary contests.

Overall, today's primary election in North Carolina will be the first time voters go to the polls since the state's new voting law was passed, and voting rights advocates will be keeping an eye on some of the law's provisions, such as a ban on same-day registration and restrictions on early voting.

Title: The Decline of the Media Elite: A Shift in the Information Landscape

The article discusses the perceived decline of the media elite and the rise of alternative sources of information. The author argues that the media's credibility has been eroded by their perceived bias and lack of objectivity. The article highlights the shift in the way people consume news, with the rise of social media and online platforms providing an alternative to traditional news sources.

The author claims that the media elite have lost their monopoly on the flow of information and are now struggling to maintain their relevance. They argue that the media's failure to adapt to the changing media landscape has led to their decline.

The article also touches on the rise of Donald Trump and how he has disrupted the media's traditional power dynamics. The author suggests that the media's inability to effectively cover Trump's presidency has led to a loss of credibility and influence.

The article concludes by highlighting the democratization of information and the rise of self-publishing, which has given individuals the ability to share their ideas and perspectives without the need for traditional gatekeepers. The author suggests that this shift has made the media elite's role less relevant and has given people more control over the information they consume.

Note: The article is written in a sarcastic and humorous tone, which may not be suitable for all audiences. The language used is also quite strong and critical of the media elite.

Title: The 2016 Election: A False Choice Between Reassurance and Policy

The 2016 presidential election is shaping up to be a pivotal moment in American politics, with many progressive groups expressing concerns that Hillary Clinton's campaign may be too focused on her opponent's personality and lack of qualifications, rather than policy. However, a closer examination of historical trends suggests that this concern may be misplaced.

David Frum, a center-right Republican dissident, argues that Clinton faces a unique challenge in that she may be tempted to move to the left to keep Bernie Sanders' supporters on board, rather than focusing on a moderate platform. This concern is rooted in the idea that Clinton's campaign may be driven by a desire to win a landslide victory, rather than a desire to pass meaningful legislation.

However, history suggests that this concern may be unfounded. The 1964 election, in which Lyndon B. Johnson won a landslide victory, is often cited as an example of a campaign that focused on the opponent's weaknesses rather than policy. However, this election also saw the passage of significant progressive legislation, including the Civil Rights Act and the Voting Rights Act.

Furthermore, the reality is that the 2016 election is unlikely to produce a large Democratic majority in Congress, making it difficult for Clinton to pass significant legislation. Instead, the shape of Congress will play a much larger role in determining policy outcomes. Even a small Democratic majority reliant on moderate legislators would pass more progressive legislation than a Republican one.

Ultimately, the 2016 election presents a false choice between reassuring the center and laying the groundwork for policy. Rather than focusing on Clinton's opponent's weaknesses, voters should be concerned with the broader political landscape and the potential for meaningful policy change.

Title: House Republicans Propose Tax Increases as Part of Deficit Reduction Package

The House Republican leadership has presented a $2.2 trillion deficit reduction package that includes eliminating unspecified deductions and loopholes from the tax code, raising new revenue without increasing tax rates. While this proposal does not align with the Democratic Party's demand for increased tax rates, it has drawn criticism from some conservative lawmakers and advocacy groups.

Senate Republicans, many of whom are conservatives, have withheld harsh criticism of the plan, but have not fully endorsed it either. They have expressed concerns about the potential impact on the economy and the lack of specific details on the proposed changes to the tax code. Some Senate Republicans, such as Sen. Jim DeMint and Sen. Rand Paul, have strongly opposed the plan, citing concerns about job creation and the economy.

House Speaker John Boehner and other House leaders presented the proposal on Monday, which was met with mixed reactions from Republicans. While some, like Sen. John Thune and Sen. Roy Blunt, praised the effort as a "good faith" attempt to address the fiscal cliff, others, like Sen. Charles Grassley, expressed reservations about the lack of spending cuts to accompany the revenue increases.

Conservative groups, such as Americans for Prosperity and Heritage Action for America, have also spoken out against the proposal, citing concerns about the potential impact on the economy and the lack of entitlement reform. However, some House Republicans have defended the proposal, arguing that it is a serious and credible effort to address the fiscal cliff.

The proposal is part of a broader effort by House Republicans to respond to the White House's demand for a Republican plan to address the fiscal cliff. The proposal is seen as a way for House Republicans to demonstrate their commitment to deficit reduction and fiscal responsibility, while also acknowledging the need for some revenue increases.

Title: Former Rhode Island Governor Lincoln Chafee Ends Presidential Bid

Former Rhode Island Governor Lincoln Chafee announced on Friday that he is ending his presidential bid, citing his campaign's lack of momentum and financial struggles. Chafee, a former Republican turned independent turned Democrat, had been running on a platform of "Prosperity Through Peace," emphasizing the importance of taking chances for peace and promoting international cooperation.

Chafee's campaign had struggled to gain traction, with limited financial backing and few visits to early primary states. He had raised only $8,300 from 10 major donors during the last quarter, making it difficult to sustain his campaign. Despite his supporters' enthusiasm for his positive attitude and message, Chafee's performance in last week's presidential debate was unremarkable, with him speaking for just nine minutes during the two-hour faceoff.

In his withdrawal announcement, Chafee reiterated his anti-war stance, stating that the United States is strong enough to take chances for peace and promote international cooperation. He also highlighted his own personal experience, noting that he had never been involved in any scandals during his decades in office.

Chafee's campaign had faced criticism for his lack of preparation and experience, particularly during the debate, where he struggled to answer questions about his voting record. He had also been criticized for his decision to repeal the Glass-Steagall Act, a banking regulation he claimed he was not familiar with due to his recent appointment to the Senate.

Despite his campaign's struggles, Chafee's supporters praised his positive attitude and message, and some had hoped he would remain in the race. Chafee's decision to end his campaign leaves the Democratic field with one fewer candidate, but it is unclear whether he will consider running as an independent in the future.

Title: Ayotte Defends Gun Vote, Claims Outside Groups Misrepresent Her Stance

Ayotte, a Republican senator from New Hampshire, has faced intense criticism and declining poll numbers after voting against a bill to expand background checks on gun purchases. In an op-ed published on Monday, Ayotte sought to clarify her stance on the issue, stating that she supports effective background checks and has voted to improve the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS).

Ayotte's opposition to the bill, crafted by Senators Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) and Pat Toomey (R-Pa.), was met with criticism from outside groups, who argue that the bill would have mandated background checks for sales at gun shows and on the internet. Instead, Ayotte backed an alternative measure written by Senator Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) that focuses on encouraging states to submit mental health information to the background check database.

In her op-ed, Ayotte claimed that some of her colleagues want to expand the "broken" background check system, and that the focus should be on fixing the existing system, which criminals are flouting. However, critics argue that the Grassley-Cruz bill she supported would actually narrow the categories of mentally ill people who would be prohibited from purchasing guns and potentially call into question millions of names already in the system.

Mayors Against Illegal Guns Chairman John Feinblatt responded to Ayotte's op-ed, stating that the senator's claim that the current background check system doesn't work is incorrect. The system has blocked over two million dangerous people from buying guns, according to Feinblatt.

Title: Emory University Hospital's Ebola Treatment Experience: Lessons Learned and Protocols Shared

Atlanta's Emory University Hospital received its first Ebola patient in late July, a doctor who had been treating patients in Liberia. Within 72 hours, a second patient was on the way, prompting the hospital's staff to quickly assess what they needed to care for the patients the next day. Since then, Emory has treated four Ebola patients, all of whom have survived.

The true cure for Ebola is keeping patients alive long enough to develop antibodies that will help them recover from the infection. Emory's experience has shown that aggressively treating the illness can be effective. The hospital's plan to treat patients with diseases like Ebola began 12 years ago, when the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) started working with Emory to create a special isolation unit.

The hospital's core team of health workers has trained yearly and held practice drills every six months to stay prepared for infectious diseases. When the Ebola patients arrived, the team had to quickly train and not everyone made the cut. The expanded team focused on supportive care, administering IV fluids and preventing infections.

Emory learned lessons from each case, including the importance of increasing working space around patients and having hand sanitizer dispensers that didn't require touching. Nurses on the Ebola unit preferred 12-hour rotations, and caring for patients' emotional health was just as important as promoting physical well-being.

The hospital's entire 84-page protocol document is now available online, with over 11,300 people registering to access it. The Emory team does not claim to have all the answers, but they are sharing their experience and protocols with others to help combat the disease.

**Houston Struggles to Cope with Tens of Thousands of Evacuees Amidst Looting and Flooding**

Houston, Texas, is facing significant challenges as tens of thousands of people flee their homes and flooded roads, seeking shelter from the devastating effects of Tropical Storm Harvey. The city's emergency services are stretched to the limit, with police and first responders transitioning from rescue operations to law enforcement, and Harris County District Attorney Kim Ogg vowing to vigorously prosecute looters.

As of Wednesday, at least 40 people have been arrested for looting, including one individual who allegedly drove a sport utility vehicle into a cash machine. The storm has caused widespread damage, with over 49,000 homes affected and more than 1,000 destroyed. Thousands of other homes are threatened by swollen reservoirs, with some areas receiving up to 52 inches of rain.

The city has opened several shelters, including the George R. Brown Convention Center, which initially housed 5,000 people but quickly grew to accommodate over 10,000. The city has also opened two "mega" centers at the Toyota Center and NRG Park, which can house up to 10,000 people each.

Despite the challenges, officials are working to provide aid to those affected by the storm. The American Red Cross has brought in at least 1,000 volunteers to staff the shelters, and provided cots, blankets, and food for 34,000 across the region. The city has also allocated $20 million to storm recovery efforts, with more funding expected to be needed.

The storm has claimed at least 25 lives and forced 30,000 people to flee to emergency shelters. Texas Governor Greg Abbott has estimated that the state could need federal relief topping $125 billion, saying the region should receive more aid than was provided for Hurricane Katrina victims in 2005.

As the city struggles to cope with the aftermath of the storm, officials are urging residents to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activity. The city has implemented a midnight to 5 a.m. curfew, and residents are respecting it.

Title: Rubio and Cruz Release Tax Returns, Piling Pressure on Trump

In a move to increase transparency, Senator Marco Rubio and Senator Ted Cruz have released their tax returns, sparking renewed pressure on rival Donald Trump to do the same. Rubio's returns show his family's adjusted gross income was $335,561 in 2014, with a tax rate of 19.3%. The returns date back to 2000, when he earned $82,710.

Cruz, on the other hand, released his returns for the years 2010-2014, which show an adjusted gross income of $1.2 million in 2014, with a tax rate of 32.22%. He had previously released his returns for the years 2006-2010 when he ran for Senate.

The releases come as Trump faces criticism for not making his own tax returns public. At the debate on Thursday, Trump stated that he is being audited and cannot release his returns until the audit is finished.
