However, an NPR fact-check found that there is no law prohibiting Trump from releasing his returns while being audited, although an accountant or lawyer may have advised him to wait.

Rubio's returns show a significant increase in income over the years, with his family's largest monthly expense now being their mortgage payment. Cruz's statement emphasized the importance of transparency, saying, "It's time to stop the excuses. Donald Trump owes it to the American people to be fully vetted, and that includes releasing his tax returns so the voters can see the full financial picture."

Title: Americans' Frustration with Economic Recovery Justified, but Misdirected

Article:

The economic recovery under President Obama's watch has been marked by a decline in good-paying jobs and a decrease in family incomes by approximately $1,650. This trend has been ongoing since Ronald Reagan's presidency, with the gross domestic product growing at a 2.2% annual pace, compared to 4.6% and 3.7% during Reagan and Bill Clinton's terms, respectively. However, this does not necessarily mean that the economic growth is slowing down. Instead, the lack of workers adequately trained for a more technological demanding workplace is the primary culprit.

Automation has been a recurring theme throughout American history, with machines replacing workers in various industries. This trend is expected to continue, with robots replacing people in activities requiring manual dexterity and complex cognitive processes. By 2030, it is predicted that 90% of jobs as we know them will be replaced by smart machines.

The real challenge lies in training Americans to engage in intellectually demanding and creative work, or risk being relegated to low-paying jobs better suited for androids. In 2016, Americans should be skeptical of false promises to restore prosperity and outraged by the lack of preparation for the future.

The efforts to make a high school diploma universal have made it nearly worthless, with less than 40% of 12th graders ready to read or learn math at the college level. Additionally, many graduates lack the complex reasoning skills needed for white-collar work. The college diploma is not much better, with four in 10 graduates lacking the necessary skills for white-collar work.

The president and his presumptive heir, Hillary Clinton, remain focused on sexism in education and the workplace, while conservatives like Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio oppose universal standards for academic rigor. The future lies in educating Americans to build and teach machines that will do the work that has burdened humanity since the first branch was shaped into a hunting implement.

Without young people trained and encouraged to do sophisticated work, the locus of prosperity will permanently shift from America to Asia, where pragmatic leaders urge children to study engineering, not superstitions peddled by pious academics and deceitful politicians.

Title: Senate Faces Presidential Nominations Crisis as Democrats and Republicans Clash Over Filibuster Rules

Article:

The United States Senate is on the brink of a presidential nominations crisis as Democrats and Republicans clash over filibuster rules. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat, has vowed to press ahead with showdown votes this week that could rewrite Senate rules to allow President Barack Obama's team to bypass Republican filibusters when nominating executive branch or independent agency officials. However, this move could threaten the comity essential to the chamber's operations.

Reid defended the "nuclear option" to change the rules, stating that it is a "very, very minimal" change that would allow the president to have his nominees confirmed without obstruction. He emphasized that the changes would not apply to judicial nominees.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, countered that Democrats are seeking a fight where none exists. He pointed out that Senate Republicans have confirmed President Obama's picks at a faster rate than President George W. Bush's nominees at the same point in his presidency. McConnell also noted that Republicans have not defeated any of Obama's major executive nominees.

The two leaders did not appear on the same panel during an NBC interview, but spoke sequentially to moderator David Gregory. Reid has scheduled seven potential filibuster votes for Tuesday morning, including nominations for the Labor Department secretary, Environmental Protection Agency administrator, and three members of the National Labor Relations Board.

The question is whether Reid will force a rules change if Republicans filibuster only some of these nominees. He has scheduled the most controversial votes, including the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and two National Labor Relations Board picks, to be first, which could make Republicans cave.

McConnell said Republicans would allow most nominees, including those they strongly object to, such as Labor secretary pick Thomas E. Perez. However, the three main fights over the NLRB and CFPB nominees are trickier. Republicans argue that Reid is risking major damage to the institution of the Senate to rescue the NLRB from its precarious position.

Ahead of the showdown, each side deployed numbers to argue its case. Republicans claimed they have confirmed an exceptional number of Obama's nominees, including every executive branch appointment that has come to the Senate floor. Democrats countered that Republicans have pushed obstruction behind closed doors by slow-walking nominees in committees, demanding answers to hundreds of questions about their histories and policy positions.

The filibuster is not part of Senate rules, but rather a term applied when a single senator or group of senators wants to hold an indefinite debate on an issue. The outcome of the showdown remains uncertain, with both sides dug in and refusing to budge.

Title: White House Accuses GOP of Playing Politics Amidst Controversies

The White House has accused the Republican Party of playing politics amidst ongoing controversies surrounding the administration. The controversies include the secret subpoena of journalists' phone records, IRS targeting of conservative groups, and misleading statements about the Benghazi terrorist attack. Despite the challenges, history shows that second-term presidents can still make progress despite problems.

The scenario invites comparisons to previous presidents who faced controversies in their "lame duck" second terms, such as the Iran-Contra scandal of the Reagan administration and Bill Clinton's impeachment for perjury and obstruction of justice in the Monica Lewinsky scandal. However, a rocky start to a second term does not necessarily mean certain derailment of a president's goals or agenda.

The White House spokesman, Jay Carney, insisted that the controversies have little connection to President Barack Obama's second-term agenda. He cited campaign issues from his re-election last November, such as economic growth, expanded opportunities for the middle class, and immigration reform.

The controversies are certain to continue to dominate Washington in the coming days, with a House committee hearing scheduled for Friday to investigate the IRS political targeting. The embattled Attorney General Eric Holder announced a Justice Department investigation into whether any laws were broken in the IRS political targeting.

The Republican National Committee called for Obama to demand Holder's resignation over the matter, while some Democratic senators condemned the secret subpoena of AP phone records. Republican senators characterized the IRS political targeting as a broad abuse of power by the administration.

The White House spokesman, Jay Carney, rejected GOP statements as political hyperbole, but also sought to distance the administration from the roiling issues. He refused to discuss specific details of the Justice Department's subpoena of AP telephone records, citing the ongoing criminal investigation of the classified leak.

Title: House Passes Clean Debt Ceiling Bill, Avoiding Default Until March 2015

The House of Representatives has voted 221-201 to lift the debt ceiling until March 2015, removing the threat of a default until after the November midterm election. The bill was supported by 193 Democrats and 28 Republicans. The vote marks a reversal for Speaker John Boehner, who in 2011 advocated for debt limit increases to be accompanied by budget cuts of equal or greater magnitude.

All Republican leadership, including Boehner, Majority Leader Eric Cantor, and Majority Whip Kevin McCarthy, voted in favor of the bill. However, Rep. Paul Ryan, a potential 2016 presidential candidate, voted against it, along with House Republican Conference Chairman Cathy McMorris Rodgers, GOP Policy Chairman James Lankford, and Rep. Greg Walden.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi held her troops together, with only two Democrats, Jim Matheson and John Barrow, voting against the bill. The vote is the latest example of Boehner relying on Democrats to pass legislation that many Republicans do not support.

The Senate is expected to vote on the debt limit bill as early as Wednesday, pending agreement on fast consideration. Once the bill is cleared, Congress will not face a major fiscal decision until government funding runs dry on September 30.

White House Press Secretary Jay Carney called the House vote a "positive step in moving away from political brinkmanship." Republican leaders say they want to transform their image from the opposition party to the alternative party, with plans to pass their own health care reform bill and move legislation to reform education laws.

Title: US-Germany Tensions Escalate Over Allegations of NSA Surveillance on World Leaders

The United States and its allies are facing increased tensions over reports that the National Security Agency (NSA) monitored phone calls of 35 world leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel. The latest report in The Guardian reveals that the NSA encouraged top departments to share their "Rolodexes" to keep numbers for top foreign leaders in their surveillance systems. The document reportedly said an official handed over 200 numbers, some of which covered 35 world leaders, but the leaders were not named.

The German government has summoned the US Ambassador to account for allegations that the NSA may have targeted Merkel's cellphone. White House Press Secretary Jay Carney stated that the US "is not monitoring and will not monitor" Merkel's communications, but did not deny that such surveillance may have occurred in the past.

German Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle expressed his concerns, saying it is "unacceptable" that Merkel's mobile phone may have been subject to surveillance activities by the US. He emphasized that "spying on close friends and partners is totally unacceptable" and "undermines trust" between nations.

This is the latest in a series of flare-ups over reported surveillance, which have also involved France, Mexico, and Brazil. The Washington Post reported that US officials are telling some foreign intelligence agencies that NSA leaker Edward Snowden has documents detailing their cooperation with the United States.

The German government has been one of Washington's closest allies in Europe, with the US providing protection during the Cold War and still hosting thousands of US troops. The German government has not commented on Merkel's response to Obama's assurance that the US is not monitoring her communications, but a prominent lawmaker with her party criticized the statement, saying it does not address whether Merkel was monitored in the past.

The tensions between the US and Germany are escalating, with the German government demanding greater transparency and accountability from the US government.

Title: Supreme Court to Consider Same-Sex Marriage Cases from Five States

The Supreme Court has scheduled same-sex marriage cases from five states for consideration at its private conference on Monday, signaling the justices' willingness to tackle the national debate. The cases, which originated from Utah, Oklahoma, Virginia, Indiana, and Wisconsin, were placed on the list for the court's first conference of the 2014 term.

The inclusion of the Indiana and Wisconsin cases, which were decided by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 7th Circuit just last month, gives them equal footing with the other three cases, which were previously decided by the 10th and 4th Circuits. The court's decision could be to hear one or more cases, deny them all, or delay its decision for a while.

In all five states, federal district and appellate judges have agreed that state bans on same-sex marriage should be struck down as unconstitutional. However, those decisions are currently on hold pending the Supreme Court's review. The court's decision could have significant implications for the 31 states that still prohibit same-sex marriage, including those with cases pending before the Supreme Court.

The Supreme Court previously ruled in June 2013 that the federal government must recognize same-sex marriages legally performed in states that allow them. Since then, the list of states recognizing same-sex marriage has grown to 19, including the District of Columbia. The court also refused to overrule a California court's decision striking down that state's ban.

Title: Florida First Lady Casey DeSantis to Skip Women for Trump Event Due to Scheduled Execution

The Trump re-election campaign is hosting a "Women for Trump" event in Tampa, featuring notable Republican women, including Florida First Lady Casey DeSantis, Kellyanne Conway, and former Attorney General Pam Bondi. However, Casey DeSantis will not attend the event due to a scheduling conflict with a scheduled execution.

The event, titled "An Evening to Empower," is centered around the 99th anniversary of the ratification of the 19th Amendment, which granted women the right to vote. Conway is listed as the special guest, and Bondi and DeSantis were also scheduled to speak.

The execution of Gary Ray Bowles, a serial killer who targeted gay men, is the reason for DeSantis' absence. Alex Garcia, overseeing Trump re-election campaign efforts in Florida, acknowledged the execution as the main reason for the first lady's absence, stating that "everyone is locked down" when an execution is carried out.

Department of Corrections officials typically maintain constant contact with the governor's office during executions, informing the governor when an execution has been carried out. Helen Aguirre Ferré, a spokesperson for the governor, explained that, as the first lady is not an elected official, the executive office of the governor does not participate in any public events while an execution is carried out.

It is worth noting that Bondi faced criticism in 2013 for asking then-Gov. Rick Scott to move the date of an execution to accommodate a fundraiser for her re-election campaign. She later acknowledged that she should not have requested the date change.

Title: Republicans' Odyssey and Oddity: A Review of the Final 2015 Debate

The Republican presidential race has been marked by its volatility and unpredictability, with a significant portion of the original field either dropping out or struggling to stay relevant. According to a Fox News poll released on December 16, 2014, the top 74% of the current field is five times larger than its 15% share from a year ago.

The final debate of 2015 took place at The Venetian Las Vegas, with a smaller group of nine candidates compared to the previous debate at the Reagan Presidential Library. The debate, hosted by CNN/Salem Radio, was criticized for being too long, too slow-paced, and poorly managed.

Here are seven observations from the debate:

1. Donald Trump did not dominate the debate, despite attempts by some candidates to take him down. Trump's rivals failed to make a lasting impression on how they would defeat ISIS and protect the homeland.

2. The debate saw several candidates engaging in a "cage match," with Rand Paul taking shots at Trump, Marco Rubio, and Chris Christie. While the libertarians in the crowd enjoyed the back-and-forth, the candidates' approach came across as desperate.

3. The media's "dust-up" of the night did not materialize, as Trump and Ted Cruz avoided taking the bait. Cruz did have some brief exchanges with Rubio over Senate votes and Trump had a testy moment with Jeb Bush over demeanor and poll numbers.

4. The debate was an opportunity for the two sitting governors, Chris Christie and John Kasich, to showcase their leadership skills, but both struggled to make an impact. Christie's numbers were a problem, and Kasich's rhetorical style was criticized for being too focused on his Washington biography.

5. The debate had a "vibe" of a college student taking their final exam before a long break, with tempers short and candidates seeming tired of sharing the same oxygen.

6. The winners of the debate were Trump and Cruz, who played mostly error-free ball. The losers were those who missed the "Star Wars" premiere to watch a mostly uneventful debate.

The next GOP debate is scheduled for January 14, 2016, in North Charleston, South Carolina, hosted by the Fox Business Network.

Title: Stocks Reach New Highs as Trade Hopes and Earnings Drive Market Upward

Stocks in the United States closed at record highs on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all reaching new highs. The gains were driven by renewed trade hopes and strong earnings reports from companies such as McDonald's and Under Armour.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 114 points, or 0.42%, to book its first record close since July 23. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index finished in record territory for a second straight day. The S&P 500 gained 11.64 points, or 0.35%, to 3,363.73, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 44.13 points, or 0.46%, to 9,672.51.

The record-setting day came after the Chinese Foreign Ministry announced that President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping have remained in contact while negotiators craft the final language for the "phase one" of the trade agreement between the two economic powers.

Among individual stocks, McDonald's shares were lower after the company parted ways with CEO Steve Easterbrook over his consensual relationship with an employee. Easterbrook was instrumental in the company's turnaround, emphasizing a technological shift that included third-party delivery through apps and the installation of kiosks that let customers customize their orders.

Under Armour was sharply lower after confirming the Department of Justice and Securities and Exchange Commission are probing its accounting practices. The athletic-apparel maker reported better-than-expected third-quarter results on Monday morning but cut its sales outlook for the remainder of the year.

Ford gained after the United Auto Workers union approved the tentative labor deal that was reached last week.

Earnings reports continued to exceed Wall Street estimates, with over 70% of S&P 500 companies reporting, about 76% having topped earnings-per-share estimates, and 59% having beat on revenue, according to Refinitiv.

The Warren Buffett-led Berkshire Hathaway reported third-quarter profit rose 14% versus a year ago to $7.86 billion as its cash pile swelled to a record $128.1 billion.

Ferrari also beat on both the top and bottom lines, sending shares higher.

Commodities gained, with West Texas Intermediate crude oil up 0.57% at $56.52 a barrel and gold ending little changed near $1,510 an ounce.

Treasurys were lower as selling ran the yield on the 10-year note up 5.8 basis points to 1.786%.

Global stock markets followed Wall Street higher on Monday after the unexpectedly strong U.S. jobs data helped to soothe investor worries. On Friday, the Labor Department said American employers added 128,000 jobs in October, better than the 89,000 forecast.

In Europe, Germany's DAX all gained 1.35% to pace the advance. In Asia, the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.6% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng advanced 1.7%. Japan's markets were closed for a holiday.

Title: Pope Francis Weighs in on Free Speech and Religious Offense

Pope Francis has sparked controversy with recent comments on the limits of free speech, specifically in regards to religious beliefs. During a press conference on a flight to the Philippines, the Pope gestured a pretend punch to demonstrate his stance on not tolerating insults against one's faith. The Vatican later clarified that his words were spoken colloquially and consistent with his free-spirited speech.

The Pope's comments were in response to the massacre of journalists at Charlie Hebdo magazine by Islamist militants in Paris. While he did not explicitly state that the slain cartoonists brought the attack upon themselves due to their satirical criticism of Islam, his words raised concerns about the potential for misinterpretation.

The Pope's stance on free speech and religious offense is not unique, as Bill Donahue, president of the Catholic League, has also spoken out against criticism of religion. However, some critics argue that the Pope's words may be seen as advocating for the regulation or outlawing of blasphemy.

In contrast, Jim Wallis, president of Sojourners, a progressive evangelical community and publication, suggests that people of faith should respond to the Paris attacks by embracing the principles of loving one's enemies and defending free speech, even for those who offend. The Supreme Court outlawed blasphemy laws in 1952, and many Americans believe that while offensive speech is not pleasant, it should not be regulated.

Ultimately, the Pope's comments highlight the ongoing debate about the balance between free speech and religious tolerance. While his words may have been intended as a colloquial expression of his views, they have sparked a wider discussion about the limits of free expression and the importance of respecting religious beliefs.

Title: Networks' Use of Chyrons to Fact-Check Politicians Raises Questions

Article: In recent months, CNN and MSNBC have been inserting analysis into their chyrons, or graphics at the bottom of the screen, to identify and fact-check claims made by politicians during their news reporting. This practice started in June when Donald Trump denied having said Japan should have nuclear weapons, and CNN inserted the snarky line "TRUMP: I NEVER SAID JAPAN SHOULD HAVE NUKES (HE DID)".

Since then, MSNBC has followed suit, using parentheses to correct Trump's claims, such as when he said he had seen video of $400 million being sent to Iran by the Obama administration. However, some critics have noted that this practice seems to have a double standard, as similar claims made by Hillary Clinton have not received the same level of fact-checking.

For example, Clinton recently told Chris Wallace that FBI Director James Comey had called her answers about her private email use as secretary of state "truthful", which is not accurate. Additionally, she claimed GOP vice presidential nominee Mike Pence had "slashed" education spending as governor of Indiana, which is also false. Despite these inaccuracies, CNN and MSNBC did not deploy their parentheses to correct these statements.

Outlets like Mediaite and The Daily Caller have raised questions about the double standard, suggesting that the chyrons are being used to target Trump and his supporters while giving Clinton a pass. While fact-checking may be a legitimate use of the chyrons, the uneven application of this practice has sparked concerns about bias and fairness in the media.

Title: Senate Democrats Rally Support for Iran Nuclear Deal, Obama Secures Major Foreign Policy Victory

Article:

The Senate Democrats have secured the necessary 34 votes to keep the Iran nuclear deal alive in Congress, handing President Barack Obama a significant foreign policy victory. The agreement, signed by Iran, the U.S., and five other world powers, aims to dismantle Iran's nuclear program in exchange for billions of dollars in relief from sanctions.

The deal has been opposed by Republicans, who call it a "dangerous giveaway to Iran," and the Israeli government, which believes concessions made to Iran could empower the country, which has sworn to destroy Israel. However, despite a multimillion-dollar lobbying campaign funded by the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC), critics have failed to turn the tide against the agreement.

Only two Democratic senators, Chuck Schumer of New York and Robert Menendez of New Jersey, have come out against the deal, while several undeclared Democratic senators have broken in favor of the agreement in recent weeks. The deal's supporters, including Senators Bob Casey of Pennsylvania and Chris Coons of Delaware, argue that it is the best way to curb Iran's nuclear ambitions.

Secretary of State John Kerry has sent a letter to all members of Congress outlining U.S. security commitments to Israel and Gulf Arab states in light of the nuclear deal. Kerry has also delivered a major policy speech in Philadelphia, emphasizing how the agreement makes the U.S. and its allies safer and how it is being mischaracterized by some opponents.

Kerry stated in a nationally broadcast interview that the absence of an agreement could lead to a nuclear arms race in the region, and that the deal will keep other nations from chasing a weapon on their own. He also emphasized that if the U.S. rejects the deal, it would confirm the fears of Iran's leaders that they cannot deal with the West or trust it.

The agreement is set to be voted on later this month, and if the resolution disapproving the deal passes, Obama has vowed to veto it. It would take 34 votes to uphold his veto, and Democrats now have those votes in hand.

Title: House Homeland Security Committee Requests Information on Extremist Involvement in George Floyd Protests

The House Homeland Security Committee has sent a letter to FBI Director Christopher Wray and Acting Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf, requesting more information about alleged extremist involvement in protests over the death of George Floyd. The letter, dated Tuesday, was signed by Democratic committee members and expressed concerns about the "Constitutional implications" of officials' statements linking left-wing and right-wing extremists to the violence at Floyd protests.

The committee is seeking documents from January 1 to the present, including information on intelligence gathered on ongoing protests, designations of groups as domestic terrorist organizations, deployment of Homeland Security employees at demonstrations, and surveillance of protesters. The deadline for the documents is June 19, and the committee will receive a briefing from the Department of Homeland Security and the FBI by June 12.

The letter follows reports of right-wing and left-wing anti-government groups being involved in Floyd protests in Minnesota and across the country. President Trump announced on Monday that the U.S. plans to designate anti-fascist activists, known as antifa, as a terrorist organization, although federal authorities are unable to label domestic groups as such. Attorney General William Barr also called out the decentralized group on Sunday, stating that the violence instigated and carried out by Antifa and similar groups in connection with the rioting is domestic terrorism and will be treated accordingly.

Title: Hope Hicks Returns to the White House as Senior Adviser

Hope Hicks, the former top White House aide and confidante to President Trump, is returning to the White House roughly two years after she left. Hicks will be working closely with Trump's son-in-law and senior adviser Jared Kushner and political director Brian Jack, and will not be part of the communications department.

Hicks, 31, served as a top communications aide before leaving the White House in 2018 to take a position at the Fox Corporation in California. Her return is set to begin in early March, although the exact timeline is still unclear.

Kushner praised Hicks, stating, "There is no one more devoted to implementing President Trump's agenda than Hope Hicks. We are excited to have her back on the team." White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham added that Hicks is "one of the most talented and savvy individuals I have come across. She has always impressed me with her quiet confidence, loyalty, and expertise, and I am beyond thrilled to welcome Hope back to the White House."

Hicks' return comes after the conclusion of two major investigations into the president: the Russia investigation and the impeachment saga. Hicks had virtually no experience in politics before joining the Trump campaign in its early days, but became one of the president's closest advisers. Her tenure at the White House was marked by controversy, including the resignation of then-White House staff secretary Rob Porter, who was accused of abuse by his two ex-wives. Hicks admitted during congressional testimony that she told "white lies" to defend the president.

According to a source close to Hicks, she is returning to the White House out of a sense of duty and purpose. While she was enjoying her life outside the White House, she is returning partly due to a sense of duty to this president and this administration. The former model had been considering a return over the past few months.

**PG&E to Plead Guilty to 84 Counts of Involuntary Manslaughter in Connection with 2018 Camp Fire**

Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E) has announced it will plead guilty to 84 counts of involuntary manslaughter in connection with the 2018 Camp Fire in Northern California. The fire, which occurred on November 8, 2018, killed 84 people and destroyed three towns. The plea agreement, reached with the Butte County District Attorney's office, marks the second time this decade that the company's negligence has led to criminal charges.

Under the agreement, PG&E will pay a $4 million fine, the maximum allowed, and will help pay for efforts to restore access to water for residents affected by the loss of a canal destroyed by the fire. The company will not face any prison time.

The Camp Fire was caused by PG&E's fraying electrical grid, which ignited and spread quickly due to strong winds. The fire forced thousands of people to flee their homes, with many describing caravans of vehicles engulfed by the flames.

The plea agreement comes as PG&E is still recovering from the financial impact of the fire, which led to the company filing for bankruptcy in early 2019. The company has since settled claims for $25.5 billion, including a $13.5 billion settlement for the 2017 and 2018 fires.

PG&E's CEO, Bill Johnson, stated that the company is "working to create a better future for all concerned" and that the lessons learned from the Camp Fire will drive the company's efforts to improve the safety and reliability of its power lines. The company plans to invest $40 billion in upgrades over the next few years.

The California Public Utilities Commission still needs to approve PG&E's bankruptcy plan, which is expected within the next few weeks.

Title: All 17 Members of President's Committee on the Arts and Humanities Resign Over Trump's Charlottesville Remarks

The President's Committee on the Arts and Humanities (PCAH) has seen all 17 of its members resign in response to President Donald Trump's controversial remarks on the white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia. The move follows Trump's disbanding of the American Manufacturing Council and the Strategy and Policy Forum after several business leaders resigned in protest over his comments.

In a letter of resignation tweeted by committee member Kal Penn, the committee condemned Trump's support of hate groups and terrorists who killed and injured fellow Americans in Charlottesville. The letter also contained an acrostic that spelled out the word "RESIST," a term associated with protest against the Trump administration.

The White House issued a statement claiming that the president had intended to disband the council anyway, echoing Trump's previous claim that he was disbanding the Strategy and Policy Forum after all its members had made the decision to disband it on their own. This prompted an amused response from Penn.

The PCAH is a federal agency headed by Melania Trump as honorary chair, responsible for education and cultural ambassadorship for the arts. Unlike other advisory councils Trump has recently disbanded, the PCAH is not connected to the National Endowment for the Arts and Humanities.

In its resignation letter, the committee condemned the administration's refusal to quickly and unequivocally condemn the cancer of hatred and its connection to the important work of the arts in creating empathy and love. The committee also noted the connection between the arts and humanities in supporting a vibrant free press and the administration's attacks on civil liberties.

The letter was signed by all 17 members of the committee, including author Jhumpa Lahiri and writer-director George C. Wolfe. The resignation makes the PCAH the first White House agency to officially dissolve under President Trump.

Title: Trump Administration Considers Expanding Travel Ban, Adding New Restrictions

The Trump administration is preparing to update its six-nation travel ban executive order, with officials indicating that additional countries may be added to the list. However, instead of imposing a 90-day pause on admissions, the new restrictions are likely to involve enhanced screening measures for travelers from these countries.

The original travel ban, which was implemented in January, is set to expire on Sunday. Homeland Security Secretary Elaine Duke has submitted recommendations to President Trump for countries that should still face travel restrictions or enhanced screening. While officials declined to disclose which countries are being considered, they noted that some have been added to the list due to their lack of cooperation.

The administration has gone through a months-long review of other countries' information-sharing with the U.S., with some deemed "inadequate" and given a 50-day notice to comply. Those that failed to meet the standards will face new restrictions. The new standards, recommended by Duke, are conditions-based rather than time-based.

The move has been met with criticism from political opponents, who argue that the policy is driven by religious animus and is a continuation of Trump's campaign promise to institute a Muslim ban. The original travel ban was implemented in response to concerns over terrorism and national security, with the administration citing the need for "extreme vetting" of travelers from certain countries.

The Supreme Court has delivered a mixed verdict on the current ban, ruling that Trump has important national security powers but also finding that some individuals have rights that must be respected. The administration has been consulting with the Justice Department throughout the process, and officials are unsure how the updates will affect the court case.

Title: Colorado Baker Sues State Over Alleged Violation of Constitutional Rights

A Colorado baker, Jack Phillips, who won a narrow Supreme Court victory over his refusal to make a wedding cake for a gay couple, has filed a lawsuit against the state of Colorado, alleging that the state's Civil Rights Commission is violating his constitutional rights. The lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court in Denver, claims that the commission is targeting Phillips' Christian beliefs and violating his rights to free speech, freedom of religion, equal protection, and due process.

Phillips, the owner of Masterpiece Cakeshop in Lakewood, is seeking permanent injunctions against the state from taking any enforcement action against him. The lawsuit also names Governor John Hickenlooper and Attorney General Cynthia Coffman as defendants.

The lawsuit stems from a complaint filed by Denver attorney Autumn Scardina with the civil rights commission in 2017, alleging that Phillips refused to bake a cake that "celebrates my transition from male to female." The commission's director, Aubrey Elenis, ruled in June that Phillips discriminated against Scardina, finding that the refusal to provide service was based on her transgender status.

Phillips is seeking $100,000 in punitive damages against Elenis for her "unconstitutional actions." The lawsuit also seeks to stop the state from taking any further action against him.

The director of the state's Civil Rights Division, Aubrey Elenis, declined to comment on the lawsuit. The Alliance Defending Freedom, the conservative Christian group representing Phillips, has been criticized by the LGBTQ community for launching similar lawsuits across the country that target nondiscrimination laws and civil rights agencies.

The lawsuit is the latest development in a long-standing dispute between Phillips and the state of Colorado. In June, the Supreme Court ruled that the Colorado Civil Rights Commission was hostile toward Phillips' Christian beliefs when it cited him for refusing to bake a wedding cake for a same-sex couple in 2012. However, the court did not rule on whether Phillips violated Colorado's public accommodation statute.

Title: Study Finds Mainstream Economic News Coverage Biased in Favor of Democratic Presidents

A recent study published in the journal American Politics Research has found that mainstream economic news coverage tends to be biased in favor of Democratic presidents. The study, conducted by Eric Merkley, a Ph.D. candidate at the University of British Columbia, analyzed the tone of 400,000 news articles related to unemployment and inflation published between 1985 and 2013 by 23 high-circulating American newspapers and the Associated Press.

Merkley used automated content analysis software to evaluate the tone of the articles, excluding editorials and opinion pieces. The study found that the tone of economic news coverage was more positive during Democratic presidencies, even after controlling for economic performance. The findings suggest that journalists may subtly frame news content in ways that serve their partisan interests, although the study does not provide evidence of deliberate bias.

The study's results are consistent with confirmation bias, where journalists are more charitable to Democratic presidents during times of economic growth and more critical during times of economic downturn. Merkley noted that the findings do not necessarily imply that journalists are intentionally trying to harm Republican presidents, but rather that their cognitive biases and social identities may influence their reporting.

The study's limitations include the fact that it only examined economic news coverage and did not account for other types of news or issues. Merkley acknowledged that patterns of bias may vary across different issue types and that more research is needed to fully understand the scope of media bias.

The study's findings have implications for the health of democracy, as trust in the mainstream media has been declining among Republican supporters. Merkley emphasized the importance of addressing these concerns and ensuring that the media remains a trusted source of information for the public.

**Investigation Underway in Fatal Shooting of Ahmaud Arbery**

A grand jury will decide whether criminal charges are warranted in the death of Ahmaud Arbery, a 25-year-old black man who was shot and killed in February in a neighborhood outside Brunswick, Georgia. Arbery's family and their attorneys claim he was jogging when he was killed, while the father and son who chased him, Gregory and Travis McMichael, told police they believed he was a burglary suspect.

The incident occurred on February 23 in the Satilla Shores neighborhood, where Arbery lived just a short distance away. The Glynn County Police Department received a 911 call from Gregory McMichael, who claimed he and his son saw Arbery running and believed he was a burglary suspect. The McMichaels armed themselves with guns and got into a truck to pursue Arbery, who was shot and killed after being chased.

The Georgia Bureau of Investigation (GBI) is leading the investigation, with District Attorney Tom Durden recusing himself due to his previous professional relationship with Gregory McMichael. The GBI has promised to "bring to bear every resource and experience" to resolve the case.

A video of the incident has been posted online, showing Arbery being chased by the McMichaels and being shot. The video has sparked widespread outrage and calls for justice, with many calling the killing a "murder" and a "lynching." The Georgia NAACP and other organizations have planned protests and demonstrations to demand justice for Arbery.

The case has also drawn attention from politicians, with Georgia Governor Brian Kemp tweeting that "Georgians deserve answers" and Attorney General Chris Carr expressing concern about the events surrounding the shooting. Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden called the killing "cold-blooded," while former Georgia gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams called for a "full investigation, appropriate charges, and an unbiased prosecution."

Title: Senator Jeff Flake Predicts Republican Challenge to President Trump in 2020 Election

Article:

Senator Jeff Flake, a Republican from Arizona, has expressed his doubts about President Trump's chances of winning the 2020 presidential election. In an interview, Flake stated that he believes someone from the Republican Party will challenge Trump, and he is encouraging it. Flake also predicted that an independent candidate may emerge, particularly if the Democratic Party puts up a candidate from the far left.

Flake's comments come as President Trump has announced his intention to run for re-election in 2020. Trump has highlighted his accomplishments in his first year in office, including tax reform and the appointment of a record number of judges, including a new conservative on the Supreme Court.

Flake, who has been a vocal critic of Trump, has had a tumultuous relationship with the president. In his book "Conscience of a Conservative," Flake criticized Trump for leading Republicans to compromise their principles. Trump responded by calling Flake "weak" on borders during a rally in Arizona.

Flake also compared Trump's rhetoric to that of Joseph Stalin's, stating that he does not think it is appropriate to use a phrase that has been rejected as too loaded by a Soviet dictator. When Flake announced his retirement from the Senate, he appeared to make a similar comparison.

It remains to be seen whether Flake will ultimately decide to challenge Trump in the 2020 election. However, his comments suggest that he is not optimistic about the president's chances of winning re-election.

Title: False Claims Act's Overreach in Healthcare: A Threat to Patient Care and Access

The False Claims Act (FCA), a 1863 statute aimed at exposing and punishing fraud in government contracting, has evolved into a tool used to extract large sums from healthcare providers, rather than promoting transparency and accountability. According to a new Independence Institute working paper, attorneys Mark W. Pearlstein and Laura McLane argue that the FCA's aggressive application in healthcare cases goes beyond the original intent of the law.

The FCA authorizes private individuals to sue anyone they believe is defrauding the federal government, with awards ranging from $11,000 to $22,000 per fraud detected. The statute provides for treble damages, and the spoils are divided among the person alleging the fraud, their attorneys, and the federal government. This has led to a surge in lawsuits, with over 4,700 FCA actions filed between 2009 and June 2016.

The federal government must investigate each FCA case, with the initial investigation done under seal. Defendants may be investigated for years without knowing about it until their business documents are subpoenaed. The individual alleging fraud can proceed with a case even if the government decides against it.

The FCA has been used to sue a wide range of healthcare providers, including nursing homes, hospitals, doctors, insurers, clinical laboratories, pharmaceutical manufacturers, software providers, managed care organizations, and universities funded by federal grants. Plaintiffs often allege too little care, too much care, billing errors, record-keeping violations, and differences in opinion about medical necessity.

The Department of Health and Human Services certifies provider performance using various methods and has numerous administrative enforcement tools to influence the behavior of contractors in substantial but not complete compliance with its regulations. However, the FCA is often used as a blunt instrument to extract large sums from healthcare providers, rather than working with them to improve their performance.

A recent example is the $237 million FCA verdict in United States ex rel. Drakeford v. Tuomey, where a business entity related to Tuomey Regional Medical Center was sued for allegedly violating the Stark Law by having part-time employment agreements with surgeons and gastroenterologists. The case highlights the complexity and potential consequences of the FCA, with the government requiring a $72.4 million settlement and the sale of the hospital to another health system.

A judge in the Tuomey case wrote that the hospital was caught in an "impenetrably complex set of laws and regulations that will result in a likely death sentence for a community hospital in an already medically underserved area." The judge concluded that "even for well-intentioned healthcare providers, the Stark Law has become a booby trap rigged with strict liability and potentially ruinous exposure – especially when coupled with the False Claims Act."

Pearlstein and McLane argue that the aggressive use of the FCA in healthcare cases goes beyond the traditional understanding of fraud and will continue to harm patients, raise costs, and impair access to care unless Congress revises the statute.

Title: Obama Embarks on West Coast Fundraising Tour to Bolster Democratic Party

Article:

President Barack Obama has embarked on a three-day fundraising tour to bolster the Democratic Party's coffers for the 2014 election cycle. The tour is a critical obligation for the president, who is no longer focused on building his own war chest after his re-election. According to Jim Manley, a former aide to Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and a Democratic strategist, "It's kind of better late than never. There are a whole bunch of Democrats on the Hill who wish he had done more in years past."

The fundraising tour aims to provide the Democratic Party with the necessary funds to operate in what is expected to be a tough election cycle, particularly in the Senate. The Affordable Care Act's flawed rollout and the controversy surrounding whether Obama misled the public about keeping their insurance have made Democrats anxious about the law's potential failure.

Obama's job approval and favorability ratings have taken a hit, according to a recent poll. This could have a trickle-down effect on Democratic candidates running for re-election. Bill Galston, a former policy adviser to President Bill Clinton and chair of the Brookings Institute's Governance Studies program, noted that "History suggests that a president's popularity has an influence on the fortunes of his party in off-year elections. If the president is way down in the public's esteem, that's going to create a big headwind for Democrats running for re-election."

However, Obama is not the first president to face criticism from within his own party. Poll numbers are also notoriously fleeting, and weeks ago, the government shutdown seemed to have left Republicans down for the count, but today the GOP is invigorated by the health care law's early troubles.

Despite the challenges, Obama's fundraising tour is seen as a necessary step to help the Democratic Party. Joel Benenson, a top Democratic pollster, noted that "We have work to do. We've got to keep our focus on restoring the nation's economic health. That's got to be the number one priority."

However, Obama is also facing criticism from Democratic activists who are frustrated with the lack of progress on other issues, such as immigration reform. The timing of the fundraising tour could not have been worse, according to Manley, who noted that "I assume they're hearing from the liberal base about just about every issue under the sun right now."

Title: Governors Push Back Against Trump's Support of Protesters Demanding Return to Work

Governors J.B. Pritzker of Illinois and Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan have spoken out against President Donald Trump's support of protesters in their states demanding the right to return to work and reopen businesses. The governors claim that Trump's stance is spreading fear and putting the public at risk.

Pritzker, in an interview with the Washington Post, stated that Trump's tweets calling for protesters to "LIBERATE" are a "political maneuver in the middle of a national emergency" that could lead to violence. He also expressed concern that people gathering in large crowds will be giving each other coronavirus and some may die as a result of the president's rhetoric.

Whitmer, in an interview with the Associated Press, called Trump's call to suspend immigration during the coronavirus crisis a part of his "inconsistent messages" designed to spread fear and put the public in greater danger. She emphasized that the focus should be on making swabs for coronavirus testing, rather than introducing new concerns.

Whitmer denied that her comments against Trump's actions are part of an audition to become presumptive Democrat nominee Joe Biden's running mate, stating that she is focused on managing the coronavirus crisis in her state. However, her stringent rules, including bans on certain purchases and travel restrictions, have led to protests at the state capital, with some individuals demanding the right to return to work as unemployment rates soar. Over 1 million people in Michigan are currently unemployed due to closures under the governor's office or job losses since the outbreak began.

Title: Trump Congratulates Pakistani Prime Minister, Expresses Willingness to Play Role in Addressing Outstanding Issues

In a phone call on Wednesday, President-elect Donald Trump congratulated Pakistani Prime Minister Muhammad Nawaz Sharif on his election victory and expressed his willingness to play a role in addressing outstanding issues between the two countries. According to a readout provided by the Pakistani government, Trump praised Sharif as a "terrific guy" who is doing "amazing work" and invited him to visit the United States.

During the call, Trump congratulated Sharif on his election victory and invited him to visit Pakistan, stating that he would "love to come to a fantastic country, fantastic place of fantastic people." Sharif, in turn, congratulated Trump on his election victory and invited him to visit Pakistan.

The readout of the call, provided by the Pakistani government, also included Trump's statement that he is "ready and willing to play any role that you want me to play to address and find solutions to the outstanding problems." Trump also expressed his admiration for the Pakistani people, stating that they are "one of the most intelligent people" and that "all Pakistanis I have known are exceptional people."

The call was seen as a significant development in the diplomatic strategy of the Trump administration, as it marks one of the first high-level interactions between the new administration and a key player in the region.

Title: Federal Judiciary Crafts New Standard of Judicial Review, Challenging Existing Precedent and National Security

The federal judiciary is developing a new standard of judicial review, dubbed "Trumplaw," which prioritizes defeating Donald Trump over national security and existing precedent. The latest victim of this new jurisprudence is the Trump administration's temporary halt on immigration from six majority-Muslim countries, upheld by the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals.

The court's ruling centered on Trump's campaign statements, which allegedly caused harm to a Muslim resident, granting him standing to challenge the executive order. The court concluded that the harm to the plaintiff's feelings and his wife's possibly delayed entry into the United States outweighed the government's asserted national-security interest in pausing immigration from hostile and war-torn countries.

This new standard of judicial review is challenging to square with existing precedent, as it involves yanking laws out of context, misinterpreting them, and rewriting them to achieve the desired outcome. The Fourth Circuit's reading of the Supreme Court case Kleindienst v. Mandel is a prime example. In Mandel, the court ruled that the government's denial of a non-immigrant visa to a Belgian Marxist journalist was lawful, citing a legitimate and bona fide reason. However, the Fourth Circuit interpreted Mandel to argue that the court can look beyond the face of the document to determine "good faith."

The dissenting opinion, written by Judge Paul Niemeyer, is scathing and correct, stating that the majority's approach would alter the outcome of other key Supreme Court cases and grant courts the power to conduct an extratextual search for evidence of bad faith.

The implications of Trumplaw are far-reaching, as it establishes the principle that a court can invalidate a government action based on a politician's campaign statements, even if those statements are later retracted or changed. This sets a dangerous precedent, as it gives judges the authority to second-guess political decisions and undermine national security.

The timing of this ruling is particularly concerning, as it comes in the aftermath of the Manchester bombing, which highlights the very real dangers of lawless regions gripped by jihad. The Fourth Circuit's decision to pause the travel ban, citing concerns over Trump's campaign statements, risks our national security and undermines the government's ability to properly vet and screen for ISIS sympathizers.

Title: Texas Avoids Major Power Outages Thanks to Wind Power Amid Record-Breaking Demand

The recent Polar Vortex has pushed Texas to a new winter record for power usage, with demand remaining high on Tuesday. However, the state was able to avoid major power outages thanks in part to increased output from West Texas wind farms. This is not the first time wind power has helped Texas avoid power outages during extreme weather conditions. In 2011, high wind outputs during peak demand helped the state's grid weather temperatures above 100 degrees Fahrenheit.

Wind energy is also playing a crucial role in helping other states weather the Polar Vortex. According to the American Wind Energy Association (AWEA), when temperatures first began dropping in the Upper Midwest, wind generated enough energy to power 6 million average homes. The Mid-Atlantic region also saw high wind energy output, which helped bolster the grid after some power plants failed unexpectedly due to the weather.

The recent extreme weather events have put the vulnerability of the U.S. energy grid in focus. On Tuesday, electricity demand in parts of the Southeast U.S. was the second-highest it's been in winter since the 1920s, according to the Tennessee Valley Authority. Parts of Tennessee lost power during the night, and parts of South Carolina instituted rolling blackouts to manage the electricity demand. Earlier this week, 40,000 people in Indiana lost power, and people across the country were urged to conserve power so that the grid could deal with the spike in demand.

Severe weather is the number one cause of power outages in the U.S., meaning that as extreme events become more common, the U.S. power grid will be put more and more at risk. Between 2003 and 2012, extreme weather caused more than 675 power outages and cost the U.S. $18 billion to $33 billion per year, according to the President's Council of Economic Advisers and the Department of Energy. According to a report released in August, transmission line construction in the U.S. has slowed from 10,000 miles built per year in the late 1960s to just 1,000 miles per year in the mid-2000s – a slowdown that means about 70 percent of U.S. transmission lines and power transformers are over 25 years old.

Massoud Amin, an electrical engineering professor at the University of Minnesota, estimates that updating the country to Smart Grid technology would cost $21 billion per year for the next two decades, but would ultimately result in savings of between $79 and $94 billion per year. "As a nation, we must take action to improve our electric grid if we want to meet the power needs of a pervasively digital society," Amin wrote in Forbes in 2012. "Americans should not accept or learn to cope with increasing blackouts."

Title: Conservative Groups Launch Ad Campaign, Town Halls to Defund Obamacare

Conservative groups are intensifying their efforts to defund President Barack Obama's healthcare law, also known as the Affordable Care Act (ACA), by launching online ads and a series of town halls starting this week. Heritage Action for America, a leading political advocacy group, announced it will spend over half a million dollars to run online ads in the districts of 100 House Republican lawmakers who have not joined the drive to try and defund the healthcare law.

The ads, which will target lawmakers who have not signed up to support the defunding effort, urge the American people to "seize the moment" and demand Congress defund the entire law. Heritage Action CEO Michael A. Needham stated, "The American people may have been locked out of the legislative process that gave us Obamacare, but they will be the force behind stopping this unworkable, unaffordable law."

Two other conservative groups, ForAmerica and Tea Party Patriots, also launched an online ad campaign targeting GOP senators and House Speaker John Boehner in an effort to persuade them to defund ObamaCare. Some conservative lawmakers, including Senators Ted Cruz of Texas, Marco Rubio of Florida, and Mike Lee of Utah, are using upcoming budget battles as leverage, vowing to oppose any measure that provides funding for the federal government that includes funding for the healthcare law.

The measure funding the federal government expires on September 30, setting up another Capitol Hill budget battle between congressional Republicans and the White House. So far, only slightly more than a dozen fellow Republican senators have signed up to support the cause, leaving it up to outside conservative groups to rally the base.

The Heritage Action announcement comes on the same day the group is launching a nine-stop "Defund Obamacare Tour," which will kick off Monday in Fayetteville, Arkansas, and will feature former Sen. Jim DeMint, the Heritage Foundation president, and Rafael Cruz, the father of Sen. Cruz. The senator from Texas will join DeMint and his father at the second town hall, Tuesday in Dallas.

Two progressive groups, Americans United for Change and Protect Your Care, plan to hold counter protests outside the town halls. "Pro Health Reform advocates are going to meet the repealers and defunders on the battlefield and confront them directly and aggressively," says Brad Woodhouse, president of Americans United for Change. "A strong majority of the American people want the Affordable Care Act implemented and fixed if necessary – they do not want it repealed – which is the only plan for health care Republicans have."

Americans appear divided on whether they want the law, which passed in 2010 along party lines when the Democrats controlled both houses of Congress. In one of the most recent surveys on the law, conducted last month for CBS News, nearly four in ten called for the entire law to be repealed, with 18% saying that just the measure's controversial individual mandate should be repealed. Thirty-six percent of those questioned said that the law should be kept as is, or expanded.

Title: Americans Overwhelmingly Support Universal Background Checks, Despite Opposition from Gun Manufacturers

A recent poll has revealed that 91% of Americans support universal background checks for gun purchases, with an overwhelming 88% of households with guns also in favor of the policy. This widespread support is in stark contrast to the opposition from gun manufacturers and the National Rifle Association (NRA), who argue that such checks would impose a "logistical nightmare" on gun transactions.

According to the poll, only 8% of Americans and 11% of households with guns oppose universal background checks. However, the NRA and gun manufacturers have managed to convince some Americans that these checks would lead to gun confiscation, with 48% of respondents believing that the government would use the information gathered during background checks to confiscate legally owned guns.

The reality is that universal background checks would impose a minor burden on gun transactions, but would also limit the size of the market and reduce profits for gun manufacturers. The checks would ensure that criminals and the mentally ill are not able to purchase guns, which would reduce crime and subsequently reduce the public's demand for guns for self-protection.

Gun owners may have concerns about universal background checks, but the poll suggests that these concerns are largely unfounded. The same poll found that only 8% of Americans and 11% of households with guns oppose universal background checks, indicating that the majority of gun owners do not see the checks as a significant inconvenience.

The opposition to universal background checks is largely driven by the gun manufacturers and the NRA, who are motivated by a desire to maintain their profits and avoid any regulation that could limit their sales. The manufacturers are concerned that background checks would reduce their profits by limiting the size of the market and reducing the number of guns sold to criminals and the mentally ill.

In conclusion, the overwhelming majority of Americans support universal background checks, and the opposition to these checks is largely driven by the gun manufacturers and the NRA. While some gun owners may have concerns about the checks, the reality is that they would impose a minor burden on gun transactions and would reduce crime and the public's demand for guns for self-protection.

Title: President Trump Unveils New Cuba Policy, Emphasizing Empowerment of Cuban People

Article:

On Friday, Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) joined President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence in Miami, Florida, to unveil the White House's new Cuba policy. The policy aims to empower the Cuban people, who continue to struggle under the dictatorial leadership of Raul Castro.

According to Rubio, President Trump has been focused on finding solutions to address the situation in Cuba since the election. Trump expressed his appreciation for the Cuban-American community, praising their resilience and cultural achievements. He noted that the community's success is a testament to what a free Cuba can be.

The President emphasized that his administration will expose the crimes of the Castro regime, listing several demands he will make of the dictator. These demands include not lifting sanctions until all political prisoners are freed, all parties are legalized, and free elections are scheduled. The administration will also restrict U.S. dollars going to the Cuban military, enforce the ban on tourism and embargo, and demand that investments flow directly to the people to open private businesses.

Additionally, Trump demanded that Castro stop harboring fugitives and criminals, such as Joanne Chesimard, who escaped from prison in 1979 and gained political asylum in 1984.

The President concluded his remarks by signing the new contract, stating that America will expose the crimes of the Castro regime and stand with the Cuban people in their struggle for freedom.

Title: World Leaders' Guide to Dealing with Trump: Flattery and Conciseness Key

Article: Saudi Arabia's King Salman has mastered the art of diplomacy when it comes to dealing with US President Donald Trump. According to Politico, King Salman greeted Trump at the airport with a ceremony that included a military flyover, cannons, and a cardamom coffee service, as well as the presentation of a gold medal. This level of adulation is a departure from the treatment extended to former President Barack Obama during his visit in 2009.

The New York Times has compiled a checklist of dos and don'ts for world leaders when meeting with Trump. The key takeaways are to keep it short and sweet, with no lengthy monologues, and to lavish praise on the president. Compliments on his Electoral College victory and comparisons to his predecessor, Barack Obama, are also seen as effective. Avoiding discussions of campaign rhetoric and focusing on tangible deals are also recommended.

Several world leaders have taken note of these guidelines. During her visit in January, British Prime Minister Theresa May called Trump's election win "stunning." Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu name-dropped Trump's book "The Art of the Deal," while Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe complimented his golf swing.

In contrast, Trump's diplomatic efforts on his first day in Saudi Arabia were not as overt. Ivanka and Melania Trump, who accompanied the president on his trip, opted not to wear headscarves, despite Trump's own knowledge of Middle Eastern customs. However, Trump did thank King Salman for the medal by dipping what appeared to be a tiny curtsey.

Title: ISIS Attacks Kirkuk in Northern Iraq, Peshmerga Forces Respond

The Islamic State (ISIS) militants launched an attack on Kirkuk, a city in northern Iraq, on Friday, reportedly attempting to capture the key oil-rich city or divert Kurdish troops fighting to capture the extremist group's stronghold of Mosul. The attack began with heavily armed militants storming an abandoned hotel in central Kirkuk, which had been used as the local police headquarters. Peshmerga and Kurdish anti-terror units later regained control of the hotel, killing three ISIS militants and foiling an attempt by two suicide bombers to repel the Kurdish forces.

Additionally, ISIS militants took control of the Maktab Khalid area, about 12 miles southwest of Kirkuk, after heavy clashes with the Peshmerga. Brig. Gen. Shirko Fateh, the highest-ranking operational commander of the Peshmerga brigade in Kirkuk, was among those killed.

The U.S. military announced that an ISIS chemical weapons expert, Abu Malik, was killed in a coalition strike last week. Malik had previously worked in Saddam Hussein's chemical weapons program and joined al-Qaeda in 2005. The U.S. military stated that his death will temporarily degrade and disrupt the terrorist network and diminish ISIS's ability to produce and use chemical weapons.

Kirkuk is a strategically important city in the ongoing fight against ISIS, with the Peshmerga, Iraqi government troops, and an international coalition conducting airstrikes against the terrorist group. The city is located on top of some of Iraq's largest oil reserves, which are a significant source of revenue for ISIS. The Kurds and the central Iraqi government have long disputed control of the reserves, with each side seeking to maintain control.

The Peshmerga forces took control of the Kirkuk area in June after the Iraqi army retreated in the face of ISIS advances. Since then, the Peshmerga have played a crucial role in defending the city against ISIS. In December, ISIS claimed responsibility for a suicide car bomb attack in Kirkuk that killed at least 17 people and injured over 20.

The attack on Kirkuk may be part of ISIS's effort to divert attention from its ongoing fight against the Peshmerga around Mosul, Iraq's second-largest city. The city has been held by ISIS since June, and the extremist group has invested heavily in governing it. The Peshmerga have made significant progress against ISIS north and west of Mosul over the past two months, taking back over 3,000 square kilometers of territory and choking off ISIS's main supply routes.

Despite the setbacks, ISIS remains a significant threat in much of Iraq and neighboring Syria, with its goal of establishing a vast caliphate under its strict version of Sharia law. The group has been blamed for numerous atrocities, including mass killings, kidnappings, and the forced enslavement of women and girls.

Title: The Complexity of Erasing the Past: A Look at Progressive Heroes and Their Complicated Legacy

The recent trend of removing references to historical figures deemed problematic or racist has sparked a heated debate about the nature of historical revisionism and the complexity of erasing the past. While some argue that it is necessary to confront and condemn the mistakes of the past, others believe that this approach can be problematic and hypocritical.

The article highlights the cases of several progressive heroes who have been criticized for their racist views and actions. Margaret Sanger, the founder of Planned Parenthood, was an unapologetic racist and eugenicist who believed in reducing the non-white population through abortion. Ruth Bader Ginsburg, a Supreme Court Justice, made a racist comment about abortion, stating that it was necessary to reduce the population of certain groups. Susan B. Anthony, a suffragist, believed that women's suffrage was more important than African-American suffrage.

The article also mentions the cases of Woodrow Wilson, who was a progressive who ensured the segregation of civil-service agencies and the Armed Forces, and Robert Byrd, a Democratic senator who was a former Klansman. Hugo Black, a Supreme Court Justice, was also a Klansman in the 20th century.

The article questions whether it is fair to condemn the past while ignoring the problematic actions of progressive heroes. It also asks whether the rules of exemption for progressives are clear and consistent, and whether some sins can be forgiven if someone makes a certain percentage of "good progressive" actions.

The article concludes by asking whether erasing the past is a sign of raw power and ego, and whether it will cease when modern progressives are forced to confront the memories of their own racist heroes.

Title: Trump's Tweets: A Conundrum of Policy and Psychology

The recent withdrawal of the United States from the Paris climate agreement has sparked widespread criticism, with many labeling it a "traitorous act" and a "war against the American people." However, some argue that the agreement itself was flawed, lacking uniform commitments and enforcement provisions. China, for instance, pledged to peak its CO2 emissions around 2030, meaning emissions will continue to rise for another 13 years.

The article's author suggests that the West should not apologize for its historical role in industrialization, and instead proposes a strong and enforceable climate pact that would impose uniform demands on all participating countries. The author believes that withdrawing from the Paris agreement was a plausible policy choice, and that the subsequent attacks on President Trump were "unhinged" due to his other behavior over the past few weeks.

The article focuses on Trump's tweets, which the author views as a direct conduit from the president's unfiltered id to the public. The author argues that Trump's tweets have consequences, particularly for the president of the United States, and that they erase the membrane between internal disturbances and external manifestations. The article highlights several examples of Trump's tweets, including his mocking of the mayor of London after a recent terror attack and his use of the crisis to support his travel ban.

The author also criticizes Trump's tweets that undermined the case for his travel ban and his claim that the administration was already doing "extreme vetting." The article also notes Trump's tweets that credited his own interventions in Saudi Arabia for the sudden squeeze on Qatar, which the author views as an attempt to feed the presidential id.

The article concludes by stating that Trump was elected to do "politically incorrect" and needed things, but not to do "crazy" things, starting with his tweets. The author suggests that if Trump cannot distinguish between his policy and psychological impulses, Trump Derangement Syndrome will become an epidemic.

Title: Michelle Obama's Racial Narrative Under Scrutiny

Article:

Michelle Obama, the former First Lady of the United States, has spoken out about her experiences with racism in an exclusive interview with People magazine. According to her, she and her husband, former President Barack Obama, still face "racist experiences" and "sting" incidents. Mrs. Obama shared a story about being asked to help a woman retrieve an item from a shelf at a Target store, which she perceived as a symbol of racial oppression.

However, critics have questioned the validity of her claims, pointing out that the incident is not unique to African Americans and that it is a common courtesy for people of all heights to help those who may need assistance. The article also notes that Mrs. Obama has previously shared a similar story on David Letterman's show in 2012, which was met with laughter and applause.

The article goes on to criticize Mrs. Obama's decision to share her story in a popular celebrity magazine, suggesting that it is a calculated move to pander to the left-leaning audience. The author also references Mrs. Obama's past experiences and education, including her senior thesis at Princeton University, which criticized the university's treatment of African Americans.

The article concludes by questioning Mrs. Obama's narrative of racial oppression, suggesting that she has fabricated racial tall tales to advance her own interests and gain sympathy. The author argues that Mrs. Obama's experiences are not unique to African Americans and that she has benefited from her privileged upbringing and education.

It is essential to note that the article's tone is critical and skeptical, questioning the validity of Mrs. Obama's claims and her motivations. The article does not provide a balanced perspective, and it is unclear whether the author has spoken to Mrs. Obama or any other sources to provide a more nuanced understanding of the situation.

Title: Senate Votes to Set Rules for Impeachment Trial, With No Witnesses or Documents

The United States Senate has voted to set rules for the impeachment trial of President Trump, with a 51-49 majority rejecting the idea of calling witnesses or presenting new evidence. The decision effectively brings the trial to a close, with a final vote on acquittal expected on Wednesday.

The rules set by the Senate do not allow for any additional witnesses or motions, and the trial will proceed without the presentation of new evidence. The decision was seen as a major blow to the Democrats, who had been pushing for a more extensive investigation and the presentation of new evidence.

The vote was seen as a result of a series of mistakes made by the Democrats, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's decision to hold onto the articles of impeachment for weeks, attempting to dictate to senators how they should run the trial. Senator Elizabeth Warren's attempt to embarrass Supreme Court Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. was also seen as a major misstep, as it convinced two holdout Republicans to oppose witnesses and give the GOP the necessary votes to shut down the trial.

Senator Ted Cruz said that Warren's move helped deliver the votes of Senators Lisa Murkowski and Lamar Alexander, who ultimately voted against witnesses. "Elizabeth Warren helped defeat the impeachment of the president of the United States," Cruz said.

The decision to reject witnesses and evidence was seen as a major victory for the Republicans, who argued that the Democrats had bungled the impeachment process in the House and delivered two articles that were fatally flawed. The White House official said that Pelosi's move to hold onto the articles for weeks helped build GOP unity against the impeachment effort.

The Democrats, however, argued that the trial without witnesses would not be legitimate and that any subsequent acquittal would always have an asterisk. "To not allow a witness, a document, no witnesses, no documents, in an impeachment trial is a perfidy. It's a grand tragedy," said Senator Charles E. Schumer, the Democrats' floor leader.

The decision to reject witnesses and evidence was seen as a major blow to the Democrats, who had been pushing for a more extensive investigation and the presentation of new evidence. The trial is expected to conclude with a final vote on acquittal on Wednesday, with President Trump likely to be acquitted.

Title: Controversy Erupts at Nebraska Coffee Shop Over Political Views

Article:

A recent incident at Cultiva Espresso & Crepes in Lincoln, Nebraska, has sparked controversy after a transgender employee of the coffee shop confronted a customer, Marilyn Synek, over her political views. Synek, a 23-year-old communications specialist, had been a regular customer at the shop, visiting once a week for breakfast.

According to Synek, the employee, Natalie Weiss, approached her, called her by name, and began yelling profanities, accusing her of being "bigoted" and "trash" due to her past involvement with Republican U.S. Sen. Ben Sasse and her affiliation with the Nebraska Family Alliance, a conservative policy organization that supports marriage and family, religious liberty, and the unborn.

Weiss, who wrote about the incident on Facebook, stated that she told Synek she was not welcome to return to the shop, citing the organization's stance on LGBTQ+ issues. She also claimed that over 80% of the shop's employees are queer and that Synek's views are not welcome.

Cultiva Espresso & Crepes management responded on Facebook, stating that the employee involved was "fired almost immediately" after the incident. The management emphasized that while they are "proudly liberal" and value human rights and diversity, they do not condone treating customers with disrespect. They also emphasized that their shop is a place where people can discuss politics with civility, as has been a tradition in coffee shops for centuries.

The incident has sparked a heated debate on social media, with some defending Weiss's actions and others condemning the employee's behavior. Marilyn Synek, who has accepted the shop's apology, hopes that the incident demonstrates the need for civility in political discussions.

The incident highlights the ongoing tensions between individuals with differing political views and the importance of maintaining a respectful and professional environment in public spaces.

Title: Edwards' Corruption Case Ends in Mistrial, Former Presidential Candidate Speaks Out

Article:

A mistrial was declared in the corruption case of John Edwards, a former Democratic presidential candidate, after a federal jury found him not guilty on one count of accepting illegal campaign contributions but was deadlocked on the remaining five counts.
