The mistrial was announced by Judge Catherine Eagles, who had initially indicated the jury was ready to announce a verdict on all counts by mid-afternoon Thursday. However, the jury had only reached a verdict on one count, leading to the mistrial declaration.

Edwards, who was accused of using nearly $1 million in donations to keep his extramarital affair with Rielle Hunter a secret during the 2008 presidential campaign, expressed gratitude to the jury and said he believes God is not finished with him. He also acknowledged his mistakes, stating, "I did an awful, awful lot that was wrong. There is no one else responsible for my sins. I am responsible. And if I want to find the person who should be held accountable for my sins, honestly I don't have to go any further than the mirror. It's me. It is me and me alone."

Edwards also spoke about his daughter, Frances Quinn Hunter, whom he fathered out of wedlock with Rielle Hunter. He expressed his love for his daughter and gratitude for her presence in his life. The remarks were the most anyone has heard from Edwards since the trial began.

The trial, which lasted over a month, focused heavily on Edwards' character and his alleged violations of campaign finance laws. Prosecutors argued that he knowingly had nearly $1 million in donations channeled to his mistress to keep her silent and prevent the affair from scuttling his presidential bid. The defense argued he was merely trying to keep the secret from his wife.

It is unclear whether federal prosecutors will seek to retry Edwards. A Justice Department spokeswoman declined to comment on the next step, while a law enforcement official told Fox News that it is unlikely the Justice Department would retry Edwards.

Title: June Jobs Report Shatters Expectations, but Broadcast Networks Raise Questions

The June jobs report, released on Thursday, showed a significant improvement in the US labor market, with 4.8 million jobs added and the unemployment rate falling to 11.1%. However, the major broadcast networks, ABC, CBS, and NBC, chose to focus on the "catch" in the report, citing the fact that the numbers were taken before the recent surge in coronavirus cases.

ABC's World News Tonight anchor Tom Llamas warned that while the report showed "good news" and President Trump was pleased, "critics" were "cautious" due to 19 states reversing their reopening plans. CBS Evening News anchor Margaret Brennan and NBC Nightly News anchor Lester Holt also highlighted the "catch" in the report, with Brennan stating that the "welcome news" came with a "big catch" and Holt saying the "record number" was "not telling the whole story."

The networks' anchors and correspondents also emphasized that the report's numbers were taken before the recent spike in coronavirus cases, which could potentially impact the economy. CBS correspondent Adriana Diaz noted that the Black and Hispanic unemployment rates were higher than the national average, at 14.5% and 15.4%, respectively.

The networks' coverage of the report was sponsored by various advertisers, including IBM, Capital One, and Liberty Mutual.

It is worth noting that the report's numbers were taken before the recent surge in coronavirus cases, which could potentially impact the economy. However, the report's overall positive tone and the fact that it showed a significant improvement in the labor market were not highlighted by the networks.

Title: Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia's Death Sets Off Election-Year Battle Over Replacement

Article:

The sudden death of Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia has sparked a heated debate over how and when to replace him, with Congressional leaders and presidential candidates taking sides. The dispute pits Democrats against Republicans, who argue that the Constitution does not require President Obama to fill the vacancy before the next election.

Senate Democrats claim that the Constitution compels the President to act, while Republicans insist that the high court can function with eight members, giving voters a chance to shape its future. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, has ruled out a vote on a replacement this year, stating that the American people should have a voice in the selection of their next Supreme Court justice.

Democrats, on the other hand, argue that they have an obligation to follow the Founding Fathers' constitutional design and fill the court, which is poised to rule on several key issues, including Obama's amnesty program for certain illegal immigrants and the birth control rules for religious nonprofits.

The standoff adds a new layer of complexity to an already challenging year on Capitol Hill, with few opportunities for bipartisan agreement expected. The debate has already spilled onto the campaign trail, with presidential candidates weighing in on the issue.

Title: Obama's ISIS Strategy Under Scrutiny: Lawmakers Demand Action, Debate on Military Authorization

Article:

President Barack Obama's handling of the war against the Islamic State (ISIS) has come under scrutiny from lawmakers on both sides of the aisle, who are frustrated with the lack of action on formally requesting an authorization for the use of military force (AUMF). Two weeks ago, Obama promised a debate on the issue, but so far, no formal request has been made.

Senator Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., expressed frustration, stating that the president should take the lead and write down what he is looking for in terms of authority and let Congress debate it. Senator Robert Menendez, D-N.J., echoed this sentiment, saying that it is difficult to move forward without the administration producing witnesses and providing clear guidance.

Bill O'Reilly, host of "The O'Reilly Factor" on Fox News Channel, criticized the president's hesitation to take decisive action, citing the recent beheading of Peter Kassig, 26, of Indiana, by ISIS. Obama's former defense secretary, Robert Gates, emphasized the importance of providing U.S. special operations troops on the ground to defeat ISIS, stating that denying the military the authorities they require leads to frustration.

The National Security Council's Bernadette Meehan confirmed that the administration is having conversations with lawmakers regarding an AUMF, but Senator Graham believes a written request is necessary. The Washington Post noted that Obama appears to recognize the severity of the ISIS threat but may be constrained by ideological resistance to deploying ground forces.

The article concludes that Obama has stated that a final resolution on the approach to the campaign against ISIS may carry over into the next Congress, while The New York Times suggests that Congress should take action immediately, rather than waiting for the president to act.

Title: Trump's Reversals on Obamacare Subsidies Create Uncertainty for Consumers

The Trump administration's recent changes to the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, have created confusion over the availability and pricing of health insurance for consumers. The administration's decision to stop paying billions of dollars in subsidies to insurers, which help low-income households receive discounts, has sparked concerns about the impact on consumers.

Insurers must still offer discounts on deductibles, co-pays, and other out-of-pocket costs, even if the government stops reimbursing them. However, the uncertainty surrounding the subsidies has led to higher proposed prices on monthly premiums for 2018. In all but a handful of states, insurers submitted two sets of premium rates – a lower rate to use if the subsidies remained, and a higher rate to use if the funding was cut.

The fate of the subsidies remains uncertain, with a senior White House aide stating that President Trump will demand steps towards repealing Obamacare in any healthcare legislation. This casts doubt on the prospects for a bipartisan effort to shore up insurance markets. A California court is expected to consider a request by Democratic attorneys general to keep the subsidies flowing until a legal challenge to Trump's decision is resolved.

If the funding is not restored when 2018 enrollment opens on November 1, many consumers will see premium rates that are on average 20 percent higher than they would have been otherwise. The Congressional Budget Office predicts that Republican policies to roll back Obamacare enrollment efforts will lead to 4 million fewer people signing up for insurance in 2018 than previously forecast.

Leading insurers are unsure how ending the subsidies or reinstating them through potential congressional action will affect pricing next year. Anthem Inc. CEO Joseph Swedish stated that he cannot yet predict how the changes will impact pricing, while Intermountain Healthcare CEO Marc Harrison said that reinstating the subsidies would be the right thing to do and would allow for mid-year changes to premiums.

Washington state's insurance regulator has said it would allow insurers to change rates as soon as practical if lawmakers reinstate the funding, an approach backed by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. However, this could run up against federal government objections, as the Affordable Care Act does not allow for changes to premium rates after they have been finalized. The administration is also working to approve higher rates in several states that did not take into account Trump's cut in subsidies for 2018.

Title: Hungary Declares State of Emergency, Deploys Military to Border with Serbia Amid Migrant Crisis

Hungary has declared a state of emergency in two southeastern counties, paving the way for the deployment of the military to the border with Serbia to stem the flow of migrants entering the country. The move gives authorities greater powers to deal with the crisis, allowing them to shut down roads and limit the working of public institutions, as well as speed up court processes for asylum-seekers.

The state of emergency comes as tougher laws aimed at preventing asylum-seekers from entering the country have come into effect. The legislation makes it a crime to try to breach a razor-wire fence along the border with Serbia and includes longer prison terms for convicted human traffickers.

Hungarian officials have closed two of seven border crossings with Serbia, and a boxcar covered with razor wire has been deployed to block a key border crossing along a railroad track that had been the main entry point for migrants. Thousands of migrants remain stranded on the border, with some staging a sit-in protest, refusing food and water until they are allowed to cross into Hungary.

A record 9,380 migrants entered Hungary on Monday, beating the previous record of 5,809 set just a day earlier. Some 200,000 migrants have entered Hungary so far in 2015, nearly all by walking across the southern border with Serbia. Almost all of them are transit migrants, seeking to reach Western Europe, particularly Germany.

Under the new laws, most migrants entering the country from Serbia can be turned away, as Serbia is considered a safe country and could theoretically provide them asylum. The laws also make it a crime to damage the 4-meter razor-wire fence that Hungary has built on the 110-mile border with Serbia, giving police the power to detain anyone trying to breach it.

The state of emergency allows the government to mobilize the army, pending parliamentary approval next week, to help police with border control. It also forces courts to prioritize cases involving migrants caught entering Hungary illegally, and police can enter and search homes where migrants who entered Hungary illegally are believed to be hiding.

Germany's interior minister, Thomas de Maiziere, has expressed support for cutting European Union funding to countries that refuse to share the burden of hosting refugees. He believes that countries rejecting mandatory quotas for refugee distribution should receive less EU funding.

Title: Local Politicians Take a Middle Ground as Federal Government Shutdown Drags On

As the federal government shutdown continues, local politicians across the United States are taking a pragmatic approach, setting aside partisan differences to deliver essential services to their constituents. This shift towards moderation is evident in states like Indiana, Wisconsin, and California, where governors from both parties are finding ways to fund vital programs and services.

Indiana's Republican Governor Mike Pence has announced that the state will continue to fund food stamps and welfare checks, while Wisconsin's Republican Governor Scott Walker has removed barriers to a federally supported boat launch on the Mississippi River and pledged to fund state parks that were previously shut down. In California, Democratic Governor Jerry Brown has been praised for his fiscal conservatism, taking a similar approach to his Republican counterparts.

According to David McCuan, a political science professor at Sonoma State University, this trend is likely to continue as the shutdown drags on. "It's no longer the suburbs versus the cities, it's delivery of services to the people," he said. "There is an old adage that when it comes to the streets, there are no Democratic or Republican streets, there are only American streets."

Government policy attorney Leonard Wolfe notes that politicians who are up for reelection want to show that they are in control of their state, and are making gestures to demonstrate their ability to deliver services to their constituents. "People want to know why they can't get into their parks or get their benefits check," he said. "They are not interested in partisanship. They expect their local politicians to be able to help."

However, there are limits to how much local politicians can "bail out" the federal government, even when they are inclined to do so. Christine Kelleher-Palus, an associate professor and chair of Villanova University's Department of Public Administration, notes that states are struggling to cope with the economic downturn and are doing their best to analyze and plan for the impact of the shutdown.

As the shutdown continues, it remains to be seen how more extreme politicians will respond as the shared pain spreads among constituents. Barbara O'Connor, a political analyst, notes that politicians like Governor Chris Christie of New Jersey and Governor Jerry Brown of California are taking a more moderate approach, and that this trend may continue. "We are facing an interesting dynamic with politicians," she said. "There are more and more willing to do the helpful thing."

Title: Democrats Debate Economic Inequality and Party Vision

The 2020 Democratic presidential primary has seen a growing concern among party members about the country's economic system and the ability of candidates to address the issue. Former Massachusetts Governor Michael S. Dukakis, who backed Hillary Clinton, emphasized the need for a more equitable tax system and questioned why the majority of Americans are not doing better in the current economic recovery. Dukakis noted that Bernie Sanders is speaking directly to voters' concerns about the economy, but the senator's own vulnerabilities have hindered his ability to convincingly present a vision to a broad audience.

Sanders' tax plans have yet to resonate with voters, and his lack of experience in foreign policy has raised concerns among some Democrats. His stance on not intervening in overseas conflicts has also sparked concerns about his ability to balance domestic and international priorities. On the other hand, his supporters, such as Nevada Democrat Erin Bilbray, appreciate his vision for the party and are willing to pay more in taxes to ensure healthcare and education for their families.

Clinton, meanwhile, faces lingering negative sentiment among some voters who view her as too close to Wall Street and too hawkish on foreign policy, particularly her vote to authorize the Iraq War. A recent CNN/WMUR poll found that 55% of likely Democratic primary voters in New Hampshire consider Clinton the least honest candidate in the field, up from 46% in December.

Title: White House Calls Contempt Proceedings Against Eric Holder a "Fishing Expedition"

The White House has responded to the contempt proceedings against Attorney General Eric Holder, calling the investigation a "fishing expedition" and accusing Republicans of targeting Holder due to his department's efforts to combat voter ID laws. The White House Press Secretary, Jay Carney, stated that the investigation is a political ploy aimed at suppressing the vote.

House Speaker John Boehner, on the other hand, believes that the Obama administration is hiding something in the Fast and Furious scandal and is using executive privilege to cover up the truth. Senator Marco Rubio has also joined the chorus of lawmakers calling for Holder's resignation.

The Justice Department has downplayed the implications of the executive privilege claim, stating that it does not necessarily imply involvement by the president or White House staff. The department noted that any deliberative communications among Executive Branch officials could be covered under the privilege.

The controversy surrounding the contempt proceedings and the executive privilege claim has sparked a heated debate, with both sides accusing each other of political gamesmanship. The dispute is likely to continue as the investigation unfolds and the stakes remain high.

Title: Trump Lawyers Seek to Stop Release of Book Containing Damaging Allegations

Article:

Lawyers for US President Donald Trump are attempting to stop the release of a book, "Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House," which contains damaging allegations about his administration. The book, written by Michael Wolff, cites former top aide Steve Bannon as describing a meeting with a group of Russians as "treasonous." The book also portrays Trump as being surprised at winning the presidency.

Despite the legal threat, the book's publishers have brought its release forward, with the book now available for purchase on Friday. The White House has disputed the book's accuracy, with Trump earlier saying Bannon, who was sacked in August, had "lost his mind" after losing his White House position.

The book reportedly contains explosive statements, including Bannon's claim that Trump's eldest child, Donald Trump Jr., would "crack like an egg on national TV" in reference to a Trump Tower meeting between top campaign officials and Russia. The meeting is being investigated by Special Counsel Robert Mueller as part of his inquiry into possible collusion between Trump campaign officials and Russia to win the election.

Bannon responded to Trump's criticism on his Breitbart radio show, saying he was a "great man" and supported him "day in and day out." Trump responded by saying he didn't know if Bannon had betrayed him, but noted that Bannon had called him a "great man" the previous night.

The legal notice, published by the Washington Post, demands that Wolff and the book's publisher, Henry Holt and Co Inc, "immediately cease and desist from any further publication, release or dissemination of the book." The lawyers accuse Wolff of making "numerous false and/or baseless statements" about Trump and say they are considering pursuing libel charges.

The book's release has been met with widespread media attention, with many outlets publishing excerpts and summaries of the book's contents. The book is reportedly based on over 200 interviews, but some of the book's excerpts have already been criticized and questioned.

Title: National Security Advisor McMaster's Alleged Ties to George Soros Raise Questions

Article:

National Security Advisor H.R. McMaster has been accused of being an operative of globalist billionaire George Soros, according to three separate domestic and foreign intelligence sources. The allegations suggest that McMaster is a foreign intelligence agent for a multi-national combine controlled by Soros, which may explain why he is often seen as a obstacle to President Trump's agenda.

According to correspondent Roger Stone, Israeli intelligence has intercepted email communications between McMaster and Soros, informing the latter of everything happening inside the White House. Stone claims to have confirmed this information with two high-ranking Israeli intelligence officials and expects the Israeli ambassador to the US to confirm it.

This raises concerns about McMaster's role in leaking sensitive information, given Soros's extensive ties to the mainstream media. It is already known that McMaster was a member of the International Institute for Strategic Studies, which was funded by Soros's Open Society Foundation and another Soros-financed group.

Last month, Israel publicly accused Soros of continuously undermining democratically-elected governments. The Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs criticized Soros when it spoke out against the vandalism of anti-Soros posters in Hungary, which were defaced with anti-Semitic graffiti. The ministry stated that it deplores any expression of anti-Semitism and stands with Jewish communities in confronting hatred.

Soros's influence on the National Security Council is said to have begun as early as May, when his operative Fiona Hill joined the council's staff. Hill is a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and the Soros-funded Eurasia Foundation. Hill had previously helped the Soros-founded Central European University in Hungary, which has tried to influence the Hungarian government's stance on EU migrant quotas and Soros's meddling in its affairs.

The article does not provide conclusive evidence to support the allegations against McMaster or Soros, and it is essential to note that the claims are based on anonymous sources and unverified information.

Title: Obama's Potential Executive Actions on Guns: What Could He Do?

The Obama administration is considering taking executive actions to address gun-related violence, with Vice President Biden stating that the administration might take steps without Congressional approval. While the exact measures being contemplated are unclear, some potential actions could include strengthening the FBI's database used for background checks, demanding states share more information from their crime and mental-health databases, and bolstering federally funded mental-health programs.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation's National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) currently relies on information from federal agencies, but not all agencies contribute to the database. Strengthening this database could help prevent gun sales to individuals who are prohibited from owning firearms. Additionally, the administration could require federal agencies to report records to NICS, which would help ensure that more information is available for background checks.

The Mayors Against Illegal Guns coalition, led by New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg, has called for several executive actions that do not require Congressional approval. These measures include stepping up prosecution of felons and others prohibited from buying weapons when they attempt to purchase them, requiring federal agencies to report records to NICS, and appointing an ATF director. The federal agency responsible for enforcing gun laws has gone without a confirmed director for six years.

While some changes to the current system require Congressional approval, others can be implemented through executive action. The Obama administration is expected to provide concrete proposals on reducing gun violence by the end of the month, following the mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut. Vice President Biden has met with various groups, including the National Rifle Association, to discuss potential measures.

Title: Pete Buttigieg Enters 2020 Presidential Race, Promising a "Totally Different" Politics

Pete Buttigieg, the 37-year-old mayor of South Bend, Indiana, has officially launched his bid to become the Democratic Party's nominee for the 2020 presidential election. In his campaign launch event, Buttigieg set out his vision for a "re-imagined future" and promised a "totally different" politics from that of President Donald Trump. If elected, Buttigieg would be the first openly gay US president.

Buttigieg's campaign has focused on issues such as gun control, climate change, and LGBT rights, which he hopes will appeal to millennial voters. His track record as mayor of South Bend, where he has overseen an improvement in the city's economy, has also earned him praise. Since announcing his presidential run in January, Buttigieg has raised over $7 million in funds and gained attention from the media and voters.

Analysts believe Buttigieg could appeal to both moderates and progressives within the Democratic Party. Opinion polls in Iowa and New Hampshire have placed him third in both states, behind Bernie Sanders and former Vice-President Joe Biden. Sanders launched his run last month, while Biden has yet to announce his candidacy.

Buttigieg's campaign has emphasized his personal story and values, but critics argue that he lacks a distinctive policy agenda. His supporters, however, see him as a fresh face with a strong vision for the future. With over a dozen rivals running for the Democratic nomination, the process of selecting a candidate will begin early next year.

Title: Trump's Claims on Stock Market, GM Plant, and Ventilators Face Fact-Checking

The White House press briefing on Friday saw President Donald Trump making several claims that have been met with skepticism and fact-checking. The President's statements on the state of the stock market, a General Motors plant, and ventilators have been disputed by experts and officials.

According to Trump, the stock market was "going beautifully" 22 days ago, with the Dow hitting an all-time high. However, the facts suggest otherwise. On March 5, the Dow dropped 3.6% or 970 points, its fifth-worst single-day point drop on record, adding to a 3,000-point drop since its peak on February 12.

Trump also claimed that the current situation with the coronavirus is unprecedented and unforeseen, stating that "nobody was prepared for this" and that past presidents did not anticipate such an event. However, experts had warned for years that the country was at risk from a pandemic, and public health experts had warned about the need for additional ventilators in the event of a pandemic.

Regarding General Motors, Trump suggested that the company should manufacture ventilators at its Lordstown, Ohio plant. However, there is no evidence to support this claim.

The President also made statements about the coronavirus, saying it can be called the "flu" or "germ," and that nobody knows what it is. Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, has stated that the coronavirus is "very much more transmissible than flu and more importantly, it's significantly more serious" with a mortality rate approximately 10 times higher than the flu.

Additionally, Trump claimed that New York had been unaware of thousands of ventilators sitting in a warehouse, but New York state Health Commissioner Dr. Howard Zucker disputed this, stating that the state knew the ventilators had arrived and needed more. Cuomo also stated that the state does not need to dip into the stockpile at the moment, as his estimate of 30,000 ventilators needed is about the expected peak of the crisis in approximately 21 days.

Finally, Trump claimed that China pays 25% interest on $250 billion worth of product, but this is inaccurate. A tariff is a tax paid by the importer, not a charge paid by an entity that has borrowed money.

Title: President Obama Clarifies "Red Line" Statement, Blames International Community for Credibility at Stake

Article:

During a press conference in Stockholm on Wednesday, President Obama clarified his previous statement about drawing a "red line" on the use of chemical weapons by Bashar Assad in Syria. The President emphasized that the world, not he, set the red line, citing the international community's condemnation of chemical weapons and the ratification of a treaty prohibiting their use. He also pointed out that Congress set a red line when it ratified the Syria Accountability Act, which aimed to hold accountable those responsible for the humanitarian crisis in Syria.

The President further shifted the focus from his own credibility to that of the international community and Congress, stating that their credibility is at stake in the Syria vote. This move has been criticized by some as an attempt to deflect personal responsibility and shift the blame to others.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee subsequently passed a use-of-force resolution on Wednesday, but with a slim 10-7 vote. The President lost support from two Democrats and five Republicans, including Senators John Barrasso and Marco Rubio.

The article concludes that President Obama has yet to understand that the United States is the primary enforcer of world order, and that he must take personal responsibility for leading the country. If he fails to do so, it will be a reflection of his leadership.

Title: California's Controversial Housing Bill SB 50 Fails to Pass Again, Despite Efforts to Address State's Housing Crisis

The highly debated housing bill, SB 50, has failed to pass the California state legislature for the third time in recent years. The bill aimed to revolutionize land use and housing in the state, but fell short of passing the state Senate by just three votes. The bill's failure was met with disappointment from supporters, who had hoped it would help address the state's housing crisis.

The bill's opponents, including many lawmakers from the Los Angeles area, cited concerns about top-down control and intrusion into their neighborhoods. However, the opposition was not limited to NIMBYs (Not In My Backyard) groups, as some housing justice groups also voiced concerns about the bill's potential to exacerbate displacement of low-income residents and not doing enough to protect them.

Coalitions of housing justice groups and tenants' rights organizations wrote letters of opposition to the bill, citing concerns about inequitable development and the potential for gentrification. Some legislators also expressed concerns about the bill's impact on vulnerable communities.

The failure of SB 50 highlights the complexity of the issue, as both NIMBYs and housing justice advocates have different goals and motivations. While NIMBYs want to preserve their neighborhoods, housing justice advocates are concerned about the displacement of low-income communities and communities of color.

The distinction between the two groups is crucial, as some NIMBYs have co-opted housing justice language to justify their opposition, and some YIMBYs (Yes In My Backyard) groups have lumped both together, making it difficult to understand the nuances of the issue.

As California lawmakers prepare to reintroduce housing production legislation, it is essential to recognize the differences between NIMBYs and housing justice advocates. While NIMBYs may still resist development near their neighborhoods, housing justice advocates may cooperate if they feel the policy will help and not hurt vulnerable communities.

The housing crisis is not going away, and it will remain a legislative focus in the coming year. Senator Scott Wiener has already introduced two housing policy spot bills, and the Assembly is considering legislation that guarantees a legal right to housing for families and children. Senate President pro Tempore Toni Atkins challenged opponents of SB 50 to put forward their own legislation, stating that they have offered no substantive alternative with the same scope as SB 50.

Title: Zuckerberg-Backed Political Advocacy Group FWD.us Launches with Focus on Immigration Reform

The FWD.us, a political advocacy group backed by Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, officially launched on Thursday with a list of prominent Silicon Valley CEOs and a team of strategists. The group's initial focus will be on comprehensive immigration reform, with the aim of increasing the number of H-1B temporary visas for high-skilled foreign workers and reducing the wait times for green cards for their employees.

The group's founders include Reid Hoffman, co-founder of LinkedIn, and John Doerr, a venture capitalist who has backed Google and Amazon.com. Other notable contributors include Marissa Mayer, Yahoo's chief executive, and Eric Schmidt, Google's executive chairman. The organization also boasts a team of political players from both sides of the aisle, including Rob Jesmer, a former executive director of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, and Joe Lockhart, former White House press secretary for President Bill Clinton.

In an op-ed published in The Washington Post, Zuckerberg wrote about his encounter with a middle school student who is an undocumented immigrant and unsure if he will be able to attend college due to his immigration status. He stated that the current immigration policy is "unfit for today's world" and called for reform.

The group's exact plans are still unclear, but it is expected to engage in activities such as advertising, campaign support, public communications, and grassroots organizing. The organization has posted testimonials from its members on its website, FWD.us.

The group's co-founder and president, Joe Green, issued an apology last week after a leaked prospectus listed executives who had not committed to the effort, including Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates. The group has since moved past the misstep and is focusing on its initial goal of passing comprehensive immigration reform.

Title: Congressional Republicans Unveil $1.4 Trillion Tax-Cut Plan

Congressional Republicans have officially unveiled their final $1.4 trillion tax-cut plan, which aims to slash corporate and individual rates, wind down certain credits and exemptions, and impose new international tax rules. The plan, which has been months in the making, is set to be voted on next week and is expected to reach President Trump's desk before Christmas.

The plan lowers the corporate tax rate from 35 percent to 21 percent, effective January 1, a change Republicans are billing as the biggest corporate tax rate reduction in U.S. history. It also preserves the existing number of individual tax rates at seven, not counting the zero rate, and lowers the top rate from 39.6 percent to 37 percent. The new top rate applies to individuals making more than $500,000 and couples making more than $600,000.

The plan also includes several other key provisions, such as doubling the standard deduction to $12,000 for individuals and $24,000 for families, increasing the number of "zero filers" who face no federal income tax liability, and preserving the current mortgage interest deduction for existing mortgages. It also repeals the Obamacare individual mandate starting in 2019 and doubles the exemption for the estate tax on inheritances from $5 million to $10 million.

For small businesses, the plan introduces a new 20 percent deduction for the first $315,000 of joint income for so-called "pass-through" companies that file their taxes as individuals. Businesses will also be able to immediately write off capital expenses for new equipment, rather than the current system that has them do it over a number of years.

The plan also repeals the corporate alternative minimum tax and raises the income thresholds for the individual alternative minimum tax. The state and local tax deduction, which had been on the chopping block at the start of the process, was preserved in part, with individuals able to take a deduction of up to $10,000 for sales, income, and property taxes paid.

On the international side, the bill imposes a 15.5 percent "repatriation" tax for cash holdings that companies have parked overseas, and an 8 percent tax for non-cash holdings.

While Republicans are looking for swift passage next week, Democrats have criticized the plan, saying it is tilted towards corporations and the wealthy and doesn't do enough for the middle class. "This tax bill is a moral and economic obscenity," said Sen. Bernard Sanders, Vermont Independent. "It is a gift to wealthy Republican campaign contributors and an insult to the working families of our country."

Title: Former Russian Ambassador to the US Says He Had Many Discussions with People Close to Trump

Article:

Sergey Kislyak, Russia's former ambassador to the United States, made a humorous comment during an interview on Russian state-owned television, stating it would take him over 20 minutes to list every discussion he had with people close to President Trump. When asked to name every person associated with Trump he had met with or spoken to on the phone, Kislyak responded, "First, I'm never going to do that. And second, the list is so long that I'm not going to be able to go through it in 20 minutes."

Kislyak served as Moscow's ambassador to Washington from 2008 until August 2017 and was elected to represent Mordovia in the Russian legislature's upper chamber in September. His meetings with people close to Trump's presidential campaign have been scrutinized by Democrats on Capitol Hill, including Attorney General Jeff Sessions' testimony before the House Judiciary Committee.

Sessions testified during his January confirmation hearing in the Senate that he "did not have communications with the Russians" while serving as a surrogate for Trump's campaign, but admitted during Tuesday's hearing to meeting with Kislyak at least twice during the 2016 race. Representative Ted Lieu, a California Democrat, questioned Sessions' statements, saying, "Either you're lying to the U.S. Senate or you're lying to the U.S. House of Representatives."

Kislyak downplayed the significance of his meetings with Sessions, stating, "I will tell you that in not one meeting, not with Sessions, not with anyone else, did we use any kinds of techniques or arguments that I would not be able to speak about publicly." He added, "This is no longer about me. This isn't about contacts with us. This is a war that's going on between the opponents of the president, the president and everyone surrounding him."

Separately, other members of Trump's campaign, transition team, and administration have faced scrutiny for meeting with Kislyak prior to Trump's inauguration. Michael Flynn, Trump's former national security adviser, resigned from his role in February after it emerged that he discussed lifting sanctions against Russia with Kislyak prior to Trump's inauguration and then with Vice President Mike Pence about the nature of those talks. Jared Kushner, Trump's son-in-law and senior adviser, reportedly spoke with Kislyak during the transition period about establishing a secret back channel between the White House and Kremlin.

U.S. intelligence officials have determined that Russian President Vladimir Putin interfered in the 2016 White House race in hopes of electing Trump over his Democratic rival, Hillary Clinton. Russia's alleged involvement in the race and any collusion between Moscow and Trump's inner circle are currently being investigated by probes underway in the House, Senate, and Department of Justice, including a probe led by DOJ-appointed special counsel Robert Mueller that has resulted in criminal charges so far for three members of Trump's 2016 campaign. Russia has denied meddling in the U.S. election, and the White House has denied colluding with the Kremlin.

Title: Sen. Joe Manchin Says Proponents Lack Votes to Pass Gun-Purchase Background Check Expansion

Article:

Senator Joe Manchin, a West Virginia Democrat and co-sponsor of a measure to expand gun-purchase background checks to online and gun show sales, stated that proponents do not have the votes to pass the bill on Wednesday. This development is a significant setback for gun-control advocates, who had hoped for more ambitious controls, such as bans on certain types of weapons and magazines, and universal background checks on all gun sales.

President Obama has made campaign-style trips to promote the administration's package, crafted by Vice President Joseph R. Biden, who has been the point man on the issue. Senator Manchin expressed optimism on MSNBC's "Morning Joe," stating that if nine Republican senators supported the bill, it would pass. He also emphasized that he remains hopeful and will continue to explain the bill to his colleagues until the vote.

Senator Manchin's spokesman, Jonathan Kott, said the senator remains optimistic that if senators read the bill, they will support it. Kott noted that Senator Manchin has garnered support from an A-rated NRA member and three Republican senators, as well as 90% of his own party.

On the Senate floor, Senator Manchin expressed uncertainty about having the necessary votes, stating that it would be close. He emphasized that he feels good about the bill and hopes his colleagues will consider it before voting.

The prospects for the amendment faded significantly as Senators Kelly Ayotte (R-NH) and Heidi Heitkamp (D-ND) announced they would not support it. The amendment, which includes more far-reaching background-check language, stiff penalties for gun trafficking, and provisions to bolster school safety, was initially supported by Senators Ayotte and Heitkamp, who voted to move debate forward on the underlying legislation last week.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-NV) has scheduled votes on eight other amendments to the underlying gun legislation, including bans on certain types of guns and magazines. Senator Chuck Grassley (R-IA) and other co-sponsors unveiled a substitute amendment to strengthen the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) and address mental health and school safety, among other provisions. Senator Tom Coburn (R-OK) also announced his own amendment to replace the background-check provision, which would allow people to conduct self-checks through a consumer portal, among other measures.

Title: Gun-Rights Group Challenges State-Ordered Shutdown of Non-Essential Businesses Amid Coronavirus Outbreak

A top gun-rights group, the Firearms Policy Coalition, has filed a case with the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, challenging the state's order to shut down non-essential businesses, including gun stores, due to the coronavirus outbreak. The group argues that weapons and ammunition retailers are essential businesses and that the government cannot shut down the right to keep and bear arms.

The Pennsylvania Supreme Court has given Governor Tom Wolf until 8 p.m. on Friday to respond to the arguments in the case. The shutdown of non-essential businesses in several states, including California and Pennsylvania, has raised concerns that more gun retailers could be ordered to close their doors. At least one gun store near San Jose has already been forced to close.

Gun-rights advocates argue that Americans' access to firearms and ammunition should not be prohibited despite the threat of the virus. They claim that gun stores are required by the government to be a point of access to the exercise of fundamental human rights.

The shutdown of gun stores would drastically limit Americans' ability to purchase firearms for self-defense and raise significant constitutional questions that gun-rights groups are prepared to challenge in court. The National Rifle Association (NRA) and the Second Amendment Foundation (SAF) are monitoring the situation and are prepared to take legal action if necessary.

The National Shooting Sports Foundation, the gun industry's trade group, is also monitoring the situation and is ready to defend its businesses if necessary. The group believes that gun stores are essential businesses and are starting to prepare to defend that stance.

The case highlights the ongoing debate over the balance between public health measures and individual rights during the pandemic. While some argue that shutting down non-essential businesses is necessary to slow the spread of the virus, others believe that it is a violation of their constitutional rights. The outcome of this case could have significant implications for the future of gun rights in the United States.

Title: Democrats Face Challenges in the 2016 Presidential Election

The 2016 presidential election is heating up, with Hillary Clinton, the clear front-runner for the Democratic nomination, facing challenges from both within her own party and from potential Republican opponents. A recent poll by Quinnipiac University found Clinton trailing former Florida Governor Jeb Bush in the Sunshine State and enjoying only a 2-percentage-point lead over Senator Marco Rubio (R-Fla.).

The same poll found Clinton ahead of the Republican field in the must-win state of Pennsylvania, but with only a 1-point lead over Senator Rand Paul (R-Ky.). Her favorability rating in both states has dropped, by 4 points in Florida and 6 points in Pennsylvania.

The controversy surrounding Clinton's decision not to use a government email address while she served as Secretary of State has taken a toll on her public image, according to Quinnipiac pollster Peter A. Brown. Republicans have seized on the issue to tarnish Clinton's reputation and raise questions about her trustworthiness.

The Republican field of potential challengers is growing, with Senator Ted Cruz (Texas) being the first to formally enter the race last week. Paul is expected to make an announcement next week, and Rubio could follow the week after. The deep bench of potential GOP challengers could also include Bush, Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, and retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson.

Despite the challenges, Democrats argue that Clinton maintains a sizable lead in the polls and predict GOP candidates will begin to get into their own trouble as the race gears up. "There's not one person right now, when you match them head to head, who is even in Clinton's weight class," said Rodell Mollineau, a Democratic strategist.

Clinton has a major advantage over potential Republican opponents in that she faces a lightly contested path to the nomination. She has a huge lead over all likely Democratic candidates, according to polls. "No amount of money or organization is going to erase Jeb Bush's family name or his brother's legacy," Mollineau said. "As much as he says he's his own man, it seems the advisers he's collecting are a redux of the Bush-Cheney administration."

**Sydney Hostage Situation Ends, Police Storm Cafe After Gunfire and Explosions**

A tense standoff in Sydney, Australia, came to an end on Tuesday after police stormed a cafe where an armed gunman had taken hostages. The situation unfolded on Monday night, with hundreds of police, many of them heavily armed, cordoning off the area and evacuating nearby buildings.

The hostage taker, identified as Man Haron Monis, an Iranian national, was reportedly using a black and white flag bearing the Shahada, a general expression of Islamic faith, as a symbol. While the exact number of hostages involved is unclear, it is believed that around a dozen people remain in the Lindt Chocolate Cafe.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott stopped short of calling the incident a terrorist attack, but said it appeared to be politically motivated. "This is a very disturbing incident," he said. "It is profoundly shocking that innocent people should be held hostage by an armed person claiming political motivation."

Police Commissioner Andrew Scipione emphasized the priority of safely evacuating the hostages, stating, "Our plan, our only goal tonight and for as long as this takes, is to get those people that are currently caught in that building, out of there safely."

The situation comes just three months after Australia's terror threat level was raised to high, following a knife attack on a policeman in Melbourne believed to be inspired by the Islamic State. The country has since passed tough anti-terror laws, including restrictions on media reporting and new powers to confiscate passports.

Professor Greg Barton of Monash University, who studies regional terrorist organizations, believes the hostage taker's use of the Shahada flag suggests he is responding to the Islamic State's call for "lone wolf" attacks. "The new twist is the use of hostage taking. This is a very worrying development because these things tend to get copied," he said.

Local Muslim leaders swiftly condemned the hostage taking, with the Australian National Imams Council denouncing the act as "criminal" and "denounced in part and in whole in Islam."

Title: Pope Francis' Fiat: A Symbol of Humility and Simplicity

Pope Francis, the first pontiff to speak before a joint meeting of Congress, has been making headlines with his choice of transportation during his visit to the United States. The Pope's ride of choice is a humble black Fiat, which has sparked conversations about the symbolism behind his decision.

The Fiat, a 1984 Renault 4, was given to the Pope by a priest from northern Italy. It is a departure from the typical armored limousines used by previous popes, which were designed for security and grandeur. Francis' choice of a smaller, more modest vehicle reflects his commitment to humility and simplicity, values that are central to his message.

According to Stephen Schneck, director of the Institute for Policy Research and Catholic Studies at The Catholic University of America, the Fiat is a perfect metaphor for the Pope's message. "It looks like a clown car when they all get in it," he said. "But it's just such a perfect metaphor for his message."

The Pope's decision to use a Fiat also reflects his vow of poverty, which he took as a Jesuit priest. Although he no longer has to abide by this vow as the Pope, it remains an important part of his identity and philosophy.

Alejandro Cañadas, a professor of economics at Mount St. Mary's University, notes that the word "fiat" appears in the Bible, specifically in Luke 1:38, where Mary responds to the angel Gabriel's announcement that she will conceive and give birth to Jesus. "I think for the Pope, fiat is what he tries to do with his life," Cañadas said. "He tries to imitate the Virgin Mary, trying to do the will of God all the time. And the only way to do that is to be humble and to become poor with the poor in the way that he can do it."

The Pope's Fiat has also been seen as a way to connect with people, as it allows him to be more accessible and relatable. Paula Martin, 71, who was among those who saw the Pope's motorcade, said, "He was right there. I felt like I could almost touch him. It was an amazing experience."

Title: Ocasio-Cortez Defends Support for Cost-of-Living Increases for Members of Congress

Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) has defended her stance on providing cost-of-living increases for members of Congress, stating that it helps keep "dark money" out of politics. She argued that voting against such increases can create an environment where "money loopholes" and "self-dealing" are rewarded.

Ocasio-Cortez emphasized that consistency is important and that all workers, including minimum wage workers, deserve cost-of-living increases. She also suggested that worker co-ops and collective bargaining are alternative forums where worker pay increases can be voted on.

The representative's comments come after House Democrats pulled a spending bill that would have provided raises to members of Congress for the first time in a decade, following pushback from swing state lawmakers. Ocasio-Cortez has been a vocal advocate for living wage issues and campaign finance reform.

Title: Trump's Business Picks: Puzder and Tillerson Bring Relevant Experience to the Table

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump's cabinet choices have sparked controversy among Democrats, with some business leaders being met with skepticism. Two such individuals, Andrew Puzder and Rex Tillerson, have been chosen for the Departments of Labor and State, respectively. While some may question their qualifications, both men bring relevant experience and seasoned judgment to their new roles.

Puzder, the head of CKE Restaurants, parent company of Hardee's and Carl's Jr. fast-food chains, has learned a great deal about hiring and managing employees, which is the focus of the Department of Labor's activities. He has expressed concerns about big increases in the minimum wage, stating that it could lead to millions of people having no wage at all. This stance aligns with standard economic theory, as Nobel laureate Paul Krugman noted in 1998.

Puzder's background gives him a different perspective than a labor activist would offer, but he is not hostile to compromise. He has expressed openness to a minimum wage higher than the current federal level of $7.25 an hour, or even indexing it to inflation.

Tillerson, chosen for secretary of state, is not a one-dimensional figure. As president of the Boy Scouts of America, he pushed for allowing gay troop leaders, and Exxon Mobil has donated to Planned Parenthood. He has also endorsed a carbon tax to combat global warming, which could be beneficial for the environment.

Critics argue that Tillerson will prioritize the interests of big oil over those of the American public. However, CEOs are not free agents; they are used to serving the interests of shareholders while catering to customers. As head of Exxon Mobil, Tillerson profited from high oil prices, but he can adapt to serving the public interest if his boss allows.

Tillerson's background invites scrutiny of any decision that affects his old industry, and he can expect to be held to a tougher standard on such matters. His experience working with regimes he did not necessarily approve of, like John Kerry and Condoleezza Rice, may also be beneficial.

Business executives like Puzder and Tillerson can bring valuable assets to government, offering relevant experience and seasoned judgment. Senate Democrats should consider approving them before Trump can change his mind, as they may be a welcome change from some of the other candidates considered for important jobs.

Title: House Lawmakers Struggle to Pass Born Alive Protection Act Amidst Democratic Opposition

Article:

In a recurring pattern, lawmakers in the House of Representatives have once again been unable to bring the Born Alive Protection Act to the floor for debate and vote. The bill, which aims to protect babies born alive after an attempted abortion, has been met with resistance from Democratic lawmakers, who are using House rules to prevent its consideration.

According to Representative Kevin McCarthy (R-CA), the bill has been blocked for the 17th time, with Democrats refusing to allow a vote. Representative Steve Scalise (R-LA) emphasized the gravity of the issue, stating that "there are babies being born alive and then ultimately murdered."

Representative Chris Smith (R-NJ), leader of the House pro-life caucus, shared a disturbing account of a baby being born alive and then discarded like trash in a Florida abortion clinic. The clinic owner allegedly cut the umbilical cord, placed the baby in a biohazard bag, and threw it away like garbage.

Other lawmakers, including Representative Liz Cheney (R-WY), have expressed outrage and shame over the situation, calling it an "abomination" that this practice is still occurring in the United States.

Meanwhile, some states are pushing for radical abortion legislation, fearing the Supreme Court may overturn Roe v. Wade and legalize abortion nationwide. Illinois, for example, has introduced the Reproductive Health Act, which could cement the state as a "Midwest abortion oasis," according to Jill Stanek, national campaign chair of the Susan B. Anthony List.

Pro-life activists like Melissa Cifuentes are fighting against similar legislation in Rhode Island, emphasizing the importance of protecting innocent lives. "We are called to use our voice to speak the truth on behalf of innocent lives that are sacred and that are worthy of our protection," she said.

Legislators are urging Americans to contact their representatives in Congress to sign the discharge petition for the Born Alive Protection Act, which would require 218 signatures to bring the bill to the floor. If successful, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi would be forced to allow a vote.

Title: Trump Criticized for Comments on Paris and London Gun Violence

Article:

US President Donald Trump sparked controversy during a speech at the National Rifle Association (NRA) convention, where he made comments about the 2015 terrorist attacks in Paris and the recent increase in knife violence in London. Trump stated that strict gun laws failed to prevent the Paris attacks and that if individuals in the cafes under attack had been armed, the terrorists would have fled or been shot.

The French government expressed its "firm disapproval" of Trump's remarks, calling for respect for the memory of the victims. Former French President François Hollande tweeted that Trump's comments were "shameful" and "obscene," and that the friendship between the two countries would not be tainted by disrespect and excessiveness.

Trump also compared an unnamed London hospital to a "war zone," citing the high number of knife attacks in the city. He stated that despite tough gun laws in the UK, the hospital has blood on its floors due to knife attacks. British officials did not respond to Trump's comments, but former UK Cabinet minister Charlie Falconer tweeted that the US murder rate is over five times higher than the UK's, and that making it easier to get guns does not reduce the murder rate.

It is unclear which hospital Trump was referring to, but a trauma surgeon at the Royal London Hospital, Dr. Martin Griffiths, invited Trump to visit the hospital to discuss violence reduction in London. Professor Karim Brohi, a trauma surgeon at the Royal London Hospital, disputed Trump's claims, stating that the hospital has seen a significant reduction in knife attacks and that gunshot wounds are more lethal and difficult to repair.

The controversy surrounding Trump's comments has sparked a heated debate about gun laws and violence in both the US and the UK.

Title: GOP Establishment's Omnibus Bill Sparks Outrage Among Conservatives

The recent omnibus spending bill passed by the Republican-controlled Congress has sparked widespread outrage among conservatives, who feel betrayed by the party's failure to uphold its campaign promises. The bill, which funds various government programs and initiatives, has been criticized for its lack of fiscal responsibility and its failure to address key issues such as border security and healthcare.

Conservatives are particularly upset about the bill's inclusion of provisions that fund Planned Parenthood, provide visas for unvetted Muslim migrants, and support the H-2B visa program, which allows foreign workers to take jobs from American citizens. The bill also does not include funding for a southern border wall, a key campaign promise of many Republicans.

The bill's passage has led to accusations of duplicity and betrayal against the Republican Party, with some conservatives calling for a change in leadership and others advocating for a complete overhaul of the party's platform. The article's author argues that the GOP establishment is more concerned with maintaining its own power and influence than with serving the interests of its constituents.

However, not all Republicans are pleased with the bill's passage. The article notes that some members of the House Freedom Caucus, a group of conservative lawmakers, were absent or did not vote on the bill, and that some Republicans have spoken out against its provisions.

The article concludes by urging conservatives to stay engaged and active in the political process, rather than abandoning the party. It argues that the GOP establishment's actions are a sign of its own weakness and that it is up to conservatives to hold them accountable and demand better.

Title: US Economy Cools, But Growth Remains Stronger Than Expected

The United States economy grew at a 2.6% annualized rate in the fourth quarter of 2018, slightly below expectations, according to a Commerce Department report released on Thursday. This growth rate follows a 3.4% advance in the previous quarter, and suggests that the economy may be stronger than initially thought.

Consumer spending, which accounts for the majority of the economy, grew at a 2.8% rate, slightly below forecasts. Non-residential business investment, however, accelerated to a 6.2% gain, driven by increased spending on equipment, software, and research. Government spending slowed, while trade was a minor drag on the economy, and inventories gave GDP a small boost.

The report shows that Republican-backed tax cuts may have continued to aid growth, bringing the full-year figure to 3.1%, just above President Donald Trump's 3% goal. While the expansion is poised to become the nation's longest on record at midyear, the pace could slow amid the trade war, slowing global growth, and fading impact of fiscal stimulus.

The Labor Department reported that initial claims for unemployment benefits rose by more than expected last week to 225,000, still near a five-decade low. The week included the Presidents' Day holiday, and claims tend to be more volatile around such events.

Growth, while slower than the prior two quarters, remains above both the average pace of the expansion and what the Federal Reserve sees as the economy's long-run potential of 1.9%. However, surveys and gauges such as Treasury yields indicate that chances of a recession have increased in recent months, although they remain unlikely for 2019.

The report also showed that final sales to domestic purchasers increased at a 2.6% pace, following a 2.9% gain in the previous quarter. This measure is monitored by economists for a better sense of underlying demand.

The increase in consumer spending was driven by health care, financial services, and insurance, as well as other nondurable goods and services, while spending on food services and accommodations fell. The GDP data may reinforce analyst criticism of the government's recent report on December retail sales, which showed the biggest drop in nine years, even as other figures indicated consumers continued to open their wallets in the quarter.

The report showed that the third-quarter slowdown in business spending may have been temporary, with non-residential fixed investment contributing 0.82 percentage points to growth, following a 0.35-point contribution in the third quarter. Within that category, spending on structures fell 4.2%, the biggest drop in a year, while business-equipment investment rose 6.7%, and intellectual property spending jumped 13.1%.

Housing remained a weak spot, posting the fourth consecutive drag on GDP growth, with a contraction of 3.5%. Home sales tumbled in late 2018 amid elevated mortgage rates and price increases that continued to outpace wages, although there are signs of demand picking up in early 2019 thanks to a drop in borrowing costs.

Net exports subtracted 0.22 percentage points from GDP growth during the quarter, following a 1.99-point reduction in the prior period. The drag reflected a 2.7% rise in imports that outpaced a 1.6% increase in exports, with the tariff war buffeting both sets of flows.

Inventories added 0.13 percentage points to the pace of expansion. Meanwhile, inflation remained muted, adding little urgency for the Fed to consider resuming interest-rate hikes. The GDP report showed the Fed's preferred price index rose at a 1.5% annualized pace last quarter, below the central bank's 2% goal. Excluding food and energy, the index rose 1.7%.

Title: Trump Signs $1.3 Trillion Spending Bill, Ending Government Shutdown Threat

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump signed the newly passed $1.3 trillion spending bill on Friday, bringing an end to several hours of confusion sparked by his tweeted veto threat. The bill, which had been passed by Congress, had been met with criticism from Trump, who had expressed concerns over certain provisions.

Despite his reservations, Trump ultimately decided to sign the bill, citing a $60 billion increase in military spending as a major factor in his decision. However, he warned that he would not sign another bill like this again, stating, "I'm not going to do it again."

The bill had been the subject of much debate, with Trump initially expressing concerns over the lack of funding for the border wall and the treatment of Dreamer immigrants. He had tweeted that he was considering a veto, citing the abandonment of the 800,000-plus DACA recipients and the lack of funding for the border wall.

However, Trump ultimately decided against vetoing the bill, after being advised by his senior advisers that doing so would lead to a government shutdown and that discussions on the issues he was concerned about would continue. The bill includes $1.6 billion for six months of work on the border wall, but Trump had sought $25 billion for the project.

The signing of the bill brings an end to the uncertainty surrounding the government's spending plans, and allows lawmakers to take a two-week spring recess. The bill's passage had been met with criticism from some conservative lawmakers, who had expressed concerns over the spending increases and deficit.

Title: Sen. Cory Booker Introduces Bill to Provide Interest-Bearing Savings Accounts for Every U.S. Child

Sen. Cory Booker (D-N.J.) has introduced a bill aimed at addressing rising economic inequality by providing every U.S. child with an interest-bearing savings account at birth. The bill, which is seen as a potential policy proposal for the 2020 presidential election, would create accounts funded by the federal government, with a $1,000 principal balance and up to $2,000 annual deposits depending on family income.

The accounts would be administered by the Treasury Department and would be federally insured, with funds only usable for homeownership and "human and financial capital investments that change life trajectories." The program would cost approximately $60 billion if implemented in 2019 and would be funded by increasing the capital gains tax rate by 4.2 points, increasing the estate tax to its 2009 level, and raising taxes on multimillion-dollar inheritances.

Booker's proposal aims to address the growing wealth gap between the richest and poorest Americans, which has steadily risen since the 2007-8 financial crisis. The bill also seeks to address the racial wealth gap, which has been exacerbated by decades of discriminatory laws and business practices that have prevented minorities from accessing the same financial products and investments as whites. The median net worth of whites is roughly 10 times larger than that of blacks, with nearly 1 in 5 black families having zero or negative net worth, according to Federal Reserve data from 2017.

This is not the first policy proposal from a 2020 hopeful aimed at bolstering the economic stability of working- and middle-class Americans. Several potential Democratic primary rivals, including Sens. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-N.Y.) and Kamala Harris (D-Calif.), have rolled out bills to increase low-income household wealth and provide affordable housing. A similar federally funded savings program was instituted in Israel last year.

Title: Turkey Launches Military Operation Against Kurdish Fighters in Northern Syria

Turkey launched a military operation against Kurdish fighters in northern Syria on Wednesday, just days after the United States announced it would withdraw its troops from the region. The operation, dubbed "Operation Peace Spring" by Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, aims to destroy what Turkey considers a "terror corridor" on its southern border and bring peace to the region.

The Turkish military has been pounding the region with airstrikes and artillery, softening defenses for a ground offensive. The operation has been met with criticism from the international community, with the United States expressing concerns over the potential humanitarian crisis and the United Nations Security Council set to meet behind closed doors on Thursday to discuss the conflict.

Turkey views the Kurdish People's Protection Units (YPG) in Syria as terrorists due to their ties to militants waging an insurgency inside Turkey. The YPG is a key component of the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), an overarching coalition that has been fighting against the Islamic State (ISIS).

The airstrikes have caused significant damage and displacement, with at least seven civilians and one member of Kurdish-led forces killed in the first day of fighting. The Turkish military has also struck the town of Tal Abyad, where bombs hit an office of the SDF, sending nearby residents fleeing for their lives.

The United States had been working with the YPG to fight against ISIS, but President Trump announced the withdrawal of US troops from the region earlier this week. Trump has defended his decision, stating that the United States has spent $8 trillion fighting and policing in the Middle East and is now bringing its soldiers home. He also emphasized that Turkey has committed to protecting civilians, religious minorities, and ensuring no humanitarian crisis takes place.

The situation remains fluid, with the international community closely monitoring the developments and the United Nations Security Council set to meet to discuss the conflict.

Title: Trump Administration Overturns Obama-Era Rules for Handling University Sex Assault Allegations

The Trump administration has announced new guidelines for handling sexual assault allegations on university campuses, reversing rules introduced by the Obama administration. Education Secretary Betsy DeVos stated that the previous guidance was "unfairly tilted against the accused" and aimed to strike a balance between ensuring the rights of both the accused and the alleged victims.

The new interim instructions allow universities to decide the standard of evidence to be used when handling complaints, introducing the option of requiring "clear and convincing evidence" in campus sex assault cases. Under the Obama administration, universities were required to investigate complaints even if there was a separate criminal inquiry, with a standard of proof being a "preponderance of evidence."

The change has been met with criticism from advocates for sexual assault victims, who warn that it may deter victims from coming forward. The American Association of University Women's CEO, Kim Churches, stated that the policy reversal is a "blatant rollback from the strong and much-needed guidance that was in place." House of Representatives Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi also denounced the change as a "shocking attack" on women.

The new guidelines have been met with controversy, with some critics arguing that they may lead to a lack of accountability for perpetrators of sexual assault. The Education Department has stated that 360 sexual violence cases are currently under investigation at 250 colleges and universities across the US.

Title: Banning Flavored Vaping Products: A Misguided Approach to Addressing Youth Vaping

The article discusses the recent bans on flavored vaping products, citing concerns over the rising number of vaping-related illnesses and deaths. However, the author argues that this approach is misguided and that policymakers should focus on enforcing existing laws and educating children about the dangers of vaping, rather than imposing blanket bans.

The article highlights that underage individuals typically obtain vaping products from older friends and siblings, rather than purchasing them directly from retailers. This suggests that the root of the problem lies not with the products themselves, but with the actions of individuals who provide them to minors.

The author notes that other products, such as alcohol and tobacco, are also meant for adults only, but are not banned due to the actions of a small number of individuals who provide them to underage individuals. The article argues that a similar approach should be taken with vaping products, rather than punishing all adults for the actions of a few.

The article also points out that the cause of the vaping-related illnesses is still unclear, and that the bans may be a knee-jerk reaction to the crisis. The author notes that the Washington Post has reported that the majority of those affected by the illnesses have used marijuana oil, and that the vitamin E acetate found in some vaping products may be the culprit.

The article concludes that banning flavored vaping products is a misguided approach, as it may not address the root of the problem and may have unintended consequences, such as driving the market underground and making it more difficult for adults to access e-cigarettes, which can be a useful tool for quitting smoking. Instead, the author suggests that policymakers should focus on enforcing existing laws and educating children about the dangers of vaping.

Title: Brands Reassess Trademarks Amid Growing Awareness of Harmful Stereotypes

The recent decision in the Matal v. Tam case, which ruled that the US Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) cannot refuse trademark registration based on the content of the mark, has had far-reaching implications. The case, brought by the Asian-American rock band The Slants, was seen as a victory for free speech. However, the outcome has had an unintended consequence: it has emboldened brands to re-examine their trademarks and eliminate harmful stereotypes.

The decision has led to a significant shift in the way brands approach their branding and marketing strategies. In recent days, several companies have announced changes to their branding, including Quaker Oats, which will change the name of its Aunt Jemima brand to make progress towards racial equality. The brand had long been criticized for its romanticization of antebellum American slavery, even going so far as to hire an actual former slave to impersonate the character of Aunt Jemima at the 1893 Chicago World's Fair.

The Mars corporation has also announced that its Uncle Ben's rice products will "evolve" in light of recent events. Even Mrs. Butterworth's pancake syrup, whose bottle features a racist caricature of a black woman, is undertaking a "complete brand and package review."

The decision in Matal v. Tam has had a profound impact on the way brands approach their trademarks. While the case was seen as a victory for free speech, it has also highlighted the need for brands to be more mindful of the impact their branding can have on marginalized communities. As brands continue to reassess their trademarks, it is clear that the decision has sparked a much-needed conversation about the importance of cultural sensitivity and awareness.

Title: Six Cities Vie for 2016 Democratic National Convention

The Democratic National Committee (DNC) has announced the six cities that have submitted bids to host the 2016 Democratic National Convention. The cities are Birmingham, Alabama; Cleveland, Ohio; Columbus, Ohio; New York; Philadelphia; and Phoenix. The technical advisory committee will evaluate the cities over the coming months, including site visits and other inquiries, with the decision expected to be announced later this year or in early 2015.

New York City, led by Mayor Bill de Blasio, is one of the final five cities vying for the convention. The city's bid focuses on Brooklyn as the main venue, with the Barclays Center serving as the principal site for the convention. Other events and accommodations will be spread across Brooklyn, Manhattan, and the city's other boroughs.

Philadelphia is the only city among the final five that has previously hosted a major party convention, having hosted the 2000 Republican National Convention, where George W. Bush was nominated as the party's standard bearer.

The other cities that submitted bids to the DNC include Atlanta, Chicago, Detroit, Indianapolis, Las Vegas, Miami, Nashville, Orlando, Pittsburgh, and Salt Lake City. The Republican National Committee (RNC) has already narrowed down its choices to Denver, Dallas, Cleveland, and Kansas City, with a final decision expected in the fall.

Title: Interactive Tool Helps Put Climate Change and COVID-19 in Perspective

The ACES: A Post-COVID Emissions Simulator, developed by artificial intelligence start-up HyperGiant, provides a free and interactive way to understand the impact of COVID-19 and climate change on the environment. The tool allows users to adjust pandemic-induced behaviors, such as working from home and reduced air travel, to calculate the resulting reduction in carbon dioxide emissions.

According to the simulator, if 30% of the workforce works from home, air traffic is reduced by 50%, and people eat 15% less meat, it would eliminate 18 billion tons of carbon dioxide, which is 38% of the way towards the changes dictated by the Paris climate accord. The tool also allows users to explore the impact of new technologies, such as carbon capture, renewable power generation, and revolutionary land management and agriculture strategies, to reach carbon neutrality.

For example, if 30% of the workforce works from home, air traffic is reduced by 50%, and people eat 15% less meat, and all vehicles in the U.S. are made electric, it would eliminate 33 billion tons of carbon dioxide by 2050, according to the simulator. However, this would not be enough to reach carbon neutrality and avoid the worst effects of climate change.

HyperGiant's climate advisor, Noam Bar-Zemer, notes that understanding the size of the climate problem relative to the size of potential solutions can be challenging. The tool aims to make it easier for people to compare and understand the impact of proposed solutions. HyperGiant, founded in 2018, has over 230 employees and generates mid-eight-figure revenue, according to CEO Ben Lamm.

Title: President Obama Weighs in on George Zimmerman Verdict, Discusses Racial Tensions

Article:

President Barack Obama recently addressed the George Zimmerman verdict, stating that he could have been Trayvon Martin, given his own experiences as an African American male. The president highlighted the historical context of racial tensions and the disproportionate involvement of African American young men in the criminal justice system. He acknowledged that this reality is not unique to the African American community, citing examples of white women clutching their purses when a black person enters an elevator.

However, some critics argue that the president's comments oversimplify the issue and fail to acknowledge the complexities of poverty, family dynamics, and societal pressures that contribute to violence in African American communities. They point out that not all poor people in these neighborhoods engage in violent behavior, and that there are many examples of African Americans who make different choices despite facing similar challenges.

The article also touches on the role of politics in shaping public discourse around race. The president's critics argue that he rarely comments on violence within the African American community, and that his silence perpetuates a narrative that only black lives matter when they are lost at the hands of non-blacks. They also point out that the president has not taken any significant steps to address the root causes of poverty, family dysfunction, and other social issues that contribute to violence in African American communities.
