According to reports, a coworker spotted the pistol case and called the police, who arrived and took the woman into custody. The Chicago Tribune reports that the woman was placed on leave by the university.

In a separate incident, a 22-year-old man was found stabbed to death in an alleyway, marking the 50th murder in the city this year. The victim was later identified as a resident of Calumet City.

President Obama is set to visit Chicago to promote his "cradle to career" educational initiatives, but the city's high murder rate is likely to be a topic of discussion. Chicago has seen a sharp increase in murders this year, with 535 reported in 2022, compared to a decline in murder rates nationwide.

Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel has taken a strong stance on gun control, implementing strict gun laws and advocating for stricter regulations. However, the recent arrest of the University of Illinois researcher highlights the complexity of the issue, as the woman was carrying a licensed, registered weapon that was unloaded and in a case.

The city's crime wave has led to concerns about public safety, with shopkeepers and homeowners demanding protection. The question remains whether a national gun ban would be effective in reducing murder rates, given the results in Chicago.

Title: House Democrats Urge Release of Non-Violent Immigrants from Detention to Prevent Spread of COVID-19

Two leading House Democrats, Chairwoman Carolyn Maloney (D-N.Y.) and Rep. Jamie Raskin (D-Md.), have written to the Department of Homeland Security and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) urging the immediate release of non-violent immigrants from detention to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. The lawmakers expressed concerns about the risk of the virus spreading rapidly inside overcrowded immigrant detention facilities, citing reports of detainees and staff testing positive for COVID-19 at multiple detention centers.

According to Maloney and Raskin, 19 immigrants detained at six facilities across the United States have contracted COVID-19, along with seven facility staff members. As of the end of March, over 35,000 immigrants were being detained across the country. ICE has already released at least 160 immigrants who were at risk of contracting the virus and has identified 600 others who are at higher risk.

ICE has stated that it is reviewing cases of individuals in detention who may be vulnerable to the virus, utilizing guidance from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and advice from medical professionals. The agency may place individuals in alternative detention options.

Maloney and Raskin are calling for the release of non-violent detainees, prioritizing those who are at higher risk for complications from the virus. They argue that releasing these individuals will prevent unnecessary infection, sickness, and death among both detainees and facility staff.

Title: Trump Calls for Multiple News Outlets Amid Rumors of CNN Sale

Article:

President Donald Trump expressed his support for having "as many news outlets as you can" during a press conference on Air Force One, amidst rumors of a potential sale of CNN as part of the proposed merger between AT&T and Time Warner. Trump's statement comes as the Department of Justice (DOJ) and AT&T are in negotiations over the $85 billion merger, with conflicting reports emerging about whether the DOJ is mandating the sale of CNN.

The President's comments were met with skepticism by some, who alleged that he may be seeking to retaliate against CNN for his frequent criticism of the network as "fake news." However, the head of the DOJ's antitrust division, Makan Delrahim, denied any involvement by the White House in the transaction, stating that he has never been instructed by the White House on this or any other transaction under review by the antitrust division.

The White House also denied any involvement, with spokesman Raj Shah stating that the President did not speak with the Attorney General about the matter and no White House official was authorized to speak with the DOJ on this matter.

Trump himself maintained that he was not involved in the decision, saying "I didn't make that decision - it was made by a man who's a very respected person, a very very respected person." The President also vowed to block the merger during his campaign last year, citing concerns about the concentration of power in the hands of too few.

The exact details of the proposed merger and any potential sale of CNN remain unclear, with both AT&T and Time Warner declining to comment on the matter.

Title: IRS Awards Over $2.8 Million in Bonuses to Employees with Disciplinary Issues

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has faced numerous controversies in recent years, from the targeting of conservative groups to the individual mandate tax. Amidst this backdrop, a recent report by the Treasury inspector general for tax administration revealed that the agency paid over $2.8 million in bonuses to employees with recent disciplinary problems, including those who owed back taxes. The bonuses were awarded between October 2010 and December 2012.

According to the report, over 2,800 employees received bonuses despite facing disciplinary action in the previous year. This includes 1,150 employees who owed back taxes. The report noted that the bonus program does not violate federal regulations, but it is inconsistent with the IRS's mission to enforce tax laws.

The news has sparked outrage among some, with many questioning the fairness of awarding bonuses to employees who have been disciplined for not paying their own taxes. As Mary Katharine Ham noted, it is unclear why the IRS cannot codify a rule prohibiting such bonuses, given the agency's role in collecting taxes.

The timing of this revelation is particularly sensitive, as the IRS is already facing scrutiny over its handling of the individual mandate tax and its treatment of conservative groups. The report's findings have sparked calls for reforms within the agency, but it remains to be seen whether this public embarrassment will lead to meaningful changes.

Title: Rep. Patrick Meehan Resigns Amid Ethics Investigation, Escaping Accountability

Article:

Rep. Patrick Meehan, a Republican representative from Pennsylvania, announced his resignation on Friday, effectively ending an ethics committee investigation into allegations of sexual harassment and the use of taxpayer funds to pay a settlement. The House Ethics Committee has no jurisdiction over lawmakers once they leave office, meaning the investigation will be closed. However, Meehan has promised to repay the taxpayer-funded settlement, but there is no mechanism to ensure he makes good on that pledge.

This resignation is the second this month, following Rep. Blake Farenthold's resignation amid a similar controversy. Farenthold, a Texas Republican, resigned on April 6 after allegations of sexual harassment and the use of taxpayer funds to pay an $84,000 settlement. Like Meehan, Farenthold promised to repay the settlement, but has yet to do so.

The House voted earlier this year to change its sexual harassment policies, requiring members to pay out of their own pockets for any sexual harassment settlements even after they leave office. However, the measure has stalled in the Senate, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell reportedly objecting. Senators Roy Blunt and Amy Klobuchar, the top Republican and Democrat on the Senate Rules Committee, are working on a compromise proposal and hope to release it in the coming weeks.

The hold-up is due to unclear language in the House-passed legislation, with some lawmakers pushing for the liability provisions to be narrowed. Even if lawmakers reach an agreement, it would not address the ability of lawmakers to keep ethics committee findings under wraps by resigning.

Jan Baran, a Washington attorney who specializes in federal ethics matters, noted that some lawmakers only resign when they see "the handwriting on the wall." He cited the case of ex-Sen. John Ensign, who faced allegations of using campaign funds to pay his mistress and her family. Ensign eventually paid $54,000 in civil penalties to the Federal Election Commission to settle a parallel case.

The resignation of Rep. Meehan and Rep. Farenthold highlights the need for stronger ethics laws and accountability measures to ensure lawmakers are held accountable for their actions.

Title: Celebrities Gather to Discuss Elizabeth Warren's Potential Presidential Run

Article:

A recent gathering of celebrities and influencers in a Chinatown loft aimed to discuss the potential presidential run of Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren. The event, dubbed "Artists for Warren," brought together around 150 "cultural tastemakers" who are lending their support to the senator. The attendees included actors Mark Ruffalo, Edward Norton, Susan Sarandon, Natasha Lyonne, Olivia Wilde, and Kim Gordon, among others.

According to Vanity Fair, the gathering aimed to convince Warren to take on Hillary Clinton in the Democratic primary. Ruffalo, who was scheduled to show an exclusive video at the event, explained that even if Warren doesn't win the primary, she will still push the conversation towards progressive values. The article notes that The New York Times and The Atlantic have also published pieces supporting Warren's candidacy.

The article also quotes Rutgers political-science professor Ross Baker, who explained that there is a constituency on the Democratic left that has never forgiven the Clintons for welfare reform. The event's menu featured charred broccoli with roasted eggplant and a meatless "Superiority Burger," as described by Vanity Fair.

The gathering's purpose is to generate buzz and support for Warren's potential presidential run. While the event's attendees are experts on little else, they are certainly experts on their own celebrity status.

Title: Poll Reveals Democrats More Likely to Believe Election Was Rigged, Despite Lack of Evidence

A recent poll conducted by the Media Research Center and YouGov has shed light on the ongoing debate surrounding the 2016 presidential election. The survey found that despite a lack of evidence, Democrats are more likely to believe that Russia tampered with the vote tallies to get Donald Trump elected. The poll asked respondents whether it is true or false that "Russia tampered with vote tallies in order to get Donald Trump elected President." The results showed that despite half a year's worth of news developments and no concrete evidence, Democrats are more likely to believe the election was rigged now than they were initially.

The poll also explored public opinion on James Comey, the former FBI director who was fired by Trump in May. Despite being a polarizing figure, the survey found that Democrats now favor Comey, with 42% having a positive view of him, while Republicans disfavor him, with 57% having a negative view. This shift in opinion is attributed to Trump's preferences, with Democrats aligning themselves with the former president's stance on Comey.

The poll's findings are consistent with another recent survey conducted by Harvard-Harris, which also showed Comey in positive territory among Democrats. However, the YouGov poll was conducted before the news about Comey's memo broke, making it unlikely that the shift in opinion is due to new information. Instead, the results suggest that partisan tribalism is driving perceptions of Comey.

The poll highlights the ongoing challenges in addressing misinformation and the importance of fact-based decision-making. Despite the lack of evidence, the notion that Russia tampered with the election has persisted, and the public's perception of Comey remains divided along party lines.

Title: Clinton Emphasizes Women's Issues as Economic Agenda in New Hampshire Rally

In a speech delivered in Portsmouth, New Hampshire, Hillary Clinton, the Democratic front-runner, defined her entire economic agenda as a women's issue, emphasizing the impact of her policies on women's lives. The rally, attended by about 1,000 supporters, marked the first time Clinton has placed her domestic and economic agenda in terms of how it affects women.

Clinton highlighted several issues, including childcare, paid family leave, equal pay, and the minimum wage, stating that these issues are not only women's issues but also economic issues. She emphasized that women should not have to lose their paychecks or jobs when they have a baby or someone in their family gets sick.

Clinton also took aim at Republican presidential candidates, specifically mentioning Donald Trump and Dr. Ben Carson, criticizing their stances on women's health and reproductive rights. She emphasized that her opponents' views on these issues are not only harmful to women but also have broader economic implications.

The rally took place in New Hampshire, a state with a history of electing women to its highest offices, including Clinton herself, who won the state's primary in 2008. Clinton's speech was seen as a nod to the state's strong support for women's rights and its reputation as a leader in women's empowerment.

Clinton's emphasis on women's issues is a departure from her 2008 campaign, where she shied away from explicitly gender-based appeals. This time around, she is hoping that a real contrast on the issues will motivate female voters and help her win the general election.

Title: Trump Announces Plan to Distance Himself from Business Interests

Article:

President Donald Trump has announced that he will be taking steps to distance himself from his business interests, citing the importance of avoiding conflicts of interest. Trump stated that he will be holding a news conference in New York City on December 15 to discuss his plan, which involves transferring his business operations to his children and existing Trump Organization executives.

According to Trump, this move is necessary to ensure that his business interests do not interfere with his duties as President. He emphasized that the law is on his side, stating that the President cannot have a conflict of interest. Trump has previously discussed the possibility of a "blind trust," but it appears that this plan has been scrapped in favor of a more limited approach.

Under Trump's plan, his children and Trump Organization executives will manage his business operations, while he focuses on his duties as President. Trump has not provided further details on the specifics of the plan, but it is unclear whether this approach will be sufficient to address concerns about conflicts of interest.

It is worth noting that Trump's previous statements on the issue have been met with skepticism, as he has continued to involve his family members and business associates in his decision-making process. The effectiveness of Trump's plan remains to be seen, and it is unclear whether it will be enough to quell concerns about the potential for conflicts of interest.

Title: The Case Against Confederate Statues: A Reevaluation of America's History

The removal of Confederate statues has been a contentious issue in the United States, with some advocating for their preservation and others calling for their removal. The debate has sparked a wave of cancellations, with Confederate statues being graffitied, assaulted, and torn down. President Donald Trump has been a vocal defender of the statues, stating that they should be preserved and that the country should build on its heritage rather than tear it down.

Conservatives have also expressed opposition to the removal of Confederate symbols, fearing that it will lead to the erasure of American history and the destruction of cultural heritage. However, others argue that Confederate statues and symbols are an affront to black citizens, who should not have to see defenders of chattel slavery put on a pedestal.

The statues were often erected as part of a push to enshrine a dishonest and sanitized version of the Confederacy, and many were built to make a point about the supposed glories of the Confederacy. While some argue that the statues should be preserved in museums or battlefields, others believe that they should be removed from prominent public spaces.

The Confederate flag, which has been used as a symbol of a viciously flawed cause, should be shunned, while direct commemorations of the Confederate war dead, such as obelisks with lists of names and Confederate cemeteries, should be preserved to mark the human cost of a terrible conflict.

The removal of Confederate statues is not a new phenomenon, with the Richmond statue of Robert E. Lee, which is set to be removed, being a point of contention. The statue's unveiling in 1890 was a key moment in the creation of a cult of Lee as a man of "moral strength and moral beauty," which was later scorned by Frederick Douglass.

The apotheosis of Lee was part of a Lost Cause mythology that maintained that the Civil War was not truly about slavery, but rather Southern states defending their legitimate rights. However, this theory was debunked by Alexander Stephens, the vice president of the Confederacy, who said that the new government was built on the "great truth" of slavery.

In conclusion, while some argue that Confederate statues should be preserved, others believe that they should be removed from prominent public spaces and reevaluated in the context of American history. The removal of Confederate statues is a complex issue that requires a nuanced understanding of the context in which they were erected and the impact they have on contemporary society.

Title: Federal Judge Rules President Obama's Immigration Executive Actions Unconstitutional in Criminal Case

Article:

A federal judge in Pennsylvania has ruled that President Barack Obama's recent executive actions on immigration are unconstitutional, but the decision came in a criminal case, leaving its broader impact uncertain. U.S. District Court Judge Arthur Schwab issued the ruling on Tuesday in the case of Elionardo Juarez-Escobar, a Honduran immigrant charged with unlawful re-entry after being arrested earlier this year in Pennsylvania for drunken driving.

Judge Schwab's 38-page opinion stated that President Obama's November 20, 2014 Executive Action goes beyond prosecutorial discretion because it provides for a systematic and rigid process by which a broad group of individuals will be treated differently than others based on arbitrary classifications, rather than case-by-case examination. The judge also noted that the action allows undocumented immigrants who fall within these broad categories to obtain substantive rights.

The Pittsburgh-based judge rejected the Justice Department's legal opinion arguing that Obama's actions fall within the traditional realm of the executive's discretion about which cases to pursue and which to overlook. Schwab, a George W. Bush appointee, also quoted in detail from a series of public statements Obama made in recent years about the limits on his executive authority to make sweeping changes in immigration enforcement.

A Justice Department spokesman rejected the judge's legal rationale and his decision to opine on the legality of Obama's actions, stating that the decision is unfounded and the court had no basis to issue such an order. The department also argued that the executive actions did not apply to the criminal matter before the court.

The ruling has sparked reactions from both sides of the immigration debate. While some see it as a political swipe at Obama, others question why his actions do not apply to criminal prosecutions as well as deportations. The judge's opinion raises the question of what is the point of protecting immigrants from being expelled from the country if they can still be sent to prison for having illegally entered the country in the first place.

The ruling is not expected to have a significant impact on the broader debate over Obama's immigration policies, as it was made in a criminal case and does not address the constitutionality of the executive actions in a more direct way. However, the judge's opinion could have some influence on the pending lawsuits challenging Obama's policies in Washington, D.C. and Brownsville, Texas.

Title: Trump's Unconventional Approach to Governance: A New Era in American Politics?

Article:

President Donald Trump took office in 2017 amidst widespread skepticism and negative media coverage. According to the Pew Research Center, 62% of news stories about his first 60 days were negative, compared to 20% for President Obama and 28% for Bush and Clinton. However, Trump's supporters had different expectations, and he is not disappointing them. As he navigates Washington with his unique approach, it is reminiscent of Frank Sinatra's classic song, "My Way."

Trump is indeed doing things his way, and it's causing some to take notice. The economy is growing, the most significant tax reform since 1986 has been passed, and deregulation is underway. The number of pages in the Federal Register, where new regulations are published, is now two-thirds of what it was during the Obama years. Trump has already made his mark on the nation, with 12 federal appeals court judge nominations confirmed by the Senate and Neil Gorsuch taking Antonin Scalia's seat on the Supreme Court.

With two Supreme Court justices over 80, Anthony Kennedy and Ruth Bader Ginsburg, it's likely that Trump will have the opportunity to place another conservative on the Court during his first term. Reports suggest that Trump will meet with Senate Majority Leader McConnell and House Speaker Ryan soon at Camp David to discuss legislative plans for 2018. Major campaign issues still on the table include immigration reform, welfare reform, and national infrastructure investments.

It's reasonable to expect that the product of these deliberations will reflect a combination of idealism and political realism. McConnell's challenge in the Senate has increased with his Republican margin now a razor-thin 51 to 49. On the other hand, Trump has a reputation for being a man with plans to accomplish his goals, even if it means going against the grain.

Trump's recognition of Jerusalem as the capital city of Israel is an example of his willingness to take a stance despite opposition. In immigration reform and welfare reform, two issues with significant impacts on the nation, Trump has the opportunity to make a meaningful difference. However, the inability of Washington to address these issues is what drove many voters to Trump in the first place. If he ignores or forgets this, he risks becoming just another politician.

Title: Stocks Surge to Best Day This Year Amid Speculation of Government Support

Stocks in the United States and Europe surged to their best day this year, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 286.84 points to close at 12,414.79. The rally was fueled by speculation that governments in the U.S. and Europe may take action to support their economies.

Atlanta Federal Reserve President Dennis Lockhart said in a speech that weak job growth over the past two months highlighted the "halting and tenuous" recovery. He noted that if the trend continues, "further monetary actions to support the recovery will certainly need to be considered."

Meanwhile, news reports indicated that Germany and European Union officials were considering a plan to lend money from the European bailout fund to help rescue Spain's hobbled banks. This development sent stocks higher, with the Dow Jones industrial average turning positive for 2012 and erasing the biggest loss of the year.

The rally was led by companies whose stocks have been clobbered the most over the past month, including homebuilders Hovnanian Enterprises, PulteGroup Inc., and Lennar Corp. Hovnanian's CEO said he sees signs that the housing industry may be entering the early stages of recovery, while the Mortgage Bankers Association reported that applications for mortgages rose 1.3 percent last week.

The gains were spread across the market, with only 11 companies in the S&P 500 dropping, and every industry group in the index rising, led by energy and financial companies. Roughly seven stocks rose for every one that fell on the New York Stock Exchange.

Jim Russell, chief equity strategist at U.S. Bank Wealth Management, said it's natural for the market to have a strong day after an extended beat-down. "In market language, it's called a technical bounce," he said. "There's no bad news today, so the market goes up. Frankly, it's that simple."

U.S. markets followed major European indexes higher, with indexes rising 2.4 percent in the U.K. and France. Borrowing costs eased for Spain, another positive sign. A Federal Reserve survey showed growth across the country, with hiring steady, according to the Fed's "Beige Book."

Title: Clinton's Relief and Challenges in New Hampshire Primary

The article discusses Hillary Clinton's relief and challenges as she approaches the New Hampshire primary. Clinton, who has been a known quantity for decades, is facing a tough competition from Bernie Sanders, a 74-year-old socialist who has gained popularity among Democratic voters. The article highlights Clinton's struggles to connect with voters and her need to shift her campaign's tone from defensive to more optimistic.

The article also touches on Clinton's past mistakes, such as her inability to connect with voters in 2008 and her perceived lack of authenticity. It notes that Clinton's repeated invocation of her work on behalf of President Obama and her post-Obama work on the speech circuit may not be enough to win over voters.

The article also mentions Clinton's family's financial ties to Goldman Sachs, which could be a liability in the general election. It notes that Clinton's husband, Bill, and daughter, Chelsea, have made millions from speaking fees, which could raise questions about the family's trustworthiness.

The article concludes by noting that Clinton's campaign needs to shift its tone and focus on personality and passion, rather than simply touting her experience and credentials. It also notes that Sanders lacks the cutthroat skills to exploit Clinton's weaknesses, but that a more adroit rival could potentially do so.

Title: Trump Admits Son Met Russian Lawyer to Gather Information on Opponent, But Denies Knowledge

Article:

US President Donald Trump has acknowledged that his son, Donald Trump Jr., met with a Russian lawyer, Natalia Veselnitskaya, in June 2016 to gather information on an opponent, but has denied any knowledge of the meeting. The meeting has been investigated by Special Counsel Robert Mueller as part of his inquiry into Russia's alleged role in helping Trump win the 2016 presidential election.

According to reports, Trump Jr. met with Veselnitskaya at Trump Tower, and the meeting has been described as a "short introductory meeting" that focused on Russian adoptions. However, Trump Jr. later admitted that he was promised damaging information about Hillary Clinton before the meeting, but claimed that "no meaningful information" was exchanged.

The meeting has raised concerns that Trump Jr. may have violated campaign finance laws, which prohibit accepting anything of value from a foreign government or national. Legal experts argue that Trump Jr.'s enthusiastic response to the offer of information about Clinton could also breach conspiracy laws.

Trump's lawyer, Jay Sekulow, has denied that the meeting broke any laws, stating that "nobody's pointed to one." However, some analysts believe that by having the meeting at all, Trump Jr. may have broken the law.

The meeting is part of a larger investigation into Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 election, which Trump has called the "greatest political witch hunt in history." Russia has repeatedly denied any involvement in the election.

The investigation is ongoing, and it remains to be seen whether Trump Jr.'s meeting with Veselnitskaya will be deemed illegal or unethical.

Title: Trump's Foreign Policy Uncertainties Spark Global Concerns

The world is holding its breath as President-elect Donald Trump prepares to take office, with many nations worried about the implications of his campaign rhetoric on global security and alliances. Trump's comments on NATO, the alliance that has underpinned global peace and security since World War II, have raised concerns about the future of the partnership. He has questioned the value of the alliance, suggesting that European allies are "ripping off" the United States and that Washington should charge more for its defense.

While Trump is correct that European defense spending is lower than the 2% of GDP target, NATO serves American interests as much as European ones. The alliance has participated in major anti-terrorism efforts, including the 10-year war in Afghanistan, and has contributed to the fight against Islamic State in Syria and Iraq.

Trump has also called NATO "obsolete" and suggested that the alliance should focus on new challenges such as migration and terrorism. However, NATO has already addressed these issues, with member countries contributing to naval forces to stem illegal immigration in the Aegean and participating in counter-terrorism efforts.

The Baltic nations, which were once part of the Soviet Union and are now NATO members, are particularly nervous about Moscow's intentions, having watched Russia annex Crimea. Trump has indicated he might acquiesce in Crimea's fate and called for improved relations with Moscow.

In Asia, Trump's stance on North Korea and China has raised concerns. He has suggested that the United States might pull its forces out of South Korea unless Seoul pays more for their upkeep, and has not clarified his plan to prevent North Korea from developing a nuclear weapon. Japan, which suffered a nuclear attack in World War II, is particularly concerned about the potential for a destabilizing arms race in Asia.

In Australia, Trump's election has thrown long-held assumptions about the country's security into question, as China flexes its military muscle more assertively. The country's defense analyst, Dr. Peter Dean, notes that Australia's approach to the rise of China has been to build a deeper and broader alliance with the United States, and that becoming an independent state would require significant increases in defense spending.

As Trump prepares to take office, the world is waiting to see how his words will translate into action, and whether his campaign rhetoric will lead to a more isolated and uncertain world.

Title: Georgia Secretary of State Investigates Voter Registration Drive, Accusations of Voter Suppression Fly

The Georgia Secretary of State's office has launched an investigation into a voter registration drive by the New Georgia Project, a group founded by Georgia House Minority Leader Rep. Stacey Abrams. The investigation centers around allegations of fraud and forgery in the group's efforts to register over 100,000 minority voters before the October 6 deadline.

Rev. Raphael Warnock, pastor of Atlanta's Ebenezer Baptist Church and a prominent supporter of the New Georgia Project, has spoken out against the investigation, calling it a form of voter suppression. "You don't have to wear a hood or be a member of the Ku Klux Klan to be engaged in voter suppression," Warnock said at a press conference. "We know voter suppression when we see it."

Georgia Secretary of State Brian Kemp's office has confirmed 28 cases of fraud in 14 counties, including 25 fraudulent voter registration applications and three fraudulent canvassing sheets. Some of the applications had forged signatures, while others contained false information. An additional 26 cases were labeled suspicious.

Falsifying a voter registration form is a felony in the state of Georgia. Kemp has stated that any instance of fraud is "very serious" and that his office is working to identify those responsible.

The New Georgia Project has denied any wrongdoing and has accused Kemp's office of launching a "witch hunt" and "fishing expedition." The group has also claimed that the subpoena issued by Kemp's office is "overly burdensome" and is taking valuable time away from their voter registration drive.

The investigation has become a hot-button issue in the race to replace retiring U.S. Sen. Saxby Chambliss, with polls showing Democratic candidate Michelle Nunn narrowly trailing Republican David Perdue. The New Georgia Project's efforts to register minority voters could potentially swing the election in Nunn's favor.

Kemp has denied any allegations of voter suppression and has stated that his office is simply doing its job in investigating reports of fraud and forgery. The Secretary of State has also emphasized that any valid voter registration forms will be processed by the appropriate county officials.

The controversy has sparked heated rhetoric on both sides, with the New Georgia Project accusing Kemp's office of a pattern of voter suppression and intimidation, while Kemp has denied any wrongdoing and has called for an end to the "dog and pony show" of subpoenas and accusations.

Title: Democratic National Committee Chairman Encourages States to Hold Presidential Primaries Amid COVID-19 Pandemic

The Democratic National Committee Chairman, Tom Perez, is urging states to proceed with their scheduled presidential primaries despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and federal social distancing guidelines. On Tuesday, Florida, Illinois, and Arizona held their elections as planned, while Ohio, Georgia, Kentucky, and Louisiana postponed theirs to mitigate the spread of the virus.

Perez praised the states that went ahead with their primaries, citing the example of Arizona, where more people voted early than in the entire 2016 Democratic primary. He emphasized that it is not a choice between protecting safety and democracy, but rather a way to ensure both. The Arizona Democratic Party reported a surge in turnout due to early mail-in voting, which Perez is encouraging other states to adopt.

However, not all states were willing to take the risk. Ohio Governor Mike DeWine (R) refused to hold his state's primary on Tuesday, pushing it back to June instead. DeWine explained that he did not want to force voters and poll workers to choose between their health and their constitutional rights and duties.

The two leading Democratic presidential candidates, former Vice President Joe Biden and Senator Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), chose not to campaign in person and instead reached out to voters online in Florida, Illinois, and Arizona. Biden ultimately won all three states.

Title: Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl Faces Charges of Desertion and Misbehavior Toward the Enemy

Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who was exchanged in a prisoner swap by the Obama administration in 2014, has been charged with desertion and misbehavior toward the enemy under the Uniform Code of Military Justice. Bergdahl's legal defense team will argue that he did not desert his unit, but was attempting to report wrongdoing within his Army unit. However, a report from the Naval Criminal Investigative Service (NCIS) suggests that Bergdahl deliberately deserted his unit and sought out the Taliban and other enemies of the United States.

According to a 2009 NCIS investigation, Bergdahl had Afghan contacts and was attempting to offer himself up to the Taliban. This investigation resulted in Bergdahl being charged with misbehavior toward the enemy. Lt. Col. Anthony Shaffer, who discussed the investigation on Fox News' "The O'Reilly Factor," stated that Bergdahl had a deliberate plan to go over to the other side and that he was trying to offer himself up with the Taliban. Shaffer also noted that President Obama had to have known about Bergdahl's desertion through the NCIS before making the decision to negotiate his release.

A preliminary Article 32 hearing has been scheduled for Bergdahl's case, which will be held at Ft. Sam Houston, Texas. The exact date of the hearing has not been announced.

Title: Senate Debates Keystone XL Pipeline Vote Amid Pressure from Both Sides

The Senate is facing pressure to vote on the Keystone XL pipeline, with some lawmakers pushing for a binding vote and others advocating for a non-binding "sense of the Senate" resolution. The debate comes as Majority Leader Harry Reid is under pressure to take action on the project, which has been stalled for over five years.

A bipartisan bill to approve the pipeline was introduced on Thursday, but Reid has not yet indicated whether he will allow a vote. Some lawmakers, including Republican Senator John Thune, are pushing for a binding vote that would force the issue on the White House. Others, like Senator Jeanne Shaheen, are supporting a non-binding resolution that would simply express support for the pipeline.

The debate is also being fueled by the Obama administration's decision to delay a decision on the pipeline last month. Some lawmakers, including Senator Mary Landrieu, are frustrated with the delay and are pushing for a vote in the coming weeks.

The Keystone XL pipeline has been a contentious issue, with some arguing that it would create jobs and reduce dependence on foreign oil, while others believe it would harm the environment and increase carbon emissions. The Senate has already passed a non-binding resolution in support of the pipeline, but some lawmakers are pushing for a binding vote to move the project forward.

The White House has expressed concerns that a binding vote could slow down the process and has urged lawmakers to "run it by the book" outside of politics. However, critics argue that the project has already been delayed for over five years and that further delays would be detrimental to the economy and the environment.

The debate is expected to continue in the coming weeks, with some lawmakers pushing for a vote on the pipeline as part of a broader energy efficiency bill.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Email Scandal Continues to Damage Her Presidential Ambitions

Article:

Hillary Clinton is facing renewed scrutiny over her use of a private email server while serving as Secretary of State, with new reports suggesting that her messages contained classified information above the "top secret" level. The intelligence community's inspector general, I. Charles McCullough, revealed in a letter to Congress that the information is so sensitive that even senators with clearance must go through additional hoops to access it.

The Clinton campaign has responded by accusing McCullough of politically motivated leaks aimed at sabotaging her campaign. However, the slow drip of the email scandal has already taken a toll on Clinton's presidential ambitions. Surveys show that voters view her as less honest and trustworthy than her primary challenger, Senator Bernie Sanders.

A recent Quinnipiac University poll found that 93% of Democratic primary voters consider Sanders honest and trustworthy, while just 66% said the same of Clinton. A CNN survey conducted this month found that 55% of Democratic voters consider Clinton the "least honest" candidate in the race.

The latest revelations suggest that Clinton's private email server contained several dozen more classified emails than previously thought, including some from "special access programs" or SAP. Even top members of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations are unable to view these messages without additional security steps, including signing new nondisclosure agreements.

Clinton has maintained that she never knowingly sent or received classified information on her private server, which was housed outside the formal State.gov domain. However, her campaign has faced criticism for its handling of the email controversy, with many arguing that the messages appear to have been forwards of a New York Times article on a classified drone program.

The State Department is under a court order to produce about 55,000 emails from Clinton's home server, with most having been released and the last expected on January 29. Clinton's use of private email has dogged her since it was first revealed publicly in March 2015, and she has since said she regrets using the private server.

Specialists say that voters on the fence in the Democratic primary election may very well take the email scandal – and the larger questions about Clinton's honesty – into account when picking a candidate. "The problem for Hillary Clinton is that there are alternatives to her candidacy in Bernie Sanders," said Brandon Rottinghaus, a political science professor at the University of Houston who specializes in political leadership. "This is why polls of Democrats don't think Sanders can win the general election but are willing to vote for him anyway."

Title: Secretary of State John Kerry's Comments on Israel Spark Controversy

Article:

Secretary of State John Kerry recently sparked controversy when he made comments suggesting that Israel could become an "apartheid state" if it does not come to a two-state agreement with the Palestinians. Kerry made the statement in a closed-door meeting with influential world leaders, stating that if Israel does not make peace soon, it could become "an apartheid state, like the old South Africa."

The comments have been met with strong reactions from Jewish leaders, who are fuming over the comparison. Senior American officials have rarely used the term "apartheid" in reference to Israel, and President Obama has previously rejected the idea that the word should apply to the Jewish state.

Kerry has since walked back his comments, denying that he made the "apartheid" comment and stating that he should have used different words to describe the situation. In a statement, Kerry emphasized his commitment to Israel and denied that he had ever suggested that Israel intends to become an apartheid state.

The controversy has also led to a renewed focus on the Democratic Party's stance on Israel. The Orthodox Union, a Jewish advocacy group, pointed out that the 2012 Democratic National Convention refused to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, a decision that has been criticized by some as a betrayal of Israel's sovereignty.

The controversy highlights the ongoing challenges and complexities of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, as well as the delicate balance that Secretary of State Kerry must navigate in his efforts to promote peace and stability in the region.

Title: Obama's Aggressive Use of Executive Power on Gun Control Raises Questions

The article discusses President Barack Obama's recent actions on gun control, which have sparked controversy and debate. As a candidate, Obama criticized President George W. Bush's use of executive power, but now, seven years into his own presidency, Obama is using executive action to push for gun control measures. The article highlights the new measures, including tightening the "gun-show loophole" and boosting enforcement of federal gun laws, as well as the potential for congressional approval.

The article also notes that some of Obama's measures require congressional approval, while others, enacted by executive order, have the force of law but can be undone by the next president. The article quotes Republican presidential candidates, including Donald Trump, Ted Cruz, and Chris Christie, who have criticized Obama's aggressive use of executive power.

The article also notes that the reality is that whoever the next president is, they are likely to follow Obama's lead on the use of executive authority. The article concludes by stating that Obama has shown a willingness to send his advisers back to interpret laws even more permissively to find ways to circumvent Congress and get things done.

The article provides a neutral and factual account of the situation, presenting both sides of the debate and highlighting the controversy surrounding Obama's use of executive power.

Title: Troubled Past of Florida School Shooter Nikolas Cruz Revealed

The 19-year-old suspect in the recent mass shooting at a South Florida high school, Nikolas Cruz, had a history of disturbing behavior and hints of future violence before the tragic event. According to an acquaintance, Cruz would often introduce himself as "I'm Nick, I'm a school shooter." He also posted photos on Instagram featuring guns and knives and made a chilling online comment about a mass shooting carried out in New York this summer.

Cruz's attorneys have described him as having a chronic battle with mental illness and depression, which was exacerbated by the recent death of his adoptive mother, Lynda Cruz. He was taken in by the parents of a schoolmate after his mother's death, according to the family's attorney.

A former classmate, who grew up with Cruz and attended school with him since the sixth grade, described him as "very, very strange" and said he would sometimes introduce himself as a "school shooter." The classmate recalled that Cruz would often get into trouble and was known for stealing mail, throwing rocks at cars, and tormenting animals.

Documents obtained by CNN show that law enforcement officers responded to Cruz's house on 39 occasions over a seven-year period, but no police reports were immediately available for those calls, making it unclear whether Cruz was involved.

Another neighbor, who asked not to be identified, took video of Cruz dressed in boxer shorts shooting what appeared to be a BB gun in his backyard. The neighbor described Cruz as "acting weird" and said he sometimes pointed the gun toward their window.

Cruz had two Instagram accounts featuring weapons and photos. In one picture, he is wearing a kerchief over his face and a Make America Great Again hat. Another photo is taken from behind a gun sight looking out the window. He also made an online comment in response to a story about a disgruntled doctor in New York who used an AR-15 to shoot seven people, killing one and wounding six others.

Not everyone who crossed paths with Cruz saw reason for concern. The attorney for the family who took him in after his mother's death said they were aware of trouble he'd earlier had at school and saw signs of depression. However, they did not see any danger.

Hunter Vukelich, a former manager at a Dollar Tree store where Cruz worked, said he saw nothing alarming about the young man who would ride his bike back and forth to the job. "You could tell he was a little off, but not dangerous," Vukelich said.

According to authorities, Cruz was initially able to leave the crime scene at the school by blending in with students fleeing campus in the wake of the massacre. He went to a Walmart and a McDonald's before being found by police and taken into custody. He has since confessed to the killings, according to court documents.

Gordon Weekes, one of Cruz's public defenders, said he believed Cruz has been placed on suicide watch. He said the defense team would be exploring mental health issues and "the possibility of autism." "We are trying to save this young man's life," he said.

Title: GOP Needs a Scientific Revolution to Improve Political Strategy

The recent Conservative Political Action Conference saw a heated discussion about the performance of Republican consultants, with some critics accusing them of being ideologically soft and more focused on approval from the Washington elite and profits than on achieving political victories. This criticism is part of a growing chorus of discontent with the Romney campaign, the Republican Party, and conservative organizations.

Critics argue that the Romney campaign's polling, messaging, strategy, tactics, and targeting were all failures, suggesting not just incompetence but malfeasance on the part of those in charge. However, some experts warn against turning this self-examination into a witch-hunt, instead advocating for a more scientific approach to determine what works and what doesn't.

The article highlights the Democratic Party's use of social science experiments to test the effectiveness of their messages and tactics, a practice that has been adopted by progressive interest groups for over a decade. This approach allows for the development of an objective base of knowledge on what works and what doesn't, with expert opinions being treated as hypotheses to be tested through experiments.

The article notes that the Obama campaign invested heavily in grassroots field offices, which were found to be the most effective way to increase voter turnout through randomized-controlled experiments. Similarly, the campaign's use of video pledges and voter report cards was found to be effective in getting out the vote.

The article concludes that the Republican Party and conservative organizations would benefit from adopting a similar scientific approach to improve their political strategy and tactics, rather than relying on conventional wisdom and personal opinions.

Title: Russian Cyberattacks: A Growing Concern in the United States

The Russian cyberattacks on the United States have been a growing concern for years, with the country's intelligence agencies and cybersecurity experts warning of the potential threats. While the Chinese have been more brazen in their cyberattacks, stealing designs for the F-35 fighter jet, corporate secrets, and blueprints for gas pipelines that supply much of the United States, the Russians have been more stealthy.

According to Kevin Mandia, a former Air Force intelligence officer and founder of Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm, the Russians have been quick to turn their attacks to political purposes. In 2007, a cyberattack on Estonia, a former Soviet republic that had joined NATO, sent a message that Russia could paralyze the country without invading it. The next year, cyberattacks were used during Russia's war with Georgia.

However, American officials did not imagine that the Russians would dare try those techniques inside the United States. They were focused on preventing what former Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta warned was an approaching "cyber Pearl Harbor" - a shutdown of the power grid or cellphone networks.

In 2014 and 2015, a Russian hacking group began systematically targeting the State Department, the White House, and the Joint Chiefs of Staff. According to Michael Sulmeyer, a former cyberexpert for the secretary of defense, and Ben Buchanan, now both of the Harvard Cyber Security Project, the Russians grew stealthier and stealthier, tricking government computers into sending out data while disguising the electronic "command and control" messages that set off alarms for anyone looking for malicious actions.

The State Department was so crippled that it repeatedly closed its systems to throw out the intruders. At one point, officials traveling to Vienna with Secretary of State John Kerry for the Iran nuclear negotiations had to set up commercial Gmail accounts just to communicate with one another and with reporters traveling with them.

Former President Barack Obama was briefed regularly on the cyberattacks, but he made a decision that many in the White House now regret: he did not name Russians publicly, or issue sanctions. There was always a reason: fear of escalating a cyberwar, and concern that the United States needed Russia's cooperation in negotiations over Syria.

Title: Republican Presidential Debate: Winners and Losers in the Face of Terrorism

The fifth Republican presidential debate, held in Las Vegas, saw a focus on terrorism and national security, with several candidates showcasing their strengths and weaknesses. The debate, which took place on the eve of the holiday season, produced some clear winners and losers.

Marco Rubio, the Florida senator, was one of the most consistent debaters throughout the election season, conveying clear convictions and a common-sense policy framework. He avoided the Senate speak that afflicted others on stage and showcased a likeability that emanates from his personal story.

Ted Cruz, the Texas senator, was the most relentless counter-puncher, scoring points with his passion and black-and-white diagnoses of issues that appeal to evangelicals and others in the conservative wing of the party.

Donald Trump, the billionaire businessman, delivered another Main Act performance, scoring points with his take-no-hostages, make-no-apologies style that rails against the political ruling class. His humorous embrace of Ted Cruz near the end of the debate was a classic showman at work.

Lindsey Graham, the South Carolina senator, was the dominant winner of the undercard debate, with his communication skills honed by years of frequent TV talk-show appearances. His three decades in the Air Force and Air Force Reserves allowed him to dominate the discussion on fighting terrorism and rebuilding the U.S. military.

Chris Christie, the New Jersey governor, played to his strengths as a former federal prosecutor after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, scoring some effective points when he counterpunched after Rubio and Cruz got bogged down in a debate on Senate legislative minutiae. He also provided the most pointed attack on President Obama, calling him a "feckless weakling."

Rand Paul, the Kentucky senator, scored some points against several onstage in his most assertive performance to date, but at times seemed evasive or circular in reasoning when the debate moderators tried to pin him down on his own positions or his differences with parts of the GOP debate.

Ben Carson, the neurosurgeon, was more confident and explicit in discussing his foreign policy positions, a challenge where he has struggled in the past, while retaining the likeability that's at the core of his popularity.

Jeb Bush, the former Florida governor, gave a more assertive performance than prior debates, but still comes off like the middle daughter Jan from "The Brady Bunch" - always complaining about everything "Donald, Donald, Donald."

Carly Fiorina, the former Hewlett-Packard CEO, seemed flat and grumpy onstage, and her repeated efforts to inject herself into the debate with her screed "This is what is wrong in Washington" didn't prove effective.

John Kasich, the Ohio governor, has a record of success in Ohio but comes off on the national stage more like a dour college professor lecturing students than a presidential contender with an optimistic vision for America.

Title: President Obama to Campaign During Republican National Convention

Article:

President Barack Obama will embark on an ambitious campaign trip next week, coinciding with the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Florida. While it is unusual for an incumbent president to campaign during their opponent's convention, Obama will visit college campuses in Ames, Iowa, and Fort Collins, Colorado, on Tuesday, and Charlottesville, Virginia, on Wednesday. Vice President Joe Biden will also participate in campaign events in Tampa on the first two days of the convention.

First Lady Michelle Obama will appear on "The Late Show with David Letterman" on Wednesday. The Obama campaign aims to "cut through some of the political chatter" and highlight the choice facing American voters in November, according to campaign spokeswoman Jen Psaki.

Stephen Hess, a scholar on the presidency at the Brookings Institution, attributes the trend of campaigning during opponents' conventions to a lack of respect for traditional norms. However, it is not uncommon for challengers to try to make news during their rival's moment in the spotlight.

A recent poll by the nonprofit group Generation Opportunity found that 89% of voters younger than 30 believe the economy is affecting their daily lives negatively. The survey also showed that 64% of young voters prioritize the availability of more quality, full-time jobs upon graduation over lower student-loan interest rates, an issue on which President Obama has been vocal.

The poll indicates that young voters are motivated to vote this year, with 76% saying they intend to go to the polls in November. However, it may not be good news for President Obama, who is seeking to recapture the youth vote that helped him win four years ago. The survey did not ask voters for their preference in the presidential election.

The unemployment rate for 18- to 29-year-olds in July was 12.7%, and 22.3% for blacks in the same age range. If the 1.7 million young adults who have given up looking for jobs are included, the actual unemployment rate for voters younger than 30 is 16.7%.

Title: FDA's Oversight on Opioid Prescribing Training Lacking, Study Finds

The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has been criticized for its inadequate oversight on a program aimed at reducing opioid misuse by requiring pharmaceutical manufacturers to provide training for doctors on safe prescribing practices. A new study published in JAMA Internal Medicine found that the agency has failed to track the effectiveness of this program, which was implemented in 2012 as part of the Risk Evaluation and Mitigation Strategy (REMS) program.

Researchers from Johns Hopkins University analyzed thousands of internal FDA documents and found that the agency has not been able to demonstrate the program's impact on reducing overdoses and deaths. The study revealed that opioid manufacturers did not collect the necessary data to track the training's effectiveness, and even after the FDA discovered this, it did not take corrective action.

The study's authors noted that the program's design was flawed from the start, and that the FDA did not insist on a more scientifically rigorous evaluation of the safety program. The goal of the program was for 60% of doctors who prescribe long-acting opioids to enroll in the training, but only 27% did between 2012 and 2016.

The study's findings are concerning, as nearly 50,000 people died from opioid overdoses in 2017, a record high. While prescription rates have decreased since 2012, rates remain high in certain parts of the country. The FDA has acknowledged the issue and is working with manufacturers to better study the impact of the training on prescriber behavior and patient outcomes. The agency has also taken other steps to address the opioid epidemic, including going after illegal imports and sales of opioids and supporting treatment for those struggling with addiction.

Title: Obama Acknowledges Frustrations and Mistakes in Healthcare.gov Rollout

The rollout of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and the HealthCare.gov website has been marred by technical issues and controversy. President Barack Obama has acknowledged the frustrations and mistakes made during the process, including the promise that "if you like your plan, you can keep it," which turned out not to be true for millions of Americans.

At a press conference, Obama expressed his regret over the cancellation notices sent to over 3 million Americans, stating that it is "on me" and that he is working to fix the issue. He also acknowledged the failure to roll out the ACA smoothly, which has put a burden on Democrats who supported the effort.

Obama also took aim at the federal procurement system for technology, describing it as "cumbersome, complicated, and outdated." He suggested that the process of purchasing technology at the federal level is too complex and slow, which contributed to the problems with HealthCare.gov.

The president also reflected on what he could have done differently, stating that he might have done more to break the mold and improve the setup of the healthcare system. However, he emphasized the need to move forward and find solutions to the current problems.

Overall, Obama's comments provided a rare glimpse into the frustrations and regrets he has experienced over the past few weeks, as well as his commitment to finding solutions and improving the healthcare system.

Title: Texas Governor Rick Perry's Jobs Recruitment Campaigns Spark Controversy

Article:

Texas Governor Rick Perry has launched a high-profile campaign to lure jobs to the state from other parts of the country, touting its low-tax and pro-growth policies. The efforts have sparked controversy, with Democrats criticizing Perry's tactics as "jobs raids" and "poaching." The campaign has also drawn attention from other Republican governors, who are following suit.

Perry's ads and personal appearances have targeted states like California and Illinois, which have been criticized for their business climates. The ads have been effective, with some experts calling Perry's approach "brilliant marketing and very smart politics." However, others have criticized the governor's aggressive tactics, saying they are more about politics than substance.

Perry's efforts have been the most aggressive in the nation, according to experts, and have drawn attention from President Barack Obama's home state of Illinois. Illinois Governor Jerry Brown has mocked Perry's attempts to steal jobs, saying they are as effective as "breaking wind." Other business leaders have also criticized Perry's approach, saying it raises eyebrows as much for his grating style as for the substance of his pitch.

Despite the controversy, Perry's efforts have been seen as a way to boost the Texas economy and create jobs. The governor's current term is up in 2014, and he has not ruled out a 2016 presidential run.

Title: Boston Bombing Suspect Dzhokhar Tsarnaev's Condition Improves to Fair

Boston, Massachusetts - Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the 19-year-old suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings, has seen his medical condition upgraded from serious to fair, according to hospital officials at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center. The update came on Tuesday, with the U.S. Attorney's Office for Massachusetts confirming the change in a tweet.

Tsarnaev was captured on Thursday night inside a boat in a backyard in the Boston suburb of Watertown, Massachusetts. He is being held under heavy guard at the hospital. The 19-year-old is suspected of committing the Boston Marathon bombings, which killed three people and injured over 170 others, along with his deceased brother, Tamerlan Tsarnaev, 26.

The Tsarnaev brothers allegedly committed a carjacking and murdered an MIT police officer before engaging in a firefight with authorities early Friday morning, which left Tamerlan Tsarnaev dead. Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was arraigned on two terrorism-related charges on Monday, during which he nodded his head in answering questions and responded "no" when asked if he had enough money to hire an attorney.

The criminal complaint charging Dzhokhar Tsarnaev with the bombings indicated that he suffered wounds to his "head, neck, leg, and hand." His next court hearing is scheduled for May 30.

New details have emerged about the brothers' plans had they not been captured or killed by authorities. The carjacking victim told authorities that the brothers were planning to go to New York City, with the only recognizable word being "Manhattan." Most of the conversation between the brothers was conducted in Russian.

Title: US Employment Falls in September for First Time Since 2010 Amid Hurricane Impact

The US labor market experienced a decline in employment for the first time since 2010, with 33,000 jobs lost in September. The Labor Department attributed the drop to the impact of hurricanes Harvey and Irma, which struck Texas and Florida in late August and early September. The leisure and hospitality sector saw a significant decline, while employment in other industries, including health care and transportation and warehousing, remained largely unchanged.

Despite the job losses, the unemployment rate slipped to 4.2%, the lowest since February 2001. Economists had expected a rise of 90,000 jobs last month. The discrepancy between the payrolls data and the unemployment rate suggests that the job decline may not indicate a long-term trend.

The strongest job gains in September came in the health care and transportation and warehousing industries. However, employment in the leisure and hospitality sector shrank significantly, while job figures in many other industries, including construction and government, were largely unchanged.

The US has been experiencing one of the longest stretches of job creation in its history, with the economy adding a monthly average of over 170,000 jobs over the past year. Economists have said that this pace is unsustainable and predicted it would slow. The September report showed that average hourly earnings rose 0.5% from August and have now risen 2.9% over the past 12 months.

Analysts noted that the earnings figure showed that job market slack is fading, but others said the figure may have been skewed by the unusual hurricane-related job decline in the low-wage food industry. Despite this, economists do not see anything in the September report to dissuade the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates before the end of the year, as expected.

Revised jobs estimates for July and August showed that US employers added 38,000 fewer jobs than previously reported. However, Ian Shepherdson of Pantheon Macroeconomics expects recovery to begin in October, with a bigger rebound in November.

Title: Trump to Urge House Republicans to Rally Behind Healthcare Repeal and Replacement Legislation

Article:

President Donald Trump is set to personally urge House Republicans to rally behind legislation to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, as GOP leaders prepare for a three-day push to make or break the White House's agenda. The President will meet with conservatives who say the plan does not go far enough and centrists who have demanded more help for older Americans whose premiums would rise under the GOP plan.

House Republicans have agreed to set aside at least $75 billion to help people who buy insurance on their own but are not yet old enough for Medicare, the popular program for seniors. The amended bill does not increase tax credits for Americans aged 50 to 64, but leaves room for the Senate to make changes. The bill formalizes agreed-upon changes to Medicaid, designed to win over a vital bloc of conservatives.

The House Freedom Caucus, a group of over 30 Republicans, remains the most visible obstacle to the bill in the lower chamber. Its chairman, Rep. Mark Meadows of North Carolina, said the group did not plan to take an official position on the bill, leaving the door open for arm-twisting from Trump and GOP leadership. However, members say the votes are not there.

House Speaker Paul D. Ryan and his chief aides are counting on Trump's role as the ultimate "closer" to fulfill their seven-year pledge to kill Obamacare and maintain momentum to overhaul the tax code before the summer recess. Republicans cannot lose more than 21 GOP votes, as every Democrat is expected to reject the bill.

The "manager's amendment" submitted late Monday would repeal many of Obamacare's taxes sooner, this year instead of 2018, while barring any more states from expanding their Medicaid populations and receiving generous federal matching funds outlined by the 2010 law. The implementation of the so-called "Cadillac tax" on particularly generous employer plans is moved back from 2025 to 2026.

Democrats have invited former Vice President Joe Biden to rally in defense of Obamacare on Wednesday, saying the GOP bill would fully unwind its extension of coverage to over 20 million Americans. The House Rules Committee will meet early Wednesday to vet final changes to the GOP replacement and set the terms of debate for floor votes on Thursday, the seventh anniversary of Obamacare's passage.

Title: Thousands of Students and Church Members to Attend Obama's Democratic Nomination Speech

Article:

College students from across North Carolina and members of predominantly black churches in neighboring South Carolina are expected to arrive in Charlotte by the busload to attend President Obama's speech on the final night of the Democratic Party's national convention. The event is set to take place at Bank of America Stadium, which has a capacity of 74,000 seats. The goal is to fill the stadium to capacity, as anything short of a full house could be used by Republicans as a symbol of waning voter enthusiasm for Obama.

Polls have shown a decline in voter enthusiasm, and Obama's crowds for his battleground state campaign rallies have been smaller compared to his 2008 campaign. However, Obama's campaign insists that the stadium will be filled on Thursday night, with Vice President Joe Biden and Massachusetts Senator John Kerry also scheduled to speak.

Convention delegates, volunteers, and other Democratic officials already in Charlotte for the party gathering could make up as much as one-third of the crowd. The remaining seats are being filled through a piecemeal process, with Obama's campaign giving away thousands of tickets to new volunteers in North Carolina who complete three volunteer shifts totaling nine hours.

Several large black churches in South Carolina are planning to send busloads of members to attend the speech, with Lonnie Randolph, the president of the South Carolina chapter of the NAACP, stating that "there are plenty of people who wouldn't miss it for the world." Obama's campaign has also given away tickets to several thousand people who have completed volunteer shifts, helping to boost his grassroots network in North Carolina, a battleground state he won in 2008.

The event is expected to draw comparisons to Obama's 2008 speech, when he accepted the Democratic nomination before a capacity crowd at an 84,000-seat stadium in Denver. However, this time around, Obama's crowds are smaller, with his biggest audience being around 14,000 people at his campaign kick-off rally in May. The campaign has kept the size of its events small this summer, citing the costs and security requirements of hosting a sitting president.

Despite the concerns over crowd size, convention organizers in Charlotte are more worried about the weather, with heavy evening rains dousing the city over the weekend and thunderstorms forecasted for Thursday. However, officials say the outdoor event will go on rain or shine, except in the event of severe weather.

Title: Governor Christie's Visit with President Obama Raises Questions About Political Motives

Article:

Governor Chris Christie of New Jersey's recent visit with President Barack Obama has sparked speculation about the governor's political motives. The visit, which came in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, has been seen by some as a chance for the governor to gain favor with the president and potentially boost his own political prospects. However, Governor Christie's aides have dismissed the idea that the visit was a political move, saying that the governor is focused on his job and not looking at the partnership through a political lens.

The visit has also raised questions about Governor Christie's relationship with Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney. While some have criticized the governor for not mentioning Romney's name during his keynote speech at the Republican National Convention, others have pointed out that declining the president's invitation to visit New Jersey would have been seen as playing politics.

Despite the controversy, Governor Christie has remained focused on his job, saying that he is not looking at the partnership with the president through a political lens. His aides have also emphasized that the governor is not looking to run for president in 2016, and that his focus is on helping his state recover from the devastating effects of Hurricane Sandy.

The visit has also been seen as a chance for Governor Christie to gain favor with the president and potentially boost his own political prospects. However, some have criticized the governor for not mentioning Romney's name during his keynote speech at the Republican National Convention, saying that it was a missed opportunity to show support for the Republican presidential candidate.

Overall, the visit has raised questions about Governor Christie's political motives and his relationship with President Obama and Mitt Romney. While some have seen it as a chance for the governor to gain favor with the president, others have criticized the governor for not being more supportive of Romney.

Title: Democratic Presidential Hopefuls to Appear at SXSW Festival in Austin, Texas

The 2020 Democratic presidential hopefuls will take the stage at the South by Southwest (SXSW) festival in Austin, Texas, this weekend. The event, which combines technology, film, and music, provides an opportunity for the candidates to connect with young voters and showcase their policies.

Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) and Senator Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) will speak on Saturday, while former San Antonio Mayor Julian Castro, Colorado Governor John Hickenlooper, and Washington Governor Jay Inslee will speak on Sunday. Former Representative Beto O'Rourke, who has not yet announced his candidacy for the 2020 presidential election, is expected to attend a film premiere about his 2018 Senate bid against Senator Ted Cruz.

Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.), a rising star within the Democratic Party, will be interviewed onstage on Saturday night. Texas is an early primary state for Democrats, but it is also a traditionally red state in presidential elections. However, O'Rourke's close race against Cruz in 2018 suggests that the state may be shifting towards being a purple state.

The Democratic National Committee Chair, Tom Perez, believes that events like SXSW provide real opportunities for the party ahead of the 2020 campaign. "It's become an iconic national event, and I wanted to make sure people understood what we're doing at the Democratic Party to win," Perez said. He also cited the 2018 Texas Senate race as a sign that Texas could eventually be up for grabs for Democrats: "Texas is very much in play for Democrats. We made tremendous progress."

Title: Supreme Court Rules Wyoming Can't Abrogate 1868 Treaty with Crow Tribe, Guaranteeing Hunting Rights

The United States Supreme Court has ruled that Wyoming cannot abrogate a 1868 treaty with the Crow Tribe, citing the treaty's guarantee of American Indians' hunting rights on federal lands. The decision, announced on Monday, breathes new life into American Indian-U.S. relations and could guarantee hunting rights on some federal lands.

The case was brought by Clayvin Herrera, a member of the Crow Tribe, who was charged with offseason hunting in 2014 after state officials discovered him and other tribe members hunting bull elk on the Big Horn National Forest. Herrera argued that he was permitted to hunt on the land, citing the treaty that guaranteed American Indians the right to hunt on unoccupied lands of the United States so long as game may be found thereon.

The Crow Tribe signed the treaty in 1868, handing over roughly 30 million acres to settlers while retaining about 8 million acres. Wyoming argued that the treaty expired when it gained statehood in 1890, but the justices, in a 5-4 ruling, sided with Herrera, saying the treaty is good law.

Justice Neil M. Gorsuch, President Trump's replacement for the late Justice Antonin Scalia, sided with the court's four Democratic-appointed justices. The court's 22-page opinion, written by Justice Sonia Sotomayor, states that there is no evidence that Congress intended to abrogate the 1868 treaty right through the Wyoming Statehood Act, nor is there any evidence in the treaty itself that Congress intended the hunting right to expire at statehood.

Advocates for Herrera said the ruling is significant because other tribes have similar treaties with the U.S., and the decision gives them broader access to national forests. Forrest Tahdooahnippah, a lawyer who specializes in tribal issues, said the decision gives "life" to the rights of American Indians by overruling the prior precedent.

The justices' major issue was the language of the treaty, which said it applied to "unoccupied lands." Wyoming argued that once it became a state, all of the lands were deemed occupied. The high court rejected both arguments, though it did leave room for some regulations within the forest, including where Wyoming decides it has an interest in conservation.

The four dissenting justices said the majority was ignoring a clear precedent - a similar case in 1895 involving the same treaty language and the Shoshone-Bannock Tribes. Justice Samuel A. Alito called Monday's majority opinion "wasted ink."

Title: US Automakers Face New Rules in Revised North American Trade Deal

The revised North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) requires automakers to produce at least 75% of a vehicle's content in North America to qualify for zero tariffs, up from the current 62.5%. However, the deal still needs congressional ratification before it can take effect. According to Kristin Dziczek, vice president for industry, labor, and economics at the Center for Automotive Research, the changes may not encourage significant investment in the United States, as most vehicles can already meet the new thresholds.

The automotive industry has seen a slight increase in employment under President Trump's watch, with around one million workers employed in November 2018 compared to 955,800 in January 2017. However, the number of vehicles manufactured in the United States has continued to decline, despite a slight uptick last summer. The Reshoring Initiative reports that announcements to increase investment or move companies back to the United States peaked in 2016.

In related news, President Trump has renegotiated NAFTA and a bilateral trade deal with South Korea. The revised NAFTA strengthens intellectual property rights in Canada, while the US-China trade dispute remains ongoing. An investigation into China's trade practices concluded that Beijing had violated American intellectual property rights, leading to tariffs on $250 billion worth of Chinese products. The two sides are currently in talks over a trade deal to resolve the dispute.

Separately, President Trump signed the "Right to Try" legislation into law in May, allowing terminally ill patients to seek access to experimental medicine that is not approved by the Food and Drug Administration. The law allows patients, with the approval of their doctor, to ask drug companies directly for access, rather than wait for approval by the agency. The FDA notes that a similar program, known as compassionate use or expanded access, has been in place since the 1970s and authorizes 99% of the requests it receives.

**Defense Policy Bill Clears Senate Hurdle, Heads to President's Desk**

The Senate has overcome a filibuster and passed the annual defense policy bill, also known as the National Defense Authorization Act, with a vote of 73-26. The bill, which authorizes defense spending and sets policy for the Pentagon, now heads to President Barack Obama's desk, where it is likely to face a veto.

The bill includes provisions to raise troops' pay, set policy for Guantanamo Bay detainees, and authorize funding for various military programs, including the A-10 aircraft and new strike fighters for the Navy and Marine Corps. However, the bill has become entangled in a broader fight over government spending for fiscal year 2016.

Republicans want to increase defense spending and have proposed classifying some of it as emergency war spending, while Democrats insist that any increase must be matched by an equal amount for domestic spending. The White House has threatened to veto the bill, citing concerns over its funding priorities and restrictions on transferring Guantanamo Bay detainees.
