The bill's passage sets up a potential showdown between Congress and the President, with Republicans arguing that an Obama veto would be equivalent to declaring surrender in the face of dangerous threats to national security. If the President follows through on his threat, it would be his fifth veto of his tenure, and Republicans believe there may be enough support in both the House and Senate to override the veto.

The bill's passage also highlights the ongoing debate over government spending, with Democrats insisting that any increase in defense spending must be matched by an equal increase in domestic spending. The White House has expressed concerns over the bill's restrictions on transferring Guantanamo Bay detainees, while Republicans argue that the bill is a must-pass measure that authorizes the ability of Americans to defend the nation.

Title: President Trump Marks 16th Anniversary of 9/11 Attacks, Pledges to Keep US Safe

Article:

President Donald Trump marked the 16th anniversary of the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks on Monday, paying tribute to the victims, first responders, and the military. Trump delivered remarks at the Pentagon, emphasizing the United States' resolve to keep its citizens safe from future attacks.

In his speech, Trump stated that the terrorists who attacked the US thought they could incite fear and weaken the nation's spirit, but America cannot be intimidated. He warned that those who try to harm the country will soon join the list of vanquished enemies who dared to test its mettle.

Trump also shared the story of a Pentagon police officer who rushed into the wreckage and saved as many as 20 people over nearly 36 hours. The attacks, he said, made the nation more resilient and continue to do so.

The ceremony was preceded by remarks from General Joseph Dunford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Defense Secretary James Mattis, who emphasized that Americans are not intimidated by their enemies and that the military does not scare.

Vice President Mike Pence paid tribute to the passengers of United Airlines Flight 93, who fought against hijackers on 9/11. Pence spoke in Shanksville, Pennsylvania, saying that many people, including himself, were able to return home that day to hug their families because of the courage and selflessness of the heroes of Flight 93.

Earlier in the day, the president and first lady Melania Trump observed a moment of silence on the South Lawn of the White House. The president wore a dark suit and a solid red tie, while Melania wore a long-sleeved black dress. The couple stood with their hands over their hearts as a bell tolled and a Marine bugler played "Taps." Other administration officials, including Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner, were also present.

Title: Trump Claims Sondland's Testimony Clears Him of Wrongdoing, But Ambassador's Account Raises Questions

President Donald Trump stated on Wednesday that Ambassador to the European Union Gordon Sondland's testimony before the House Intelligence Committee exonerates him of any wrongdoing in the ongoing impeachment inquiry. Trump claimed that Sondland's testimony means "it's all over" for the proceedings and that the House inquiry into him should come to a halt.

During his testimony, Sondland discussed a conversation with Trump where the president asked what he wanted from Ukraine. According to Sondland, Trump said, "I want nothing. I want nothing. I want no quid pro quo. Tell Zelensky to do the right thing. Something to that effect." Trump argued that this statement proves there was no quid pro quo between his administration and Ukraine, which is at the heart of the impeachment probe.

However, Sondland's account provided a more nuanced view. While he confirmed he never heard directly from Trump on a quid pro quo linking military aid for Ukraine to politically advantageous investigations, he said "we all understood" that a meeting at the White House for Ukraine's president and a phone call with Trump would happen only if President Volodymyr Zelensky agreed to an investigation into the 2016 U.S. election and the Bidens. Sondland also stated that he came to presume aid was linked to investigations too.

Sondland sent an email on July 19, just days before the July 25 call at the center of the impeachment inquiry, where he laid out the issue in detail to members of the State and Energy departments and White House staff. He also testified that he worked with Trump's lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, on Ukraine at Trump's "express direction" and pushed a "quid pro quo" with Kiev because it was what Trump wanted.

House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff, D-Calif., called Sondland's testimony "a very important moment in the history of this investigation" and said it showed "for the first time that knowledge of this scheme was pervasive."

**Austin Explosion: Two People Injured, Police Investigate Possible Link to Previous Package Bombings**

A fourth explosion occurred in Austin, Texas, on Sunday night, injuring two people on bicycles. The blast occurred around 8:30 p.m. in the Travis Country neighborhood, a suburban area. The Austin Police Department has not yet confirmed the cause of the explosion, but Chief Brian Manley suggested it may have been triggered by a trip wire.

The explosion is believed to be connected to the previous three package bombings that have shaken the city. Manley stated that investigators are working under the assumption that the latest blast is linked to the others, but the scene has not yet been fully processed.

The blast injured two men in their 20s, including one who had nails in his leg. The victims were treated at a local hospital and are in good condition.

The Austin Police Department has urged people within a half-mile radius to stay in their homes until the area is cleared of any hazards. Authorities have also issued an emergency alert on cellular phones and are working to determine the cause of the explosion.

The latest blast is the fourth to occur in Austin in less than three weeks. The previous explosions occurred on the east side of the city and targeted packages left on doorsteps. The victims of those blasts were black or Hispanic, but Manley has not ruled out any possible motive.

The reward for information leading to an arrest in the deadly explosions has increased by $50,000, bringing the total to $115,000. Over 500 officers, including federal agents, have conducted 236 interviews and followed up on 435 leads in the investigation.

Title: Roger Stone Indicted on Charges of Lying About Role in Russian Meddling

Roger Stone, a veteran political consultant and longtime adviser to President Donald Trump, was indicted on Friday on charges of lying about his role in Russian meddling during the 2016 election. The indictment alleges that Stone lied about his contacts with WikiLeaks and the Trump campaign, including dealings with website founder Julian Assange, as well as interactions with members of the Trump campaign about stolen emails.

According to the indictment, Stone spoke to senior Trump campaign officials about Organization 1 (WikiLeaks) and information it might have had that would be damaging to the Clinton campaign. He is also accused of being contacted by senior Trump campaign officials to inquire about future releases by Organization 1.

Stone has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing and has claimed that the investigation is a vendetta against him and the president. After being released on bail, Stone made appearances on CNN and Fox News to denounce the charges and boast that he would never testify against the president.

Stone's social media accounts have also been active, with him posting a doctored image of special counsel Robert Mueller dressed as a waiter holding an empty bun on a silver platter, accompanied by the caption "Here's what Mueller has on me #nothingburger." He also posted a photo of himself with the words "Who framed Roger Stone?", a play on the 1988 movie "Who Framed Roger Rabbit".

The indictment marks a significant development in the investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election, which has been led by special counsel Robert Mueller. The investigation has already led to charges against several individuals and organizations, including several Trump campaign officials and Russian intelligence officers.

Title: Fiorina Defends Campaign Strategy Amid Sliding Poll Numbers

Carly Fiorina, a Republican presidential candidate, addressed concerns about her campaign's momentum and poll numbers on Friday, emphasizing the importance of careful spending and earned media. Speaking to reporters after a town hall event in Bluffton, South Carolina, Fiorina explained that her campaign is focusing on grassroots efforts and building a strong foundation, rather than relying on advertising.

Fiorina noted that her campaign has the "lowest burn rate" among her opponents, indicating a cautious approach to spending. She emphasized that she is prioritizing building a strong team and connecting with voters on the ground, rather than relying on paid advertising. While Fiorina acknowledged that she will eventually need to invest in advertising, she believes that the time is not yet right.

When asked about the dip in her poll numbers, Fiorina attributed it to the fact that many voters are still getting to know her and her platform. She pointed to her strong "fave and unfave" ratings, which she believes indicate that her attacks on her business record are not having the desired effect. Fiorina also noted that her campaign has been off national television for a few weeks, focusing instead on regional media and town hall events.

Fiorina emphasized the importance of looking at the bigger picture and not getting caught up in short-term fluctuations in the polls. She believes that her campaign is building momentum and will continue to gain traction as voters learn more about her and her platform.

Title: Democrats' Stance on Gun Control: A Growing Concern for Second Amendment Supporters

Article:

The recent CNN town hall on gun control, held in Sunrise, Florida, has reignited the debate on the Second Amendment and the Democratic Party's stance on gun rights. The event saw Senator Marco Rubio and NRA spokesperson Dana Loesch facing a crowd of anti-gun advocates, sparking concerns about the party's intentions. A recent YouGov poll suggests that 82% of Democrats want to ban semiautomatic firearms, with 55% supporting a total handgun ban. This raises concerns about the party's commitment to the Second Amendment and the potential implications for gun owners.

The poll's findings are concerning, as they indicate a significant shift in the Democratic Party's stance on gun control. The party's support for stricter gun laws has become more pronounced, with many Democrats advocating for a ban on semiautomatic weapons. This is a departure from previous years, when the party focused on strengthening background checks and improving mental health provisions.

The media's role in shaping public opinion on gun control is also worth noting. Many Americans may not fully understand the terms used in the debate, such as "assault weapon" and "full semi-automatic," which can lead to misconceptions about the capabilities of certain firearms. This lack of understanding can contribute to the high support for bans on semiautomatic weapons.

The Democratic Party's stance on gun control is a growing concern for Second Amendment supporters, as it appears to be driven by a desire to restrict and potentially repeal the Second Amendment. The party's shift on gun politics has significant implications for gun owners and the broader debate on gun control.

Title: White House Leaves Door Open to Alternative Explanations of Libya Attack

The White House has opened the door to the possibility of alternative explanations for the deadly attack on the U.S. Consulate in Libya, which killed four Americans. White House Press Secretary Jay Carney stated that the FBI is investigating the incident and will follow the facts wherever they lead. Carney emphasized that the administration does not have any indication of premeditation or pre-planned attacks, but acknowledged that the investigation may uncover a different version of events.

This stance contrasts with that of U.S. Ambassador Susan Rice, who claimed on Fox News Sunday that the attack was not pre-planned or premeditated, but rather a spontaneous reaction to protests in Egypt over an anti-Islam film. However, Libyan President Mohamed Yousef el-Magariaf has disputed this account, stating that the attack was premeditated.

An intelligence source in Libya, who spoke to Fox News, corroborated the Libyan president's claims, stating that there was no major protest in Benghazi before the attack and that extremist elements joined the fray. The source also claimed that RPGs and mortar fire were used in the attack, which has raised questions about the spontaneity of the incident.

The White House has deferred to the ongoing investigation, stating that it is an absolute tragedy that four Americans were lost in Benghazi and that the investigation will examine what role the video played in the attack, among other things. The investigation is still ongoing, and the White House has not made any definitive statements about the motivations behind the attack.

The conflicting accounts of the attack have sparked questions about the security situation in eastern Libya, which U.S. officials had deemed to be deteriorating before the attack. The CIA had determined that the security situation was deteriorating based on four attacks on diplomatic and Western targets in Benghazi, starting in June. However, U.S. officials insist that there was no specific warning of an armed assault like the one that killed the four Americans.

Title: Washington and Lee University Faculty Votes to Remove Robert E. Lee's Name

The faculty of Washington and Lee University in Virginia has voted overwhelmingly to remove the name of Robert E. Lee, the former Confederate general, from the institution. The decision was made on Monday, with 188 faculty members voting in favor of the name change and 51 against. The move comes after the student government and over 200 faculty members had previously signed a petition calling for the name change.

Lee's name was added to the university in 1870, shortly after his death. However, the faculty has since come to realize that his legacy does not align with the values of the institution. "Lee was a symbol of who that faculty wanted to be, and who they were," said Alison Bell, head of the Faculty Affairs Committee. "The faculty is asking the university to change its name because Lee does not represent who we are and who we want to be."

The university's board of trustees would need to approve the name change, and a spokeswoman stated that they are "carefully monitoring developments regarding issues of race, monuments, and symbols of the Confederacy and their implications" for the university.

This move is part of a broader trend in Virginia, where Confederate names are being stripped from public K-12 schools. The Washington Post reports that Stonewall Middle School in Prince William County and Robert E. Lee High School in Fairfax County are both getting new names, while Loudon County High School is dropping its "Raiders" mascot, which referenced Confederate Col. John S. Mosby's guerrilla troops.

Historians have noted that the wholesale rejection of Confederate iconography by Virginia schools is unprecedented, although some have pointed out that Black students, parents, and communities have been objecting to the names since the 1950s and 1960s, in response to the Supreme Court's Brown v. Board of Education ruling. "It was trying to make black students feel unwelcome, while white students and white communities were emboldened to resist desegregation," said historian Adam Domby.

Title: Trump Attorney Jay Sekulow Criticizes Mueller's Testimony and Investigation

Article:

Jay Sekulow, one of President Donald Trump's attorneys, criticized Robert Mueller's testimony on Capitol Hill regarding his report, calling it "incoherent as written and worse as played out on live TV." Sekulow appeared on Fox News' "Fox and Friends" on Thursday morning, stating that the investigation was a "terrible, terrible waste of taxpayer money" and that the president has been under a "witch hunt."

Sekulow also noted that commentators from various networks described Mueller's testimony as a "disaster," "train wreck," and "horrible." He added that even House Speaker Nancy Pelosi was trying to put on a "happy face" during her press conference, but that some Democratic Party members acknowledged the investigation was a "train wreck."

Sekulow pointed out that 12-13 prosecutors were involved in the investigation, which he claimed twisted and turned to create a collusion, conspiracy, and obstruction narrative. Despite their efforts, they were unable to produce evidence to support these claims.

The attorney highlighted the issue of Mueller's testimony regarding the concept of exoneration, stating that Mueller admitted there is no historical precedent for the policy he presented. Sekulow argued that this means the president is being treated differently than any other citizen in the context of the burden of proof.

Sekulow did not discuss any potential pardons for those arrested during the investigation, but expressed his belief that there has been "a lot of injustice" in the process.

**Nepal Hit by 7.8-Magnitude Earthquake and Aftershocks, Causing Widespread Devastation**

A powerful 7.8-magnitude earthquake struck Nepal over the weekend, causing widespread destruction and loss of life. According to the Associated Press, the earthquake has killed at least 4,400 people and injured at least 8,000. The earthquake triggered avalanches that killed at least 18 people at a Mount Everest base camp, with hundreds more injured.

The earthquake, which struck around noon, has caused significant damage to buildings and infrastructure in the heavily populated Kathmandu Valley, where building quality is often low. Home Ministry official Laxmi Dhakal has warned that the death toll is likely to rise.

Rescue operations have been hampered by further earthquakes and aftershocks, with nearly 100 reported in the region. "There have been nearly 100 earthquakes and aftershocks, which is making rescue work difficult," said Kathmandu district chief administrator Ek Narayan Aryal.

The earthquake was more powerful than the one that devastated Haiti in 2010 and the same magnitude as the 1906 earthquake in San Francisco. However, it falls below Nepal's worst recorded earthquake in 1934, which measured 8.0 and ravaged the cities of Kathmandu, Bhaktapur, and Patan.

Avalanches killed at least 18 people and injured at least 61 more in Nepal over the weekend. German climber Jost Kobusch posted footage of an avalanche that hit a Mount Everest base camp, showing the devastating impact of the disaster.

The earthquake has also had a significant impact on Nepal's economy, which relies heavily on tourism from trekkers and mountain climbers. The country's infrastructure is poorly equipped to withstand earthquakes, making it particularly vulnerable to damage and loss of life.

Experts had warned of the possibility of a devastating earthquake in Nepal just a week before it happened. A group of 50 earthquake and social scientists from around the world had gathered in Kathmandu to discuss ways to prepare the country for a major earthquake. Seismologist James Jackson, head of the earth sciences department at the University of Cambridge, said that while experts did not expect such a huge earthquake to hit so soon, they had warned that something like it was possible.

The earthquake has highlighted the need for improved infrastructure and disaster preparedness in Nepal, which is located on top of a natural seismic fault and has a high risk of earthquakes.

Title: Thousands of Young Illegal Immigrants Line Up to Apply for Obama's Deportation Reprieve

The Obama administration's new program allowing young illegal immigrants to apply for a two-year reprieve from deportation has drawn thousands of applicants to consulates across the country. As many as 1.8 million undocumented immigrants may be eligible for the program, which kicked off on Wednesday. To qualify, applicants must fill out a six-page form, pay a $465 fee, and submit documents proving their identity.

Immigration officials have emphasized the importance of verifying the authenticity of the documents, citing concerns about potential fraud. Applicants must demonstrate that they arrived in the United States before the age of 16 and are either enrolled in school or vocational training, or have a high school degree. The program is similar to the DREAM Act, which failed to pass Congress, but has more lenient requirements.

The crowds of applicants began forming on Tuesday, with many seeking to get a head start on the application process. "We are waiting for our passports. We want to get our passport because Obama might be asking for them," said Kristi Alarcon, an applicant waiting outside the Mexican consulate in Houston.

Advocates held workshops in Los Angeles on Wednesday to help applicants navigate the application process. The crowds are the most visible demonstration yet of the interest in the program, which is seen as a way for the Obama administration to boost its political standing among Hispanic voters.

However, some Republican lawmakers have criticized the program, accusing the Obama administration of circumventing Congress and favoring illegal immigrants over unemployed U.S. citizens. House Judiciary Committee Chairman Lamar Smith, R-Texas, called the policy "backdoor amnesty" and expressed concerns about fraud. "While potentially millions of illegal immigrants will be permitted to compete with American workers for scarce jobs, there seems to be little if any mechanism in place for vetting fraudulent applications and documentation submitted by illegal immigrants," Smith said.

The program is set to begin just months before the presidential election, which could play a significant role in determining the outcome. The Obama administration has faced criticism from Hispanic voters and others for not fulfilling its campaign promise to overhaul the nation's immigration laws.

Title: Republicans Prepare for Post-Election Day Fight in Louisiana and Georgia

The Republican Party is gearing up for a prolonged fight in key Senate races in Louisiana and Georgia, where the outcome may not be decided on Election Day. In Louisiana, Senator Mary Landrieu's re-election campaign is preparing for a potential runoff against Republican Representative Bill Cassidy, while in Georgia, the campaigns for both parties are preparing for a nine-week runoff ending in January.

According to sources, the National Republican Senatorial Committee has reserved $3.4 million in TV time for the Louisiana runoff, while the conservative outside group Freedom Partners has booked an additional $1.5 million. Karl Rove-backed Crossroads GPS has also reserved $2.1 million in the state starting October 7. In Georgia, both sides have built an infrastructure they plan to rely on if the race goes to a runoff and are already predicting a major fundraising blitz if the winner is not decided on election night.

Democrats, on the other hand, are focusing on winning the election outright in November, taking advantage of a split between Cassidy and his main conservative foe, tea party challenger Rob Maness. If a runoff occurs, Democrats believe their best shot at emerging victorious is to win outright in November, taking advantage of a split between Cassidy and his main conservative foe, tea party challenger Rob Maness.

Senator Johnny Isakson, a Georgia Republican who battled in his own runoff race in 1996, said, "You've got to recapitalize almost immediately, and it's a matter of who gets their voters out to the polls." The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee is mum on what its runoff plans entail, while Senator Mary Landrieu's campaign is focused on winning the election outright in November.

In Georgia, both sides have built an infrastructure they plan to rely on if the race goes to a runoff and are already predicting a major fundraising blitz if the winner is not decided on election night.

Title: President Obama to Deliver Economic Speech at Knox College, Focus on Middle Class and Legacy

Article:

President Barack Obama will deliver an economic speech at Knox College in Galesburg, Illinois, on Wednesday, marking the beginning of a new series of speeches on the economy. The address is designed to build public pressure on lawmakers ahead of key budget deadlines in the fall, specifically the start of the new fiscal year in October and the government's borrowing limit.

The speech is expected to focus on the condition of the economy when Obama took office and its current state, as well as his vision for an expanded and strengthened middle class. The speech will also likely include calls for more green energy investment, the importance of the middle class, and the need for the rich to pay their fair share.

After the speech at Knox College, Obama will travel to Missouri and Florida to deliver similar messages. The most interesting aspect of the speech will be how he sells the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) as part of a better economy. Last week, the Associated Press fact-checker called out Obama for exaggerating the benefits of his signature healthcare legislation.

The speech may also address Obama's approach to Republicans who refuse to vote for an increase in the debt ceiling without defunding Obamacare. Congress has just a few weeks to reach a deal.

While the speech is expected to focus on the economy, some analysts believe Obama may be using the speech to start thinking about his legacy and how he will be viewed in history. The speech will be streamed live at WhiteHouse.gov at 12:55 ET.

**TikTok Hires Internet Police to Monitor US Users, Former Censor Says**

A former Chinese internet censor has come forward with claims that TikTok, a popular short-video app owned by Beijing-based ByteDance Technology Co., is hiring internet police to monitor and police videos posted by international users, including those in the United States. Liu Lipeng, who worked as an online censor in China for a decade, said he was interviewed for the role in 2018 but was rejected after expressing concerns about the app's content moderation policies.

According to Liu, the company's secrecy and lack of transparency during the interview process raised red flags. He described the experience as "ridiculous" and likened it to visiting a "den of a drug lord." Liu stated that the company's facility housed at least 4,000 employees, with a portion working on TikTok, and that surveillance cameras monitored workers to ensure they did not remove any materials from the site.

Liu's claims coincide with growing concerns over TikTok's ties to the Chinese government and the potential risks it poses to national security. U.S. officials and experts have warned that the app could be used to spy on and censor American users.

TikTok has previously denied using Chinese moderators to handle content on its platform, but Liu's claims have sparked renewed scrutiny of the app's content moderation practices. The company has announced plans to open a "transparency center" in Los Angeles to allow outside experts to see how TikTok moderates content.

The U.S. review panel is currently investigating ByteDance's acquisition of Musical.ly, which was rebranded to TikTok, in 2017, to determine whether the deal raised national security risks. The Pentagon has ordered U.S. military personnel to delete TikTok from their work phones, and several other organizations have warned staff members about using the app.

Title: Candidates Highlight Economic Inequality and Call for Systemic Reforms

The article discusses the concerns of Democratic presidential candidates regarding the widening economic gap in the United States. They emphasize the need for systemic reforms to address the issue, citing the struggles of low-wage workers and the growing number of Americans living paycheck to paycheck.

One candidate notes that the current economic system is not working for many Americans, with basic costs of living outpacing earnings from low-wage jobs, even for families with multiple workers. They propose rewriting the tax code to ensure big corporations pay their fair share and investing in programs that benefit the American people.

Another candidate highlights the importance of community colleges in preparing students for employment and connecting them to growing industries. They suggest providing federal student aid for quality short-term certificate programs and extending the earned income tax credit and unemployment insurance to Americans in training programs.

The article also touches on the topic of air quality, with one candidate criticizing the Trump administration's rollbacks on environmental regulations, which could worsen air pollution.

In a separate section, the article discusses the recent strike against Iranian General Qasem Soleimani, with one commentator questioning the strategic implications of the action and the potential consequences of a war with Iran. They note that the strike may not have decapitated the Iranian regime and that the administration has not provided a clear plan for what a war with Iran would look like or what the war aim is.

Overall, the article presents a range of perspectives on the current state of the US economy and the need for systemic reforms to address economic inequality, as well as the potential consequences of military action against Iran.

Title: US National Debt Reaches Record $22 Trillion, Contradicting Trump's Campaign Promises

The United States Treasury Department has released a report confirming that the national debt has surpassed $22 trillion, a milestone reached nearly four years after then-candidate Donald Trump promised to reduce the debt from $18 trillion. The report notes that the total public debt has reached $22.012 trillion, exceeding the previous record of $21 trillion.

The debt increase is attributed to underlying trends in the growth of Medicare and Social Security costs, as well as the trillion-dollar deficit resulting from the 2017 tax cuts, which primarily benefited corporations and the wealthy. This development stands in stark contrast to Trump's earlier campaign promises.

During his 2015 campaign launch address, Trump vowed to reduce the debt, stating, "I will reduce our $18 trillion in debt, because, believe me, we're in a bubble." He also promised to "freeze the budget" and claimed he could eliminate the debt "fairly quickly" over an eight-year period. However, these promises have not been fulfilled.

Since taking office, Trump has not made significant efforts to reduce the debt, and his administration's budget proposal is projected to add $7.2 trillion more to the debt over the next 10 years. The administration has not presented a plan to reduce the debt, and Trump has only tweeted about it a handful of times.

The ballooning debt is a stark contrast to Trump's campaign promises, which emphasized his business acumen and ability to reduce the debt. The administration's failure to address the debt has been met with criticism, and it remains unclear whether any significant efforts will be made to reduce the debt in the future.

Title: Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker Wins Recall Election, Republicans See Glimmer of Hope in Presidential Election

Article:

Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker won a recall election on Tuesday, defeating Milwaukee Mayor Tom Barrett in a repeat of their 2010 showdown. The election was seen as a test of the Republican governor's popularity and the strength of the labor unions that backed his opponent. Walker's victory was attributed to his ability to outspend his opponent, with a 7-to-1 margin in fundraising and a significant amount of outside corporate money.

The election was seen as a sign that the Republican Party may be gaining momentum in the state, which has not voted for a Republican presidential candidate since 1984. Walker's victory could encourage presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney to make a play for Wisconsin in the general election.

However, the results of the election were not as decisive as they seemed. Exit polling showed that voters preferred President Obama to Romney, and the actual results showed Walker winning by a 7-percentage-point margin. This could indicate that the presidential race in Wisconsin is closer than previously thought.

The election was also seen as a test of the power of labor unions, which backed Barrett's campaign. While Walker's victory was seen as a blow to the unions, a union-backed Democrat unseated a state senator in another recall election, which will switch control of the chamber to the Democrats.

The results of the election have left some analysts skeptical about the importance of Wisconsin in the presidential election. John Zogby, a pollster, said that the election was "ugly" and that neither side won, with both parties "climbing a mound of cow dung and trying to plant a flag." He suggested that Romney should run more quietly and not spend too much money in the state.

On the other hand, some Republicans see the election as a sign of growing unease with the Democratic Party's ties to labor unions. Bill Palatucci, a Republican National Committee member, said that the election will put an "at-least-temporary smile" on Republicans' faces.

The election has also raised concerns about the role of big money in politics. Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee Chairman Steve Israel called for Democrats to go after big donors the way Republicans have with great success. He said that the Wisconsin results should serve as a wake-up call for Democrats to couple their ground organizing with an aggressive air campaign.

Overall, the election was seen as a mixed bag, with some analysts seeing it as a sign of Republican momentum and others viewing it as a stalemate. The results will likely have implications for the presidential election and the role of big money in politics.

Title: FBI Investigates Suspect in Boston Marathon Bombing, Seeks Public Help to Identify Individual

The FBI is investigating a suspect in the Boston Marathon bombing, with authorities reviewing video footage from a Lord & Taylor department store across the street from the second explosion site. The footage shows a young white man wearing a black jacket, gray hooded sweatshirt, and a white or off-white baseball cap on backwards, acting suspiciously and dropping a bag before walking away. The FBI is now going through logs of cellphone calls to determine who made calls from the area around the time of the bombing.

The agency is also seeking the public's help to identify the individual, having initially released images from the Lord & Taylor video before pulling back. However, the decision to release the images was reportedly reconsidered due to concerns that the suspect may flee if he knows he is being sought.

The investigation is ongoing, with the FBI also seeking the identification of a second person captured on video carrying a backpack and behaving suspiciously in the vicinity of the first person of interest. While this new lead may provide a breakthrough, it is not uncommon for false leads to emerge in high-profile cases.

The FBI is utilizing modern facial recognition software to speed up the identification process, and surveillance cameras in airports and public locations can be programmed to look for individuals with similar features. The investigation is a complex and time-consuming process, with authorities carefully reviewing evidence and following leads to ensure a thorough investigation.

The nation remains on edge following the Boston Marathon tragedy, with the FBI announcing the arrest of a Mississippi man in connection with the mailing of letters laced with ricin to President Obama and a US senator. The city of Boston remains a crime scene, with police barricades sealing off the area. Massachusetts Governor Deval Patrick expressed frustration that no one responsible has yet been caught, but emphasized that the investigation will not be rushed and will require careful and thorough work.

Title: White House and Congress Consider Third Coronavirus Spending Package Worth Hundreds of Billions

The White House and congressional lawmakers are working on a third coronavirus spending package, worth hundreds of billions of dollars, as the Senate works to move forward with a more modest second relief bill. The White House is pushing an $850 billion stimulus package, with roughly $500 billion tied to payroll tax cuts, $250 billion in Small Business Administration loans, and $58 billion for the airline industry.

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin will meet with Senate Republicans to discuss the comprehensive proposal, which is expected to put cash in the hands of individuals and businesses. Senate Democrats, led by Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, are proposing a $750 billion package to address the economic crisis caused by the coronavirus.

The proposed package would include expanded unemployment insurance and Medicaid funding, addressing strained hospital capacity, providing urgent assistance to small businesses, and assisting schools in transitioning to remote learning. Senator Elizabeth Warren backed Schumer's proposal, stating that the US is heading towards a recession and that a major fiscal stimulus package is necessary to ward off economic disaster.

It is unclear what exactly will be included in Mnuchin's proposal, but there may be significant overlap with Schumer's ideas. Mnuchin has been the White House's point person in negotiating with congressional Democrats and has spoken with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi multiple times.

Other lawmakers have also chimed in with ideas for combating the coronavirus and helping Americans affected by the economic shutdown. Senator Mitt Romney proposed providing every American with a $1,000 check to cover expenses due to layoffs, forced leave, or other coronavirus-related expenses. Representative Tulsi Gabbard proposed a similar plan, introducing a non-binding House resolution for a monthly $1,000 payment until the coronavirus threat is over.

Title: Lawyers for Michael Flynn Halt Communications with Trump's Legal Team in Russia Probe

Article:

Lawyers for former national security adviser Michael Flynn have stopped communicating with President Donald Trump's legal team, a significant development in the investigation into contacts between Trump's 2016 presidential campaign and Russia. According to sources familiar with the investigation, Flynn's lawyer, Robert Kelner, called Trump's private lawyer, John Dowd, to inform him that the two could no longer discuss the matter.

The exact reason for the halt in communication is unclear, but it may be related to Flynn's potential cooperation with Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation. Flynn, a retired Army general, is a central figure in the probe, which is investigating whether Trump aides colluded with Russian efforts to boost his presidential campaign.

Flynn's cooperation would be a major asset in the investigation, which is examining three key areas: any collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia, money laundering and other possible financial crimes by Trump aides, and whether Trump sought to obstruct justice when he fired former FBI Director James Comey in May.

Two congressional officials involved in separate probes into the Trump campaign's contacts with Russia said one key area of investigation is whether Flynn or other advisers to Trump ever suggested lifting U.S. economic sanctions on Russia in exchange for favorable business deals. Possible deals include a proposed commercial nuclear power project involving Russian firms that Flynn worked to promote to potential clients in the Middle East.

It is unclear whether Flynn has any information about such deals, but he is near the top of the list of people who would know if there was any such effort. Trump fired Flynn on February 13 after disclosures that Flynn had discussed U.S. sanctions on Russia with then-Russian Ambassador Sergei Kislyak in December, the month before Trump took office, and later misled Vice President Mike Pence about the conversations.

Flynn has acknowledged contacts with Kislyak dating back to 2013, but has said nothing about the content of their conversations during Trump's campaign and after his election. Mueller has been investigating Flynn in several areas, including whether he knowingly made false statements to the government about his foreign travels, income, and contacts on his security clearance form.

Flynn's son, Michael Flynn Jr., has also been under scrutiny for his involvement in some of his father's business dealings in Russia, Turkey, and elsewhere, which could provide a potent additional incentive for Flynn to cooperate.

Title: Trump's Words Spark Concerns for Whistleblower's Safety, as Impeachment Inquiry Continues

The lawyers representing the whistleblower whose complaint triggered a US presidential impeachment inquiry have expressed concerns that Donald Trump's words are putting their client in danger. The whistleblower's identity remains anonymous, and the lawyers have urged steps to protect their client's identity.

Since the transcript of Trump's call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky was revealed, Trump has called for the whistleblower to be unmasked. The call, which showed Trump urging Zelensky to investigate corruption allegations against former Vice President Joe Biden and his son, is at the center of the impeachment inquiry.

The whistleblower's legal team sent a letter to Acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire, citing Trump's language and the $50,000 "reward" offered by two conservative Trump supporters for information about the whistleblower. The letter expressed concerns that the situation will worsen and become more dangerous for the whistleblower and other whistleblowers.

Meanwhile, Trump has continued to tweet about the situation, calling for the whistleblower to be identified and suggesting that they may be a spy. He has also retweeted a Fox News guest who warned that removing him from office could lead to a "Civil War-like fracture" in the country.

Some Republicans have begun to defend Trump, while others have condemned his actions. Tom Bossert, a former Homeland Security Advisor, called the call "deeply disturbing." The impeachment inquiry is ongoing, with Democrats planning to remain in Washington over the break to move "expeditiously" on with hearings and subpoenas.

Title: Gilead Sciences Reveals Cost of Five-Day Coronavirus Treatment Remdesivir

Gilead Sciences, the manufacturer of the investigational antiviral remdesivir, has announced the cost of its treatment for COVID-19 patients. According to an open letter penned by Chairman and CEO Daniel O'Day, the company will charge $2,340 per patient for Medicare and governments of developed countries, equivalent to approximately $390 per vial. For U.S. patients with private health insurance, the cost will be $3,120, with an estimated minimum of $520 per vial or up to $5,720 per patient for a longer duration.

Gilead Sciences claims the prices are below market value, aiming to provide "broad and equitable access" to the treatment. O'Day stated, "As with many other aspects of this pandemic, we are in uncharted territory in pricing remdesivir. Ultimately, we were guided by the need to do things differently. As the world continues to reel from the human, social, and economic impact of this pandemic, we believe that pricing remdesivir well below value is the right and responsible thing to do."

The company has also entered into agreements with drug manufacturers capable of producing generic forms of the drug in developing countries, with plans to begin charging in July. However, some medical experts and doctors have expressed concerns about the cost, citing the lack of mortality benefit and the results of healthcare as a big business.

Dr. Eugene Gu tweeted, "Gilead Sciences charging $2,340 for a 5-day course of Remdesivir that maybe reduces time to recovery, doesn't improve survival, and is likely inferior to the much cheaper dexamethasone for ventilated patients reveals Big Pharma's greed and opportunism during this pandemic."

Gilead Sciences received a $37.5 million grant from the US government to develop and test Remdesivir, and the company projected 2020 revenue for the drug to be $1 billion. Despite some concerns, Dr. Anthony Fauci previously touted the drug as showing promise.

Title: Tariffs' Short-Term Costs: Study Reveals Reduction in Employment and Increased Prices for Manufacturers

A recent study by Federal Reserve economists has shed light on the short-term effects of tariffs on the US manufacturing sector. The research found that the tariffs, implemented as part of the ongoing trade war, have reduced employment and increased prices for American manufacturers.

The study analyzed the impact of tariffs on different industries, comparing trends across various sectors to understand how they corresponded to changes in trade policy. The researchers found that while some industries benefited from being protected from foreign competition, this benefit was largely offset by the increased costs of tariffs on their own inputs and foreign retaliatory tariffs on their exports.

The study's findings are summarized in a series of charts, which break out the three main effects of the trade war: employment, production, and prices. The results show that rising input costs decreased employment and increased producer prices, while foreign retaliation decreased employment as well. Import protection did seem to increase employment, although the effect was borderline statistically significant.

The study's authors compared industries more exposed to each type of effect with those less exposed, finding that the former suffered a reduction in employment of 1.4 percent, with the positive contribution from import protection offset by the negative effects of rising input costs and retaliatory tariffs. The same comparison for producer prices revealed a 4.1 percent increase.

The study's findings must be considered in the context of overall trends. American manufacturing employment was on the rise in 2017 and 2018, but it stalled thereafter, when the tariffs were in full effect. The policy aimed to promote manufacturing work may have contributed to its stagnation instead.

While the study provides valuable insights into the short-term effects of tariffs, it is essential to consider the limitations and potential caveats. The analysis is based on a complex model and may not account for all factors, and the effects of increased uncertainty about future trade policy are not explicitly considered. Nevertheless, the study's findings suggest that the tariffs have had a significant impact on the US manufacturing sector, reducing employment and increasing prices for American manufacturers.

Title: Senate Democrats Plan to Block Neil Gorsuch's Nomination, Potentially Triggering "Nuclear Option"

Article:

The Washington Post and other media outlets report that at least 41 Democrats are planning to block the nomination of Neil Gorsuch on the Senate floor, which could potentially lead to Republicans triggering the so-called "nuclear option" and eliminating the filibuster for Supreme Court nominees. The 60-vote threshold in the Senate, which is required to close debate on most legislation, is a unique aspect of the upper chamber's rules.

The filibuster has survived for so long due to a bipartisan, institutional belief in its importance. However, it has been weakened in the past, with Democrats rewriting the rules in 2013 to eliminate the 60-vote threshold for most federal court appointments, except for Supreme Court nominations.

If Republicans fail to get 60 votes to close debate on Gorsuch's nomination, Democrats would be able to filibuster and stall the Senate until the nomination is withdrawn from the confirmation process. Republicans, led by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, are likely to trigger the "nuclear option" and abolish the filibuster for Supreme Court nominees if they cannot get the necessary votes.

The process would involve several steps, including a vote to invoke cloture, a Republican senator moving to reconsider the cloture motion, and a point of order being raised by McConnell. The Senate President pro tempore would then rule on the point of order, and if it is overruled, McConnell would appeal the decision, triggering a vote on the Senate President's ruling. If the majority votes against the filibuster, a new precedent would be set, allowing for a simple majority vote to approve Supreme Court nominees.

The process is reminiscent of the 2013 rewriting of the rules, which was described by Peter Suderman as "Calvinball," a fictional game with complex and arcane rules that can be changed at any time. The Senate's rules are similar, with the ability to rewrite them with a simple majority vote.

Title: Amazon Rainforest Fires: Separating Fact from Fiction

The recent reports of the Amazon rainforest burning at an unprecedented rate have sparked widespread concern and alarm. However, a closer examination of the data and context reveals a more nuanced picture.

According to NASA's Global Fire Emissions Database, fire activity in the Amazon is above average in some states, but below average in others. The data also shows that the overall numbers are in line with historic data going back to 2003, which is a much longer period than the Brazilian data.

It's essential to understand that the Amazon fire season begins in late July and peaks in mid-September, with most fires being intentionally set by ranchers to clear land for agriculture. The region's dry season makes it difficult to start and spread fires, and the majority of the forest has already been cleared, mostly in the 1990s and 2000s.

The promotion of alarmist and false information about the Amazon fires distracts from the real issues and undermines trust in media and public institutions. It's crucial to separate fact from fiction and understand the complexities of the situation.

In conclusion, while the Amazon rainforest is a vital ecological niche, the data suggests that the recent fires are not as unprecedented as claimed. It's essential to approach this issue with a balanced perspective and not let misinformation dominate the narrative.

Title: Boy Scouts of America Renames Program to Include Girls, But Girl Scouts Remain Skeptical

The Boy Scouts of America (BSA) has announced that it will drop the term "Boy" from its signature program, effective February, and will now be known as Scouts BSA. The decision is part of the organization's efforts to become more inclusive and welcoming to girls. However, the Girl Scouts of the USA (GSUSA) has expressed skepticism about the move, stating that it does not provide any new programming specifically for girls.

The BSA has been facing declining membership numbers, and the decision to open its doors to girls is seen as a way to increase its appeal and attract more young people. The organization has already seen over 3,000 girls participate in its Early Adopter Program, with more expected to join in the coming months. The BSA claims that allowing girls to participate will make it easier for families to consolidate their children's activities under one umbrella.

The Girl Scouts, on the other hand, have been facing their own challenges, including declining membership numbers. The organization has been focusing on developing new programming and resources to stay ahead of the competition. In recent months, the Girl Scouts have introduced new merit badges in STEM fields and a LinkedIn network aimed at supporting female advancement in the workforce.

The BSA's decision to admit girls has already had an impact on the Girl Scouts, with one regional leader reporting a decline of over 500 girls in her council's youth membership this year. The two organizations have historically been at odds, with the BSA's decision to admit girls seen as a direct challenge to the Girl Scouts' dominance in the scouting world.

The BSA's Chief Scout Executive, Mike Surbaugh, has launched a marketing campaign called "Scout Me In" to promote inclusiveness and encourage girls to join the organization. The organization's marketing director, Stephen Medlicott, emphasized that Cub Scouts is now available to all kids, and the organization is excited to welcome girls to the program.

It remains to be seen how the BSA's efforts will impact the Girl Scouts, but the two organizations will likely continue to compete for young people's attention and loyalty.

Title: Clinton's Ties to For-Profit University Raise Questions About Her Critique

Article:

Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton has been vocal about her criticism of for-profit universities, accusing them of charging high prices and delivering degrees of questionable value. However, her own family connections to Laureate Education, a major for-profit university, have raised questions about her motives and trustworthiness. According to a Brookings Institution study, Laureate's Walden University in Minnesota has accumulated $9.8 billion in loans, the second-highest amount of any U.S. college.

Clinton's husband, former President Bill Clinton, received $17.6 million from Laureate for his role as honorary chancellor, which involved advising executives and speaking to students. Additionally, Laureate and its investors have donated millions to the Clinton Foundation, Clinton's presidential campaigns, and related organizations. This raises concerns about the potential for conflicts of interest and the influence of special interests on her policy decisions.

Laureate's business practices have also been criticized, with some practices bordering on ethical red lines. The company pays recruiters commissions for enrolling students, a practice banned in the U.S. due to concerns about predatory lending practices. Additionally, Walden University's loan default rates are higher than the national average, with 56% of graduates failing to repay their loans three years after graduation.

While Clinton's Republican opponent, Donald Trump, has faced criticism for his involvement with Trump University, Clinton's ties to Laureate Education have received less attention. However, the public deserves to know about the potential conflicts of interest and the influence of special interests on her policy decisions.

Title: Millennials' Low Turnout in Elections: A Growing Concern

Millennials, born between 1981 and 1996, are often considered a crucial demographic in American politics. However, despite being well-informed and passionate about issues, they are not translating their awareness into voting action. According to the Harvard Institute of Politics, only 23% of voters under 30 are expected to participate in the upcoming midterm elections, a significant decline from previous years.

The low turnout among young voters is not a new phenomenon. In the 2010 midterm elections, fewer than a quarter of voters aged 18-29 showed up at the polls. This trend has continued, with the Pew Research Center reporting a steady decline in voter registration among young people since 2008. In 2012, the rate of registered voters younger than 30 dropped to 50%, the lowest number recorded since 1996.

So, why are millennials not voting? Some attribute the low turnout to a lack of engagement, but others argue that young people are simply disillusioned with the political process. Ashley Spillane, president of Rock the Vote, believes that millennials are turned off by the current state of politics, which is "really disheartening." The Pew Research Center also notes that the number of millennials identifying as independents has increased to 50%, indicating a lack of affiliation with political parties.

Despite the low turnout, Rock the Vote remains optimistic that millennials are not apathetic. According to Spillane, young people are getting involved at the local level, creating startups, volunteering with organizations, and addressing problems in real-time. Eva Guidarini of the Harvard Institute of Politics shares this optimism, stating that if politics changes in a direction that benefits all Americans, young people will re-engage.

The question remains whether politics will improve unless a new generation gets more involved and pushes for change. As the article concludes, the answer lies in whether millennials will take action and demand a better political system.

Title: Sen. Bernie Sanders Drops Lawsuit Against DNC, But Keeps Options Open

Article: Sen. Bernie Sanders has announced that he will not pursue his lawsuit against the Democratic National Committee (DNC) over his access to voter data files, but has kept the case open, citing the possibility that the DNC may backtrack on its agreement. The decision comes after the DNC suspended Sanders' access to its voter files last month, following allegations that his staffers exploited a computer breakdown to access rival presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's files.

According to Sanders' lawyer, Garvey Schubert Barer, the parties are engaged in discussions to resolve the pending litigation, and Sanders does not intend to serve the DNC with the lawsuit at this time. However, the lawyer noted that Sanders reserves the right to serve the DNC if the dispute is not resolved.

The Federal Rules of Civil Procedure give Sanders up to 90 days to serve notice of his complaint on the DNC. The case had been languishing, with Sanders never serving papers on the DNC, until Judge Tanya S. Chutkan demanded that Sanders make his intentions known earlier this week.

The controversy surrounding Sanders' access to voter data files began when his staffers were accused of exploiting a computer breakdown to access Clinton's files on the DNC's system. Sanders apologized for his staff's behavior and initiated an investigation into the wrongdoing. However, he claimed that the DNC had no power to instantly suspend his access to the voter files, which his campaign needs to develop a strategy for targeting voters in the primaries and caucuses.

The dispute has sparked controversy among liberal activists, who argue that by suspending Sanders' access to the voter files, DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz is putting her finger on the scale for Clinton.

Title: Jeb Bush Urges Vladimir Putin to Respect Ukraine's Sovereignty, Vows Tougher Stance on Russian Aggression

Jeb Bush, a potential Republican presidential candidate, has warned Russian President Vladimir Putin to respect Ukraine's sovereignty and cease his aggressive actions in the region. During a visit to Berlin, Bush emphasized the importance of maintaining the international order and the need for the United States to take a harder line on Russian aggression.

Bush stated that Russia must respect the sovereignty of its neighbors and that its aggression will go unchecked if left unanswered. He also urged Putin to stop his efforts to return Ukraine to the Russian fold, emphasizing that Ukraine is a sovereign European nation that must be allowed to choose its own path.

The Russian president has denied allegations that he has sent troops into Ukraine to stir discord, but satellite photos suggest otherwise. Bush supports economic sanctions on Russia and has backed delivering some U.S. military equipment to Ukraine.

The remarks come after President Obama's comments on Monday, during his visit to the G-7 in Krun, Germany, where he also expressed support for continuing sanctions on Russia and urged Putin to seek compromise. The Kremlin has vowed to adhere to a Cold War-era nuclear treaty, with Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov stating that Russia has no intention to break the treaty.

The U.S. has accused Russia of flight-testing a ground-launched cruise missile with a range prohibited by the treaty, which Russia has denied. In turn, Russia has alleged that some elements of the U.S. missile defense shield violate the treaty.

Bush will meet with German Chancellor Angela Merkel on Tuesday at the conference of the Christian Democratic Union, where they will deliver speeches.

Title: Big Tech Takes a Beating on Capitol Hill, But Stock Market Remains Unfazed

Article:

The Big Four tech companies, Facebook, Apple, Amazon, and Google, faced intense scrutiny on Capitol Hill on Tuesday, with lawmakers from both parties questioning their business practices and influence on the global economy. Despite the grilling, the companies' stock prices remained largely unchanged, underscoring their continued dominance in the market.

Facebook's proposed digital currency, Libra, was met with skepticism from the Senate Banking Committee, with concerns over regulatory and trust issues. The company was also singled out as an antitrust menace in an afternoon hearing before the House Judiciary Committee. Apple, Amazon, and Google faced criticism for user-data transgressions and restrictive business practices.

The companies took a beating from lawmakers, with some calling for greater regulation and oversight. Sen. Martha McSally, R-Ariz., bluntly told Facebook's David Marcus, "I don't trust you guys." Apple is facing a class-action lawsuit over its App Store practices, and Google was questioned about its business dealings in China.

Despite the intense scrutiny, the companies' stock prices remained steady, with Facebook's stock flat at $203.84, Alphabet's shares up slightly to $1,153.46, Apple's shares flat at $204.50, and Amazon's shares down 0.5% to $2,009.90. The quartet has a cumulative market valuation of more than $3 trillion.

Analysts believe the government's efforts to regulate the tech industry will likely result in tweaks to business models and potential fines, rather than forced company breakups. Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives said, "The battle between the Beltway and Big Tech is'more bark than bite' that will likely result in tweaks to business models and potential fines rather than forced company breakups."

The intense scrutiny is unlikely to deter the companies, with some analysts predicting it could even drive innovation and diversification in the industry. As Stanford law professor Doug Melamed noted, "Everybody wants to take a swipe at Big Tech these days, but the stock market seems to be ignoring all that is happening out of Washington, except for the Fed."

Title: President Obama's Biggest Failures: A Consistent Inconsistency

Article:

President Barack Obama has been asked about his biggest failure or disappointment during his first term three times this year, and he has given three different answers. In his most recent response, Obama cited not getting comprehensive immigration reform done as his biggest failure. However, in previous answers, he mentioned not changing the tone in Washington and not achieving his goal of creating a more collaborative atmosphere in the nation's capital.

In an interview with CBS News' Charlie Rose, Obama explained that his biggest mistake during his first term was underestimating the importance of storytelling in his role as President. He stated that while getting policy right is crucial, he also needs to tell a story to the American people that gives them a sense of unity, purpose, and optimism, especially during difficult times.

Obama's answers about his biggest failure have been inconsistent, with him citing different reasons each time. He has also been inconsistent in his claims about his presidency, saying he has not raised taxes and making nearly everything a "top priority." Despite having a super majority of Democrats during his first two years in office, Obama was unable to pass comprehensive immigration reform.

It is worth noting that Obama's biggest failures, as he has described them, are not getting comprehensive immigration reform done, not changing the tone in Washington, and not getting people back to work or turning the economy around as he promised.

Title: Polarization in American Politics: A Growing Trend

The Pew Research Centre has reported that American voters are more polarized than ever before, with the share of Americans expressing consistently conservative or liberal opinions doubling over the past two decades. This growing partisanship has become apparent in various ways, including the rise of the Tea Party and the government shutdown of 2013. The campaign platforms and actions of both Republican and Democratic presidential candidates have also shown a significant shift towards polarization.

One notable example is Republican candidate Mike Huckabee's suggestion that he might use the American military to prevent women from getting abortions. This move is seen as a shocking and unprecedented step, highlighting the increasing polarization of American politics. On the left, Bernie Sanders' campaign is gaining traction, with the self-proclaimed democratic socialist trailing closely behind Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton in many polls. Sanders' willingness to support socialist policies and openly admit to subscribing to socialist ideologies has sparked controversy and raised concerns among some Americans.

The Pew Research Report suggests that the majority of Americans do not have uniformly conservative or liberal views, but the most ideologically oriented and politically active individuals make their voices heard through greater participation in the political process. This vocal minority can be seen as responding to the drastic changes in the American economic climate, including the 2008 recession, which shocked the American psyche and led to widespread unemployment, job insecurity, and housing foreclosures.

The rise of partisan politics can also be attributed to the emergence of candidates who are addressing issues generally considered peripheral to their party's concern or even opposed to their basic principles. For example, Ron Paul's libertarian principles brought him into conflict with fellow Republicans on numerous occasions. The popularity of mixed platforms, which are not generically conservative or liberal, has increased in tandem with the increased polarization of American politics.

The interest in non-traditional and innovative politics can also be seen in the increased interest in US third parties. According to a recent Gallup poll, six to ten Americans now believe a third party is needed. The Free and Equal Elections Foundation sponsored a televised third-party presidential debate in protest of their exclusion from mainstream political debates.

The US may be primed for dramatic political change that goes beyond the mere polarization or radicalization of basic party principles. The unbridled economic growth and stability of the 90s and early 2000s have dissipated, and Americans are striving to reconcile themselves with that fact. This polarization of American politics could be seen as giving way to a widening of the ideological spectrum, which can be seen through the increasing popularity of libertarian platforms within the Republican Party and growing interest in US third parties.

Title: CMS Official Michelle Snyder Announces Retirement After 41 Years of Public Service

Article:

Michelle Snyder, the chief operating officer at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS), has announced her retirement, effective at the end of 2013. Snyder oversaw the development and launch of HealthCare.gov, the federal Obamacare website, which experienced technical issues in its early stages. According to CMS Administrator Marilyn Tavenner, Snyder is retiring after 41 years of public service and will be missed as a key member of the agency's leadership team.

Snyder's deputy, Tim Love, will serve as acting chief operating officer. This marks the second high-level departure from CMS since the launch of Obamacare's insurance markets in October. The agency's chief information officer, Tony Trenkle, left in November.

Prior to Congress in November, Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius named Snyder as a key person responsible for the HealthCare.gov project. However, Representative Darrell Issa, a California Republican and chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, criticized Snyder's role in the website's troubled launch. Issa stated that documents and interviews indicate Snyder was involved in bypassing the recommendation of CMS's top security expert, who recommended delaying the launch of HealthCare.gov due to concerns about security vulnerabilities.

**New Health Law Offers Relief for Those with Employer-Provided Insurance**

The Affordable Care Act, often associated with helping the uninsured, also provides new protections for those with employer-provided health insurance. The law aims to simplify insurance purchases, but its wording can make it difficult for some families to access affordable coverage. The Callaway family, for instance, saw a 30% increase in their health insurance premium, leaving them paying $760 a month.

The law requires essential health benefits, including drugs and hospital care, but these benefits can vary by state. The law also prohibits pre-existing condition waiting periods and allows preventive healthcare services to be covered in full. Additionally, out-of-pocket expenses count towards maximum out-of-pocket expenses, making it easier for individuals to reach their maximum spending limit.

Families like the Callaways can still shop on the new exchanges, but they may not be eligible for subsidies or tax credits. If their plans become unaffordable, they may qualify for a special enrollment opportunity. To determine whether a policy is considered affordable, individuals can consult their state exchange or a navigator.

The new law also introduces changes to insurance plans, including the requirement for all plans to cover essential benefits, such as maternity care, prescription drugs, and in-patient hospital care. Each state is required to select a benchmark plan that other plans must be comparable to, ensuring consistency across the country.

Title: MPs Introduce Bill to Prevent No-Deal Brexit, EU Chief Negotiator Warns of Increased Likelihood

A cross-party group of MPs has introduced a bill aimed at preventing a no-deal Brexit in 10 days' time. The bill, presented by Labour MP Yvette Cooper, would require Prime Minister Theresa May to ask for an extension of Article 50, which mandates the UK's exit from the EU, beyond the current 12 April deadline. If passed, the bill would make it UK law for the PM to request an extension, but it would be up to the EU to grant it or not.

The bill is expected to be debated in the Commons on Wednesday, with supporters hoping to pass it through the House in one day. The Prime Minister is expected to make a statement shortly.

The move comes after the cabinet, which remains split over Brexit, met for eight hours in No 10. The BBC's John Pienaar reported that ministers considered plans to "ramp up" no-deal Brexit preparations and a snap general election was also discussed.

Meanwhile, the EU's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, warned that a no-deal Brexit is now more likely but can still be avoided. He stated that a long extension to the UK's 12 April exit date had "significant risks for the EU" and a "strong justification would be needed."

French President Emmanuel Macron and Irish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar are meeting in Paris to discuss the impact of Brexit. President Macron said the EU "cannot be hostage to the political crisis in the UK" and the government must come forward with "credible" reasons for an extension. He suggested these could include an election, second referendum, or alternative proposals for the future relationship, such as a customs union.

Tory MP Sir Oliver Letwin, who supports Ms Cooper's bill, said: "This is a last-ditch attempt to prevent our country being exposed to the risks inherent in a no-deal exit. We realise this is difficult. But it is definitely worth trying."

Ms Cooper said the UK is "in a very dangerous situation" and MPs "have a responsibility to make sure we don't end up with a catastrophic no deal." She added: "We have been attempting to squeeze into just a couple of days a process that really should have been happening for the last two years - a process of trying to build a consensus around the best way forward."

The bill would need to be agreed by the House of Lords and receive Royal Assent before it becomes law, which could happen as soon as Thursday if the Commons agrees.

Title: Rolling Stone's Investigation into Campus Sexual Assault Raises Questions about Accuracy and Responsibility

Rolling Stone's high-profile story about a alleged gang rape on campus has raised serious questions about the accuracy of the reporting and the responsibility of journalists in covering traumatic events. The story, which was published in November, told the narrative of a young woman named "Jackie" who claimed to have been gang-raped at a fraternity party. However, Rolling Stone has since issued an apology, stating that there are discrepancies in Jackie's account and that they have lost trust in her.

The article highlights the challenges of reporting on traumatic events and the ethical responsibilities that come with it. The author, a former lawyer who worked with refugees and trauma victims, emphasizes the difficulties that people who have experienced trauma face in telling their stories accurately. The author notes that post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) can cause memory loss or make it difficult for individuals to recount their experiences, leading to errors or omissions.

The article also raises questions about the responsibility of journalists in reporting on traumatic events. The author argues that Rolling Stone and the reporter, Sabrina Rubin Erdely, failed to check the details of Jackie's story before publishing it, leaving her vulnerable to scrutiny and potential harm. The article notes that the fraternity where Jackie claimed the attack took place did not host a party on the night she said she was raped, and that no member of the house fits her description of her assailant.

The author concludes that the failure to check the details of Jackie's story was not only a mistake but also a breach of journalistic ethics. The article emphasizes the importance of verifying the accuracy of traumatic stories before publishing them, not only to protect the individuals involved but also to maintain the credibility of the media.

Title: Avaaz Launches Campaign to Mobilize Global Citizens to Vote Against Trump

Avaaz, a registered U.S. charity and one of the world's largest and most powerful activist groups, has launched a campaign to mobilize a "secret swing state" of more than 8 million mostly unregistered "global citizens" and "progressive" Americans living abroad to vote in the U.S. election. The campaign, dubbed the "October surprise that will end Trump," aims to tap into this massive untapped voting block, which Avaaz claims is more likely to be progressive due to its high education level and history of donating to Democratic candidates.

According to Avaaz, 88% of Americans living abroad did not register to vote in the last presidential election, and the charity claims that this massive untapped voting block could decide the outcome of the election. The campaign is centered around a new "super easy" tool enabling left-wing American expats to register to vote quickly and en masse.

Avaaz has enlisted over 30 million people around the world to share the tool, which can be accessed through a tweet. The charity claims that the more people who share the tool, the more Americans abroad will see it, and the more they will be able to stop Trump.

The campaign was launched in London, which has the largest concentration of U.S. expats outside of North America. At the event, several Americans registered to vote before the media to prove how easy it is with Avaaz's new tool.

Avaaz's website encourages people to email potential U.S. voters in other countries, providing a template that reads: "8 million Americans abroad could defeat Trump... if they vote! I wanted to make sure you saw this new overseas registration tool that makes voting dead-easy. It literally takes a few minutes : )"

The campaign makes no mention of other presidential candidates and is framed as simply anti-Trump. Avaaz's website states that the campaign is "not authorized by any candidate or candidate office" and links to Avaaz.org/VoteAbroad, an unintentionally close sound to "Voter Fraud" – an issue that campaigners will be keen to avoid discussing.

Avaaz's Campaigns Director, Meredith Alexander, denied any connection to the Hillary Clinton campaign, stating that Avaaz is a charity governed by American law and is not allowed to coordinate with any candidate. However, she emphasized that Avaaz is allowed to advocate for its position, which is that Trump is a global threat.

Avaaz was formed in 2007 to agitate for various left-wing causes, including animal rights and mass migration. The charity has organized the biggest climate change march in the UK's history and has been described as the globe's largest and most powerful online activist network.

Title: Brazil's Jair Bolsonaro Wins Presidential Election, Promising Radical Change

Brazil's Supreme Electoral Tribunal declared Jair Bolsonaro, a champion of traditional Brazilian values, the winner of the country's presidential election. With 96% of ballots counted, Bolsonaro secured 55.5% of the votes, while his opponent, leftist Fernando Haddad, received 44.5%.

Bolsonaro, a 63-year-old congressman with a 27-year career in Congress, campaigned on a platform of tackling violent crime and corruption, which have plagued Brazil for years. He also promised to reduce the size of the government and privatize state companies, winning over much of the business community.

The election was marked by concerns over Bolsonaro's extreme views, including his reputation for making offensive statements and his support for loosening gun laws. However, his message resonated with many Brazilians who are frustrated with the political class and want change.

Voters in the runoff election appeared to look past warnings that Bolsonaro's presidency could erode democracy and embraced a chance for radical change. His supporters celebrated in the streets, with fireworks and car horns echoing through the cities of Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo.

The election was marked by a tight race, with Bolsonaro going into the election as the clear front-runner after receiving 46% of the votes in the first round. However, Haddad was unable to make up the difference, and Bolsonaro ultimately secured the presidency.

The election has sparked concerns over the future of democracy in Brazil, with some warning that Bolsonaro's presidency could lead to a crackdown on civil rights and an erosion of institutions. However, Bolsonaro has vowed to respect the Constitution and institutions, and his supporters are hopeful that he will bring about positive change to the country.

Title: Rep. Todd Akin Huddles with Conservative Activists in Tampa Amid Pressure to Abandon Senate Bid

Rep.
