Trump also defended his performance at the NATO summit in Brussels, claiming that allies are spending more money on defense at his behest and throwing in criticism of the media and Russia. However, NATO countries said they were already increasing defense spending, and questioned Trump's commitment to the alliance.

Several Republicans, including Sen. Rand Paul, defended Trump's meeting with Putin, while others, such as former House Speaker Newt Gingrich, called for Trump to clarify his statements and correct his mistakes. Former New Jersey Gov. Christine Todd Whitman even called for Trump to resign, saying that his actions are "irrational and dangerous."

Congressional Democrats continued to condemn Trump's relationship with Putin, with House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi calling his actions "dangerous, disgraceful, and damaging." Some Democrats even called Trump's comments "treasonous," with former CIA Director John Brennan saying that Trump is "wholly in the pocket of Putin."

Title: Republican Leaders Announce Boycott of ObamaCare-Related Committee, Citing Concerns Over Medicare Costs

Article:

In a move seen as a challenge to the Affordable Care Act, Republican leaders in the House and Senate announced on Thursday that they will boycott the Individual Payment Advisory Board (IPAB), a committee established to help control Medicare costs. The decision was met with criticism from the White House, which slammed the move as "out of touch" with the American people.

The IPAB, also known as the "death panel" by some critics, has the authority to force payment cuts on insurers, drug companies, and other service providers if Medicare costs rise beyond certain levels. Republicans argue that these cuts would lead to reduced access to care for seniors, with House Speaker John Boehner stating that "reduced payments will force providers to stop seeing Medicare patients, the same way an increased number of doctors have stopped taking Medicaid patients."

The 15-member advisory board is supposed to be composed of members from both parties, with nominees subject to Senate confirmation. However, the boycott by Republican leaders may not have a significant impact on the panel's functioning, as the law requires the President to consult with Congress on nominations, but the President has the authority to make their own appointments.

The move is seen as a renewed effort by Republicans to repeal the Affordable Care Act, with Boehner stating that he supports total repeal rather than efforts to amend the law as it goes into effect over the next year. The House has voted to repeal or partially repeal the law over 30 times, with several of these votes being signed into law.

Economists have predicted that the Medicare board's services may not be needed in the near future, as Medicare cost increases appear to be manageable. The White House, however, has defended the IPAB as a necessary measure to ensure the long-term sustainability of the Medicare program.

Title: Obama Meets with Allies to Discuss ISIS Strategy Amid Concerns Over Progress

Article:

President Barack Obama met with defense chiefs from 21 countries to discuss the campaign against the Islamic State (ISIS) amid concerns over the group's continued gains in Iraq and Syria. The United States has assembled a coalition to combat the extremist group, but critics argue that the strategy has both upsides and downsides. While the U.S. has enjoyed some successes, such as driving ISIS away from the Mosul Dam, the president remains concerned about the besieged Syrian town of Kobani and parts of Iraq's Anbar province.

Critics, including Republican Senator John McCain, have challenged the president's strategy, citing the group's continued territorial gains in both countries. McCain dismissed the U.S.-led airstrikes as "pinpricks" that have not stopped the militants. Military analyst Anthony Cordesman at the Center for Strategic and International Studies agrees, stating that the air war has been a "very limited, very slow campaign."

Despite the challenges, Obama emphasized that the campaign to defeat ISIS cannot be waged solely on military terms. He stressed the need to offer political and economic alternatives to the militants and to address the ideological strain of extremism that has taken root in the region. The U.S. and its allies are also hampered by sectarian and political divisions, including disagreements over which enemy in Syria is a bigger threat - ISIS or the regime of Bashar al-Assad.

The U.S. strategy depends on cooperation from local ground forces to beat back ISIS, but until that cooperation materializes, airstrikes can only do so much. Michael O'Hanlon of the Brookings Institution warns that ISIS will likely expand its control by a few percent, but it is unlikely to make huge new inroads. Obama has been adamant that he will not order American ground forces into battle, but O'Hanlon suggests that a limited presence of U.S. Special Forces and military spotters could be helpful.

The president has been clear that the U.S. is still in the early stages of what he promises will be a long-term campaign. The U.S.-led military effort is ongoing, with airstrikes continuing to target ISIS positions in both Iraq and Syria.

Title: Flynn's Influence Lingers in White House Despite Dismissal

Article:

Former national security adviser Michael Flynn has been out of the White House for 84 days, but his presence still casts a long shadow over Donald Trump's presidency. Since Flynn's highly public dismissal in February, the president has praised him as a "wonderful man" and tweeted in his defense hours before former acting Attorney General Sally Yates testified that she warned the White House that Flynn had been "compromised" by the Russian government.

This continued loyalty from Trump has given Flynn a lingering influence over policy in the White House, where staffers initially hired by Flynn, including his deputy K.T. McFarland, remain on the National Security Council and in other positions. Senior administration officials, including chief strategist Steve Bannon, also remain loyal to Flynn and have worked to undermine his successor, Lt. Gen. H.R. McMaster, according to several people familiar with the situation.

Flynn, a three-star general who was dismissed from his post as Defense Intelligence Agency chief under President Barack Obama in 2014, backed Trump early and campaigned alongside him. He developed a close and trusted relationship with the candidate and his senior aides at a time when few serious Republicans would agree to advise him. "Flynn was by far the most accomplished of all of them, and, in the land of the blind, the one-eyed man is king," said a former George W. Bush national security official.

Trump's refusal to disavow Flynn has drawn the administration further into a controversy that began with allegations that Trump campaign aides had inappropriate contacts with Russian government officials. Those claims remain under investigation by congressional committees as well as the FBI. Flynn's failure to disclose his contacts with officials and payments received from Russian government-related entities has deepened the appearance of scandal around the administration. On Monday, NBC News reported that Flynn failed to disclose to the DIA when it renewed his security clearance last year that he received a check totaling nearly $34,000 from a Russian propaganda network.

Yates told lawmakers on Monday that she warned the Trump administration that Flynn was susceptible to blackmail, though she declined to say why. She echoed the concerns of Obama, who fired Flynn as head of the DIA in 2014 and warned Trump against hiring him when the two sat down after Trump's victory in November.

The relationship Flynn enjoyed with the president differs markedly from that of his successor, McMaster, who has clashed with the president repeatedly since joining the administration. Trump pushed back against McMaster's attempt to replace McFarland, who is set to become ambassador to Singapore. Last week, it was McFarland, not McMaster, who accompanied the president to a meeting with the Australian prime minister in New York, and Trump and McFarland kept reporters waiting on the tarmac for 40 minutes as they talked inside the plane at Andrews Air Force Base on Sunday night, after the president spent the weekend golfing at his club in New Jersey.

White House chief of staff Reince Priebus earlier this month prevented McMaster from bringing on Brig. Gen. Ricky Waddell as his deputy, and though McFarland was supposed to depart for Singapore in mid-May, she has been telling associates in recent weeks that she's not leaving her NSC post anytime soon. McMaster has worked to reshape the organization in the wake of Flynn's departure, removing Bannon from the NSC's Principals Committee and eliminating a handful of positions created by Flynn.

Executive officer John Reed, a Flynn hire, was reassigned to the Coast Guard last week, and Adam Lovinger, a longtime national security official dispatched to the NSC from the Pentagon at Flynn's request, had his security clearance revoked by Secretary of Defense James Mattis' chief of staff, Kevin Sweeney. Lovinger, according to internal communications reviewed by [source], had also clashed in recent months with his boss at the Pentagon over the types of issues the office focuses on, urging more attention be given to the threat of Iran and Islamic extremism – two issues on which Flynn was outspoken and controversial both in his career at the Defense Intelligence Agency and on the campaign trail with Trump. In response to questions about Lovinger's status, the Pentagon declined to comment on a personnel issue.

A senior administration official rejected the notion that McMaster is working to rid the NSC of Flynn aides, pointing to over a dozen Flynn hires who McMaster has kept on board, including Matt Pottinger, the council's senior director for Asia, who received an award at an all-hands meeting last Thursday.

Title: Reflecting on the Life and Legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

As we mark the 50th anniversary of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s assassination, it is a moment to reflect on the life and legacy of a courageous leader who fought for equality and justice. For many, including the author, Dr. King's message of nonviolent resistance and civil rights resonated deeply.

The author's personal connection to Dr. King began at the age of 8, when he was living in poverty and first became aware of the young civil rights leader's efforts to bring about change. Watching Dr. King on television, the author was captivated by his manner, empathy, and kindness. As he learned more about Dr. King's work, the author was inspired by his unwavering commitment to the fight against discrimination and oppression.

Despite facing immense danger and threats, Dr. King never wavered in his pursuit of justice. His "I Have a Dream" speech, which the author read as a child, emphasized the importance of recognizing the inherent rights of all individuals, regardless of their gender, race, faith, or sexual orientation.

The author's personal experiences with poverty and homelessness made Dr. King's message particularly relatable and impactful. As someone who has worked in politics and the White House, the author notes that the nation is currently more divided than ever, and Dr. King's wisdom, words, and compassion are needed now more than ever.

Fifty years after his assassination, Dr. King's legacy continues to inspire and guide individuals from all walks of life. His unwavering commitment to justice and equality serves as a reminder of the importance of recognizing and protecting the rights of all individuals.

**Ethiopia Faces Worst Drought in Decades, Millions at Risk of Malnutrition**

Ethiopia is facing its worst drought in decades, leaving millions of people without food and water. The crisis has forced the government and the United Nations to launch a $1.4 billion appeal to feed 10.2 million Ethiopians, but only half of the required funds have been received so far.

The drought has been exacerbated by a strong El Niño, which has blocked two consecutive rainy seasons, affecting 85% of the country. The government has had to seek additional food aid from the United States and other donors. The U.S. Agency for International Development has dispatched an emergency response team to provide assistance, including nearly $4 million in corn and wheat seeds for over 200,000 families.

Malnutrition rates in the worst-affected areas have surpassed 20%, higher than the World Health Organization's emergency threshold of 15%. The United Nations' World Food Programme estimates that over 2 million children, pregnant women, and breast-feeding mothers are suffering from moderate acute malnutrition. The UNICEF estimates that almost 500,000 children need treatment for severe acute malnutrition.

The situation is dire, with many families forced to migrate in search of water and pasture for their livestock, making it difficult for them to access food rationing programs. One woman, Haso Bultum, 27, has been walking for hours in the sun with her malnourished 9-month-old twins, searching for food and water.

The World Food Programme warns that it could run out of food within two months unless significant new funding is received. The organization has been calling for urgent funding for months, but only a quarter of the required resources have been received.

The lack of access to water is another major issue, with almost 6 million people in need of emergency water supplies. The Children's and Family Charitable Organization in Fentale notes that the lack of water makes sanitation impossible, increasing the risk of disease.

For those affected, the future looks bleak. Genet Tamisat, 27, and her young children are among the millions struggling to survive. "We have no water and no food," she said, wiping sweat off her forehead. "I don't know what is coming for the future, but I have no hope about the rain."

Title: Denver City Council Rejects Proposal to Ban Marijuana Use on Private Property in Public View

The Denver City Council has voted 7-6 to reject a proposal that would have prohibited marijuana use on private property if it was in public view. The proposal, introduced by Councilwoman Jeanne Robb, aimed to ban marijuana consumption in any outdoor location on private residential property where it was "clearly observable from a public street, highway, or sidewalk."

The proposal was met with opposition from advocates who argued that it would strip away the rights of residents to consume cannabis on their own property. Mason Tvert, communications director for the Marijuana Policy Project, stated that the proposal is "irrational" and "strips away the rights voted by residents of Colorado to consume cannabis."

The Denver City Council's decision comes as Colorado prepares to start legalizing the sale of recreational marijuana on January 1. The city's police chief, Robert White, has stated that if the proposal had been passed, it would not have been a high priority for enforcement.

The decision is seen as a victory for advocates of marijuana legalization, who argue that it is a matter of personal freedom and autonomy. The debate surrounding marijuana use is not limited to Denver, as other cities and states are also grappling with the issue. Washington state, for example, is expected to start allowing pot sales in 2014.

In related news, the city of Chicago is working on legislation to regulate the growth and dispensing of medical marijuana. The proposed measure would allow 22 centers to grow and dispense cannabis in the city, but would prohibit them from opening within 2,500 feet of any school, day care center, or residential area. The measure still needs to be voted on and approved by the Chicago City Council.

Title: Conservative Media to Address Identity Crisis at CPAC

Conservative media outlets are set to gather at the annual Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) to discuss the future of their industry and how to gain more recognition and credibility among the mainstream media. The panel, titled "Survivor: Conservative Journalism," will bring together representatives from leading conservative news outlets, including Fox News, Townhall, and The Daily Caller, to address the challenges they face.

The discussion comes on the heels of a recent controversy surrounding the conservative website Breitbart.com's publication of false information about Chuck Hagel, now President Obama's secretary of defense. The website alleged that Hagel received funding from a group called "Friends of Hamas," which was later found to be nonexistent. This incident has sparked criticism about the lack of fact-checking and accountability in conservative media.

Thought leaders on the right have argued that conservative journalism is too aggressive, too weaponized, and too loose with the facts. Erick Erickson, a prominent conservative blogger, wrote that conservative journalists have "forgotten the basics of reporting" and are too focused on highlighting controversies, no matter how trivial. Alex Koppelman, editor at The New Yorker, echoed this sentiment, stating that right-wing journalists need to take their commitment to journalism more seriously if they want to be taken seriously.

The panelists, including Keith Urbahn, a former chief of staff to Donald Rumsfeld, and Katie Pavilch, news editor of Townhall, agree that building up good journalists committed to the basics and conducting solid, documented investigative reporting will be key to gaining credibility in the industry. The discussion at CPAC aims to address these challenges and provide a platform for conservative media outlets to reflect on their practices and improve their reputation.

Title: Trump Criticized by Professional Athletes Over NFL and NBA Comments

President Donald Trump faced backlash from professional athletes over the weekend after he made comments about NFL players kneeling during the national anthem and NBA star Stephen Curry's decision not to visit the White House.

At a campaign rally in Alabama on Friday night, Trump said that NFL players who kneel during the national anthem should be fired and fans should leave games. He also criticized Curry, saying that the Golden State Warriors point guard was "hesitating" and that the invitation to visit the White House was withdrawn.

Several NFL players responded to Trump's comments on Twitter, with Washington Redskins linebacker Zach Brown telling the president to "stay in his place" and Detroit Lions tight end Eric Ebron suggesting that Trump should "stick to politics."

The NBA also weighed in, with Chris Paul, the head of the NBA Players Association, questioning whether Trump would call players "a son of a b----" to their face. LeBron James, the vice president of the NBA Players Association, called Trump a "bum" and said that visiting the White House was an honor "until you showed up."

Trump's comments came as his party's latest efforts to repeal and replace ObamaCare stumbled, with Sen. John McCain coming out against the plan on Friday. Trump also swiped at McCain during the rally, calling his opposition "terrible" and vowing that Republicans would replace his predecessor's signature health-care law "eventually."

The NFL and NBA have been at the center of controversy in recent months, with many players using their platforms to speak out on social justice issues and protest police brutality. Trump's comments have been criticized as divisive and disrespectful, with many seeing them as an attempt to distract from the country's real problems.

The White House has not issued a formal invitation to the Golden State Warriors, but the NBA has been communicating with the White House about a potential visit.

Title: American Families' Financial Situation Revealed in New Survey

The latest survey from the Federal Reserve has shed light on the financial situation of American families, providing a detailed picture of the impact of the economic crisis on household finances. According to the report, consumer spending has remained surprisingly resilient, despite the devastating losses suffered by the middle class.

The survey found that American families saved less and only slowly repaid debts, with the share of families saving anything decreasing to 52% in 2010 from 56.4% in 2007. Additionally, the median amount saved by families has not changed significantly since 2007. The report also noted that families are saving less for long-term goals, such as retirement, education, and buying a home, and more as a precautionary measure to ensure they have enough liquidity to meet short-term needs.

The survey also revealed that families are struggling to reduce their debt burden, with 74.9% of households still owing something. The median amount of debt has not changed since 2007, and the decline in reported incomes has increased the weight of those debts. However, historically low interest rates have helped to offset this effect, and families have been able to reduce debt payments by refinancing into mortgages with longer terms and deferring repayment of student loans and other obligations.

The survey also showed that Americans are shifting the types of debt they carry, with a decline in credit card debt and an increase in education-related debt. The share of families with credit card debt decreased by 6.7 percentage points to 39.4%, and the median balance fell 16.1% to $2,600. Additionally, families reduced the number of credit cards they carried, with 32% of families saying they had no cards, up from 27% in 2007.

The report also highlighted large disparities in the impact of the crisis, with families in the middle 60% of the population losing a larger share of their wealth over the three-year period than the wealthiest and poorest families. This is largely due to the fact that the wealth of the middle class is mostly in housing, and the median amount of home equity dropped to $75,000 in 2010 from $110,000 in 2007. The report also noted that the recession reduced income inequality in the United States, at least temporarily, as the average income of the wealthiest families fell much more sharply than the median.

Title: Republicans Face Reality of Tax Rate Increases as Deadline Looms

As the deadline for the Bush tax rates to expire approaches, Republicans are coming to terms with the reality of tax rate increases. With three weeks to go, the only question is by how much and for whom the rates will rise. Many Republicans are discussing a small boost in marginal tax rates, coupled with raising the threshold for wealthy Americans facing tax increases from $250,000 to $500,000 or higher in annual income.

The proposal would require serious cuts to entitlement programs, but there is no evidence that President Barack Obama and Democrats have given in on any specific entitlement cuts in closed-door negotiations. If House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) and Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) are unable to come to an agreement with Obama, the highest marginal tax rate will jump from 35% to 39.6% on January 1, the same as it was under former President Bill Clinton.

Tax rates on estates will also soar, and nearly 30 million more Americans will get hit with the alternative minimum tax, originally aimed at making sure wealthier individuals and families couldn't completely avoid federal taxes. However, there are numerous problems with the modest tax hikes for entitlement cuts trade-off, which GOP Hill aides stressed has not been formally offered yet.

Democrats believe they are dealing from a place of strength in these negotiations and are unlikely to give up concessions on entitlement programs without big moves by Boehner. "We are winning," said a top Hill Democratic staffer. "We don't have to give up on anything yet."

Boehner also faces pressure from his right and is concerned whether House Majority Leader Eric Cantor (R-Va.) and Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) will support him. He has so far refused to agree to any increase in tax rates, even though many in his party are already acknowledging such an outcome is unavoidable. The best Republicans can do, these lawmakers say, is limit the size of the increases while working to shift the political blame to Democrats.

The speaker is opposed to raising tax rates, because raising tax rates costs jobs, said Michael Steel, spokesman for Boehner. On top of that, any suggestion Republicans could back a tax increase faces some stiff opposition in the Senate. "That doesn't really help solve the problem," said Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-Utah), ranking member of the powerful Finance Committee. "I'm against raising tax rates. We know that if we raise those tax rates and we don't have corresponding reductions in spending, we'll get the tax rates and no spending reductions. That's just a game that the Democrats play over and over and over, and the American people let them get away with it sometimes."

Title: Senate Republicans Revise Tax Cut Bill to Include Repeal of Obamacare's Individual Mandate

The Senate Republicans have revised their tax cut bill to include the repeal of Obamacare's individual mandate, a move that could free up more money for deeper tax cuts and take a swipe at the healthcare law they have repeatedly tried to repeal. The change is expected to save the government over $300 billion over the next decade by freeing people from the obligation to have health care coverage and the government from the responsibility of subsidizing much of that coverage.

The revised bill would eliminate the individual mandate, which requires most Americans to have health insurance or face a penalty. This change is expected to result in 13 million fewer people having coverage in 2027 without the pressure from the mandate.

The move is seen as a way for Republicans to win over wavering senators and make their tax cut plan more ambitious. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said the inclusion of the individual mandate repeal would be "helpful" and allow for more tax relief for the middle class.

Democrats, however, have blasted the move, saying it adds insult to an already injurious tax cut package that delivers most of its benefits to businesses. They argue that ending the individual mandate will chase younger, healthier people out of the markets, leaving only older, sicker customers and thus ruining the economics of the 2010 healthcare law.

The revised bill also includes other changes, such as doubling the child tax credit from $1,000 to $2,000 and making changes to individual tax rates. The plan would eliminate some deductions, such as the one for state and local taxes paid, and use the savings to pay for lowering the rates.

The revised bill is expected to be voted on in the Senate this week, with possible floor action the week after Thanksgiving. The House tax bill, which advanced out of the Ways and Means Committee last week, did not include a repeal of the individual mandate, but some Republicans said they would like it to be part of the discussion as leaders prepare for a floor vote in the House this week.

Title: Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's Testimony on Benghazi Attack Raises Questions

Article:

Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton recently appeared before two congressional panels to answer questions about the 2012 Benghazi attack, which resulted in the death of the U.S. ambassador and three other Americans. The attack, which occurred on September 11, 2012, saw heavily armed terrorists overrun the U.S. consulate in Libya, killing the ambassador and setting the building on fire. The attackers then followed dozens of Americans to a more heavily fortified annex nearby, where three more were killed, including two Navy SEALs.

The White House and top administration officials initially claimed that the attack was a spontaneous protest turned violent, sparked by a YouTube video deemed offensive by Muslims. However, it was later revealed that no one in the intelligence community ever said the attack was spontaneous or caused by the video.

During the hearing, Secretary Clinton grew defensive and angry when asked why the administration had given out faulty information for so long. She stated, "What difference, at this point, does it make?" This response has been seen as a characteristic of the Democratic mindset, which prioritizes achieving goals over transparency and accountability.

The hearing was intended to find out why the administration said the attack was caused by a video, but Secretary Clinton refused to answer, saying it was less important to focus on the past and more important to find and bring those responsible to justice. This response has been criticized as evasive and uncooperative.

The incident has raised concerns about the Obama administration's handling of the crisis and its willingness to prioritize political expediency over transparency. The incident has also sparked questions about the Democratic Party's approach to accountability and honesty, with some critics arguing that the party prioritizes winning over truth.

The incident has also drawn comparisons to the Clinton family's history of controversy, including Bill Clinton's affair with a White House intern and Hillary Clinton's own financial dealings. The incident has raised concerns about the potential for future politicians to prioritize their own interests over the truth.

Title: Roger Ailes, Founder of Fox News, Dies at 77

Roger Ailes, the television pioneer who built Fox News into a cable powerhouse before leaving the company last year, died on Thursday at the age of 77. Ailes was a confidant of presidents and an acknowledged master of communications, known for his ability to shape America's media landscape.

Ailes founded Fox News in 1996 and built it into the nation's longest-running No. 1 cable news network. He resigned from Fox in July amid charges of sexual harassment. His widow, Elizabeth Ailes, confirmed the news in a statement, describing him as a "loving husband, father, and friend."

According to the Palm Beach County Medical Examiner's Office, Ailes died of complications from a fall at his home on May 10. Rupert Murdoch, executive chairman of 21st Century Fox and Fox News Channel, expressed his sadness over the development, saying that Ailes was a "brilliant broadcaster" who played a huge role in shaping America's media over the last 30 years.

Fox News host Sean Hannity also paid tribute to his former boss, describing him as a "great patriotic warrior" who had dramatically changed the political and media landscape for the better. Ailes left Fox under a cloud of controversy in July, although he denied the allegations.

Ailes was born in Warren, Ohio, and attended Ohio University, where he majored in radio and television. He launched his career in black and white-era television by working for local personality Mike Douglas. He later worked on several presidential campaigns, including those of Richard Nixon, Ronald Reagan, and George H.W. Bush. He also helped build CNBC before being chosen by Murdoch to launch Fox News.

Ailes was married to Elizabeth Ailes in 1998, and they had one son, Zachary, born on New Year's Day 2000.

Title: State Department Releases Previously-Unreleased Hillary Clinton Emails from 2009

The State Department has released 44 previously-unreleased emails from Hillary Clinton's time as Secretary of State, which were obtained by the conservative legal group Judicial Watch as part of a lawsuit. The emails, which cover Clinton's first three months in office in early 2009, show her interacting with lobbyists, political donors, and business interests.

The emails were recovered from a search of agency computer files from longtime Clinton aide Huma Abedin and include messages exchanged with a senior Morgan Stanley investment executive, whom Clinton met with later that year at her office in Washington. The emails are separate from a larger batch of work-related emails recovered from Clinton's private server, which her legal team turned over to the State Department last year.

One email, dated February 2009, shows Clinton's chief of staff, Cheryl Mills, informing her that National Security Agency and State Department officials discussed developing a modified BlackBerry for Clinton that could be used in restricted State Department offices. Clinton called the development "good news," but she continued using a private BlackBerry tied to her private server.

The FBI plans to turn over the reconstructed Clinton emails to the State Department for public release. The emails are part of a larger batch of several thousand work-related emails recovered from Clinton's private server, which her legal team turned over to the State Department last March.

Title: New Report Suggests John Podesta's Email Hack Was a Simple Phishing Attack

A new report by SecureWorks, a security firm, has shed light on the hacking of John Podesta's email account, which was part of a larger cyber-attack on the Democratic National Committee (DNC) and Hillary Clinton's campaign. According to the report, Podesta fell victim to a common phishing attack, where he was tricked into giving away his email password to a Russian hacking ring known as Fancy Bear.

Fancy Bear, also known as APT28 and Sofacy, is believed to be sponsored by the Russian government, and has been linked to several high-profile breaches, including those of the German parliament, the Italian military, and the Saudi foreign ministry. The group's mistake was not setting the Bitly links to private, allowing investigators to identify other targets.

The hacking of Podesta's email account was part of a larger cyber-attack on the DNC, which resulted in the release of thousands of emails belonging to the Democratic National Convention and Clinton's campaign. While Trump claimed that the hacking could have been carried out by anyone, including China or another country, 17 intelligence agencies have concluded that Russia was behind the attacks.

The hacking has become a key issue in the 2016 election, highlighting the vulnerability of America's cybersecurity and the Russian government's efforts to influence the outcome of the election.

Title: Governors Divided on Trump's Plan to Reopen Businesses Amid COVID-19 Pandemic

The White House released a three-phase plan on Thursday to provide guidelines for states to reopen their economies while ensuring the safety of their citizens. The plan suggests that states should begin loosening restrictions after new COVID-19 cases have declined for at least 14 days. However, governors across the United States are divided on the plan, with Democrats expressing concerns about the lack of testing support from the federal government and Republicans showing enthusiasm for a swift return to normalcy.

Democratic governors, such as New Mexico's Michelle Lujan Grisham and New York's Andrew Cuomo, emphasized the need for more testing and hospital capacity before reopening the economy. They argued that premature reopening could lead to a resurgence of the virus and undo the progress made by health workers and first responders.

On the other hand, Republican governors, such as Tennessee's Bill Lee, Iowa's Kim Reynolds, Nebraska's Pete Ricketts, and Idaho's Brad Little, expressed enthusiasm for the plan and are planning to implement similar strategies in their states. They believe that the federal government is providing the necessary guidance and support to help states reopen their economies.

Some governors, like Colorado's Jared Polis, acknowledged that the plan resembles the state's own plan but wished for a national testing strategy. Others, such as Oregon's Kate Brown, emphasized the need for more federal assistance in terms of personal protective equipment and increased testing capacity.

Texas Governor Greg Abbott announced on Friday a series of executive orders to start reopening shuttered businesses, making it the first state to lay out a defined rollback of COVID-19 restrictions. Retail outlets will be able to open on April 24, as long as they can deliver items to customers' cars or homes to minimize contact. The state will also loosen restrictions on surgeries, permitting procedures that would not deplete hospital capacity or personal protective equipment needed to cope with COVID-19.

The varying responses from governors highlight the challenges and complexities of reopening the economy during the ongoing pandemic. While some governors are optimistic about the plan, others are more cautious, emphasizing the need for more testing and hospital capacity before taking steps towards normalcy.

Title: Trump Criticizes Media, Accuses Washington Post of "Fake News"

President Donald Trump lashed out at the media, specifically targeting The Washington Post, in a series of tweets on Monday. He claimed the "Mainstream Media" has "gone bonkers" and accused the media of pushing "Radical Left Democrat views." Trump also accused the media of "large scale false reporting" and called it "the Enemy of the People."

The president's criticism came after The Washington Post published a story recounting the fallout of his incendiary tweets targeting four progressive congresswomen, including Reps. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Ilhan Omar, Rashida Tlaib, and Ayanna Pressley. Trump took issue with a line in the story that said his advisers wrote out talking points and handed him "reams of opposition research" on the four congresswomen.

Trump denied the claim, stating that he had no talking points and that "reams of paper" were never given to him. He also claimed that the story was "made up" and that The Post had no sources. However, a Post photographer had previously captured a photo of Trump at a White House event with sheets of paper containing bullet points of information about Omar and the other representatives.

Trump's criticism of the media is not new, as he frequently describes coverage he deems unfavorable as "fake news" and has labeled certain media outlets the "enemy of the people." The president has been preoccupied with the media coverage of his attacks on the four congresswomen, which began with tweets eight days ago saying the lawmakers should "go back" to their countries despite all four being U.S. citizens.

Title: Giuliani Clarifies Trump's Potential Pardon Stance in Russia Investigation

The lead attorney for President Donald Trump, Rudy Giuliani, clarified the president's stance on potential pardons for individuals involved in the ongoing investigation into Russia's interference in the 2016 election. Giuliani stated that the president is not planning to issue pardons in the current investigation, emphasizing that "the president is not going to issue a pardon in this investigation."

However, Giuliani left open the possibility that the president could take action after the investigation concludes if he determines that individuals were "treated unfairly." He also raised the prospect that the president might consider pardons in the future, stating that "when the whole thing is over, things might get cleaned up with some presidential pardons."

Giuliani's comments come after he previously suggested that targets in the investigation could be pardoned. The former New York mayor also renewed his attacks on the legitimacy of the Russia inquiry headed by Justice Department special counsel Robert Mueller, citing findings in the recent inspector general's report on the conduct of two senior FBI agents.

Giuliani called for a review of the origins of the Russia investigation, citing the inspector general's report, which revealed text messages exchanged by the agents disparaging Trump. He also expressed concerns about the potential impact of FBI agent Peter Strzok's involvement in the investigation, stating that it is important to learn whether Strzok had "infected" the investigation before he was removed last year.

The investigation, which has led to charges against 20 individuals, including former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort, is ongoing, with Mueller's team seeking an interview with Trump as part of their inquiry into whether the president sought to obstruct the probe. Giuliani stated that a decision on the interview would likely be made by July 4.

Title: Democrats Surpass Republicans in Fundraising for Midterm Elections

The 2018 midterm elections are just four weeks away, and the Democratic Party is gaining momentum in terms of fundraising. According to recent reports, 60 Democratic candidates have raised $1 million or more in the last three months, erasing the Republican Party's typical fundraising edge. This surge in donations is fueled by an energetic base of small donors, with many contributing to opposition to President Trump.

In Fresno, California, Democratic candidate Andrew Janz raised an impressive $4.1 million in the third quarter, aiming to topple eight-term Republican Representative Devin Nunes, chair of the House Intelligence Committee and a strong ally of President Trump. Janz attributes his donor base to widespread opposition to Nunes, stating, "In many parts of the country and in many parts of our state here, and even locally, people wanted this guy out of office."

Other Democratic challengers have also announced significant fundraising totals for the third quarter, including Sharice Davids in eastern Kansas, Amy McGrath in central Kentucky, and Elissa Slotkin in southern Michigan.

The Congressional Leadership Fund, a GOP super PAC aligned with House Republicans, has spent $90 million on the general-election campaign, compared to $51 million by its Democratic rival, the House Majority PAC. However, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) has outspent the National Republican Congressional Committee (NRCC) $64 million to $47 million. Additionally, Democratic House candidates have outspent Republican candidates $109 million to $60 million, thanks to the outpouring of small-donor contributions.

While fundraising success does not guarantee victory, it does provide a significant advantage for Democratic candidates. However, many are still challenging incumbents who have won at least once before, making the race more competitive.

Title: Fox News Undergoes Major Changes After Roger Ailes' Departure

Fox News, a 24-hour cable news channel, has undergone significant changes following the departure of its co-founder, Roger Ailes. The sudden exit of Ailes, who was accused of sexual harassment by former anchor Gretchen Carlson, led to a wave of allegations from other women who worked at the network. In response, James Murdoch, the CEO of 21st Century Fox, and his brother Lachlan, the executive chairman, launched an internal investigation, led by the law firm Paul, Weiss.

The investigation was prompted by allegations of sexual harassment and a toxic work environment. Ailes denied all allegations of sexual harassment, and his attorney, Susan Estrich, stated that he has a permit to carry handguns for personal protection. The investigation led to the departure of several high-ranking executives, including Ailes' closest allies.

In a surprising move, the Murdochs elevated Bill Shine, Ailes' closest deputy, and Jack Abernethy, a Fox Television Stations executive, to co-presidents of Fox News. They also kept on Dianne Brandi, the general counsel, and Suzanne Scott, executive vice president, programming and development. These moves seemed counter-intuitive to those who saw the younger Murdochs as agitating for change.

The Murdochs' decision to promote Shine and Brandi has raised questions about whether the company is truly committed to change or simply trying to put the past behind them. Ailes' departure was seen as a concession to the younger Murdochs, who were not fans of their father's prized deputy. James Murdoch, in particular, was reportedly troubled by Ailes' role in fueling the rise of Donald Trump and the demographics of Fox's aging audience.

The internal investigation, led by Paul, Weiss lawyers, presented a list of women whom they should speak to, according to three people briefed on the matter. The investigation is ongoing, and its findings have not been made public.

Title: Hundreds of White Nationalists Rally at University of Virginia Against Confederate Statue Removal

Hundreds of white nationalists gathered at the University of Virginia, protesting the planned removal of a statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee. The group, almost entirely white and male, waved torches and chanted slogans such as "White lives matter" and "You will not replace us" as they marched through the university campus. The rally was met by a smaller group of counter-protesters, who held a banner reading "VA Students Act Against White Supremacy."

The marchers, who were organized and well-coordinated, gathered at Nameless Field and formed a line that snaked through the campus to the university's statue of Thomas Jefferson. The group chanted slogans such as "Blood and soil" and "One people, one nation, end immigration," and some observers noted that the use of lit torches was reminiscent of the Ku Klux Klan.

The rally was marked by clashes with counter-protesters, with one counter-protester reportedly spraying pepper spray at the marchers. Police intervened, and the marchers extinguished their torches, filling the air with acrid smoke.

The event was criticized by local residents and politicians, with Charlottesville Mayor Mike Signer calling the march "a cowardly parade of hatred, bigotry, racism, and intolerance." The Southern Poverty Law Center, a civil rights organization, noted that the rally was a response to the city council's decision to remove the statue of General Lee, which has become a focal point for white nationalists.

The rally was also seen as a reaction to the election of President Donald Trump, who has been accused of emboldening the far right. The Southern Poverty Law Center stated that Trump's campaign "electrified the radical right, which saw in him a champion of the idea that America is fundamentally a white man's country."

Title: Trump to Address UN General Assembly, Criticize North Korea and Iran

Article:

United States President Donald Trump is set to deliver his first speech to the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday, where he is expected to call for increased international pressure on North Korea over its nuclear weapons program. The speech is scheduled to take place at 10:30 a.m. New York time (14:30 GMT).

According to White House officials, Trump will refer to Islamist militants as "losers" and criticize Iran and Venezuela during his address. The officials also stated that Trump will urge UN member states to take action against North Korea's "destabilizing, hostile, and dangerous behavior."

North Korea has responded to the expected criticism by saying that more sanctions and pressure will only accelerate its nuclear program. The country has conducted repeated missile tests this year, despite international condemnation, and conducted its sixth nuclear test earlier this month.

In addition to North Korea, Trump is also expected to express concern about Iran in his speech. The US president has been a vocal critic of the 2015 nuclear deal between Iran and world powers, and has hinted at the possibility of withdrawing from the agreement. US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson has accused Iran of not contributing positively to regional security, citing its support for the Assad regime in Syria and its development of ballistic missiles.

A White House official described Iran and North Korea as a "shared menace" to the world, stating that nations cannot be bystanders to history and must confront the threats now or risk them becoming more formidable. Trump also met with world leaders on Monday, including a special meeting on UN reform, and held discussions with Latin American leaders about the situation in Venezuela, which he described as "totally unacceptable."

Title: White House Spokesperson Warns of Trump's Frustration with Attorney General Sessions

The White House Press Secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, warned on Tuesday that President Trump's frustration with Attorney General Jeff Sessions is not abating, following a series of tweets in which the President criticized Sessions as "VERY weak" on Hillary Clinton's supposed "crimes." Sanders made the comments during an appearance on "Fox & Friends," where she neither confirmed nor denied reports that Trump has discussed the possibility of firing Sessions.

According to Sanders, Trump is "frustrated and disappointed" in Sessions for recusing himself from the Russia meddling probe. She stated that the President's frustration has not gone away and that he is considering potential replacements. However, she did not rule out the possibility of Trump firing Sessions, saying that it is a decision that the President will make if he chooses to.

The President's tweets, which targeted Sessions' handling of the Russia investigation and his recusal from the probe, sparked speculation about the possibility of Sessions' resignation or firing. Sessions has been under fire since last week, when Trump criticized his decision to recuse himself from the Russia investigation, calling it "very unfair to the President."

The Associated Press reported that Trump has discussed the possibility of firing Sessions with aides, but those who have spoken with the President cautioned that a change may not be imminent or happen at all. Department of Justice officials told Fox News that Sessions is in "good spirits."

If Trump were to fire Sessions, Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein would be elevated to the top post on an acting basis, leaving the President with another attorney general who has been sharply critical of his handling of the Russia probe. The possibility of Trump asking Rosenstein or a new attorney general to fire Robert Mueller, the special counsel leading the investigation into Russia's meddling in the 2016 election, has also raised concerns.

The President's criticism of Sessions has sparked concerns about staff morale, with Newt Gingrich, a frequent Trump adviser, warning that the President's attacks on his team can have repercussions. Sessions and Trump were once close, but their relationship has deteriorated in recent weeks, with Sessions asking senior White House staff how he might patch up relations with the President, but that effort did not go anywhere.

Title: Trump Administration Sends Federal Agents to Chicago, Mayor Lightfoot Rejects Deployment

The Trump administration has sent federal agents to Chicago to address violent crime, but Mayor Lori Lightfoot has rejected the deployment, citing concerns over the agents' lack of insignia and potential for unlawful detentions. The move comes after the president threatened to send federal agents to the city, following a weekend in which 12 people were killed and 63 others were wounded by gunfire.

According to reports, federal agents from the U.S. Marshals Service were sent to Portland, Oregon, to protect federal property, but were seen detaining people who were not near federal property. This move has sparked anger among local politicians and protesters, who are calling for an end to the deployment.

Trump has continued to threaten to send federal agents to other cities, including New York and Philadelphia, blaming Democrats for the unrest and violence in inner cities. In a tweet, he stated that the Radical Left Democrats, who "totally control Biden," will destroy the country as we know it.

In response, Mayor Lightfoot sent a letter to the White House rejecting the idea of deploying federal agents who "arrest and detain residents without any cause." She suggested alternative measures, such as universal background checks, federal enforcement of existing laws, and help from the federal government on illegal gun sales.

The Department of Homeland Security is planning to send about 150 agents to Chicago, according to the Chicago Tribune. However, Lightfoot has expressed concerns over the deployment, stating that it would make communities less safe and would not be under the control of the Chicago Police Department.

In an interview with MSNBC, Lightfoot said she would defend her city against Trump's plans and would use every tool at her disposal to stop the deployment. She emphasized that the city would not tolerate tyranny and would use the constitution and laws on the books to defend against it.

Title: Study Finds Google's Top News Stories Dominated by Left-Leaning Sources, But Google Insists Results Are Apolitical

A recent study by the Computational Journalism Lab at Northwestern University analyzed the results of over 200 news-related searches on Google in November 2017 and found that the majority of the top news stories came from just 20 news sources, with three sources dominating the coverage: CNN, The New York Times, and The Washington Post. The study counted an "article impression" each time one of those links appeared and found that 86% of Google's Top Stories came from these 20 sources.

The researchers, Daniel Trielli and Nicholas Diakopoulos, counted 6,303 individual links to articles and found that 23% of all impressions counted were from just three sources: CNN, The New York Times, and The Washington Post. The study also found that 62% of the impressions were from sources considered left-leaning and only 11% from right-leaning outlets.

Google, however, disputes the findings, stating that its algorithms are designed to elevate news from authoritative sources and do not detect political affiliations or sentiments. The company notes that bigger outlets have more manpower to produce more content, which may contribute to their dominance in the Top Stories box.

The study's methodology has been questioned, with some critics pointing out potential duplication of certain links and the fact that the study only examined results from 2017, when Google makes thousands of changes to its search engine each year. Google has also launched its own "How News Works" page, which emphasizes its commitment to fostering a healthy and diverse news ecosystem.

The study's findings have sparked concerns about the potential influence of Google's algorithmic curation of news on the news cycle and the need for greater transparency from the company. While the study's results are not definitive, they do highlight the importance of understanding the algorithms and editorial design of news platforms like Google.

Title: James Carville Defends Clinton Foundation Against Criticism, Claims It Does "Enormous Amount of Good"

James Carville, a long-time Democratic strategist and Clinton booster, has come to the defense of the Clinton Foundation, dismissing criticism over potential conflicts of interest. On MSNBC's "Morning Joe," Carville argued that the pros outweigh the cons when it comes to the foundation's fundraising efforts, despite the controversy surrounding its operations during Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign.

According to Carville, the Clinton Foundation's mission to raise money from wealthy individuals and distribute it to those in need is a "pretty good idea." He emphasized that the foundation's work has a positive impact, stating, "What the Clinton Foundation does is it takes money from rich people and gives it to poor people. Most people think that's a pretty good idea."

Carville acknowledged that, as a political adviser, he understands the potential political implications of the foundation's operations. However, as a human being, he believes the foundation does an "enormous amount of good." He added, "Somebody is going to hell over this because somebody – not saying here, but somewhere – this is saving people's lives."

Co-host Joe Scarborough countered Carville's defense, calling the claim "BS" and suggesting that the charity could have operated independently without Bill Clinton's involvement. Scarborough argued that if the foundation is a "great charity," it can stand on its own and raise money without relying on Bill Clinton's fundraising efforts.

Title: Michael Cohen Expresses Willingness to Cooperate with Investigations, Denies Animosity Toward Robert Mueller

Michael Cohen, the former lawyer and fixer for President Donald Trump, has stated that he does not share Trump's animosity toward special prosecutor Robert Mueller and is open to cooperating with the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. In an off-camera interview with ABC News correspondent George Stephanopoulos, Cohen expressed his willingness to cooperate with Mueller's investigation as well as with federal prosecutors in New York investigating him for possible election law and financial crimes.

Cohen's lawyer, Guy Petrillo, will provide guidance on his decisions regarding cooperation. When asked about his priorities, Cohen emphasized his family, stating, "My wife, my daughter, and my son have my first loyalty and always will. I put family and country first."

In contrast, Trump had previously tweeted that Cohen was a businessman he "always liked and respected," and that he did not believe Cohen would "flip" and cooperate with the government. However, Cohen has denied this, stating, "I will not be a punching bag as part of anyone's defense strategy. I am not a villain of this story, and I will not allow others to try to depict me that way."

The investigation into Russian ties to the 2016 Trump campaign has resulted in charges against several former Trump associates, including Michael Flynn, Paul Manafort, and George Papadopoulos. Federal investigators have also been looking into Cohen's business dealings, including payments to adult-film star Stormy Daniels and other women who claimed they had affairs with Trump. In April, investigators raided his home and office, and since then, Trump's personal lawyers, Cohen's attorneys, and federal officials have been engaged in a legal battle over access to millions of documents.

In the interview, Cohen expressed respect for the prosecutors and the investigation process, stating, "I would not do or say anything that might be perceived as interfering with their professional review of the evidence and the facts."

Title: White House Chooses Trump National Doral as Site for Next Year's G7 Summit

The White House has announced that President Donald Trump's golf resort in Miami, Trump National Doral, will host the 2020 G7 summit. The decision has sparked criticism from critics who argue that it is the most blatant example of Trump using his office to boost his business empire.

According to Acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney, the resort was chosen for its location and amenities, and the president will not profit from the event as the resort will be booked "at cost." However, critics argue that the decision takes Trump's apparent conflicts of interest to a new level, as foreign dignitaries will have no choice but to spend money at his resort during the June 10-12 summit.

Ethics lawyer Kathleen Clark of Washington University School of Law in St. Louis stated, "He is doubling down on his corruption. He's daring anyone to prevent him from further enriching himself from the presidency."

The decision comes as several lawsuits accuse Trump of violating the Constitution's emoluments clause, which bans the president from receiving gifts or payments from foreign governments. Trump has repeatedly accused Joe Biden's family of profiting from public office due to Hunter Biden's business activities in Ukraine while his father was vice president.

Mulvaney brushed off concerns about the summit at Trump's Doral course being a massive promotion for his brand, stating, "Donald Trump's brand is strong as it is. It's the most recognized name in the English language."

The chief of staff recounted that Trump himself raised the idea during a brainstorming session on possible sites, saying, "What about Doral?" Mulvaney said, "That's not the craziest idea I've ever heard."

Trump boasted at this year's G-7 summit in France that Doral would be a "natural" choice, touting its sprawling acreage, proximity to the airport, three golf courses, "incredible" restaurants, and separate buildings for every delegation.

Critics noted that the Doral resort, the biggest source of revenue among Trump's 17 golf properties, appears to have been struggling since even before he became president. Financial disclosure reports filed by the president show revenue is barely growing, up just $1 million last year, to $76 million. The Trump Organization itself has admitted it was struggling, arguing in a tax appeal to local authorities last year that it is "seriously underperforming," according to a Washington Post review of tax appeal documents.

The Doral, which Trump purchased out of bankruptcy in 2012 for a reported $150 million, also faces a heavy debt load. At the end of last year, Trump had two mortgages on the resort, one for more than $50 million and another for as much as $25 million.

The Trump Organization did not respond to questions about Doral's finances. Instead, it issued a statement saying that it is "excited to have been asked to host" the summit and "honored by this recognition."

Title: Former Trump Lawyer Michael Cohen to be Released from Prison to Home Confinement Amid COVID-19 Pandemic

The United States Department of Justice has announced that Michael Cohen, former lawyer and fixer for President Donald Trump, will be released from federal prison to serve the remainder of his sentence in home confinement due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Cohen, who is currently serving a sentence at FCI Otisville in New York, will remain under quarantine for 14 days before being released. According to federal statistics, 14 inmates and seven staff members at the prison have tested positive for the coronavirus.

Cohen, who pleaded guilty to numerous charges including campaign finance fraud and lying to Congress, will serve the remainder of his sentence at home, according to a Justice Department official and another person familiar with the matter. The decision comes as prison advocates and congressional leaders have been pressing the Justice Department to release at-risk inmates ahead of a potential outbreak, citing the difficulty of maintaining social distancing behind bars.

As of Thursday, 473 federal inmates and 279 Bureau of Prisons staff members had tested positive for the coronavirus at facilities across the United States, with 18 inmates having died since late March. The Bureau of Prisons has moved over 1,000 inmates to home confinement since March 26, but advocates have accused the agency of moving too slowly to release inmates.

Cohen's release is part of a broader effort by the Justice Department to reduce the risk of the coronavirus spreading in federal prisons. Attorney General William Barr had ordered the Bureau of Prisons to increase the use of home confinement and expedite the release of eligible high-risk inmates, starting at three prisons identified as coronavirus hotspots.

Title: Trump Refuses to Endorse Ryan and McCain, Amid Growing GOP Rift

The Republican nominee, Donald Trump, has declined to endorse the re-election campaign of House Speaker Paul Ryan, the highest-ranking member of his party in Washington, and Senator John McCain, the party's 2008 nominee. This decision comes amid growing divisions within the GOP, with Trump's controversial statements on Muslims and his treatment of the Khan family sparking criticism from many Republicans.

In an interview with the Washington Post, Trump stated, "I like Paul, but these are horrible times for our country. We need very, very strong leadership. And I'm just not quite there yet. I'm not quite there yet." This comment was likely a reference to Ryan's comments in May, when the House speaker said he was not ready to endorse Trump.

Trump also refused to back McCain in his bid for re-election, despite being endorsed by both men earlier. Both Ryan and McCain are longtime critics of many of Trump's remarks, but have said they would support the Republican nominee in the general election.

Ryan's campaign responded through a spokesman, Zack Roday, saying, "Neither Speaker Ryan nor anyone on his team has ever asked for Donald Trump's endorsement. And we are confident in a victory next week regardless."

The pair of senior Republicans have been critical of Trump in recent months following a string of increasingly racially and religiously charged statements. In June, Ryan described Trump's attacks on a federal judge, Gustavo Curiel, as "the textbook definition of a racist comment," and McCain issued a strong rebuke of Trump's remarks about the Muslim family of a dead army captain on Monday.

Other high-profile Republicans have also spoken out against Trump's comments, including Chris Christie, the New Jersey governor and a Trump ally, who said Trump's remarks on the Khans were inappropriate. Two weeks after a party convention that attempted to focus on party unity, new rifts are appearing between Republicans and their candidate.

The article also mentions that Richard Hanna, a retiring New York representative, became the first Republican member of Congress to say he would vote for Hillary Clinton in November, citing Trump's behavior as unfit to serve the party and the country. Meg Whitman, a prominent Republican fundraiser, also threw her support behind Clinton, stating that Trump's demagoguery has undermined the fabric of our national character.

The article concludes by noting that veterans and the families of soldiers killed in war are continuing to call on Trump to apologize for his treatment of the Khan family, and that Trump's refusal to support McCain and Ryan comes exactly one week before Ryan faces a primary challenge from Paul Nehlen, a candidate who has sought to emulate Trump's rhetoric and policies.

Title: Europe Offers Greece $96 Billion Bailout in Exchange for Economic Reforms

Europe has agreed to offer Greece a new $96 billion bailout package, contingent on the country implementing significant economic reforms. The rescue deal, Greece's third since 2010, aims to secure its place in the eurozone, but the country's potential exit from the currency union would have significant implications for the region.

Under the agreement, Greece has agreed to implement pension cuts, higher taxes, and the sale of some government assets. The key to the deal is proof that Greece will follow through on its commitments. Eurozone leaders have agreed in principle to start negotiations on the bailout, pending Greece's approval of the measures by Wednesday.

Greece's Parliament must approve the reforms, and the country will be assigned monitors to ensure it adheres to the agreement. The monitors will also oversee the sale of government assets, with the majority of the proceeds going towards debt payments.

The deal does not mark an immediate end to the crisis, as it still requires approval from Greece's Parliament and other eurozone countries. The European Central Bank has not yet agreed to restart money flows to Greek banks, which remain shuttered.

Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras faced intense pressure from European leaders to accept the conditions, which include giving up control of the proceeds from government sales. The country's economy has deteriorated sharply in recent weeks, and it is running out of money. Greece needs the European Central Bank to restart money flows to re-open its banks and avoid a complete economic collapse.

The deal is not without its challenges, as it requires Greece to implement a broader overhaul of its economy, including tax changes and pension reforms. The country's banks have been shut for two weeks, and cash withdrawals are capped. The vital tourism industry is suffering, and the healthcare system is running out of imported medicines.

While the deal is a significant step towards resolving the crisis, it is not a guarantee of success. Greece still faces significant challenges, including the need to push through reforms in Parliament and persuade the European Central Bank to ease restrictions on funding for its banks.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates' Stances on Abortion Revealed

The New York Times has conducted a survey of the 2020 Democratic presidential candidates on the issue of abortion, revealing a shift towards a more expansive abortion rights agenda. The survey found that the top-tier candidates, Elizabeth Warren, Pete Buttigieg, and Bernie Sanders, want to force all private insurers to cover elective abortions and make abortion drugs available over-the-counter. Additionally, they all support repealing the Hyde Amendment, which restricts taxpayer funding of elective abortions for Medicaid recipients.

Only one candidate, South Bend, Ind. mayor Pete Buttigieg, expressed willingness to sign a budget that includes the Hyde Amendment, while the other candidates dodged the question. Among the entire field, only Tulsi Gabbard, Joe Sestak, and Marianne Williamson still use the phrase "safe, legal, and rare" to describe their stance on abortion.

Notably, only Joe Sestak and Tulsi Gabbard support restrictions after 24 weeks of pregnancy, with Gabbard also supporting restrictions in the third trimester. In contrast, the rest of the top-tier candidates, including Elizabeth Warren, Pete Buttigieg, and Bernie Sanders, oppose any restrictions after 24 weeks.

The survey also highlights the shift in the Democratic Party's stance on abortion, with the candidates moving away from the "safe, legal, and rare" language popularized by President Bill Clinton and Hillary Clinton. Instead, many candidates prefer to describe their stance as "affordable" or "accessible" rather than "rare."

In comparison, the last Democratic presidential candidate to win the White House, Barack Obama, expressed support for restricting late-term abortions with a strict, well-defined exception for the health of the mother. However, Joe Biden's campaign is dodging the question on whether he supports any restrictions on aborting viable babies.

The article concludes that the 2020 Democratic presidential candidates have coalesced around an abortion rights agenda more far-reaching than anything past nominees have proposed, with only Joe Sestak standing out as willing to support some modest legal restrictions on abortion after viability.

Title: Senate Democrats Threaten to Let Bush-Era Tax Cuts Expire Unless Republicans Agree to Obama's Plan

Article:

Senate Democrats are willing to let the Bush-era tax cuts expire at the end of the year if Republicans do not agree to President Obama's plan to raise taxes on America's top earners. This move would effectively trigger the "fiscal cliff," a term used to describe the combination of tax increases and spending cuts set to take effect in 2013.

Senator Patty Murray, the head of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, warned that if Republicans do not relent, her caucus will let the deadline pass, which would allow the country to fall off the fiscal cliff. Murray emphasized that this move would give Democrats a better negotiating position and would make it clear that any change to the tax code would be a tax cut.

Murray also suggested that if Republicans do not negotiate to her party's liking on the automatic spending cuts, known as the "sequestration," set to take effect at the start of next year, her party would let those cuts happen as well. She believes that Republicans would be to blame if the country falls off the fiscal cliff.

On the other hand, Republicans claim that Democrats are standing in the way of relief for millions of Americans and are pushing a tax hike that will hurt employment. Senator Rob Portman, R-Ohio, accused President Obama of pushing a tax hike that will increase the cost of doing business and make it harder to create jobs.

The debate over the Bush tax cuts has become increasingly heated, with each side accusing the other of threatening to trigger tax hikes in 2013. The political strategy underscores the risks for the American people, as the country approaches the fiscal cliff.

**Title:** Senator Al Franken Calls for Transparency in Domestic Surveillance Programs

**Article:**

Senator Al Franken, a member of the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Privacy, Technology, and the Law, has emphasized the need for greater transparency in domestic surveillance programs. Franken believes that Americans are unaware of the scope of these programs and the legal authorities behind them, making it difficult to determine whether the balance between national security and privacy is being maintained.

Since the Edward Snowden leaks, the government has been criticized for its secrecy surrounding these programs. Franken has been working to address this issue by proposing legislation that would require the federal government to annually report on the use of key authorities under the Patriot Act and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. The proposed legislation would also allow companies to publicly report on the number of Patriot and FISA orders they receive and how many customers are affected.

Franken believes that transparency is crucial in maintaining the public trust and allowing citizens to hold their government accountable. He notes that while some may argue that secrecy is necessary for national security, he believes that there are ways to achieve transparency without compromising national security. For example, Google has been reporting on the number of national security letters it receives since 2009 without any negative consequences.

Franken also highlights the need for a public conversation about what constitutes a reasonable expectation of privacy in the digital age. He believes that the Supreme Court's 2013 decision in the Katz v. U.S. case, which established that wiretaps constitute a search under the Fourth Amendment, is outdated and needs to be reevaluated in light of modern technology.

Ultimately, Franken wants to give Americans the information they need to make informed decisions about the balance between national security and privacy. He believes that transparency is essential in maintaining the public trust and ensuring that the government is accountable to its citizens.

Title: White Nationalist Protesters Return to Charlottesville, Chanting Anti-Diversity Slogans

The small group of white nationalist protesters, led by far-right figure Richard Spencer, returned to Charlottesville, Virginia, on Saturday, two months after a violent clash that left one woman dead. The brief, torch-lit rally took place in front of a statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee, which has been covered up while a legal challenge to its removal is underway.

The protesters, estimated to be between 40 and 50 people, chanted slogans such as "You will not replace us" and "We will be back," as well as "The South will rise again" and "Russia is our friend." Another speaker criticized the local community and media, stating that the group was there to "represent white America's interests."

Charlottesville Mayor Mike Signer condemned the event, calling it "another despicable visit by neo-Nazi cowards." The city is still reeling from the August "Unite the Right" rally, which was held to oppose the removal of the Lee statue. During that event, a participant drove a car into a group of counter-protesters, killing 32-year-old Heather Heyer.

Richard Spencer, the founder of a right-wing website and think-tank, live-streamed the event and claimed that Charlottesville had become a symbol of the suppression of free speech and destruction of historical monuments. He has made controversial comments in the past, including allegedly advocating for "peaceful" ethnic cleansing.

The US has been grappling with a national debate on whether to remove Confederate symbols from the US Civil War, due to their association with slavery. After the violence in Charlottesville, many local governments have taken action to remove Confederate monuments.

Title: ExxonMobil Wins Climate Change Lawsuit, Judge Rules Attorney General Failed to Prove Securities Fraud

Article:

A New York State Supreme Court judge has ruled in favor of ExxonMobil, finding that the oil giant did not break the law by downplaying the financial risks of climate change to its investors. The decision marks a significant blow to the New York Attorney General's Office, which brought the case against ExxonMobil.

Justice Barry Ostrager concluded that the attorney general failed to prove that ExxonMobil made any material misrepresentations that would have significantly altered the information available to investors. The judge noted that while ExxonMobil may have contributed to climate change through greenhouse gas emissions, this was not the focus of the securities fraud case.

The New York Attorney General's Office had argued that ExxonMobil had downplayed the financial risks it faces from possible climate regulation, making its assets appear more secure than they really were. This, they claimed, had defrauded investors. However, the judge found that the state failed to prove this by a preponderance of the evidence.

Attorney General Letitia James released a statement following the verdict, stating that the case had compelled Exxon to answer publicly for its internal decisions that misled investors. James emphasized that the case was not about climate change, but about Exxon's internal decisions and their impact on investors.

ExxonMobil celebrated the ruling, saying it affirms their position that they provided accurate information on the risks of climate change to investors. The company noted that the attorney general's office failed to make a case, even with the lower burden of proof under the Martin Act.

The case was notable for its high-profile witness, former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who testified as Exxon's CEO from 2006 to 2017. Tillerson explained Exxon's methods for estimating the impact of potential climate-change regulations on its future business, including using two different approaches to calculate greenhouse gas costs.

The ruling is seen as a significant setback for the New York Attorney General's Office, which had sought to hold ExxonMobil accountable for its role in climate change. The case is part of a larger trend of lawsuits against fossil fuel companies, with similar cases pending in Massachusetts and elsewhere.

Title: Obama Proposes Budget with Increased Spending and Tax Increases

Article:

President Barack Obama has released his 2013 budget proposal, which aims to lift the automatic spending caps and add billions to government spending. The proposal, worth $3.99 trillion, is already drawing criticism from Republicans.

In his remarks, Obama emphasized the need for "smart investments that strengthen America" and expressed his willingness to work with Congress to achieve this goal. He stated that his budget will end sequestration and fully reverse the cuts to domestic priorities in 2016, while matching investments in defense spending.

The proposal includes tens of billions of dollars in new government spending, which would pay for initiatives such as an expanded child care tax credit and subsidies to help students attend community college at no cost. The plan also includes an additional $38 billion in defense spending, which would help fund the fight against the Islamic State and military support for NATO allies.

To offset these costs, the president is proposing higher taxes on big banks and the wealthy. The plan would raise about $210 billion over the next decade by raising the capital gains tax rate and taxing gains on inherited wealth.
