A new financial fee on highly leveraged banks would generate another $110 billion over the next 10 years.

The president is also proposing a one-time, 14% tax on the profits that U.S. corporations have amassed overseas, which would raise an estimated $238 billion to help fund improvements to roads, bridges, and other public works.

The proposal is expected to face opposition from Republicans, who control both chambers of Congress. They are unlikely to approve the president's proposed tax hikes and may be willing to give ground on the spending caps.

The White House says the budget would cut the federal deficit to $474 billion in the upcoming fiscal year, which is just 2.5% of the overall economy. However, the deficit would remain at a manageable 3% of GDP or less throughout the 10-year budget window, pending Republican agreement to a substantial boost in tax revenues.

A preliminary analysis by the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center found that while the wealthiest Americans would pay higher taxes under the president's plan, most of the benefits would go to those at the bottom of the income ladder. The 60% of Americans in the middle would more or less break even.

Title: Harvard Freshman's Education in Jeopardy After Detention and Deportation Threats

A 17-year-old Palestinian student, Ismail B. Ajjawi, was detained and subjected to invasive questioning by American immigration officials at Boston Logan International Airport on Friday night. The incident has left his education at Harvard University in doubt, as his study visa was allegedly canceled and he was threatened with deportation.

According to reports, Ajjawi was held in custody for eight hours and questioned by a female immigration officer, who asked him about his religion and religious practices in Lebanon. The officer also demanded access to his phone and laptop, which was searched for five hours. Ajjawi alleges that the officer questioned him about his friends' social media activity and refused to return his phone when he asked.

After the search, the officer allegedly found posts on his friends' social media accounts that opposed the US, and she became aggressive, screaming at Ajjawi and accusing him of being responsible for the posts. Ajjawi denied any involvement and told the officer he had no control over his friends' online activities.

University officials are working to resolve the situation, but Ajjawi's enrollment at Harvard is now in jeopardy. His education was made possible by a scholarship from a nonprofit organization, and he was set to start classes on September 3.

Title: Trump's Unprecedented News Conference: A Rorschach Test for the Media

The recent news conference held by President Trump was a unique and extraordinary event, with the president delivering a scathing critique of the media and its coverage of his administration. The event was marked by Trump's characteristic candor and passion, with some viewing it as a bold takedown of a perceived corrupt media, while others saw it as a sign of a president struggling to cope with the intense scrutiny.

Trump's speech touched on several topics, including the flood of illegal leaks aimed at damaging his administration, the tone of his coverage, and the accuracy of specific reports. He criticized the media for its negative coverage, stating that it has been "unrelentingly negative" and that some journalists have "hatred" for him. He also took aim at specific news outlets, such as CNN and The New York Times, accusing them of spreading false information.

However, Trump's claims were not without controversy. Some of the reports he criticized, such as the Washington Post's reporting on Michael Flynn's contacts with the Russian ambassador, were based on unnamed sources and have been widely corroborated. Additionally, Trump's denial of the allegations of sensitive intelligence being withheld from him was met with skepticism, as a White House official was quoted as denying the claims.

The news conference was also marked by Trump's characteristic use of hyperbole, with him describing his administration as running like a "fine-tuned machine" and joking that today's headlines would be about him "ranting and raving." While some of his supporters may have seen this as a bold and refreshing change, others may have viewed it as a sign of a president struggling to cope with the intense scrutiny.

Ultimately, the news conference was a Rorschach test for the media, with different people seeing different things. While Trump scored some points by denouncing fake news and criticizing the media's negative coverage, his claims were not without controversy and left many questions unanswered.

Title: Colorado Court Rules Marijuana Use Can Still Lead to Termination, Despite State Law

A recent ruling by the Colorado Court of Appeals has clarified that employees in the state can still be terminated for testing positive for marijuana, even if they are using it for medicinal purposes. The decision comes despite Colorado's legalization of marijuana for recreational and medicinal use.

The case involved Brandon Coats, who was fired by Dish Network after testing positive for marijuana. Coats, who was rendered quadriplegic in a car accident, was using medical marijuana to manage his condition. He sued the company, arguing that a Colorado law protected him from being fired for engaging in lawful activities outside of the workplace. However, the district court ruled against him, citing federal laws prohibiting marijuana.

The Colorado Court of Appeals upheld the ruling, stating that federal laws trump state laws. In the majority opinion, Judge Janice Davidson wrote, "While we agree that the general purpose of [the worker protection law]... is to keep an employer's proverbial nose out of an employee's off-site off-hours business... we can find no legislative intent to extend employment protections to those engaged in activities that violate federal law."

Coats and his lawyer plan to take the case to the Colorado Supreme Court, stating that they will "pick a fight with the federal government" if necessary. The ruling highlights the ongoing tension between state and federal laws regarding marijuana use.

Title: Virginia Governor Candidates Court Diverse Electorate in Intense Campaign Efforts

Article:

In the midst of the Virginia governor's race, candidates Terry McAuliffe and Ken Cuccinelli have made a concerted effort to court the state's rapidly diversifying electorate. The two candidates have made dozens of campaign stops, with McAuliffe, the former Democratic National Committee chairman, even wielding a spatula behind the counter at a local supermarket to emphasize his commitment to passing a state-level DREAM Act.

McAuliffe's campaign has focused on outreach to various communities, including the Asian-American and Pacific-Islander communities, with events such as a special campaign kickoff aimed at these groups and a "Ramadan Kareem!" message on Facebook to mark the Muslim holy month. He has also celebrated the Lunar New Year with Korean, Chinese, and Vietnamese groups in Northern Virginia and addressed a meeting of the Democratic Latino Organization of Virginia.

Cuccinelli, the Republican candidate, has also made a concerted effort to reach out to diverse communities, attending meetings with the Pakistan American Business Association and the Moroccan American Network, celebrating Filipino-American culture at festivals in Richmond and Virginia Beach, and giving interviews to Indian, Korean, Moroccan, and Vietnamese-oriented media outlets.

The political logic behind these efforts is straightforward: while Virginia has always had a sizable African-American population, the last 10 years have seen a sharp rise in other nonwhite voting groups. In the 2004 presidential race, Latino voters made up 3% of the Virginia electorate and Asians made up 2%, according to exit polls. By 2012, those numbers were 5% for Latinos and 3% for Asians – a combined 60% increase in those two heterogeneous groups. In a low-turnout election, that shift could be all the more consequential.

Cuccinelli, who won multiple state Senate elections in a Fairfax-based district, near the epicenter of Virginia's demographic change, is well aware of the state's transformation. He has been meeting with leaders in various communities, including Asian-American business leaders, and emphasizing his long ties to the state and his involvement in local institutions.

The candidates' efforts to court the diverse electorate are likely to be replicated in more and more elections as demographic change transforms the American political landscape.

Title: President Trump Addresses Thanksgiving, Rejects Efforts to Change Holiday's Name

Article:

President Donald Trump addressed a rally in Sunrise, Florida, on Tuesday, where he spoke about the upcoming Thanksgiving holiday. Trump expressed his opposition to any efforts to change the name of the holiday, stating that some people want to replace it with a different term. He claimed that the "radical left" is behind this movement, which he believes is an attempt to erase the holiday's historical significance.

Trump also referenced the controversy surrounding Christmas, which he said was initially targeted by those who wanted to eliminate it as a secular holiday. However, he noted that Christmas is now widely celebrated again. He implied that a similar fate might await Thanksgiving if the "radical left" gets its way.

The president's comments were met with criticism from some social media users, who used the hashtag #WhatLiberalsCallThanksgiving to mock his remarks. One user, who identified as Native American, suggested renaming the holiday a "National Day of Mourning" to acknowledge the historical trauma and genocide inflicted upon Native American communities by European settlers.

In fact, since 1970, Native Americans in New England have organized an annual protest, dubbed the National Day of Mourning, on the same day as Thanksgiving. The protest is held at Cole's Hill in Plymouth, Massachusetts, and is meant to commemorate the genocide of millions of Native Americans, the theft of their lands, and the assault on their culture.

Earlier on Tuesday, Trump pardoned two turkeys, Bread and Butter, and wished Americans a Happy Thanksgiving. He also made a joke about the turkeys receiving subpoenas to appear in a basement meeting with Representative Adam Schiff, the California Democrat leading the impeachment inquiry against him.

Title: Target Ditches Health Care Plan for Part-Time Workers, Citing Low Participation and Obamacare Options

Article:

Retail giant Target Corporation has announced that it will discontinue its health care plan for part-time workers, citing low participation rates and the availability of alternative coverage options under the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). The company will provide a $500 cash payment to each affected employee to ease the transition.

According to Target, less than 10% of its part-time employees participated in the company's health care plan. The company believes that employees may prefer to explore individual marketplaces and state-based exchanges for health care coverage, which may offer subsidies to reduce their overall health insurance expenses.

This move raises questions about the impact of Obamacare on employer-based coverage, where most Americans receive their health insurance. Analysts suggest that employers may be inclined to shift health care coverage to individual markets and state-based exchanges, where people may be eligible for government subsidies based on income.

Target is not the first company to make changes to its health care plan in response to Obamacare. In August, UPS announced it would drop health care coverage for about 15,000 employees' spouses who are eligible for coverage from their own workplaces.

The impact of Obamacare on the employer-based market is difficult to assess, given the various factors that affect annual premium changes. However, critics are poised to blame any premium increases on the law, given the political climate and early problems with HealthCare.gov and the individual market.

Smaller employers face significant consequences due to the law's provisions, including the prohibition on rejecting people with pre-existing conditions and charging older consumers more than young people by a 3-1 ratio. Additionally, the health care overhaul includes numerous taxes and fees that may be passed along to consumers in the employer-based insurance market.

Target emphasized that employees who work 20-31 hours per week will still be eligible for other benefits, including vacation, dental, disability, life insurance, and 401(k) benefits. The company also stated it has no plans to cut hours as part of the move.

Employees who are interested in working more hours can discuss their availability with their managers, and Target has offered additional hours and cross-training opportunities during the holiday season.

Title: Obama Campaigns in New Hampshire, Faces Questions About Second Term Agenda

President Barack Obama rallied supporters in Manchester, New Hampshire, on Thursday, attempting to answer criticism from Republican nominee Mitt Romney that he lacks an agenda for a second term. The president's campaign team has outlined plans to hire 100,000 more teachers, boost domestic energy production, create more manufacturing jobs, and cut the deficit. However, some supporters, like Cynthia Malbon, are skeptical about what a second Obama term would look like.

A Suffolk/7News poll on Monday showed the candidates tied at 47 percent, with voters giving Romney the edge in fixing the economy. The poll found that people are unclear about Obama's vision for the future, with 45 percent of voters saying they don't know what his policies are or where he's headed.

Obama's campaign has emphasized his record on job creation, citing a decrease in unemployment from 10 percent to 7.8 percent. However, some supporters, like Ron Chito, are still uncertain about the president's vision for a second term. "If you're a good reader and you know what is going on, then you have a good idea what his policies are and where he's headed," Chito said.

The president also criticized Romney's economic plan, calling it "a sketchy deal" and warning that it would allow insurance companies to charge women more for health care coverage. Obama emphasized the importance of access to affordable contraception and warned that Romney would repeal the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare.

The Romney campaign responded, saying Obama's leadership has failed over the past four years and that the economic future under him would be even bleaker because he won't confront the looming "fiscal cliff" of spending cuts and tax increases pending before Congress in January.

Title: President Obama Delivers Unifying Speech at Democratic National Convention

Article:

President Barack Obama accepted the nomination for a second term at the Democratic National Convention in Charlotte, North Carolina, delivering a speech that focused on his record and the choice between himself and his Republican opponent, Mitt Romney. The speech was notable for its more subdued tone compared to his 2008 acceptance speech, with Obama emphasizing the challenges the country still faces and the need for continued effort to address them.

Obama's speech highlighted his administration's accomplishments, including the killing of Osama bin Laden and the passage of the Affordable Care Act. He also emphasized his commitment to creating jobs, particularly in the manufacturing sector, and to continuing to work towards a more balanced economy.

The speech was also marked by a series of attacks on Romney's foreign policy experience and his stance on various issues, including the war in Iraq and Afghanistan. Obama accused Romney of being stuck in a "Cold War time warp" and of not being prepared to engage with international leaders.

Throughout the speech, Obama emphasized the importance of perseverance and the need for continued effort to address the country's challenges. He acknowledged that the road ahead would be difficult, but expressed confidence in the American people's ability to overcome them.

Overall, Obama's speech was seen as a solid performance that effectively made the case for his reelection and highlighted the choice between himself and Romney.

Title: Senate Republicans Unveil Legislation to Address Racial Disparities in Law Enforcement

Article:

Senate Republicans have unveiled a new bill aimed at addressing racial disparities in law enforcement, the latest effort by lawmakers to overhaul U.S. law enforcement in the wake of George Floyd's death. The bill, dubbed the JUSTICE Act, is led by Senator Tim Scott (R-SC) and backed by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY).

The legislation includes several provisions aimed at promoting transparency and accountability in law enforcement. These include incentivizing law enforcement agencies to ban the use of chokeholds, ramping up data collection efforts to track officer use of force, providing federal money for additional training on alternatives to the use of force, and recognizing the history of lynching in the United States.

The bill also requires law enforcement agencies to send reports to the attorney general on no-knock warrants and creates a commission to study issues affecting Black men and boys. The legislation does not address the issue of qualified immunity, a doctrine that largely shields officers from legal liability unless a plaintiff can show that their constitutional rights were clearly violated. The Trump administration has stated that amending qualified immunity is a "non-starter."

The GOP proposal also does not end the use of "no-knock" warrants in drug cases, as the Democratic bill does, and provides new funds to police departments for training. The 106-page bill is the latest effort by lawmakers to address concerns about racial disparities in law enforcement, following President Donald Trump's executive order to incentivize police departments to update their standards and practices and strengthen efforts to track officer misconduct.

The bill has the support of the Trump administration, with White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany stating that it is a "great bill" and expressing hope for bipartisan support. The legislation is seen as a compromise between the Republican and Democratic proposals, with the GOP proposal being more focused on providing incentives for police departments to adopt best practices and the Democratic proposal being more focused on addressing systemic issues and holding officers accountable.

Title: Amazon Eliminates Bonuses and Stock Awards for Warehouse Workers, Raises Minimum Pay to $15 an Hour

Amazon.com Inc. has announced that it will eliminate monthly bonuses and stock awards for its warehouse workers and hourly employees, effective immediately. The decision comes after the company pledged to raise its minimum pay to at least $15 an hour, a move aimed at addressing criticism from politicians and activists.

According to sources familiar with Amazon's pay policies, warehouse workers were previously eligible for monthly bonuses that could total hundreds of dollars per month, as well as stock awards. However, the company has informed employees that these compensation categories will be eliminated to help fund the pay increases.

Despite the elimination of bonuses and stock awards, hourly operations and customer-service workers will still see their total compensation increase, according to Amazon's statement. The company emphasized that the new compensation structure will be more immediate and predictable.

Workers whose pay was already above $15 per hour will receive hourly raises of $1, while some long-time employees have expressed frustration that their raises are relatively small compared to those of newly hired workers, who may receive hourly pay bumps of up to 40 percent.

David DeBoskey, an accounting professor at San Diego State University, believes that the higher hourly wage is a more effective recruiting tool in a tight labor market, especially in the warehousing industry, which sees high turnover. Amazon plans to hire 100,000 seasonal workers for the holiday season, and temporary workers will not receive stock options.

Amazon's decision to raise its minimum pay to $15 an hour has been seen as a strategic move to attract and retain workers in a competitive job market. The company's decision to eliminate bonuses and stock awards is likely aimed at streamlining its compensation structure and providing more immediate benefits to employees.

Title: Bipartisan Meeting on DACA and Spending Bill Looms Amid Partisan Divide

A bipartisan meeting between President Donald Trump and lawmakers is set to take place on Tuesday, aimed at finding a solution to protect hundreds of thousands of immigrants from deportation. The meeting comes as negotiations on a must-pass January spending bill stall due to a partisan divide over immigration policy and a looming deadline.

The Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which allows undocumented immigrants who came to the US as children to stay, work, or study without fear of deportation, has become the key to unlocking any funding agreement. Republicans charge that Democrats are holding the deal hostage, while Democrats argue that the White House has not been fully engaged in the negotiations.

The meeting at the White House is expected to symbolize Trump's growing seriousness about finding a bipartisan resolution. However, the fact that the White House invited GOP lawmakers seen as hostile to finding a consensus deal on DACA has added tension to the meeting.

A bipartisan group of Senate lawmakers, led by Democrat Dick Durbin and Republican Lindsey Graham, continues to negotiate a plan to help recipients of DACA. However, the negotiations are ongoing, and the group acknowledges that they need Trump to lay out clear priorities to move forward.

The meeting comes after Trump met with Republicans last week at the White House, and Senator Jeff Flake of Arizona refused to attend, citing the lack of bipartisanship. White House Chief of Staff John Kelly will also be present at the meeting, having led outreach to lawmakers on Capitol Hill on the ongoing talks.

The meeting will include a range of lawmakers, including Democratic Senators Kamala Harris and Bob Menendez, as well as Republican Senators John Cornyn and James Lankford. The meeting is seen as a crucial step towards finding a solution to the ongoing impasse over immigration policy and the spending bill.

Title: Americans Weigh in on President Obama's Second Term: Infrastructure, Education, and Leadership Top the List

The economy has long been a top concern for many Americans, with nearly half of respondents naming it the most important issue facing the nation today, according to a recent CNN poll. As President Obama begins his second term, Americans are weighing in on what they believe he should prioritize. CNN's iReporters and commenters shared their thoughts on the issues that matter most, with infrastructure, education, and leadership emerging as top concerns.

One iReporter, Cherry Davis, believes that rebuilding the nation's infrastructure is key to creating jobs and stimulating economic growth. She suggests that a "modern New Deal" approach, inspired by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, would be the best way to achieve this goal. Davis, who has been struggling to find work in the Los Angeles job market, believes that updating the nation's infrastructure would create jobs and bring the middle class back.

Education was another top concern, with rising East Carolina University student Tyler Stocks citing the rising cost of tuition and textbooks as a major concern. Stocks hopes that President Obama will work to ensure that students like him are afforded the opportunity to receive a good education.

Mark Ivy, a Mitt Romney supporter, believes that President Obama's top priority should be to show strong leadership in dealing with Congress. Ivy argues that the president's approach to Congress has been lacking in his first term and that he needs to take a more decisive role in leading the country.

The tax structure was also a topic of discussion, with some commenters arguing that the wealthy should be taxed more heavily to address income and wealth inequality. Small business owner Egberto Willies believes that changing the tax structure is key to resolving these issues and ensuring the middle class continues to thrive.

These are just a few of the many opinions shared by CNN's iReporters and commenters on what President Obama should prioritize in his second term. As the country looks to the future, it is clear that Americans are eager for solutions to the pressing issues facing the nation.

Title: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Complex and Ambitious Leadership

Article:

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been a prominent figure in Israeli politics for nearly two decades. As a columnist for Haaretz and author of "My Promised Land: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel" (2013), Ari Shavit has had a unique perspective on Netanyahu's leadership. Shavit describes Netanyahu as a "serious statesman" with an "extraordinary comprehension and uncanny foresight," despite his flaws.

Netanyahu's ambition and sense of purpose have driven him to cast himself in a larger-than-life role, likening himself to Winston Churchill, the British leader who played a crucial role in World War II. According to Shavit, Netanyahu views Iran as the "Nazi Germany of the 21st century" and Israel as the "Great Britain of the 21st century," with himself as the voice in the wilderness. This Churchillian complex has driven Netanyahu to act like a "Churchill wannabe," seeking to emulate the British leader's wisdom, courage, and rhetorical prowess.

Shavit notes that Netanyahu's Churchill complex is deep, obsessive, and multidimensional, dating back to his 1993 op-ed in the New York Times, where he compared former Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin's peace ambitions with the Palestinians to Neville Chamberlain's "peace in our time" with Hitler. Today, Netanyahu views a nuclear deal with Iran in the same light.

As a result of this complex, Netanyahu is perceived as scornful of Democratic politicians and liberal intellectuals, whom he sees as weaklings. He is unconcerned with social justice, human rights, and the rule of law, instead focusing on his mission to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear arms and regional hegemony.

Shavit concludes that Netanyahu is a very focused man, having marshaled enormous forces to complete his mission. He notes that Netanyahu's military training in an elite unit of the Israeli Army made him into a warrior who does not waver, and he has employed these capabilities to turn himself into the Churchill of the 21st century.

Title: Romney Narrows Gap with Obama Among Women, but Election Still a Dead Heat

A new Associated Press-GfK poll shows that Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney has erased President Barack Obama's 16-point advantage among women, and Obama has largely eliminated Romney's edge among men. The poll indicates that the presidential race remains a virtual dead heat, with Romney favored by 47% of likely voters and Obama by 45%, a result within the poll's margin of sampling error.

Romney has gained ground with Americans on several key fronts, including their confidence in his ability to handle the economy and their impressions of his understanding of their problems. However, the poll also shows that Obama still maintains a strong lead among women on issues such as women's rights and reproductive health.

Romney's campaign has been focusing on the economy as a key issue, and the poll suggests that this message is resonating with some women. A month ago, women favored Obama over Romney on the economy 56% to 40%. Now, the split is 49% for Romney and 45% for Obama.

The poll also shows that Obama's job approval ratings among men have improved, with his advantage among unmarried men narrowing to 5 points. Obama's election chances hinge on turning out voters like Jon Gerton, a disabled construction worker from Arkansas who is a staunch Obama supporter.

The poll was conducted Oct. 19-23 by GfK Roper Public Affairs & Corporate Communications and involved landline and cellphone interviews with 1,186 adults nationwide, including 839 likely voters. The results have a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points for the full sample and 4.2 points for likely voters.

Title: Ohio Early Voting Enthusiasm Gap Favors Clinton, Data Shows

The hashtag #OHVotesEarly, which started trending on Twitter as early voting kicked off in Ohio, has revealed an enthusiasm gap between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump supporters. According to Twitter's data, 75% of tweets using the hashtag over the last 24 hours mentioned Clinton, while only 25 mentioned Trump. This disparity is significant, despite Twitter's own data being an "inexact science."

The gap may be attributed to various factors, including the fact that a Clinton supporter originally tweeted the hashtag on October 2, Clinton's Ohio digital team spreading it widely, or Trump's campaign tweeting an incorrect start date for early voting. Additionally, Trump's recent comments about sexual assault may have contributed to the disparity.

A new poll by Baldwin Wallace University Community Research Institute shows Clinton surging in Ohio, beating Trump 43% to 34% in a four-way race and 48% to 37% in a head-to-head race. This is a significant turnaround from just a month ago, when most polls showed Trump winning the state handily.

Early voting returns in other states also show Clinton with a slight advantage, with more votes received during the early voting period in Iowa, Virginia, Wisconsin, Michigan, and North Carolina, while Trump is leading in Georgia and Florida. The Clinton campaign is optimistic about these results, citing increased vote-by-mail requests among key demographics such as black and Asian American voters.

While the enthusiasm gap may be a significant indicator of voter enthusiasm, it is essential to note that it is not a definitive measure of actual political support. The Trump campaign has dismissed the idea that Clinton is winning the enthusiasm game, citing door-to-door canvassing efforts and claiming an Election Day win for Trump.

Title: Trump Secures Strong Showing in New Hampshire Primary, More Than Doubles Obama's 2012 Vote Total

Article:

President Donald Trump secured a strong showing in the New Hampshire primary, receiving more than 120,000 votes with 87% of precincts reporting. This marks a significant increase from former President Barack Obama's 2012 vote total of 49,080. Trump's performance is likely to continue to grow as more precincts report their totals.

The Republican National Committee and the Trump campaign worked together to drive up turnout for Trump in New Hampshire, a strategy that paid off. Trump himself revved up his supporters at a packed rally in Manchester, New Hampshire, on Monday, the eve of the primary.

In the line to get into Trump's rally, many of his voters expressed enthusiasm and support for the president. Jay McDonald of North Providence, Rhode Island, said he "100 percent" supported Trump four years ago and "nothing's changed." McDonald expressed anger over the impeachment proceedings against Trump and hopes he will pick up more voters, including independents.

The Democratic primary saw a strong turnout, with first and second-place finishers Bernie Sanders and Pete Buttigieg combining for almost 140,000 votes with 87% reporting. However, the Democratic primary remains wide open, and there was little at stake for Trump in the New Hampshire race.

Trump's only primary challenger, former Massachusetts Governor Bill Weld, received less than 10% of the GOP vote with 87% reporting. At his rally, Trump touted his accomplishments and criticized Democrats, stating that his administration has reduced the cost of childcare, expanded paid leave, and given 40 million American families an average of $2,200 more in their pockets.

The Trump campaign also highlighted a record turnout for an incumbent in the Iowa caucuses, which took place on the same night that Democratic turnout fell well below expectations. About 176,000 Iowa Democrats attended their precinct caucuses, a slight uptick from 2016 but fewer than expected.

The New Hampshire numbers come as Trump's supporters have been fired up in recent days, following his acquittal on two articles of impeachment and a well-received State of the Union address. Meanwhile, Democrats have been running attack ads on each other and dealing with the fallout of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's decision to tear up Trump's speech at the end of the State of the Union.

Title: Rep. Justin Amash Forms Exploratory Committee for 2024 Presidential Run

Rep. Justin Amash, a 40-year-old congressman from Michigan, has announced the formation of an exploratory committee to run for the Libertarian Party's presidential nomination in 2024. Amash, known for his libertarian views, has been a vocal critic of President Donald Trump and has left the Republican Party. He would be the most high-profile presidential candidate in the Libertarian Party's 50-year history.

Amash has been a strong advocate for limited government and individual freedom, and has led congressional efforts to reform surveillance laws and restore legislative branch responsibility. He has also been a vocal critic of big government and has described himself as "the only libertarian member of Congress."

However, Amash's path to the Libertarian Party's nomination is not without challenges. He has been criticized by some party members for his lack of involvement in the party's internal processes, such as attending conventions and participating in debates. Future of Freedom Foundation founder Jacob Hornberger has been particularly critical of Amash, stating that he has not attended LP conventions or debates and is trying to avoid scrutiny.

Despite these challenges, Amash has a strong reputation among libertarians and has been touted as the heir to the legacy of former congressman Ron Paul. He has also been praised for his eloquence and ability to bring people together.

The Libertarian Party's nomination process is still ongoing, with the party's national convention scheduled for May 2. Amash has three weeks to convince delegates to select him as the party's nominee.

Title: US Coronavirus Death Toll Surpasses 100,000, Highest in the World

The United States has surpassed 100,047 confirmed coronavirus deaths, the highest number of any country in the world, according to data compiled by the Center for Systems Science and Engineering at Johns Hopkins University. This milestone is equivalent to the entire population of mid-sized cities like Albany, N.Y. or Boca Raton, Fla. It is also more American lives lost than were lost in the Korean War, the Vietnam War, and the September 11, 2001 attacks combined.

Despite a decline in daily cases and deaths since April, experts warn that rural areas may not have seen the worst of the pandemic yet. Hundreds of people in the US are still dying from coronavirus each day, with around 7,000 deaths reported during the week ending May 26, according to Johns Hopkins University's COVID-19 tracker.

The US leads the world in both coronavirus cases and deaths, with nearly 1.7 million reported cases as of May 27, according to Johns Hopkins data. However, this number is likely an underestimate due to inadequate testing capacity and the number of people who develop mild illnesses and do not seek medical attention.

The trend of declining new confirmed cases has reversed itself in recent days, likely due to a decline in social distancing measures as states reopen and summer weather draws people out of their homes. A top World Health Organization official warned on May 26 that "we're right in the middle of the first wave [of coronavirus cases] globally" and that "we're still very much in a phase where the disease is actually on the way up" in many parts of the world.

Experts emphasize that social distancing is among the best ways to keep infection, hospitalization, and death rates as low as possible, and that a vaccine providing widespread immunity is still needed. A Columbia University analysis published on May 20 estimated that 36,000 lives could have been saved if the US had broadly adopted social distancing policies a week earlier than many places did, in mid-March. The 100,000 lives already lost in the US serve as a painful reminder of what happened instead.

Title: Obama's Grand Bargain Efforts Face Significant Obstacles

The article discusses the challenges facing President Obama's efforts to revive a grand bargain, a comprehensive deal addressing budget and tax issues. The main obstacles are the $600 billion in tax increases implemented in December, which may be the only new revenue Obama will get, and the strained relationship between the President and Republicans on Capitol Hill.

According to sources, the $600 billion in tax increases, which Obama touted as a victory, now seem like a missed opportunity. Republicans have made it clear they are done raising taxes for this Congress, and Democrats and Republicans alike believe the grand bargain is unlikely to happen.

The article also highlights the strained relationship between Obama and Republicans, citing an anecdote from House Majority Whip Kevin McCarthy's encounter with the President at a dinner event. McCarthy described Obama as a "loner" who would rather lecture than engage in dialogue. The article concludes that this dynamic makes it difficult to envision a grand bargain being reached.

Title: Justice Department Releases Additional Text Messages Between FBI Officials, Revealing Insights into Clinton Investigation

The Justice Department has provided congressional committees with nearly 400 pages of additional text messages between two FBI officials, Peter Strzok and Lisa Page, who were removed from Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into alleged collusion between the Trump campaign and Russian officials. The newly discovered messages appear to indicate that Strzok and Page knew that charges would not be filed against Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton as a result of the investigation into her email server, before Clinton was interviewed by the FBI.

According to a letter from Sen. Ron Johnson, R-Wis., the chairman of the Senate Homeland Security Committee, the Justice Department provided 384 pages of messages to lawmakers on Friday. However, Johnson noted that additional texts sent between Dec. 14, 2016, and May 17 of last year were not preserved by the FBI's system.

One exchange between Strzok and Page, dated July 1, 2016, referenced then-Attorney General Loretta Lynch's decision to accept the FBI's conclusion in the Clinton investigation. Lynch's announcement came days after it was revealed that the attorney general and former President Bill Clinton had an impromptu meeting aboard her plane in Phoenix.

"Yeah, that is awful timing," Page agreed. In a later message, she added: "It's a real profile in courage, since she knows no charges will be brought."

Four days later, then-FBI Director James Comey announced that no charges would be brought against Clinton, even though, as he put it, her actions in regard to the private server were "extremely careless."

Another exchange from the day before referenced a change to Comey's statement closing out the investigation. While an earlier draft of the statement said Clinton and President Barack Obama had an email exchange while Clinton was "on the territory" of a hostile adversary, the reference to Obama was changed to "senior government official" and then omitted entirely in the final version.

The release of the additional messages has sparked controversy, with Republican lawmakers contending that the FBI and the Mueller team were politically tainted and biased against Trump. The FBI has flatly rejected these assertions.

The Justice Department's release of the additional messages is part of an ongoing effort to provide transparency and accountability in the investigation. The FBI has been criticized for its handling of the investigation, including the discovery of Strzok and Page's anti-Trump messages and their subsequent removal from the investigation.

Title: Investigative Journalist Exposes "Smear Machine" and its Influence on News Coverage

Renowned investigative journalist Sharyl Attkisson has written a new book, "The Smear: How Shady Political Operatives and Fake News Control What You See, What You Think, and How You Vote." In a recent interview, Attkisson discussed her findings with Jenna Browder, highlighting the existence of an industry that targets journalists, whistleblowers, and political figures to shape public opinion and sway elections.

Attkisson emphasized that this "smear machine" is designed to create a false narrative, often with the help of paid corporate or political interests. She cited an anonymous source who stated, "Everything you see is put there for a reason. It's like a movie. It's like a scene in a movie that the images that you come across, whether it's what a comedian jokes about on a national program, whether it's social media, whether it's on the news, it's put there for a reason, often by someone who paid a lot of money to put it there."

Attkisson pointed to the 2016 election as a prime example of the "smear machine" in action. She noted that Democrats had a significant advantage in controlling the messaging and using the news media to their advantage. However, Republicans were able to overcome this advantage, and Attkisson believes this may be due to voters becoming more media savvy.

The journalist also discussed the Russia probe, stating that President Trump is correct in calling it a "witch hunt" based on the evidence to date. Attkisson emphasized that the coverage of the Russia story has been wildly disproportionate to the evidence, with many incorrect reports from respected news outlets that have not been corrected or apologized for.

Attkisson's book uses statistics from Freedom of Information Act requests and information exposed by outlets like WikiLeaks to demonstrate the extent of the smear machine's influence. She believes that it's essential to approach nearly everything you see or read with a healthy dose of skepticism, questioning who is behind the information and what their motivations are.

In conclusion, Attkisson's work highlights the importance of media literacy and the need for individuals to critically evaluate the information they consume.

Title: Obama Leads Romney in Key Battleground States, Poll Shows

A recent Quinnipiac University/New York Times/CBS poll has revealed that President Barack Obama holds a significant lead over Republican challenger Mitt Romney in three crucial battleground states: Florida, Ohio, and Pennsylvania. According to the poll, Obama leads Romney by six points in Florida and Ohio, and by 11 points in Pennsylvania.

In Florida, Obama garnered 51% of likely voters' support, compared to 45% for Romney. In Ohio, Obama held a 50-44 advantage, and in Pennsylvania, he led 53-42. The poll also found that Obama is viewed more positively by voters in each state, with at least 50% holding a favorable opinion of him.

In contrast, Romney's favorability ratings were underwater in all three states, with 39% of Pennsylvania voters holding a favorable view of him, compared to 47% with an unfavorable opinion. The poll suggests that Romney's supporters in these states are more likely to back him because they dislike Obama, rather than vice versa.

The poll also found that Obama's supporters in each state are more strongly committed to their candidate, with 59% of Pennsylvania voters, 64% of Ohio voters, and 63% of Florida voters strongly supporting Obama. In contrast, 49% of Romney's backers in Florida, 42% in Ohio, and 41% in Pennsylvania strongly support him.

The poll also highlighted the importance of the economy as the top issue for voters in all three states. However, the poll found that a majority of voters in each state support Obama's plan to raise taxes on households making more than $250,000 to reduce the federal deficit, with 62% of Pennsylvania voters, 60% of Ohio voters, and 58% of Florida voters in favor of the plan.

The poll was conducted by landline and cell phones from July 24 to July 30 among 1,193 likely voters in Ohio, 1,168 likely voters in Florida, and 1,168 likely voters in Pennsylvania.

Title: U.S. Economy Adds 157,000 Jobs in July, Unemployment Rate Dips to 3.9%

The United States added 157,000 jobs in July, according to the Labor Department's latest report. The unemployment rate remained steady at 3.9%, matching analysts' expectations. Payrolls were revised upward by 59,000 for the prior two months, with June's job growth revised to 248,000 and May's to 268,000.

Manufacturing jobs grew by 37,000, while professional and business services added 51,000 jobs, and leisure and hospitality jobs rose 40,000. Over the past 12 months, payrolls have been growing at an average rate of 203,000 per month.

Private analysts had estimated that about 190,000 jobs were added in July, and the unemployment rate was expected to dip to 3.9% from June's 4%. The last time the jobless rate was this low was in 2000.

Average hourly earnings increased by 7 cents to $27.05, up 2.7% over the past year. However, some economists argue that wages should be growing at a faster rate, with some predicting a 3.5% annual rate. When factoring in the cost of living, wage growth appears even weaker.

The economy has been growing at a strong pace, with the second quarter seeing a 4.1% growth rate, the strongest in nearly four years. Some economists attribute this to temporary factors, such as the Republican tax cuts and increased export shipments ahead of retaliatory tariffs by China on U.S. agricultural products. However, President Trump has called the numbers "very sustainable" and predicted that the next quarter will be "outstanding."

The Federal Reserve noted that the labor market has "continued to strengthen" and the economy has been strong overall. While the central bank decided to keep interest rates unchanged, it has signaled that it will hike them twice more this year.

Title: Republican Party's Immigration Stance: A Complex Issue with No Easy Solutions

The Republican Party's reaction to the 2012 presidential election has been marked by a mix of panic, wishful thinking, and attempts to appeal to Latino voters through immigration reform. However, a closer examination of the data suggests that the relationship between immigration policy and the Latino vote is more complex than often portrayed.

According to exit polls, Senator John McCain's support for amnesty in 2008 did not significantly improve his standing among Latino voters, with Mitt Romney performing similarly in 2012. This raises questions about the assumption that immigration reform is the key to unlocking the Latino vote.

A closer look at the demographics of the Latino community reveals that many households with children are headed by unmarried mothers, and a significant percentage receive benefits from major welfare programs. This does not necessarily mean that the GOP should not try to appeal to these voters, but it does suggest that they are not natural Republican voters.

Furthermore, a poll conducted by ImpreMedia/Latino Decisions found that 61% of Latinos support keeping the Affordable Care Act in place, and 66% believe the government should ensure access to health insurance. This may be due to the fact that 32% of non-elderly Latinos lack health insurance, which is about twice the national average.

In conclusion, the relationship between immigration policy and the Latino vote is more nuanced than often suggested. While some Republicans may argue that amnesty is the right policy on its merits, it is not a magic key to unlocking the Latino vote. The GOP must consider the broader demographic and economic factors that shape the Latino community's attitudes and behaviors.

Title: Defense Secretary James Mattis Resigns, Citing Differences with President Trump

Defense Secretary James Mattis resigned on December 20, 2018, submitting a letter to President Donald Trump stating that he was stepping down due to differences in their views. The resignation comes a day after Trump announced the withdrawal of 2,000 troops from Syria. In his letter, Mattis emphasized the importance of maintaining strong alliances and being resolute in challenging countries like China and Russia.

Mattis, a retired four-star general, had been a key figure in the Trump administration, serving as Secretary of Defense since 2017. He was known for his strong views on the importance of alliances and his commitment to upholding American values. In his letter, he reiterated his "core belief" in the need for a strong international order and emphasized the importance of working with allies to advance American interests.

Trump characterized Mattis' decision to resign as a retirement, crediting him with helping the administration with the purchase of new military equipment and getting allies to pay their share of military obligations. Trump announced that he would name a new Secretary of Defense shortly.

Mattis' resignation has sparked concerns about the potential impact on the Trump administration's national security team. With his departure, National Security Adviser John Bolton and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo may face less resistance as they offer more hawkish advice on North Korea, Iran, and other issues.

Mattis had a mixed record of success with Trump, opposing the withdrawal from the Iran deal, moving the US embassy in Israel to Jerusalem, and starting a trade war with America's allies. However, he failed to persuade Trump on each of these issues, despite his good rapport with the president.

Despite his successes, Mattis also faced criticism for his handling of certain issues, including his recommendation of an attack on terrorists in Yemen that led to the death of a Navy SEAL and his support for continuing the war in Afghanistan.

Title: Biden's Testy Exchange with The Breakfast Club's Charlamagne tha God: A Misunderstood Conversation

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden recently sat down for an 18-minute interview with Charlamagne tha God, the host of the popular radio show The Breakfast Club. The conversation has been described as a "testy exchange," but a closer examination reveals a nuanced and informative discussion between two individuals with a deep understanding of each other's perspectives.

Charlamagne, with 2.1 million Twitter followers, is known for his ability to hold politicians accountable while still allowing them to share their thoughts and opinions. He did just that with Biden, pressing him on several topics, including the 1994 crime bill, mass incarceration, and the lack of black women in leadership positions.

Throughout the conversation, Biden did most of the talking, but Charlamagne's questions and comments kept the discussion engaging and thought-provoking. The interview was interrupted twice by a Biden staffer, who attempted to end the conversation due to a virtual event with Jill Biden. However, Biden pushed through, and the discussion continued.

The most notable moment came when Charlamagne expressed frustration with Biden's attempt to end the interview, saying "You can't do that to black media." Biden responded by joking that he also has to deal with white media and that his wife had a virtual event to attend. This exchange has been misinterpreted by some as Biden being dismissive of black media, but in context, it appears to be a lighthearted moment between two individuals who have a strong relationship.

Biden's comment about not being sure if someone is black if they don't support him or Trump has been taken out of context. In the context of the previous 17 minutes of conversation, it's clear that Biden is poking fun at the idea that someone's political beliefs define their racial identity. He is acknowledging the overwhelming majority of African Americans' disapproval of Trump's policies and expressing his own affinity with the black community.

The article concludes by expressing hope for Biden's return to The Breakfast Club, where he will continue to face tough questions and engage in meaningful discussions about the issues affecting African Americans.

Title: Women Lag Behind Men in Political Donations, Despite Increased Efforts

Article:

Despite some notable exceptions, women continue to lag behind men in political donations, with a significant gap in the amount and frequency of their contributions. According to a review of Federal Election Commission reports and data from the Center for Responsive Politics, women accounted for only 17% of the top 100 donors in the 2012 election, with the top female donor, Miriam Adelson, contributing around $46 million, mostly to Republican committees and super PACs.

The reasons for this disparity vary, with some women citing a lack of cash, distaste for the process, or a decision to donate to other causes. However, the outcome is clear: women are not equally represented among the top donors, and this has an impact on what gets discussed on the campaign trail or rises to the top of the agenda in Congress.

Wealthy men, such as Charles and David Koch, Jeffrey Katzenberg, and Foster Friess, have the clout and are often the ones who drive the national conversation. This is not to say that women are not making significant contributions, but rather that they are not as prominent in the political giving landscape.

Some women, like Amber Mostyn, a Democratic megadonor and Houston trial lawyer, acknowledge the impact of their lack of representation among top donors. "It's like picking a football team and getting them to kick a field goal the other way," she said. Mostyn's husband, Steve, received more attention for their donations in 2012, and she noted that even when she makes a donation, articles often credit the Mostyns together.

The numbers are stark: of the top 100 overall donors, 11 were women, and they contributed about 17% of the total amount given by those 100 donors. Among the top 31,000 donors, women accounted for 28% of the donors, according to the Sunlight Foundation.

While some women are breaking barriers in other areas of the political world, the lack of women among top donors is a persistent issue. It's not just about money, but also about opportunity and the political structure. "The reason women don't give to politics is because they're lacking the mentorship and the support that men receive," said Susie Tomkins Buell, a Democratic megadonor associated with Democracy Alliance. "But once they get invited in, they feel very empowered by the act."

Title: Prince Andrew Uncooperative in Jeffrey Epstein Sex Trafficking Investigation

Article:

A U.S. prosecutor overseeing the Jeffrey Epstein sex trafficking investigation has stated that Prince Andrew, the Duke of York, has been uncooperative in the inquiry so far. Geoffrey Berman, the top federal prosecutor in Manhattan, made the announcement during a news conference outside Epstein's New York mansion on January 27, 2020. Berman stated that prosecutors and the FBI had contacted Prince Andrew's lawyers and asked to interview him, but he has provided "zero cooperation" to date.

The investigation is focused on Epstein's alleged sex trafficking ring, which involved recruiting young girls from around the world, including the United States, to engage in sexual activities with him and his associates. One of the alleged victims, Virginia Roberts Giuffre, claims she had sexual encounters with Prince Andrew at Epstein's behest, starting when she was 17.

It is unclear what legal exposure Prince Andrew might have in the case, as the age of consent for sex is 16 in England and 17 in New York. However, Giuffre claims she was paid by Epstein for her sexual encounters with Andrew, which could constitute a violation of U.S. sex trafficking laws if she was under 18 or was coerced into unwanted sex acts.

Prince Andrew has denied any knowledge of Epstein's alleged sex trafficking activities and has stepped back from his royal duties amid renewed public attention on the allegations. The investigation is ongoing, and U.S. Attorney General William Barr has vowed to aggressively investigate and bring charges against anyone who may have helped Epstein.

Title: Obama Administration to Pursue Assault Weapons Ban as Part of Gun Control Efforts

The Obama administration plans to seek passage of an assault weapons ban as part of its efforts to implement new gun control laws, according to an administration official. This decision comes after Vice President Joe Biden's meeting with stakeholders in the gun control debate, including the National Rifle Association (NRA) and other gun owners' groups.

On Thursday, Biden outlined a series of potential proposals under consideration by his gun task force, focusing on a new universal background check system for gun buyers and restrictions on high-capacity magazines. The omission of an assault weapons ban from this list led to speculation that the White House had dropped consideration of such a ban. However, White House spokesman Matt Lehrich clarified that the President has been clear that Congress should reinstate the assault weapons ban and that avoiding this issue is not an option.

Administration officials note that Biden's comments on Thursday were aimed at "consensus" proposals coming out of the task force meetings, and an assault weapons ban would not fit that category. The White House is prepared to move aggressively on its proposals, with Biden meeting with the NRA just before making his public comments.

The gun lobby expressed disappointment in its discussion with the vice president and later released a statement accusing the administration of mounting an agenda to attack the Second Amendment. Organizations seeking tougher gun control laws insist an assault weapons ban is critical to addressing the nation's recent rash of mass shootings. However, such a ban could be difficult in a Congress mired in gridlock.

The Biden task force is expected to deliver its recommendations to the President on Tuesday, and once the President makes some recommendations, House Speaker John Boehner's office will review them.

Title: Clinton Campaign Highlights Trump's Focus on Personal Grievances Over Governance

Article:

Hillary Clinton and her running mate, Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia, spoke to reporters on her campaign plane on Saturday, drawing a contrast between their approach to governance and that of their Republican rival, Donald Trump. The Clinton campaign is focusing on Trump's recent statement that he would sue the women who have accused him of making unwanted sexual advances, which they see as a sign that he is more interested in avenging personal grievances than in governing the country.

During a rally in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Clinton emphasized that Trump's focus on personal scores to settle is a departure from the kind of leadership the country needs. She noted that Trump's agenda for his first 100 days in office is centered around settling scores with his opponents, rather than working to address the country's pressing issues.

Kaine, who accompanied Clinton to the rally, added that Trump seems "most personally invested in...all of the scores that he needs to settle with people he's mad at." The Clinton campaign is trying to make inroads among college-educated women who normally vote Republican, and this message is part of their strategy to appeal to this demographic.

Clinton also touched on the theme that Trump is a danger to America's democratic traditions, citing his refusal to commit to accepting the results of the election and his suggestion that he might not concede if he loses. She emphasized that failing to accept election results is a fundamental aspect of democratic governance and that Trump's behavior shows a disregard for constitutional freedoms and protections.

In addition to discussing Trump's behavior, Clinton also spent time making a case for Democratic Senate candidate Katie McGinty, who is challenging incumbent Republican Pat Toomey in Pennsylvania. The Clinton campaign believes that defeating Toomey is crucial to retaking control of the Senate and providing a friendlier Congress if she wins in November.

Title: Senate Blocks Republican Push to Unanimously Pass Additional Funding for Small Business Loan Program

Article:

The United States Senate failed to pass a bill to inject an additional $250 billion into the small business loan program, which was designed to help companies affected by the coronavirus pandemic. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) attempted to pass the measure by a unanimous vote, but was blocked by Senator Ben Cardin (D-Md.), who objected to the request.

The move comes as the Trump administration has cited strong demand for the loans, with the program exhausting its initial $350 billion funding. The program allows small businesses to apply for loans, which can be forgiven partly or fully if used for expenses such as payroll, rent, and utilities.

Senate Democrats, led by Speaker Nancy Pelosi, have proposed additional funding for hospitals, health systems, state and local governments, and food assistance programs, in addition to the small business loan program. However, McConnell argued that the small business aid is the only part of the $2 trillion rescue law at risk of exhausting its funding, and that Democrats are holding up the process by seeking additional funding.

The debate comes as the Senate adjourned until Monday, with it unclear if Republicans and Democrats will be able to reach an agreement on emergency legislation in the coming days. House Speaker Pelosi has indicated she may try to pass a Democratic bill on Friday, which Republicans can likely block with most representatives out of Washington.

The Trump administration has asked Congress for more money for the program, citing strong demand, but has not provided data to justify the request. The program is designed to help small businesses keep employees on payroll, and lawmakers initially approved $350 billion for loans.

Title: Ezra Klein's "Why We're Polarized" Explores the Roots of American Political Polarization

Ezra Klein, editor-at-large at Vox and host of The Ezra Klein Show podcast, has released a new book, "Why We're Polarized," which delves into the reasons behind the growing political polarization in the United States. In an exclusive interview, Klein discussed his book's arguments and the role technology plays in the phenomenon.

Klein's book argues that over the past 50 years, the country's dominant political coalitions have sorted along various lines, including ideology, race, religion, geography, psychology, consumer behavior, and cultural preferences. This has led to a self-reinforcing cycle of polarization, where political institutions and actors adopt more polarized strategies to respond to and appeal to a more polarized audience, further polarizing the audience, and so on.

While social media is often seen as a primary driver of polarization, Klein believes it is merely an accelerant, rather than the core cause. The bulk of the increase in American party polarization predates the rise of social media, making it a relatively small part of the overall story.

Klein also discussed the feedback loop that can occur within the media industry, where outlets that are critical of a particular politician or ideology may attract a primarily like-minded audience, creating incentives to produce more content that reinforces those views. This can lead to a vicious cycle of polarization, where both sides become entrenched and unwilling to compromise.

The author identifies two primary problems caused by polarization: the constant anger and agitation it creates, and the inability to resolve political disputes due to the need for high levels of compromise. Klein argues that the political system requires bipartisanship to function effectively, but with parties as polarized as they are, this becomes irrational for the out-of-power party to offer. As a result, the public is left trapped in a system where everyone is fighting, but problems are not being solved.

Title: Obama's Next Big Campaign: Selling Health Care to the Public

The White House is gearing up for a massive campaign this summer to promote the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, across all 50 states and Washington, D.C. The campaign aims to encourage uninsured individuals to sign up for health insurance when it becomes available on October 1. The administration hopes to enroll 7 million people in the first year, requiring a multi-faceted approach involving TV ads, door-to-door canvassing, and social media outreach.

The administration is developing an Expedia-style website to make the enrollment process customer-friendly. However, getting people to the website is a significant challenge, as a recent Kaiser Family Foundation poll showed that 4 in 10 Americans are unaware the health care law is still in effect.

Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius has requested funding from Congress to implement Obamacare, but Republicans have repeatedly denied her requests. In response, Sebelius has turned to independent groups, such as Enroll America, to raise funds. However, this move has drawn criticism from Republicans, who are investigating the solicitations.

The success of the campaign relies heavily on getting young and healthy individuals to sign up for health insurance, as they are crucial to making the system financially sustainable. To achieve this, administration officials will be giving more commencement speeches, urging young adults to sign up for health coverage in the fall.

The campaign faces significant challenges, including the need for funding and the need to overcome public apathy. However, the administration remains committed to implementing universal health coverage, and the success of the campaign will be crucial to President Obama's legacy.

Title: House Republicans Resist Efforts to Crack Down on Tax Cheats

Article:

House Republicans are pushing back against efforts to crack down on tax cheats, citing concerns about the Internal Revenue Service's (IRS) handling of tax-exempt organizations. The move is a significant shift from just a few years ago, when Republicans led the charge to help the IRS clamp down on tax shelters and require foreign banks to help the US authorities catch Americans stashing income abroad.

The change in stance comes after an inspector general report in May 2013 criticized the IRS for excessively scrutinizing tea party groups seeking tax breaks. Since then, more than 20 congressional hearings have been held, eroding trust in the agency among lawmakers and the public.

Representative Pat Tiberi (R-Ohio), who sits on the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, expressed skepticism about giving the IRS more authority. "There's not a whole lot of confidence right now about what the Internal Revenue Service does among the American people, let alone members of Congress," he said. "Why should we give them more tools to harass taxpayers?"

The dispute threatens to derail efforts to collect the approximately $400 billion in taxes that go unpaid every year, as well as unrelated legislation. A highway budget bill and a measure offering tax cuts to startup companies, small businesses, bike-sharing programs, and theatrical productions are at risk of dying in the Senate due to House Republican opposition.

Senate Republicans, however, have not been as opposed to the idea of cracking down on tax cheats. Senator John Thune (R-S.D.) said, "I don't think Senate Republicans on the [Finance] committee have a big problem with just making sure taxes that are owed are being collected. It's just a function of enforcing the law."

Senate Finance Committee Chairman Ron Wyden (D-Ore.) expressed disappointment at the House Republicans' stance, saying it is a departure from the traditional bipartisan cooperation on tax compliance measures. "This has been a traditional position supported by both sides of the aisle," he said. "Certainly, this is a departure that needs to be addressed."

Title: Islamic State Releases Video Showing Beheading of Syrian Soldiers and Claimed Killing of U.S. Aid Worker Peter Kassig

The Islamic State group has released a video showing the beheading of a dozen Syrian soldiers and claiming responsibility for the death of U.S. aid worker Peter Kassig, a 26-year-old American who was captured in eastern Syria last year. The video, posted on websites used by the group, shows the beheadings of the Syrian military officers and pilots, all dressed in blue jumpsuits, and a militant claiming to have killed Kassig.

The video identifies the militants' location as Dabiq, a town in northern Syria, and warns that U.S. soldiers will meet a similar fate. The militant, who has a British accent, claims Kassig was killed because he "fought against the Muslims in Iraq while serving as a soldier."

Kassig, who was born in Indiana, served in the U.S. Army's 75th Ranger Regiment and deployed to Iraq in 2007. After being medically discharged, he formed the aid organization Special Emergency Response and Assistance (SERA) in Turkey to aid Syrian refugees. He delivered food and medical supplies and provided trauma care to wounded Syrian civilians before being captured.

The White House confirmed Kassig's death on Sunday, with President Barack Obama calling the killing "an act of pure evil" and "a brutal murder of an innocent American." The U.S. intelligence community is examining the video, and the White House would be "appalled by the brutal murder of an innocent American" if it is authentic.

The Islamic State group has been responsible for the beheading of several Western hostages, including two American journalists and two British aid workers. The latest video does not show the beheading of Kassig, unlike previous videos, and does not show other Western captives or directly threaten to behead anyone else.

The group has been responsible for the beheading and shooting of hundreds of captives, mainly Syrian and Iraqi soldiers, during its sweep across the two countries, and has celebrated its mass killings in extremely graphic videos. The group has declared a self-styled Islamic caliphate in the areas under its control, governing according to its violent interpretation of Shariah law.

The U.S.-led coalition is targeting the Islamic State group in airstrikes, supporting Western-backed Syrian rebels, Kurdish fighters, and the Iraqi military. The group has its roots in al-Qaida's Iraqi affiliate but was expelled over its brutal tactics and refusal to obey orders to confine its activities to Iraq. It became even more extreme amid the bloody civil war in neighboring Syria and grew strong enough to launch a lightning offensive across Iraq.

**House Democrats Release Documents from Lev Parnas, Giuliani Associate, in Impeachment Inquiry**

House Democrats have released a trove of documents obtained from Lev Parnas, a close associate of President Donald Trump's personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, as part of the impeachment investigation. The documents include a handwritten note that mentions asking Ukraine's president to investigate "the Biden case."

The documents, obtained as part of the impeachment investigation, show Parnas communicating with Giuliani before the removal of Marie Yovanovitch, who was the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine. A man named Robert F. Hyde disparaged Yovanovitch in messages to Parnas and gave him updates on her location and cell phone use, raising questions about possible surveillance.

The documents add new context to the charges that Trump pressured Ukraine to investigate Democrats as he withheld military aid. Parnas was in frequent communication with Giuliani and Ukrainian officials, the messages show. He appeared to be pushing unsubstantiated allegations that Democrat Joe Biden and his son, Hunter Biden, were somehow engaged in corruption in Ukraine.

Among the documents is a screenshot of a previously undisclosed letter from Giuliani to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, dated May 10, 2019, which was before Zelensky took office. In the letter, Giuliani requests a meeting with Zelensky "as personal counsel to President Trump and with his knowledge and consent."

The documents also include a handwritten note on stationery from the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Vienna that says "get Zalensky to Annonce that the Biden case will be Investigated." Trump asked Zelensky in a July call to investigate his political rival, Democrat Joe Biden, and his son Hunter. Hunter Biden served on the board of a gas company based in Ukraine.

The documents were sent to the House Judiciary Committee by three other House panels "to be included as part of the official record that will be transmitted to the Senate along with the Articles of Impeachment," according to a statement. Some of the materials were made public while others were marked as sensitive.

Parnas and his business partner, Igor Fruman, both U.S. citizens who emigrated from the former Soviet bloc, were indicted last year on charges of conspiracy, making false statements, and falsification of records. Prosecutors allege they made outsize campaign donations to Republican causes after receiving millions of dollars originating from Russia. The men have pleaded not guilty.

In several of the documents, Parnas communicated with Giuliani about the removal of Yovanovitch. The ambassador's ouster, ordered by Trump, was at the center of the Democrats' impeachment inquiry. Yovanovitch testified in the House impeachment hearings that she was the victim of a "smear campaign."

Title: Romney Addresses Religious Conservatives, Discusses Israel Policy

Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, addressed religious conservatives at the Faith and Freedom Coalition in Washington via video uplink, discussing his stance on Israel and the Middle East. During the address, Romney stated that he would do the opposite of what President Obama has done on Israel, emphasizing his hawkish views on the issue.

Romney's bus tour, which is taking him through six pivotal states won by President Obama in 2008, has been met with protests from Democrats. In Pennsylvania, Romney's bus was forced to take a detour after former Governor Ed Rendell and other Democratic officials held a press conference outside a Wawa gas station where Romney had planned to stop. The Republican candidate instead visited a different Wawa store and made a quick tour through the store.

Romney's tour is aimed at challenging President Obama in states where he is strong, targeting smaller cities and towns through Pennsylvania's more conservative midsection. The tour has been seen as a test of Romney's ability to connect with average people and adapt to less-scripted environments.

In his address to religious conservatives, Romney criticized President Obama's policy towards Iran, stating that the president is more concerned about Israel attacking Iran than he is about Iran obtaining a nuclear weapon. Romney also discussed his stance on Israel, saying that he believes the president has not done enough to support the country.

Romney's bus tour is his first traditional campaign swing since the primary and is aimed at undecided voters in six pivotal states. The tour represents a new mode for Romney in the general election, as he seeks to connect with average people and adapt to less-scripted environments.

Title: Chicago Mayor Rebukes Ivanka Trump's Tweets on Gun Violence

Article:

Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot responded to a pair of tweets from presidential adviser Ivanka Trump, which highlighted the city's gun violence problem. The tweets were posted in response to the recent mass shootings in Dayton, Ohio, and El Paso, Texas. Ivanka Trump's tweets mentioned that Chicago experienced its deadliest weekend of the year, with seven people killed and 52 wounded near a playground.

However, Mayor Lightfoot disputed the accuracy of Ivanka Trump's claims, stating that the incident was not a single event, but rather multiple shootings that occurred across the city. "It wasn't a playground, it was a park. It wasn't seven dead. It wasn't 52 wounded in one incident, which is what this suggests. It's misleading," Mayor Lightfoot said.

A spokeswoman for Ivanka Trump issued a statement reiterating that Chicago had experienced one of the deadliest weekends this year and that the first daughter's point remains the same about inner-city violence. The statement also acknowledged that the quote was misleading in implying that all the shooting incidents occurred in one location, but emphasized that there were seven deaths and 52 wounded across the city, resulting in one of the deadliest weekends in the city this year.

The mayor and Ivanka Trump have met previously, discussing workforce development and criminal justice reform. Despite the disagreement over the accuracy of the tweets, the mayor's office stated that she is focused on addressing the issue of gun violence and working to keep the city safe.

Title: Alabama Governor's Campaign Draws Comparisons to 1970s Segregationist Governor

The Alabama governor's race has drawn comparisons to the 1970s segregationist governor, George Wallace, due to the volatile nature of the campaign. While candidate Roy Moore has not made statements as incendiary as Wallace, he has used political jujitsu to address racial politics. Moore's campaign sent out a mailer featuring an African-American with the question, "Think if a black man went after high school girls, anyone would try to make him a senator?" The mailer was met with criticism, with some viewing it as a veiled attempt to appeal to white voters.

Political veterans have drawn parallels between Moore's campaign and Wallace's 1970 run for governor, which took on an "unholy coalition" of Republicans, Democrats, African-Americans, and wealthy whites. However, those who knew Wallace well note that while the messages may be similar, the messengers are not.

Title: Obama Dismisses Criticism Over Syria Response, Prioritizes Policy Over Style

President Barack Obama has responded to criticism over his handling of the Syria crisis, stating that Washington is more concerned with style than substance. In an interview with ABC's "This Week," Obama emphasized that he is focused on getting the policy right, rather than receiving praise for his approach.

The president faced intense scrutiny after his statement that Syrian President Bashar Assad would "cross a red line" if he used chemical weapons in the country's ongoing civil war. The criticism intensified when Obama announced plans for a military strike against Assad, but later sought congressional approval. The proposal ultimately gained little traction, leading to diplomatic efforts to address the crisis.

Some lawmakers, including Tennessee Republican Sen. Bob Corker, have criticized Obama's handling of the situation, describing it as "ad-hoc," "improvised," and "unsteady." However, Obama remains unfazed by the criticism, prioritizing the effectiveness of his policy over public perception.
