The president also discussed the pursuit of a nuclear weapon by Iran, stating that it is a "far larger issue" for the United States than the use of chemical weapons in Syria. Obama has exchanged letters with Iran's new president, Hasan Rouhani, but the two have not spoken directly. The president believes Rouhani understands the potential for a diplomatic solution to Iran's disputed nuclear program, but will not make it easy.

In the interview, Obama also touched on his approach to fiscal negotiations with House Republicans, expressing concerns over the potential consequences of not increasing the federal debt limit.

**New Yorkers Adapt to New Etiquette Rules Amid Pandemic**

As New York City navigates the uncharted territory of the COVID-19 pandemic, residents are learning to adapt to new etiquette rules to make quarantine life more bearable for everyone. The usual rules for behavior are out the window, and it's time to tackle etiquette – basic rules for behavior to maintain social distancing and sanity.

Experts, including therapists, professional shoppers, and individuals with good opinions, have shared their insights on how to navigate these new norms. For instance, when grocery shopping, it's recommended to wear a mask, even if it's annoying, and to follow suit if your store hasn't mandated it. Heavy items, like cases of water bottles or large bags of rice, can be a challenge for delivery drivers, so it's best to note any special requests in the app or contact your driver.

When it comes to tipping, doing so within the app is best, as most drivers are operating under no-contact delivery orders. Delivery people don't want to touch you as much as you don't want to touch them, so it's best to stay inside your house when receiving deliveries.

Personal space is also a concept that's taken on new importance. In normal times, New Yorkers are used to packing themselves like sardines into subway cars, but now it's crucial to be mindful of how much room you're taking up on the sidewalk. It's okay to go on walks with members from your household, but step aside when around strangers, and make sure to stay 6 feet apart.

Working from home doesn't change your behavior all that much, says Maggie Craddock, founder of Workplace Relationships. If you normally wouldn't alert your team if you're stepping out for 20 minutes, there's no need to now, either. Videoconference calls through Zoom or Google Hangouts have become the norm, but they should be used wisely. Ask your team if they'd prefer to do a call over video or by phone, as everyone's moods are fluid right now.

It's also essential to be extra kind – to your teammates, who are also under additional strain right now, and to yourself. If you're feeling burnt out or dealing with a personal problem, be honest about it and ask for assistance. If you're living with someone who isn't taking social distancing seriously, be blunt and say, "Sorry, I know you think I'm being unreasonable, but I need to really insist on this."

For other issues, compromise is key. Adults moving back into their parents' house should be extra careful to keep the peace right now – which can mean reigning it in when you want to sound off. This is not the time to have fights that make you re-evaluate your relationship with your mother. "People are needing to make concessions to survive," says Matt Lundquist, a psychotherapist and the founder of Tribeca Therapy.

As the pandemic continues, it's essential to remember that it's okay to prioritize your own well-being and set boundaries. If you're not feeling up for a video call or don't want to receive a surprise visit, be direct with your loved ones. You can say, "I'm really down today and I'm not up for it," or "I'm exhausted and I had a busy work day."

Title: Presidential Campaign Enters Uncharted Territory as Contenders Emerge and Fall

The 2024 presidential campaign is shaping up to be one of the most unpredictable and entertaining in recent history. With a mix of seasoned politicians and newcomers vying for the top spot, the outcome is far from certain. Even Mitt Romney is reportedly considering another run, possibly seeking to capitalize on the investment of some familiar backers.

Hillary Clinton's campaign continues to receive respectful attention, but her chances of winning seem increasingly unlikely. If she were to win, the question of what to call her would become a topic of discussion. "Madame President" and "Mrs. President" have been suggested, but neither seems to have the desired ring.

Joe Biden, known for his lovable but gaffe-prone nature, has also been mentioned as a potential candidate. His suggestion that gun owners take their shotguns to the front porch to defend themselves against varmints and prowlers has raised eyebrows. The Republican establishment, meanwhile, is struggling to take Donald Trump seriously, despite his growing poll numbers.

The liberal media has been scrutinizing Trump's rally in Mobile, Alabama, which drew around 20,000 attendees to a stadium that seats 30,000. While the police declined to estimate the crowd size, it was larger than any other candidate has drawn so far. Trump himself compared the event to a Billy Graham revival meeting.

President Obama's endorsement could be a game-changer in the Democratic primary, signaling that a candidate has his approval and will protect his legacy. However, his endorsement could also be a kiss of death in the general election, as voters may view it as a sign of a candidate who is out of touch with the times.

The Republican establishment is wary of Trump's rise, fearing that his lack of political experience and outsider status could lead to a repeat of the 1940 mistake, when Wendell Willkie, a Wall Street lawyer with no political experience, was nominated. The establishment's failure to understand the impact of cable-TV, the internet, and a succession of unpolished candidates has contributed to Trump's popularity.

The Republican grassroots, meanwhile, is seeking rough justice and is willing to take risks. These passionate and angry voters are a minority of a minority, but they are loud and determined. As the campaign continues, it remains to be seen which candidates will emerge and which will fall by the wayside.

Title: Federal Government's Human Resources Agency Faces Scrutiny Over Data Breach

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM), the federal government's human resources agency, is under intense scrutiny after a data breach potentially affected as many as 32 million Americans. The agency's director, Katherine Archuleta, faced tough questions from lawmakers during a hearing on Wednesday, with some calling for her ousting.

The OPM has acknowledged two breaches, one of which stole personal information from about 4.2 million current and former federal employees, while the second breach gained access to the background check system, compromising sensitive information on millions of Americans. The agency has not disclosed the total number of individuals affected, with Archuleta refusing to provide a specific figure.

The cybersecurity firm Recorded Future reported that federal employees' login and password information is scattered across the internet, making it vulnerable to hacking. Many workers use the same login and password combination for both personal and work purposes, making it easier for hackers to access sensitive information.

The OPM's Chief Information Officer, Donna K. Seymour, was also criticized for her handling of the situation, with Committee Chairman Jason Chaffetz, Utah Republican, stating that she is "in over her head." Seymour acknowledged that the agency may have broken federal law and contracts by not informing a key company about the first data breach more than a year ago.

The White House has expressed confidence in Archuleta, but Congress has lost patience. The agency's inspector general, Patrick McFarland, expressed major concerns about the agency's handling of the situation, predicting that costs will balloon far beyond the $93 million projected. He also criticized the agency for being secretive and delaying answers.

The OPM has released a cybersecurity plan, which includes hiring a cybersecurity adviser by August 1 and learning best practices from industry leaders. The agency has also put in place a modernization plan to update its systems. Archuleta emphasized that the agency is taking the situation seriously and is committed to doing its best to address the problem.

Title: Beyond Marco Rubio, Other Latinos Could Be Mitt Romney's Vice Presidential Pick

The article discusses the possibility of Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney selecting a Latino running mate to help bridge the gap with Hispanic voters. While Sen. Marco Rubio is a prime contender, other options include Govs. Susanna Martinez of New Mexico and Brian Sandoval of Nevada. Historically, Republicans have struggled to win over Hispanic voters, with the best performance being George W. Bush's 44% in 2004.

Republican strategist Leslie Sanchez believes that adding a Latino candidate to the ticket could help the party appeal to independent Latino voters and show inclusiveness. However, others argue that experience and qualifications are more important than ethnicity. Gov. Martinez, a gun-toting conservative, has clashed with fellow Hispanics over her stance on illegal immigration, while Gov. Sandoval's support for abortion rights could be a drawback.

The article notes that Hispanic-Americans are diverse, with different cultural backgrounds and languages, making it challenging to find a candidate who can appeal to the entire community. Some strategists argue that Hispanics are a natural constituency for the GOP, citing their fiscal and social conservatism. However, the party's historical lack of outreach and its stance on immigration reform have hampered efforts to win over Hispanic voters.

While there is disagreement among Republican strategists about the impact of a Latino running mate, many agree that it would be an important gesture of inclusiveness. If Romney were to select a Latino candidate, it could help the party appeal to Hispanic voters in the long run.

Title: Pompeo's Confirmation as Secretary of State Faces Opposition, But Not Due to Lack of Qualifications

Article:

CIA Director Mike Pompeo is set to face a confirmation vote as Secretary of State, with some Democrats opposing his nomination. However, the reasons cited by opponents are not related to Pompeo's qualifications or abilities. As a seasoned intelligence professional, Pompeo has managed the CIA effectively, earning the respect of his peers. He has also served in Washington since 2011, initially as a congressman, and holds a strong educational background, having graduated top of his class at West Point and edited the Harvard Law Review.

The opposition to Pompeo's nomination is largely driven by his stance on social issues, such as his opposition to gay marriage and being pro-life. Senator Jeanne Shaheen, who supported his nomination as CIA director, has expressed concerns about these views. However, this standard would effectively bar any secretary of state nominee who does not align with certain political views.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, which has historically given its blessing to secretary of state nominees, has declined to do so this time. Pompeo's confirmation will likely require Democratic votes, as some Republicans, such as Steve Bannon and Rand Paul, have created a challenging environment for the Republican-controlled Senate to function. Senator Paul has expressed opposition to Pompeo, citing concerns about his stance on foreign policy.

Another Republican, Senator Jeff Flake, has hinted at opposing Pompeo due to his travel restrictions to Cuba. However, this issue is not a sufficient reason to block a secretary of state nominee, especially given the ongoing mystery surrounding the attacks on U.S. embassy employees in Havana.

On a positive note, Senator Heidi Heitkamp, a Democrat from North Dakota, has expressed support for Pompeo's nomination. It is likely that a few more red-state Democrats will follow suit. Despite Pompeo's expected confirmation, the vote will be historically narrow, reflecting the intense opposition to Trump's administration and a potential sign of things to come if Democrats take back the Senate in the next election.

Title: Senate Passes Stopgap Spending Bill, Averts Government Shutdown

The United States Senate passed a stopgap spending bill on Friday, averting a potential government shutdown and keeping federal agencies running until April. The bill, known as a "continuing resolution," keeps most government agencies operating at 2016 levels, with some increases in defense spending and disaster relief funding.

The bill was passed with 63 votes in favor and 36 against, after a late push by coal-state Democrats to extend miners' health benefits. The Senate also passed a water projects bill, which includes a "Buy America" provision requiring infrastructure projects to use U.S.-made steel and iron.

The spending bill was the result of a contentious negotiation between Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer. McConnell warned Democrats that if they did not accept the bill, they would be responsible for a partial government shutdown. Schumer said his party pushed the issue to the brink of a midnight deadline to highlight the seriousness of the matter.

The bill includes $8 billion in new defense spending, $4.1 billion in disaster relief and reconstruction funding, and $170 million to address drinking water problems, including the lead-tainted water in Flint, Michigan. It also includes $7 million to reimburse law enforcement agencies protecting President-elect Donald Trump in Manhattan.

The bill was passed with the help of enough Democrats linking arms with Republicans, after Sen. Joe Manchin III of West Virginia and fellow Democrats effectively conceded defeat in their push for a year-long extension of coal workers' health benefits. The bill will keep government agencies running until April 28, buying time for Trump to get his team up and running before Congress resumes its budget fights.

The spending bill is one of the dozen annual spending bills that Congress is supposed to approve each year, but only one of the bills has been passed so far, leaving most agencies running on stopgap funding since October 1.

Title: Ferguson Voter Registration Numbers Revised: Actual Number of Registrations Significantly Lower Than Initially Reported

Ferguson, Missouri, has seen a surge in voter registration following the August 9 police shooting of Michael Brown. Initially, reports indicated that 3,287 residents had registered to vote, a significant increase from previous years. However, an investigation by the local director of elections revealed that the actual number is significantly lower, at 128.

According to USA Today's Yamiche Alcindor, the director of elections attributed the discrepancy to a mistake, stating that a wrong report was pulled. The director described the error as "a mistake, pure and simple... no hanky-panky." The Secretary of State's office confirmed that the St. Louis County Election Board pulled the incorrect report.

The revised numbers have sparked concerns about the accuracy of voter registration data and the potential impact on the community. The surge in registrations was seen as a sign of residents seeking change and increased representation in the city. However, the actual number of new voters is significantly lower than initially reported.

The Ferguson protests, which began after the shooting, highlighted concerns about the lack of representation of the city's black community. Although 67% of Ferguson's population is black, the mayor and police chief are white, and only one council member is black. The low voter turnout during local elections has been a concern, with only 12.3% of eligible voters casting ballots in the recent mayoral and city council election.

The revised numbers may not necessarily translate to thousands of new votes, as only 1,484 of the 12,096 registered voters cast ballots during local elections in April. However, even if 12% of new registrants vote, that's 400 more voters, which could still impact a municipal election.

Title: Treasury Secretary Warns of "Catastrophic" Consequences of Failing to Raise Debt Limit

Article:

Treasury Secretary Jack Lew warned Congress on Thursday that failing to raise the debt limit would have "catastrophic" effects on the economy. Lew's warning comes as some lawmakers and market analysts have questioned the severity of the consequences of a government default, which Treasury officials, business leaders, and most economists agree would cause havoc in financial markets and hurt the economy.

The Treasury Department has stated that the government will run out of its ability to borrow money starting on October 17 and will soon after be unable to pay all government bills on time and in full. Lew emphasized that it is irresponsible and reckless to insist on a forced default to learn how bad it is, and that any potential lessons learned would only convince those who can work their will to avoid putting the entire economy at risk in the name of an ideological fight.

Some Republicans have been critical of Lew's warnings, arguing that he is trying to scare financial markets to get Congress to boost the debt ceiling without attaching a budget deal or changes to the president's health care law to the legislation. Senator Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) told Lew that the administration's warnings of deep cuts to Social Security recipients and disabled workers are unnecessary and that the Financial Stability Oversight Council has been silent on the issue.

Financial markets were more focused on reports of growing interest in Congress for a short-term debt ceiling increase than the public sparring at the hearing. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up more than 180 points in early morning trading.

Lew also addressed the idea that the Treasury Department can prioritize payments to bondholders, avoiding a technical default, even if payments to other government creditors are delayed. He did not rule out this course of action if the debt ceiling is not raised, but did not provide details on how the Treasury would manage a default. Lew emphasized that the legal and technical questions surrounding prioritization are many and that the system was not designed to be turned off selectively.

A failure to raise the debt limit will have "deeply damaging" and "catastrophic" effects on the economy, Lew warned.

Title: Bridging the Political Divide: A Call to Action for Northwestern Students

As the United States grapples with growing political polarization, it is easy to become disheartened and disengaged. However, as young Americans and future leaders, it is our responsibility to address this issue and work towards a more inclusive and empathetic society. The Brookings Institution, a renowned think tank, has labeled political polarization as "damaging to the political process," and it is up to us to take action.

The Pew Research Center has found that Americans self-segregate politically, clustering geographically by ideology, and consuming news that reinforces their beliefs. This phenomenon is not limited to politicians, but is a reflection of the American people's behavior. It is crucial to recognize that political polarization is not solely the responsibility of politicians, but rather a complex issue that requires a grassroots approach.

As Northwestern students, we have the unique opportunity to engage with individuals from diverse backgrounds and ideologies. By joining non-partisan political organizations, such as the NU Political Union and Politics & Policy, we can engage in respectful debates and discussions that challenge our perspectives. Through these interactions, we can develop a deeper understanding of others' beliefs and foster empathy.

Empathy is the key to bridging the ideological divide. By developing strong friendships with individuals from different political backgrounds, we can gain a deeper understanding of their experiences and perspectives. This empathy counteracts the notion that our political opponents are inherently bad or evil, and instead, recognizes that they are individuals with their own beliefs and values.

Political polarization extends beyond the Democrat-Republican divide, touching on issues such as political correctness and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. These debates can be difficult and sensitive, but it is essential to engage in respectful discussions and listen to each other's perspectives.

College is the perfect opportunity to bridge the ideological divide. Before social norms prohibit discussing politics in other settings, we should take advantage of this time to engage with fellow students and build relationships. Establishing boundaries and trust is crucial, and starting with less sensitive topics can help facilitate more meaningful discussions.

As future voters and leaders, it is our responsibility to take action and address political polarization. By engaging with individuals from diverse backgrounds, developing empathy, and fostering respectful discussions, we can work towards a more inclusive and compassionate society. The views expressed in this piece do not necessarily reflect the views of all staff members of The [insert publication name].

Title: Republican Voters Prioritize Economy Over Pandemic Control, Contrary to Overall Voter Sentiment

A recent New York Times/Siena poll has revealed a stark contrast between Republican voters and the general public regarding the COVID-19 pandemic. While voters overall strongly favor prioritizing pandemic control over reopening the economy, Republican voters take a different stance, aligning with the White House and Fox News.

The survey also highlights a significant disparity in individual behavior, with self-identified Democrats more likely to wear face masks and practice social distancing compared to self-identified Republicans. This partisan divide raises questions about the Republican Party's stance on the pandemic.

Some argue that the party's stance is driven by short-term political considerations. At the beginning of the year, former President Donald Trump's re-election message focused on economic triumphalism, and his administration delayed acknowledging the viral threat to avoid bad news. The push for premature reopening was also driven by a desire to return to pre-pandemic conditions.

However, others suggest that the Republican Party's denial of the pandemic has deeper roots. The key point is that COVID-19 is similar to climate change – an impersonal threat that requires an effective policy response and inconveniences like wearing face masks. The party may not want to acknowledge such threats, instead preferring to focus on more tangible, hate-based fears, such as those directed towards people of different races or perceived liberal elites.

The article does not provide information on the specific numbers or statistics from the New York Times/Siena poll, but it highlights the stark contrast between Republican voters and the general public on the issue of pandemic control.

Title: Rex Tillerson Fired as US Secretary of State, Warns of Russia's "Troubling Behavior"

Rex Tillerson, the former ExxonMobil chief and US Secretary of State, was fired by President Donald Trump on March 13, 2018. In a parting statement, Tillerson warned of Russia's "troubling behavior and actions," stating that the country must assess its actions in the best interest of the Russian people and the world. He also expressed concerns about the potential consequences of Russia's current trajectory, which could lead to greater isolation.

Tillerson's departure was announced via Twitter by Trump, who named CIA Director Mike Pompeo as his replacement. Pompeo will need to be confirmed by the Senate. Gina Haspel, a former CIA operative, was also named as the agency's first female director.

Tillerson's tenure as Secretary of State was marked by public disagreements with the White House, including over issues such as the Iran nuclear deal and North Korea. He had also been criticized for his handling of the crisis in Syria and his response to the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

In his statement, Tillerson acknowledged that he had spoken to Trump to ensure a smooth transition, but did not thank the president or praise his policies. He also expressed concerns about the challenges facing the country, including the need to respond to Russia's "troubling behavior and actions."

The firing of Tillerson is the latest in a series of high-profile departures from the Trump administration, including the resignation of Secretary of State Rex Tillerson's deputy, John Sullivan, who will take over running the State Department until Pompeo's confirmation.

The White House and Tillerson have offered different accounts of when the secretary was told he was being fired, with the White House saying he received a phone call from Chief of Staff John Kelly on Friday, while Tillerson's team claims he was not informed until after Trump's tweet.

Title: Mental Health Professionals' Diagnosis of President Trump: A Threat to Democracy

The article discusses the recent trend among mental health professionals to diagnose President Trump with various mental health conditions, including Alzheimer's, narcissistic personality disorder, and paranoia. The author, a Harvard Law School professor, argues that this is a dangerous and unethical practice that undermines the principles of democracy. The author notes that the American Psychiatric Association has condemned the practice of diagnosing public figures without examination, and that this trend is a threat to the democratic process.

The article highlights the historical context of this issue, citing the example of the 1964 presidential election, where psychiatrists questioned Senator Barry Goldwater's mental fitness to be president. The author notes that this was a flawed diagnosis, as Goldwater was later found to be emotionally stable and served with distinction in the Senate.

The author argues that mental health professionals have no more right to pathologize political opponents than do politicians or prosecutors, and that this practice is a form of political persecution. The author believes that it is important to focus on the merits and demerits of President Trump's policies and personality, rather than making unfounded diagnoses.

The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of respecting the democratic process and the principles of medical ethics. The author believes that mental health professionals should not diagnose public figures without examination, and that this practice is a threat to democracy.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Backs Constitutional Amendment to Limit Campaign Spending

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has expressed strong support for a proposed constitutional amendment that would limit campaign spending by outside groups, regardless of their political affiliation. The amendment, introduced by Democratic Senators Tom Udall and Michael Bennet, would give Congress the authority to regulate raising and spending limits for federal elections.

Reid announced on the Senate floor that the Judiciary Committee will soon hold a hearing on the amendment and that the full Senate will vote on the legislation. The measure aims to curb unlimited campaign spending by outside groups, which have grown significantly since the 2010 Supreme Court ruling in Citizens United.

Reid targeted billionaire industrialists David and Charles Koch, who have spent hundreds of millions of dollars through conservative non-profit political advocacy groups to attack Democrats and support Republicans. He emphasized that the Koch brothers' spending is unmatched, with no other group coming close to their level of spending.

The proposed amendment is likely to pass the Judiciary Committee, but its chances of passing the full Senate are slim due to broad GOP opposition. The amendment requires a two-thirds majority to pass, which is a high bar to clear.

The issue of campaign spending has been in the spotlight recently, with the Supreme Court's decision earlier this spring eliminating limits on individual donations to federal elections. The decision left intact the $5,200 limit on individual donations to a single candidate during a two-year election cycle.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Republican, criticized the proposed amendment, calling it an "all-out assault on the right to free speech" and a desperate attempt by Democrats to hold onto power. He argued that the amendment would vest the federal government with authority over free speech and political participation.

The debate surrounding campaign spending is closely tied to the upcoming midterm elections, with control of the Senate at stake. The Democrats hold a slim majority in the chamber, but are defending 21 of the 36 seats up for grabs in November's elections.

Title: Congressional Republicans Intensify Attacks on ObamaCare, Seek Changes to Health Care Law

The House Energy and Commerce Committee is set to vote on a bill that would allow Americans to keep their current health insurance plans, capitalizing on President Obama's recent apology for earlier assurances that people could keep their plans. The bill, backed by House Republicans, aims to address concerns that millions of Americans are losing their health insurance due to the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as ObamaCare.

The bill's proponents, led by Energy Committee Chairman Fred Upton, argue that the president should support the legislation if he is serious about offering relief to Americans whose health plans are being canceled. Upton stated, "Actions speak louder than words. If the president is serious about offering relief to Americans whose health plans are being canceled, then he should strongly support the Keep Your Health Plan Act."

The Republican-controlled House has also proposed legislation to delay the individual mandate, which requires Americans to purchase health insurance, as well as verifying that low-income individuals receiving federal subsidies to pay for insurance indeed qualify for them.

Some moderate Democrats have begun to support the House bill, while others, such as Senators Mark Begich, Mary Landrieu, and Kay Hagan, have introduced similar legislation to allow Americans to keep their existing health plans. Landrieu stated, "When we passed the Affordable Care Act, we did so with the intention that if you liked your health plan, you could keep it. A promise was made and this legislation will ensure that this promise is kept."

The renewed focus on ObamaCare comes as the government is still recovering from the partial shutdown, which was sparked by disagreements over the healthcare law. The House Energy and Commerce Committee's bill is scheduled for a vote on Friday, and the debate is expected to continue as the 2016 presidential election cycle approaches.

Title: House Speaker John A. Boehner Rules Out Immigration Negotiations with Senate, Setting Up Hurdles for Action

House Speaker John A. Boehner has ruled out entering into negotiations with the Senate on the immigration bill, effectively ending any hope of action on the issue this year. Boehner, an Ohio Republican, stated that the House will instead pursue a "common-sense, step-by-step approach" to address immigration, rejecting the Senate's comprehensive bill that would legalize most illegal immigrants and revamp the legal immigration system.

Boehner's remarks marked a significant shift from his previous stance, as he had expressed optimism about working with President Obama on the issue after the president's re-election last year. However, House Republicans have been divided on the issue, and Boehner has faced pressure from his colleagues to prioritize border security and enforcement over legalization.

The Senate bill, which passed with bipartisan support, would grant legal status to most illegal immigrants and revamp the legal immigration system. However, House Republicans have rejected this approach, instead opting to address immigration in smaller pieces, such as border security, interior enforcement, and guest-worker programs.

Despite the setback, immigrant rights supporters remain hopeful that the House will eventually come around to supporting a comprehensive approach. Senator Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat who wrote the Senate bill, believes that the House will eventually realize the need for a bipartisan solution.

The White House has also expressed disappointment with Boehner's decision, with Press Secretary Jay Carney stating that it is "a little bit late in the game." Immigrant rights advocates, however, are urging Boehner to reconsider, warning that his party risks alienating key voting groups if they do not take action on the issue.

The impasse has left the future of immigration reform uncertain, with some lawmakers predicting that the issue will not be addressed until after the midterm elections.

Title: Trump Imposes Tariffs on Brazil and Argentina, Citing Currency Manipulation

The Trump administration has announced tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from Brazil and Argentina, citing concerns over currency manipulation. This move marks a shift in Trump's rationale for tariffs, which he initially imposed in 2018. The tariffs are the latest in a series of unpredictable trade shocks from the White House, leaving business leaders seeking more certainty.

Brazil and Argentina are dealing with their own economic challenges, including a financial crisis in Argentina and a struggling currency in Brazil. According to the US Treasury Department, neither country is currently on the watch list for currency manipulation. The tariffs are seen as a surprise move, given the close relationship between the US and Brazil, with President Jair Bolsonaro having strengthened ties with the Trump administration.

The US-China trade spat has rattled the global economy, and Trump is still waging a trade battle with the EU. The tariffs on Brazil and Argentina add to the uncertainty, as the US heads into the 2020 election year.

The article also touches on the US-China trade talks, with investors betting on a partial deal soon. However, some experts warn that this may actually make a broader phase two agreement harder to achieve. The article also discusses the Medicare plans of Democratic presidential candidates, with Elizabeth Warren providing more detail on Medicare financing and taxes than her opponents.

Title: US Consumer Prices Rise by Most in Nearly Eight Years in June, But Inflation Remains Muted

The US consumer price index (CPI) increased by 0.6% in June, the largest gain since August 2012, according to the Labor Department. This marks the end of three consecutive months of declines. The rise was driven by increases in gasoline and food prices. In the 12 months through June, the CPI climbed 0.6%, the smallest year-on-year rise since September 2015.

Economists had forecast the CPI to increase 0.5% in June and 0.6% year-on-year. The reopening of businesses, which had shuttered in mid-March to slow the spread of COVID-19, contributed to the increase. However, new cases of the respiratory illness have surged in large parts of the country, prompting some states to dial back or pause reopenings.

The Federal Reserve is pumping money into the economy through extraordinary measures, including large-scale asset purchases and funneling loans to firms. The government has also provided nearly $3 trillion in fiscal stimulus, contributing to a record monthly budget deficit in June. Fears of inflation have been raised due to the unprecedented stimulus, but with a record 33 million people on unemployment benefits, economists expect inflation to remain benign.

Excluding food and energy components, the CPI rose 0.2% in June, after slipping 0.1% in May. Increases in apparel and healthcare costs were offset by a moderation in rental inflation. The core CPI, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, increased 1.2% in the 12 months through June, matching May's gain. The Fed tracks the core personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index for its 2% inflation target. The core PCE price index increased 1.0% on a year-on-year basis in May, the smallest advance since December 2010. June's core PCE price index data will be released at the end of this month.

**Multiple Explosions and Stabbings Rock East Coast**

A series of explosions and stabbings occurred on Saturday, September 18, 2016, in New Jersey, New York City, and Minnesota, leaving multiple people injured and one suspect dead.

In Seaside Park, New Jersey, an improvised explosive device (IED) detonated at a Marine Charity 5K event, but fortunately, no one was hurt. The FBI is investigating to determine if the incident was terrorism-related. Multiple explosive devices were found in a trash can, designed to send shrapnel flying, but only one detonated. Remnants and residue from the bomb are being sent to an FBI lab for analysis.

In New York City, a pipe bomb exploded in a Chelsea neighborhood, injuring an estimated 25 people but killing none. A possible secondary device was discovered, but its status is unclear. The NYPD is investigating the incident.

In St. Cloud, Minnesota, a stabbing attack occurred at a shopping mall, leaving multiple victims with stab wounds. The suspect, who was wearing a private security firm uniform, was shot and killed by an off-duty police officer. Authorities believe the attacker had prior contact with police through traffic stops only.

The events unfolded as follows: In Seaside Park, a trash can containing multiple explosive devices was discovered, and authorities believe the IED was designed to send shrapnel flying. The discovery of a backpack near a media tent led to a delay in the 5K event, potentially saving lives and avoiding injuries.

In New York City, a pipe bomb exploded in a Chelsea neighborhood, injuring an estimated 25 people but killing none. A possible secondary device was discovered, but its status is unclear.

In St. Cloud, Minnesota, a stabbing attack occurred at a shopping mall, leaving multiple victims with stab wounds. The suspect, who was wearing a private security firm uniform, was shot and killed by an off-duty police officer. Authorities believe the attacker had prior contact with police through traffic stops only.

The investigations are ongoing, and authorities are working to determine the motives behind the incidents.

Title: Hillary Clinton Refuses to Turn Over Email Server, Claims She Wiped It Clean

Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has declined to hand over her email server to an independent third party, stating that she has deleted all emails from the server. This decision has dealt a setback to the special investigative committee looking into the 2012 Benghazi terrorist attack.

According to Committee Chairman Trey Gowdy, the whole House will have to decide what the next steps are in the push to pry information from Mrs. Clinton. Gowdy expressed disappointment and frustration with Mrs. Clinton's decision, stating that she was the "sole arbiter of what was a public record" and that she "summarily decided to delete all emails from her server, ensuring no one could check behind her analysis in the public interest."

Gowdy also noted that Mrs. Clinton's response to the subpoena was to re-transmit several hundred pages of emails that the State Department had already turned over. Rep. Elijah E. Cummings, the top Democrat on the Benghazi probe, countered that Mrs. Clinton has already produced all of her official records concerning the terrorist attack and that it is time for the committee to stop the "political charade" and make the documents public and schedule Mrs. Clinton's public testimony.

Mrs. Clinton has maintained that she culled through over 60,000 emails from her time as secretary and decided about 30,000 of them were public records that should have been maintained. She stated that the rest were private messages relating to her daughter's wedding or her yoga class schedule, and she did not keep those. However, Gowdy's statement suggests that Mrs. Clinton's lawyers informed him that she "unilaterally decided to wipe her server clean and permanently delete all emails" from it.

The controversy surrounding Mrs. Clinton's email practices has put the Obama administration in a difficult position. Obama lawyers have admitted that for years, they were not correctly performing open-records searches because they did not have Mrs. Clinton's emails, but they are now unilaterally going back and doing those searches.

Title: Polish President Expresses Reservations Over Trump's Push to Rejoin Russia in G-7

Polish President Andrzej Duda expressed skepticism about President Donald Trump's proposal to reinstate Russia into the Group of Seven (G-7) during a news conference with Vice President Mike Pence in Warsaw, Poland. While Duda did not outright reject the idea, he emphasized the need to consider Russia's actions, particularly its occupation of Crimea.

Duda stated, "I believe we must not proceed according to the business-as-usual principle when it comes to Russia. This is my position, and I don't hesitate to express it." He also highlighted Russia's continued occupation of Crimea and other concerns, saying, "Russia, over the last years, has been undertaking actions which... nobody who wants to have peace in the world, and nobody who respects the dignity of other nations and states, can turn a blind eye to."

Pence, during his two-day visit to Poland, lauded the "remarkable bond" between the U.S. and Poland, emphasizing the importance of NATO allies remaining vigilant about countering Russia's intentions and actions. The two leaders discussed various issues, including Poland's plan to buy weaponry from the U.S., the U.S.'s plans to send an additional 1,000 troops to Poland, and the possible establishment of a permanent military base for U.S. troops in Poland.

The U.S. and Poland also signed a joint agreement to work together to improve the security of Poland's 5G telecommunications system, amid concerns over Chinese telecom giant Huawei's influence. When asked if Poland has any evidence of Chinese espionage, Duda stated that Polish counterintelligence services have detected actions "which might have been of an espionage nature."

The G-7 is a group of seven major economies, comprising the United States, Canada, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, Japan, and Italy. Russia was previously a member of the group, known as the G-8, but was ousted in 2014 over its annexation of Crimea.

Title: Appeals Court Sides with Obama Administration in Contraception Mandate Dispute

The 6th Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled in favor of the Obama administration, upholding the requirement for employers to provide contraception coverage as part of the Affordable Care Act. This decision marks the second time a federal appeals court has rejected a company's claim that the mandate violates their religious beliefs.

The ruling comes as a split decision, with a third court, the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals, having granted an injunction to Hobby Lobby, a craft store chain, allowing it to opt out of the mandate until its case can be heard. The split decisions are likely to lead to a Supreme Court review.

The 6th Circuit Court, seated in Cincinnati, ruled that Autocam, a Michigan-based manufacturing company, must comply with the mandate, despite its owners' Roman Catholic beliefs. The Kennedy family, who own Autocam, had argued that the mandate would force them to choose between violating their beliefs, dropping employee health coverage, or facing massive fines.

The Obama administration's rule requires employers to provide coverage for contraception, which supporters argue is widespread but often unaffordable for many women. Opponents, including conservative lawmakers and religious groups, have lobbied for a religious exemption, citing objections to morning-after pills they equate with abortion.

The 6th Circuit panel agreed with government lawyers that Autocam had not demonstrated a strong likelihood of success on the merits of its case. The judges noted that the Kennedy family's actions were taken in their capacity as officers and directors of the corporation, rather than as individuals.

The decision tracker at the Becket Fund for Religious Liberty shows that 29 companies have secured an injunction against the mandate at the district or circuit court level, while five firms, including Conestoga Wood Specialties and Autocam, have been denied relief.

The Obama administration has until September 25 to decide whether to ask the Supreme Court to take up the Hobby Lobby case. The Becket Fund's Kyle Duncan said he does not expect the administration to acquiesce in the face of the split decisions.

Title: House Republicans Express Frustration Over Senate's Failure to Pass Health Care Repeal Bill

The House Republican leadership expressed disappointment and frustration on Friday after the Senate failed to pass its health care repeal bill earlier in the morning. The bill, which aimed to repeal or delay some of Obamacare's mandates and taxes, was voted down on a 49-51 vote, with three Republican senators joining Democrats to block the legislation.

House Republicans, including Rep. Morgan Griffith of Virginia, criticized the Senate for not following through on its promises to "save" Americans from Obamacare. "The Senate's got to do the Senate thing," Griffith said, referring to the House's passage of a health care bill in May. "The Senate needs to decide whether they can do anything. If the Senate is incapable of functioning, then the House will have to once again step up to the plate and figure out what we're going to do."

Rep. Diane Black, chair of the House Budget Committee, accused the Senate of breaking its promise to the American people. "The Senate's failure to even continue the legislative process is a slap in the face to the voters that trusted and elected them. They deserve better," she said.

House Speaker Paul D. Ryan expressed disappointment and frustration, but urged lawmakers not to give up. "While the House delivered a bill to repeal and replace Obamacare, unfortunately, the Senate was unable to reach a consensus," he said in a statement.

Rep. Trent Franks, an Arizona Republican, warned that the parliamentary rules of the Senate make it difficult to pass significant legislation. "We're in a situation here where the parliamentary physics of the existing Senate rule construct makes doing things almost impossible if they're of consequence," he said.

Title: Domestic Terrorists Occupy Federal Building in Oregon: A Call for a Calm and Strategic Response

The occupation of a federal building in Oregon by heavily armed protesters, led by Ammon Bundy, has sparked concerns about domestic terrorism. CNN National Security Analyst Juliette Kayyem, a professor at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government and former assistant secretary in the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, argues that this group is, by any definition, domestic terrorists.

Kayyem emphasizes that the group's claims of being a peaceful militia or lawful group are unfounded, as they are using violence and intimidation to achieve their goals. She notes that their cause is difficult to decipher, but it appears to be related to the imprisonment of a rancher who refused to sell his land to the government.

Kayyem suggests that the federal response should prioritize avoiding violence and instead use a strategy of "divide and conquer" to separate the group and offer incentives for them to disarm and surrender. She also recommends that federal authorities remind those inside that they will be considered accomplices to murder if anyone is harmed or killed during the standoff.

The article highlights the importance of not turning the protesters into martyrs or heroes through excessive force or unnecessary violence. Kayyem also notes that the situation is different from the 1993 Waco siege, where a 51-day standoff ended in tragedy after the FBI mounted an assault, and emphasizes that time is on the side of the federal authorities.

Overall, Kayyem's commentary provides a nuanced and informed analysis of the situation, emphasizing the need for a calm and strategic response to address the domestic terrorism threat posed by the occupation.

Title: Democrats and Republicans Disagree on Giuliani's Ukraine Meetings

The impeachment trial has revealed a discrepancy between Democratic and Republican officials regarding the involvement of former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani and his associate, Lev Parnas, in the Ukraine pressure campaign. A Democratic official acknowledged that the initial interpretation of a document was incorrect, but maintained that "z" was commonly used as shorthand for "Zelensky" among those involved in the campaign. The official noted that the document does not reveal its author or source.

The official also emphasized that there is no question that Giuliani and Parnas sought high-level engagement with President Zelensky and his administration. The official stated that Giuliani and Parnas actively sought high-level engagement with Zelensky's administration to carry out the President's corrupt scheme, and that if Giuliani sought out dirt from other sources, it would be consistent with their overall effort.

The article highlights that there are numerous examples of Giuliani attempting to arrange meetings with Zelensky, and he did meet with top aides to the Ukrainian president. However, Parnas' role in the matter remains unclear. Democrats have not predicated their impeachment trial arguments on Parnas' new allegations, making limited references to the former Giuliani associate in their brief.

A Republican aide criticized the assumption that "mr Z" refers to Zelensky, calling it "sloppy oversight work at best." The aide suggested that the Democratic staff may have committed "Congressional malpractice" by not thoroughly investigating the facts before presenting the information to their colleagues and the public. The aide also questioned the selective redactions and contextual clues, implying that Chairman Schiff may have intentionally portrayed an innocuous meeting with Ukrainian oligarch Mykola Zlochevsky as an insidious one with the President of Ukraine simply because both surnames start with the letter Z.

Title: U.S. Army Sergeant Bowe Bergdahl Charged with Desertion and Misbehavior

The U.S. Army has formally charged Sergeant Bowe Bergdahl, a former Taliban prisoner in Afghanistan, with desertion and misbehavior before the enemy. Bergdahl, 28, could face a maximum sentence of life in prison if convicted of the most serious count. The Army announced the charges on Wednesday, stating that Bergdahl was charged with desertion with intent to shirk important or hazardous duty and misbehavior before the enemy by endangering the safety of a command, unit, or place.

The charges stem from Bergdahl's disappearance from his post in Afghanistan in 2009 and his subsequent capture by the Taliban. He was released in a prisoner swap last summer, along with five Taliban prisoners held at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, who were transferred to Qatar.

The Army has scheduled an Article 32 investigation hearing on April 22 to determine whether there is sufficient evidence to proceed with a court-martial. The investigation will take place at Fort Sam Houston in San Antonio, Texas.

Bergdahl's attorney, Eugene Fidell of Yale Law School, stated that the Army had scheduled the investigation, similar to a civilian grand jury proceeding. The investigation will examine the circumstances surrounding Bergdahl's disappearance and capture.

Some of Bergdahl's former Army comrades have spoken out against him, stating that he deserted his post and put their lives in danger. Former Army Sergeant Evan Buetow, who served with Bergdahl, said that Bergdahl needed to answer for what he did. "He put all of our lives in danger," Buetow said. "Men from our company died, when I don't believe they would have if he wouldn't have left."

Republican lawmakers have also backed the Army's decision to move ahead with the charges. Senator John McCain, head of the Senate Armed Services Committee, called it an "important step" towards determining Bergdahl's accountability. Representative Mac Thornberry, head of the House Armed Services Committee, accused the administration of making the case more difficult by failing to follow the law surrounding the release of the Taliban 5.

Bergdahl's case has been under review by General Mark Milley, head of U.S. Army Forces Command, who was asked to look at the circumstances surrounding Bergdahl's capture. As a result of the review, Bergdahl was charged with desertion with intent to shirk important or hazardous duty and misbehavior before the enemy by endangering the safety of a command, unit, or place.

The desertion charge carries a maximum prison term of five years, while the misbehavior count carries a maximum term of life in prison. The charges also carry a number of other potential punishments, including a dishonorable discharge, reduction in rank to private, and forfeiture of all pay.

Bergdahl's parents declined to comment on the Army's decision to charge their son. Some residents in his hometown of Hailey, Idaho, also expressed reluctance to comment on the developments, citing anger and frustration at the community that showed support for him following his release.

Title: Ben Carson Threatens to Leave Republican Party Over Allegations of Manipulation

Ben Carson, a presidential hopeful and retired neurosurgeon, has threatened to leave the Republican Party after reports emerged of a closed-door meeting between Republican establishment leaders discussing the possibility of a "brokered national convention" if no clear winner emerges in the party's primary election season. The meeting, which included Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, allegedly discussed the possibility of a brokered convention if the party's nominee is not determined through the regular primary process.

In a statement, Carson expressed his concerns about the reports, stating that if the allegations are true, he would not stand for it and would consider leaving the party. He referenced Donald Trump's repeated threats to leave the GOP if treated "unfairly," saying that if the reports are correct, every voter who is seeking change would be betrayed.

The Republican National Committee did not immediately respond to questions about the meeting and Carson's threat. A third-party run by Carson or Trump would be a nightmare scenario for the GOP, as it could siphon votes away from the party's nominee and make it difficult for them to win the general election.

Carson's spokesman, Doug Watts, acknowledged that Carson signed a pledge not to launch a third-party bid, but emphasized that the pledge is not meaningless. Watts stated that Carson signed the pledge based on everyone playing by the rules, implying that the reports of manipulation and attempts to subvert the will of the voters are unacceptable.

Title: The Blurred Lines Between Government and Personal Freedom

The recent celebrations in China honoring President Xi Jinping's words, complete with street-side banners, billboards, and song-and-dance routines, raise questions about the balance between government and personal freedom. In the United States, a similar debate is unfolding in the context of the Supreme Court's decision on a Colorado baker's refusal to create a cake for a gay couple.

The court's decision will likely be closely watched, with some arguing that the baker's religious beliefs should be respected, while others believe that the government has a responsibility to protect the rights of marginalized groups. However, the larger question remains: where is the stopping point for the promotion and enforcement of views backed by government power rather than popular consensus?

In China, the government's power is seen as limitless, with the party's views being enforced without question. In the United States, the concept of consent of the governed has long been a cornerstone of democracy. However, the line between government and personal freedom can become blurred when government attempts to impose conformity in the name of a "beneficial" cause.

A historical example of this is the busing for racial balance, which was intended to promote racial integration in schools. However, the program ultimately led to widespread resistance and segregation, as students and parents refused to comply with the court-ordered assignments. Similarly, government attempts to silence or impede doubters on issues like gay marriage could have similar negative effects, stifling attempts at reconciliation and perpetuating a culture of non-think.

The "American way of life" is often touted as a beacon of freedom and individuality, but the reality is that government has often played a significant role in shaping public opinion and behavior. As the author notes, there is room in this great tent for freedom from unnecessary molding of thought and behavior by government, but the line between government and personal freedom can become blurred when government attempts to impose its will on the population.

Ultimately, the question remains: where is the stopping point for the promotion and enforcement of views backed by government power rather than popular consensus?

Title: Social Media Companies Allow Chinese Communist Party Propaganda to Circulate with Little Oversight

A congressional investigation has found that the largest social media companies, Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube, are allowing the Chinese Communist Party to disseminate propaganda to American audiences with little oversight or warning. The investigation, led by House Foreign Affairs Committee leader Rep. Michael McCaul (R-Texas), has been pressing these companies to deplatform Chinese Communist Party officials and news outlets for disseminating propaganda, particularly related to the coronavirus pandemic.

The report card-style investigation graded each company on whether it has banned communist officials and news outlets, applied warning labels to their content, and fact-checked their claims for accuracy. Twitter received a D-, Facebook a C+, and YouTube a C-, indicating that all three companies still permit the dissemination of anti-U.S. communist propaganda, often without warning labels for readers.

The investigation found that Twitter emerged as the most abused platform, with the company not removing any of the propaganda posts identified by congressional investigators. Twitter's lack of oversight allows Chinese Communist Party officials to operate as verified users, providing legitimacy to their claims. The report also noted that Twitter does not equally apply its rules, as prominent conservatives, including President Donald Trump, have had their content censored or removed in recent months.

Facebook allows several Chinese state-controlled propaganda organs to freely post misinformation, potentially reaching millions of Americans. While Facebook received a higher grade than Twitter, it still permits these outlets to post content on its site without taking sufficient action to prevent the spread of propaganda.

YouTube demonstrated similar failures, not blocking communist officials and news outlets or removing their materials. While YouTube does attempt to fact-check and police this content for inaccuracies, it often fails to label CCP content as propaganda and does not provide viewers with complete information about the biased nature of these videos.

The investigation highlights the need for social media companies to take a more proactive approach in policing communist propaganda and ensuring transparency about the nature and operations of CCP propaganda outlets.

Title: North Carolina Governor Signs Controversial Election Law Reform

North Carolina Governor Pat McCrory signed into law on Monday a measure that overhauls the state's election laws. The new law requires government-issued photo IDs at the polls, reduces the early voting period by one week, and ends same-day registration. McCrory, a Republican, described the changes as "common sense reforms" aimed at ensuring the "integrity" of the voting process.

In a 95-second YouTube video, McCrory explained that photo ID has become a part of everyday life and reminded residents that they can obtain a free photo ID at local Department of Motor Vehicle offices throughout the state. He also stated that the photo ID requirement will not be enforced until the 2016 elections.

Democrats and minority groups have criticized the new law, claiming it will suppress voting and make it harder for certain groups, such as minorities, the elderly, and youth, to cast ballots. The American Civil Liberties Union and other civil rights groups have vowed to challenge the changes.

The North Carolina chapter of the NAACP has filed a legal challenge to the measure, with Reverend William Barber, its president, calling the law a "trampling on the blood, sweat, and tears of the martyrs – black and white – who fought for voting rights in this country." The NAACP believes the law puts Governor McCrory "on the wrong side of history."

The signing of the bill comes just weeks after the U.S. Supreme Court struck down a section of the Voting Rights Act that required North Carolina and other states to obtain approval from the federal government before changing their election laws. The Justice Department is currently fighting a similar law in Texas and may file a lawsuit against the North Carolina measure.

Title: Turkey's President Erdogan Threatens Europe with Refugee Influx over Syria Invasion Label

Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has issued a warning to European leaders, stating that if they label Turkey's military operation in northern Syria as an "occupation," he will open the borders and allow 3.6 million refugees to enter the continent. This threat was made during a speech to officials from his ruling AK Party, according to Reuters.

The Turkish military operation, which began on Wednesday, involves airstrikes and artillery fire targeting U.S.-allied Kurdish forces on the ground. The operation started just days after U.S. President Donald Trump announced the withdrawal of U.S. troops from a part of Syria that had been reclaimed from the Islamic State (IS). Trump framed his decision as one that would hand the responsibility of containing IS to Turkey.

The ground fighting against IS, which began in 2014, was spearheaded by Kurdish forces that made up the bulk of the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), a U.S.-backed organization tasked with governance of the area and containment of resurgent IS fighters and overcrowded IS prisons. Turkey has refused to help the Kurdish forces in the fight against IS, viewing them as allies to dissident Kurds in Turkey.

Erdogan has pledged to clear the area of "terrorists" and says his aim is to allow a path for Syrian refugees in Turkey to return home. However, numerous U.S. officials have cast doubt on this promise. Ankara has long vowed to wipe out the Kurdish militia presence along its border in northern Syria, which it views as a security threat and indistinguishable from a separate Kurdish terrorist group that is waging a counterinsurgency inside Turkey.

Title: A Cautious Optimism: A Non-Partisan Perspective on Trump's Presidency

The article presents a personal account of the author's initial reservations about Donald Trump's candidacy and their subsequent surprise and excitement upon his election. The author notes that Trump's victory brought about a significant shift in the balance of power in state capitals, with Republicans gaining control of more governorships and state legislatures than in decades.

The author expresses gratitude for Trump's respect for law enforcement and the military, as well as his appointments to the Supreme Court and other key positions. They also acknowledge the concerns about Trump's temperament and character, but are cautiously optimistic about his conservative appointments and actions.

The article also touches on the author's surprise at the hypocrisy on the left, citing the lack of outrage over Bill Clinton's alleged misconduct and the selective outrage towards Trump's past comments and allegations. The author emphasizes the importance of holding Trump accountable, but also notes that accountability should be fair and proportionate.

Overall, the article presents a nuanced and non-partisan perspective on Trump's presidency, highlighting both the author's concerns and their cautious optimism.

Title: Washington Post Suspends Reporter Felicia Sonmez Over Kobe Bryant Tweets, Raising Questions About Editorial Judgment

The Washington Post suspended national political reporter Felicia Sonmez on Monday, citing her tweets about Kobe Bryant's death. Sonmez had shared a 2016 Daily Beast article detailing allegations of sexual assault against Bryant, which sparked a wave of criticism and abuse on social media. In response, Sonmez posted a screenshot of her email inbox, showing a message from a reader who used profanity and made personal attacks.

According to Erik Wemple, the Post's media critic, Sonmez was placed on administrative leave after being told to delete her tweets. Wemple described the suspension as "misguided," questioning what Sonmez did to deserve it. The Post's managing editor, Tracy Grant, stated that Sonmez's tweets displayed "poor judgment that undermined the work of her colleagues," but did not provide further explanation.

The Post's social media policy does not appear to have been violated, and it is unclear how Sonmez's tweets undermined her colleagues' work. The article in question was well-reported and accurate, and Sonmez had simply shared it. The journalist Matthew Keys reported that Sonmez was suspended because she revealed the full names of those who had written her, but Sonmez denied hearing this explanation from the Post. Instead, she was doxxed, with her address being posted online, prompting her to check into a hotel for safety reasons.

The Post's decision to suspend Sonmez has sparked controversy, with many questioning the editorial judgment behind the move. The incident highlights the challenges faced by journalists in sharing important information and the need for a nuanced understanding of the complexities of reporting on public figures.

Title: Senate Democrats Criticize Trump Administration's Handling of 3D-Printed Guns

The Senate Democratic leadership has expressed strong criticism towards the Trump administration's decision to allow a Texas company, Defense Distributed, to post blueprints for 3D-printed guns online. Senators Ed Markey and Richard Blumenthal, both Democrats, have stated that President Trump will be "totally responsible" and will have "blood on his hands" if the administration does not take immediate action to block the posting of the blueprints.

The controversy surrounds the company's decision to post downloadable blueprints for AR-15-style firearms, which can be printed at home using 3D printers. The company, Defense Distributed, had previously been blocked from posting the blueprints due to a legal battle that spanned both the Obama and Trump administrations. The company and its founder, Cody Wilson, argue that their right to post the blueprints falls under constitutionally-protected free speech.

Senator Markey and other congressional Democrats are pushing legislation to block the company from posting the blueprints online, citing concerns that the untraceable and unregulated guns will end up on the streets and contribute to gun violence. The proposed legislation would also ban "untraceable" guns that do not have serial numbers or metal parts.

President Trump has tweeted that he is looking into the issue and has spoken to the National Rifle Association (NRA) about it. However, Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer has predicted that nothing will come of the administration's efforts, calling it "a dollar short and a day late." House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi has also criticized the decision, stating that it is a "death warrant for countless innocent men, women, and children."

The debate surrounding 3D-printed guns has sparked a wave of legal action, with the State Department and the company agreeing to a settlement last month allowing the company to post the blueprints once again. The issue is expected to continue to be a contentious topic in the coming weeks and months.

Title: Health Insurance Exchanges Face Criticism for Lack of Quality Ratings

The Affordable Care Act requires health insurance exchanges to provide consumer ratings for health plans, allowing shoppers to compare treatment outcomes, service, and consumer satisfaction. However, many states have not published these ratings, sparking controversy and criticism from health care providers and analysts. The National Council on Quality Assurance (NCQA) rates almost every health plan nationwide on treatment, prevention, and customer service, with scores ranging from 1 to 5. Eighty percent of insurers are rated by the NCQA, but only eight states post these ratings. The remaining 34 state health care exchanges managed by the federal government do not.

Some states, such as Colorado, Minnesota, and Oregon, do post ratings, with Oregon's website listing quality scores next to price, allowing for an apples-to-apples comparison. Western Health Advantage CEO Garry Maisel argues that consumers deserve to know the difference between plans with established quality ratings and those without. "Consumers deserve to know what is unrated versus what has been around a long time and has a good quality rating," Maisel said.

Health care analyst Betsy McCaughey emphasizes the importance of having this information, stating, "To make a smart choice, we need more information, that is why this rating system is so important. Otherwise, choosing a plan on these exchanges is just a shot in the dark." The controversy arose in California, where Western Health Advantage and two other highly rated providers complained that the state failed to post their ratings due to opposition from lower-rated plans.

The Affordable Care Act requires health care exchanges to display quality-of-care data by 2016. Until then, consumers may be left without the information they need to make informed decisions about their health insurance plans.

Title: Fox News Host Tucker Carlson Questions Double Standard in Handling of Vandalism and Destruction

Article:

Fox News host Tucker Carlson opened his Tuesday program by questioning the double standard applied to the "mob" responsible for vandalism and destruction of private and public property. Carlson pointed out that the Department of Justice and FBI investigated the alleged "hate crime" at the Talladega Superspeedway in Alabama, but failed to take similar action against similar incidents committed by the mob.

Carlson argued that the apparent conclusion was that the "mob" was an arm of the Democratic Party's establishment. He cited six high-profile "hate crimes" involving nooses between 2015 and 2018, which were heavily promoted by the media but ultimately turned out to be hoaxes.

The host also referenced the recent incident involving NASCAR driver Bubba Wallace, where the FBI sent 15 agents to investigate a supposed hate crime, but ultimately found no evidence of a hate crime. Carlson noted that this incident was part of a larger pattern of the FBI and federal prosecutors being duped by hoaxes.

Carlson also drew parallels between the treatment of NASCAR driver Bubba Wallace and the lack of action taken against the mob that destroyed a statue of American patriot Francis Scott Key in San Francisco, with the words "Kill the colonizers. Kill whitey" spray-painted on the pedestal. He argued that this incident would qualify as a hate crime, but the FBI did not investigate.

The host also pointed out that Democratic politicians, such as Philadelphia Mayor Jim Kenney and District Attorney Larry Krasner, have cheered on mobs that have destroyed public property, while working-class citizens who tried to protect a statue of Christopher Columbus were threatened with prosecution. Carlson concluded that the mob operates with the permission of the Democratic establishment and is their foot soldiers.

Title: Justice Department Sues Ferguson Over Troubled Police and Court Operations

The United States Justice Department has filed a lawsuit against the city of Ferguson, Missouri, seeking to force the city to overhaul its troubled police and court operations. The decision comes after city leaders rejected a long-negotiated settlement, citing prohibitive costs of implementation.

According to Attorney General Loretta Lynch, the city's refusal to accept the agreement leaves the Justice Department with no choice but to take legal action. Lynch stated that the residents of Ferguson have been waiting "decades for justice" and have endured civil rights breaches that established a pattern and practice of racially biased policing.

The Justice Department's lawsuit alleges that local law enforcement conduct has routinely violated the Constitution, and that the city's police department has failed to adopt reforms to ensure the rights of its citizens. The city's refusal to accept the agreement has left the Justice Department with no choice but to take legal action.

Ferguson Mayor James Knowles defended the city's decision to revise the agreement, citing concerns over the costs of implementation. Knowles stated that the city is willing to take on the Justice Department in federal court and is waiting for the department to take legal action.

The controversy surrounding the agreement stems from the city's concerns over the costs of implementing the reforms, which could total nearly $10 million over the next three years. The city's budget is approximately $14 million, and it is facing about $2.8 million in debt after the August 2014 police shooting death of an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown.

The Justice Department's investigation found that the city's police and municipal court unfairly targeted African-American residents, who make up about 70% of the population. The city's troubles and similar problems in cities across the country have prompted a national discussion on police tactics and the appointment of a special White House panel, which urged the adoption of new strategies to rebuild trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve.

The city's decision to reject the agreement has sparked a heated debate, with some residents urging the City Council to reject the deal and take their chances in court, while others favored the agreement as a way for the city to regain the trust of the African-American community.

The Justice Department's lawsuit seeks to force the city to adopt reforms to ensure the rights of its citizens and to prevent further violations of the Constitution. The city's refusal to accept the agreement has left the Justice Department with no choice but to take legal action, and the case is now headed to federal court.

Title: Lessons from the Afghanistan Withdrawal: The Importance of Clear Communication and Realistic Expectations

The recent agreement between the United States and the Taliban to reduce violence for seven days has raised questions about the effectiveness of the deal and the future of the war in Afghanistan. While the agreement may not be perfect, it is essential for negotiators to learn from this experience and apply the lessons to future negotiations.

One key takeaway is the importance of explicit language in treaties. The United States should have been more explicit about the duration of the violence reduction period, as any extension would have been expected. Additionally, the prisoner exchange should have been negotiated with the consent of the Afghan government, which holds the Taliban prisoners.

The prisoner swap issue is a significant concern, as the Taliban has long requested a large prisoner release before talks. The Trump administration should have anticipated this and done more to manage the situation beforehand. Afghanistan is still a challenging country to govern and conquer, and the United States has been struggling to articulate its mission in the country.

President Trump has made it clear that he wants to end American involvement in the war, and it is time to acknowledge that the country has run out of good reasons to continue fighting. The politics of the moment should not obscure the fact that ending American involvement is the right decision.

It is worth noting that the Trump administration has achieved what previous administrations were unable or unwilling to do in their first term. However, the deal may not be good enough to prevent the Taliban from dominating the country again. Nonetheless, it is essential to recognize that nothing was ever likely to be good enough to achieve this goal.

In conclusion, the recent agreement between the United States and the Taliban serves as a lesson for negotiators to be more explicit in their language and to have realistic expectations. The United States has run out of good reasons to continue fighting in Afghanistan, and it is time to acknowledge that it is time to leave.

**Deadly Shooting at Annapolis Newspaper Office**

A shooting occurred at the Capital Gazette newspaper office in Annapolis, Maryland, on Thursday, resulting in the deaths of at least five people. The suspect, identified as Jarrod Ramos, 38, of Laurel, allegedly fired through a glass door and sprayed the newsroom with gunfire, killing five people, including assistant editor Rob Hiaasen, 59, and journalists Wendi Winters, 65, Rebecca Smith, 34, Gerald Fischman, 61, and John McNamara. The victims were all employees of the Capital Gazette.

According to Acting Police Chief William Krampf, the shooting was a targeted attack on the newspaper, and the suspect was prepared to cause harm. The motive behind the attack is still unclear.

Ramos had a history of harassment and defamation lawsuits against the newspaper and its employees, including a 2012 lawsuit against former staff writer and columnist Eric Hartley and editor and publisher Thomas Marquardt. In 2015, a Maryland court upheld a ruling in favor of the Capital Gazette and a former reporter who were accused by Ramos of defamation.

The shooting has sent shockwaves through the media community, with many outlets deploying extra security measures as a precaution. The White House has also been briefed on the incident, with President Donald Trump offering condolences to the victims and their families.

The Capital Gazette, which has been in operation since 1727, is part of the Tronc Inc media group and publishes newspapers in and around Annapolis. The shooting has left the community in shock, with many expressing their condolences and solidarity with the victims and their families.

Title: Mitt Romney Calls for Comprehensive Strategy to Eradicate Islamic State, Stem Refugee Flow

Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, has written a commentary in The Washington Post calling for the West to take a more decisive approach to combating the Islamic State (ISIS) and to stem the flow of refugees from the Middle East.
