Romney argues that the current strategy of airstrikes alone is insufficient and that the United States must lead a comprehensive war effort to defeat the enemy.

According to Romney, the Islamic State is a "cancer that metastasized" on President Barack Obama's watch, and the president must take a more proactive approach to defeating the group. He suggests that the president should consult with military leaders and develop a comprehensive strategy that integrates efforts with allies in the region, including the Kurds, Turks, Saudis, Egyptians, and Jordanians.

Romney also emphasizes the need to stem the flow of refugees from the Middle East, particularly young men, who he believes pose a significant security risk. He argues that the West must stop accepting refugees without proper vetting, citing the recent discovery of a Syrian passport near the body of one of the Paris attackers.

Romney believes that the United States must take a leadership role in the fight against ISIS, and that this requires being willing to devote whatever resources are necessary to win, including boots on the ground. He criticizes President Obama's assertion that the advance of the jihadists had been "contained," calling it "clearly proven wrong."

Romney also emphasizes the importance of identifying the enemy and acknowledging that radical Islamists are responsible for the heinous acts of terror. He notes that the broader Islamic world will play a critical role in this war, as the enemy lives within Islam.

Title: Democrats Consider Trading Hunter Biden for John Bolton in Impeachment Trial

Article:

The impeachment trial of President Trump has reached a new level of complexity, with Democrats considering a potential trade-off: calling Hunter Biden, the son of former Vice President Joe Biden, as a witness in exchange for John Bolton, the former National Security Adviser, to testify. According to a recent Washington Post report, Democrats believe that having either Hunter or Joe Biden testify could "backfire" on Trump and the GOP, giving the Bidens a platform to paint Republicans and the White House as obsessed with damaging one of Trump's 2020 presidential rivals.

However, experts argue that this move would be a strategic mistake. Despite good intentions, Democrats have not been able to do much to hurt Trump, and he has consistently found ways to survive and even thrive. Moreover, the Bidens are likely to be damaged in the process, with Hunter facing public scrutiny over his role on the board of a Ukrainian energy company and Joe facing criticism over his son's appointment.

Furthermore, public polling suggests that Americans are unsympathetic to Hunter's role in Burisma, with a majority believing it was a bad judgment and half believing he should return the money he earned while there. Additionally, there are concerns that putting Joe Biden on the stand could lead to embarrassing revelations about his own personal scandals.

Sen. Chris Coons, a Biden supporter, has even goaded Republicans into calling Joe Biden as a witness, saying he would be comfortable answering questions about the president's actions. However, this could backfire, as Biden would be sitting across from four of his current Democratic opponents who have their own reasons to criticize him.

The bigger question is what Democrats would gain from this move. Public sentiment about impeachment is largely cemented, and John Bolton is likely to corroborate what we already know: that Trump used his office for personal gain. The truth is, no matter how skillfully Democrats try to protect the Bidens, there's only so much they can do to keep them from being damaged in the process.

Title: California Voters Overwhelmingly Approve Changes to Three-Strikes Law, Reject Death Penalty Abolition

California voters have approved a ballot initiative to alter the state's controversial three-strikes law, which could lead to sentence reductions for thousands of prisoners. The measure, which eliminates the mandatory 25 years-to-life sentence for a third felony, if that crime is nonviolent, is expected to benefit around 3,000 inmates. The revision aims to reduce the state's prison population and alleviate the burden on the criminal justice system.

On the other hand, voters rejected Proposition 34, which would have abolished the death penalty in California. The proposition would have replaced capital punishment with life imprisonment without the possibility of parole. Mark Klass, the father of a 12-year-old girl who was brutally murdered in 1993, expressed relief that the man convicted of the crime will remain on death row. Klass believes that the worst offenders, such as serial killers and mass murderers, should face the death penalty.

The vote to revise the three-strikes law is seen as a significant shift in California's criminal justice system. The state's original three-strikes law, adopted in 1994, was designed to punish repeat offenders with long prison sentences. However, critics argue that it has led to overcrowding and wasted resources. Los Angeles District Attorney Steve Cooley believes that the revised law will still hold repeat offenders accountable, but with more proportionate sentencing.

The vote to revise the three-strikes law is also seen as a trend that may spread to other states. Adam Gelb, director of the Public Safety Performance Project at the Pew Center on the States, believes that California's decision to scale back its three-strikes law will resonate across the country. Gelb notes that California helped start the three-strikes trend, and its decision to revise the law may prompt other states to reevaluate their own policies.

Former Los Angeles District Attorney Gil Garcetti, who joined the ACLU and a former head warden of San Quentin prison to try to abolish the death penalty, believes that the vote shows that Californians are increasingly opposed to the death penalty. Garcetti notes that the state has spent $4 billion to house death row inmates and pay for their appeals, and that the vote is a sign that the state is moving away from capital punishment.

Title: Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel to Step Down, Successor to be Named

The White House confirmed on Monday that Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel will be resigning from his position. The announcement was made by President Obama, who accepted Hagel's resignation on Monday morning. According to a senior administration official, Hagel has been a "steady hand" during his nearly two-year tenure, guiding the military through a period of transition and responding to various challenges, including the Islamic State and Ebola.

Hagel's resignation was reportedly discussed with the President in October, and he submitted his resignation on Monday morning. The official stated that a successor will be named "in short order," and Hagel will remain in his post until then.

The White House official also noted that the President and Hagel determined it was time for new leadership in the Pentagon. Hagel's resignation comes as the Obama administration faces a range of issues, including the ongoing military campaign against the Islamic State terrorist group.

Potential replacements for Hagel include Michele Flournoy, the former under secretary of defense; Sen. Jack Reed, a Democrat from Rhode Island and a former Army officer; and Ashton B. Carter, a former deputy secretary of defense.

Title: The Rise of ISIS: A Complex and Multifaceted Issue

The rise of the Islamic State (ISIS) is a complex and multifaceted issue that cannot be attributed to a single individual or event. Peter Bergen, a national security analyst and author of the forthcoming book "United States of Jihad: Investigating America's Homegrown Terrorists," argues that Trump's charge that Hillary Clinton's actions led to the rise of ISIS does not hold water. Clinton left the State Department in January 2013, while ISIS was not founded until three months later.

The roots of ISIS can be traced back to Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, a Jordanian thug who founded al-Qaeda in Iraq. Zarqawi's tactics and policies, including televised beheadings and igniting a civil war against the Shiites, remain at the core of ISIS. The opportunity for Zarqawi to create al-Qaeda in Iraq was provided by George W. Bush's decision to invade Iraq in 2003, which removed Saddam Hussein's brutal regime and allowed al-Qaeda to gain a foothold.

The group grew in strength in 2006, controlling much of the Anbar province in western Iraq. However, by 2008, U.S. troops, led by General David Petraeus, had largely extirpated al-Qaeda from Iraq through an alliance with Sunni tribesmen. The group's resurgence can be attributed to four key factors: the Syrian civil war, the role of former Iraqi officers, the feckless rule of Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki, and the hollowing out of the Iraqi army.

The Obama administration's withdrawal of U.S. troops from Iraq in 2011 did not create ISIS, but rather provided an opportunity for the group to regroup and reorganize. The administration was slow to recognize the threat posed by ISIS, famously referring to the group as a "JV team" in a January 2014 interview. Since then, the Obama administration has mounted an aggressive campaign against ISIS from the air, but has been reluctant to do much on the ground.

While more could be done to combat ISIS, it is essential to recognize that the issue is complex and multifaceted, and cannot be attributed to a single individual or event. Rather than making unsubstantiated claims, it would be more productive for policymakers to advance real policy ideas about how to solve the Syrian and Iraqi civil wars.

Title: Trump's Tax-Cut Proposals Spark Debate on Fiscal Discipline

The Trump administration's new tax-cut proposals have raised questions about the country's fiscal discipline, with some experts warning that the plan could lead to increased government debt and deficits. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has outlined goals and principles for the plan, which includes slashing corporate tax rates from 35% to 15% and cutting individual taxes. While the plan is not yet detailed, it has sparked a larger debate about the country's fiscal priorities.

Many fiscal-policy experts argue that politicians and economists are no longer focused on restraining government debt and deficits, as they were in the past. This shift is attributed to the 2000s, when politicians like George W. Bush pushed for big tax cuts despite warnings from nonpartisan forecasts of widening deficits.

Despite the shift, some lawmakers are still committed to fiscal discipline. Roberton Williams, an expert at the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center, notes that the economy is doing reasonably well, but the country has not yet figured out how to get back on a balanced track during good times. He draws a metaphor from states, which have created rainy-day funds to cushion against recession.

The article also highlights the importance of fiscal discipline, citing the dangers of too much debt, which can lead to higher interest rates or financial panic over default risks. However, many economists and ordinary Americans agree that the time is ripe for simplifying the tax system and seeking to make it promote greater economic growth and fairness.

The Trump administration's proposal includes paring the number of individual tax brackets to three, giving businesses a "massive" tax cut, and eliminating the estate tax. While voters rarely complain about a cut in their taxes, some 61% of respondents in a recent Gallup poll called what they owe "fair." Two-thirds say businesses pay too little in taxes, not too much.

The legislative outlook is uncertain, but some experts are hopeful that forces of fiscal restraint can revive. Bill White, a former Houston mayor, notes that the fiscal tradition in America recognized the link between decisions on spending and taxes, and that conservatives believed having a visible price tag (taxes) would help put a check on public spending.

Title: Tillerson Hails "Historic Moment" in US-Saudi Relations Amid Arms Sales and Investment Deals

Article:

Secretary of State Rex Tillerson hailed a "historic moment" in US-Saudi relations during a joint address with Saudi Arabian Foreign Minister Adel bin Ahmed Al-Jubeir in Riyadh on Saturday. The occasion marked President Donald Trump's first trip abroad as commander-in-chief, accompanied by a significant announcement of $109 billion in arms sales to Saudi Arabia and $350 billion in direct US investment over 10 years.

Tillerson emphasized the importance of strategic and economic partnerships between the two nations, citing multiple potential threats facing both countries. He referenced the development of a new center for combating extremist ideology, to be based in Riyadh, and the need to defeat ISIS on the battlefield and in cyberspace.

The secretary of state also highlighted the benefits of the new defense deal, which includes upgrades to Saudi communications, missile defense, maritime, border, and cyber security. He stated that the deal will reduce the burden on the US military and strengthen Saudi security forces for the future, enabling them to carry a greater share of the burden.

Tillerson also discussed the ongoing conflicts in the Middle East, including Yemen, where he emphasized the need for a political solution and pressure on parties to come to the table and negotiate. He also touched on Iran, criticizing its support for foreign fighters and militias operating in Yemen, Iraq, and Syria. While no plans are set for a conversation with Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif, Tillerson left the door open, stating, "I've never shut off the phone to anyone."

The secretary of state also highlighted the potential benefits of Saudi Arabia's direct investment in the US, which could bring "hundreds of thousands" of jobs to American workers. Earlier, President Trump described the day as "tremendous," with "hundreds of billions of investments into the United States" and job creation.

Saudi Foreign Minister Al-Jubeir echoed Trump's rhetoric, calling for a shift in the global conversation towards "partnership" and emphasizing the need to "drain the swamp" of extremism and terrorism.

Title: Senate Republicans Block Two Nominations, Sparking Debate Over Filibuster Rules

The United States Senate has seen a resurgence of partisan gridlock, as Republicans blocked two nominations to the executive and judicial branches, sparking renewed debate over the use of the filibuster and the need for rule changes. The votes, which came on Thursday, saw the Senate reject President Barack Obama's nominations of Rep. Mel Watt (D-N.C.) to head the Federal Housing Finance Agency and Patricia Millett to the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals.

The votes were seen as a setback for the Obama administration and a victory for Senate Republicans, who have long been resistant to the president's nominees. The blockages were achieved through the use of procedural votes, with Republicans using their majority to prevent the nominations from moving forward.

The move has sparked a heated debate among Senate Democrats, who are calling for changes to the chamber's rules to eliminate the need for a 60-vote threshold for cloture votes. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) has said he wants to see how the remaining judicial nominees fare before considering further action.

Not everyone is satisfied with the current state of affairs, however. Senate liberals are pushing for a more drastic overhaul of the rules, citing the need to eliminate the filibuster and allow for more efficient confirmation of presidential nominees. Some Democrats have expressed frustration with the lack of progress on key nominations, including those to the Federal Reserve and Homeland Security Department.

The debate over the filibuster and rule changes is not new, and it has been a contentious issue in the Senate for years. The "nuclear option," which would allow for a simple majority vote to overcome a filibuster, has been discussed but not yet implemented. The debate is likely to continue in the coming weeks, as the Senate considers additional nominations and the political landscape shifts in the lead-up to the 2014 midterm elections.

Title: Colorado Voters' Support for Recreational Marijuana Law Increases, but Majority Still View it as Harmful to State's Image

A recent Quinnipiac University survey has found that a growing number of Colorado voters support the state's new recreational marijuana law, with 58% of respondents in favor, up from 54% in August. The law, which went into effect on January 1, allows residents to grow up to a dozen marijuana plants in their homes.

The survey also broke down support by demographics, revealing that 39% of Republicans, 76% of Democrats, and 55% of independents support the law. The law is most popular among those aged 18-29, with 78% in favor, while support decreases with age, with only 33% of those 65 or older supporting the law.

Despite the growing support, a majority of Colorado voters, 51%, believe the law is bad for the state's image, while 38% disagree and 10% are unsure or have no opinion. The survey also found that 51% of respondents have tried marijuana previously, but only 10% have used it since it became legal last month.

The survey also touched on attitudes towards marijuana use in social settings. While 17% of respondents said it is very or somewhat likely they would try marijuana brownies at a gathering, 81% would be somewhat or very uncomfortable riding in a car with a driver who has had moderate amounts of marijuana.

The Quinnipiac University survey interviewed 1,139 registered voters in Colorado by telephone from January 29 to February 2, with an overall sampling error of plus or minus 2.9 percentage points.

Title: Former President Bill Clinton Calls for Supreme Court to Overturn Defense of Marriage Act

Former President Bill Clinton, who signed the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) into law in 1996, is now urging the Supreme Court to rule the law unconstitutional. In an op-ed published by The Washington Post, Clinton acknowledged that his views on same-sex marriage have evolved over time. He stated that, in 1996, he believed the law would "defuse a movement to enact a constitutional amendment banning gay marriage," but now believes it is "contrary to those principles and, in fact, incompatible with our Constitution."

Clinton noted that the climate has changed significantly since the law was passed, with nine states and the District of Columbia now allowing same-sex marriage. According to a CBS News poll, 54% of Americans believe same-sex couples should have the right to legally wed, while 39% oppose it.

Clinton emphasized that same-sex couples who are legally married in the United States are still denied over 1,000 federal statutes and programs available to other married couples due to the law. He urged the Supreme Court to overturn DOMA, stating that it is "itself discriminatory" and provides an "excuse for discrimination."

Clinton's views on same-sex marriage have evolved over time. In 2009, he publicly announced that he was no longer opposed to same-sex marriage, stating that "if people want to make commitments that last a lifetime, they ought to be able to do it." He joined the Obama administration, petitioner Edith Windsor, and other advocates in urging the Supreme Court to overturn DOMA.

Title: White House Officials Criticize Netanyahu's Planned Speech to Congress

The White House has expressed strong disapproval of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's decision to accept an invitation to speak before the US Congress in March. According to unnamed senior US officials, Netanyahu's move is seen as a "public slight" against President Barack Obama, with one official stating that "there are things you simply don't do" and that "he spat in our face publicly and that's no way to behave."

The planned speech is expected to focus on urging lawmakers to impose tougher sanctions on Iran to force it to stop its nuclear program. This move is seen as a challenge to President Obama's policy on Iran, which has promised to veto any new sanctions legislation.

Secretary of State John Kerry is said to be particularly offended by Netanyahu's apparent "disrespect" for the US leadership, as he had made numerous efforts on Israel's behalf on the world stage over the past month. Kerry had made dozens of calls to world leaders to convince them to oppose a UN Security Council resolution setting a time frame for the establishment of a Palestinian state.

Israel's intelligence chief, Tamir Pardo, has denied claims that he contradicted Netanyahu by criticizing new sanctions during a January meeting, stating that they would be akin to "throwing a grenade into the process." Instead, Pardo reiterated the need for "firm pressure" to bring about meaningful compromises from the Iranian side.

The White House has not publicly commented on the matter, but the language used by unnamed officials suggests a strong sense of disapproval and frustration with Netanyahu's decision.

**Senate Leaders Weigh In on Russian Election Meddling Allegations**

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and other GOP senators have expressed concerns about the recent CIA findings suggesting Russian interference in the 2016 US presidential election. McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, called for the Senate Intelligence Committee to investigate the matter, stating that the panel is "more than capable of conducting a complete review of this matter."

McConnell's comments come as Senator John McCain, a leading voice on national security and Russia, has also called for a special committee to delve into the issue. McCain, an Arizona Republican, believes that the leaders of the Senate Intelligence, Foreign Relations, and Armed Services panels should play a role in the investigation.

The Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman, Richard Burr, will also be conducting his own review of cybersecurity threats facing the nation, along with McCain, who chairs the Armed Services Committee.

McConnell emphasized that the Russians are not friends of the US, citing their invasion of Crimea and expressing concerns about their intentions. He declined to comment on the possible appointment of ExxonMobile CEO Rex Tillerson, who has close ties with Russian President Vladimir Putin, to serve as Secretary of State.

The majority leader also cautioned against leaked characterizations of the motivation behind Russian hacking, suggesting that they may be partisan in nature. He noted that prior to the election, the director of National Intelligence released a statement about hacking activities directed by the Russian government.

The allegations of Russian interference in the election have sparked controversy, with some critics accusing the Trump administration of downplaying the issue. Jason Miller, a spokesman for President-elect Donald Trump, dismissed the CIA report as an attempt to delegitimize Trump's win, saying it is "an overall narrative" of "people who are bitter their candidate lost."

Title: Trump's Warsaw Speech Highlights the Importance of Historical Literacy in a Polarized World

Article:

During his speech in Warsaw, Poland, President Trump referenced Pope John Paul II's 1979 visit to the city, which some historians believe set in motion the events that led to the fall of the Berlin Wall and the dissolution of the Soviet Union. The crowd's chant of "We want God" was a powerful moment, but many people watching on TV and Twitter immediately assumed Trump was making something up or speaking out of turn. This reaction highlights the problem of widespread historical ignorance and the arrogant impatience of reaching conclusions without understanding the context.

Historical literacy is crucial in today's world, where we face numerous challenges at home and abroad. The instantaneity of TV and Twitter amplifies the problem, as people are quick to react without taking the time to understand the context. The lack of historical knowledge can lead to misinformed opinions and a lack of empathy for others.

The article notes that ideological and political polarization is a significant concern, and commentators on both the Right and Left have extensively discussed the topic. However, it suggests that one often-overlooked factor is widespread historical ignorance and the arrogant impatience of reaching conclusions without thinking.

The article also touches on the idea that the intellectual framework for understanding events has changed over time. For those in their 30s, the framework shifted from World War II and the Cold War to the Iraq War and the War on Terror. For younger generations, the new paradigm seems to be the adventures of Harry Potter, which can be of limited utility in understanding the world.

The article concludes by noting that we are not in a civil war, but we are drifting toward divorce, and that historical literacy is essential to address the challenges we face.

Title: Reid's Nuclear Option: A Game-Changer for Medicare and Healthcare Costs

The recent decision by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid to invoke the "nuclear option" and eliminate the filibuster for executive branch nominees has sparked a heated debate among pundits and politicians. Mark Halperin, a prominent journalist, recently weighed in on the topic, expressing concerns about the potential consequences of this move. However, his comments inadvertently highlighted the importance of the Independent Payment Advisory Board (IPAB), a cost-cutting panel created by the Affordable Care Act to cap Medicare spending growth.

IPAB is designed to reduce healthcare costs by making judgments about the most effective treatments and allocating resources wisely. While some critics have labeled it a "death panel," the reality is that it is a mechanism to ensure Medicare spending remains sustainable without resorting to privatization or rationing. The board's current vacancy and the potential for Republicans to reject its nominees have raised concerns about its effectiveness.

Halperin's comments sparked controversy when he suggested that rationing is necessary to control healthcare costs, specifically mentioning end-of-life care. However, his statement was misinterpreted as advocating for "death panels," which is not the case. IPAB is not designed to ration services directly, but rather to create an incentive for providers to allocate resources wisely.

The real issue is that Republicans would have likely abolished IPAB altogether if Reid had not invoked the nuclear option. This would have left the country without a mechanism to control Medicare spending growth, potentially leading to higher costs and a greater burden on the national debt. Halperin's concerns about the partisan nature of the move are valid, but they do not outweigh the benefits of having a mechanism to control healthcare costs.

In conclusion, Reid's decision to eliminate the filibuster for executive branch nominees has sparked a necessary discussion about the importance of IPAB and the need for a sustainable healthcare system. While Halperin's comments may have been misinterpreted, they highlight the complexity of the issue and the need for a nuanced understanding of the consequences of this decision.

Title: Trump Announces Change in Permanent Residency to Florida

President Donald Trump announced on Twitter that he and his family have changed their permanent residency status to Florida. The decision was attributed to the fact that he has been treated poorly by city and state political leaders in New York, despite paying millions of dollars in taxes each year. Trump stated that he cherishes New York and will always have a special place in his heart for the state.

Trump's decision to relocate his permanent residence to Florida is a significant move, as it means he will no longer be required to pay state income taxes in New York. The President's Mar-a-Lago Club is located in Palm Beach, Florida, and he has stated that he will make the area his new home.

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio welcomed the news, with Cuomo tweeting "He's all yours, Florida." De Blasio added a tongue-in-cheek remark, saying "Don't let the door hit you on the way out or whatever."

Senator Elizabeth Warren, on the other hand, accused Trump of making the move to avoid paying taxes in New York.

Title: Dr. Ben Carson Forms Exploratory Committee for Potential 2016 Presidential Run

Dr. Ben Carson, a renowned neurosurgeon and public speaker, has announced the formation of an exploratory committee to test the waters for a potential 2016 presidential run. As part of this process, he has released a video outlining his reasons for considering a candidacy. In the video, Carson stated that he would run if he believes it is necessary to challenge Washington politicians who are not listening to the people and ignoring their concerns. He emphasized his passion for building common-sense solutions and reaching out to voters.

Carson's potential candidacy has sparked interest, with some analysts suggesting that he could be a strong contender as an anti-establishment, anti-politician candidate. As a well-known figure, he has already built a devoted following. However, others have raised questions about his chances of success, citing his lack of political experience and the difficulty of winning over voters.

Jonah Goldberg, a writer, has suggested that Carson might have a greater impact as a senatorial candidate, potentially flipping a safe Democratic seat in Maryland. He notes that Carson could raise money nationally and attract support from Republicans and Democrats alike. However, Carson has not expressed interest in running for the Senate, and his exploratory committee is focused on a potential presidential bid.

While some have questioned Carson's chances of winning the nomination, it is worth noting that many candidates have successfully run for the Senate without prior political experience. Elizabeth Warren, for example, defeated incumbent Senator Scott Brown in 2012 and is now considered a serious presidential contender in 2020. Carson's decision to explore a presidential run will be closely watched, and his potential candidacy could shake up the 2016 election landscape.

Title: Kellyanne Conway Defends Trump's Remarks on Hillary Clinton, CNN's Brianna Keilar Pushes Back

Article:

Kellyanne Conway, the campaign manager for Donald Trump, appeared on CNN's The Situation Room to defend her candidate's recent remarks about sending Hillary Clinton to "jail" if he becomes president. The interview with host Brianna Keilar was a tense and confrontational one, with Conway repeatedly denying the seriousness of Trump's comments and attempting to shift the focus to Clinton's past statements.

Conway claimed that Trump's remarks were simply a "quip" and that Keilar was "stuck on" the issue. However, Keilar pressed Conway to explain why Trump continues to bring up the topic, and Conway eventually stopped responding. The host also brought up Trump's repeated attacks on House Speaker Paul Ryan, which Conway attempted to downplay.

The interview took a dramatic turn when Keilar brought up a former Miss Arizona's accusation that Trump had walked in on her changing backstage at one of his pageants. Conway refused to comment, instead shifting the conversation to Bill Clinton's past controversies. The exchange became increasingly heated, with Conway accusing CNN of ignoring the "substance" of Trump's campaign and Keilar pushing back on the campaign's focus on attacking Hillary Clinton.

The interview highlights the ongoing tensions between the Trump campaign and the media, as well as the challenges facing the campaign in terms of messaging and voter engagement.

Title: Attorney General Loretta Lynch Sworn in Amidst Ongoing Tensions in Baltimore

Article:

Attorney General Loretta Lynch was sworn in on Monday, marking a significant milestone in her career. However, her appointment has been met with controversy, with some citing the 167-day delay in her confirmation as a testament to the relentless and uncaring nature of Time. While the delay was indeed unprecedented, it is unclear whether Time bears sole responsibility for the delay.

The recent riots in Baltimore, which paralyzed the city and left a trail of destruction, have also raised questions about the role of the attorney general. Lynch's goal of improving police morale has been met with skepticism, as many argue that it is premature and will not address the root causes of the problem. The riots, sparked by the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old African-American man, have highlighted the ongoing struggles faced by minority communities and the need for accountability and justice.

The Baltimore Police Department's documented history of lawless violence has been identified as the inspiration for the riots, with many citing the death of Freddie Gray as the catalyst. An autopsy revealed that Gray had a broken neck, and an investigation is ongoing to determine what happened during his arrest and detention. The BPD has admitted that its officers did not provide Gray with necessary medical care, but the main question remains unanswered: why was Gray able to run from the police in the morning, but struggling to breathe by nightfall?

The fact that such a thing could happen, and only become a major story after the activism of peaceful protesters and the destructive hijacking of violent rioters, is exactly the problem. The BPD's reputation is such that many Baltimoreans heard Gray's story with weary outrage rather than shock or indignation, and the fact that the rank-and-file officers feel comfortable with extralegal brutality and are accustomed to wielding it is exactly the problem.

Attorney General Lynch has expressed interest in finding common ground between law enforcement and minority communities, but some argue that this approach is insufficient. What is needed instead is for authorities to stop pandering to police unions and take the rise of the "warrior cop" and police militarization seriously. The suspension of officers responsible for Gray's death with pay is not enough, and Lynch must make clear that she understands that these incidents are not tragic accidents, but crimes.

Title: Tea Party Activists Express Frustration with Republican Efforts to Repeal Obamacare

The Tea Party Patriots, a grassroots activist group, has expressed disappointment and frustration with the Republican-led efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. According to Jenny Beth Martin, the group's president and co-founder, the group's email blasts against the ACA still trigger hundreds of responses from activists angry about it. The group helped make over 100,000 phone calls to Congress during the House's vote on the bill to repeal and replace the ACA in early May.

However, Martin stated that the group is not yet on board with the Senate's current approach to repealing the ACA. Grassroots activists like Pat Daugherty, who was involved in the early days of the Tea Party movement, now express similar frustration with Republicans in Congress as they did with Democrats during the early days of the movement.

Daugherty, a retired university administrator from Athens, Georgia, questioned why Republicans are having trouble repealing the ACA, given that every Republican in Congress ran on repealing it. She noted that many conservatives are more upset with Republicans than Democrats over the issue.

David Zupan, who helped organize Tea Party groups in Ohio against the ACA, expressed similar frustration. He blamed the law for driving up health care costs and forcing him to shutter his technology support business. Zupan had hoped to confront Senator Rob Portman over the recess to demand that he and his fellow Republicans push for a full repeal. However, he gave up after being unable to figure out where Portman would be.

Zupan expressed disappointment with the Senate's approach, stating that "nothing they're going to do to this bill is going to make it better."

Title: Republican Official Accuses Whistleblower of Being a Democratic Operative, Citing Ties to Democratic Candidates and Staff

Article:

A top Republican official has accused the whistleblower who sparked a House investigation into President Donald Trump's phone conversation about U.S. aid to Ukraine of being a Democratic operative. Steve Guest, the Republican National Committee's Rapid Response Director, made the claim on Thursday, citing the whistleblower's professional ties to a 2020 Democratic candidate and coordination with House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff's staff.

Guest stated that the whistleblower's lawyers worked for former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, and donated to Joe Biden's presidential campaign. Additionally, one of the whistleblower's attorneys is allegedly a member of the #Resistance, an anti-Trump movement.

President Trump has also taken to Twitter to express his concerns about the whistleblower's credibility, stating that their facts about his conversation with the Ukrainian President were "incorrect" and that they have a "conflict of interest" due to their ties to a Democratic candidate.

The Washington Examiner reported that Inspector General Michael Atkinson wrote an August 26 letter stating that the whistleblower showed "some indicia of an arguable political bias... in favor of a rival political candidate." Under questioning from Republicans during the impeachment inquiry, Atkinson revealed that the whistleblower had a significant tie to one of the Democratic presidential candidates currently vying to challenge President Trump in next year's election.

Mark Zaid, a lawyer for the whistleblower, denied the allegations of bias, stating that the claims are "give me a break" and "seriously?" Zaid and fellow attorney Andrew Bakaj acknowledged that their client had met with presidential candidates from both parties, but not as candidates.

The controversy surrounding the whistleblower's identity and motivations has sparked a heated debate, with some Republicans accusing the media of ignoring the evidence of a Democratic plot to discredit the White House.

Title: Obama Campaign Focuses on Non-Issues, Distracting from Economic Concerns

The Obama campaign has been criticized for focusing on trivial issues and distractions during the presidential debates, rather than addressing the country's pressing economic concerns. In the first debate, Romney's statement about measuring government spending by whether it's worth borrowing money from China to pay for it was met with a response from the Obama campaign that focused on Big Bird, a character from the popular children's television show Sesame Street. This move was seen as an attempt to deflect attention away from the real issues and create a humorous distraction.

Similarly, during the second debate, Romney's comment about reviewing "binders full of women" in response to a question about gender pay equality was ridiculed by the Obama campaign, which tied it to a perceived "war on women." This move was seen as an attempt to create a controversy and distract from the real issues.

In the third debate, Obama's response to Romney's comment about the Navy having fewer ships than at any time since 1917 was to joke about the country also having fewer horses and bayonets. This move was seen as an attempt to deflect attention away from the real issues and create a humorous distraction.

The Obama campaign's strategy of focusing on non-issues and distractions has been criticized for not addressing the country's pressing economic concerns, such as the deficit and entitlement spending. Romney's five-point plan to create 12 million new jobs and his focus on the middle class have been seen as a more serious and substantive approach to addressing the country's economic challenges.

As the election nears, it remains to be seen whether the Obama campaign's strategy of focusing on non-issues and distractions will be successful. However, it is clear that the country deserves a serious discussion of the real issues, rather than political efforts to trivialize them.

Title: Clinton Leads Trump in Head-to-Head Poll, Trump's Favorability Remains Low

A recent CNN/ORC poll has found that former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton leads likely Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump by 13 points in a head-to-head matchup, with 54% of voters supporting Clinton and 41% supporting Trump. The poll was conducted from April 28 to May 1, before Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus declared Trump the presumptive GOP nominee.

The poll also found that Clinton leads Trump in several key areas, including climate change, foreign policy, education, health care, the income gap between rich and poor, immigration, and terrorism. However, Trump has an edge on the economy.

The survey also revealed that more than half of both Clinton and Trump voters said their vote was more about opposition to the other candidate than support for their preferred candidate. Fifty-one percent of Clinton voters said their vote was more about opposing Trump, while 48% said it was more about supporting Clinton. Similarly, 57% of Trump voters said their choice was more about opposing Clinton, while 43% said it was more about supporting Trump.

Ohio Governor John Kasich, who is still in the GOP race, led Clinton head-to-head by 7 points, 51% to 44%. Sanders outperformed Clinton in head-to-head match-ups against the two remaining Republicans, leading Trump by 16 points, 56% to 40%, and Kasich by 4 points, 50% to 46%.

The poll also found that Sanders had a 61% favorable rating among voters, while Kasich had a 54% favorable rating. Trump's favorability rating was lower, with 37% of voters having a favorable view of him and 56% having an unfavorable view. Clinton's favorability rating was even, with 49% of voters having a favorable view and 49% having an unfavorable view.

In head-to-head match-ups against Cruz, Clinton beat him by 10 points, 52% to 42%, and Sanders beat him by 18 points, 57% to 39%.

Title: Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Victory Spells the Death of Sane Economic Policy

Article:

In a recent debate on the BBC, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and opposition Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn faced off, with Johnson ultimately securing a victory that will likely guarantee Brexit. However, his win comes at a cost, as he abandoned core conservative principles and adopted a liberal economic platform.

Johnson's campaign focused on promising new spending and a spending blowout, which appealed to voters who turned away from Corbyn's anti-Semitism and hard-left economics. He made no attempt to make the case for the wisdom of government getting out of the way of the private sector to unleash prosperity, instead painting a picture of growth and economic security deriving from government spending.

The Left denounced him as an apostle of austerity, but it didn't work. Johnson successfully convinced voters that if only they'd allow him to pull Brexit across the finish line, he'd restore unabashed left-of-center economics. Thatcherism is dead, and Johnson's premiership will likely be marked by a significant shift to the left.

Johnson's promises included $125 billion in new infrastructure spending, $20 billion in additional annual spending on schools, a hike in the minimum wage, an increase in teacher salaries, and a huge increase in spending on the National Health Service. He also promised not to raise taxes and to decrease the budget deficit. However, these promises come at a cost, as they will likely lead to a significant increase in government spending and debt.

Some of Johnson's fiscal liberalism is linked to social conservatism, as he promised longer jail sentences for violent criminals, 20,000 additional cops, fewer limits on searching suspects, and limits on immigration through an Australian-style points system to assess the value of incoming would-be Britons.

In order to win his majority, Johnson had to vigorously contest seats in traditional Labour constituencies whose distaste for the Tory party is deeply ingrained. Perhaps free-spending promises were the only way to win those voters over, and thus to guarantee five years of Conservative government and achieve Brexit. However, the cost of these promises is a significant shift to the left, which may have long-term consequences for the British economy.

While a liberal government led by Johnson is preferable to Corbynista rule, the parameters of British economics have taken a large step to the left. If a nominally conservative party lacks the courage or communications skills to sell conservative economics, it bodes ill for those on either side of the Atlantic who wonder whether any party will ever even gesture in the direction of sane fiscal policy again.

Title: US Economy Adds 162,000 Jobs in July, Unemployment Rate Edges Down to 7.4%

The US economy added 162,000 jobs in July, according to the latest report from federal economists, while the unemployment rate edged down from 7.6 percent to 7.4 percent. The jobs count narrowly missed analyst expectations, following Wednesday's news that the economy grew by only 1.7 percent in the second quarter. Federal economists also reduced their estimate for first-quarter growth to 1.1 percent.

The 7.4 percent unemployment rate is the lowest of President Barack Obama's presidency, as the rate dipped to its lowest level since December 2008. The unemployment rate is based on a separate survey, which relies on data from a survey of households, rather than the jobs number, which is calculated via a survey of employers' payrolls. The household survey estimated 227,000 more people were employed in July than in the month before.

However, the falling unemployment rate stems from both positive and negative news, as the additional 37,000 people who left the labor force in July also contributed to the rate's decline. "The report, like many of late, contains good news and less good news," said Jared Bernstein, a senior fellow at the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities and a former economic adviser to Vice President Joe Biden. "Most of the decline in unemployment was due to more people getting jobs, but part of it was due to a slight fall-off in the labor force, a signal of not-too-strong labor demand."

The stubbornly slow job growth left 11.5 million people unemployed, with another 8.2 million part-time employees unsuccessfully looking to add more hours to their work week. Among the unemployed, 4.2 million have been unsuccessfully seeking work for six months or more. In the past year, the unemployment rate has fallen 0.8 percent, with the count of officially unemployed persons falling by 1.2 million.

The job reports are now being used as little more than talking points in the fiscal debate between the White House and Republicans, but they are a key indicator for the Federal Reserve as it weighs when it will begin to scale back its efforts to stimulate the stalled economy. Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke has said the central bank is watching for signs that it should scale back a series of monthly multi-billion-dollar asset purchases that are aimed at driving down long-term interest rates and sparking new growth.

Title: Vice President Pence Reassures NATO Allies of US Commitment to Defense Pact

Vice President Mike Pence visited Estonia on Monday, pledging to NATO's Baltic members that the Trump administration would confront threats and intimidation from Russia. In a forceful speech, Pence reassured allies of the US commitment to the defense pact and solidarity with Baltic states in the face of mounting pressure from Russian President Vladimir Putin.

Pence emphasized that the US would hold Russia accountable for its actions and called on European allies to do the same. He also reiterated the US commitment to NATO's Article 5, which pledges mutual defense for all member nations. The vice president's visit came amid mounting tensions between Washington and Moscow, following Russia's expulsion of 755 US diplomats in retaliation for new sanctions legislation signed by President Trump.

The sanctions, which codified financial and diplomatic sanctions on Russia for its annexation of Crimea and meddling in the US presidential election, were viewed as a legislative check on Trump's ability to unilaterally cancel sanctions. The move highlighted the strained relationship between Trump and Putin, with Democrats' unproven allegations that the Trump campaign colluded with Moscow to meddle in the election.

Pence's visit aimed to reassure NATO allies of the US commitment to the alliance and its solidarity with Baltic states, which became NATO members in 2004. The alliance has deployed some 4,000 troops and military hardware in the three Baltic states and Poland to counter Russia's buildup in the region.

Title: Trump's First Week in Office: A Complex Dance Between the President and Congress

The first week of President Trump's administration has been marked by a complex dance between the new president and Congress. Despite some initial optimism, the relationship between Trump and Republicans in Congress remains uncertain, with questions about whether they can work together to achieve their ambitious agenda.

At a retreat in Philadelphia, Trump presented his "record" number of executive orders and outlined his ambitious to-do list, which includes repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act, tax reform, and infrastructure development. While lawmakers were generous with standing ovations and applause, they were silent on a couple of touchy points.

Republicans sense a huge opportunity with their control of both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue, but Trump's impatience and tweeting reflexes could add friction to their efforts. The ambitious agenda is not unprecedented, as Democratic President Lyndon B. Johnson had a "massive agenda" in the 1960s, but Trump lacks Johnson's legislative skills, according to James Pitney, a congressional expert at Claremont McKenna College.

The special budget process will be used to pass the top priorities, Obamacare repeal and tax reform, by majority vote and without Democratic support. However, the issues are complicated, and views differ among Republicans about how best to address them. The agenda is considered a "clash between reality and fantasy" by Pitney.

Despite the challenges, Republicans are confident they can accomplish their two highest priorities, but they face the task of confirming Trump's 1,200 appointees and announcing a Supreme Court nominee. The House does not have to contend with the Senate's special rules and slower pace, which is something Trump is confronting.

Trump has a businessman's understanding of how Congress works, but he is on a steep learning curve. Republican lawmakers are trying to figure out how to work with a president who is unlike any they've encountered before. The voter fraud tweet seemed to roll off the backs of lawmakers, and several say they just ignore the tweet eruptions and focus on policy.

In another surprise, The New York Times reported that the Trump administration was reviewing reopening "black site" prisons and undoing restrictions on interrogations, but lawmakers put their foot down and said there would be no return to torture. The White House denied the story, saying it was an old memo from the transition period.

Despite the challenges, Republicans are eager to prove to Americans that they can get the job done and are willing to work with each other to achieve their goals. As Trump said, "This Congress is going to be the busiest Congress we've had in decades, maybe ever."

Title: Perry Criticizes Clinton on Voter ID Laws, Accuses Her of Alienating Texas Voters

Article:

Former Texas Governor Rick Perry has launched a new attack on Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton, accusing her of alienating voters by criticizing voter ID laws like those in Texas. Perry made the comments during an interview on CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday.

Perry, who signed a strict voter ID law in Texas in 2011, which was later upheld by the U.S. Supreme Court, claimed that Clinton is "way outside the norm of ridiculous" in her call for easier voter ID laws. He stated that Texas already makes it easy for residents to vote and that Clinton is not playing to the people of Texas.

Clinton's rapid-response team, Correct the Record, responded to Perry's criticisms, saying that Republicans like Perry are trying to deny citizens the right to vote under the guise of voter fraud. They also accused Perry of signing a law that was intentionally written to discriminate against minority voters.

In the same interview, Perry also defended his populist tone, taking aim at Wall Street banks. He stated that it is not right for Wall Street to be able to walk away from bad mistakes that Main Street has to pay for. He also expressed support for regulating Wall Street, but believes that the Dodd-Frank regulatory reforms went too far and are harming community banks.

Perry launched his second presidential campaign on Thursday with an upbeat speech in an airplane hangar outside Addison, Texas. He also rode a motorcycle and addressed the crowd in blue jeans and a baseball cap at an event hosted by Iowa Sen. Joni Ernst.

Title: Americans' Support for Military Action Against North Korea Remains Strong, Despite Low Approval Ratings

A recent poll by the Chicago Council of Foreign Affairs (CCFA) has found that 75% of Americans believe North Korea presents a critical threat to the United States, up from 55% two years ago. This sentiment is not swayed by President Donald Trump's historically low approval ratings, which currently stand at 38%. The poll also found that 62% of respondents are "uneasy" about Trump's ability to thwart North Korea.

The CCFA poll also found broad bipartisan support for more sanctions against North Korea, with 76% of Americans favoring increased sanctions. Additionally, 68% want sanctions extended to Chinese companies that work with North Korea.

The poll's findings come as North Korea has successfully "miniaturized" a nuclear warhead for missile delivery, overshadowing progress on the diplomatic front. North Korean missile tests are inevitably followed by successful U.S. missile defense tests.

The poll also found that for the first time in 30 years, a majority of Americans support military action if North Korea attacks South Korea. Large majorities think North Korea should not be allowed to keep its nuclear weapons.

The U.S. has taught the world some lessons about the importance of maintaining a strong military presence, and Pyongyang has been paying attention. The U.S. invaded Iraq in 2003 after George W. Bush's administration insisted that the country possessed weapons of mass destruction (WMDs) and was determined to build more. No WMD program was found, but the Iraq war did have a knock-on effect on proliferation.

The U.S. has survived despite often acting in a less than rational fashion, and the ocean buffer that sandwiches America has given us space to do that, as has our massive military superiority. From Vietnam to Afghanistan, the U.S. faces few real existential consequences for its ill-conceived actions.

Trump ran on a platform of questioning America's security commitments around the world, while embracing much of America's role as world policemen. Other countries remain understandably skeptical, leading South Korea and even Japan to consider developing their own nuclear arsenals – a development that could go a long way in improving the prospects of peace in the region.

American opinion is working against peace, coupled with Trump's sinking approval ratings, the relatively widespread approval of a more aggressive approach in Korea could prompt Trump to drop any attempts at negotiation. Diplomacy is easy to mock, after all. War comes with a rally-'round-the-flag effect.

Title: Trump Administration Proposes Changes to Health Insurance Rules, Insurers and Republicans Welcome the Move

The Trump administration has proposed changes to health insurance rules, which will be published in the Federal Register on Friday, giving the public until March 7 to comment. The proposed rules aim to stabilize the individual health insurance market and provide more flexibility to insurers. Insurers and Republican members of Congress have welcomed the move, with Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee and chairman of the Senate health committee, calling the proposals "important first steps to rescue a collapsing Obamacare individual market."

The proposed rules include allowing states to determine whether insurance plans have enough doctors, hospitals, and other healthcare providers to serve patients, which is expected to lure more insurers into the market. Insurers will also be allowed to refuse new coverage to consumers who failed to pay premiums owed in the previous year. Additionally, insurers will be allowed to sell health plans covering a smaller share of expected costs, which could result in increased deductibles and out-of-pocket costs for some consumers.

However, some critics have expressed concerns about the proposed rules. Christopher W. Hansen, the president of the advocacy arm of the American Cancer Society, warned that the tighter restrictions on special enrollment periods could "cause problems for cancer patients," delaying treatment and reducing their chances of survival.

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has also proposed changes to the individual mandate, which requires most Americans to have insurance. The IRS will accept and process tax returns even if taxpayers fail to indicate whether they had coverage, qualified for an exemption, or were paying the penalty for going without insurance. The individual mandate was to be enforced through the tax system, but it is unclear how the government will use its authority to enforce it.

The proposed rules are expected to be finalized in March or April, with insurers required to decide by early May what kinds of health plans they will offer in 2018.

Title: Republicans Lead in Latest Poll, Preferred to Control Congress

A recent survey conducted by The Wall Street Journal, NBC News, and the Annenberg Public Policy Center has found that a majority of likely voters prefer the Republicans to control Congress, with 49% of respondents choosing the GOP over 44% who prefer the Democrats. This is the first time in five weeks that the Republicans have taken the lead, according to The Journal.

The survey, which polled 1,172 voters from October 10-16, also found that Republicans have an advantage among all registered voters, with 45% preferring a Republican-led Congress compared to 43% who prefer a Democratic-led Congress.

The findings suggest that Democrats are less interested in the midterm elections, with 44% of those surveyed saying they would prefer a Democratic-controlled Congress, compared to 51% of those who are highly interested in the election. In contrast, Republicans have a 10-point lead among voters who are highly interested in the election.

The survey also found that Democrats are struggling to motivate low-interest voters, with 52% of those voters supporting the Democrats compared to 37% supporting the Republicans. This is a concern for the Democratic Party, which is trying to reach and motivate these voters through vigorous turnout operations across the country.

The results come as pundits continue to predict that the Republicans have the best chance of taking control of the Senate. Larry Sabato, director of the University of Virginia's Center for Politics, projects that the GOP could take up to eight seats, while The Washington Post predicts that Republicans will take control of the upper chamber. The New York Times election model gives Republicans a 69% chance of winning the Senate.

President Barack Obama's low approval ratings are believed to be a major factor dragging down the Democrats' chances, particularly among women in battleground states where Democrats are already lagging among male voters.

Title: Trump's Attempt to Change the Subject: A Pattern of Behavior

The release of the Mueller report has led to a common assumption that President Donald Trump is now free to act without the cloud of investigation over his head. However, this assumption may be incorrect. Trump's response to the report's findings has followed a familiar pattern, which has allowed him to weather past scandals. The pattern involves denying the facts, attacking his opponents, and changing the subject.

Trump's surrogates have claimed that the president has been completely exonerated, despite Mueller's report not making such a judgment. They have also accused the media and Democrats of conspiring to bring down the president. Trump has then attempted to change the subject by sparking a new controversy, which eclipses the old one.

Since the release of the Barr report, Trump has tried to change the subject in two ways. He has backed a legal challenge to the Affordable Care Act, which would strip healthcare benefits from millions of Americans, and has threatened to close the US-Mexico border, which would harm millions of Americans and undermine cooperation with Mexico.

These self-destructive measures demonstrate that Trump is more interested in gaining headlines than finding solutions. Democrats should not fall for his tactics and instead focus on obtaining a full copy of the Mueller report and making its contents public.

The article concludes that Trump's behavior is a pattern of hiding his connections to Russia and avoiding accountability. The author argues that it is essential to know more about the 2016 election and the compromise of American national security before moving on. Trump's reluctance to release the report and his attempts to change the subject suggest that he is hiding something.

Title: Pelosi Faces Uphill Battle to Retain Speaker Position, Finds Unlikely Support from Republicans

Article:

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., is facing a challenging road to reclaim the speaker's gavel in January, with a growing number of Democrats signaling they will not support her bid. However, Pelosi has received an unexpected boost from some Republicans who believe her return to the position could benefit them in the long run.

At least 17 House Democrats, including incumbents and incoming members, have signed a letter pledging not to support Pelosi on the House floor, according to Fox News. This means that if all those Democrats vote against her, Pelosi would not have the necessary votes to become speaker. To secure the position, Pelosi must first win a majority of the Democratic caucus in internal leadership elections and then secure an absolute majority of the House.

In an effort to gain support, Pelosi has been touting her experience and ability to get things done. However, some Democrats are skeptical, with Rep. Tim Ryan, D-Ohio, stating that the speaker's position is not yet a done deal. Ryan also hinted that he might challenge Pelosi for the position.

Meanwhile, some Republicans are considering backing Pelosi's bid, citing the potential benefits of having her as speaker. Republican Tom Reed said that if Pelosi were to embrace a bipartisan package of rules reforms, he could support her. "A Democratic candidate who embraces these rules reforms, I will stand with," he told CNN.

Other Republicans, such as strategist Chris Wilson, believe that having Pelosi as speaker would be beneficial for the party in the long run. "She reminds the American people why they don't like politics. She reminds them why they don't like Democrats, quite frankly," Wilson said on "Fox and Friends." "The best thing in the world for Republicans is to have her in that role."

Pelosi has dismissed the idea that she would need Republican support to win the speakership, stating that she intends to win with Democratic votes. However, it remains to be seen whether she will be able to secure the necessary support from her own party.

Title: Justice Department Refers Andrew McCabe's Findings to Federal Prosecutors for Possible Criminal Investigation

The Justice Department's inspector general has referred the findings of its report on former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe to federal prosecutors in Washington for possible criminal investigation. The referral, which occurred some time ago, stems from the inspector general's conclusion that McCabe had lied to investigators or his own boss, then-FBI Director James B. Comey, on four occasions, three of them under oath. The referral raises the possibility that McCabe could be charged and jailed for his alleged misconduct.

According to McCabe's lawyer, Michael R. Bromwich, the referral was made weeks ago or even longer, and they are confident that the U.S. Attorney's Office will conclude that it should decline to prosecute. The inspector general's report, which was leaked almost as soon as it was completed, found that McCabe "lacked candor" with internal investigators at the agency and concluded he wasn't authorized to disclose to reporters the existence of an investigation into the Clinton Foundation.

Former FBI Assistant Director Frank Figliuzzi called the criminal referral "unprecedented" and expressed concern that the remedy for lacking candor during an internal inquiry is termination, not criminal referral. Figliuzzi also noted that approving an unauthorized leak could rise to the level of criminal referral.

It is worth noting that the referral to federal prosecutors does not necessarily mean McCabe will be charged with a crime. The investigation is ongoing, and the outcome is uncertain.

Title: Melania Trump's Speech Raises Questions of Plagiarism

Article:

Melania Trump's speech at the opening night of the Republican National Convention has sparked controversy after it was discovered that a significant portion of the speech appears to be lifted directly from Michelle Obama's address to the 2008 Democratic convention. The similarities between the two speeches are striking, with Melania Trump repeating almost line-for-line what Michelle Obama said eight years ago.

The controversy has added to the chaotic first day of the Republican National Convention, which saw a series of events, including a fight on the convention floor, a confrontation between a comedian and conspiracy theorist Alex Jones, and a speech by Rep. Steve King that sparked outrage over his comments on white supremacy.

Melania Trump's speech focused on the values she and her husband share, including the importance of hard work, keeping promises, and treating people with respect. However, the similarities to Michelle Obama's speech are undeniable, with Melania Trump repeating phrases and sentences almost verbatim.

The Trump campaign initially did not acknowledge the plagiarism allegations, with spokesman Jason Miller stating that Melania's team of writers took notes on her life's inspirations and included fragments that reflected her own thinking. However, the campaign later attacked Hillary Clinton, claiming that the allegations were an attempt to take Melania down.

The controversy has sparked a debate among Republicans, with some defending Melania's speech and others expressing shock and disappointment. Chris Christie, a former governor of New Jersey, defended Melania's speech, stating that 93% of it was different from Michelle Obama's speech. However, the incident has raised questions about the Trump campaign's attention to detail and the importance of originality in speechwriting.

The incident is not the first time the Trump campaign has been accused of plagiarism. In 2008, Donald Trump questioned Joe Biden's running mate, Barack Obama, over a plagiarism scandal, stating that it was a "very bad statement." The incident has sparked a renewed focus on the importance of originality and authenticity in politics.

Title: SeaWorld's Controversy: Separating Fact from Fiction

The documentary "Blackfish" has sparked a heated debate about the treatment of killer whales in captivity, with millions of people visiting SeaWorld to learn more about these majestic creatures. However, the film's claims about the treatment of whales have led to a significant decline in attendance. SeaWorld has responded to the allegations, stating that much of the documentary is deceitful and that the film implies that they are doing things that they haven't done in 35 years.

The documentary claims that SeaWorld separates whales from their mothers, which the park denies. Kelly Flaherty Clark, SeaWorld's head trainer, stated that they have not done this in 35 years and have no plans to do it again. The film also claims that captive whales are psychologically traumatized, which biologist Lori Marino argues is true. However, SeaWorld's head veterinarian, Chris Dold, disputes this, stating that the whales are not miserable and that their trainers work with them daily.

The documentary also claims that captive whales have droopy dorsal fins, which Ingrid Visser, a whale expert, disputes, stating that killer whales in the wild also have collapsed dorsal fins. The film also claims that captive whales die young, which Dold disputes, citing a 50-year-old whale living at SeaWorld.

While some argue that keeping whales in captivity is cruel, others believe that marine parks and zoos are essential for education and conservation efforts. SeaWorld has helped rescue 25,000 animals and provides a platform for people to learn about nature. The debate surrounding "Blackfish" highlights the complexities of keeping animals in captivity and the need for continued research and education.

It is essential to separate fact from fiction and consider the perspectives of both sides. While some may disagree with SeaWorld's practices, it is crucial to acknowledge the efforts they have made to improve the lives of the whales in their care. Ultimately, the decision to visit SeaWorld or support conservation efforts is a personal one, and it is essential to remain informed and make an educated decision.

Title: President Trump Addresses Range of Topics in Fox News Sunday Interview

Article:

President Donald Trump addressed a variety of topics in a recent interview on Fox News Sunday, including his views on CNN correspondent Jim Acosta, his appointment of acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker, and his stance on recent elections, foreign policy, and more. The president also took to Twitter to express his thoughts on several issues, including his criticism of U.S. Representative Adam Schiff and his support for border security and a wall.

In the interview with host Chris Wallace, Trump discussed his views on Acosta, stating that the CNN correspondent was "unbelievably rude" to White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee during a recent press briefing. Trump also warned that if Acosta misbehaves, he will be removed from the press conference or have his press pass revoked.

The president also touched on his appointment of Whitaker, stating that he was unaware of Whitaker's past remarks about the Mueller investigation into possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia. Trump said he did not know Whitaker had expressed views on the Mueller investigation prior to his appointment.

Trump also discussed his views on recent elections, including his support for Republican Senate candidate Rick Scott in Florida. He claimed that he helped Scott win the election by putting a spotlight on the election and preventing voter fraud.

In addition, Trump discussed his foreign policy views, stating that North Korea has been "very tough" due to the country's close proximity to the United States. He also expressed his support for Saudi Arabia and Pakistan, stating that the U.S. has given Pakistan $1.3 billion annually, but has since stopped due to Pakistan's lack of cooperation.

Trump also expressed regret for not visiting Arlington National Cemetery on Veterans Day, stating that he was extremely busy with calls for the country and assumed it was fine to skip the visit.

Title: DEA and ATF Collaborated on Plans to Monitor Gun Show Attendees Using License Plate Readers, Documents Reveal

The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has obtained documents through a Freedom of Information Act request, revealing that the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) collaborated on plans to monitor gun show attendees using automatic license plate readers. The documents, obtained in April 2009, show that the DEA's Phoenix Division Office worked closely with the ATF to monitor gun shows and collect information on attendees using license plate readers.

According to the documents, the agencies planned to use automatic license plate readers to track the license plates of cars in gun show parking lots, without distinguishing between individuals transporting illegal or legal firearms. This means that mere attendance at a gun show would have been enough to have one's presence noted in a DEA database.

The DEA responded to inquiries about the document, stating that the monitoring of gun shows was merely a proposal and was never implemented. However, the ACLU had previously concluded that gun show monitoring was underway based on the information provided in the document.

The controversy surrounding the use of automatic license plate readers to track gun show attendees raises concerns about the government's targeting of constitutionally protected rights, such as the right to assemble. The Department of Justice's own surveys have shown that criminals do not obtain their firearms from gun shows, making it unclear why the agencies would prioritize tracking law-abiding citizens.

In a separate incident, the ATF's Phoenix office was involved in Operation Fast and Furious, which provided over 2,500 weapons to Mexican narco-terrorists, resulting in the deaths of hundreds of people, including U.S. federal law enforcement officers. The fact that the agencies prioritized tracking gun show attendees over addressing the real issue of illegal gun trafficking raises questions about their priorities and effectiveness in addressing gun violence.

Title: Assimilation and Support Crucial for Immigrant Students' Success

A recent study has shed light on the challenges faced by immigrant students in the United States, highlighting the importance of providing academic, psychological, and social support to help them succeed. The research found that many Americans hold negative stereotypes about immigrants, with 65% of students surveyed using negative adjectives to describe those of their national origin. This perception can have a significant impact on the academic performance of immigrant students, with those who arrive during their high school years facing particularly poor odds.

The study also found that having a friend who speaks English fluently is a strong predictor of positive academic outcomes, but more than a third of students reported having little or no opportunity to interact with native-born students. This lack of social connection can exacerbate the challenges faced by immigrant students, who are already dealing with the stress of adjusting to a new country and culture.

The research also confirmed that students who experience interrupted schooling, family instability, and traumatic dislocations back home face significant challenges in their academic performance. However, the study also found that some students are able to overcome these obstacles and achieve academic success, with 25% sustaining high academic performance over the five-year study period and 11% showing significant improvement.

The study's findings have implications for educators and policymakers, highlighting the need to provide targeted support to immigrant students. The Internationals Network for Public Schools is one successful model, which focuses on students' distinct needs and develops authentic connections with their families. Providing a scaffold of support, as Emma Lazarus famously wrote, is crucial for helping immigrant students succeed and fulfilling the promise of America.

Title: Shellie Zimmerman Sentenced to One Year of Probation and Community Service for Perjury

Shellie Zimmerman, the wife of George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch volunteer acquitted in the killing of Trayvon Martin, has been sentenced to one year of probation and 100 hours of community service after pleading guilty to a misdemeanor perjury charge. The charge stemmed from her testimony at her husband's bond hearing in April 2012, where she claimed the couple had little funds, when in fact, George Zimmerman had collected over $100,000 through online donations.

According to court records, Shellie Zimmerman admitted to perjuring herself before Judge Kenneth Lester, who was presiding over her husband's case at the time. The court filing revealed that Shellie Zimmerman had transferred over $74,000 to her personal account and nearly $50,000 to her sister's account days before the bond hearing. Taped phone calls between the couple showed that they discussed the money transfers in code to hide the funds.

Prosecutors alleged that Zimmerman and his wife talked about $10, $20, and $100 to mask the fact that they were referring to thousands of dollars. The calls also showed that George Zimmerman instructed his wife to "pay off all the bills," including payments to American Express and Sam's Club.

Judge Lester ruled on June 3, 2012, that Shellie Zimmerman had "testified untruthfully" about their finances. She was later arrested on June 12, 2012, and jailed briefly in Seminole County before posting a $1,000 bond.

As part of her sentence, Shellie Zimmerman was given a list of conditions she must abide by during her one-year probation. These conditions include not possessing, carrying, or owning a firearm, getting permission to own any other type of weapon, reporting regularly to a probation officer, paying $263 in court fees/fines, and paying the state of Florida $50 per month as a cost of supervision. Her probation can also be revoked if she violates the law, associates with anyone engaged in criminal activity, or uses any drugs not prescribed by a doctor.

Title: Trump Extends Social Distancing Guidelines for 30 More Days to Fight Virus

The Trump administration has extended its guidelines urging Americans to practice social distancing to slow the spread of the coronavirus for an additional 30 days, until April 30. The initial 15-day guidelines were set to expire on Monday, but President Trump announced the extension during a news conference in the Rose Garden on Sunday.

Under the guidelines, Americans are advised to avoid restaurants, bars, and other gatherings involving more than 10 people, as well as restrict non-essential travel. The president emphasized the importance of following these guidelines, stating that the better people do, the faster the pandemic will end.

Models of the virus's spread indicate that the worst days of the pandemic could hit the country in two weeks, according to Trump. The president had previously suggested that the country could "reopen" for business on Easter, but infectious disease experts expressed concerns that such a move could exacerbate the crisis.

Trump made the decision to extend the guidelines after consulting with Dr. Anthony Fauci and Dr. Deborah Birx, members of the White House's coronavirus task force.
