They pointed to leading coronavirus models, which suggest that millions of Americans could become infected and up to 200,000 could die if social distancing measures are not followed. However, the models also indicate that the number of cases and deaths could be significantly lower if social distancing is maintained.

The president expressed optimism that the country's rebound from the virus will start in June, stating that he hopes the country will see "a lot of great things happening" by then. Coronavirus cases in the United States continue to rise, with over 2,000 deaths reported, according to Johns Hopkins University researchers.

State and local officials are bracing for shortages of medical equipment and supplies, with critical supplies like ventilators expected to be in high demand in the coming weeks. The president raised concerns about medical professionals potentially "hoarding" masks and ventilators, but provided no evidence to support these claims.

The administration has also highlighted the increased pace of testing, with over 894,000 tests conducted nationally as of Saturday.

Title: Islamic State Claims Responsibility for Deadly Truck Attack in New York City

Islamic State has claimed responsibility for a truck attack that killed eight people and injured a dozen others in New York City on Tuesday. The militant group described the accused attacker, Sayfullo Saipov, 29, as "one of the caliphate soldiers" in its Al-Naba newspaper.

Saipov, an Uzbek immigrant, was charged in federal court with acting in support of Islamic State by plowing a rented pickup truck down a popular riverside bike trail, crushing pedestrians and cyclists. According to the criminal complaint against him, Saipov told investigators he was inspired by Islamic State propaganda videos on his cellphone and felt good about what he had done.

Saipov was taken to Bellevue Hospital after being shot in the abdomen by a police officer before his arrest. U.S. President Donald Trump, who has called for Saipov to receive the death penalty, tweeted that Islamic State had claimed the "Degenerate Animal" who killed and wounded "the wonderful people on the West Side" of Lower Manhattan.

In the Middle East, Islamic State's self-proclaimed caliphate looked to be on the verge of defeat on Friday, with Syrian government forces seizing its last major city on one side of the border and Iraqi troops taking its last big town on the other. The group's leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, is believed to be hiding in the desert near the frontier, and regional officials fear it will reconstitute itself as a guerrilla force, capable of waging attacks without territory to defend.

Saipov's sister believes he may have been brainwashed, and she appealed to Trump to ensure he gets a fair trial. Speaking by phone from the Uzbek capital Tashkent, she told [reporter] she hoped Trump would help make sure her brother was given "more time" and "a fair trial." In a separate interview with Radio Free Europe, she said she spoke with her brother the day before the attack and he was in a good mood. "It was a usual, good conversation," she said.

Five Argentine tourists, a Belgian woman, a New Yorker, and a New Jersey man were killed in Tuesday afternoon's attack. The attack unfolded just blocks from the site of the World Trade Center, where some 2,600 people were killed when suicide hijackers crashed two jetliners into the Twin Towers 16 years ago. The Federal Bureau of Investigation has said it has located another Uzbek man, Mukhammadzoir Kadirov, 32, who it said was wanted for questioning as a person of interest in the attack.

Title: Bill Gates Warns of Future Epidemics: "We Must Prepare for Diseases That May Spread More Effectively Than Ebola"

Bill Gates, a renowned businessman and philanthropist, has sounded the alarm about the potential for future epidemics in an article published in the New England Journal of Medicine. Gates emphasized the importance of preparing for diseases that may spread more effectively than Ebola, citing the significant chance of an epidemic occurring within the next 20 years.

Gates referenced historical examples of major epidemics, including the Spanish influenza pandemic of 1918-1919 and the ongoing human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) pandemic. He noted that an epidemic stemming from either natural causes or bioterrorism poses a significant threat, potentially killing more than 10 million people worldwide.

Gates emphasized the need for a comprehensive plan to manage and coordinate responses to future epidemics, likening it to preparing for war. He stressed that a global warning and response system is necessary, with countries contributing to its development and implementation. However, some experts disagree with Gates' assessment, citing local preparedness and response as the key to preventing major epidemics.

Emmanuel d'Harcourt, senior health director of the International Rescue Committee, argued that local preparedness and response are crucial, stating that early response efforts are often led by local authorities. The World Health Organization (WHO) reported that cases of Ebola continue to occur in Sierra Leone and are on the rise in Guinea, a year after the outbreak began.

Gates' warning serves as a reminder of the importance of preparedness and cooperation in the face of potential epidemics. As the world continues to grapple with the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, it is essential to learn from past experiences and work towards developing a robust global response system to mitigate the impact of future epidemics.

Title: Media Criticism of Donald Trump's Presidential Bid

The media has been heavily critical of Donald Trump's presidential bid, with many outlets publishing scathing articles and editorials. The New York Times, in particular, has been accused of bias against Trump, with some critics claiming that the newspaper has dedicated itself to discrediting the Republican candidate.

The article highlights the media's intense scrutiny of Trump, with some outlets labeling him as "puerile," "sophomoric," and "bigoted." The author argues that the media's focus on Trump's personal attributes, rather than his policies, is a deliberate attempt to distract voters from Hillary Clinton's weaknesses.

The article also touches on Clinton's lack of conviction and ideas, stating that she has "spent her life prepping to be the Great Something or Other" and that her attempts to humanize herself as a grandmother and good neighbor are insincere. The author suggests that Clinton's willingness to adopt progressive policies, such as free college and a higher minimum wage, is driven by a desire to gain votes rather than a genuine commitment to the issues.

The article concludes by warning against the dangers of a president who is beholden to the left, citing concerns about Obamacare, tax policy, and Supreme Court appointments. The author argues that Clinton's lack of conviction and willingness to adopt progressive policies make her a poor choice for the presidency.

Overall, the article presents a critical view of the media's coverage of the presidential election, arguing that it is biased against Trump and focused on personal attacks rather than policy issues.

Title: Presidential Candidates' Vice Presidential Vetting Processes: A Look Back and Ahead

The process of selecting a running mate is a crucial part of a presidential campaign, and several candidates have taken different approaches to finding their ideal partner. In 2012, Mitt Romney narrowed his list of potential running mates from 80 to five, ultimately choosing Representative Paul Ryan. Donald Trump's vetting process was less streamlined, with Senator Joni Ernst of Iowa being one of the candidates he interviewed.

Hillary Clinton started with a list of 40 possible candidates, which was narrowed to nine who underwent a process of serious vetting, including an interview and a campaign appearance. While she considered several women to be vice president, only Senator Elizabeth Warren advanced to the final stages of the process.

In 2020, Joe Biden's campaign announced that he would select a woman as his running mate, aiming to give his ticket a modern-day balance in a party focused on issues of racial and gender representation. Past nominees have chosen running mates who provided geographic diversity or offered the promise of winning a key state. Biden's campaign hopes that announcing his selection of a woman will give his operation a shot of enthusiasm from voters, even as the presidential election heads into a deep freeze due to the coronavirus.

By choosing a woman, Biden is aiming to provide a balance to his ticket, which would also add a black woman to the ticket after black voters helped revive his campaign in February. However, the memory of Kamala Harris's debate stage attack may hinder her chances.

Title: Foxconn's Wisconsin Factory Plans in Jeopardy: A Shift from Manufacturing to Technology Hub

Foxconn, a Taiwan-based manufacturer of smartphone parts, is reconsidering its plans to build a factory in suburban Milwaukee, Wisconsin. The company had promised to create 13,000 blue-collar jobs and invest over $3 billion in the state. However, Foxconn is now likely to turn the facility into a "technology hub" with research facilities and specialized tech product production, creating "knowledge" jobs instead.

According to Louis Woo, a high-ranking assistant to Foxconn's chairman, the company is shifting its strategy because it cannot make television screens in the US and remain competitive in the global marketplace. This change in plans is a significant departure from the original promises made by former Republican Gov. Scott Walker and President Donald Trump.

Foxconn had already fallen behind its job-creation promises, with the actual number of jobs created expected to be around 1,000, far short of the original 5,200 jobs promised by the end of 2020. The company had also planned to import workers from Taiwan and China to meet its hiring goals in Wisconsin.

The problems with the Foxconn factory were evident from the start. Building television screens with relatively expensive American labor was always a major question mark, and it was unclear how the company would operate a massive manufacturing center in a location without a dense ecosystem of suppliers and sub-suppliers.

There were warning signs that Foxconn would struggle to follow through on its promises. The company had previously walked away from similar deals in India, Vietnam, and Brazil. Even in the US, there were concerns about Foxconn's ability to deliver on its promises, as seen in its failed plans to invest $30 million and create 500 jobs in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania.

The Foxconn deal was widely criticized as a bad idea from the start. Wisconsin's Legislative Fiscal Bureau calculated that it would take the state until 2043 to recoup the $3 billion handout, which was the largest such subsidy in Wisconsin history. Even if all 13,000 promised jobs went to Wisconsinites, the tab would be more than $230,000 per job created.

The deal also raises concerns about the use of eminent domain to remove residents of Mt. Pleasant, Wisconsin, where the new facility is to be built. Foxconn will receive over 1,000 acres of land for free, with the logic being that the subsequent increase in land value will pay for itself eventually in the form of higher property taxes.

The failure of the Foxconn deal serves as a warning to future politicians considering similar schemes. It is clear that the promises made by Foxconn, Walker, and Trump were overly optimistic, and the actual outcome is a significant departure from the original promises.

Title: Pet Adoption Surges in New York City and Beyond Amid COVID-19 Pandemic

The COVID-19 pandemic has brought about numerous shortages and changes in consumer behavior, but one unexpected trend has emerged: a surge in pet adoption. In the New York City area, shelters are reporting a significant increase in adoption applications, with some shelters running out of or almost out of cats and dogs. This trend is not limited to New York, as shelters in Los Angeles and other disease hotspots are also seeing a rise in animal adoptions.

According to Muddy Paws Rescue and Best Friends Animal Society, shelters they work with are experiencing a 10-fold increase in adoption applications over the past two weeks. This surge is attributed to people being ordered to stay at home and seeking companionship to alleviate boredom and anxiety. "For the moment, we don't have any dogs left to match with foster volunteers," said Anna Lai, marketing director at Muddy Paws. "Which is a great problem to have."

The demand for pets has also led to a surge in online pet food sales, with Chewy Inc. seeing a 7% increase in shares this year. PetMed Express Inc., an animal pharmaceutical company, is also outperforming, with its shares up more than 7%. Freshpet Inc. shares are down 2.3% compared to the S&P 500 Index's 23% decline.

The trend extends beyond New York, with the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals reporting a 70% increase in animals going into foster care in Los Angeles. Best Friends said many shelters it partners with across the U.S. are also reporting the same phenomenon.

While the surge in pet adoption is a welcome trend, rescue organizations are concerned about the potential for a rise in surrendered pets as many Americans lose their jobs. Shelters may be asked to take in more animals than they have room to house. "We're doing whatever we can to empty all of our shelter facilities," said Lisa LaFontaine, CEO of the Humane Rescue Alliance.

For some, the pandemic has provided an opportunity to adopt a pet. Tom Drescher and his wife, Becky Nolin, recently brought home Goldie, a 10-year-old mixed breed, and are enjoying the companionship. "It occurred to us it would be a good time to adopt a dog because we'd have the time and bandwidth to help it settle in," said Drescher. "It's been a blast for us so far – we've been thrilled to have her."

Title: FBI Investigation into Hillary Clinton's Emails Intensifies as Election Day Approaches

The FBI has obtained a warrant to search through newly discovered emails belonging to Hillary Clinton's top aide, Huma Abedin, which were found on the laptop of her estranged husband, Anthony Weiner. Weiner is currently under investigation for allegedly sexting an underage girl. The FBI's review of the emails is unlikely to be completed by Election Day, adding to the uncertainty surrounding the presidential race.

The presidential contest has tightened dramatically in recent days, with the gap between the two candidates narrowing significantly. Clinton still holds an advantage in the Electoral College, but both candidates are focusing on key swing states where the election will likely be decided.

Clinton addressed supporters at a rally in Kent, Ohio, where she expressed defiance about the email controversy. "I'm sure a lot of you may be asking what this new email story is about and why in the world the FBI would decide to jump into an election with no evidence of wrongdoing with just days to go? That's a good question," she said. "First of all, for those of you who are concerned about my use of personal email, I understand. As I said, I'm not making excuses, I understand and I regret it. They should look at them. And I'm sure they will reach the same conclusion they did when they looked at my emails for the last year. There is no case here."

Meanwhile, Republican rival Donald Trump continued to focus on Clinton's latest controversy. "Thank you, Anthony. I never liked you, Anthony, but thank you very much," Trump said. "The Clinton crime spree ends on Nov. 8. It's going to end on Nov. 8."

Clinton may face more problems in the days ahead, as WikiLeaks is reportedly set to release more hacked emails related to the presidential campaign. The organization has already caused another problem for Democratic operatives, with CNN dropping former analyst Donna Brazile after WikiLeaks revealed she had leaked a question from one of the debates in the Democratic primary to the Clinton campaign. The last week before the election could be as unpredictable as the entire campaign has been so far this year.

Title: Senate Democrats Elect Chuck Schumer as Minority Leader, Vowing to Focus on Middle Class and Economic Inequality

Washington - Senate Democrats have elected Chuck Schumer, a seasoned and charismatic New York Senator, as their new minority leader. Schumer, who has been a vocal advocate for the middle class and economic reform, emphasized the need for his party to learn from its recent electoral defeats and unite behind a stronger economic message that acknowledges the unfairness in the American economic system.

In his first remarks as minority leader, Schumer stated that he will focus on finding ways to help the middle class and those struggling to join it. He emphasized the importance of understanding the concerns of all Americans, rather than dividing the party into different factions. Schumer believes that Democrats must develop a "bigger, bolder, sharper-edged economic message" that addresses the unfairness in the system and helps middle-class Americans do better.

Schumer's election marks a change in leadership for the Democratic Party, as he replaces Harry Reid, who opted to retire rather than run for re-election. Schumer, a Brooklyn native, brings a different style to the role, with a more outgoing and telegenic presence.

Schumer's new leadership team includes Bernie Sanders of Vermont as outreach chairman, Tammy Baldwin of Wisconsin as Democratic Conference secretary, and Joe Manchin of West Virginia as vice chair of the Democratic Policy and Communications Committee. He will be negotiating with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, who was re-elected to the top leadership spot by his GOP colleagues.

Schumer's background includes a long history of advocating for middle-class Americans and addressing economic inequality. He has sponsored several notable bills, including the Omnibus Crime Bill, the Violence Against Women Act, and the Brady Bill. He was also a key player in the "gang of eight" senators who crafted a bipartisan immigration reform bill that passed the Senate in 2013.

Schumer's personal life includes being born in Brooklyn in 1950, graduating from Harvard Law School, and serving in the New York State Assembly and House of Representatives before being elected to the Senate. He and his wife, Iris Weinshall, have two grown daughters.

Title: Record Number of Voters Register for Midterm Elections as Political Engagement Surges

The 2018 midterm elections are just around the corner, and states across the United States are reporting record numbers of voters registering to cast their ballots. According to a Pew Research Center survey, 60% of Americans said their vote would be an expression of opposition to or support of President Donald Trump. This surge in political engagement comes as the country prepares to head to the polls on November 6.

The uptick in voter registration is evident across the country, with several states reporting record numbers. California's secretary of state announced that 19 million residents had registered to vote, an increase of about 1.5 million compared to the 2014 midterms. Texas also saw an 11% rise in registered voters from the previous midterms.

The increased political engagement is not limited to one party, with both Democrats and Republicans seeing higher levels of engagement. Democrats are hoping to flip 24 Republican seats to take back the majority in the House of Representatives, while Republicans are looking to expand their narrow 51-49 seat majority in the Senate.

The outcome of the elections will determine which party controls Congress and has the potential to change the course of Trump's presidency. Michael McDonald, an associate professor of political science at the University of Florida, noted that midterms are typically a referendum on the president and his party.

While it remains to be seen how many of those who registered will show up at the polls, politicians, celebrities, and other public figures have escalated their calls on voters to register as deadlines come to a close in states that could prove influential in November.

Title: Missouri Senate Candidates Debate: A Civil and Factual Discussion on Key Issues

The three Republican candidates vying for Missouri Democratic Sen. Claire McCaskill's seat engaged in a civil and informative debate on Monday night, discussing topics such as health care, federal spending, and foreign policy. The 90-minute debate at Lindenwood University in St. Charles saw Rep. Todd Akin, businessman John Brunner, and former state Treasurer Sarah Steelman answering questions and sharing their views on key issues.

Health care dominated the evening's discussion, with all three candidates expressing their desire to repeal President Obama's health care law. Mr. Brunner suggested that the system is "infested with termites" and advocated for the Medicare plan written by Rep. Paul Ryan and Sen. Ron Wyden. Mrs. Steelman proposed allowing insurers to sell across state lines and increasing access to health savings accounts. Mr. Akin, on the other hand, would dismantle the employer-based insurance system, allowing Americans to keep their coverage even when changing jobs.

When asked which parts of the federal government they would eliminate, Mr. Akin and Mrs. Steelman quickly named the Department of Education and the Environmental Protection Agency. This prompted a brief exchange between the two candidates, with Mrs. Steelman jokingly suggesting that Mr. Akin should have already cut these agencies from the budget during his time in Washington. Mr. Akin responded by saying that many Republicans are eager to make changes, but lack Democratic support.

The candidates also discussed the growing unrest in Syria, with Mrs. Steelman and Mr. Brunner expressing caution but openness to committing troops to the country. Mr. Akin, however, believed that the US should stay out of the "no-win situation."

On Social Security, all three candidates agreed that the system should be preserved for current seniors, but younger individuals should be allowed to set up private savings accounts.

The McCaskill campaign quickly responded to the debate, accusing the candidates of prioritizing Wall Street investors over seniors. The latest polls show Mr. Brunner and Mr. Akin trailing Mrs. Steelman, but all three candidates perform better against Mrs. McCaskill in hypothetical matchups. Despite the intense campaigning in recent weeks, Mr. Brunner and Mrs. Steelman did not engage in any personal attacks during the debate.

Title: US Evaluates Whether to Keep or Scrap Iran Nuclear Deal

The Trump administration is currently assessing whether to maintain or abandon the nuclear agreement with Iran, which was negotiated by the Obama administration and other world powers. The deal, aimed at halting Iran's nuclear program in exchange for relief from economic sanctions, has been criticized by President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence as a "terrible deal" that allows Iran to develop a nuclear weapon in the future.

In an interview with ABC News, Vice President Pence stated that no decisions have been made regarding the deal's fate, but emphasized that the administration is evaluating the agreement. He criticized the deal, saying it allows Iran to develop a nuclear weapon and receive hundreds of millions of dollars in cash.

The US imposed new sanctions on Iran last week after the country conducted ballistic missile tests, which were condemned by top Democrats and the White House. Senator Dianne Feinstein, a California Democrat, stated that Iran was "wrong" in conducting the tests.

House Speaker Paul Ryan, a Republican, expressed skepticism about the possibility of reimposing multilateral economic sanctions on Iran, which were lifted as part of the agreement. He noted that "a lot of that toothpaste is already out of the tube" and that it may be logistically impossible to reconstitute the sanctions.

The fate of the nuclear deal remains uncertain, as the Trump administration continues to evaluate its options.

Title: U.S. Officials Debated Definition of Boko Haram Threat in 2012, Delaying Designation as Terrorist Organization

The United States government was engaged in a behind-the-scenes debate in 2012 about how to publicly define the threat posed by Boko Haram and what actions to take in response to the growing violence in Nigeria. According to analysts and officials speaking anonymously, there was resistance to adding Boko Haram to the official list of terrorist organizations due to concerns that it would boost the group's stature and enhance its ability to recruit new members.

In June 2012, the State Department did designate three Boko Haram leaders as "global terrorists" with ties to al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb. However, despite mounting evidence of the group's growing access to military hardware and its increasing violence, the Obama administration continued to resist labeling the entire group as a terrorist organization.

Instead, the administration appeared to be considering a strategy proposed by Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan, which involved creating an amnesty program that would allow Boko Haram members to avoid prosecution in exchange for laying down their weapons. This approach had previously been used in Nigeria's Christian south with some success, but it had yielded little progress in the predominantly Muslim north, where security forces were accused of human rights violations, including the execution-style killings of detainees.

A Human Rights Watch report in October 2013 highlighted these abuses and the rapidly deteriorating situation in northern Nigeria. This report, along with the ongoing violence, ultimately led to the State Department's decision in November 2013 to officially designate Boko Haram as a terrorist organization.

The recent dispatch of U.S. and British officials to aid Nigerian authorities in rescuing the kidnapped schoolgirls remains to be seen, and it is unclear whether this will lead to a deeper U.S. involvement in the situation.

Title: Pelosi Asks Trump to Reschedule State of the Union Address Amid Government Shutdown

Article:

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has asked President Donald Trump to reschedule his State of the Union address or deliver it in writing if the government remains shuttered. In a letter to Trump on Wednesday, Pelosi cited security concerns and the fact that many government employees, including those responsible for logistics and security, are furloughed or working without pay due to the shutdown.

The partial government shutdown, now in its 26th day, is the longest in U.S. history. Trump has demanded $5.7 billion to pay for a wall along the U.S.-Mexican border and has vowed to veto any legislation that does not include the sum. Democrats oppose a wall and refuse to appropriate the money.

Pelosi pointed out that Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen has designated State of the Union addresses as a "National Special Security Event," which requires a high level of security. The Secret Service, responsible for such events, is affected by the shutdown.

Trump can deliver the speech from the Oval Office if he chooses, Pelosi said. The Department of Homeland Security and the U.S. Secret Service are fully prepared to support and secure the State of the Union, according to Pelosi.

House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy defended Trump's right to deliver the speech, saying Americans have the right to hear it. McCarthy criticized Pelosi's decision, calling it "unbecoming of the office" to disinvite the president.

The tradition of delivering the State of the Union address has evolved over time. Written addresses were once common, with the first two presidents, George Washington and John Adams, delivering annual messages to Congress in person. The practice of delivering speeches in person was revived by President Woodrow Wilson in 1913.

The U.S. Constitution requires presidents to "from time to time give to the Congress Information of the State of the Union," remarks formally known as the "Annual Message." The term "State of the Union" was officially adopted in 1947 during Harry Truman's administration.

The last president to submit only a written State of the Union was Jimmy Carter in January 1981, four days before he left office.

In other news, Trump met with the Problem Solvers Caucus, a bipartisan group of House members, to discuss the shutdown. Seven Democrats were among those who met with Trump, saying they are committed to reopening the government and finding common ground to tackle the country's toughest problems.

Title: Trump Selects Charter School Advocate Betsy DeVos as Education Secretary

President-elect Donald Trump has chosen Betsy DeVos, a charter school advocate and GOP donor from Michigan, as his Education Secretary. DeVos is the second woman to be selected for a Cabinet-level position in Trump's administration, following Nikki Haley's appointment as U.S. ambassador to the United Nations.

DeVos has been a longtime advocate for charter schools and school vouchers, and currently leads the advocacy group American Federation for Children. She also sits on the board of the Jeb Bush-led Foundation for Excellence in Education. Trump praised DeVos as a "brilliant and passionate education advocate," stating that under her leadership, the U.S. education system will be reformed and bureaucracy will be broken to deliver world-class education and school choice to all families.

However, DeVos's selection has faced criticism from some conservatives who warn that she has supported the Common Core education standards, which Trump railed against during his campaign. Frank Cannon, president of American Principles Project, called her an "establishment, pro-Common Core secretary of education," stating that it does not align with Trump's education policy.

The American Federation of Teachers' President Randi Weingarten expressed concerns about DeVos's lack of experience in the classroom or in schools, stating that her nomination makes it clear that Trump's education policy will focus on privatizing, defunding, and destroying public education in America.

On the other hand, former presidential contender Jeb Bush called DeVos an "outstanding pick" for the position, praising her long history of championing the right of all parents to choose schools that best ensure their children's success.

Trump's selection of DeVos and Haley has sparked controversy, with some critics questioning their qualifications and others praising their appointments. The appointments are subject to Senate confirmation.

Title: Former Presidents and First Ladies Gather to Honor Barbara Bush

Article: Several past residents of the White House came together to pay tribute to former First Lady Barbara Bush on Saturday. The gathering was shared on social media by the office of former President George H.W. Bush on Sunday. The event saw the attendance of former Presidents Barack Obama and Bill Clinton, along with their wives, Michelle Obama and Hillary Clinton. The Bush family members present included former Presidents George H.W. and George W. Bush, as well as former First Lady Laura Bush.

Notably absent from the gathering was President Donald Trump, who chose to watch the funeral services from his Mar-a-Lago resort in Palm Beach, Florida. The White House explained that the president's decision was made to avoid disruptions due to added security and out of respect for the Bush family and friends attending the service.

First Lady Melania Trump attended the funeral, accompanied by two White House staff members who were close to the Bush family. The staff members were George Hainey, the former White House head maitre d', and Buddy Carter, the current White House usher.

It is not uncommon for sitting presidents to skip the funerals of former first ladies, and the White House cited security concerns and respect for the Bush family as the reasons for President Trump's absence.

Title: Trump to Announce Supreme Court Pick Monday, Senate Republicans Praise Final Four Candidates

Article:

President Donald Trump is set to announce his pick to replace retiring Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy on Monday. The president has narrowed down his choices to four finalists: Brett Kavanaugh, Raymond Kethledge, Amy Coney Barrett, and Thomas Hardiman. Trump described the candidates as "excellent" and "you can't go wrong" when asked about his decision.

Senate Republicans are optimistic about the nominees, with Senator Lindsey Graham (R-SC) stating that "if you're a conservative Republican, the four named – particularly Thomas Hardiman – are all winners." Graham believes that the nominees are highly qualified and will be a winner in the eyes of the public.

However, Senate Democrats are opposed to the nomination process, citing the so-called "McConnell rule" of not voting on nominees during an election year. Senator Dick Durbin (D-IL) argued that this rule is "totally inconsistent" and that the Senate should not rush through the nomination process.

Democrats are also concerned that the nominee may be committed to overturning Roe v. Wade, a landmark abortion rights case. Senator Richard Blumenthal (D-CT) stated that the president has said he will only nominate someone who is committed to automatically overturning Roe v. Wade.

Trump's Supreme Court advisor, Leonard Leo, dismissed the Roe v. Wade conversation as a "scare tactic," noting that only one individual on the current Supreme Court has expressed a desire to overturn the decision.

In an effort to secure the nomination, Democratic leaders are targeting moderate Republicans, hoping to get them to oppose the nomination. Senator Lindsey Graham believes that red-state Democrats may be the key to securing the nomination, as they may be hesitant to oppose a highly qualified nominee.

The choice of nominee is expected to have major implications for vulnerable candidates in the midterm elections.

Title: Clinton Leads Trump by 8 Points in Latest NBC News|SurveyMonkey Poll

Article:

According to the latest NBC News|SurveyMonkey poll, Hillary Clinton has taken the lead over Donald Trump by 8 points, with 50% of registered voters supporting the Democratic nominee and 42% supporting the Republican nominee. This marks a significant shift from last week's single-point difference.

The poll, conducted online from July 25 to July 31 among 12,742 registered voters, suggests that Clinton's gains are a result of her well-received speeches at the Democratic National Convention, as well as Trump's controversial comments regarding the family of a fallen American soldier and his suggestion that Russian hackers should seek out deleted Clinton emails.

In a four-way general election match-up against Trump, Libertarian Gary Johnson, and Green Party candidate Jill Stein, Clinton now leads Trump by 5 points, a reversal from last week's 2-point lead by Trump. Support for Johnson and Stein remained virtually unchanged.

The poll also found that Clinton's favorability among Democrats and Democratic-leaning voters rose from 74% to 80%, while her unfavorable rating dropped from 24% to 19%. President Obama's job approval rating also saw a 3-point increase, with 52% of voters approving of his performance.

The Democratic National Convention, which took place last week, offered Democrats the opportunity to unite as a party. While most voters who watched or followed the convention did not view the Democratic Party more favorably as a result, half of Democrats and Democratic-leaning voters said they have a more favorable opinion of the party.

The poll results suggest that four in 10 voters said they were more interested in this year's Democratic National Convention compared to previous years, with 58% of Democrats saying they were more interested. The same number of Republicans said they were more interested in the GOP convention last week.

The NBC News|SurveyMonkey Weekly Election Tracking poll has an error estimate of plus or minus 1.2 percentage points. For full results and methodology, click here.

Title: German Police Continue Search for Perpetrator of Christmas Market Attack

Berlin police are still searching for the perpetrator of a deadly truck attack on a Christmas market in the city, which left at least 12 people dead and over 50 injured. The attack occurred on Monday evening, when a truck plowed through a crowded market outside the Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church.

German authorities have identified the truck's passenger, 37-year-old Lukasz Urban, but he has denied any involvement in the attack. No witnesses have come forward to confirm his presence at the scene, and no forensic evidence has been found linking him to the crime.

Berlin police chief Klaus Kandt warned that the true perpetrator may still be at large and could cause further harm. "We may still have a dangerous criminal out there," he said.

The attack bears similarities to the Nice truck attack in France in July, which was also claimed by the Islamic State. German authorities are investigating all possible leads and have urged the public to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activity.

The truck's owner, Ariel Zurawski, described Urban as a dedicated worker who would defend his truck to the end. "It was really clear that he was fighting for his life," Zurawski said.

Six of the 12 victims have been identified as German citizens, but the identities of the remaining six are still unknown. German Interior Minister Thomas de Maiziere said authorities have "no doubt" that the attack was intentional.

The attack has raised concerns about the safety of public gatherings and the potential for further attacks. The U.S. State Department had warned of the risk of extremist attacks on public places in Europe, particularly during the holiday season.

German Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed her shock and sadness over the attack, saying it would be "particularly sickening" if it was confirmed that the attacker was an asylum-seeker who sought refuge in Germany.

Title: Trump Mocks Christine Blasey Ford's Testimony at Mississippi Rally

Article:

At a campaign-style rally in Mississippi on Tuesday night, President Donald Trump mocked Christine Blasey Ford's testimony about her alleged sexual assault by Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh. Ford testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee last week, describing a violent sexual assault she alleges Kavanaugh committed against her in the early 1980s. Trump's remarks drew criticism from Republican Senator Jeff Flake, a key member of the committee, who called them "kind of appalling."

Trump's imitation of Ford's testimony included a series of questions, including "How did you get home?" and "How did you get there?" to which Ford replied "I don't remember." Trump's remarks were met with cheers from the crowd in Southaven, Mississippi.

Trump has been accused of sexual misconduct by at least 20 women, whom he has denied and dismissed. However, he previously called Ford a "very credible witness" and said her testimony was "very compelling."

The president's remarks were condemned by Michael Bromwich, a member of Ford's legal team, who called them a "vicious, vile, and soulless attack." Bromwich tweeted that Ford is a "remarkable profile in courage" and Trump is a "profile in cowardice."

Ford's testimony included a detailed account of the alleged assault, which she said occurred at a party in the Washington DC suburbs in the early 1980s. She accurately placed multiple people in Kavanaugh's social circle at the scene, as established by his archived calendars from the era. In contrast, Trump's portrayal of Ford's testimony was inaccurate and dismissive.

Kavanaugh has been accused of sexual assault by Ford and two other women who have spoken out publicly. The confirmation process for his nomination has been marked by controversy, with doubts about his testimony and concerns about his honesty.

Title: President Obama Vows to Continue Acting Without Congress, Seeks Partnerships to Advance Goals

President Barack Obama has reiterated his commitment to taking executive actions to advance his policy goals, stating that he will "take steps to expand opportunity for more families on my own" whenever possible. In his weekly address, the president emphasized his intention to seek partnerships with business leaders, education leaders, and philanthropic leaders to achieve his objectives.

As part of his "year of action," Obama has already demonstrated his willingness to work with CEOs, higher education institutions, and other stakeholders to accomplish his goals. For example, he recently announced an agreement with over 300 businesses, including major companies like Apple, AT&T, and Ford, to aid the long-term unemployed. Under the deal, companies will place less emphasis on job applicants' employment history and credit scores, aiming to get the long-term jobless back into the workforce.

The president has also used executive power to raise the minimum wage for federal contractors from $7.25 to $10.10, established new government-backed retirement accounts for all American workers, and taken other steps. Republicans on Capitol Hill have countered the president's executive actions by introducing legislation that they believe both sides of the aisle should support.

Representatives Gregg Harper, Martha Roby, Susan Brooks, and Fred Upton offered specific responses to the president's weekly address, highlighting bills that aim to address issues like prioritizing research funding, allowing workers to use overtime for paid time off, and consolidating federal training programs. Republicans believe these bills can help spur new cooperation with the president and slow down the wave of executive actions.

The president's "year of action" has sparked a debate about the balance of power between the executive and legislative branches. While Obama has emphasized his commitment to taking bold action, Republicans have countered with legislation that they believe can achieve similar goals. As the year progresses, it remains to be seen whether the president's executive actions will be met with cooperation or resistance from Congress.

Title: Democratic Candidates' Apologies and Confessions: A Test of Free Society

Article:

The concept of living in a free society can be tested by asking a simple question: Are you allowed to express obviously true statements in public, or are you forced to lie? George Orwell's quote from "1984" highlights the importance of freedom, stating that "freedom is the freedom to say that two plus two make four." However, what if this freedom is not granted? What if you are required to repeat statements that are not true, and everyone knows it, but cannot express their disagreement?

The current Democratic presidential primary is a prime example of this phenomenon. Pete Buttigieg, a candidate in the race, previously stated that "all lives matter." He said it because it is true, but in the modern Democratic Party, this statement is no longer acceptable. As a result, Buttigieg recently apologized for his "wrongthink."

Beto O'Rourke, another candidate, was asked about a harmless joke he once told about his wife staying home to raise their kids. O'Rourke became emotional and apologized for his past actions, even going so far as to apologize for being born. This is reminiscent of Maoist tribunals during the Cultural Revolution.

Most Democratic presidential candidates have had to face similar inquisitions, writing confessions of guilt and begging for forgiveness on social media. Kirsten Gillibrand, for example, expressed sympathy for the idea of a closed border in the past, but now regrets her stance. This is not liberal, but rather authoritarian, as it prioritizes obedience over ideas and punishes dissent.

The latest example of this phenomenon is the Democratic candidates' support for Al Sharpton, a low-grade mafia figure, being hailed as a legitimate civil rights leader. They recently visited his tax-exempt organization to pretend he is the new Martin Luther King Jr. However, it is worth noting that none of these candidates were aware of Sharpton's past actions, such as denouncing a Jewish landlord in Harlem as a "white interloper" shortly before his store was firebombed and eight people were killed.

The question is not whether we will get reparations, but whether we want to live in a country where people like Sharpton have political power, where humor and dissent are criminal acts, and where lying is the currency of public life. This is a world we have seen before, and it is called Twitter. Imagine if it had control of the U.S. military.

Title: Pragmatic Paul: A Study in Contrasting Votes

Article:

Representative Paul Ryan, known for his pragmatic approach to politics, has recently made headlines with his votes on two separate bills. On one hand, he voted with President Obama and most of his Republican colleagues to raise taxes on wealthy Americans and add $4 trillion to the national debt. On the other hand, he opposed a bill that would have allowed the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) to take on $9.7 billion in new debt to help those affected by Hurricane Sandy.

Ryan's stance on the Sandy bill was not surprising, as he had previously expressed concerns about the program's debt and called for reforms. In a statement, he emphasized the need to help those affected by the hurricane, but criticized the bill for not prioritizing disaster relief over pork-barrel spending.

Ryan's vote on the fiscal cliff bill, which aimed to prevent the country from going over the fiscal cliff, was also notable. He had previously spoken out against some of the extraneous items in the legislation and stated that it would be irresponsible to raise the debt ceiling without making necessary reforms.

Ryan's spokesperson, Kevin Seifert, attributed his votes to his commitment to voting his conscience. However, some political strategists believe that Ryan's votes could be used against him in future elections. Republican strategist Ron Bonjean noted that the votes could be explained as a pragmatic approach to governance, with Ryan prioritizing protecting 98% of taxpayers and seeking to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse.

Bonjean also pointed out that the Sandy relief bill ultimately passed with a significant majority, and that Ryan's vote on the fiscal cliff bill was part of a larger effort to address the country's debt and spending issues. As the debate over the debt ceiling looms, it remains to be seen whether Ryan will take a more vocal role in the discussion.

Title: Fox News Goes Silent on Twitter Amid Boycott Over Harassment of Host Tucker Carlson

Fox News has been silent on Twitter since November 8, refraining from posting any updates on its official accounts, including the Fox Business Network and a few other official feeds. The network's decision to boycott Twitter comes after a group of demonstrators posted Tucker Carlson's home address on the social media platform, leading to a safety concern for the host. Fox News has expressed frustration with Twitter's response to the harassment, claiming the platform did not respond quickly enough to requests to remove the offending tweets.

The boycott, which has now entered its third week, has not been publicly explained by Fox News, leaving many wondering what the network hopes to achieve by avoiding the platform. According to analytics tracker SimilarWeb, about 1.4% of FoxNews.com's traffic came from Twitter in October, with nearly 70% coming from direct clicks on the site. This suggests that Twitter is not a crucial source of traffic for the network.

Raju Narisetti, a Columbia Journalism School professor and former senior vice president at News Corp, notes that Twitter is not a significant revenue driver for Fox News or News Corp. "It is a good megaphone and helpful for breaking news discovery and some brand building, but not sure any major media company thinks of its use/non-use as a major revenue issue per se," he said.

Despite the boycott, some Fox News employees and former executives are perplexed by the network's decision to remain silent. "It's weird that a news organization would do a silent boycott," said one former executive. "It's like having a protest inside your bedroom and not telling anybody."

The boycott has also raised questions about the potential impact on the network's promotion of its new subscription streaming service, Fox Nation, which launched on Tuesday. With Fox News's Twitter feed capable of reaching 18.3 million followers, some had expected the network to use the platform to promote the new service. However, Fox News and Twitter declined to comment on the matter.

Fox News's owner, Rupert Murdoch, has been a vocal critic of social media platforms like Twitter, which he believes benefit greatly from news publishers' content without offering enough in return. In January, he declared that Facebook and Google should pay publishers for the right to use their links. The boycott may be seen as a way for Fox News to express its frustration with Twitter's perceived unfairness.

Title: Google's President of Media Matters Has a Checkered Online Past

Article:

The article discusses the online past of David Carusone, the president of Media Matters, a conservative organization. According to a report by Daily Caller News Foundation reporter Peter Hasson, Carusone's now-defunct blog included inflammatory language and derogatory comments towards certain groups, including transgender individuals, Jews, and Bangladeshis.

The article highlights specific examples of Carusone's past writings, including a 2005 post that used derogatory language to describe a Bangladeshi man who was robbed by a group of transgender individuals. Carusone also made comments about "tranny bars" and "tranny lovers," which are considered offensive and hurtful.

The article notes that this is not the first time that a prominent figure has been accused of having a checkered online past. It references the controversy surrounding Brett Kavanaugh's hiring of lawyers who had previously defended him against allegations of sexual assault, as well as the resignation of a #MeToo organization leader who defended her son against allegations of sexual misconduct.

The article concludes by noting that a consistent free-speech stance has multiple virtues, including preserving a culture of free expression and allowing individuals to opt out of the "gotcha game" that focuses on vengeance and punishment rather than meaningful debate.

Title: Trump's Budget Priorities: Defense and Immigration Enforcement Take Center Stage

Article:

The White House has released a preview of President Donald Trump's second budget, which outlines "an aggressive set of spending reforms" aimed at reducing the deficit by $3 trillion over a decade. According to White House budget chief Mick Mulvaney, the budget "makes hard choices: fund what we must, cut where we can, and reduce what we borrow." However, critics argue that the language of "hard choices" is dishonest, as the budget prioritizes defense spending and immigration enforcement while cutting programs that benefit middle- and working-class families.

The budget includes a significant boost to the Pentagon, aimed at creating a "ready, larger, and more lethal military." Additionally, it allocates funds for border security and Immigration and Customs Enforcement's (ICE) ability to detain and imprison immigrants. While the budget does address the opioid crisis, it focuses on law enforcement approaches rather than treatment and recovery.

The budget's priorities are not surprising, given Trump's previous statements and actions. The White House has emphasized the need for a "hard-nosed" approach to budgeting, which has led to cuts in programs that benefit low-income families, such as Medicaid and food stamps. The budget's focus on defense spending and immigration enforcement has been met with criticism from those who argue that it prioritizes the interests of corporations and wealthy individuals over those of the general public.

It is worth noting that the budget's language of "hard choices" is misleading, as the Republican-led Congress has already made the choice to give corporations and wealthy individuals a significant tax break, which has contributed to the deficit. The Trump administration's budget choices are a reflection of these priorities, and the impact will be felt by middle- and working-class families who rely on government programs for support.

Title: Senator Dick Durbin Apologizes to Senator Tim Scott Over Police Reform Bill Criticism

Article:

Senator Dick Durbin, the Senate minority whip, apologized to Senator Tim Scott, the Senate's only black Republican, after criticizing Scott's police reform bill as a "token, half-hearted approach" during a Senate Judiciary Committee meeting on Capitol Hill. Durbin's communications director, Emily Hampsten, stated that Durbin sought out Scott on the floor and apologized after realizing he had offended him.

Durbin's criticism was aimed at Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, who he believes is not doing enough to address systemic racism and police brutality. Durbin argued that addressing these issues requires more than just one Judiciary hearing, one floor vote, or one conversation. He emphasized the need for meaningful change to prevent the killing of Black Americans by police officers.

Senator Scott responded to Durbin's remarks in a tweet, referencing the African kente cloths worn by some Senate Democrats earlier this month to show solidarity with Black Americans. Scott also expressed disappointment and hurt over Durbin's comments, which he believes undermine the opportunity to restore hope and confidence among African Americans and communities of color.

Title: Sen. Cory Booker Releases Additional "Confidential" Documents from Brett Kavanaugh's Time as White House Lawyer

Sen. Cory Booker (D-N.J.) has released two new batches of "confidential" documents from Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh's time as a White House lawyer during the George W. Bush administration. The documents, totaling 26 pages, are marked "committee confidential" and have not been cleared for public release or discussion.

The releases bring the total number of "confidential" documents released by Booker to five. The documents include a four-page tranche in which Kavanaugh attempts to set up a meeting with Manny Miranda, a then-GOP Senate aide who was accused of hacking Democratic files. In another 22-page tranche, Kavanaugh forwards an op-ed in 2003 describing Roe v. Wade as a "bad law," adding that it is "interesting" to read.

Booker's move has sparked a rhetorical firefight, with Republicans implying that he is breaking Senate rules in an effort to bolster his potential 2020 White House ambitions. Sen. John Cornyn (R-Texas) stated that "running for president is no excuse for violating the rules of the Senate" and encouraged colleagues to avoid treating witnesses unfairly.

A spokesman for the Republican National Committee blasted Booker's actions, saying that he "can't keep his grandstanding straight." However, Booker has defended his decision, arguing that the document process set up by Republicans on the Judiciary panel is a "sham" and that the American people should be outraged that critical documents are being kept hidden from the public.

Title: Trump Hires Giuliani to Bolster Legal Team as Russia Probe Nears Completion

The White House has announced that Rudy Giuliani, a longtime supporter of President Donald Trump, will join his legal team to help navigate the ongoing Russia investigation. Giuliani, a former US attorney, will focus on the Russia probe as the White House aims to bring the investigation to a close.

According to Trump's personal attorney, Jay Sekulow, Giuliani will be a fierce defender of the president in the media. The president himself stated that he wants to "get the investigation over with, done with, put it behind us and we have to get back to business." In recent days, Trump has appeared more relaxed about the investigation, suggesting he has put the notion of firing Special Counsel Robert Mueller or Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein on the back burner.

Last week, Rosenstein told the president that he is not the target of any part of the special counsel's investigation or the probe into his longtime lawyer, Michael Cohen. Trump has maintained that he has been transparent throughout the investigation, providing 1.4 million pages of documents to the special counsel.

Meanwhile, the Department of Justice has given Congress copies of several of James Comey's infamous memos, written while he was director of the FBI. The memos detail Comey's accounts of his meetings with President Trump before he was fired. In a joint statement, the chairmen of three congressional committees noted that the memos show that Trump made clear he wanted allegations of collusion, coordination, and conspiracy between his campaign and Russia fully investigated.

Trump has tweeted that the memos prove what he has said all along, stating that there was no collusion and no obstruction. The investigation is expected to continue, with Giuliani's addition to the legal team likely to be a key factor in the White House's efforts to bring the investigation to a close.

Title: ICE Conducts "Enforcement Surge" in Los Angeles and Other Cities, Arresting Over 160 Undocumented Immigrants

The Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agency has conducted an "enforcement surge" in the Los Angeles area over the past five days, arresting more than 160 undocumented immigrants. This increased activity has also been reported in several other cities, including Atlanta, Phoenix, Charlotte, and Austin. While ICE officials and the White House have described the actions as routine, immigration activists and lawyers have expressed concerns about the sudden and widespread nature of the arrests.

According to immigration attorney Sarah Owings, ICE agents have been conducting door-to-door searches in apartment buildings in the Atlanta area, asking residents to show proof of legal residency. Owings estimates that over 40 undocumented immigrants have been detained in the Savannah, Georgia, area over the past two days.

ICE officials have denied reports of "checkpoints" and "random sweeps," calling them "false, dangerous, and irresponsible." However, immigration activists and lawmakers have expressed concerns about the agency's motives, with some suggesting that the increased enforcement may be a response to President Trump's recent defeat in the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals, which blocked his travel ban.

Rep. Raúl Grijalva, a Democrat from Arizona, has expressed skepticism about ICE's claims, stating that there is "not much" confidence in the agency's statements. Bob Libal, executive director of Grassroots Leadership, estimates that around two dozen undocumented immigrants were arrested by ICE agents in Austin over the past two days.

The increased enforcement activity has sparked concerns among immigration activists, who point to President Trump's executive order on immigration as the impetus behind the surge. The order, titled "Enhancing Public Safety in the Interior of the United States," made undocumented immigrants a priority for deportation.

Title: Brazil's President Blames NGOs for Amazon Fires, Despite Lack of Evidence

Article:

Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro has stated that his government lacks the resources to fight the thousands of fires in the Amazon rainforest, and has again suggested that non-governmental organizations (NGOs) may be responsible for the blazes. However, he admitted that he has no evidence to support this claim.

The Amazon rainforest, the world's largest, is a vital carbon store that slows down the pace of global warming. Satellite data published by the National Institute for Space Research (INPE) shows an increase of 85% this year in fires across Brazil, most of which are in the Amazon region.

Bolsonaro's comments have sparked anger among those concerned about the rapid deforestation of the Amazon, which has accelerated since he took office. The president has been accused of encouraging the clearing of land by loggers and farmers, which has led to a significant increase in deforestation.

The Brazilian Environment Minister, Ricardo Salles, was heckled at a meeting on climate change, with some attendees booing and shouting "The Amazon region is burning." The conference, organized by the United Nations, aims to promote action on climate change in the region.

Satellite data shows that there have been more than 75,000 fires in Brazil so far this year, compared to just over 40,000 in 2018. The figures are the highest since 2010. The Amazon is home to about three million species of plants and animals, and one million indigenous people.

The US space agency, NASA, has stated that overall fire activity in the Amazon basin is slightly below average this year. However, the region is still experiencing a significant increase in fires, which are often deliberately started in efforts to illegally deforest land for cattle ranching.

The Brazilian government has been criticized for its handling of the situation, with many accusing it of prioritizing development over conservation. The Amazon rainforest is a vital component of the global ecosystem, and its destruction could have severe consequences for the planet.

Title: Trump Poised to Shape Supreme Court with Second Nomination

Article:

Washington, D.C. - With the retirement of Justice Anthony Kennedy, President Donald Trump is set to make a second Supreme Court nomination, potentially cementing conservative control of the court and influencing the direction of social issues. The selection process is expected to begin immediately, with Trump aiming to appoint a justice who will be on the court for decades to come.

According to White House officials, Trump sees this opportunity as a chance to shape the court's direction and further his agenda. The selection of a social conservative to replace Kennedy could lead to a reliable 5-4 majority on the Supreme Court, even on hot-button social issues.

While Trump did not make rolling back abortion rights a central plank of his campaign, many conservative voters want Roe v. Wade overturned, and Trump promised to put anti-abortion justices on the Supreme Court. However, picking an ultra-conservative nominee could carry risks, as Trump would need to rely on moderate Republicans to win approval in the Senate.

White House officials believe the timing of the nomination could help boost conservative voters' enthusiasm and turnout at congressional elections in November, as Republicans fight to maintain control of both houses of Congress.

The Supreme Court has already handed Trump several wins in recent weeks, including upholding his travel ban and repeatedly ruling in his favor on 5-4 votes. With Kennedy's retirement, the court's sharply divided justices have an opportunity to shape the country's laws and policies.

Trump has already made a significant impact on the federal judiciary, appointing 21 judges to influential federal appeals courts and 20 District Court judges. His selection of Neil Gorsuch, a conservative justice, was seen as a key factor in rallying conservatives behind his presidential election campaign in 2016.

Trump has expressed his excitement about the new opportunity to reshape the federal judiciary in a conservative direction, stating that the search for a new justice will begin immediately. The selection process is expected to be swift, with an eye to getting the new justice confirmed by the Senate in the autumn.

Title: Iowa Poll: Trump Edges Out Democrat Frontrunners in Head-to-Head Matchups

A recent Emerson College poll in Iowa has shown that President Trump is leading Democrat frontrunners Sen. Elizabeth Warren and Joe Biden in hypothetical general election matchups. The poll, conducted from October 13-16, 2019, among 888 registered voters in Iowa, found that Trump bested both Warren and Biden with 51% of the vote, compared to their 49%.

In a hypothetical matchup against Trump, Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-VT) appeared to hold an advantage, leading the president by two points, 51% to 49%. The margin of error is +/-3.2%, indicating that the race is still in flux.

The poll also showed that Warren and Biden are tied with 23% support each, followed by Mayor Pete Buttigieg (D) with 16% support. Sanders fell to fourth place with 13% support, followed by Andrew Yang (D), Gov. Steve Bullock (D), and Sen. Cory Booker (D-NJ) with 5%, 4%, and 3% support, respectively.

The results highlighted the most trouble for Sen. Kamala Harris (D-CA), who has tried to revive her floundering campaign by focusing on Iowa. Despite her efforts, she was only able to garner 2% support in the state, alongside Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D-HI) and Tom Steyer (D).

The poll also found that more Iowans oppose impeachment than support it, with 48% opposing it and 42% supporting it. Impeachment does not appear to be a top priority among Iowans, with only 6% considering it an important factor in choosing whom to support for president. Thirty-three percent said the economy, 19% said health care, and 10% chose "social issues" as their top priority.

"The Democrats have some work to do in Iowa convincing voters that impeachment is a top priority of Congress; 67% of Democrats in Iowa support impeaching the president, but only 10% identify it as the most important issue in deciding their vote for president," Emerson Polling Director Spencer Kimball said.

Title: Obama Weighs in on Marijuana Legalization: "Not More Dangerous Than Cigarettes"

Article:

In a recent interview with The New Yorker, former President Barack Obama shared his thoughts on marijuana legalization, citing his own experiences as a young person who experimented with the drug. Obama stated that he does not encourage marijuana use and views it as a "bad habit and a vice," similar to his own past use of cigarettes. However, he also acknowledged that marijuana is not more dangerous than alcohol or cigarettes in terms of its impact on the individual consumer.

The president expressed concern about the disproportionate incarceration rates of minorities and those in poverty for marijuana-related offenses, noting that middle-class kids are less likely to face consequences for using the drug. He also highlighted the hypocrisy of individuals who write and enforce laws receiving lenient treatment while those who break them face harsher penalties.

Regarding the legalization of marijuana in Colorado and Washington state, Obama emphasized the importance of moving forward with the process. He noted that it is crucial for society to address the issue of unequal enforcement and punishment, stating, "It's important for it to go forward." However, he also cautioned that legalization may lead to tougher debates on harder drugs and raised concerns about the potential for "finely calibrated doses" of drugs like cocaine and methamphetamine.

Overall, Obama's comments on marijuana legalization reflect his nuanced and balanced approach to the issue, acknowledging both the potential risks and benefits of the drug.

Title: The Left's Prioritization of Symbolic Battles Over Real Evil

The article argues that the Left has a tendency to focus on fighting lesser evils or perceived evils, rather than confronting the greatest evils in the world. The author claims that this is a characteristic that has been consistent throughout history, from the Left's lack of support against Communism to its current stance against Islamism. The Left, according to the author, labels those who fight against these evils as "cold warriors" or "Islamophobes," and instead focuses on fighting those who fight against these evils.

The article also highlights the Left's tendency to prioritize symbolic battles over real evil. The author notes that the Left has been quick to condemn racism and sexism in America, but fails to address the same issues in other parts of the world. The article also mentions the Left's focus on fighting Nazis and white supremacists, despite their negligible numbers and lack of power.

The author concludes that the Left's priorities are driven by a desire to feel good about their own morality, rather than a genuine commitment to fighting evil. They argue that the Left's focus on lesser evils and made-up evils is a way to avoid confronting the real evil in the world, such as totalitarian Islamism.

The article presents a critical analysis of the Left's priorities and actions, highlighting the perceived inconsistencies and contradictions in their stance on various issues.

Title: Congress to Vote on Keystone XL Pipeline Amid Controversy

The United States Congress is set to vote on two bills that would authorize the construction of the Keystone XL pipeline, a project that has been a contentious issue in the country. The bills, sponsored by Senator Mary Landrieu (D-La.) and Representative Bill Cassidy (R-La.), are expected to be voted on in the coming days.

The Keystone XL pipeline, which would carry tar sands oil from Canada to Texas, has been a polarizing issue, with proponents arguing that it would create thousands of jobs and opponents claiming that it would increase greenhouse gas emissions and damage the environment. The pipeline has been a key issue in Louisiana, where the oil and gas industry plays a significant role.

The project has been stalled since 2011, when the Obama administration announced that it would not approve the pipeline until further review. The administration has since stated that it prefers to evaluate the pipeline through a long-stalled State Department review, rather than through legislative action.

The vote on the Keystone XL pipeline comes as Senator Landrieu and Representative Cassidy face off in a runoff election on December 6. The two have taken different stances on the issue, with Landrieu calling for action on the pipeline and Cassidy supporting its construction.

The pipeline has also faced opposition from landowners along its proposed route, who have expressed concerns about the potential disruption to their property and the potential for environmental damage. In February, a Nebraska judge struck down a 2012 law that allowed part of the pipeline to run through the state.

The White House has expressed its skepticism about the pipeline, with Press Secretary Josh Earnest stating that President Barack Obama takes a "dim view" of legislative efforts to force action on the project. The administration has reiterated its preference for evaluating the pipeline through a long-stalled State Department review.

Title: Vanessa Trump Speaks Out About Being Rushed to Hospital After Opening Envelope with White Powder

Vanessa Trump, the wife of Donald Trump Jr. and mother of five, has spoken publicly for the first time about being rushed to the hospital after opening an envelope containing white powder addressed to her husband in February. The incident occurred at the Trump family's New York City residence, where she was joined by two other individuals who were also present at the time.

According to Vanessa Trump's statement to Axios, she felt sick and started coughing after opening the envelope, fearing the substance could be deadly. The authorities later determined the substance to be cornstarch. She was hospitalized for two weeks, during which time she was treated with antibiotics and underwent testing to determine whether the powder was harmful.

In her statement, Vanessa Trump expressed her personal connection to the recent bomb scares targeting prominent Democrats, stating, "This is personal for me because I know firsthand what it is like to be targeted and terrorized by a coward with a vendetta." She also condemned the recent acts of terrorism, saying, "These recent acts are the acts of a coward and nothing more than terrorism, pure and simple. No one, regardless of political party or ideology, should ever have to go through what I went through."

Donald Trump Jr. responded to his wife's statement on Twitter, expressing pride in her decision to share her story and emphasizing that these acts of terrorism are not limited to one political party. He also condemned all violence and thanked his wife for sharing her experience.

In related news, Daniel Frisiello, the individual accused of sending the envelope containing white powder and a threatening note to Trump Jr., pleaded guilty earlier this month. He will be sentenced in January and has agreed not to appeal his sentence if it is 7 1/4 years or less.

Title: India's Ruling Party Accused of Mocking Anti-Citizenship Law Protesters

India's governing Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has sparked controversy with a tweet posted by its Karnataka unit, which critics say mocks a phrase used by protesters against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA). The tweet, which has gained over 31,000 likes and been retweeted over 10,000 times, reads: "Keep the documents safe, you will need to show them again during the NPR exercise."

The phrase "Kaaghaz Nahi Dikhayenge Hum" (We will not show the documents) has become a rallying cry for protesters against the CAA, which critics argue is discriminatory towards Muslims. The CAA, passed by Parliament in December, fast-tracks citizenship for non-Muslims from three neighboring countries.

The tweet has been criticized by many, including senior journalist Suhasini Haider, who called it "utterly crude" and "disgraceful." Gazala Wahab, an assistant professor at JNU's Centre for the Study of Law and Governance, said the tweet's tone is "against everything India stands for."

The BJP's Karnataka unit has faced criticism before for controversial tweets. Last month, it posted a tweet comparing a JNU student to a gunman who fired at protesters near Jamia Millia Islamia university in New Delhi.

Some BJP supporters have also expressed disappointment with the tone of the tweet, with Amrita Bhinder, a vocal supporter of the BJP and former member of the Bharatiya Janata Yuva Morcha, saying it "adds to the fear factor" and "derails PM Modi's pitch."

The controversy comes as the government has yet to decide on the implementation of the National Register of Citizens (NRC), but wants to go ahead with the National Population Register (NPR), which critics say is a precursor to the NRC. The NPR exercise is meant to identify and verify the citizenship of all individuals living in India.

The CAA and NPR have sparked widespread protests across the country, with nearly 30 people having died in the anti-CAA protests so far. Critics argue that the laws are discriminatory and go against India's secular constitution.

Title: Senators Introduce Bill to Improve Long-Term Budget Planning and Transparency

Article:

Two senators, John Thune and Tim Kaine, have introduced a bill aimed at improving the long-term budget planning and transparency in Washington. The Intergenerational Financial Obligations Reform Act (INFORM) would require the administration and Congress to analyze the long-term effects of their budget decisions and provide a detailed accounting of how they will impact future generations.

The senators argue that current budget planning only looks at the next 10 years, neglecting the long-term consequences of policy decisions. They believe that this lack of transparency and accountability has led to a fiscal gap that burdens future generations with unknown financial burdens. The INFORM Act would require the Government Accountability Office to provide an annual analysis of the impact of future budget realities on generations to come and account for any fiscal gaps.

The bill would also require the president to provide a detailed accounting of how the administration's budget and policy recommendations would affect young people down the line. This approach, known as generational accounting and fiscal gap analysis, would examine the full scope of the government's obligations, present and future, and then look at the effect those obligations will have on current and future generations.

The senators believe that this approach will help improve the fiscal health of the country and provide young Americans with a better understanding of the decisions made by lawmakers today. They argue that it is time for Washington to stop kicking the can down the road and start being honest about the long-term challenges facing future generations.

Title: Remote Work Becomes Permanent for Many as Pandemic Forces Companies to Adapt

The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the shift towards remote work, with many companies extending their work-from-home policies until the end of the year. This sudden mass migration of the white-collar workforce has raised questions about whether some workers will ever return to the office. Industry experts believe that a significant portion of workers will never come back, citing the benefits of remote work, including reduced commuting time and expenses, increased productivity, and more opportunities to spend time with family.

Large companies, particularly in the tech sector, have already made permanent remote work arrangements available to their employees. Twitter became the first major firm to allow employees to work from home permanently, if they choose. The pandemic has forced companies to tackle the expense and logistical challenges that may have been barriers to broad work-from-home policies.

While some experts believe that remote work will become permanent, others are skeptical. They argue that extended periods of remote work could result in a surge in depression and loneliness, and that certain industries that rely on creativity and problem-solving may suffer without in-person collaboration. Some firms may also be reluctant to surrender the control that comes with having all employees in the same place.

The pandemic has shown that people can effectively work from home, and companies are expected to continue allowing many employees to do so for a long time. The economic impact of the pandemic will likely force many employers to cut costs, making remote work an attractive option. Executives and managers can also benefit from remote work, as they can value quality over quantity of work and prioritize creative ideas that emerge outside of the office.

However, high unemployment may reduce workers' power to insist on working from home. As the job market tightens, companies may not feel the need to offer remote work options, and employees may be forced to choose between their personal safety and job security.

Overall, the pandemic has accelerated the shift towards remote work, and it is likely that many companies will continue to allow employees to work from home for the foreseeable future.

Title: Trump Accepts North Korean Invitation for Historic Summit, But Cautious Approach Needed

The article discusses President Trump's decision to accept an invitation from North Korean leader Kim Jong Un for a historic summit, which could potentially lead to a major breakthrough in the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. The author, a former foreign policy strategist, emphasizes the importance of caution and careful consideration in the negotiations.

The article highlights the significance of the meeting, comparing it to historic events such as President Nixon's visit to China and the collapse of the Soviet Union.
