Republican lawmakers have raised concerns about whether organizations and navigator personnel have been properly vetted. Sen. John Cornyn, Texas Republican, said it is astounding that the administration is urging the American people to give their Social Security numbers and sensitive personal information to people who have not been properly vetted.

The grant has also raised questions about the role of lobbying firms in the healthcare industry. The firm's principal, Priscilla Chatman, works for the Livingston Group, another lobbying firm, on behalf of Rush University Medical Center in Chicago. The firm has lobbied on behalf of the hospital on various issues, including the Affordable Care Act.

Title: The Case Against Social Media Censorship: A Free Market Perspective

The recent decision by YouTube to remove conservative commentator Steven Crowder from their Partner Program has sparked a debate about the role of social media companies in policing online content. While some argue that these companies have the right to regulate their platforms, others believe that this move is a form of censorship that stifles free speech. In this article, we will examine the free market perspective on social media censorship and why it is essential to protect the rights of all users, regardless of their political beliefs.

The argument against social media censorship is rooted in the concept of "bigger is better" economics. Just as electric utilities are required to provide power to all customers willing to pay the standard price, social media companies should not be allowed to discriminate against certain users based on their political beliefs. This is because social media platforms benefit from network externalities, where the value of the platform is proportional to the number of customers on it. This makes it difficult for new entrants to establish a rival platform, giving social media giants a significant advantage.

Moreover, social media companies are not like electric utilities, which provide a necessary service. While power is essential for daily life, social media is a luxury that many people can live without. This means that social media companies have no inherent right to dictate what content is acceptable or not.

Some may argue that social media companies have the right to remove content that is offensive or disruptive. However, this is a slippery slope. If social media companies can remove content based on their own subjective standards, they can also remove content that is critical of their own policies or those of their allies. This is why it is essential to have laws in place to prevent viewpoint discrimination.

In conclusion, the free market perspective on social media censorship is clear: social media companies should not be allowed to discriminate against certain users based on their political beliefs. This is not only a matter of free speech, but also a matter of economic competition and the protection of individual rights.

Title: Intelligence Community Warned of Coronavirus Threat in January and February, Reports Show

The intelligence community was aware of the danger posed by the novel coronavirus as early as January and February, according to reports. However, the White House was slow to take action, with some officials stating that the administration was slow to make test kits available and ceded much of the response to state governments.

U.S. officials familiar with spy agency reporting told The Washington Post that the reports did not provide specific information on when the virus might spread in the U.S. or recommend specific steps to prevent an outbreak. However, they did track the international spread of the coronavirus and warned that China was initially dismissing the seriousness of the situation.

While President Trump did take early action to close the border to any travelers from China, where the coronavirus first appeared, the White House was slow to respond to the threat. Intelligence agencies have been warning about the virus since January, according to a U.S. official who had access to intelligence reporting.

The White House has defended the president's response, dismissing claims that the administration was caught flat-footed and insisting that Trump took early and significant action. However, some officials have criticized the administration's response, stating that it was slow to make test kits available and ceded much of the response to state governments.

It is worth noting that the exact timeline of the administration's response to the coronavirus is still being debated, and more information is needed to fully understand the situation.

Title: Trump Defends Decision to Withdraw US Forces from Syria, Visits Troops in Iraq

President Donald Trump visited American servicemen and women in western Iraq on Wednesday, where he defended his decision to withdraw US forces from Syria. Trump stated that the US is "no longer the suckers" and is now respected again as a nation, citing military gains as the reason for the withdrawal. He emphasized that the US presence in Syria was not meant to be "open-ended" and that other wealthy nations should take responsibility for rebuilding the country.

During his visit, Trump also announced that Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has agreed to take out any remaining Islamic State (IS) remnants in Syria. The US has been working with Turkey to combat IS, and Trump's decision to withdraw troops has raised concerns about the potential for extremist groups to fill the vacuum.

The US has been involved in the fight against IS in Syria since 2014, with around 2,000 troops currently stationed in the country. Trump's decision to withdraw these forces has been met with criticism from some quarters, including Defense Secretary Jim Mattis, who resigned in protest.

Trump's trip to Iraq was shrouded in secrecy, with Air Force One flying overnight from Washington to an airbase west of Baghdad under the cover of darkness. The visit marked Trump's first trip to a troubled region since taking office, and he used the occasion to emphasize his support for the US military.

The US still has around 5,000 troops stationed in Iraq, where they are supporting the government in its fight against remaining IS pockets. The terrorist group has lost significant territory in Iraq and Syria, but is still seen as a threat. Trump's decision to withdraw US forces from Syria has raised concerns about the potential for IS to regroup and launch attacks in the region.

Title: Registered Nurses Speak Out Against Police Violence and "Less Lethal" Weapons

Registered nurse Asantewaa Boykin, a volunteer medic in Sacramento, California, was recently caught in the midst of a protest-turned-chaotic scene when police fired tear gas at protesters, causing them to flee. Boykin, who has worked in the emergency department at Sacramento's UC Davis Medical Center, found herself overcome by the gas. As a protest medic, she has seen firsthand the devastating effects of police violence on protesters, including fractured skulls, abrasions, and injuries from projectiles.

Boykin, along with other registered nurses, is speaking out against the use of "less lethal" weapons, such as tear gas and stun grenades, which have been used against protesters nationwide. These weapons can cause serious harm, including burns, hearing loss, and temporary blindness. Rubber bullets, which often have metal cores, have also been responsible for deaths and serious injuries.

Nurses have seen these violent police tactics before, including during deployments to Occupy Wall Street, Standing Rock, and the U.S.-Mexico border. At Standing Rock in 2016, nurses met Vanessa Dundon, whose eye was shot out by a tear gas canister fired by police. Similarly, Brandon Saenz's eye was recently shot out with "less lethal ammunition" at a May 30 Dallas protest, and freelance photographer Linda Tirado's eye was shot out by a foam bullet at a May 29 Minneapolis protest.

As advocates for public health and safety, registered nurses are calling for an end to police violence and the use of "less lethal" weapons. Heather Honstein, a cardiovascular surgical ICU nurse at Washington D.C.'s MedStar Washington Hospital, was among protesters gathered peacefully in Lafayette Square near the White House on June 1. She left around 6 p.m., 30 minutes before federal police violently dispersed peaceful crowds, using gas canisters, grenades, and significant force.

Nurses know what it takes to keep patients safe, and violence and "less lethal" weapons are not the answer. The use of force against protesters exercising their constitutional right to assembly is a threat to democracy and a colossal waste of public resources that would be better spent on public health and other social programs.

Title: US and China Agree to 90-Day Ceasefire in Trade War, Pledge to Reduce Tariffs and Improve Trade Relations

The United States and China have agreed to a 90-day ceasefire in their trade war, with both sides pledging to reduce tariffs and improve trade relations. The agreement was reached during a meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping on Saturday.

According to White House officials, China has committed to reducing its 40% tariffs on autos to zero, and the US has agreed to hold off on imposing new tariffs for 90 days. The two sides have also agreed to work towards a broader trade deal to end the dispute.

The agreement has been met with a positive response from global markets, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite all gaining more than 1% on Monday. US soybean futures also rose to their highest level since August.

China has offered over $1.2 trillion in additional commitments on trade, according to Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin. However, the exact details of the agreement are still unclear, and administration officials have expressed skepticism about whether China will follow through on its commitments.

The US has also appointed a new trade representative, Robert Lighthizer, to oversee the negotiations, which may signal a harder line with Beijing. Lighthizer has been a vocal critic of China's trade practices and has been involved in previous trade agreements.

The agreement is seen as a significant step towards improving trade relations between the two countries, which have been strained over issues such as tariffs, intellectual property theft, and forced technology transfers. The US has accused China of unfair trade practices, while China has denied any wrongdoing.

The agreement is not without its challenges, however. The two sides have less than 90 days to reach a deal, and many specifics have yet to be worked out. The US has also appointed a new trade representative, Robert Lighthizer, who has been a vocal critic of China's trade practices.

Despite the challenges, the agreement is seen as a positive step towards improving trade relations between the two countries.

Title: Trump's Behavior Raises Concerns, But Removal via 25th Amendment Not the Solution

The first 100 days of Donald Trump's presidency have come to an end, and while the initial period was marked by hectic and often confusing activity, it was within the bounds of normalcy. However, the past 10 days have seen a significant shift, with Trump's behavior becoming increasingly erratic and chaotic. The country is now caught in the midst of a presidential meltdown, with no guardrails in sight.

The firing of FBI Director James Comey and the subsequent revelations about Trump's disclosure of classified information to Russia have raised concerns about the president's judgment and decision-making. While the media has been quick to sensationalize the situation, it is essential to separate fact from fiction and examine the facts as they emerge.

The 25th Amendment, which provides for removing an incapacitated president, has been proposed as a potential solution to Trump's behavior. However, this idea is misguided and would be a drastic measure. The amendment was intended for situations where a president is physically or mentally incapacitated, not for addressing a president's poor decision-making or erratic behavior.

Strengthening the guardrails around the presidency and increasing oversight are essential to ensure that the country is protected from the president's mercurial nature. The American electorate chose Trump, and it is up to them to hold him accountable. The country must follow the facts, especially the Comey memos, and let the chips fall where they may.

Title: US Revokes Travel Privileges for Fierce Critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin

The United States government has revoked travel privileges for Bill Browder, a British financier and a prominent critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin. Browder, a key figure behind the Magnitsky Act, which punishes human rights abusers in Russia, was notified that his Global Entry program status had been revoked, preventing him from entering the country.

According to Browder, he was informed of the decision by the Department of Homeland Security late last week. When he tried to book a flight to the United States, he discovered that his privileges to enter the country as a citizen of Great Britain had been revoked. Browder uses the Electronic System for Travel Authorization to gain entry into the US under the Visa Waiver Program.

The revocation of Browder's travel privileges is believed to be triggered by Russia's decision to place him on the Interpol wanted list, which was made on October 17. Browder has been a vocal critic of Putin and has been targeted by Russia on multiple occasions. In the past, his visa privileges were revoked as a result of Russia's actions, but he said the US government previously resolved the issue within hours.

Senators John McCain and Ben Cardin have called for an immediate review of the decision to revoke Browder's visa, stating that it would be "unfortunate" if the US decided to bar him based on a decision by Russian officials who have been targeted by the Magnitsky Act.

Browder has expressed hope that the revocation is a technical issue driven by Interpol and will be resolved quickly. The Department of Homeland Security did not respond to a request for more information, and Browder received little information when he inquired about his Global Entry status.

The revocation of Browder's travel privileges has sparked scrutiny among critics of the Trump administration, with some calling for the US government to take action to resolve the issue.

Title: North Korea's Internet Access Restored After Nine-Hour Outage

North Korea's internet access has been restored, according to technology news service Dyn Research, after being offline for over nine hours and 30 minutes. Although access is still partial, the country's main news service and newspaper have been restored online.

The outage began late Friday, according to Doug Madory, director of internet analysis at Dyn Research, and was confirmed by San Francisco-based CloudFlare, a network and security company that monitors global web access. CloudFlare described North Korea's internet access as "toast."

The cause of the outage remains unclear, with State Department spokeswoman Marie Harf declining to comment on possible response options or scenarios. Matthew Prince, chief executive of CloudFlare, suggested four possible explanations: North Korea turning off its own internet, China's upstream provider turning it off, router failure, or a denial-of-service attack from a hacking group or the U.S. Prince believes it is unlikely the U.S. was behind the reported outage.

North Korea has one of the lowest internet penetrations in the world, with access limited mostly to the country's elite. The U.S. has linked the recent hacking of Sony Pictures to North Korean hackers, although North Korea has denied responsibility. Some computer security experts question whether Pyongyang is behind the hack.

The recent hacking incident led to Sony canceling the planned Christmas Day release of The Interview, a comedy that centers on a plot to assassinate North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The threats against moviegoers and theaters that showed the film were attributed to the group that claimed responsibility for hacking Sony.

Title: Supreme Court Grants Trump Administration's Request to Stay Injunction on Border Wall Funding

The Supreme Court has granted the Trump administration's request to stay a district court's permanent injunction against the diversion of $2.5 billion in military spending to begin construction on portions of the border wall. This decision allows the construction to proceed, pending the outcome of the case in the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.

The funding in question comes from the Department of Defense's Support for Counterdrug Activities, as outlined in the February 15, 2019, announcement by the Trump administration. The administration identified up to $8.1 billion in funding sources to finance the border wall, including $2.5 billion from the Department of Defense and $3.6 billion reallocated from military construction projects.

The Sierra Club and the Southern Border Communities Coalition filed a lawsuit, alleging that the funding diversion would harm the environment and violate congressional appropriations. However, the Supreme Court ruled that the private parties lacked standing to challenge the government's action, as they failed to demonstrate a concrete and legally-recognized injury.

The court's decision is not a final judgment on the merits of the case, but rather a stay that allows the construction to proceed while the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals reviews the case. The Supreme Court may ultimately decide the case on its merits, but for now, it has cast doubt on the lower-court injunction granted to the plaintiffs.

Title: Oregon Governor John Kitzhaber Resigns Amid Allegations of Conflict of Interest

Oregon Governor John Kitzhaber has submitted his resignation, effective 10 a.m. Wednesday, amid allegations that his fiancée, Cylvia Hayes, used their public positions for private gain. According to sources, Kitzhaber met with administration officials on Friday morning to make his plans known.

The controversy surrounds Hayes' acceptance of nearly $200,000 in payments from green nonprofits to work on low-carbon fuel standard policies, which coincided with the administration's promotion of new legislation on the issue. Kitzhaber's resignation comes after reports of the allegations surfaced earlier this week.

Oregon Secretary of State Kate Brown is expected to assume the office and become the nation's first openly bisexual governor. Senate Minority Leader Ted Ferrioli expressed disappointment and sadness over Kitzhaber's resignation, stating that it has turned what should be a day of celebration into a day of reflection and mourning. Ferrioli also expressed hope that the next governor will prioritize the real needs of citizens over symbolic gestures.

House Republican Leader Mike McLane called it a "sad day for Oregon," but acknowledged Kitzhaber's decision. He emphasized that House Republicans will remain focused on working for the people of Oregon and will continue to do so moving forward.

Title: Supreme Court Declines to Hear Challenge to Obamacare's Origination Clause

The Supreme Court has declined to take up an appeal from the Pacific Legal Foundation, which argued that the Affordable Care Act (ACA) violated the Constitution's origination clause by starting in the Senate instead of the House. The origination clause states that revenue bills must begin in the House of Representatives.

The Pacific Legal Foundation, representing plaintiff Matt Sissel, an Iraq War veteran and small business owner, claimed that the ACA raises hundreds of billions of dollars in taxes and therefore should have originated in the House. However, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit rejected the suit in August, ruling that the primary purpose of the law was not to raise revenue, but to increase healthcare coverage.

The Supreme Court's decision not to hear the case marks the latest in a series of challenges to the ACA. The court has previously upheld the law as constitutional, with Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. ruling in 2012 that the individual mandate was valid as an exercise of the government's taxing power. In 2015, the court also ruled that states could choose not to expand Medicaid under the law.

The Constitutional Accountability Center, a non-partisan organization, has criticized the challenges to the ACA, calling them "meritless" and stating that the court has already upheld the law twice. The organization's chief counsel, Elizabeth Wydra, urged opponents of the ACA to "give it a rest" and move on from the issue.

Title: Ad Rates for Trump-Favored TV Shows Surge as Advertisers Target President and His Lieutenants

Ad rates for TV shows favored by President Donald Trump have seen a significant increase in recent weeks, as companies and outside groups seek to influence the president and his top advisors. According to a veteran media buyer, the ad rates for MSNBC's "Morning Joe" have more than doubled since the election, while Fox News' "The O'Reilly Factor" and other prime-time programs have seen a 50% boost.

Trump's frequent viewing of these shows, particularly "Morning Joe," has made them attractive to advertisers seeking to reach the president and his inner circle. A prominent D.C. consultant noted that some clients, including a major bank and pharmaceutical company, are negotiating ad buys on "O'Reilly" and "Morning Joe" because they know they have a good chance of reaching the president.

The consultant also pointed out that Trump often responds directly to what he's watching on television and tweets statistics and topics he sees on-air, which can drive news coverage throughout the day. This has led some companies to proactively place ads in an effort to avoid a Trump tweet or, in one instance, prompt a tweet against their competitors.

MSNBC acknowledged that ad rates for "Morning Joe" are likely to increase, with a source stating that strategically placed ad buys in New York and D.C. would likely drive up rates and capitalize on increased interest. Fox News declined to comment on the matter.

Title: Camp David: A Presidential Retreat with a Rich History of High-Stakes Diplomacy

The Camp David presidential retreat, nestled in a Maryland national park, has been a hub for high-stakes diplomacy throughout its history. The secluded retreat, built by the Works Progress Administration in the 1930s, has hosted numerous world leaders and presidents as they navigated complex global issues.

From the Cold War to the Middle East tensions, Camp David has been the site of many significant meetings between leaders. President Franklin Delano Roosevelt hosted British Prime Minister Winston Churchill in 1943, during World War II, and later, President Dwight D. Eisenhower met with Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev in 1959. The two leaders made some progress, but the good will was ultimately scuttled when an American U-2 spy plane was shot down over the Soviet Union.

In 1978, President Jimmy Carter brought Egyptian President Anwar al-Sadat and Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin to Camp David, forcing the two leaders to sit down and broker a peace accord. The 12-day secret negotiations resulted in a historic agreement. President Bill Clinton attempted to recreate the momentum in the Middle East with his own summit in 2000, but Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Palestinian Authority leader Yasser Arafat failed to reach an agreement.

More recently, President George W. Bush hosted Russian President Vladimir Putin in 2003, and President Barack Obama held a G8 summit at Camp David in 2012, which included Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev.

The idea of President Donald Trump hosting the Taliban at Camp David sparked outrage from lawmakers, including Rep. Liz Cheney, who expressed concern that the group's presence would be seen as a prestige boost. Trump defended the idea, citing past meetings with "bad people" at the retreat.

Title: Conservative Groups Scramble to Prove Their Worth After Election

Conservative super PACs and outside groups are facing the possibility that they may have spent over $1 billion and failed to elect Mitt Romney or deliver a GOP Senate majority. As a result, they are scrambling to prove they made a difference in any way they can. This includes positioning themselves to claim credit for successes, dodge blame for failures, and prove they are not one-trick ponies that can only do narrowly targeted advertising.

Karl Rove's Crossroads outfit, which focused primarily on television ads boosting Romney and GOP Senate candidates, has been expanding its efforts to include House races and get-out-the-vote activity, working with Ralph Reed's Faith and Freedom Coalition. A coalition of groups in the Koch brothers' network, including Americans for Prosperity, 60 Plus, Concerned Women for America, and CitizenLink, recently met to discuss how to prove they were giving donors a return on their investment.

The pro-Romney Restore Our Future super PAC has been boasting to donors that its advertising in Michigan and Wisconsin helped make both states competitive, while the nonprofit American Future Fund has sought to differentiate itself by spending on anti-Obama ads in previously Republican-leaning states like Minnesota. The groups are doing this with an eye toward after the election, when operatives, donors, and fundraisers expect a major reshuffling of the conservative groups that reaped an unprecedented flow of cash resulting from rich Republicans' animosity towards President Barack Obama and the Supreme Court's 2010 Citizens United decision loosening campaign finance rules.

"Without question, after it's over, there is going to be a sorting out of who got the job done, and I think there will be some who might lay claim to accomplishments that they maybe didn't personally accomplish," said Idaho businessman Frank VanderSloot, who has contributed $1.1 million to Restore Our Future and raised at least $2 million more for Romney's campaign. "Some of these organizations will gain in stature and some will probably fall by the wayside," he added, hinting that he may have also given to Crossroads.

Title: Special Counsel Mueller Acquires Communications of Trump Ally Erik Prince, Who Acknowledges Cooperation in Russian Probe

Special counsel Robert Mueller has obtained the communications of Erik Prince, the founder of Blackwater and a close ally of former President Donald Trump, according to a report. Prince has acknowledged cooperating with the Russian investigation, including providing investigators with access to his phones and computer.

In a statement to ABC News, Prince's representative said that he has spoken voluntarily with Congress and cooperated fully with the special counsel's investigation. The representative also stated that Prince has a lot of opinions about the various investigations but will keep them to himself for now and let the investigators do their work.

The investigation has reportedly uncovered evidence that a secret meeting in Seychelles, held shortly before Trump's inauguration, was intended to create a back channel between the incoming administration and the Kremlin. The meeting, which took place between Prince and a Russian official close to President Vladimir Putin, was coordinated to discuss how the Trump administration could communicate with Moscow.

However, Prince has told Congress that the meeting was a chance encounter "over a beer." ABC News reported earlier this year that Mueller had obtained evidence that created doubt about this testimony. Investigators believe the meeting was intended to establish a line of communication between the countries that was outside normal diplomatic channels.

The information came to light after it was revealed that Lebanese-American businessman George Nader, a representative of the United Arab Emirates who was part of the Seychelles meeting, was cooperating with Mueller's probe under immunity. It is unclear whether Mueller's office will prosecute Prince or make a referral to the US attorney for the District of Columbia if they find convincing evidence of perjury.

Representative Eric Swalwell (D-Calif.), a member of the House Intelligence Committee, welcomed the renewed focus on Prince. "I have a lot of questions about whether he was being straight with us," Swalwell told ABC News. "I'm heartened to hear that the special counsel is doing what Republicans on the committee were not willing to do... and follow up and not take Mr. Prince at his word."

Title: President Obama Seeks Congressional Authorization for Military Action Against ISIS

Article: President Barack Obama has sent over 1,900 airstrikes against the Islamic State (ISIS) in Iraq and Syria over the past six months without explicit congressional authorization. In a letter to lawmakers, Obama reiterated that he believes he has the authority to conduct this campaign under current law, but emphasized the importance of bipartisan support and the differences between his proposal and those of his predecessors.

Unlike previous presidents, Obama is seeking congressional authorization for his military campaign against ISIS, which would rule out "enduring offensive ground combat operations." However, he left room for limited ground action, such as "rescue operations" or the use of Special Operations forces to target ISIS leadership. The proposed legislation would also allow for the use of ground forces for intelligence gathering, spotting ground targets for airstrikes, and planning assistance to ground troops of allies like the Iraqi government.

In his remarks, Obama emphasized his commitment to avoiding another prolonged ground war in the Middle East, stating, "I do not believe America's interests are served by endless war, or by remaining on a perpetual war footing." He also noted that he would not hesitate to take action against ISIS leaders if necessary, saying, "If we had actionable intelligence about a gathering of ISIL leaders, and our partners didn't have the capacity to get them, I would be prepared to order our special forces to take action, because I will not allow these terrorists to have a safe haven."

Title: Cruz Wins Wisconsin Primary, Shaking Up Republican Presidential Race

The Wisconsin primary has delivered a significant blow to Donald Trump's presidential campaign, with Senator Ted Cruz emerging as the winner. According to exit polls, Cruz led Trump by 53% to 30%, with John Kasich trailing behind with 15%. The victory marks a turning point in the race, as Cruz's momentum grows and he gains support from five of his former GOP rivals.

Cruz attributed his win to the backing he has received from hardworking men and women in Wisconsin, stating that it is a call to the people of America to make a real choice. He emphasized that his victory is a sign of his growing momentum and highlighted the support he has received from recent contests in Utah, Colorado, and North Dakota.

Trump, on the other hand, struggled to recover from a bad week that saw his campaign manager charged with simple battery and the candidate himself stumbling on issues such as abortion and conservative orthodoxy. He also faced questions about his sliding poll numbers among female voters, leading him to deploy his wife Melania on the campaign trail.

The Cruz victory makes it more challenging for Trump to win the nomination outright on the first ballot at the July convention. Ohio Governor John Kasich, the third candidate in the race, insisted he will continue his campaign despite another loss.

The exit polls revealed that 56% of GOP voters believe the candidate who collects the most votes in the primaries should win the party's nomination, while 40% favor a contested convention. The polls also showed that trade weighed heavily on the minds of Republican voters, with over half saying the United States is getting the raw end of trade deals. Six in ten voters supported offering a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants, while a third called for their deportation.

In terms of candidate preferences, Cruz was seen as the best bet to beat Hillary Clinton in a general election match-up, followed by Trump and Kasich. The outcome of the Wisconsin primary has left the Republican presidential race wide open, with Cruz, Trump, and Kasich vying for the nomination.

Title: Midterm Elections: A Look Back at History, But Not a Guarantee

The 2006 midterm elections saw the Democratic Party take control of both the House and Senate, with several high-profile Republican politicians facing scandals and investigations. Fast forward to today, and a similar scenario is unfolding, with several Republican lawmakers facing charges and investigations. Rep. Duncan Hunter Jr. and Rep. Chris Collins, both early supporters of President Trump, are among those facing charges. While some may draw parallels between the two periods, it's essential to remember that history doesn't always repeat itself.

In 2006, the Republican Party was reeling from scandals and investigations, including the Jack Abramoff lobbying scandal and the Mark Foley sexting scandal. This led to a Democratic sweep in the midterm elections, with the party gaining control of both the House and Senate. However, this year's election is shaping up to be different.

While Rep. Hunter's attorney has accused the Justice Department of being "politically motivated" in their indictment, Cohen's attorney has made a strong case against the President, stating that Trump directed him to commit a crime by making payments to women to influence the election. The charges against Hunter and Collins are unrelated to the Manafort and Cohen scandals, but the timing is certainly suspicious.

The midterm elections are always unpredictable, and this year is no exception. While some may point to the 2006 elections as a guide, it's essential to remember that each election is unique, with its own set of factors and circumstances. The outcome of the elections is far from certain, and it's impossible to predict what will happen in the coming months.

In the meantime, the political landscape is already shaping up to be a wild ride, with the potential for an "October Surprise" that could tip the scales in one direction or another. The international stage is also volatile, with ongoing tensions with Russia, Turkey, Iran, North Korea, and Syria. And, of course, there's always the possibility of a surprise from the President himself.

In the end, it's impossible to know for certain what will happen in the midterm elections. But one thing is certain: the political landscape is always changing, and the next few months will be filled with twists and turns that will keep us all on the edge of our seats.

Title: Trump's Speech: A Mixed Bag of Unity and Division

The recent speech delivered by President Donald Trump to a joint session of Congress was a mixed bag, showcasing both attempts at unity and nods to division. While Trump's speechwriters crafted a well-written address, the president's delivery and content raised questions about his commitment to bringing the country together.

The speech began with a nod to Black History Month, acknowledging the nation's progress towards civil rights and the work that remains. However, Trump's recent reluctance to condemn anti-Semitic incidents and his suggestion that Jews might be staging attacks to discredit neo-Nazis sparked controversy. The speech could have been an opportunity for Trump to recognize the resilience and community displayed by local Muslims rallying around Jewish neighbors to repair damaged cemeteries. Instead, it was missed.

Despite this, Trump did make some attempts at unity, stating that the country must build bridges of cooperation and trust, rather than driving wedges of division. He also emphasized the shared identity of Americans, saying they all bleed the same blood and are made by the same God. Additionally, he called for Democrats and Republicans to unite to repeal the Affordable Care Act.

However, these messages of unity were overshadowed by Trump's characteristic divisive rhetoric. He described the election as a "chorus of earthquake" with his supporters united in demanding America put its citizens first, and touted his new Victims Of Immigration Crime Engagement office, which some critics argue is designed to spread hatred and fear.

The speech was a mixed bag, with Trump's words and actions sending conflicting messages. While he may have managed to act presidential for a brief moment, it remains unclear whether he truly wants to bring the country together.

Title: Egypt's President Mansour Names ElBaradei as Interim Prime Minister, Then Reverses Decision

Article: Egypt's new President Adly Mansour has faced a major setback in his efforts to assert his authority and regain control of the streets, as his decision to name Nobel Peace laureate and former IAEA chief Mohamed ElBaradei as interim prime minister was met with opposition and ultimately put on hold. The move was seen as a bid to appease the opposition and restore stability to the country, which has been gripped by dueling protests and street battles since the military ousted President Mohamed Morsi on Wednesday.

According to reports, ElBaradei's appointment was initially announced by Mansour's office, with reporters gathered at the presidential palace told to wait for the president to arrive and make the announcement. However, the decision was later reversed, with a senior opposition official citing objections from the ultraconservative Salafi el-Nour party as the reason.

The move comes as tensions remain high in Egypt, with tens of thousands of Morsi supporters rallying for a third day near a mosque in a Cairo neighborhood that has traditionally been a stronghold of Islamists. The protesters are demanding the reinstatement of Morsi, who was democratically elected as the country's first president in 2012.

Mansour, who was installed as interim leader by the military, met with General Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi and Interior Minister Mohammed Ibrahim on Saturday, as well as with the leaders of the Tamarod youth opposition group, which organized the massive protests that led to Morsi's ouster. The Muslim Brotherhood, meanwhile, has vowed to boycott the political process, calling the military's actions a coup that overturned a democratically elected government.

Morsi, a U.S.-trained engineer, remains under detention in an undisclosed location. The country's political landscape remains uncertain, with no clear indication of how the crisis will be resolved.

Title: Congress Faces Fiscal Cliff Deadline, Parties Disagree on Tax Rates

Congress is racing against an end-of-year deadline to avoid massive spending cuts and tax breaks expiring, including the Bush-era tax cuts at the end of December. The so-called fiscal cliff also includes automatic across-the-board spending cuts set to trigger at the beginning of 2013 if Capitol Hill fails to create a deficit-reduction plan.

House Speaker John Boehner and Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid have agreed that Tuesday's election was a mandate to find compromise and avoid the fiscal cliff. However, they sharply disagree over the key issue of whether top tax rates should be raised to help resolve the looming crisis. Republicans argue that higher rates would damage the economy, while Democrats believe it's the only equitable way to tackle the debt.

Boehner said in a speech on Capitol Hill that he is willing to accept new revenue under the right conditions, but emphasized that it should come from a growing economy, energized by a simpler, cleaner, and fairer tax code with fewer loopholes and lower rates for all. He also emphasized the need for concrete steps to put the country's entitlement programs on a sounder financial footing.

Reid, on the other hand, insisted that raising taxes on wealthier Americans has to be part of any compromise to resolve the crisis and that Republicans "can't push us around" on the issue. He believes that people making all this money have to contribute a little bit more.

The two leaders have different approaches to reaching an agreement. Boehner wants to reach a framework or bridge that would postpone the cuts and tax-rate changes for one year until a broader deal on deficit reduction, including entitlement and tax reform, can be worked out. Reid, however, opposes "kicking the can down the road" and wants to reach a deal as soon as possible.

The parties' disagreement on the fiscal cliff has been ongoing, with no clear solution in sight. The White House has weighed in, with President Obama placing separate calls to Reid, Boehner, McConnell, and House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, emphasizing that tax increases for wealthy Americans need to be part of a deal to avoid the fiscal cliff and reduce the debt.

Title: Bush's Legacy on the Supreme Court: A Legacy of Defending Accused Nominees

Article:

The legacy of former President George H.W. Bush has been praised as the antithesis of President Donald Trump's approach to politics. While both presidents have been criticized for their handling of Supreme Court nominations, their approaches to defending their nominees have been vastly different. Bush's legacy on the Supreme Court is marked by his defense of Clarence Thomas, who was accused of sexual harassment by Anita Hill, and later, Brett Kavanaugh, who faced allegations of sexual misconduct.

Bush's nomination of Thomas was controversial from the start, with many expecting him to choose a more moderate candidate. Instead, he selected Thomas, who was known for his conservative views. After Hill's allegations surfaced, Bush stood by Thomas, calling him a "very powerful and convincing" nominee and stating that he had "total confidence" in him. Thomas was ultimately confirmed, and his decisions have had a lasting impact on the country.

Similarly, Trump's defense of Kavanaugh was marked by his dismissal of the allegations against him and his criticism of Christine Blasey Ford, who accused Kavanaugh of assaulting her when they were in high school. Trump's defense of Kavanaugh was criticized for its tone and substance, with many arguing that it perpetuated a culture of disbelief and blame-shifting.

The similarities between Bush's and Trump's defenses of their nominees are striking. Both presidents chose to stand by their nominees despite allegations of sexual misconduct, and both were criticized for their handling of the situations. While Bush's approach was more polished and restrained, Trump's was more crude and over-the-top.

The impact of these decisions will be felt for generations to come. Both Thomas and Kavanaugh have been accused of having a lasting impact on the country, with Thomas being a staunch opponent of abortion and Kavanaugh being accused of having a role in the rise of dark money in politics. The legacy of these two presidents on the Supreme Court is a reminder that a president's decisions have far-reaching consequences, and that the choice of who serves on the Court is a critical one.

In conclusion, while Bush's legacy on the Supreme Court may be marked by his defense of Thomas, it is also marked by his failure to stand up for Anita Hill and the women who came after her. Trump's legacy on the Court is marked by his defense of Kavanaugh and his dismissal of the allegations against him. Ultimately, the legacy of these two presidents serves as a reminder that a president's decisions have lasting consequences and that the choice of who serves on the Court is a critical one.

Title: Carbon Emissions Continue to Break Records Despite Pandemic-Induced Declines

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a significant decline in carbon emissions, with estimates suggesting a 5-8% drop globally. However, despite this temporary reduction, the planet is still experiencing record-breaking levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association, the atmospheric concentration of carbon hit a new record of 416.21 parts per million in April, the highest level in 800,000 years.

Experts liken the situation to a plugged-up bathtub, where slowing the flow doesn't mean the tub will stop filling. The world needs to see a 7.6% drop in total carbon emissions every year for the next decade to contain warming below a disastrous 2 degrees Celsius.

While the pandemic-induced shutdown has cut back on demand from the biggest consumers of energy, including industry, transportation, and power sectors, experts warn that this decline is not enough to address climate change. The University of East Anglia and Global Climate Project published a new article in the journal Nature Climate Change, estimating that global carbon emissions fell by 17% compared to daily levels in 2019. However, this decline only puts us at the 2006 carbon emissions levels, and the effects are likely to be short-lived.

The report notes that emissions could eventually rebound to levels worse than before if politicians choose to delay climate programs, such as weakening standards for more efficient buildings and cleaner cars. The authors emphasize that the extent to which world leaders consider the net-zero emissions targets and the imperatives of climate change when planning their economic responses to COVID-19 will influence the pathway of CO2 emissions for decades to come.

Energy Innovation, a climate policy think tank, modeled economic projections from organizations such as Goldman Sachs and the U.S. Energy Information Agency, finding that U.S. emissions will bounce back from an 11% drop to business-as-usual by 2025. From 2030 on, the pandemic would have no material impact on pollution levels.

Experts stress that a fundamental shift in energy production and consumption is needed to address climate change. "We're still going to be relying on the same fossil fuel technology we relied on before the pandemic," says Megan Mahajan, an energy policy analyst with Energy Innovation. "The types of fuels we're relying on have not changed. There isn't a fundamental shift from how we power our electricity, our homes, and modes of transportation. We can't just do things to make modest shifts in our energy demand of the nation."

Title: Arizona Governor Appoints Rep. Martha McSally to Fill Vacant Senate Seat

Arizona Governor Doug Ducey has appointed Rep. Martha McSally to fill the vacant Senate seat left by the passing of Sen. John McCain. McSally, a two-term congresswoman, was a candidate in the recent election for the other Senate seat, but lost to Democrat Rep. Kyrsten Sinema. Despite this, McSally will now join Sinema as the only bipartisan pair of female senators representing Arizona.

McSally's appointment comes just over a month after Sen. Jon Kyl announced his decision to step down from the role. In a press release, Ducey praised McSally's qualifications, stating that she is "uniquely qualified to step up and fight for Arizona's interests in the U.S. Senate."

McSally's appointment is seen as a way to fill the seat until a special election can be held in 2020. The appointment is not without controversy, as McSally did not receive an endorsement from the McCain family during the midterm election. However, Cindy McCain, Sen. McCain's wife, posted a tweet supporting the decision and calling on McSally to remember her husband's legacy.

In a news conference, McSally expressed her gratitude for the opportunity to serve and her willingness to work with Sinema, her recent rival. She stated that she looks forward to working with Sinema and getting to work from day one. McSally also echoed this sentiment at the news conference, saying that she plans to work with Sinema "just like we did in the House."

The appointment of McSally and Sinema as the only bipartisan pair of female senators representing Arizona is seen as a historic moment for the state. The two senators will serve alongside each other for the next two years, with McSally's appointment set to expire in 2020.

Title: Domestic Violence Rates Appear to be Soaring Amidst the COVID-19 Pandemic

The Fresno Sheriff's Department has reported a 77% increase in domestic violence cases over the past two weeks, while the Seattle Police Department received 22% more domestic violence calls than the average rate. Domestic violence prevention organizations in Boston have also warned of an increase in cases. The surge in domestic violence is attributed to the confinement of families due to stay-at-home orders, job loss, and worry over the COVID-19 pandemic.

Data suggests that excessive alcohol consumption is a significant factor in domestic violence. Reducing access to alcohol during the pandemic can help reduce the frequency of home violence. Finland's liquor store employee strike in the 1970s and Sweden's curtailment of liquor store sales on certain days in the 1980s both resulted in a decrease in domestic violence. South Dakota's implementation of twice-daily sobriety breathalyzer checks for individuals with multiple arrests for drunk driving also led to a decrease in domestic violence.

Healthcare workers and professionals are often the first to identify domestic abuse victims, but the pandemic has made it challenging to identify and report cases. Telemedicine visits and online support groups can provide some relief, but they also come with limitations. The pandemic has also exacerbated the issue of domestic violence, as each house call by police or paramedics is another opportunity for the disease to spread.

While banning alcohol sales may come with some costs, such as the potential for withdrawal symptoms in those addicted to alcohol, the benefits to domestic violence victims and potential victims outweigh the drawbacks. The closure of liquor stores can help reduce the frequency of home violence and provide a safer environment for those affected.

Peter B. Bach, a physician at Memorial Sloan Kettering in New York City, emphasizes the importance of prioritizing the well-being of domestic violence victims and potential victims during this crisis.

Title: Trump and Sanders Win Big in Michigan and Mississippi Primaries

The Republican and Democratic presidential primaries in Michigan and Mississippi saw significant victories for Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders, respectively. Trump won both the Michigan and Mississippi primaries, while Sanders won the Michigan Democratic primary.

In the Republican primary, Trump regained momentum after a weekend of mixed results, sweeping to convincing victories in Michigan and Mississippi. He defeated Ted Cruz in both states, with Cruz finishing second in Michigan and third in Mississippi. Marco Rubio, who was hoping to gain some momentum, finished fourth in both states.

On the Democratic side, Clinton won the Mississippi primary, thanks in part to her strong support from black voters. She is expected to pick up more delegates than Sanders from Tuesday's contests. However, Sanders' surprise win in Michigan could give him a boost as the campaign heads into the March 15 primaries in Florida, Ohio, Illinois, Missouri, and North Carolina.

Trump celebrated his wins at a press conference, teasing the "special interests" and others who ran ads against him. He also took shots at his remaining rivals, including Cruz and Rubio. Cruz, meanwhile, argued that Trump is not the candidate he claims to be, and that he is pretending to be an outsider.

The stakes were higher for Trump, whose delegate lead over Cruz shrunk on Saturday. Trump used his wins to downplay the chances for his remaining rivals, as he and the rest of the field look ahead to next week's vital winner-take-all contests in Ohio and Florida.

Clinton's campaign is still trying to regain its footing, as Sanders has demonstrated his grassroots support in several recent contests. Despite this, Clinton maintains a huge delegate lead over Sanders, thanks in part to so-called "superdelegates" – party leaders and officials free to support whomever they want.

The delegate count stands at Trump 446, Cruz 347, Rubio 151, and Kasich 54 on the Republican side, while Clinton leads Sanders 1,221 to 571 on the Democratic side.

Title: Catholic Church Figures Push for Recognition of Homosexual Relationships at Upcoming Synod

The Catholic Church is facing a concerted effort to push for the recognition of homosexual relationships, with influential figures from Germany and northern Europe seeking to make the upcoming Synod on the Family a platform for this agenda. The group, comprising mainly German and northern European church leaders, is using vague and abstract language to promote their goals, which include "enriching" the "biblical and theological foundations" of the synod and creating a "new theology of love."

The synod, scheduled for October, aims to examine how to better apply the church's teaching on marriage and the family. However, some critics argue that the meeting is already being hijacked by powerful lobbies, including those pushing for the recognition of same-sex relationships.

A recent study day at Rome's Gregorian Jesuit university, attended by 50 participants, including nine bishops and over 20 liberal theologians, saw none of the attendees oppose church recognition of same-sex relationships when it was proposed. The meeting was organized by the heads of the German, Swiss, and French bishops' conferences.

Cardinal Reinhard Marx, president of the German bishops' conference, gave the meeting's closing address. Professor Manfred Spieker, a German church expert, criticized the event, saying it undermined the purpose and intent of the upcoming synod and promoted views with "schismatic potential."

The study day took place just days after a referendum in Ireland legalizing same-sex marriage, leading some to believe the timing was not coincidental. German Cardinal Walter Kasper, whose theology Pope Francis admires, has said the Irish vote means the church needs to address same-sex couples more fully, and that what was once a "marginal topic" has now become "central."

The church's recognition of same-sex relationships is opposed by many faithful Catholics, who view it as surrendering to secular values and sowing confusion. However, the church's homosexual lobby is unlikely to be deterred, using tools such as a book to be published in September by a group of Catholic academics pushing the homosexual agenda.

The book, titled "Who Am I to Judge?" after the Pope's misquoted remark on the issue, calls for more acceptance of the homosexual lifestyle, citing that condemning homosexuality no longer meets with a "positive response" among the faithful.

Title: Obama's Re-election Strategy Faces Uncertainty as Election Day Approaches

As the first day of November arrives, the presidential election remains deadlocked, with both campaigns having a convincing argument for why they will have the edge on Election Day. President Obama's top political adviser, David Plouffe, describes the president's re-election message as "not the real Mitt Romney," according to top campaign advisers interviewed by The Wall Street Journal.

The race has become a wild ride, with both sides having made significant gains and losses. Team Obama claims that the tide has turned in their favor, but not enough to carry them to an electoral victory in Ohio and the rest of the Rust Belt. Meanwhile, Team Romney argues that close is good enough for the Republican nominee, citing high voter intensity on the Republican side and strong performances with key groups that were crucial to Obama's 2008 victory.

The polls do not provide a clear indication of where the race is heading, leaving both sides with a chance to win. However, if the challenger is to win, it will be due to three key factors: the riskiest part of President Obama's re-election strategy, the enthusiasm gap, and the independent vote.

The Obama campaign focused on disqualifying Mitt Romney, often to the detriment of making the president's own case. Despite spending millions on negative advertising, Romney and his running mate, Paul Ryan, survived the attacks. Obama will spend the final five days making a more positive closing argument, but it will be in an atmosphere where both he and his challenger are deemed plausible.

The enthusiasm gap has been a significant issue for Democrats since the early days of the Obama era. The president's decision to move left after taking office and stay there hardened Republican opposition and boosted a traditional turnout advantage for the Red Team. The Obama campaign argued that superior resources and a community organizing approach to governance and campaigning would allow Obama to overwhelm the organic advantage of the Republicans. However, the latest Pew study and other polls show that the enthusiasm gap has been erased, and maybe even reversed.

Early voting is the best indicator of base enthusiasm, and the latest polls show that Romney leads Obama among early voters. The Obama campaign's assumption that Romney would win among Election Day voters but would be carried through by early votes has been proven wrong. Romney leads widely among the most passionate voters and has matched Democrats in contacting voters directly.

The independent vote is the most promising field of persuadable voters, and Romney is succeeding by a wide margin. In the latest poll, Romney holds a 7-point lead among independent voters, with 16 percent on the fence or supporting a marginal candidate. It seems highly unlikely that the incumbent will get half of those remaining.

Title: McConnell Prepares Aggressive Campaign for Reelection

Kentucky Senator Mitch McConnell, the top Senate Republican, is gearing up for a ruthless campaign to retain his seat, with a war chest expected to exceed $21 million. He has already launched nearly $200,000 in TV and radio ads, assembled data to target voters with tailored messages, and secured support from most state GOP legislators.

McConnell's strategy is similar to those employed by Senate stalwarts Harry Reid and John McCain, who won reelection with big fundraising numbers and constant attack ads. His opponents, including tea party foes and Democrats, see him as a prime target, but neither has yet recruited a challenger.

In an interview, McConnell stated, "My view is if you're going to be a bigger target, you're going to adopt different tactics. I think we've made it pretty clear... that we intend to be very aggressive from Day One. And we are. And that involves not ignoring any potential opponent."

The focus now shifts to Alison Lundergan Grimes, the 34-year-old Kentucky secretary of state, who may or may not run against McConnell. If she doesn't, Democrats could be without a top-tier candidate to challenge the GOP leader.

McConnell has worked aggressively to win over major players in the tea party movement through outreach, fundraising, and political support. He is also trying to balance his appeal to the GOP base with bipartisan deals that could appeal to middle-of-the-road voters. On gun control, he is considering backing a Republican alternative to a Democratic bill expanding background checks, but would oppose a more sweeping measure.

In terms of spending, McConnell has shifted his focus from promoting his own pet projects to attacking President Barack Obama and the Democratic budget plans. However, he also touts his role in drafting three bipartisan deals with the White House: the 2010 tax accord, the 2011 Budget Control Act, and the 2013 New Year's Day law to avert the fiscal cliff.

Title: White House Warns of Devastating Consequences of Looming Spending Cuts

The White House has outlined the potential consequences of the looming spending cuts, known as the sequester, which are set to take effect in March. The administration warned that the cuts would have a devastating impact on various programs and services, including Head Start, small business loans, and food safety inspections.

According to the White House, the $85 billion in cuts would result in 70,000 youngsters being removed from Head Start programs, 100,000 formerly homeless people losing government-financed housing, and 7,200 school employees losing federal support for special education. Additionally, job safety inspectors might have to be furloughed, which could lead to an increase in worker fatality and injury rates.

The White House also highlighted the broader negative consequences the sequester would have on the economy as a whole. Private forecasters, the Congressional Budget Office, and others have estimated that letting the sequester take hold would cost the country millions of jobs.

The administration is urging lawmakers to delay the sequester by at least a three-month period to allow time to find targeted spending cuts, rather than an across-the-board slash to all budgets, defense and domestic. The White House is seeking to rally public pressure on Republicans to avoid the sequester and find alternative spending cuts.

House Speaker John A. Boehner's office has stated that Republicans want to avoid the sequester and are willing to consider alternative spending cuts, but reject tax hikes. The White House has argued that the wealthy can afford to pay more in taxes to avoid the sequester.

The sequester is a result of the 2011 debt deal, which required automatic cuts to be made to the federal budget every year for the rest of the decade. The White House has said that the sequester is a "blunt and indiscriminate instrument" that poses a serious threat to national security, domestic priorities, and the economy.

Title: Senate May Reconsider Bipartisan Gun Background Checks Bill Amid Recent Mass Shooting

The Senate may revisit the bipartisan gun background checks bill, which failed to pass last year, in the wake of a recent mass shooting in Las Vegas. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid hinted on Tuesday that the chamber may vote on the legislation again this year, citing the need to prevent similar tragedies. The bill, sponsored by Senators Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) and Pat Toomey (R-Pa.), aimed to expand background checks for gun purchases.

Reid made the case that since the bill's failure, there have been few days without reports of gun violence. He pointed to the recent shooting in Las Vegas, which left five people dead, including the shooters, and said that if the man involved had undergone background checks, the tragedy might have been prevented.

Senator Manchin, a co-sponsor of the bill, expressed optimism that the legislation could pass if the Senate can secure five more votes to break a 60-vote threshold filibuster. He emphasized that responsible gun owners do not sell their weapons to strangers or those who may be mentally impaired or irresponsible.

While Senator John McCain of Arizona, one of the four Republicans who supported the bill, said he would vote the same way if the bill comes up again this year, Senator Manchin has not yet met privately with Reid to discuss a renewed push for gun legislation. However, the topic may come up in a meeting scheduled for Wednesday.

Title: House Republicans Consider Suing President Obama Over Immigration Executive Actions

Article: House Speaker John Boehner announced on Tuesday that the House of Representatives is considering a resolution that would allow Congress to join a lawsuit against President Obama's recent executive actions on immigration or file its own lawsuit against the president. The lawsuit would allegedly claim that the program announced by Obama, which grants protection from deportation to unauthorized immigrant parents of US citizens and permanent residents, exceeds his legal authority. It is unclear whether the lawsuit would also challenge the existing "deferred action" program for young unauthorized immigrants, which has been in place since 2012.

The existing Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which has granted protection from deportation to approximately 600,000 unauthorized immigrants, has been criticized by some as an acceptable use of presidential authority. However, the new deferred-action program would not be considered acceptable by some, as it follows the same model as the existing program. Unauthorized immigrants who meet certain requirements can apply for temporary protection and must renew it every few years. Any legal criticisms that apply to the new program also apply to the existing one.

The decision to sue the president over both programs raises questions about why Congress is only taking legal action now, if it truly believes the existing program is a threat to the Constitution. The GOP's legal case and the politics surrounding the issue are also relevant, as the DACA program was widely popular when it was first announced. Polls are mixed on the new executive action, with some showing Americans favoring the action being allowed to stand and others wanting it blocked.

Title: Politicians' Attempts to Define Patriotism Raise Concerns

The article argues that politicians have no business defining or directing patriotism, as their rhetoric often sounds like 1950s-era Soviet sloganeering. The author criticizes former President Barack Obama's declaration of his first Inauguration Day as a "National Day of Renewal and Reconciliation" and President Donald Trump's declaration of his Inauguration Day as a "National Day of Patriotic Devotion." The author believes that this kind of self-aggrandizement is not American republicanism, but rather a cult-like devotion to a particular individual or party.

The article also references the Obama administration's emphasis on "economic patriotism," which the author sees as a euphemism for punishing American companies that try to lower their tax burden. The author argues that this approach is not truly patriotic, as it prioritizes power over principles like liberty.

The article concludes that patriotism is driven by idealism, not chauvinism or ethnicity, and that nationalism is not the same as patriotism. The author believes that politicians should not be treated like quasi-religious figures, and that devotion to a particular party or president is not the same as devotion to the country.

Title: Trump Targets Biden with Doctored Video Amidst Own Accusations of Inappropriate Behavior

Article:

Less than two months ago, Alva Johnson, a former Trump campaign staffer, accused Donald Trump of kissing her without her consent in 2016, making him the 16th woman to accuse the president of groping, kissing, or assaulting her. At least seven additional women have accused Trump of sexual harassment. This is not the first time Trump has faced allegations of inappropriate behavior, as he was famously recorded bragging about groping women on a hot mic in 2016.

Despite these accusations, Trump has continued to try to score political points against his opponents by using their own words against them. On Thursday, Trump tweeted out doctored footage of Joe Biden, attempting to mock the former vice president for a video he shared the day before. In the original video, Biden responded to accusations he repeatedly invaded women's personal space by promising "to be much more mindful."

The doctored video shows Biden grabbing himself on the shoulders and kissing himself on the head, similar to the inappropriately handsy behavior he is now reckoning with. Trump's decision to try to capitalize on accusations of inappropriate behavior despite all the allegations against him illustrates the sheer shamelessness of his administration.

White House counselor Kellyanne Conway also weighed in on the matter, saying that video of Biden's "creepy" behavior would be "a big problem" for him if he ran for president, ignoring the fact that her boss has been accused of far worse. None of this is meant to defend Biden, who has not apologized for his behavior and has obfuscated the fact that at least two women accused him of conduct they say was inappropriate at the time.

If Biden decides to run in the first post-#MeToo presidential election, his treatment of women will rightfully be something he has to answer for. However, Trump is definitely not in a position to make a good faith case against him. The likelihood is that Trump's tweet was meant to end Biden's candidacy before it officially begins, as the vice president continues to outpoll the Democratic presidential candidates who are already officially running, and is currently outpolling Trump by anywhere between five and 13 points.

Title: Sen. Bernie Sanders Speaks at Presidential Gun Sense Forum in Des Moines, Iowa

Article:

Sen. Bernie Sanders, a prominent Democratic senator from Vermont, recently spoke at the Presidential Gun Sense Forum in Des Moines, Iowa. The event aimed to discuss gun control measures and gun violence prevention. Sanders, known for his progressive views, has been a vocal advocate for gun control and has introduced several bills to address the issue.

The article highlights Sanders' rise to prominence, noting that he was considered an "irrelevant lone socialist" five years ago but gained significant attention during his 2016 presidential primary run. The article also mentions the growing popularity of socialism among young Americans, citing a recent Harris poll that found about half of millennials would like to live in a socialist country.

The article explores the reasons behind this trend, including the burden of student loan debt, the perceived lack of job opportunities, and the appeal of "free stuff." It also notes that many young people are concentrated in urban areas, where they may feel disconnected from the traditional American values of self-reliance and homeownership.

The article concludes by highlighting the importance of education and historical context in understanding the rise of socialism. It notes that many young people are unaware of the devastating consequences of socialist regimes throughout history, including the millions of deaths caused by communist leaders such as Pol Pot, Stalin, and Mao Zedong. The article suggests that a lack of understanding of economics, history, and politics has contributed to the romanticization of socialist leaders like Che Guevara and Fidel Castro.

Overall, the article provides a balanced analysis of the growing popularity of socialism among young Americans, highlighting both the economic and historical factors driving this trend.

Title: Trump's Response to the Coronavirus: A Missed Opportunity for Populist Nationalism

The article discusses President Donald Trump's initial response to the coronavirus outbreak, which has been criticized for being slow and dismissive. Despite being a self-proclaimed nationalist who has emphasized the importance of borders and the dangers of China, Trump has not taken a strong stance against the virus, which originated in China and has spread globally. Instead, he has downplayed the threat and focused on economic concerns.

The article argues that Trump's supporters have also been slow to react, citing various reasons such as the virus being similar to the flu or that it only affects older people. However, the author notes that this response is misguided, as the virus has the potential to spread rapidly and has already caused significant economic disruption.

The article highlights several key points that Trump and his supporters have gotten wrong, including the importance of borders, the role of globalization in spreading the virus, and the need for government action to respond to the crisis. The author notes that Trump's supporters have been quick to blame the "Deep State" and the media for the government's slow response, but argues that this is an unfair and misguided criticism.

The article also notes that there are some honorable exceptions among Trump's supporters, such as Senator Tom Cotton and Tucker Carlson, who have been vocal about the dangers of the virus from the beginning. The author concludes that Trump's response to the coronavirus has been a missed opportunity for populist nationalism, and that the country needs a more robust and coordinated response to the crisis.

Title: Ohio Gunman's Social Media Profile Reveals Left-Wing Views, Anti-Trump and Law Enforcement Sentiment

Article:

A recent investigation by Heavy.com has revealed the social media profile of Connor Betts, the gunman responsible for the mass shooting in Dayton, Ohio, which left nine people dead and dozens injured. The investigation found that Betts described himself as a pro-Satan "leftist" who wanted to see the Joe Biden generation die off, hated President Trump and law enforcement, and expressed support for Senator Elizabeth Warren for president.

Betts' Twitter account, @iamthespookster, showed a strong affinity for left-wing ideology, with tweets expressing support for socialism and criticizing Republicans. He also shared posts about gun control, blaming Republicans for school shootings, and expressed disdain for anti-immigration policies.

In contrast to the El Paso gunman's manifesto, which focused on anti-immigration and white nationalist beliefs, Betts' tweets painted a picture of a left-wing anarchist and discontent. He expressed support for gun control, despite having a fascination with guns, and blamed Republicans for school shootings.

The investigation found that Betts' Twitter account was active from 2017 to 2019, with his most recent tweet posted on August 3, 2019. The account was verified through multiple verification factors, including a matching tattoo on a selfie and prominent news outlets' pictures of Connor Betts, as well as family linkages and similar photos.

As of Sunday, Dayton police said they had no proof of Betts' motive for the shooting. The investigation is ongoing.

Title: Former White House Communications Director Hope Hicks Testifies Before House Judiciary Committee

Article:

Former White House communications director Hope Hicks testified before the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday, answering questions related to the special counsel's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. Hicks, who served as a close aide to President Trump, declined to answer a range of questions about her tenure in the White House, according to reports.

The hearing was conducted behind closed doors, and the transcript of the testimony will be released in the coming days. Hicks was the first senior administration official to agree to testify before the committee about the Mueller investigation and President Trump's orders.

Representatives from both sides of the aisle expressed differing opinions on the purpose and outcome of the hearing. Democratic Representative David Cicilline (D-RI) lamented the presence of a large team of lawyers representing Hicks, stating that they were there to prevent Congress from conducting its oversight duties. Republican Representative Doug Collins (R-GA) criticized the Democratic Party for wasting taxpayer money and refusing to focus on more pressing issues, such as the immigration crisis.

President Trump himself weighed in on the matter, tweeting that the Democrats were putting Hicks "through hell" and asking why they were not investigating Hillary Clinton's email practices instead. The tweet referenced Clinton's deletion of emails and use of a private email server while serving as Secretary of State, which was the subject of an FBI investigation.

The hearing was originally subpoenaed by the committee, but Hicks agreed to testify after negotiations. The outcome of the hearing remains unclear, but the transcript is expected to be released in the coming days.

Title: Obama Faces Strategic Choice in Nominating Replacement for Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia

President Barack Obama is expected to uphold his constitutional responsibility to nominate a replacement for Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, who passed away over the weekend. The decision comes as a significant opportunity for Obama to shape the court's balance of power, potentially shifting it from conservative to liberal for the first time in decades. However, Senate Republicans have already stated they will not confirm a new justice before the fall's presidential elections, leaving Obama with a strategic choice to make.

Constitutionally, Obama cannot force the Senate to vote on his nominee, but he can use Republican inaction to generate public pressure. Some Democrats have expressed hope that Republicans will at least allow a hearing, even if they block Obama's nominee. Obama can also use his nomination to make a statement by choosing a lower court judge who has already survived a rigorous vetting process or by reaching out to a politically acceptable candidate.

One leading candidate to replace Scalia is District of Columbia Circuit Court Judge Sri Srinavasan, who was confirmed by the Senate 97-0 in May 2013. Democrats believe that an unambiguous verdict on Srinivasan could make it awkward for Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell to block a vote on his nomination. However, Republicans are still fuming over Democrats' move in 2013 to eliminate filibusters for lower court federal judges, which could be a significant obstacle for any Obama nominee.

As Obama has already made Democratic appointees the majority on nine of the nation's 13 circuit courts, Republicans are unlikely to give in on Scalia's replacement easily. This could lead Obama to nominate an overtly liberal candidate, using the political fallout from the stymied nomination to help drive voters to the polls in November.

The political maneuvering speaks to the stakes behind the nomination, which will likely have enormous consequences for constitutional law in the nation, affecting issues from campaign finance and affirmative action to religious freedom and the Second Amendment.

Title: NBC News Aims to Achieve 50% Diversity in Workforce

NBC News, a leading news organization, has set a goal to increase diversity in its workforce, with a target of having 50% of its employees be women and 50% of its total workforce be people of color. According to NBCUniversal News Group Chairman Cesar Conde, this effort is aimed at reflecting the country and the communities they serve.

As of now, women make up 50% of the organization's workforce, while people of color account for 27%. Conde emphasized the importance of increasing diversity and inclusion both in front of and behind the camera, stating that the company wants to earn the trust of every community in America that relies on them for exceptional journalism.

The company will also focus on producing more long-form investigative pieces on issues that impact people of color. This shift comes as businesses and organizations across the country address concerns stemming from the Black Lives Matter protests and riots following the death of George Floyd.

It is worth noting that the company's chairman has emphasized the importance of achieving this goal, stating that it will take time and effort, but it is essential to start working towards it today.

Title: Giuliani Weighs in on Whether a Sitting President Can Pardon Themselves

In a recent interview on ABC News' "This Week," Rudy Giuliani, President Trump's confidant and lead attorney in the ongoing Russian investigation, was asked whether a sitting president has the power to pardon themselves. Giuliani responded that President Trump "probably" has this power, but emphasized that he has no intention of pardoning himself. Giuliani noted that other presidents have pardoned individuals in similar circumstances, both within their own administration and in subsequent administrations.
