The state's results also mean Biden will likely win the lion's share of the state's 36 delegates to the national convention, further extending his delegate lead.

Sanders performed well with the youth vote, ages 17-29, carrying it in Michigan and Missouri, but this demographic only accounted for 12.5% of the electorate in these states, not enough to save his campaign. The Vermont senator's campaign may be premised on the passion of new young voters, but they did not show up in sufficient numbers at the polling booths.

While this may be good news for Biden in the short term, it is a warning sign for the general election if he is the nominee. Young voters were a key part of the coalition that delivered the White House to Barack Obama in 2008, and if Biden does not improve his standing with this demographic, he may suffer the same fate as Hillary Clinton.

Biden made his pitch to Sanders' voters, acknowledging their tireless energy and passion, and expressing his commitment to defeating Donald Trump. The former Vice President will need to continue to build momentum and improve his standing with key demographics if he is to secure the Democratic nomination.

Title: Americans Flee High-Tax States, Red States Gain Population

The article reports on a study by Arthur Laffer and Stephen Moore, co-authors of a report from the American Legislative Exchange Council, which suggests that around 3.5 million Americans have relocated from high-tax states like California and those in the Northeast to low-tax states like Texas and Arizona over the past decade. The study estimates that California and New York will lose around 800,000 residents over the next three years, roughly double the previous three years, while Connecticut, New Jersey, and Minnesota will lose around 500,000 people in the same period.

The study attributes this migration to the Republican Party's tax bill, which caps the deduction for state and local taxes (SALT) at $10,000 per family. High-earning individuals in states with high income taxes, such as California, New York, Minnesota, and New Jersey, will bear more costs of their state government under the new SALT cap. According to the study, 90% of taxpayers are unaffected by the change, but high earners in these states will feel the impact.

The article also mentions that nine states, including Florida, Nevada, Texas, and Washington, impose no tax on earned income. Since 2007, low-tax states like Texas and Florida have gained 1.4 million and 850,000 residents, respectively, from elsewhere in the U.S., while high-tax states like California and New York have lost more than 2.2 million residents.

Texas Republican Governor Greg Abbott has even extended an invitation to residents of high-tax New Jersey to move to Texas, touting his administration's tax cut of $4 billion.

Title: Christ Church in Alexandria Removes Memorial Plaques to George Washington and Robert E. Lee

Christ Church in Alexandria, Virginia, has announced that it will remove memorial plaques to its founding member George Washington and Robert E. Lee, citing concerns that the presence of the plaques makes some visitors feel unsafe or unwelcome. The decision was made after a unanimous vote by the vestry, with the plaques expected to be removed by next summer.

The plaques, which were erected in 1870, were a bit of a sensation at the time, earning mentions in newspapers from Massachusetts to San Francisco. They were paid for by subscription from citizens of Alexandria and are attached to the front wall of the church, on either side of the altar.

The church's leadership acknowledged that the decision was not taken lightly, but stated that the plaques are relics of another era and have no place in a church that proclaims its motto as "All are welcome – no exceptions." The church's rector, Rev. Noelle York-Simmons, said in an email that the decision was made to provide a fuller narrative of the church's history, including the influence of the two men on the church and the country.

The decision to remove the plaques has sparked a backlash, with some supporters praising the church for its "courageous" stand, while others have compared the church's leaders to the Taliban or Islamic State. The church's Facebook page has become a battleground, with some users expressing outrage and others defending the decision.

The church's leadership has not commented on whether it will attempt to return the $10,000 gift from Mary Custis Lee, Robert E. Lee's daughter, which was used to begin the church's endowment. The church's senior and junior wardens did not respond to questions about the decision, and Rev. York-Simmons only provided a brief statement.

In recent years, Lee monuments have been under scrutiny, with violence breaking out in Charlottesville this year surrounding a Lee statue that the city is trying to take down. The Washington National Cathedral has also removed a stained-glass window with an image of Lee.

Title: Obama Adjusts Economic Timeline, Says Middle Class Was Affected Before Financial Crisis

Article: President Barack Obama has seemingly moved the goalposts on his timeline for turning around the economy, stating that it will take more than one term to achieve his goals. This comes as the Labor Department is set to release the October jobs report, which could provide a crucial boost to his re-election campaign. In a speech in Green Bay, Wisconsin, Obama acknowledged that the middle class was struggling before the financial crisis hit, and that it will take more time to recover.

This is a departure from his previous statement in 2009, when he said that if he didn't turn the economy around within three years, it would be a "one-term proposition." Obama's campaign has long argued that he needs more time to finish the job he started, and that his opponent, Mitt Romney, is offering a return to the policies of the George W. Bush administration.

Romney's campaign, on the other hand, claims that Obama is simply re-packaging his broken promises and failed policies, and that Romney is the only one offering real change. The two candidates have been campaigning in key battleground states, with Obama visiting Wisconsin, Nevada, and Colorado, and Romney making a three-stop swing through Virginia. The Romney campaign has also announced plans to expand its reach into Pennsylvania, a state that has traditionally backed Democrats in recent presidential races.

The October jobs report, to be released on Friday, is the last major economic survey before Election Day, and could provide a crucial boost to Obama's re-election campaign. Some economists have questioned the accuracy of the report, but it remains to be seen how it will impact the election.

Title: UN Arms Trade Treaty: Concerns Over Potential Impact on Second Amendment Rights

The United Nations Arms Trade Treaty (ATT) has been a topic of controversy, with some arguing that it could infringe on Second Amendment rights. Despite the first round of talks falling apart, the UN has already initiated another attempt to finalize the treaty. The Obama administration has stated that it will not accept any treaty that infringes on the constitutional rights of American citizens to bear arms. However, critics argue that the language of the treaty is too broad and vague, leaving room for interpretation and potential threats to Second Amendment rights.

The treaty's language instructs countries to "take the necessary legislative and administrative measures to adapt, as necessary, national laws and regulations to implement the obligations of this treaty." Critics argue that this language could be stretched to pose a threat to the Second Amendment. The UN's own report, "The Impact of Poorly Regulated Arms Transfers on the Work of the UN," recognizes that states have a right to individual or collective self-defense, but also notes that the arms trade must be regulated to minimize the risk of misuse of legally owned weapons.

The Obama administration has echoed claims that the treaty will not pose a threat to domestic gun owners, but critics are skeptical. A Washington Times editorial argues that the treaty's language is too broad and vague, and could be stretched to pose a threat to the Second Amendment. The administration's track record on gun control and its keen interest in the treaty have raised concerns among gun rights advocates.

The treaty's backers argue that it will help to prevent violence, terrorism, and intra-state conflicts, but critics argue that the logistics are impossible and that the Obama administration's willingness to work with dictatorial regimes like Iran raises concerns. The treaty's language and the administration's track record have led some to question whether they can be trusted to uphold the Second Amendment.

In conclusion, the UN Arms Trade Treaty has sparked concerns over its potential impact on Second Amendment rights. While the Obama administration has stated that it will not accept any treaty that infringes on American citizens' rights, critics argue that the language of the treaty is too broad and vague, leaving room for interpretation and potential threats to Second Amendment rights.

Title: San Francisco Police Department Instructed Officers to Disable Body-Worn Cameras During Raid on Journalist's Home

The San Francisco Police Department (SFPD) instructed officers to disable their body-worn cameras during a high-profile raid on journalist Bryan Carmody's home in May 2019, according to a memo obtained by the Reporters Committee. The memo, which was obtained through a public records request, states that Lieutenant Pilar Torres told officers conducting the raid not to use their department-issued body-worn cameras (BWCs) because the video footage could compromise the "confidential investigation."

The SFPD raided Carmody's home with search warrants and a sledgehammer on May 10, 2019, about a month after the freelance journalist refused to reveal the source of a leaked police report concerning the death of Jeff Adachi, a longtime San Francisco public defender. Officers seized computers, cameras, and phones from Carmody's home before conducting a separate search of the journalist's office. The search warrants were later deemed illegal under California's "shield law," which protects journalists' confidential sources and materials. The incident sparked nationwide outrage, especially among journalists and press freedom advocates.

The Reporters Committee, a non-profit organization that advocates for press freedom and the First Amendment, has been investigating the raid and has called for an investigation into the incident. The organization has also sued to unseal Carmody's arrest and search warrant records and has pursued records related to the FBI's presence during the raid. According to an FBI document obtained through a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit, FBI agents knew Carmody was a journalist when they questioned him, but it is unclear whether the FBI followed Justice Department guidelines requiring authorization from the attorney general before questioning a member of the news media.

Title: Turning Point USA Leaders Charlie Kirk and Candace Owens Reportedly Harassed and Attacked by Antifa in Philadelphia

Article:

Conservative leaders Charlie Kirk and Candace Owens, founders of Turning Point USA, were allegedly harassed and attacked by Antifa members in a Philadelphia cafe on August 6, 2018. According to their social media posts, the incident began when they were eating breakfast, with Antifa members surrounding the establishment and using bullhorns. When they left the cafe, they were met with hissing, chanting, and screaming, and Kirk was doused with water. The police had to intervene for safety reasons.

Kirk and Owens took to Twitter to share their account of the incident, describing the aggressive behavior of the Antifa members and the presence of an all-black and Hispanic police force protecting them. They also accused Rep. Maxine Waters of inciting the violence, citing her previous tweet calling for people to "get in the faces" of Trump administration officials.

The incident was discussed on the TV show Hannity on August 7, 2018, with Kirk and Owens sharing their experiences and expressing concerns about the safety of conservatives.

Title: President Obama Nominates Jeh Johnson as Next Secretary of Homeland Security

President Barack Obama has chosen Jeh Johnson, a former Pentagon attorney, to be the next secretary of the Department of Homeland Security. Johnson, who served as general counsel for the Defense Department during Obama's first term, will be introduced by the president at a ceremony on Friday. If confirmed by the Senate, Johnson would replace Janet Napolitano, who left the administration to run the University of California education system.

According to a White House official, Johnson was selected for his "sound judgment" and "prior legal review and approval of every military operation approved by the president and secretary of Defense" during his tenure at the Defense Department. The official described Johnson as a "critical member of the president's counterterrorism team" and someone who worked closely with Homeland Security officials during his years at the Pentagon.

Johnson's specialties include cybersecurity, and he played a key role in repealing the Pentagon's "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" policy that banned openly gay servicemembers. He also provided legal guidance on the use of unmanned drones against terrorism suspects overseas and in the use of military commissions to try suspects.

Johnson, who left his Pentagon post in 2012, led a crackdown on unauthorized news leaks at the Defense Department, including a warning to a former Navy SEAL who wrote a book about the 2011 raid that killed Osama bin Laden.

During a speech at Britain's Oxford University last year, Johnson said that the nation's war on terrorism should not be endless and that the focus should shift to law enforcement and intelligence operations. "War must be regarded as a finite, extraordinary and unnatural state of affairs," Johnson said. "In its 12th year, we must not accept the current conflict, and all that it entails, as the new normal."

Elisa Massimino, president of Human Rights First, said Johnson "grappled with the challenges of protecting national security while respecting human rights and upholding American ideals" during his time at the Pentagon. "These are key issues in the Department of Homeland Security, and we would welcome the opportunity to work with him should he be confirmed to lead DHS," she said in a statement.

Sen. Jeff Sessions, R-Ala., criticized Obama for nominating a "loyalist and fundraiser" to lead what he called a "mismanaged" department. "This is deeply concerning," Sessions said. "This huge department must have a proven manager with strong relevant law enforcement experience, recognized independence and integrity, who can restore this department to its full capability."

Title: Budget Battles Reoccur Regularly, and Each Time Seems Worse

The United States is facing another round of budget battles, with the possibility of a government shutdown looming. This is not a new phenomenon, as budget battles have become a regular occurrence in recent years. According to Julian Zelizer, a historian and journalist, Republicans have used the weapon of a shutdown to cripple Democratic presidents, and this tactic has become the new normal.

The budget process is broken, and the nation is so focused on scrambling out of each specific budget battle that there is hardly time to understand what dynamics are driving this process. Partisan strategy is one of the main culprits, with polarization making almost every issue more contentious on Capitol Hill. Republicans have taken the initiative to use the budget as a way to handcuff Democratic presidents, a strategy that has deep roots.

In the past, Republicans have used aggressive techniques to force Democratic presidents to accept spending cuts. Since 2010, a growing number of Republicans have been willing to use these tactics to force President Barack Obama's hand on the issue. They have demonstrated that they would be fine with shutting down the government and threatening not to raise the debt ceiling, which would send the country into default.

The budget process is becoming more brutal, with the filibuster being used more frequently and on mundane issues. The result is that the Senate has become a chamber where a supermajority is required on most issues. Similarly, threatening a government shutdown was once seen as a highly dramatic act, but now it is viewed as a legitimate part of congressional debate.

The 24-hour news media has also contributed to the budget wars, providing a platform for politicians to gain attention and stay in the headlines. As a result, legislators like Ted Cruz have made a name for themselves and stayed in the spotlight.

At some point, there will be pressure to reform the process. Some Republicans, like Senator John McCain, have been openly critical of their colleagues and called for a different approach. Budget reform is possible, and there have been discussions about repealing the need for a congressional vote to raise the debt ceiling. It might be time to start that debate again, as the country has seen several moments in U.S. history where the entire budget process has been overhauled, such as in 1921 and 1974.

Title: Former CIA Agent Warns of ISIS Cells in the United States

A former CIA agent has expressed concern about the presence of Islamic State (ISIS) cells in the United States, stating that some members have already entered the country through the Mexican border. According to Bob Baer, a former CIA agent, intelligence agencies are aware of some suspected ISIS members and are working to gather evidence to apprehend them, but fear there may be more unknown individuals.

Baer told CNN that people working in intelligence-gathering are "very alarmed" about the situation, and that ISIS members, including American citizens who have traveled to Syria and returned, pose a definite concern. The former agent emphasized that intelligence agencies are aware of some suspected ISIS members and are working to gather evidence to apprehend them, but fear there may be more unknown individuals.

ISIS, also known as the Islamic State, has taken control of large portions of Syria and Iraq, claiming to have established a caliphate and planning to wage a global jihad. The group has released videos of the beheadings of American journalists James Foley and Steven Sotloff, among others, and has threatened to strike back against the United States in response to airstrikes against its strongholds in Iraq.

Baer believes that ISIS will continue to target Western captives, including Americans, as a way to strike back against the United States. He expects more beheadings to occur as ISIS continues to be hurt by American attacks.

Title: Experimental Vaccine Shows Promise in Early-Stage Clinical Trials

AstraZeneca and Oxford University's experimental vaccine, AZD1222, has shown an immune response in early-stage clinical trials, according to data published in The Lancet medical journal on Monday. The vaccine, which is being developed to combat the new coronavirus, prompted no serious side effects and elicited antibody and T-cell immune responses in participants.

The trial, which included 1,077 healthy adults aged 18-55 years with no history of COVID-19, showed that the vaccine caused minor side effects more frequently than a control group. However, some of these side effects could be reduced by taking the painkiller paracetamol, also known as acetaminophen.

The vaccine, which has been hailed as the leading candidate in the global race to halt the pandemic by the World Health Organization's chief scientist, is still in the early stages of development. Researchers cautioned that more work is needed to confirm whether the vaccine will help manage the COVID-19 pandemic.

AstraZeneca has signed agreements with governments around the world to supply the vaccine should it prove effective and gain regulatory approval. The company has said it will not seek to profit from the vaccine during the pandemic.

The vaccine is being developed in collaboration with the University of Oxford and has been licensed to AstraZeneca. The company has put it into large-scale, late-stage trials to test its efficacy and has signed deals to produce and supply over 2 billion doses of the shot, with 300 million doses earmarked for the United States.

While the results are promising, researchers emphasized that more work is needed to determine the optimal dosage and whether the vaccine will provide long-term immunity. The trial showed a stronger immune response in 10 people given an extra dose of the vaccine after 28 days, echoing a trial in pigs. However, Oxford's Sarah Gilbert said that the early-stage trial could not determine whether one or two doses would be needed to provide immunity.

AstraZeneca's biopharma chief, Mene Pangalos, said the company is leaning towards a two-dose strategy for later-stage trials and does not want to risk a single or lower dose that might not work. The antibody levels generated by the vaccine were "in the region" of those seen in convalescent patients, he said.

The vaccine is expected to be available by the end of the year, pending the outcome of late-stage trials. AstraZeneca has said it will produce doses by September, but the timeline depends on how quickly the trials can be completed, given the dwindling prevalence of the virus in Britain. Late-stage trials are currently underway in Brazil and South Africa and are due to start in the United States, where prevalence is higher.

Title: Trump Delivers Economic Speech in Detroit, Proposes Tax Cuts and Trade Reforms

Donald Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, delivered a speech in Detroit on Monday, outlining his economic policy proposals, which included tax cuts, trade reforms, and infrastructure spending. The speech aimed to reassure mainstream Republicans and workers who support his "America First" philosophy.

Trump's plan includes reducing individual income tax rates from seven to three brackets, with rates of 33%, 25%, and 12%. He also proposed reducing the business tax rate from 35% to 15% and allowing parents to fully deduct the average cost of child-care spending from their taxes. Additionally, Trump called for tariffs against countries that "cheat" by unfairly subsidizing their goods.

The speech was seen as a reset and contrast speech, blending conservative economic theory with Trump's populist message. Republican strategist Ford O'Connell described it as "one of his best policy speeches," as Trump aimed to solidify the Republican base while pushing back against the notion that he lacks substance.

Trump's plan has been met with mixed reactions from economists and experts. Jared Bernstein, an economist with the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, said that while Trump's plan raises more revenue than his earlier proposal, it still loses trillions of dollars. He questioned what Trump plans to renegotiate on NAFTA and how it would benefit average families.

Douglas Holtz-Eakin, president of American Action Forum, called Trump's plan a "peace offering to House Republicans" but criticized it for not being forward-looking, citing Trump's focus on reviving American steel.

Donald Grimes, an economist at the University of Michigan, praised Trump's proposal for a 10% tax rate on profits earned abroad but repatriated to the US, but noted that Trump's trade protectionism is out of step with economic realities.

Overall, Trump's speech presented a mix of policy prescriptions aimed at uniting Republicans and workers, but experts remain skeptical about the details and potential impact of his proposals.

Title: Government Audit Reveals Minimal Impact of Sequestration on Jobs

A recent Government Accountability Office (GAO) audit has found that the 2013 sequestration had a minimal impact on jobs, with only one permanent position eliminated at the U.S. Parole Commission. The audit, released last month, contradicts warnings from politicians and administration officials that the budget cuts would have devastating consequences on government services and the economy.

According to the GAO, seven departments or agencies did furlough employees, but this was less than a third of government agencies and departments surveyed. Instead, those 15 departments and agencies that didn't furlough employees ended up using leftover savings or cutting other programs. NASA, for example, slowed down the development of a program that would allow the U.S. to stop relying on Russia for trips to the International Space Station.

The audit also found that nearly every agency or department affected by sequestration canceled or limited bonuses, cut travel and training, and limited overtime. Nearly half of agencies and departments offered employees early retirement or bonus payments to get them to leave early. However, most managed to avoid furloughing or cutting jobs altogether.

Senator Tom Coburn, an Oklahoma Republican, has praised the audit, stating that it shows the worries over sequestration's impact on jobs were overblown. He has called on the White House to explain why some programs were cut, but federal employees were spared. The White House budget office has not yet responded to a request for comment.

Title: Analyst Urges Democrats to Consider Al Gore as a Presidential Candidate

Article:

A recent article by Sean Illing, a political theorist for Salon, has sparked a renewed discussion about Al Gore's potential presidential bid. Illing argues that Gore is a viable alternative for Democrats, citing 10 reasons why he believes the former vice president could bridge the gap between the party's establishment and progressive wings. According to Illing, Gore's political life may seem distant, but his activism and business savvy have kept him in the public eye.

The proposal has garnered attention from various conservative outlets, including Powerline, Newsbusters, and PJ Media, which have jokingly encouraged Gore to run. Rumors about Gore's potential presidential bid have been circulating for about a year, with reports of him being a vegetarian. However, Gore has denied any interest and has been focused on climate issues and his "Live Earth - Road to Paris" concert, scheduled for September 19.

In an interview at an advertising awards symposium in France in late June, Gore declined to endorse Hillary Clinton for the White House, stating it was "too early" to weigh in. This development has added to the speculation about Gore's potential presidential ambitions. While Gore has not publicly confirmed his interest in running, the idea of him as a presidential candidate has sparked a lively discussion among political analysts and observers.

Title: Trump Administration Takes Action Against University of Vermont Medical Center Over Alleged Forced Participation in Abortions

The Trump administration has taken action against the University of Vermont Medical Center (UVMC), which receives federal funds, after a nurse claimed her supervisors forced her to participate in an abortion against her will. The nurse, represented by the American Center for Law & Justice (ACLJ) attorney Jordan Sekulow, filed a complaint in May 2018, alleging that UVMC broke the law by forcing her to assist in an elective abortion despite her conscience-based objection.

According to Sekulow, the Trump administration, through the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), is the first to enforce the federal law, the Church Amendment, passed by Congress in 1973. The amendment protects healthcare providers who object to performing or participating in certain medical procedures, including abortions.

The nurse, who wishes to remain anonymous, alleged that she was forced to assist in an elective abortion, which she believed was a miscarriage, only to later discover it was an abortion. Sekulow stated that UVMC's policy, which dates back to 2017, allows for elective abortions, or "abortions for abortion's sake," after the former CEO of Planned Parenthood New England joined the Board of Trustees.

HHS's Office of Civil Rights (OCR) has given UVMC 30 days to change its policies. Sekulow emphasized that UVMC is ignoring the nurse's rights by saying it will accommodate her objections, stating that the federal law requires the accommodation of objectors.

UVMC responded, stating that it has "robust, formal protections that safeguard both our employees' religious, ethical, and cultural beliefs, and our patients' rights to access safe and legal abortion." The medical center added that it does not discriminate against employees who exercise their rights to opt out of procedures they object to, including "termination of pregnancy."

Title: US Secretary of State Pompeo to Meet with Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov Amid Ongoing Tensions Over Venezuela

Article:

United States Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is set to meet with Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov on Monday in Finland, amidst ongoing tensions over Russia's role in supporting Venezuelan dictator Nicolas Maduro. The meeting comes as the situation in Venezuela continues to deteriorate, with the country's military and government officials defecting from Maduro's regime.

During a press conference on his plane, Pompeo stated that the US is working to ensure the Venezuelan people receive the democracy they deserve. He emphasized that it is only a matter of time until Maduro is gone, citing the worsening conditions on the ground and the fact that many military officials have defected.

Pompeo also noted that Maduro was convinced by the Russians to stay in the country after being ready to leave permanently for Cuba late last week. He stated that the Venezuelan people can see the conditions continue to deteriorate, making it difficult for Maduro to maintain his presence.

The US has been critical of Russia's continued support for Maduro, with White House National Security Advisor John Bolton tweeting that the US will not tolerate foreign military interference in the Western Hemisphere. Bolton emphasized that President Trump has made it clear that there will be costs for those who further Maduro's usurpation and repression.

During his visit to Finland, Pompeo will also give a speech on Arctic policy and meet with leaders from the Arctic Council.

Title: Obama and Romney Prepare for Final Debate, Jabs Intensify

Article:

In the final stretch of the presidential campaign, President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney are gearing up for their third and final debate on Monday. The two candidates have been trading barbs and jokes, with Obama labeling Romney's policy changes as "Romnesia" and Romney criticizing the president's handling of foreign policy.

The debate will focus on foreign policy, an area where Obama has traditionally polled better. However, last week's debate exposed a weakness in the president's record, particularly regarding the September 11 attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi, Libya, which left four Americans dead. Romney has capitalized on this by criticizing the president's delayed response to the attack.

The stakes are high, with the race tightening and both candidates seeking to gain an edge. According to a George Washington University professor, Albert May, "anything that moves the polls a point or two is going to be important." The debates have taken on an outsize importance this year, with Romney receiving his biggest poll bump after the first debate and Obama having his best fundraising day ever after the second debate.

The Obama campaign is touting the president's record on foreign policy, highlighting his decision to end the war in Iraq and refocus on al-Qaeda. Romney, on the other hand, has been criticized for his lack of a clear plan to end the war in Afghanistan and his failure to outline a plan to keep the country safe.

While some experts believe the debates may not have as much impact as the first debate, others argue that they will still be crucial in shaping the outcome of the election. According to a Gallup study, only two debates between 1960 and 2004 moved the meter and changed the direction of the polls. This year's debates seem to be altering the electoral landscape, with Romney closing the gap with Obama in the polls.

The Obama campaign has received a boost from recent polls, which show the president with healthy leads in key swing states Iowa and Wisconsin. The debates have also had an impact on fundraising, with Obama raising a record amount after the second debate.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Immigration Stance Questioned by Hispanic Advocacy Group

The Hillary Rodham Clinton campaign's stance on immigration is facing scrutiny from at least one Hispanic advocacy group after former New York Governor Eliot Spitzer revealed that he was instructed to cancel a proposal to issue driver's licenses to illegal immigrants in 2007 to help her presidential campaign. In an interview with former Obama strategist David Axelrod, Spitzer stated that the Clinton campaign called him in 2007 and asked him to drop the proposal to make the issue go away.

At the time, Clinton was a junior senator from New York and had struggled to answer whether she supported the policy or not during a debate. The Dream Action Coalition, a group of illegal immigrant "Dreamers," expressed disappointment and frustration with Clinton's decision, stating that she "threw the immigrant community under the bus." The group believes Clinton's record on immigration is becoming increasingly suspect as she seeks to win the Democratic presidential nomination.

The issue of licenses for illegal immigrants was a contentious topic in 2007, with some arguing that it would make it easier for terrorists to obtain identification and board planes. Clinton initially danced around the issue, taking both sides before ultimately announcing she would not support states issuing the licenses. However, she has since reversed her stance and now says she would support such licenses.

Clinton's two major opponents for the Democratic nomination, Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren, have taken consistent stances on Hispanic rights issues throughout their careers, even when they were not popular.

Title: Sanders Endorses Democratic Opponent of Wasserman Schultz in Florida Primary

Washington (CNN) - Senator Bernie Sanders has announced his support for Tim Canova, the Democratic opponent of Debbie Wasserman Schultz in Florida's 23rd congressional district, in the August 30 primary. Sanders, who has been critical of Wasserman Schultz's performance as Democratic National Committee Chairwoman, stated that he favors Canova's views over those of Wasserman Schultz.

In an interview with CNN's Jake Tapper, Sanders said, "Well, clearly, I favor her opponent. His views are much closer to mine than hers." Canova, a law professor at Nova Southeastern University, has been endorsed by Sanders and has received a fundraising email from the senator's campaign.

Canova has accused Wasserman Schultz of ignoring the economic issues in her home district and has expressed doubt that she can heal the intra-party rifts created during the primary. Sanders has also stated that if he is elected president, he would not reappoint Wasserman Schultz as DNC Chairwoman.

Wasserman Schultz responded to Sanders' endorsement by stating that she remains neutral in the Democratic presidential race and is confident in her ability to serve the people of Florida's 23rd district. She also emphasized her commitment to working with Sanders for Democratic victories in the fall.

The endorsement is the latest development in the ongoing feud between Sanders and Wasserman Schultz, who has been criticized by Sanders' campaign for her handling of the Democratic primary process. Sanders has accused the DNC of favoring his presidential primary challenger, Hillary Clinton, through debates held on Saturday nights, closed primaries in major states, and the use of superdelegates.

Title: Nikki Haley Pokes Fun at Trump, Kanye West, and Jeff Sessions at Al Smith Dinner

Nikki Haley, the outgoing US Ambassador to the United Nations, took aim at several high-profile targets during her speech at the annual Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation dinner in New York City. The event, which raises funds for Catholic charities, is a tradition where speakers often poke fun at themselves and political figures.

Haley, a 46-year-old Indian-American woman, poked fun at President Donald Trump, Kanye West, and Attorney General Jeff Sessions. She joked about Elizabeth Warren's recent DNA test, which aimed to prove her Native American heritage. Haley quipped that Trump asked her if she was from the same tribe as Warren, referencing the president's past criticism of Warren as "Pocahontas."

Haley also shared some humorous anecdotes about her time as UN ambassador, including a conversation with Trump, who advised her to "brag about my accomplishments" during her remarks. She also joked about fake news reports that Kanye West had been sworn in as her replacement.

In addition to her lighthearted jabs, Haley used the platform to offer her perspective on the current state of US politics. She noted that the "toxic political environment" has led politicians to describe their opponents as enemies or evil, and emphasized that this is not the case. "In America, our political opponents are not evil," she said.

Haley's speech was part of the annual dinner, which raised almost $4 million for Catholic children's charities this year. The event, now in its seventh decade, honors the late Governor of New York and America's first Catholic presidential nominee, Alfred E. Smith.

Title: Vice President Mike Pence Visits Migrant Shelters, Criticizes CNN's Coverage

Vice President Mike Pence visited migrant shelters in the McAllen, Texas, area on Friday, where he blasted CNN's coverage of his trip, calling it "dishonest." Pence took to Twitter to express his discontent, stating that CNN's coverage was "dishonest" and that the network only showed footage of a large group of male migrants, who shouted "no shower!" to cameras, while ignoring the excellent care being provided to families and children.

During his visit, Pence and his team took reporters to a detention facility on the border, where they were told that the migrants were being treated well. Pence also defended U.S. Customs and Border Protection agents from comparisons made by freshmen Democrats that holding centers are similar to concentration camps. He emphasized that the Nazis killed people, while CBP agents are saving lives every day.

Pence's tweet stated that CNN's coverage was "dishonest" and that the network only showed footage of men in a temporary holding area, ignoring the compassionate care being provided to families and children. He also claimed that the crisis at the southern border is real and overwhelming the system, and that Democrats in Congress have refused to fund additional bed space.

The visit and Pence's tweet sparked a heated debate on social media, with some criticizing his comments as political grandstanding and others defending his stance on the border crisis.

Title: Trump's Promise to Investigate Clinton's Emails Sparks Outrage, But Double Standards Persist

Article:

In the aftermath of the presidential debate, Donald Trump's promise to instruct the attorney general to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate Hillary Clinton's email scandal has sparked widespread outrage. Trump's statement, which accused Clinton of lying and deleting emails, has been met with criticism from pundits and analysts who claim it is a threat to the rule of law and an attempt to politicize the justice system.

However, some critics argue that Trump's statement is a reflection of the anger and frustration many Americans feel towards Clinton's handling of her email server. They point out that Clinton deleted 33,000 emails and claimed she was unaware of the subpoena, which has led to accusations of deception.

Clinton responded by saying that Trump's temperament is not suitable for the presidency, and Trump shot back, "Because you'd be in jail." The exchange has led to accusations that Trump wants to jail his political enemies and turn America into a banana republic.

However, some analysts argue that the outrage over Trump's statement is misplaced and ignores the real anger towards Clinton's handling of her email server. They point out that Clinton has been treated differently by the Department of Justice, which has been accused of being soft on her and other high-profile individuals.

The article also highlights the case of Jeffrey Hurant, the CEO of gay escort site Rentboy.com, who pleaded guilty to federal charges of promoting prostitution and was forced to hand over $10 million in revenue. The article questions why there is more outrage over Trump's statement than the way the Department of Justice treats individuals like Hurant.

Clinton has also called for a special prosecutor to investigate trade deals between the United States and other countries, specifically mentioning China's alleged dumping of steel in the US. However, some critics argue that this is a double standard, as Clinton has not shown any willingness to investigate China's actions.

The article concludes by noting that the real outrage should be focused on the way the government treats individuals like Hurant, rather than Trump's statement. It also highlights the potential consequences of overturning the Citizens United decision, which could lead to the criminalization of certain types of privately funded political speech.

Title: Judge Rules Philadelphia's Safe Injection Site Does Not Violate Federal Drug Laws

Article:

A Philadelphia-based nonprofit, Safehouse, has received a major boost in its efforts to open the country's first medically supervised heroin consumption site. A judge ruled on Wednesday that the proposed site does not violate federal drug laws, bringing the project one step closer to reality.

The Justice Department had argued that Safehouse's plan would violate the "crackhouse statute," a decades-old law that prohibits the operation of facilities for the purpose of drug use or distribution. However, Judge Gerald Austin McHugh disagreed, stating that Safehouse intends to reduce drug use, not facilitate it.

In his ruling, McHugh noted that Safehouse's approach is closer to the harm reduction strategies endorsed by Congress than the dangerous conduct prohibited by the crackhouse statute. The judge also pointed out that there is no evidence that lawmakers considered safe injection sites when writing the statute, as they were not popular at the time.

Safehouse's plan is to provide a safe and clean environment for individuals to inject intravenous opioids, with medical personnel on hand to prevent overdoses and provide social services. The organization's goal is to reduce the number of overdose deaths and help individuals access treatment.

The Justice Department had sued Safehouse in February, citing concerns that the site would facilitate drug use and undermine efforts to combat the opioid epidemic. However, many cities and states have already implemented harm reduction strategies, including needle exchanges and medical marijuana programs, which are not explicitly prohibited by the crackhouse statute.

The ruling is a significant victory for Safehouse and its supporters, who argue that safe injection sites can help save lives and reduce the spread of diseases. The Trump administration, however, has taken a different stance, with Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein arguing that safe injection sites would destroy neighborhoods and attract drug dealers.

The decision is a major milestone in the ongoing debate over safe injection sites, with several American cities and states considering similar initiatives. While the Justice Department has repeatedly used the crackhouse statute to block or delay proposed sites, the ruling in Philadelphia's case could pave the way for other cities to move forward with their own harm reduction strategies.

Title: Unraveling the DNC Hack and Antifa: Exposing Media Bias and Government Bureaucracy

The Democratic National Committee (DNC) hack and the subsequent investigation have been shrouded in controversy, with many questions still unanswered. The FBI's conclusion that Russia was responsible for the hack, based on a private cybersecurity firm's findings, has been met with skepticism by WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, who claims the emails were not provided by Russia. The DNC's decision to outsource the investigation to a private firm raises concerns about the reliability of the evidence.

The story of the hack is still unfolding, and it may ultimately reveal that other actors were involved beyond Russia. The FBI's handling of the investigation has been criticized, with some questioning the agency's motives and methods. Former FBI Director James Comey's actions during the 2016 election, including his decision to leak his own notes to the media, have been scrutinized.

The media's portrayal of Comey as a dutiful FBI director, unjustly fired by a partisan President Donald Trump, has been challenged. Comey's actions during the Hillary Clinton email investigation, including his decision to clear her of wrongdoing before interviewing her, have been questioned. His testimony about the infamous meeting between Bill Clinton and then-Attorney General Loretta Lynch has also been disputed.

The media's narrative about Antifa, a group known for using violence during protests, has been criticized for being overly sympathetic. Few have condemned their violent tactics, and some have compared their actions to those of American soldiers storming the beaches on D-Day. The FBI and Department of Homeland Security had previously warned the Obama administration that Antifa was a domestic terrorist organization, but local police departments have been criticized for their lack of action against their violent activities.

The DNC hack and Antifa's violent tactics serve as a reminder of the media's role in perpetuating bias and the government's tendency to prioritize politics over transparency and accountability. The truth behind these events remains unclear, and further investigation is needed to uncover the full extent of the truth.

Title: Secret Service Agents Investigated for Impaired Driving After Leaving Bar Near White House

A recent report by the Department of Homeland Security's inspector general has revealed that two Secret Service agents were likely impaired by alcohol when they disrupted an investigation of an unattended package outside the White House in March. The agents, Marc Connolly and George Ogilvie, had spent five hours at an Irish bar and restaurant less than a mile from the White House, celebrating a colleague's retirement, before driving into the scene of the investigation.

According to the report, Ogilvie bought 14 drinks in three hours at the bar, while Connolly claimed to have consumed fewer than three drinks all night. Two other Secret Service employees corroborated Ogilvie's account, stating they consumed three drinks that he bought, and he told investigators he gave away the rest but couldn't remember to whom.

The report concluded that Connolly and Ogilvie were probably impaired by alcohol, citing the Uniformed Division officers' observations of their behavior, the fact that they had just spent the last five hours in a restaurant/bar, and that two highly experienced Secret Service supervisors drove into a crime scene inches from what the rest of the Secret Service was treating as a potential explosive device.

The incident is the latest in a series of embarrassments for the Secret Service, whose main job is to protect the U.S. president. The inspector general's office is investigating two more Secret Service incidents in March alone. In one case, agents may have used agency computers to access the job application of Jason Chaffetz, now the U.S. House member who leads the committee with oversight responsibility for the service. In the other, a senior manager allegedly sexually assaulted a female subordinate after another farewell bash that involved drinking.

The report's findings have sparked concerns about the Secret Service's "dysfunctional environment" and the need for a major cultural overhaul. The agency's director, Joseph Clancy, stated that the behavior described in the report is unacceptable and will not be tolerated. Connolly and Ogilvie have been placed on administrative leave, and the agency will propose disciplinary actions that the two agents can contest.

Title: Chinese Companies' Use of Partnerships to Acquire Technology Raises Concerns

The partnership between Chinese companies and foreign businesses has raised concerns about the potential theft of intellectual property and technology. According to business groups that represent foreign companies, Chinese partners use these partnerships to pressure foreign companies into sharing their secrets. Additionally, Chinese officials have been accused of pressuring foreign companies to grant them access to sensitive technology as part of a review process to ensure the safety of products for Chinese consumers.

One notable example is the renewable energy industry, where China used tactics to build its own industries. In 2005, Beijing mandated that 70% of wind turbines installed in China had to be manufactured domestically. This led to foreign companies like Gamesa of Spain training over 500 suppliers in China to manufacture turbine parts and setting up a plant in Tianjin. Other multinational wind turbine manufacturers followed suit. Although the Obama administration questioned the policy as a violation of World Trade Organization rules, China withdrew the policy, and by then, Chinese state-controlled enterprises had already begun assembling turbines using the same suppliers. Today, China is the world's largest market for wind turbines, with most being made by Chinese companies.

A similar phenomenon occurred in the solar energy industry. China required its first big municipal solar project to use solar panels at least 80% made in China. Companies rushed to produce in China and share technology. The Chinese government also heavily subsidized the manufacture of solar panels, mostly for export. As a result, Chinese companies ended up producing most of the world's solar panels.

Some in the Trump administration have expressed concerns that the same pattern is emerging in the automotive industry. After China opened its market to foreign auto companies, Chinese officials held a competition among global automakers to determine which companies would be allowed to enter the market. The competition included a detailed review of each company's offer to transfer technology to a joint venture with a Chinese state-owned partner.

Title: FCC Chairman Wheeler Responds to President Obama's Net Neutrality Push

The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) is facing a delicate situation as it weighs its options on Internet regulation. FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler has been considering a "hybrid" approach, which would regulate the relationships between content companies and Internet service providers, but leave the consumer side unregulated. However, President Obama recently issued a statement calling for full net neutrality, urging the FCC to reclassify wired and wireless broadband Internet as a "common carrier" service subject to strict government oversight.

In response, Wheeler released a statement emphasizing the FCC's agreement with the President on the importance of an open Internet platform, where no players are advantaged over others, and that Internet companies should not be able to block content or degrade its delivery. However, the FCC does not seem to share the President's enthusiasm for reclassifying Internet providers as "common carriers," which would give the government the power to ensure evenhanded treatment of all traffic on the networks.

Industry groups argue that this reclassification would threaten the entrepreneurial spirit that led to the growth of the Internet, as government regulation could stifle innovation. Wheeler noted that reclassification "brings with it policy issues that run the gamut from privacy to universal service to the ability of federal agencies to protect consumers," indicating that the FCC needs more time to consider whether this approach is in the best interest of consumers.

The FCC also wants to ensure its case is legally airtight before announcing any rule changes. The Commission's 2010 Open Internet Rules were struck down by the D.C. Circuit Court in January due to the FCC's inability to prove it had the authority to impose those requirements. Reclassifying broadband providers as common carriers would be one way to establish that authority, but the Commission would need to prove that this change will benefit consumers and the Internet as a whole. Wheeler wants to ensure that the FCC can make this case and is seeking more time to examine the issue and ensure that any approach taken can withstand legal challenges.

Title: G7 Foreign Ministers Aim to Send "Clear and Coordinated Message" to Russia Over Syria

The Group of Seven (G7) foreign ministers, led by US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, are set to send a unified message to Russia regarding its support for Syrian President Bashar al-Assad. The move comes in the wake of a recent nerve gas attack in Syria that left scores dead, followed by US airstrikes on a Syrian air base.

The G7 foreign ministers, which also include British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida, and others, aim to pressure Russia to end its backing of the Assad regime. The meeting is being hosted by Italian Foreign Minister Angelino Alfano, who noted that the US airstrikes have contributed to a "renewed harmony" between the US and its European partners.

Russia and Iran have issued a joint statement, warning that they will "respond with force" to any aggression in the wake of the airstrikes. The statement reads, "What America waged in an aggression on Syria is a crossing of red lines. From now on we will respond with force to any aggressor or any breach of red lines from whoever it is and America knows our ability to respond well."

US National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster has called on Russia to re-evaluate its support for the Assad regime, stating that Russia will have to decide whether it wants to continue backing a "murderous regime." The meeting between Tillerson and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov is expected to be a key discussion point in the coming days.

Title: Experts Weigh in on U.S. Elections: A Hawk in the White House Regardless of Winner

The upcoming U.S. presidential election has sparked concerns about the potential implications for global politics. Vijay Prashad, a prominent expert, shared his thoughts on the matter in an interview with Amy Goodman. When asked about the differences between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, Prashad noted that while there are significant differences in domestic policies, the international implications are less distinct.

Prashad described Donald Trump as "erratic" and expressed concerns about his potential presidency, stating that "God knows what he'll do once he becomes president." He also highlighted Trump's association with white nationalists and his own perceived white nationalist views.

On the other hand, Prashad criticized Hillary Clinton for her role in pushing for the Libyan operation during her time as Secretary of State. He argued that this demonstrates a "profound dangerous tendency to go into wars overseas, damn the consequences." This sentiment was echoed by Medea Benjamin, who noted that regardless of who wins the election, a hawk will be in the White House.

Prashad's comments underscore the concerns about the potential consequences of the U.S. presidential election on global politics. While there are differences in domestic policies between the two candidates, the international implications may be more nuanced.

Title: Republicans Struggle to Address Minimum Wage Hike, Face Criticism for Inadequate Responses

Article:

A recent survey showing widespread support for raising the federal minimum wage has put pressure on Republican politicians to take a stance on the issue. Most have done so, and their responses have been overwhelmingly opposed to increasing the wage above its current level of $7.25 an hour. Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker and New Jersey Governor Chris Christie are among those who have faced criticism for their views on the matter.

During a speech at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, Christie expressed his frustration with the minimum wage debate, stating, "I'm tired of hearing about the minimum wage. I really am. I don't think there's a mother or a father sitting around the kitchen table tonight in America saying, 'You know, honey, if our son or daughter could just make a higher minimum wage, my God, all of our dreams would be realized.'" He added, "Is that what parents aspire to for our children? They aspire to a greater, growing America where their children have the ability to make much more money and have much greater success than they have, and that's not about a higher minimum wage."

While it is true that many parents aspire to more for their children, some argue that this is an argument for measures to redistribute wealth and opportunity, rather than simply opposing a minimum wage increase. In a socially stratified America with limited upward mobility, investing in disadvantaged communities through education funding, public works projects, and other initiatives could help bridge the gap.

Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker is facing a tough reelection battle against Democrat Mary Burke, and his administration has rebuffed efforts to raise the state's minimum wage in accordance with a state law that calls for the minimum to be a "living wage." The administration argues that $7.25 an hour is a living wage, despite MIT calculations showing that a single parent would need to earn $21.17 an hour to make a living wage in the state capital of Madison.

Walker has stated that the minimum wage does not serve a purpose and would rather help Wisconsinites secure higher-paying jobs. However, this stance has been criticized, as 500,000 workers in the state would see a raise if the minimum wage went from $7.25 to $10.10 an hour.

The Republican Party's inability to discuss the minimum wage without botching basic facts or seeming insensitive has been a recurring theme. Despite evidence showing that minimum wage hikes do not kill job growth and that most minimum wage earners are not high school students seeking a "starter wage," the party's stance remains opposed to increasing the wage.

Title: Trump Claims Democrats are Meddling in Midterm Elections through Russia Investigation

Article:

President Donald Trump tweeted on May 29, 2018, that Democrats are meddling in the upcoming midterm elections by continuing the Russia investigation. He stated that the 13 Angry Democrats, including those who worked for former President Barack Obama, are working on a "rigged Russia Witch Hunt" that should be investigating Hillary Clinton's campaign instead.

Trump's tweets also mentioned that the special counsel's investigation has been ongoing for over a year, but it is unclear when it may conclude. He expressed his desire to focus on other issues, such as North Korea, trade deals, the economy, and rebuilding the military.

It is worth noting that the Russia investigation is being led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, who is investigating potential collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia during the 2016 presidential election. The investigation has led to charges against several individuals, including former Trump campaign officials and associates.

The exact timeline for the conclusion of the investigation is unclear, as it is ongoing and dependent on the discovery of new evidence and the cooperation of witnesses.

Title: Political Divide Widens on Climate Change, Despite Consensus on Science

Article:

A recent report by the Pew Research Center highlights the growing political divide in the United States on climate change and other science-based issues. The study found that only 27% of Republicans believe the Earth is warming due to human activity, compared to 71% of Democrats. This disparity is a reflection of the increasing polarization of American society, with political party identification playing a significant role in shaping opinions on climate and energy issues.

The report, which surveyed 2,002 adults in 2014, also found that party identification was more likely to determine a respondent's stance on these issues than their level of education or scientific knowledge. However, the study did reveal some exceptions to this trend. Respondents with a greater understanding of science were more likely to support scientific advancements and futuristic technologies, such as using animals in research, expanding nuclear power, and considering genetically modified foods safe to eat.

Interestingly, the report found that politics was not the only factor at play when it came to other science-based issues. For example, respondents were less likely to have their views on the safety of eating genetically modified foods, space travel, animal research, and biomedicine determined solely by their political leanings.

The study also revealed a surprising correlation between political parties on government spending and scientific research. A majority of both Democrats (83%) and Republicans (62%) agreed that government investment in scientific research pays off in the long run.

The Pew report highlights the need for a more nuanced understanding of the factors that influence public opinion on science-based issues. While political polarization is a significant factor, it is not the only one. Education, scientific knowledge, and other factors also play a role in shaping public opinion.

Title: Washington Post Places Story About Brett Kavanaugh Coaching Basketball Under "Public Safety" Category, Sparks Controversy

The Washington Post published a story about Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh returning to coach his daughter's basketball team under its "public safety" category, drawing criticism from conservatives. The article reported that Kavanaugh had told the Senate Judiciary Committee last month that he "may never be able to coach again" due to accusations of sexual misconduct, which he denied, that were made against him during his confirmation hearing.

The story was flagged by National Republican Senatorial Committee member Logan Dobson, who questioned its placement in the public safety section. The article was placed above a story about a 6-year-old child struck by a bus in Charles County, Maryland.

A spokesperson for The Washington Post explained that stories written by the author of the piece on Kavanaugh automatically default to the public safety category. However, the spokesperson acknowledged that the story should not have been categorized as such and will no longer appear under that category.

The story has sparked controversy on social media, with some users criticizing the Washington Post for its categorization and others defending the decision. The article is not categorized as "local" but can still be seen on a page cataloging the Post's public safety stories.

Kavanaugh, 53, was confirmed by the Senate mostly along party lines, 51-49, on October 5. Senator Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) was the only Democrat to vote to confirm Kavanaugh.

Title: Tom Steyer's Climate-Focused Strategy Aims to Make Climate Change a Defining Issue in 2016 Elections

Tom Steyer, a California billionaire and hedge fund executive turned green activist, is planning to spend $100 million to make climate change a defining issue in the 2016 elections. According to sources familiar with the plan, Steyer's strategy involves targeting key races, including Senate and gubernatorial contests in Iowa, New Hampshire, Florida, and possibly Pennsylvania. This move aims to give his signature climate cause a starring role in the next presidential race.

Steyer's operation is expected to be "very aggressive" and will set itself apart from the efforts of mainstream environmental groups, said Betsy Taylor, a leader of a network of wealthy climate donors. The billionaire is not publicly disclosing how he plans to spend his projected campaign war chest through his NextGen Climate Action super PAC.

Steyer's strategy includes trying to influence the debate about climate change in Senate races in Iowa and New Hampshire, as well as the gubernatorial contest in Florida. He may also spend money influencing the governor's race in Pennsylvania, where one of the Democrats vying to unseat Republican incumbent Tom Corbett is former Bill Clinton environmental aide Katie McGinty.

The billionaire's plan also focuses on states where a candidate who supports acting on climate change faces an opponent who is a "denier." This description matches the governor's race in Florida, where Republican Gov. Rick Scott's top challenger is Democratic former Gov. Charlie Crist, and the Senate race in Iowa, where Democratic Rep. Bruce Braley and several potential Republican challengers are vying to replace retiring Democrat Tom Harkin.

Steyer's strategy is expected to make him a progressive counterweight to big conservative donors like Charles and David Koch. However, it is unclear how far even $100 million will go in the post-Citizens United world, or whether global warming can compete on the presidential campaign trail with issues like jobs and President Barack Obama's health care law.

Steyer's plan is part of a broader effort to make climate change a key issue in the 2016 elections. The billionaire has told potential backers he has big plans, including trying to influence the debate about climate change in Senate races in Iowa and New Hampshire, as well as the gubernatorial contest in Florida.

Title: IRS Paid Billions in Tax Credits to Illegal Immigrants, Study Finds

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has paid out billions of dollars in tax credits to illegal immigrants, according to a study released by the Center for Immigration Studies. The report, written by CIS fellow David North, found that the IRS doled out $4.2 billion in the "additional child tax credit" in 2010 to individuals using an individual taxpayer identification number (ITIN), which is often a sign of an illegal immigrant.

The study suggests that mid-level IRS managers may have expanded the tax credit beyond its initial scope, allowing illegal immigrants to claim the credit. North stated that he found no evidence that top leaders at the IRS made the decision to allow illegal immigrants to collect the tax credit, and that it was not the intent of Congress.

The "additional child tax credit" was created to help low-income families, but it has become an avenue for fraud, particularly when combined with illegal immigrant workers. The number of ITIN filers has increased significantly, from 796,000 in 2005 to 2.3 million in 2010. The IRS has tried to limit the issuance of ITINs and improve identity document reviews, but abuses still persist.

The study highlights several red flags, including a single address in Atlanta receiving 23,994 ITIN-related tax refunds, with 8,393 refunds deposited to a single bank account. North also identified towns with high concentrations of ITIN filers, such as Frankford, Delaware, and Parksley, Virginia. In Parksley, a tax counselor suspected a rival business was responsible for the ITIN applications.

The IRS has repeatedly stated that it does not believe the law allows it to deny illegal immigrants the tax credit, and disputes that it has the legal authority to deny claims even when they are not backed up by documents showing that the children actually live in the U.S. The agency has also said it does not have the legal authority to deny credits during processing when documentation is not provided.

Title: White House Retracts Doomsday Predictions on $85 Billion Spending Cuts

The White House is scaling back its initial warnings about the impact of the $85 billion in federal spending cuts, which have been in effect for over a week. Gene Sperling, the White House's top economic adviser, stated that the cuts will not have a significant immediate impact, but will instead be a "slow grind" over the long term. This is in contrast to previous warnings from President Obama and his Cabinet, which predicted that the cuts would result in furloughs or pay cuts for middle-class workers, such as teachers, Capitol Hill janitors, and air traffic controllers.

Sperling declined to directly address questions about whether the worst-case-scenario rhetoric has hurt the president's credibility on the issue, instead reiterating that independent economists forecast the cuts will result in 750,000 fewer jobs and slower economic growth.

Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell argued that the 2.4% reduction in spending over the next six months is comparable to the average American's experience when the payroll tax holiday expired in January. He stated that Americans absorbed similar cuts earlier this year and are now adjusting to the new reality.

The spending cuts, known as sequestration, were agreed upon in 2011 as a way to reduce defense and domestic spending. However, the cuts were intended to be so drastic that Democrats and Republicans would be forced to compromise before they started. Sperling rejected several Republican-backed plans and stated that no compromise would be reached unless the party agrees to tax increases.

Senator Kelly Ayotte, R-N.H., argued that Congress agreed to tax increases in January at the president's request and questioned why Obama and other Democrats will not agree to additional spending cuts. She proposed potential pay freezes for federal employees and reforms to the federal food stamps program.

The debate comes ahead of a new deadline on March 27, which could spell a government shutdown and a debt-ceiling clash in May. House Speaker John Boehner announced that his chamber will move to pass a measure to keep government open through September 30. McConnell stated that a government shutdown is unlikely to come from his side of Capitol Hill. The White House said it will continue to roll back the cuts, which hit domestic and defense spending equally.

Sperling emphasized that the White House is committed to finding a way for Republicans and Democrats to reach a compromise. The billions in cuts apply to the remainder of fiscal 2013, which ends September 30, and will continue to slash government spending by about $1 trillion over a 10-year period if no deal is reached.

Title: Global Economic Concerns Weigh on US Jobs Report, Stocks and Bonds

The latest jobs report in the United States has added to the global economic concerns, with the Dow Jones industrial average losing 2.22 percent and the main index of the German stock market closing down 3.4 percent. The report showed a gain of 69,000 jobs in May, but the underlying pace of the domestic economy is considered sluggish, driven by manufacturing and restrained by slowing global demand.

The report also showed a decline in construction jobs, with 28,000 fewer jobs in the sector. While some industries, such as healthcare and transportation, saw gains, others, like manufacturing, were flat. The unemployment rate remained steady at 8.2 percent.

Economists are concerned about the impact of the European debt crisis and slowing growth in China and India on the US economy. "The reason why it was never going to build momentum going forward was simply because the rest of the world was slowing down," said Steve Blitz, chief economist of ITG Investment Research.

The report also highlighted the uncertainty surrounding the global economy, with manufacturers concerned about the potential for a global slowdown. "We're very concerned about Europe because a blowup in Europe means a global slowdown," said Ellen Zentner, senior United States economist for Nomura.

The Federal Reserve may consider stepping up its stimulus campaign to boost the economy, which needs to grow by about 125,000 jobs each month just to maintain the current unemployment rate. The Fed's next meeting is scheduled for late June.

The report also showed a decline in the number of long-term unemployed, those who have been looking for work for more than half a year, with 300,000 more people in this category. Many of these individuals have been out of work for a long time and are struggling to find employment.

Overall, the report painted a mixed picture of the US economy, with some industries showing growth and others struggling. While some economists are concerned about the pace of the recovery, others believe that the data is too early to declare a significant slowdown.

Title: Trump Reverses Course, Says White House Coronavirus Task Force Will Continue "Indefinitely"

Article:

In a sudden about-face, President Donald Trump announced on Wednesday that the White House task force on coronavirus will continue "indefinitely" and shift its focus to reopening the economy and manufacturing vaccines. This decision comes a day after Vice President Mike Pence and other officials said the group's work would be transferred to federal agencies as early as this month.

The task force, created in January to coordinate the response to the virus, was initially expected to be disbanded. However, Trump's latest thinking on the matter left many questions unanswered, including the composition of the task force and its focus. The president stated that the group will focus more on "safety" and reopening the nation's economy, as well as vaccine production.

In a series of tweets, Trump emphasized the task force's continued importance, stating, "The Task Force will continue on indefinitely with its focus on SAFETY & OPENING UP OUR COUNTRY AGAIN. The Task Force will also be very focused on Vaccines & Therapeutics. Thank you!"

During a trip to Arizona on Tuesday, Trump linked the decision to disband the group with his broader desire to reopen the nation and recharge its economy. He suggested that winding down the task force would signal a new phase in the government's response to the virus.

Democrats and other critics have blasted Trump's plan to reduce the scope of the task force, citing concerns that the virus's death toll will rise as states reopen businesses and economies. The virus has killed more than 70,000 Americans, according to Johns Hopkins University, and the number of new daily cases remains high.

Representative Lloyd Doggett, D-Texas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Health Subcommittee, criticized Trump's decision, saying, "President Trump waves the white flag of surrender and winds down his 'task force,' As the death toll soars, it is the task force that gets buried." Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders, a former Democratic presidential candidate, called the decision a "true American tragedy" and predicted that "thousands will unnecessarily die" due to Trump's "contempt for science."

Title: Sen. Susan Collins Considers Libertarian Ticket, Joining Mitt Romney and Jeb Bush in Exploring Alternative

Article:

Senator Susan Collins of Maine has become the latest prominent Republican to express interest in the Libertarian Party's presidential ticket, joining Mitt Romney and Jeb Bush in considering a vote for Gary Johnson and Bill Weld. Collins, a veteran centrist, praised Johnson's running mate, former Massachusetts Governor Bill Weld, with whom she had worked on various projects. This development highlights a growing trend in 2016 politics, where libertarian candidates are making inroads in the center, rather than the rightmost precincts.

The Libertarian ticket, led by Johnson, a former New Mexico governor, and Weld, a former Massachusetts governor, has gained unprecedented support, with 8-10% of voters nationwide backing them. However, unlike past libertarian campaigns, this ticket is not relying on the Republican base for support, but rather is drawing energy from the center.

The Johnson-Weld campaign emphasizes moderation, presenting themselves as the "sane" and "responsible" choice, willing to work with the best people and ideas from both parties. A recent Johnson video contrasts the bickering and shouting of Trump and Clinton with the calm and collected Libertarian alternative.

Libertarians have historically been seen as a balance wheel against factional politics, upholding rights for all and a strong rule of law. This can make them a middle ground between opposing groups, as seen in European liberal parties, which often occupy a centrist position between labor and conservative parties.

The reaction to Collins' comments was mixed, with some libertarians and conservatives expressing skepticism, citing her not-so-libertarian voting record in the Senate. However, others see this as an opportunity to study and learn from more-or-less libertarian candidates who can win votes from non-libertarians.

The article concludes that while libertarians may not guarantee success as an independent force, they can still play a significant role in shaping the political landscape, even if they join a larger party and work within it. The wider significance of this trend will be seen after the election, when it comes time to pick up the pieces and consider the future of libertarian ideas and the party.

Title: US Job Market Report: Hiring Pace Slows, Unemployment Rate Falls, and Wage Growth Remains Sluggish

The latest US job market report has revealed a mixed bag of trends, with the pace of hiring slowing down, the unemployment rate falling, and wage growth remaining sluggish. According to the report, the US economy added 164,000 jobs in April, a slower pace than the 191,000 monthly average over the past year. The unemployment rate fell to 3.9% in April, down from 4.1% in the previous six months.

Economists believe that the labor market is beginning to tighten, with many employers struggling to find new workers. However, wage growth has not yet responded to the tightening labor market, with wages rising only 2.6% from a year earlier in April. This sluggish wage growth has confounded policymakers and investors who had expected a more significant impact on wages due to the increasingly tight labor market.

The Federal Reserve is likely to take the report as a sign that the economy remains strong, but not overheating. The central bank is expected to lift interest rates next month and consider one or two more increases later in the year. Investors see a slightly lower chance of at least four rate increases this year, according to CME Group data.

Market reactions to the jobs report were mixed, with the WSJ Dollar Index jumping in response to the report, typically a sign of a strong report. However, benchmark Treasury yields fell, suggesting some investors see weakness in the numbers. This trend has been observed in recent jobs reports, partly due to the difficulty in interpreting the numbers as the economy enters the later stages of its cycle.

Title: Sanders Unveils Proposal to Expand Estate Tax, Targeting the Very Rich

Article:

Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders has introduced a proposal to significantly expand the estate tax, which has seen a significant reduction over the years. The "For the 99.8 Percent Act" would impose a graduated rate structure on the estates of the very rich, with a maximum rate of 77%.
