This plan is similar to Senator Elizabeth Warren's wealth tax proposal, although the implementation details differ.

The proposal aims to raise revenue from the richest Americans and deter the accumulation of vast dynastic wealth. Until recently, US tax law allowed individuals to pass down $5.5 million untaxed to their heirs. The 2017 Trump tax bill doubled that exemption to $11 million. Senate Republicans have introduced legislation to eliminate the estate tax entirely, allowing billions to pass tax-free from today's rich people to their children.

Sanders' proposal would create a multi-tiered structure for taxing the largest estates, including:

* A 55% bracket for wealth from $50 million to $1 billion
* A 50% bracket for wealth from $10 million to $50 million
* A 45% bracket for wealth from $3.5 million to $10 million

The vast majority of Americans do not inherit nearly that much money, but these relatively high rates would make the tax a huge deal in practice to the richest American families. Sanders' staff estimates that Warren Buffett's tax liability would nearly double, from $33 billion to $64 billion.

From a policy perspective, the goal is to raise money from the biggest winners of the past generation of economic change and break up the large fortunes that allow a relatively small number of very wealthy individuals to wield disproportionate influence over the political system.

The proposal is estimated to raise about $2.2 trillion in a 10-year window, although the exact nature of the window is uncertain due to the impact of the plan being highly sensitive to the exact timing of the deaths of a relatively small number of ultra-wealthy individuals. The Warren wealth tax proposal, on the other hand, would levy an annual fee of 2 to 3% on large fortunes, estimated to raise $2.7 trillion in a standard Congressional Budget Office 10-year scoring window.

These numbers are not exactly the same, but they are broadly similar and reflect the fact that these are essentially two different ways to reach the same goal. Experts in tax avoidance have tended to tilt more in favor of the wealth tax direction as perhaps easier to force compliance with. However, under either scheme, the avoidance issue will come down to fussy details that neither senator has yet delved into.

In summary, the message of these dueling plans is that the left wing of the Democratic Party is eager to soak the rich, but has not yet reached a consensus on exactly how to do it.

Title: Trump Reportedly Taps Rick Perry to Lead Department of Energy

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump is reportedly set to nominate former Texas Governor Rick Perry to serve as the Secretary of the Department of Energy. Perry, a former Republican presidential candidate, had previously expressed his desire to eliminate the department during his 2012 presidential campaign. However, he forgot to name the department during a debate, famously saying "oops" when trying to recall the third agency he wanted to eliminate.

Perry's nomination comes despite his ties to the Dakota Access pipeline battle. He sits on the corporate board for Energy Transfer Partners, the parent company of Dakota Access LLC, which is pushing to build the pipeline. The Obama administration blocked the Dakota Access Pipeline easement through Lake Oahe, but the Trump administration is likely to take a different approach.

According to reports, Perry beat out two other contenders for the Cabinet post, Senator Joe Manchin, a Democrat representing West Virginia, and Ray Washburne, a Dallas investor working in oil and gas operations. Perry attended a meeting at Trump Towers on Monday but did not take questions from reporters.

The Department of Energy is responsible for promoting energy independence and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Perry's nomination has raised concerns among environmental groups, who worry about his stance on climate change and his ties to the fossil fuel industry.

Title: British Parliament Rejects Brexit Deal, Leaving Uncertainty and Crisis in Its Wake

The British Parliament has delivered a decisive blow to Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal, rejecting it by a margin of 432 to 202 votes. This outcome has sent shockwaves throughout the country, leaving the future of the United Kingdom's withdrawal from the European Union uncertain.

The vote is a significant setback for May, who had staked her premiership on the success of the deal. The rejection has triggered a no-confidence vote, which May won easily. However, the outcome has raised questions about the stability of the government and the country's ability to navigate the complex and contentious process of Brexit.

Historians are searching for parallels to this level of parliamentary rejection, with losses of 60 votes or more typically leading to the resignation of a prime minister or a no-confidence vote. However, May's deal was rejected, and she has been given a second chance to try to find a solution.

The rejection of the deal has exposed the deep divisions within the British political system. The Conservative Party, which has been divided on the issue of Brexit, has seen its hardline Brexiteers reject the deal, while many Labour Party members have opposed it as well. The rejection has also highlighted the crisis of responsibility within Parliament, as many MPs have failed to deliver on their campaign promises to deliver Brexit.

The article suggests that the rejection of the deal has made it more likely that the UK will crash out of the EU without a deal or that Brexit will be delayed or canceled altogether. The author argues that a second referendum would be more divisive and politically destructive than the first, and that failing to deliver on Brexit could do irreparable harm to the Tory party and the government's democratic legitimacy.

The article concludes that the UK must decide whether to Leave or Remain, and that it is up to Parliament to decide when and how. The rejection of the deal has left the country in a state of uncertainty, with no clear solution in sight.

Title: Rep. Paul Ryan Weighs In on Government Shutdown Debate

Article:

Representative Paul Ryan (R-Wisconsin) recently expressed his stance on the potential government shutdown debate, stating that he does not support using this tactic to force Democrats to repeal President Obama's health-care law. Instead, he believes there are more effective ways to achieve this goal, although he did not specify any particular approach.

What is notable about this debate is that Democrats are unlikely to repeal Obamacare, and the Republican Party lacks a viable political lever to make them do so. A government shutdown will not defund Obamacare, and it is unlikely to change anyone's opinion about it.

Despite this, many Republicans remain undeterred, and some, like Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, advocate for using a government shutdown as a means to defund Obamacare. This approach is driven by the changing character of Capitol Hill, where the legislative process is no longer solely focused on vote counts. Instead, some lawmakers prioritize ideological purity over practicality.

Senator Cruz has emphasized the need for the American people to "rise up" and demand that their elected officials stand by their principles, even if it means a government shutdown. However, demographics suggest that this approach is unlikely to succeed, as there are not enough like-minded voters to change the outcome.

The political polarization of America has led to a shift away from traditional vote-counting and towards ideological purity. Republicans like Senator Cruz are willing to take a stand, even if it means a government shutdown, as they believe it is better to stand by their principles than to compromise on a hated policy like Obamacare.

Representative Ryan, who sits in the middle of this ideological spectrum, faces a difficult balancing act. As the chairman of the House Budget Committee, he is committed to promoting fiscal responsibility and entitlement reform, but he also recognizes the need to work with Democrats to achieve these goals. His views on strict financial austerity elicit cheers from ideologues, but he must tread carefully to avoid losing his clout or aura.

The outcome of this debate is uncertain, as no one knows which way the political winds will blow. The stakes are high, as the House has made 40 attempts to kill Obamacare, and the consequences of failure are dire. If the government is shut down, it could have far-reaching consequences for the economy and the country's fiscal health.

Title: Secretary Kerry Discusses International Agreements and Challenges in Syria

Article:

Secretary of State John Kerry visited Indiana University to promote the Obama administration's recent international agreements, including deals on Pacific trade and Iran's nuclear program. During his speech, Kerry also addressed the ongoing crisis in Syria, where Russian warplanes are backing the government of President Bashar Assad. The U.S. has struggled to find forces to oppose Assad and the Islamic State.

In an interview with NPR's Steve Inskeep, Kerry discussed the challenges of convincing Russian President Vladimir Putin to target only Islamic extremists, not the Syrian rebels who oppose Assad. "If they're supporting Assad, they're going to attract great difficulties for themselves and for any hope of a unified, secular Syria," Kerry said.

Kerry also touched on the "deconfliction" process with Russia, aimed at avoiding clashes between U.S. and Russian warplanes. He expressed hope that the talks will lead to a broader understanding on targeting and what is truly helpful and what is not. The Secretary of State emphasized that Syria will crumble under the weight of a prolonged war and that Putin does not have an easy track in the situation.

Kerry also highlighted the importance of finding a political track to end the war in Syria, stating that if Russia is there to help prevent the takeover of the country and secure a political track, that could be positive. However, he warned that if Russia is there to uphold Assad and fake it with respect to the extremists and terrorists, that would be a serious problem.

Title: Trump's Supreme Court Shortlist: Five Conservative Nominees Emerge

The President of the United States, Donald Trump, has narrowed down his list of potential Supreme Court nominees to five finalists, with two of them being women. The median age of the reported finalists is 48, and their resumes showcase a strong conservative background. Trump has not disclosed the names of the candidates, but legal analysts, sitting jurists, and confidential sources have concluded that the following five individuals are his "final five" for the high court:

Amy Coney Barrett, 46, is a judge on the U.S. Court of Appeals (7th Circuit). She was a past editor of the Notre Dame Law Review and a law professor at Notre Dame. Barrett clerked for the late Justice Antonin Scalia and has been a subject of national headlines due to her Catholic faith and potential impact on her judicial decisions.

Joan Larsen, 49, is a judge on the U.S. Court of Appeals (6th Circuit). She graduated first in her class at Northwestern University School of Law and has had a rapid rise in her legal career, serving as a deputy assistant attorney general under George W. Bush, a justice on the Michigan Supreme Court, and a U.S. appellate judge for the past two years. Larsen is a member of the Federalist Society and a former law clerk for the late Justice Scalia.

Brett Kavanaugh, 52, is a judge on the D.C. Court of Appeals. He is a graduate of Yale Law School and clerked for Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy. Considered a protégé of Justice Kennedy, his judicial record is considered more conservative than his mentor. He later served as special prosecutor with Independent Counsel Kenneth Starr and helped lead efforts that culminated in the impeachment of Bill Clinton by the U.S. House of Representatives in 1998. He was later appointed to the federal Appeals Court by President George W. Bush.

Mike Lee, 47, is a Republican U.S. senator from Utah. Trump has mentioned Lee as a prospective high court appointee, calling him an "outstanding talent." Lee was virtually raised in the law, with his father, Rex Lee, serving as President Ronald Reagan's solicitor general, and his brother, Tom Lee, serving as a justice on the Utah Supreme Court. He clerked for Samuel Alito when the justice was an appellate judge and was general counsel to former Utah Gov. Jon Huntsman.

Amul Thapar, 49, is a judge on the U.S. Court of Appeals (6th Circuit). He is a U.C. Berkeley School of Law graduate and a protégé of Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell. Thapar has moved up the ranks, serving as U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of Kentucky, U.S. District judge from 2008 to 2015, and an appellate judge since last year. As a minority, court-watchers say he might be an attractive prospect for some Democrats in the Senate to support.

Title: Former Vice President Joe Biden Reverses Position on Complying with Congressional Subpoena

Former Vice President Joe Biden has changed his stance on complying with a congressional subpoena to testify in President Donald Trump's impeachment trial. During a town hall event in Fairfield, Iowa, Biden stated that he would obey any subpoena sent to him, a stark reversal from his earlier position.

Biden initially told the Des Moines Register's editorial board that he would defy a Senate subpoena, a stance he reiterated in a series of tweets on December 28. However, he appeared to backtrack on Saturday, saying that he would cooperate with any lawful congressional oversight requests.

When asked about the potential for a subpoena, Biden emphasized that he has "no first-hand knowledge" of the events surrounding Trump's impeachment and therefore would not be a useful witness. However, he also stated that he would "honor whatever the Congress in fact legitimately asked me to do."

Biden's reversal on the issue has sparked debate among Democratic presidential candidates, with Senator Elizabeth Warren stating that the former vice president should comply with any lawful subpoena. Warren emphasized that the focus should remain on Trump's actions and not on Biden's potential testimony.

It is worth noting that Biden's initial refusal to comply with a subpoena was met with criticism from some quarters, with some arguing that it would undermine the integrity of the impeachment process. However, Biden's subsequent reversal has brought him in line with the stance of many legal experts, who argue that complying with a subpoena is a necessary part of the democratic process.

Title: Anonymous Donors Fuel Political Ads through "Social Welfare" Organizations

The 2012 presidential campaign has seen a surge in spending on high-profile ads, with some of the heaviest advertisers being groups financed by anonymous donors. These groups, classified as "social welfare" organizations, are not organized as political committees but rather as non-profit organizations under Section 501(c)(4) of the tax code. According to NPR's money and politics correspondent Peter Overby, one such group, Crossroads GPS, has spent $29 million on ads, rivaling the campaigns themselves.

Crossroads GPS, backed by wealthy conservative donors, launched a $9 million ad campaign in swing states attacking President Obama and the health care law after the June 28 Supreme Court ruling. Officially, social welfare organizations are classified as performing some kind of public or community benefit, similar to local volunteer fire departments, Rotary International, and the League of Women Voters.

However, unlike political committees and super PACs, social welfare organizations are not required to disclose their donors. This has raised concerns about transparency and accountability in the political process. Republican strategist Karl Rove, a leader of Crossroads GPS, defended the group's classification as a social welfare organization, stating that it spends the vast majority of its money on issues advocacy, such as discussing the need to change policies on spending and debt.

Crossroads GPS, formed in 2010, has raised $77 million in its first two years, with 90% of that coming from at most 24 donors. This anonymity has made the social welfare organization approach appealing, allowing a small group of individuals to play a powerful role in the election without being accountable to anyone.

Title: Obama Meets Ukraine's President-Elect, Reiterates U.S. Policy on Providing Weapons

Article:

U.S. President Barack Obama met with Ukraine's president-elect, Petro Poroshenko, on Wednesday, discussing the ongoing crisis in Ukraine and the country's request for U.S. assistance. The meeting took place as Obama was on a trip to Poland, a key location in the Cold War era. During the meeting, Obama reiterated that the U.S. will not provide lethal weapons to Ukraine to help it fight against pro-Russian insurgents.

Poroshenko has asked for U.S. assistance, including training and advice to modernize Ukraine's military and a grant of military equipment. However, the U.S. State Department has not changed its policy on providing lethal weapons, with State Department spokesman Jen Psaki stating that the U.S. will continue to review Ukraine's requests.

During his visit to Poland, Obama also unveiled a $1 billion plan to bolster security for NATO allies, warning Russia that further aggression in Ukraine will bring more sanctions. The plan, dubbed the "European Re-Assurance Initiative," aims to increase U.S. military presence in Europe, with more troops being rotated throughout the continent, and additional military exercises and training missions.

Obama also met with Polish President Bronislaw Komorowski and other leaders, emphasizing the importance of European security and the need for Russia to "stand down" in Ukraine. He called on Russian President Vladimir Putin to encourage violent separatists in eastern Ukraine to do the same.

The president's trip will conclude on Friday in Normandy, France, with a commemoration of the 70th anniversary of the D-Day landings. Obama and Putin do not have a formal meeting scheduled, but Obama is expected to meet with his Russian counterpart during the ceremony.

In a statement, Obama emphasized the importance of rebuilding American-Russian relations, which have been strained due to Russia's annexation of Crimea. However, he noted that rebuilding trust will take time and that further Russian provocation will be met with further costs, including additional sanctions.

Title: New York City Attack Suspect's Entry into the US Under Scrutiny Amid Trump's Proposed Immigration Reforms

The recent deadly attack in New York City has brought attention to the Diversity Visa Program, which allowed the alleged perpetrator, Sayfullo Saipov, to enter the United States seven years ago. The program, established in 1990, offers a lottery for people from countries with low rates of immigration to the US. The program makes up to 50,000 immigrant visas available annually, with applicants required to prove a clean criminal record, a high school diploma or equivalent, or at least two years of work experience within the past five years.

The program has been a topic of controversy in the past, with some critics arguing it is an outdated and ineffective way to address immigration issues. President Trump has been a vocal critic of the program, calling it a "lottery" and advocating for a "merit-based" system instead. The Trump administration has also proposed revisions to the program, which could potentially impact the way immigrants are selected and admitted to the US.

Senator Chuck Schumer, who introduced the original bill that created the Diversity Visa Program, has defended the program, stating that it is a way to bring in people from underrepresented countries and promote diversity. Schumer has also called on the president to focus on anti-terrorism funding rather than politicizing the recent attack.

The attack, which occurred on Tuesday, resulted in the deaths of eight people and injuries to 11 others. The suspect, Sayfullo Saipov, is accused of driving a rented Home Depot truck down a New York City bike lane, plowing into pedestrians, and slamming into a school bus. The incident has sparked a renewed debate on immigration and national security, with some calling for stricter vetting procedures and others advocating for a more comprehensive approach to addressing the root causes of terrorism.

Title: The IRS: A Less Transparent and More Menacing Entity than Facebook

Article:

As the debate rages on about Facebook's collection of personal information, it's worth noting that many of us are already surrendering sensitive details of our lives to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) without a choice. Unlike Facebook, the IRS is not an optional service, and its demands for information are not easily ignored.

The IRS has a history of extracting and storing personal data, including financial information, business details, and family connections. This information is often obtained through audits, which can be a daunting experience for many individuals. In contrast, Facebook's data collection is based on voluntarily provided information, and users can choose to opt-out or limit their sharing.

The IRS has a poor track record of handling sensitive information, with instances of data breaches, leaks, and employee misconduct. In 2022, the agency reported that over 700,000 Social Security numbers and other sensitive records were stolen from its computers. This is a smaller number compared to Facebook's data breach, but the consequences are more severe. The stolen information includes sensitive details that few people would willingly share, such as financial information and identity verification.

The IRS has also been criticized for its handling of identity theft, with estimates suggesting that it paid out $5.8 billion in bogus refunds in 2013 due to identity theft. The agency's Data Retrieval Tool, which is used by college students to file their taxes, was breached in 2022, resulting in the theft of nearly 100,000 students' personal information and potential identity theft.

In contrast, Facebook's data collection is often seen as a minor annoyance, with users having the option to limit their sharing or opt-out altogether. However, the IRS's demands for information are mandatory, and the consequences of non-compliance are severe. As the article notes, the IRS has a history of storing data carelessly, leaking information through various channels, and hiring employees with questionable backgrounds.

While it's understandable to be concerned about Facebook's data collection, it's essential to recognize the IRS's role in extracting and storing sensitive information without consent. The agency's track record on data security and handling is far from impressive, making it a more menacing entity than Facebook.

Title: Iowa Voters Cast Their Ballots as Early Voting Begins in the Swing State

Iowa, the first swing state to open polling sites, has started its early voting process. Residents can now vote in person at their local county auditors' offices or by mail. Some areas will also offer additional satellite locations. The Polk County Auditor's office in downtown Des Moines saw a long line of voters on the first day of early voting.

Among those who cast their ballots were supporters of President Obama. Peter Clay, a 62-year-old zookeeper, volunteered for the campaign and believes it's essential to show passion and energy in the election. Victoria Walton, a librarian in Iowa City, also voted early, stating she's concerned about the election and wanted to exercise her right to vote as soon as possible.

On the other hand, some voters, like Virginia Sourbeer of Des Moines, supported Mitt Romney. She is concerned about the federal budget and spending in programs like Medicare and Social Security, and believes Romney's background and record in Massachusetts make him a better choice for the economy.

The Republican National Committee's Iowa spokesman, Tom Szold, stated that Republicans have intentionally held off on promoting absentee voting until this week, believing Romney voters will show up on Election Day if not before. However, Erin Seidler, President Obama's campaign spokeswoman in Iowa, emphasized the importance of promoting early voting, saying it makes sense to get voters to the polls as soon as possible.

As of now, Democrats have requested the overwhelming majority of absentee ballots in Iowa, while Republicans have an 18,000-person lead in voter registration. Polk County Auditor Jamie Fitzgerald noted that Democrats have a longer track record of working to get out the early vote, but Republicans are catching up. Iowa is among more than 30 states that allow early voting.

Title: Hillary Clinton Concedes Presidential Election Loss to Donald Trump

Article:

Hillary Clinton, the Democratic presidential nominee, conceded her election loss to Republican candidate Donald Trump on Wednesday morning. The outcome marked a crushing defeat for Clinton, who had been seeking to become the first female president in U.S. history. In her concession speech, Clinton acknowledged the disappointment and frustration felt by many Americans, while also urging them to respect the outcome and look to the future.

Clinton's loss was met with widespread shock and disappointment, particularly among liberal supporters who had invested heavily in her campaign. The outcome was seen as a repudiation of Clinton's candidacy, which was marred by controversy over her use of a private email server and allegations of corruption within the Clinton Foundation.

The FBI investigation into Clinton's handling of classified information and potential pay-for-play accusations involving the Clinton Foundation is expected to continue, even though she will no longer be in office. Political analysts attributed Clinton's loss to a combination of factors, including her perceived elitism and a failure to connect with voters.

Clinton's concession speech was marked by a mix of sadness and determination, as she acknowledged the disappointment felt by many Americans while also urging them to respect the outcome and look to the future. She also addressed the pain of her personal defeat, noting that her attempts to crash through the glass ceiling of American politics have been thwarted twice, first by Barack Obama in the 2008 Democratic primary and now by Trump.

Despite the disappointment, Clinton remains committed to her political ideals and encouraged young women across the country not to be discouraged by her loss. She expressed hope that someday, someone will shatter the highest and hardest glass ceiling, and that it may happen sooner than people think.

Title: Trump Signs Executive Order to Promote and Protect Religious Liberty

The White House hosted a National Day of Prayer event on Thursday, where President Donald Trump signed an executive order aimed at promoting and protecting religious liberty. The order, which marks a campaign promise fulfilled, aims to ensure that people of faith are not targeted, bullied, or silenced.

The executive order, signed in the Rose Garden, includes provisions that instruct the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) to stop enforcing the Johnson Amendment, which prohibits churches and non-profit organizations from supporting and endorsing political candidates. The order also protects the conscience of employers who do not want to provide contraception and abortion-inducing drugs in their insurance plans, as mandated by the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare).

Many evangelical leaders who pushed for the executive order see it as an important first step, but some critics argue that it falls short of expectations. Ryan T. Anderson, a senior research fellow at The Heritage Foundation, notes that the order merely reiterates existing laws and does not address the most pressing religious liberties facing Americans. He also points out that the order instructs agencies to "consider" new regulations, which is not a binding commitment.

Other faith leaders, such as Sen. James Lankford, R-Okla., and the Alliance Defending Freedom, have expressed disappointment with the order, urging the administration to take concrete steps to ensure religious freedom. However, some leaders, like Tony Perkins, president of the Family Research Council, see the order as a step in the right direction, saying it combats the hostility Christians have faced under the previous administration.

The order has also drawn criticism from the left, with some fearing it could lead to discrimination against LGBTQ individuals, same-sex couples, and women. The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) initially threatened to sue the administration but later decided against it.

The executive order is now in the hands of Congress, which is expected to take legislative action on these issues.

Title: NRA's Legal Troubles Have Cost the Organization $100 Million, CEO Wayne LaPierre Reveals

The National Rifle Association (NRA) has faced significant legal troubles, resulting in a financial hit of $100 million, according to a recording of the organization's board meeting obtained by NPR. The recording, made in January 2020, features NRA CEO Wayne LaPierre discussing the organization's financial struggles and the measures taken to stay afloat.

LaPierre attributed the financial losses to the ongoing investigations by the New York and Washington, D.C. attorneys general, which he described as "the power of weaponized government." He stated that the organization had to make $80 million in cuts to its budget to stay afloat, reducing its size and reframing its operations.

The NRA's internal turmoil began in April 2019, when then-President Oliver North resigned amid allegations of self-dealing and poor management of NRA funds. The organization has since faced eight board member resignations and is embroiled in protracted and costly legal battles with its former public relations firm.

LaPierre's comments on the financial losses are the first time he has put a figure to the cost of the ongoing legal battles. The NRA and its affiliates raised over $412 million and spent over $423 million in 2018, the last year for which there is public reporting.

The organization has maintained its membership level, with LaPierre claiming it remains at around 5 million. However, he acknowledged that there is still much work to be done to address the financial situation. The NRA has also announced layoffs and pay cuts, citing the coronavirus crisis as the reason.

The recording also features LaPierre criticizing the attorneys general of New York and D.C., comparing their investigations to oppression from autocratic regimes. The offices of the D.C. and New York attorneys general declined to comment.

The recording was made during an NRA board meeting in Virginia, attended by board members, staff, and a few dozen NRA members. Ron Carter, vice president of Save the Second, an organization advocating for financial reform and accountability within the NRA, expressed concerns about the lack of accountability and the repeated statement about the $100 million cost without an apology.

The National Rifle Association did not return a request for comment.

Title: Republican Effort to Split 9th Circuit Court of Appeals Gains Momentum

The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals, which covers a vast territory in the western United States, is facing a renewed push from Republicans to be split into smaller circuits. The proposal, introduced by Senators Jeff Flake and John McCain of Arizona, aims to create a new 12th Circuit and reduce the 9th Circuit's jurisdiction.

The senators argue that the 9th Circuit is too large, too liberal, and too slow in resolving cases. They point out that it typically takes the court 15 months to hand down a decision, which they claim is unacceptable. The 9th Circuit has a reputation for being one of the most liberal in the country, with 18 of its 25 active judges appointed by Democrats.

Conservatives have long criticized the 9th Circuit, often referring to it as the "Nutty 9th" or the "9th Circus" due to the high rate of its rulings being overturned by the U.S. Supreme Court. The court's makeup has contributed to its liberal reputation, with former Presidents George W. Bush and Barack Obama appointing six and seven judges, respectively.

The proposed legislation would carve out six states from the 9th Circuit, including Nevada, Washington, Idaho, Montana, Arizona, and Alaska, leaving the 9th with only three Pacific states, the Northern Mariana Islands, and Guam. A separate House version would leave Washington state in the 9th Circuit.

This is not the first time Congress has considered splitting the 9th Circuit. In 1998, a commission recommended against it, but the idea has been revisited in recent years due to concerns about the court's size and liberal leanings. The 9th Circuit was created in 1891, when the area it covers was sparsely populated, and its jurisdiction has grown significantly since then.

Democratic strategist Joe Lestingi pushed back against the accusations of the 9th Circuit being too liberal, arguing that the court provides the necessary conflict to settle the country's most basic disagreements. He also noted that the high rate of its rulings being overturned by the U.S. Supreme Court is a normal part of the judicial process.

Title: Rep. Rashida Tlaib Meets with Controversial Pro-Palestinian Organization

Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-Mich.) recently met with the Palestine Youth Movement (PYM) during the Arab Texas Festival in Dallas. The PYM organization has been known for its vitriolic rhetoric against Israelis and Jews, and has been caught glorifying the leaders of anti-Semitic terrorist organizations.

The meeting is unlikely to come as a surprise to the pro-Israel community, given Tlaib's history of supporting the anti-Semitic Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions (BDS) movement. The PYM organization has a history of anti-Israel activity, including a 2018 event in San Francisco where attendees called for Israeli soldiers to be kidnapped.

PYM has also memorialized Palestinian "martyrs" who were killed or imprisoned while carrying out terrorist attacks on Israel. At least three of those honored by the organization were known operatives of the Hamas terror group. The organization has also held campus events, including one at the University of California, Los Angeles, where attendees chanted "long live the intifada," a phrase often used by those advocating armed resistance against the state of Israel.

In July 2019, a PYM event in Toronto, Canada, was canceled after it was discovered that the group had advocated for terrorism by hosting an event with a member of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP), a group that has committed terror attacks on Israel. PYM blamed "Zionist organizations" for mounting a campaign against the event.

Tlaib's recent interaction with the group is just the latest in a string of meetings she has held with leading anti-Israel groups and supporters of the BDS movement. Tlaib and her freshman colleague Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-Minn.) have faced criticism for attempting to organize a trip to Israel sponsored by an organization called Miftah, which has praised supporters of terrorism and promoted anti-Semitic conspiracy theories.

Title: Rep. Mark Amodei Supports Impeachment Inquiry, but Not Necessarily Impeachment

Rep. Mark Amodei (R-NV) has expressed support for the Democratic-led impeachment inquiry into whether President Donald Trump should be impeached, but has stopped short of endorsing impeachment itself. According to The Nevada Independent, Amodei believes that the House and Senate committees should follow the facts and determine whether Trump has crossed any legal lines.

In a conference call with reporters, Amodei stated, "Let's put it through the process and see what happens. I'm a big fan of oversight, so let's let the committees get to work and see where it goes." He emphasized that he wants to see the facts unfold before making any judgments.

Amodei's stance aligns with that of Sen. Catherine Cortez-Masto (D-NV), who also supports the impeachment inquiry but has not taken a stance on impeachment itself. Cortez-Masto told KTVN-TV, "I think from all of that information, we have to follow the facts and figure out what happened here."

The congressman has clarified his position, stating that he does not support impeachment and instead wants to see the facts of the situation between President Trump and Ukrainian President Zelensky come to light. Amodei believes that the committees will investigate and determine whether Trump broke any laws, stating, "I don't care if it was a partisan spy or not. The only thing I get a vote on is, if it comes to the House floor… do I think that there is evidence there that is credible, that says he broke a specific law?"

Amodei's comments have been met with some misinterpretation, with some reading his statement as supporting impeachment. However, the congressman has clarified that this is not the case, stating that anyone who believes this is simply "individual fantasy."

Title: Justice Department Releases Documents Used to Justify FISA Surveillance Warrant Against Carter Page

The Department of Justice has released documents related to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (FISA) warrant application against Carter Page, a former campaign adviser to then-candidate Donald Trump. The documents, which include an October 2016 application and subsequent renewal applications, provide insight into the justification for the surveillance warrant.

The released documents show that the infamous Steele Dossier, an opposition research report funded by the Democratic National Committee (DNC) and Hillary Clinton campaign, was a major component of the 2016 surveillance warrant. The dossier contains salacious allegations against Trump, which were used to justify subsequent renewals. However, the visible sections of the released documents do not indicate that the dossier was ever verified. Instead, the FBI claimed that Steele was "reliable" based on his previous work.

The FISA records also reveal that a September 2016 Yahoo News article by Michael Isikoff was a significant part of the government's warrant application. However, London court records show that Steele briefed Yahoo News and other reporters in the fall of 2016 at the direction of Fusion GPS, the opposition research firm behind the Steele Dossier. Republicans have questioned whether the story is an example of circular reporting, merely repeating information from Fusion GPS.

The documents do not describe the dossier as a political document, as Democrats have asserted. Instead, the FBI speculates to the FISA court that the dossier was commissioned to damage Candidate 1, who is Donald Trump. Page's denials of the Yahoo News reporting were included in the early renewals to the FISA application.

The unredacted FISA materials contain limited references to ex-Trump adviser George Papadopoulos, who has since pleaded guilty to lying to federal investigators in Special Counsel Robert Mueller's probe. Critics have charged that Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who signed off on the FISA application renewals, should not have approved them without more reliable intelligence.

The release of the documents has sparked controversy, with President Trump calling the situation a "scam" and Republicans questioning the FBI's handling of the surveillance warrant. House Democrats, on the other hand, have characterized the documents as bolstering their arguments and emphasizing the need for the Special Counsel's investigation to continue unhindered.

Title: Ohio Senate Candidate Sherrod Brown Threatens Legal Action Against Challenger Jim Renacci Over Sexual Harassment Allegation

Article:

Ohio Senator Sherrod Brown is preparing to take legal action against his Republican challenger, Representative Jim Renacci, after Renacci's campaign released a statement accusing Brown of sexual harassment 30 years ago. The statement, released by attorney Laura Mills, claims that an unnamed woman accused Brown of making an "unexpected, uninvited, unwanted, and sudden advance" in the late 1980s. According to Mills, the woman was able to defuse the situation and Brown apologized.

The statement does not provide details on when or where the incident occurred, only stating that the woman met Brown through her work. It also does not mention any events leading up to the alleged incident. Brown's campaign responded with a cease and desist letter, demanding Renacci stop making "unsubstantiated and false claims" about the alleged incident, or face "legal ramifications."

Renacci's campaign has used Brown's contentious 1986 divorce and separate uncorroborated allegations of abuse as a way to paint Brown as hypocritical for voting against confirming Supreme Court Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh, who faced allegations of sexual misconduct. Renacci stated that the new allegation raises "even more questions and alarm over Mr. Brown's conduct toward women."

Brown leads Renacci by 16 points in the Ohio Senate race, according to the Real Clear Politics average of polls.

Title: Trump Pardons Former Cheney Chief of Staff Lewis "Scooter" Libby

The White House announced on Thursday evening that President Donald Trump has signed off on a pardon for Lewis "Scooter" Libby, the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney. Libby was convicted in 2007 of lying under oath to a grand jury investigating the leak of CIA operative Valerie Plame's identity to conservative columnist Robert Novak.

Libby was accused of revealing Plame's identity as a CIA operative, which put her life at risk. The leak was allegedly done in retaliation against Plame's husband, Joe Wilson, who had revealed that one of the main claims used to justify the Iraq War was false.

The pardon comes as a surprise to many, as Libby's case was seen as a symbol of the Bush administration's handling of classified information and the use of personal vendettas. In 2007, then-President George W. Bush commuted Libby's sentence, but did not issue a full pardon.

The timing of Trump's pardon is also notable, as it comes as several high-ranking officials from the Trump administration have pleaded guilty to making false statements and cooperating with Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. These officials include Michael Flynn, Rick Gates, and George Papadopoulos, who have all pleaded guilty to making false statements and agreed to cooperate with the investigation.

The pardon has sparked controversy, with some critics arguing that it sends a message that lying under oath is acceptable. The pardon also raises questions about Trump's motivations, with some speculating that it is an attempt to send a message that he will pardon anyone who has lied under oath.

Title: Trump Confidant Roger Stone Faces Legal Fees of at Least $500,000

Roger Stone, a longtime political adviser to former President Donald Trump, has set up a legal defense fund to help offset the costs of lawsuits and congressional inquiries, which he estimates will cost him at least $500,000. Stone is being sued by Project Democracy, a group run by former Obama administration lawyers, for allegedly being involved in the release of emails from Democratic Party officials.

Stone has already spent around $100,000 to dismiss the lawsuit, and he expects to spend more as the legal battle continues. He is also preparing to testify before the House Intelligence Committee on September 26 and assumes he will be invited to testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee.

Stone has expressed frustration with the ongoing investigations into alleged Russian interference in the 2016 election, stating that "they can't even prove the Russians hacked the [Democratic National Committee (DNC)], because they didn't...nobody can prove it." He has also criticized former CIA Director John Brennan, who has testified that he has concerns that Russia might have recruited Trump campaign aides.

Stone is not the only one in Trump's orbit facing burdensome legal fees. Former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn has set up a website to help pay off his legal fees, which are estimated to exceed $1 million. The Republican National Committee has covered over $230,000 in legal fees for President Trump, which is a legal procedure.

Stone's legal defense fund, WhoframedRogerStone.com, aims to help him cover the costs of his legal battle. The fund is separate from the legal defense funds set up by Flynn and other Trump associates facing legal challenges related to the Russia election interference probes.

Title: Progressives Weigh In on Grand Bargain Budget Agreement: A Call for Balance in Safety Net Funding

The debate surrounding the grand bargain budget agreement in the lame duck Congress has sparked a heated discussion among progressive organizations, with some, like AFL-CIO President Richard Trumka, expressing opposition to any fixes to Social Security and Medicare. However, others argue that a responsible approach to maintaining the safety net requires a balance of measures to ensure its long-term sustainability.

The author of this article posits that the time to make changes to the safety net is now, citing the need to address the growing demographic shift and the current imbalance in spending priorities. The article highlights that over the past five decades, the ratio of spending on public investments to the safety net has shifted dramatically, with the latter now receiving significantly more funding. By 2022, the ratio is expected to be 6 to 1, making it crucial to rebalance the spending priorities.

The author argues that a grand bargain budget agreement should include a balance of measures to make the programs healthy and solvent, such as new revenue, modest reductions in benefits to some recipients, and a commitment not to raise payroll taxes on working-class people in the future. This approach would ensure the safety net remains a vital component of the social safety net, providing a secure foundation for the middle class and working-class individuals.

The debate surrounding the grand bargain budget agreement highlights the importance of finding a balance between public investments and the safety net. As the nation approaches the most consequential demographic shift in its history, it is essential to prioritize a responsible approach to maintaining the safety net and ensuring its long-term sustainability.

Title: Trump Criticizes Bipartisan Immigration Deal as "Horrible" and "Very, Very Weak"

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has expressed his disapproval of a bipartisan immigration deal presented by Republican Senator Lindsey Graham and Democratic Senator Dick Durbin, calling it "horrible" on U.S. border security and "very, very weak" on reforms for the legal immigration system. The proposal aimed to address Democrats' demands for protections for young adults brought to the United States illegally as children, dubbed "Dreamers."

Trump stated that the plan fell short of what most Republicans believe is necessary and is the opposite of what he campaigned for. He declined to specify what he said during a closed-door meeting with lawmakers at the White House, where reports emerged that he questioned the value of taking immigrants from Africa and the Caribbean nation of Haiti, referring to them as "shithole" countries. Trump has denied using that word.

The proposed deal included $2.7 billion for additional border security funding, which Trump deemed insufficient. He also expressed concerns about the lack of funding for the wall he has promised to build on the U.S.-Mexican border, a project opposed by Democrats. The proposal failed to end a diversity visa lottery program and did not curb visas for extended family members of immigrants.

Trump's criticism of the deal has sparked concerns about a potential government shutdown, with Democrats threatening to withhold support for spending legislation unless an immigration deal is reached. The White House has backed a short-term spending measure by a Friday deadline to prevent a shutdown.

The controversy surrounding the immigration deal has sparked heated debate, with some critics accusing Trump of being a racist and others defending his stance on immigration. The fate of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which protects roughly 700,000 people, mostly Hispanic young adults, from deportation and provides them work permits, remains uncertain.

Title: Koch Network Launches Super PAC Ahead of Midterm Elections

The Charles Koch-led donor network has launched a new super PAC, Americans for Prosperity Action, which will enable the network to directly urge voters to support or oppose specific candidates. This move comes as the network prepares to spend up to $400 million over the two-year election cycle to help candidates and advance free-market policies.

The new super PAC is an arm of Americans for Prosperity, a grassroots organization operating in 36 states. While the nonprofit group faces restrictions on its political activity, the super PAC can raise and spend unlimited amounts of money to influence candidate elections, as long as it does not coordinate its spending decisions with the politicians it supports.

The move follows a public feud between Koch officials and President Donald Trump over trade and immigration policies. Koch's aides have criticized Trump's tariffs as "protectionism" that will harm American businesses and consumers. The Republican National Committee has warned Republican donors and candidates to distance themselves from the Koch network and its political operation.

In a statement, Koch officials emphasized their commitment to working with anyone to advance positive policies. The network has not yet disclosed how much it will spend through the new super PAC, but it has previously indicated that it will expend up to $400 million over the election cycle.

The midterm elections are crucial, with Republicans fighting to retain their majority in the U.S. House of Representatives. Democrats need to flip 23 seats to seize the chamber. The Koch network's new super PAC will likely play a significant role in shaping the political landscape ahead of the elections.

Title: Supreme Court's Asylum Policy Decision Sparks Debate Over Humanitarian Concerns and Legal Standing

The Supreme Court's recent decision to uphold the Trump administration's asylum policy has sparked a heated debate over its legal standing and humanitarian implications. Critics argue that the policy has dubious legal standing and will harm asylum seekers, while supporters see it as a necessary measure to address the crisis at the US-Mexico border.

The policy, which allows the government to reject asylum claims from individuals who pass through other countries before reaching the US, has been criticized by immigrant advocates who argue that it is illegal and ignores the historical debt the US owes to Central America. They claim that the policy will push more asylum seekers into Mexico, where they will face dangers and difficulties in finding legal representation.

The Supreme Court's decision has been seen as a blow to the Trump administration's efforts to restrict immigration, with some critics accusing the court of being overly deferential to the administration. The decision has also been criticized for its potential to exacerbate the humanitarian crisis at the border, as asylum seekers will be forced to navigate the dangers of Mexico without adequate support.

On the other hand, supporters of the policy argue that it is necessary to address the crisis at the border and to prevent the flood of asylum seekers from overwhelming the US immigration system. They claim that the policy is legal and will help to reduce the number of asylum claims.

The debate surrounding the policy has also highlighted the need for a more robust asylum process in Mexico, which is ill-equipped to handle the influx of asylum seekers. Advocates argue that individuals fleeing persecution in Central America will not find protection in Mexico and will be forced to navigate the dangers of the region without adequate support.

The Supreme Court's decision has also been seen as part of a broader trend of the court being overly deferential to the Trump administration, with some critics accusing the court of being complicit in the administration's efforts to restrict immigration.

Title: Critics of "Medicare for All" Highlight Cost and Access Concerns

The concept of "Medicare for All" has gained significant attention in recent times, with proponents arguing that it would provide a comprehensive and affordable healthcare system for all Americans. However, critics, like Scott W. Atlas of the Hoover Institution, argue that the plan would come with significant costs and access issues.

According to Atlas, implementing a single-payer healthcare system would require a significant increase in federal income and corporate taxes, which would be difficult to achieve. He cites the example of California, where a single-payer healthcare system would cost around $400 billion annually, more than twice the state's annual budget. Nationally, the cost would be over $32 trillion over the first decade.

Additionally, Atlas points out that even when factoring in savings from people not having to pay insurance premiums and co-payments, there is no way to raise the revenue to fund such a plan. He references a 2017 study by Eric Boehm, which found that a single-payer bill passed by New York's state assembly would cost $173 billion annually, more than the state's annual revenue.

The article also highlights concerns about access to healthcare in countries with single-payer systems. In Great Britain, a record 4.2 million patients were on the National Health Service waiting lists, while in Canada, the median wait time between seeing a general practitioner and following up with a specialist was 10.2 weeks, and the wait between seeing a doctor and beginning treatment was about five months.

Furthermore, Atlas notes that single-payer systems impose long delays before debuting the newest drugs for cancer and other serious diseases. A 2011 Health Affairs study found that the Food and Drug Administration approved 32 new cancer drugs in the decade after 2000, while the European Medicines Agency approved 26. All 23 drugs approved by both Europe and the U.S. were available to American patients first.

Proponents of Medicare for All argue that they do not want to fully nationalize healthcare, but rather guarantee a basic, accessible, and affordable system. However, Atlas argues that America's poor and middle class would suffer the most from a turn to single-payer, as they would be unable to circumvent the system.

The article concludes by noting that even countries with single-payer systems are moving towards private provision, with Sweden increasing its spending on private care for the elderly by 50% in the past decade and the British government spending over $1 billion on care from private and other non-NHS providers last year. Patients in Denmark can now choose a private hospital or a hospital outside the country if their wait time exceeds one month.

The article does not take a stance on the healthcare debate, but rather presents the arguments and concerns raised by critics of Medicare for All.

Title: Companies Boycotting Facebook for Hate Speech Still Advertise on Russian Platform Known for White Supremacist Activity

Article:

Over 100 companies, including Coca-Cola, Pepsi, Adidas, and Reebok, have announced a boycott of Facebook to protest divisive political speech on the platform. The boycott coincides with a public pressure campaign led by Joe Biden and other top Democrats to press Facebook to enforce stricter control over President Trump's postings. However, many of these companies have been regular advertisers on VK, a popular Russian social media website used by many white supremacists and neo-Nazis who have been banned from Facebook.

VK's popularity among white supremacists and neo-Nazis has been documented for years by media outlets and watchdog groups. Despite this, major companies have pulled ads from Facebook for not policing speech on its own site, citing concerns about "hate speech." However, these same companies continue to have a marketing presence on VK, raising questions about their recent concern about hate speech on social media sites.

Several companies that joined the Facebook boycott, including Starbucks, Ford, Unilever, Colgate, Vans, The North Face, and Patagonia, still market their products and brands in posts on their VK pages. On July 2, two days after joining the Facebook ad boycott, Colgate ran a promotion on VK offering prizes to members who purchased its products and used the VK app to scan the product code.

Coca-Cola and Pepsi have run advertising campaigns on VK, including a controversial 2016 ad in which the company included the disputed territories of Crimea and the Kuril Islands on a map of Russia. Both companies still have an active presence on the platform. None of the companies responded to inquiries about whether they would stop marketing on VK.

The Anti-Defamation League (ADL) said VK has become "an international hub for white supremacists" who have been kicked off mainstream U.S. social media websites such as Facebook. Although VK has taken some recent steps to crack down on hate groups, organizations like the National Socialist Movement and the Ku Klux Klan still maintain an active presence on the website.

Title: US Coronavirus Death Toll Surpasses 3,000, Exceeding September 11 Death Toll

The number of people who have died from the coronavirus pandemic in the United States has surpassed the number of people killed in the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. As of March 30, the virus's death toll in the US has reached over 3,100, exceeding the 2,977 victims who were killed in the World Trade Center, the Pentagon, and four hijacked planes on September 11.

While the virus's impact is incomparable to the sudden and immediate devastation of the September 11 attacks, its slow-moving toll on civilian lives promises to have a profound and lasting impact on American society. The number of confirmed cases is still rising rapidly, indicating that many more people will likely die from COVID-19 in the weeks and months ahead.

The impact of the September 11 attacks went beyond its initial death toll, with thousands of people injured and thousands more dying from diseases caused by exposure to toxic substances in the aftermath of the rubble of the Twin Towers. The economic impact was also significant, with New York City's economy losing 143,000 jobs each month and $2.8 billion in wages in the three months following the attack, according to a 2004 New York Times report.

Similarly, the coronavirus's effects will be far-reaching. An estimated 160,000 people have been infected with the coronavirus in the United States, resulting in more than 20,000 hospitalizations and placing an unprecedented strain on the nation's healthcare system. Additionally, over 3 million people have filed for unemployment due to the shuttering of non-essential businesses across the country. The economic impact has led to the passage of a $2.2 trillion stimulus package, the largest of its kind in modern history.

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie's Approval Ratings Soar After Hurricane Sandy Response

Governor Chris Christie's approval ratings in New Jersey have seen a significant surge, according to three recent surveys conducted over the past 24 hours. The polls indicate that Christie's job performance has received a boost, particularly among Democrats, following his response to the devastating effects of Hurricane Sandy.

According to a Quinnipiac University survey, 72% of Garden State voters give Christie a thumbs up on his job performance, a 16-point jump since before the storm struck in late October. The poll's release comes as Christie announced his bid for a second term as governor, citing his commitment to leading the state through the rebuilding and restoration process.

The survey also found that Christie's approval rating among Democrats has seen a significant increase, with 59% of registered voters supporting his re-election. Only 32% oppose his re-election, according to the Rutgers-Eagleton poll.

Christie's favorable impression has also seen a notable jump, with 67% of voters having a positive view of him, according to the Rutgers-Eagleton survey. The Quinnipiac University poll found that two-thirds of Republicans and a majority of Democrats think the criticism Christie received from some Republicans after Hurricane Sandy was "nonsense."

The news of Christie's re-election bid was widely expected, with much of the electoral focus now shifting to which Democrat will challenge him next fall. Several potential Democratic candidates have been mentioned, including Newark Mayor Cory Booker, State Sen. Richard Codey, State Sen. Barbara Buono, and Assembly member Lou Greenwald.

According to the Rutgers-Eagleton poll, Christie has large leads over all of his possible Democratic challengers in hypothetical 2013 general election matchups. New Jersey and Virginia are the only two states to hold gubernatorial contests in the year after a presidential election, making them a focal point for political attention.

The Quinnipiac University poll was conducted November 19-25, with 1,664 New Jersey registered voters questioned by telephone. The survey's overall sampling error is plus or minus 2.4 percentage points. The Rutgers-Eagleton poll was conducted November 14-17, with 1,108 New Jersey registered voters questioned by telephone. The survey's overall sampling error is plus or minus 2.9 percentage points.

Title: House Won't Take Up Senate GOP Bill to Limit Presidential Powers, Pelosi Says

The House will not consider a new Senate Republican bill aimed at limiting presidential powers under the National Emergencies Act, according to Speaker Nancy Pelosi. The bill, proposed by Senator Mike Lee, would limit a president's powers under the 1976 Emergencies Act in the future, but would not apply retroactively to President Trump's recent border emergency declaration or to the over two dozen emergencies still in effect from previous presidents.

Pelosi stated that the House will not take up the legislation, citing concerns that it is being used as political cover for Republicans to support Trump's border wall declaration. Democrats argue that the bill is an attempt to give Trump a pass and avoid addressing the broader issues surrounding presidential powers.

The House has already passed a resolution to overturn Trump's border emergency declaration, and enough Republicans appear ready to join Democrats in the Senate to approve it. However, Trump has vowed to veto the bill, and there is not enough support to override him.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell expressed concerns about Trump's decision to use the National Emergencies Act to redirect funds from the Pentagon to build the border wall, stating that Republicans do not question Trump's powers but have misgivings about the decision. McConnell believes that the grant of authority to the president was too broad when it was passed in the 1970s.

Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer argued that Republicans have long complained about an overbearing Executive Branch, and this is their chance to reel it in. He asked Republicans to consider whether they believe in the Constitution and conservative principles.

The vote on the border emergency declaration is set for Thursday, with Republicans defending Trump's decision and Democrats opposing it.

Title: Vice Presidential Debate Moderation Criticized for Lack of Focus and Control

The vice presidential debate between Sen. Tim Kaine and Gov. Mike Pence was criticized for its lack of focus and control, with many observers feeling that moderator Elaine Quijano struggled to keep the conversation on track. The debate, which covered nine topics in 90 minutes, saw the candidates frequently interrupting each other and failing to engage with each other's answers.

Quijano, a journalist and CNN anchor, was tasked with guiding the discussion and ensuring that the candidates stayed on topic. However, many felt that she failed to do so, often interrupting the candidates or switching topics abruptly. This led to a meandering conversation that failed to provide clear answers to the questions posed.

David Axelrod, a CNN senior political commentator, tweeted that Quijano seemed "intent on running through her questions, even when significant exchanges are happening." Jeffrey Goldberg, the Atlantic's national correspondent, added that she should "occasionally go where the debate is going, and not stop these interesting arguments."

The debate also saw the candidates frequently attacking each other's running mates, rather than addressing the questions at hand. Kaine was criticized for being overly aggressive and interrupting Pence frequently, while Pence was seen as taking a more thoughtful and reflective approach.

Despite the challenges of moderating a debate with two candidates with different styles, Quijano's performance was seen as lacking fluidity and adaptability. The debate format, which required her to cover nine topics in 90 minutes, also made it difficult for her to keep the conversation on track.

Overall, the vice presidential debate was criticized for its lack of focus and control, with many observers feeling that Quijano struggled to keep the conversation on track.

Title: Senate Republicans to Allow Democrats to Gain Control of Chamber, Continue Nomination Process

Article: Senate Republicans have decided to continue their protest against changes to the filibuster rules by refusing to grant unanimous consent to shorten debate periods and bring nominations to the floor. This move has slowed the chamber's schedule, with the remaining nominations on the calendar year's agenda still pending. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has announced plans to get through four of the nominations before adjourning for the year, with the possibility of working around the clock over the next couple of days.

According to Senate GOP Whip John Cornyn, individual senators can choose to stay in Congress on Friday and Saturday to vote on nominees, but at least one Republican senator will remain on the floor to object to Democratic requests to waive procedural hurdles. It is unclear how many Republicans will participate in this protest.

The move is seen as a response to the recent changes to the filibuster rules, which have given Democrats more control over the nomination process. However, it is worth noting that the process is still working, with people being confirmed and nominations being processed. The GOP lawmaker quoted in the article predicts that Democrats may struggle to gain the 51 votes needed for a quorum to move the nominees if most Republicans take off, but this is not a concern, as there are more than 51 Democratic members of Congress and at least one Republican senator will need to be present to execute the objection.

The Senate Republicans' decision to continue their protest is seen as a way to express their frustration with the changes to the filibuster rules, which they see as a loss of power and control. However, it is unclear what specific goals they hope to achieve by prolonging the process.

Title: Supreme Court Upholds Obama's Health Care Reform Legislation

The Supreme Court has ruled that the individual mandate requiring people to have health insurance is valid as a tax, upholding President Barack Obama's controversial health care reform legislation. The 5-4 decision has sparked debate and political implications, with presumptive GOP nominee Mitt Romney vowing to repeal the law if elected.

In a statement, Obama praised the decision, saying it is a "victory for people all over this country whose lives will be more secure because of this law." He emphasized that his push for the law was not driven by politics, but by a desire to improve the country and the American people.

The ruling has sparked a renewed debate on the campaign trail, with Romney promising to repeal the law on his first day in office. Obama, meanwhile, took a swipe at his opponent, pointing to Romney's own health care law as Massachusetts governor, which included a mandate to buy insurance.

The Supreme Court's decision has also sparked debate among political analysts, who say Republicans will likely argue that Obama's legislation introduces a massive tax onto the American public. However, Obama has vowed to continue implementing the law, saying the highest court in the land has spoken.

The Affordable Care Act, signed into law in 2010, has been a contentious issue since its inception, with both sides of the political aisle debating its merits. The Supreme Court's ruling has brought the issue back to the forefront, with political implications set to play out in the coming months.

Title: Supreme Court Justice Kennedy Criticizes Supporters of DOMA

Article:

Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy has delivered a majority decision striking down the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), which defined marriage as a union between a man and a woman for federal purposes. According to Kennedy, the decision declares that any opposition to gay marriage is motivated by a "bare congressional desire to harm a politically unpopular group." The majority held that DOMA inflicts an "injury and indignity" on gay couples, denying them an essential part of the liberty protected by the Fifth Amendment.

In his decision, Kennedy initially raised concerns about federalism, suggesting that the federal government cannot have a definition of marriage as a guide to administering federal policy and benefits. However, critics argue that the federal government has numerous programs that require such a definition. For instance, the Internal Revenue Code treats a person who is legally separated from their spouse but not yet divorced as unmarried, and the immigration laws disregard marriages entered into for the purpose of gaining an immigrant's admission, even if valid under state law.

Justice Antonin Scalia, in his dissent, pointed out that DOMA serves a clear purpose. If a gay couple marries in a state where gay marriage is recognized and then moves to a state where it is not recognized, the federal government would need to defer to the law of the state where they reside. DOMA settles this question.

Title: U.S. Officials Investigate Russian Lobbyist's Role in Trump Jr.'s Meeting with Russian Lawyer

U.S. officials are scrutinizing the involvement of a Russian lobbyist, Rinat Akhmetshin, in a controversial 2016 meeting between Donald Trump Jr. and a Russian lawyer, Natalia Veselnitskaya. The meeting, which took place at Trump Tower, was arranged by a British tabloid reporter, Rob Goldstone, and was attended by Trump Jr., his brother-in-law Jared Kushner, and then-campaign manager Paul Manafort.

Akhmetshin, a dual U.S.-Russia citizen, has been described by U.S. officials as a known "IO," or intelligence operative, with ties to Russian intelligence and alleged connections to political disinformation campaigns. He has denied these charges and declined to comment.

The meeting, which was previously undisclosed, has raised concerns that the Kremlin may have sought to exert influence over the 2016 Trump campaign. U.S. officials are investigating whether Veselnitskaya was sent to meet with Trump Jr. on direct orders from the Kremlin.

Akhmetshin and Veselnitskaya had previously worked together lobbying Congress against the Magnitsky Act, a bipartisan measure that imposed sanctions on several top Russian officials. The two also worked together for the Human Rights Accountability Global Initiative, a D.C.-based nongovernmental association that has lobbied against the Magnitsky Act.

The existence of the meeting was revealed earlier this week by The New York Times, and U.S. officials are scrambling to understand the full context of the meeting. Investigators are trying to determine whether Veselnitskaya was sent to meet with Trump Jr. on direct orders from the Kremlin and whether the meeting was part of a larger effort to influence the 2016 election.

The meeting has also raised questions about Trump Jr.'s involvement and whether he may have been aware of Akhmetshin's ties to Russian intelligence. Trump Jr. has acknowledged meeting Veselnitskaya, but did not disclose Akhmetshin's attendance.

Title: Trump Responds to Mattis' Criticism, Calls Him "Overrated" Military Leader

President Donald Trump responded to criticism from former Defense Secretary James Mattis, calling him an "overrated" military leader whom he "relished firing." Trump took to Twitter to express his thoughts, stating that he and former President Barack Obama were the only two leaders to have fired Mattis, whom he described as the "world's most overrated general." Trump also claimed that he asked for Mattis' letter of resignation and felt "great" about it.

Mattis, a retired four-star Marine general, had criticized Trump earlier in the day for "militarizing" the federal response to nationwide protests over police brutality. He also stated that Trump is the "first president in my lifetime who does not try to unite the American people – does not even pretend to try."

Trump responded by saying that Mattis' nickname "Mad Dog" was not his favorite, and that his primary strength was not military, but rather personal public relations. However, it is worth noting that Mattis was given the nickname "Mad Dog" long before Trump was elected, and a 2013 article by the San Diego Tribune refers to the nickname, stating that Mattis did not like the moniker.

Trump also claimed that he gave Mattis a "new life, things to do, and battles to win, but he seldom 'brought home the bacon.'" He stated that he did not like Mattis' leadership style or much else about him, and that many others agree. However, it is important to note that Mattis was not fired, but rather resigned after clashing with Trump over the administration's policy in Syria.

White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany also weighed in, calling Mattis' statement "little more than a self-promotional stunt to appease the DC elite." She tweeted that Trump is the "law and order President that has restored peace to our nation's streets" and that Mattis' words "pale in comparison to @POTUS' strong action."

Title: The Case for Broader Opinion Diversity in Mainstream Media

The recent debate surrounding the hiring and firing of conservative journalist Kevin Williamson at The Atlantic has sparked a discussion about the role of intellectual diversity in mainstream publications. Eric Levitz, a writer for New York magazine, has argued that liberal and conservative media outlets should prioritize hiring writers with more extreme left-wing views, citing the need to challenge the average reader intellectually. However, this argument has been met with criticism from those who believe that conservative opinions, including those of Williamson, have a place in the media.

Levitz's argument is based on the idea that conservative opinions are often irrelevant to the current political landscape and that socialist arguments have yet to be debunked. He suggests that exploring the disagreements between left-liberals and socialists would be more intellectually stimulating than publishing conservative opinions. However, others argue that this approach would only serve to further polarize the political discourse and create a false narrative that certain opinions are off-limits.

The article highlights the importance of intellectual diversity in opinion journalism, noting that even extreme or unpopular opinions can contain kernels of truth and contribute to the public's awareness of complex issues. It also emphasizes the need for publications to recognize that there are many people who dissent from both liberal and leftist orthodoxy and have valuable insights to share.

In conclusion, the debate surrounding Kevin Williamson's firing and the role of intellectual diversity in mainstream media highlights the importance of providing a platform for a wide range of opinions and perspectives. While some may argue that conservative opinions are too extreme or irrelevant, others believe that they have a place in the media and can contribute to a more nuanced understanding of complex issues. Ultimately, the goal of opinion journalism is to provide a platform for diverse voices and perspectives, even if they challenge our own beliefs and biases.

Title: Ottawa Gunman's Actions Linked to Radicalization, Authorities Say

The recent shooting incident in Ottawa, where a gunman attacked a soldier and stormed into the Canadian Parliament complex, has been linked to the gunman's radicalization, according to authorities. The gunman, identified as Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, 32, was killed in a gunbattle with authorities.

The gunman's mother, Susan Bibeau, expressed condolences to the family of the victim and apologized for the pain and chaos caused by her son's actions. She stated that she had not seen her son for five years before meeting him for lunch last week.

Authorities have not yet determined the full extent of Zehaf-Bibeau's motivation, but his actions were linked to his radicalization, said Royal Canadian Mounted Police Commissioner Bob Paulson. There is no evidence that Zehaf-Bibeau was linked to Martin Rouleau-Couture, the man who ran over two Canadian soldiers on Monday.

Zehaf-Bibeau was a Canadian citizen and may have also held Libyan citizenship. He had applied for a passport and authorities were investigating his application. His email address was found on the computer of a man arrested on a terrorism charge.

The Globe and Mail reported that Zehaf-Bibeau was a laborer and small-time criminal who had a criminal record in multiple provinces. He was also the son of a senior official at the Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada.

The Canadian Broadcasting Corp. reported that Zehaf-Bibeau was charged in 2004 with drug possession and pleaded guilty, serving 60 days in jail. He was also charged with robbery and uttering threats in 2011 and was found guilty of the lesser charge of uttering threats.

Ottawa police have ruled out the possibility of a second shooter, and it is unclear whether the incident is tied to the previous day's attack, in which two soldiers were run down by a radicalized individual. The incident has raised concerns about the potential connection between the two attacks, as Canada prepares to provide support in the fight against the Islamic State.

Title: Homeland Security Secretary Disputes Claim of ISIS Fighters Crossing US-Mexico Border

The United States Department of Homeland Security Secretary, Jeh Johnson, has disputed claims made by Representative Duncan Hunter that at least 10 ISIS fighters have crossed the US-Mexico border. Hunter, a California Republican, made the statement on Fox News on Tuesday night, citing information from Border Patrol officers. However, Johnson said on CNN's "Situation Room" that the claims are not supported by "credible, specific intelligence to that effect."

Johnson emphasized the importance of being responsible in sharing information with the public, stating that public officials should not "unduly create fear and anxiety" by spreading speculation and rumors. A Homeland Security spokeswoman also called Hunter's statement "categorically false."

Johnson assured the public that the department is vigilant in monitoring the border and has no specific intelligence indicating that ISIS is planning to enter the US through the southern border. He also mentioned that he reviews intelligence reports daily from overseas, the southern border, and the intelligence community to stay informed.

Hunter's spokesman, Joe Kasper, stood by the congressman's comments, stating that a high-level source informed him that DHS is actively discouraging any talk of ISIS on the border. Kasper also expressed skepticism about the department's statement, suggesting that it may be a case of the "left hand not knowing what the right hand is doing."

Title: Clinton Foundation to Continue Accepting Foreign Government Donations Despite Presidential Bid

The Clinton Foundation, founded by Bill and Hillary Clinton, has announced that it will continue to accept donations from foreign governments, primarily from six countries, despite Hillary Clinton's presidential bid. The foundation's board has decided to permit donations from Australia, Canada, Germany, the Netherlands, Norway, and the UK, which have supported or supported Clinton Foundation programs on health, poverty, and climate change.

According to a summary of the new policy, these countries will be allowed to make donations to the Clinton Foundation, but other nations will be prohibited from making large donations. However, they will still be able to participate in the Clinton Global Initiative, a subsidiary of the foundation where companies, nonprofit groups, and government officials work on solutions to global problems.

The decision to continue accepting foreign government donations raises questions about whether Hillary Clinton, if elected president, will prioritize the interests of the United States or the Clinton Foundation. Critics have pointed out that her use of a personal email server for official State Department business during her time as Secretary of State raised concerns about her commitment to transparency and accountability.

Additionally, some have noted that Hillary Clinton has accepted millions of dollars in donations to her foundation from countries like Saudi Arabia, where women have limited human rights. Despite being an advocate for women's rights, Clinton has not publicly spoken out against the country's human rights record.

The Clinton Foundation's decision to continue accepting foreign government donations will likely continue to be a topic of debate and scrutiny as the presidential election approaches.
